DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Saturday, Jan. 1, or the 21st day of the 11th month of the Year of the Monkey according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
44BC: Julius Caesar, founder of the Roman Empire, introduces the Julian calendar.
1622: The papacy adopts Jan. 1 as the beginning of the new year, instead of March 25.
1814: Hung Siu-tsuen, Chinese leader of the Taiping rebellion, is born. He would proclaim himself emperor Jan. 1, 1851.
1863: U.S. President Abraham Lincoln issues the Emancipation Proclamation during the American Civil War, declaring the freedom of all slaves in the rebelling southern states.
1886: Britain annexes Upper Burma.
1901: The Commonwealth of Australia is established.
1912: The Republic of China is founded, with Dr. Sun Yat-sen as the first provisional president.
1912: The lunar calendar is officially replaced by the Gregorian calendar in China.
1916: Yuan Shih-kai, unmoved by the opposition of the Kuomintang, declares himself emperor and accepts congratulations from officials at the Hsinhua Palace in Beijing.
1923: The Union of Soviet Socialist Republics is proclaimed.
1927: The Nationalist government is established at Hankow in China.
1928: China's Nationalist government orders Chiang Kai-shek to continue the Northward Expedition.
1934: Republic of China government troops launch an all-out offensive against communist rebels in Fukien.
1942: A total of 26 nations, including the ROC, sign the "Joint Declaration of the United Nations" in Washington, D.C., affirming opposition to the Axis powers.
1947: The ROC government promulgates the ROC Constitution.
1949: ROC President Chiang Kai-shek, in a New Year's Day message to the nation, expresses his wish for a peaceful settlement to the nationalist-communist dispute.
1951: Taiwan's first man-made rain experiment is carried out at Sun-Moon Lake in Nantou County.
1951: Communist Chinese and North Korean forces break through U.N. lines at the 38th parallel dividing North and South Korea.
1966: U.S. Vice President Hubert H. Humphrey arrives in the ROC to confer with Chinese leaders.
1973: Dr. Edward Teller, known as "the father of the hydrogen bomb," arrives in Taipei for a three-day visit.
1978: The Yuanshan cantilever bridge on the North-South Freeway is opened to traffic.
1979: The United States and Communist China set up diplomatic ties, 30 years after the founding of the People's Republic of China.
1988: Registrations for new newspapers in Taiwan begin, and restrictions on the number of pages per issue are relaxed.
1994: Communist Chinese authorities annul the double-track exchange rate system for the renminbi and stop issuing foreign exchange notes.
1995: The southern common market, an economic union of Brazil, Argentina, Uruguay and Paraguay, is formally established.
1999: Member nations of the European Union adopt the euro as their common currency.
2000: Premier Vincent Siew announces that Taiwan has weathered any threats posed by Y2K and has successfully marched into the new millennium.
2001: Renowned Taiwan musician and composer Hsu Tsang-houei dies of illness at Taipei's Veterans General Hospital at the age of 72.
2002: Premier Chang Chun-hsiung issued a statement on Taiwan's Jan. 1 formal entry into the World Trade Organization (WTO), hailing it as a historic event worthy of celebration.
2003: The Republic of China government reaffirmed its sovereignty claim over the disputed Taioyutai island group.
2004: President Chen Shui-bian urged mainland China to work hand-in-hand with Taiwan in pursuing true security and permanent peace.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "Riches and honors are objects of men's desire; but if I cannot have them without leaving the path of duty, I would not have them. Poverty and a low position in life are objects of men's dislike; but if I cannot leave them without departing from the path of duty, I would not leave them."

DOC.HEADLINE: RECORD NUMBER OF SMS CALLS IN FIRST HOUR OF NEW YEAR

TEXT.P: A total of 2.22 million text messages were sent via the Chunghwa Telecom mobile network in the first hour of 2005, the highest-ever hourly record, company officials said Saturday.
The figure compared with 1.7 million recorded in the first hour of 2004, according to Chunghwa Telecom chief engineer Shih Mu-piao.

A total of 8.54 million text messages were sent via the company's mobile network on New Year's eve Friday, up nearly 30 percent from the 6.31 million registered on the same day the previous year, Shih said.
The highest daily volume last year was recorded on the first day of Lunar New Year, which stood at 12 million, followed by Christmas Day, which stood at some 9 million, Shih added.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT PROMISES POLITICAL RECONCILIATION IN NEW YEAR ADDRESS

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian promised to create a new and stable environment for consultation and dialogue in his New Year address Saturday.

Noting that Taiwan's political landscape has not changed much during the last two national elections, with Chen winning the presidency while the legislature is still under the control of the opposition, the president said the people have sent a clear message: the governing party must rule with humility while the opposition parties must be rational in providing oversight.
Chen said Taiwan's society does not need bifurcation between the blue and green camps, nor does it need ongoing confrontation between the governing and opposition parties.
What the people expect from the political parties is fair competition, cooperation rather than confrontation, checks and balances, and solidarity rather than infighting, Chen said.

Although most of the people would like to see the governing and opposition parties take an initial step toward reconciliation and cooperation, these consultations should be conducted openly, should be subject to scrutiny by the people, and should not be downgraded into mere horse trading, Chen went on.

He promised to invite leaders from the governing and opposition parties, as well as representative of the executive and legislative branches, to meet as soon as possible to negotiate 10 priority bills and nine major laws desired by the people.

He said his governing party will reconcile and cooperate with the opposition parties on anything that would benefit the stability of domestic politics, the welfare of the people, harmony among ethnic groups and cross-strait peace.

Chen condemned Beijing's attempts to enact an anti-secession law, calling it an effort to seek justification for a military invasion of Taiwan, and therefore constituting a unilateral change of the status quo in the Taiwan Strait and posing the greatest threat to regional stability and world peace.
He warned the Chinese Communist Party not to underestimate the will of the Taiwan people to defend the sovereignty, security and dignity of the Republic of China.
Following is the full text of Chen's address:
President Chen's New Year's Day Address 'Creating a New and Stable Environment for Consultation and Dialogue'
Distinguished Guests, Colleagues, and My Fellow Countrymen: Happy New Year and greetings to you all!

Today marks the ninety-fourth anniversary of the founding of the Republic of China and the beginning of a new year. At a little past six o'clock this chilly morning, many people from around Taiwan joined me in welcoming the New Year and a new dawn at the flag-raising ceremony in front of the Presidential Office.

As our national flag rose slowly in the early morning light, perhaps many of those present shared a sentiment that was occupying my mind: Whether or not we were at the flag-raising ceremony, and regardless of where on this land we might be, the 23 million people of Taiwan share a common destiny, the same joy and sorrows. Under the same sky, we strive along side one another, weaving dreams for ourselves and for future generations. The collective aspirations of the people represent the hope and future of our country.

In 2004, we worked diligently and saw our efforts bear fruit. For this, my fellow countrymen must all feel rejoiced and gratified. At the Athens Olympic Games, we witnessed our national representatives win gold medals, and in this, there were tears of joy as well as the sweat of hard work. So inspiring were the scenes that they will forever remain imprinted in our memories. The people of Formosa share the same heritage and uphold a common " Taiwan Spirit." We should always cheer ourselves on and continue to forge ahead; support one other and never give up in the face of challenges, however formidable they may be.

Thanks to the ongoing global economic recovery, together with the joint efforts of the government and people, Taiwan's economy is expected to grow by 5.93 percent in 2004, the highest rate in seven years. There is hope that the unemployment rate, too, for the year overall will remain below 4.5 percent--the lowest since 2001. Per capita income in Taiwan was 13,995USD last year. If the economic growth rate in 2005 hits 4.56 percent as predicted, then per capita income this year could reach nearly 15,000USD. If we work a little harder, we might soon break through the 15,000USD threshold and set a new record for national average income.

In addition to the clear improvement in macroeconomic indices, Taiwan's national competitiveness on the whole continues to rise. In the World Competitiveness Scoreboard compiled by the Swiss-based Institute for Management Development (IMD) , Taiwan ranked 12th in 2004, up five places from number seventeen the previous year. This performance put Taiwan among the world's top ten in the category of "most improved national competitiveness." In the World Economic Forum's (WEF) Growth Competitiveness Index (GCI)--a key indicator for predicting economic growth potential in the medium to long- term future--Taiwan moved up from number ten in 2000 to fourth place last year. We have also ranked number one in Asia for three consecutive years.

These encouraging achievements are the rewards of every citizen's efforts; even more, they demonstrate the concrete results of the government's pursuit of economic revitalization and comprehensive reform over the past few years. We have already weathered the worst of storm. Now we should have even greater confidence in the future of Taiwan; and we must have even stronger faith in reform. As we face the New Year before us, we cannot deny that the trend towards slower global economic growth presents Taiwan with competitions and challenges that will remain rigorous. Only through greater initiative, unity and action will we be able to maintain our advantage and avoid falling by the wayside.

In the area of democratic consolidation and reform, we carried out the first national referendum in Taiwan's history last year. We also succeeded with four major constitutional reforms: halving the number of seats in the Legislature, adopting a "single-district, two-vote" electoral system, enshrining the right to referendum in the Constitution, and abolishing the National Assembly. Each of these major achievements represents a pivotal step in the history of Taiwan's democratic development. We want to thank the governing and opposition parties for their efforts; more importantly, we must also attribute these accomplishments in reform to the power of the people.

We can look back on Taiwan's democratization, from the lifting of the martial law and the end of the bans on new political parties and newspapers, to the complete re-election of our national legislature, the direct election of the president, and the holding of national referenda. We can even look forward to the forthcoming constitutional reengineering project. Without the power of the people to guide and propel us forward, none of this would have been possible. This is the right path, and we will continue to walk on it with courage, until our people finally have a normal, complete, progressive, beautiful and great country.

Just recently, Freedom House unveiled its Freedom in the World 2004 report. In the "civil liberties" category, Taiwan moved up one notch, from level two to the highest rating of one, making us one of 26 nations where freedom improved. We ought to take pride in this accomplishment, and protect and cherish it.

Over the past year, Taiwan held two nationwide elections, one for president and the other to elect legislators. Regardless of the outcomes, both should be regarded as part of the regular process of democratic development. Democracy is precious, because no matter which party or candidate wins, in the end they should all work towards a final victory for the people. Now that the heated campaigns have ended, the people need calm and rest, while the nation needs solidarity and stability.

The choice of the people sent a clear message: The governing party must rule with humility while the opposition parties be rational in providing oversight. Taiwan's society does not need bifurcation between the blue and green camps, nor does it need ongoing confrontation between the governing and opposition parties. The governing and opposition parties each have their own roles to play. Fair competition, cooperation rather than confrontation, checks and balances, and solidarity rather than infighting--these are now the ardent expectations of the people of Taiwan.

I myself identify very strongly with the voice of the people, and fully grasp where my duties and responsibilities as president lie. Today is the beginning of a new year; I would like to hereby advocate openly that Taiwan must head toward a new era of consultation and dialogue.

The two major elections last year did not result in any clear change in the domestic political landscape. Nevertheless, the people certainly do not wish to see a continuation and recurrence of the political impasse, confrontation and infighting of the past four years. Therefore, we must find a way to avoid repeating the same mistakes again, stop the internal squabbles, and end the political chaos. This is not just the common duty of both the governing and opposition parties, but also the primary responsibility of every political leader.

Politics is an art of possibilities. In the democratic and pluralistic society of Taiwan today, it is possible to clearly express opinions and positions through incisive confrontation and unrelenting resistance; however, this often leads to an impasse where no compromise or conclusion is possible. While the governing and opposition parties must be accountable to their supporters, each should try to take a step back, understand the others, and empathize with them. They should exhibit tolerance of each other and sincerity in negotiations. The vast majority of people would be pleased to see the governing and opposition parties take an initial step toward reconciliation and cooperation. Consultative dialogue between the governing and opposition parties cannot be for the exchange of power and position, but rather for social stability, the future of the nation, and the welfare of the people. Inter-party consultations could be conducted openly, and would be subject to scrutiny by the people and their oversight through public opinion.

Of course, we fully understand that in order to create a new and stable environment based on rational consultation and sincere dialogue, the ruling and opposition parties should start with areas on which consensus has already been formed. For instance, the governing and the opposition parties all appealed to their constituencies before the legislative election by pushing for ten priority bills and legislation of nine major laws. These proposals contain policies and bills in common that the people earnestly expect to see realized. These include tax reforms, a balanced budget, implementation of a national pension, sustainable management of National Health Insurance, review of educational expenditures and the tuition burden, military service reform, privatization of state-owned enterprises, the budget for major arms procurements, reducing the gap between rich and poor, and improvements in cross-strait relations. We believe that these policy and legislative proposals would make good starting points for the engagement of rational consultation and sincere dialogue among political parties.

To achieve this goal, I would like to wholeheartedly invite leaders from the governing and opposition parties, as well as representatives of the executive and legislative branches, to meet as soon as possible to negotiate each of the above-mentioned policies and legislative bills of public concern. Through rational dialogue and policy debate, proposals and positions of different parties would be respected, with efforts being primarily devoted to seeking common ground despite differences. Eventually, through the consensus of political parties, policies and bills would be implemented and enacted by the executive branch and the legislative branch, thereby meeting national needs and public expectations.

We expect to see a win-win situation in future relations among the governing and opposition parties as well as the interaction between the new legislature and cabinet. Only the vigorous development of the governing and opposition parties can ensure sound party politics. The executive branch has to be strong, so does the legislative branch; the governing and the opposition parties have to be robust; and citizens of this country must be tenacious, more so than myself, if Taiwan is to be a great country.

According to the Constitution, after the cabinet resigns, the President should appoint a new premier and form a new cabinet. During this process, I will listen attentively to the voice of the people and to the opinions of the governing and opposition parties. As long as it will benefit the stability of domestic politics, welfare of the people, harmony among ethnic groups, and cross-strait peace, anything can be open to reconciliation or cooperation between the governing and opposition parties. In the future, the new cabinet should enhance its functionality in consultation and dialogue, such as those between the executive and the legislative branches, among the governing and opposition parties, and with the people at the grassroots level. Special emphasis should be placed on areas such as issues that concern social wellbeing, the care for the disadvantaged, and the provision of welfare. As we strive to reinvigorate the economy and upgrade national competitiveness, we must also attend to and seek fairness and justice in society.

Distinguished guests and colleagues, we stand here today as the steward of the faith and trust our people have bestowed upon us. During the election, there might have been a Pan-Green and Pan-Blue divide; but, with the election now behind us, there should only be "one country and a unified people" here in Taiwan. Confronted by the capricious and ephemeral nature of international affairs and ever so fierce global competitions, especially with the escalating belligerent rhetoric and military intimidation from the other side of the Strait, we must stand in solidarity to face these external challenges, so as to ensure the welfare and happiness of our people and the future of our country.

Over the past four years, we have, on many occasions, extended olive branches of peace to the other side of the Strait, actively seeking to establish new basis for the resumption of cross-strait dialogue and consultation. Just this past year, we have repeatedly expressed our sincerity and goodwill for the promotion and normalization of cross-strait relations, as in my inaugural speech of May, National Day Address, and the ten-point conclusion of November 10 at a high-level national security meeting. However, regrettably, despite all our efforts, the other side remains reluctant in giving up its military intimidation against Taiwan. Moreover, the other side continues its saber rattling and suppression of Taiwan on all fronts. Now, the Chinese Communist Party (CCP) attempts to unilaterally arbitrate and sanction cross-strait issues, concocting a so-called "legal basis" for its military invasion of Taiwan. Such actions will not only unilaterally change the status quo of peace in the Taiwan Strait, but will also pose the greatest threat to regional stability and world peace.

We once again urge the CCP authorities not to under-estimate the will of the Taiwan people in defending the sovereignty, security and dignity of the Republic of China. The sustainable and peaceful development of cross-strait relation not only echoes the collective longing of peoples on both sides of the Strait, it also aligns with the expectations from the international community. We will continue to adhere to our policy of "keeping a firm stance while moving forward pragmatically" in dealing with cross-strait issues. Even in the face of the unilateral and aggressive actions by the CCP, we will "take hold of the intent, and not act on impulse." In addition, we will proceed in a manner that is "deliberate and not backward, steadfast and not hasty," to form a "Committee for Cross-Strait Peace and Development, " to forge an internal consensus in Taiwan, and actively promote and establish a peace and stability framework for cross-strait interactions.

I would like to express my appreciation for our international allies, including the United States and Japan, for their long-term support for the people of Taiwan and for their concern about peace across the Taiwan Strait. The relations Taiwan has cultivated with the international community draw strengths from not only a "value alliance" of freedom, democracy and human rights, but also the acquiescence and mutual understanding developed from long-term cooperation. However, in light of tremendous pressure and suppression in the international arena from the other side, Taiwan's foreign diplomacy faces enormous challenges. Sometimes progress can only be made tacitly, and not publicized. Other times, we must bear the weight of our responsibilities along side the indignation of unfair slanders. While constructive criticisms are always appreciated, unfounded speculation and distortion, or the denigration of the amity and friendship Taiwan shares with our international allies, are not. Fundamentally, we have absolute confidence in the future expansion of Taiwan's international space, as well as our relations with the United States and Japan.

The severe earthquake and tsunamis in South Asia have caused a tragic catastrophe and stirred compassion in our hearts. Our government and people should act on the spirit of feeling other's pain as one's own, and contribute to our utmost ability to the international relief efforts. In addition to the urgent demand for rescue work and medical aid, there will be an enormous need for materials and manpower in future reconstruction. We should continue to express our concern and bravely give ourselves to the relief efforts so that the countries and people impacted by the disaster may feel the compassion and kindness coming from Taiwan.

My dear colleagues and fellow countrymen: There is only one Taiwan, and there is only one future for our nation. The responsibilities and goals that we hold in common are to "unite Taiwan, stabilize cross-strait relations, seek social harmony, and reinvigorate the economy." Walking in humbleness and adopting a pragmatic approach, I would like to take the lead in the pursuit of a "Taiwan in unity." In the year ahead of us, let's listen carefully to the voice of the people and work together toward a new and stable environment of comprehensive consultation and dialogue. We should stand together to meet new challenges and create greater opportunities for Taiwan.
In closing, I would like to wish the Republic of China great prosperity! May all my colleagues and compatriots at home and abroad enjoy a Happy New Year!

DOC.HEADLINE: LEGISLATIVE HEAD HOPES FOR 'ICE-BREAKING JOURNEY' TO MAINLAND CHINA

TEXT.P: The head of the Legislative Yuan said Saturday that he will activate a cross-Taiwan Strait task force mechanism in the legislature this year and engage in an "ice-breaking journey" to mainland China.
Legislative Speaker Wang Jin-pyng made the remarks as he spoke of his New Year wishes for 2005.

Noting that the government has been unable to adopt a substantive and effective approach to break the present cross-strait impasse, Wang said he is worried about the people as well as the industrial sector.

He expressed the hope that after he wins his re-election bid for the legislative speakership, he will activate the cross-strait task force mechanism in the legislature and embark on the "ice-breaking journey" to the mainland.

The time for activating the cross-strait task force is ripe, Wang said, adding that cross-strait relations should not continue to stall, and that some of the things or measures that the government is incapable of doing must not be allowed to drag on forever.
"The legislature will be on the side of the people to help communicate so as to make up for the deficiencies of the administrative branch," he said.

The previous legislature passed a resolution to form the cross-strait task force, with the speaker serving as convener and the vice speaker as vice convener, and various political parties contributing a total of 21 representatives in proportion of the ratio of their legislative seats.
"If the nation needs it, the people give consent, the legislature passes a resolution, and the journey can be based on equal footing, then I'll visit mainland China," he said.
He said the cross-strait task force will have room for development, adding that it will promote anything that will contribute to cross-strait peace and stability.

He also said that if the legislative caucus of the opposition Kuomintang can coordinate with air carriers on both sides of the Taiwan Strait to reach a consensus on promoting cross-strait charter flights during the Chinese New Year holiday in February, then the task force will start from there to continue to communicate and consult with the mainland so as to promote measures that will be beneficial to Taiwan's people and industry.

He said that the legislature is currently reviewing a draft bill to promote cross-strait peace proposed by the opposition People First Party and that if the bill clears the legislature and a cross-strait peace commission is formed, it would provide a legal basis for the legislature to promote cross-strait exchanges.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN MEDICAL TEAM ARRIVES IN ACEH
DOC.DATELINE: Banda Aceh, Indonesia, Jan. 1 (CNA) (By Charles Kang and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: Members of a medical team from Taiwan arrived Saturday in Banda Aceh, capital of Aceh Province on the Indonesian island of Sumatra, which was worst-hit by the earthquake and tsunami of Dec. 26.
The team is expected to survey a potential site for setting up a temporary medical station in the city.
Indonesian President Susilo Bambang Yudhoyono, who was also in Banda Aceh to inspect the aftermath of the disaster, expressed his gratitude for the assistance and supplies provided by Taiwan.
The team, which arrived in Indonesia Thursday, has been surveying potential sites for posting its workers. Other members went to Nias, an island off western Sumatra, on Friday.
Reports said that at least 79,000 people on Sumatra have been killed by the tsunami triggered by the 9.0-magnitude earthquake.

Many other countries around the Indian Ocean, including Thailand, Sri Lanka, India, the Maldives, Malaysia and Somalia were also hit by the tsunami, with the combined death toll standing at more than 120,000 and expected to continue to rise.
At least 5 million people have been left homeless.
In Taipei, World Vision Taiwan launched a fund-raising campaign Saturday in cooperation with chain stores including 7-Eleven, Starbucks and Cosmed to help the tsunami victims.
More than 4,000 donation boxes will be set up in the store outlets until Jan. 31.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT, VICE PRESIDENT ATTEND NEW YEAR FLAG-RAISING CEREMONY

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian and Vice President Annette Lu joined the people in an annual New Year flag-raising ceremony held in front of the Presidential Office early Saturday morning.
People had started to arrive at the plaza at around 4 a.m., despite the chilly weather.

Later, Chen and Lu, as well as other high-ranking government officials including Premier Yu Shyi-kun and Presidential Office Secretary-General Su Tseng-chang, led the people to sing the national anthem as the flag was being raised.
No opposition politicians attended the ceremony, with the exception of Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou.
In addition to the one in front of the Presidential Office, other flag-raising ceremonies were also held in various counties and cities around Taiwan to welcome in the New Year.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN, MAINLAND CHINA SHOULD HOLD PEACE TALKS: MAC OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: Taiwan and mainland China should hold talks to mend their differences and resolve their disputes to avoid changes to the status quo across the Taiwan Strait, a government official urged Saturday.

Chiu Tai-san, vice chairman of the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) , made the remarks after President Chen Shui-bian gave his New Year message earlier the same day in which he called for reconciliation between the ruling and opposition parties to create political stability, benefits for the people, ethnic harmony and cross-strait peace.

Beijing has initiated moves to draft an "anti-secession" law apparently aimed at Taiwan, which Chiu described as a gross attempt to unilaterally alter the status quo in the strait. He called for bilateral negotiations to deal with rifts.

According to the MAC vice chairman, the "anti-secession" law being established by the Beijing regime would be worse than a "unification law" by seeking to view the two sides of the Taiwan Strait -- two independent states under separate rule -- as an integral entity.

Saying that the cross-strait status quo should not be unilaterally dictated or arbitrated by either side, he urged Beijing to resolve its disputes with Taipei through peaceful means to secure peace and prosperity in the region, as this is the expectation and demand of the Taiwan people and the international community.

Relations between Taiwan and the mainland have become even more sensitive than usual since the campaign for Taiwan's Dec. 11 legislative elections, in which Chen brought up issues such as changing the names of state-run enterprises and government offices overseas by including the word "Taiwan" in their official titles.
The move led to the countermeasure late last month by Beijing, which has repeatedly warned that it will not allow Taiwan to declare de-jure independence at any cost, including the use of force.
The cross-strait rift goes back to 1949, when the Kuomintang retreated to Taiwan after losing a civil war to the Chinese communists in mainland China.

Despite the fact that the two sides are sovereign states ruled by independent governments since that year, Beijing claims that Taiwan forms an inalienable part of the mainland and makes every effort to block the island on the international stage.

DOC.HEADLINE: POLITICAL PARTIES GIVE MIXED REACTION TO 'ICE-BRAKING JOURNEY' PROPOSAL

TEXT.P: The various political parties reacted predictably Saturday to Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng's proposal to reactivate a cross-Taiwan Strait task force mechanism and embark on an "ice-breaking journey" to mainland China to help break the current cross-strait impasse.
Tsai Huang-liang, whip of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) caucus in the legislature, said that the DPP welcomes anything that will be conducive to cross-strait peace.
However, if Wang wants to make the mainland visit on behalf of the legislature, he should "exercise caution," Tsai said.
He noted that Beijing has always tried to downgrade Taiwan's sovereignty and said Wang should be alert that his status as a legislative speaker is not downgraded by Beijing.
Meanwhile, the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) said it will support Wang's proposal to activate a cross-strait task force mechanism in the legislature and to visit the mainland.
KMT Legislator Tseng Yung-chuan claimed that Beijing has given up hope on President Chen Shui-bian and that it is impossible that Beijing will ever resume talks with Chen's administration.

Judging from Chen's campaign theme in the 2004 presidential election, cross-strait relations will continue to be strained and Wang's advocacy of a cross-strait task force "comes in the nick of time," he said.
He pointed out that cross-strait charter flights during Chinese New Year are being organized by the KMT because Chen's government is incapable of doing the job.

The KMT has coordinated with six air carriers in Taiwan to call on the Mainland Affairs Council -- Taiwan's highest mainland policy charter -- and air carriers on the mainland to help bring about the charter services for Taiwan businessmen operating on the mainland and their dependents who wish to return to Taiwan during the Chinese New Year holiday.
The People First Party, an ally of the KMT, said that it will be pleased to see Wang lead a delegation to visit the mainland.
Liu Wen-hsiung, the PFP caucus whip, said that the PFP will also send representatives to take part in the proposed cross-strait task force.
But the Taiwan Solidarity Union, an ally of the DPP, said it would be "inappropriate" to reactivate the cross-strait task force, which was first launched in 2000 but has been moribund ever since.
Huang Tzung-yuan, TSU caucus whip, said that the proposed task force should be appointed by President Chen Shui-bian and formed by the government rather than by the Legislative Yuan.
If the task force is formed according to the ratio of legislative seats held by each party, he questioned whether it will represent the nation or just the legislature itself.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT CHAIRMAN CALLS FOR 'PAN-BLUE' UNITY

TEXT.P: Opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan called on supporters of the "pan-blue alliance" Saturday to unite for the future development of the Republic of China.

Lien made the remarks after hosting a New Year flag-raising ceremony in Taipei for a group of opposition supporters. The event was arranged in an obvious attempt to differentiate from the official ceremony presided over by President Chen Shui-bian in front of the Presidential Office.
Lien said 2005 marks the 94th year of the foundation of the ROC by Sun Yat-sen and that it is a moment of honor and pride to see the ROC flag being raised again.
Lien pointed out that the Legislative Yuan will pass a new milestone in the new year, with the new legislature set to be formed Feb. 1 based on a new mandate.

He pledged that the KMT will work in the new legislature to safeguard the sovereignty and dignity of the ROC, promote cross-Taiwan Strait peace, deepen the democratic politics of Taiwan, enhance social solidarity and peace and boost the country's economic development.

In addition, he said, the KMT will push for legislation aimed at offering education subsidies for youth, regulating education funding, protecting the retirement benefits of teachers, upgrading health care for farmers, enhancing social aid, starting a national pension program, replacing compulsory military service with a volunteer one, regulating major arms procurement items and boosting financial discipline.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAITUNG PRISON INMATES TO DONATE FOR TSUNAMI VICTIMS IN ASIA

TEXT.P: Most of the inmates of the Taitung Prison have decided to donate money to the victims of the tsunami spawned by Sunday's 9.0-magnitude earthquake that affected Indonesia, India, Thailand, Malaysia, Sri Lanka, the Maldives and Somalia, Taitung Prison Governor Huang Wei-hsien said Saturday.

After learning of the tragedy, one of the inmates called on all the other inmates to give a helping hand to the victims by donating money earned from their prison labor, Huang said, adding that 70 percent of the inmates voiced their support for the idea.
Some said they would donate a month's earnings of a few hundred dollars, while others said they would donate from their deposit accounts, Huang added.

DOC.HEADLINE: TOLL-FREE CALLS OFFERED TO COUNTRIES RAVAGED BY EARTHQUAKE, TSUNAMI

TEXT.P: The state-run Chunghwa Telecom, in collaboration with the Council of Labor Affairs, has begun offering subscribers five-minute toll-free phone calls to countries ravaged by the Dec. 26 earthquake in Indonesia and the ensuing tsunami, Chunghwa Chairman Ho Chen Tan said Saturday.

Under the terms of the offer, Ho Chen told a news conference, any subscriber's first call each day with the 019 prefix to Thailand, Indonesia, India, Sri Lanka and the Maldives will be free of charge for the first five minutes. The offer will run through Jan. 7.

Given that the country has 28,000 Indonesian workers and about 100,000 Thai workers, Ho Chen urged the employers of these workers to tell them of the program, adding that Chunghwa will also set up service stations in Taipei, Taoyuan, Yunlin and Kaohsiung counties, all of which have large populations of foreign workers.
He estimated that the program will cost his company about NT$10 million (US$314,911).

DOC.HEADLINE: STOCK MARKET TURNOVER POSES 15% GROWTH LAST YEAR

TEXT.P: The total turnover of Taiwan's stock market registered an increase of 15.1 percent in 2004 over the previous year's level, according to the latest statistics released Saturday by the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX).

A cumulative 1.97 trillion shares changed hands during 2004, an increase of 128.14 billion shares from the year before, or an 11.7 percent growth, according to the statistics. The total market turnover for last year reached NT$24.12 trillion (US$759.57 billion), adding NT$3.64 trillion over the 2003 level.

The figures also indicate that the largest daily turnover in the stock market was recorded March 5, with NT$255.60 billion-worth of shares changing hands, while the smallest was Aug. 16, with NT$27.58 billion-worth of stock transactions.
The daily transaction average was registered at NT$96.50 billion, according to the TAIEX statistics.

Meanwhile, affected by various factors, including skyrocketing international oil prices, mainland China's economic adjustment and political unrest stemming from the March 20 presidential election, the TAIEX weighted price index, the market's key barometer, posted a slight climb of 4.23 percent for the whole of last year, according to the TAIEX figures.

The figures show that as of the end of 2004, there were a total of 697 listed companies in the market, up 28 from that of the previous year, while the total capital of the businesses had increased to NT$5.58 trillion at the end of last year from the NT$4.73 billion of a year ago, representing a 7.05 percent growth.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP LAWMAKERS SUPPORT PRESIDENT'S EFFORTS FOR CONSULTATION

TEXT.P: A lawmaker of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) pledged Saturday to support President Chen Shui-bian's calls for political consultation with the opposition.

Tsai Huang-liang said Chen offered an olive-branch to the opposition in his New Year address by promising to invite leaders from the ruling and opposition parties, as well as representative of the executive and legislative branches, to negotiate the country's major bills.
He urged the opposition parties to reciprocate the president's goodwill by embracing reconciliation and cooperating with the DPP on policies desired by the people.
Chen who won re-election in March but failed to follow it up with success in controlling the legislature in the Dec. 11 legislative elections, promised to govern with humility.
Tsai said he would approach the opposition lawmakers next week to discuss with them how to organize negotiations on the bills named by Chen in his address as priorities.

DOC.HEADLINE: TSU WELCOMES PRESIDENT'S DECLARATION FOR CONSULTATION

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Solidarity Union, a political ally of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) , welcomed President Chen Shui-bian's call Saturday for political consultation among various parties on bills and national policy.

Huang Tsung-yuan, TSU convener at the Legislative Yuan, said his party believes the ruling party should seek the opposition's support by forming a coalition with the major opposition parties and replacing confrontation with cooperation.
Huang said his party will not take issue with Chen's proposal to set up a cross-strait peaceful development council with the chief of an opposition party as its head.
On the part of the other opposition parties, TSU lawmaker Chen Chien-nien said, they should match the president's goodwill by subordinating party interest to the general welfare of the people.

DOC.HEADLINE: TOTAL STOCKS FUTURES TRADING HIT RECORD HIGH LAST YEAR

TEXT.P: A Total of 591.46 million contracts changed hands in Taiwan's stock futures market in 2004, a record high, according to statistics released Saturday by the Taiwan Futures Exchange.
The figure registered a 85 percent surge over the previous year's level, while the daily transaction average was recorded at 237,000 contracts, the statistics show.

The most popular futures products last year were options, which accounted for 75 percent of the 2004 total futures transactions with a total amount of 442.34 contracts changing hands, the figures show.

DOC.HEADLINE: 'TAIWAN ROOTS' MEDICAL TEAM DEPARTS FOR TSUNAMI-HIT SRI LANKA

TEXT.P: A 42-member medical mission organized by the private Taiwan Roots Medical Peace Corps (TRMPC) left Saturday for Sri Lanka to help victims of the Dec. 26 tsunami disaster.
The group took with them 2,500 kg of medicine and medical supplies.

TRMPC head Liu Chi-hsiang said the priority of the mission is to prevent an outbreak of infectious diseases after the disaster and that members of the mission include 14 physicians specialized in general medicine and infectious diseases.
While this is the 126th overseas medical aid mission of the TRMPC, the organization made two other medical missions to Sri Lanka last year, Liu said.
The group is set to return to Taiwan Jan. 9.

More than 28,000 people have been confirmed killed and nearly 1 million are left homeless in Sri Lanka by the tsunami, which were triggered by a 9.0-magnitude earthquake off Indonesia's Sumatra island.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN ECONOMY PROMISING DESPITE OBSTACLES: TAITRA HEAD

TEXT.P: Backed by an estimated economic growth rate of nearly 6 percent for 2004, Taiwan's economy is expected to continue to expand this year, despite the fact that various factors remain in the way, a prominent trade official said Saturday.

Speaking in an exclusive interview with CNA, Hsu Chih-jen, chairman of the semi-official Taiwan External Trade Development Council (TAITRA) , said that international prices of oil and raw materials and the course of the U.S. and Taiwan currencies will be the prime factors affecting the performance of the domestic economy in the year to come.

In addition, Hsu pointed out, the effects arising from mainland China's economic integration with the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) will also be an important issue that Taiwan must address properly. Both the mainland and ASEAN member states are Taiwan's key export markets.

Although the Cabinet-level Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics and the Chung-Hua Institution for Economic Research both forecast that the economy will grow by more than 4 percent in 2005, he failed to echo their predictions but instead called for measures to build up consumer confidence to secure continued economic development.

Should the mainland economy take a "hard landing" after its currency is revalued, global economies, including Taiwan, will be dealt a blow, he said, predicting that the renminbi will gain in value in the second half of next year.

On the other hand, a "hard landing" of the mainland economy will not be totally bad for Taiwan, he went on, basing his argument on the grounds that a cooler mainland economy should help bring down oil and commodity prices in the international market.
The TAITRA chairman also warned of the impact of the free trade agreement (FTA) clinched by the mainland with ASEAN that is slated to take effect in July.

Convinced of the possibility that Taiwan runs the risk of being marginalized by the mainland-ASEAN FTA, he played down, however, the impact speculated upon by the media and encouraged Taiwan companies to adopt flexible approaches to counter the changes through multilateral trade mechanisms.
Many domestic businesses have already relocated to the mainland and countries in Southeast Asia, and none of those in Taiwan are making money out of customs duties, he pointed out.

TAITRA, formerly known as the China External Development Council, was set up in 1970 to help Taiwan businesses explore international trade. It is Taiwan's No. 1 non-profit trade promotion body and Hsu has served as its chairman for more than a year.

Meanwhile, Tu Sheng-cheng, chairman of the Cabinet-level Council for Economic Planning and Development, acknowledged that the recent earthquakes and tsunami that devastated many countries in Southeast Asia and South Asia will have negative effects on Taiwan's economy.
Currently, ASEAN member states absorb some 13 percent of Taiwan's outbound shipments and this portion will go up to 50 percent if Taiwan's export ratio to mainland China is included.
Nevertheless, an economist said that the worst for Taiwan's economy is already over, evidenced in that the country's jobless rate has been falling with an increasingly adjusted industrial structure.

Wu Chung-shu, a researcher at the Institute of Economics under Academia Sinica, made the comment at a year-end seminar to check the country's economic performance over the past year and look to its outlook for the coming year.
According to Wu, the domestic economy has come out of the shadow cast by consumer price inflation over the past few years.

Quoting the newest statistics made public in November by the government, he reported that Taiwan's consumer price index began to post a positive growth rate in January year-on-year after having registered negative growth for three years in a row. It hit a high of 3.34 percent in July and stood at 1.49 percent in November, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: OUTPUT OF SOUTHERN TAIWAN SCIENCE PARK TOPS NT$270 BILLION IN 2004

TEXT.P: The production value of the Southern Taiwan Science Park reached NT$270 billion (US$8.44 billion) in 2004, an official said Saturday.

Tai Chein, director-general of the Southern Taiwan Science Park Administration, said the figure has achieved the targeted annual goal of NT$250 billion and that the park is looking at production value of at least NT$300 billion in 2005.
In 2004, the park also met its goals of attracting 30 manufacturers to set up new operations in the park and increasing the staff number to above 30,000 people, Tai said.
The park comprises two bases in Tainan and Kaohsiung counties, respectively.
A total of 157 manufacturers have been approved to set up operations in the park, with 127 in the Tainan section and 30 in the Kaohsiung section.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT SHOULD MATCH WORDS WITH DEEDS: OPPOSITION ALLIANCE

TEXT.P: The opposition "pan-blue alliance" of the Kuomintang (KMT) and its ally the People First Party (PFP) said Saturday that President Chen Shui-bian should match his words with deeds if he really wants harmony between the ruling and opposition parties.

The "pan-blue alliance" was responding to an olive branch extended by Chen in his New Year message in which he called for reconciliation between the parties now that the two nationwide elections in 2004, one for president and the other to elect legislators, are over.

The president also said that during the process of appointing a new premier, he will listen to the voice of the people and to the opinions of the ruling and opposition parties. In the future, the new cabinet should enhance its functionality in consultation and dialogue, he added.
However, KMT spokesman Chang Jung-kung claimed that the confrontation between the parties can be traced to the president himself, especially during election times.
If the president wants to preach harmony and reconciliation, he should start with himself, Chang added.

He said that during the Dec. 11 legislative elections, Chen vehemently attacked KMT Chairman Lien Chan as well as PFP Chairman James Soong. The president should apologize for attacking Lien and Soong or vow not to do so again, Chang said.

He also said that the formation of a new cabinet should show respect to the dual-head system stipulated in the Constitution as well as the majority in the legislature, but claimed that the president has no substantive ideas on either of these two aspects.
"It is empty words for the president to say that he will listen attentively to the voice of the people," according to Chang.
Meanwhile, the PFP officials said Chen should build up his credibility to "regain the trust of the people" and forego his path toward Taiwan independence.
Liu Wen-hsiung, PFP whip in the legislature, said the PFP is pleased with what he described as Chen's response to Soong's earlier call for an end to party confrontation.

Nonetheless PFP legislators Lee Hung-chun and Lee Yung-ping criticized the president for having "more words than deeds" and expressed hope that he will really do things to improve the lives of the people.

Lee also expressed hope that Chen will support the legislation of a draft bill to promote cross-strait peace before the current legislature ends later this month and then form a peace delegation that can travel to the mainland to promote cross-strait peace.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT DECLARES 2005 `HEALTHY LIFE' YEAR

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian and Vice President Annette Lu jointly proclaimed 2005 as a "healthy life" year during a series of activities held Saturday in Taichung, central Taiwan.

The activity drew an enthusiastic response from the private sector, with around 600 members from 60 civic groups from Taipei and Kaohsiung gathering at the square in front of the National Taiwan Museum of Fine Arts in Taichung to take part in the event.

The president noted that Taiwan has the longest official working hours in the world and said that although it represents the diligence of the local people, the satisfaction level with life of Taiwan people is relatively lower than other countries, showing that hard work does not necessarily bring a happy life.
He urged a positive attitude toward life, saying that it will help one's health and happiness.
Lu for her part said that people should be largely responsible for their own health, saying that in addition to the pursuit of fortune, people should also pay attention to health.

She compared the average lifespan of Taiwan people and happiness index with its economic achievements, saying that the happiness index lags far behind its economic performance and that the nation should make further efforts in this respect.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TO PROVIDE WATER TO DROUGHT-STRICKEN MATSU

TEXT.P: Taiwan will provide water to the outlying island of Matsu, which has been seriously affected by a shortage, government officials said Saturday.

Currently, Matsu's Nankang area has been troubled by a grave shortage, as local reservoirs contain only a combined 75,000 tons of water, officials of the Water Resources Agency (WRA) under the Ministry of Economic Affairs said, adding that Matsu residents are provided water only two days out of every three.
The WRA has already transported a total of 8,471 tons of water to the remote island in four shipments and will continue to do so to help meet demand for potable water, the officials noted.

Thanks to abundant rainfall brought by typhoon Nanmadol in early December, Taiwan proper, in particular the northern regions, is rich in water reserves, according to the officials. They added that water supply for civic and industrial use is secured through May, when the annual rainy season will begin for spring seeding.

DOC.HEADLINE: EXPORTS, IMPORTS TO REGISTER DOUBLE-DIGIT GROWTH IN 2005: BOFT

TEXT.P: Taiwan's exports and imports will register double-digit growth in 2005, officials of the Bureau of Foreign Trade (BOFT) said Saturday.

According to studies carried out by the Chung-Hua Institution for Economic Research under the commission of BOFT , the officials said that riding on the coattails of worldwide weak performance beginning in the third quarter in 2004, exports in 2005 will reach US$195.05 billion, while imports will reach US$182.66 billion, up 11.46 percent and 10.35 percent over the previous year's levels, respectively.
It also said that one of the factors favorable to Taiwan's exports in 2005 will be the maintenance of international oil prices at about US$40 per barrel.

Unfavorable factors will include the possible raising of U.S. interest rates in 2005, coupled with the continued sluggishness of the U.S. dollar against the yen and the euro, which will in turn affect the world economy.
According to the studies, Taiwan's economic growth rate for the year is expected to increase to 5.8 percent, while the U.S. dollar will be worth an average NT$33. (Nick Huang)

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN MANUFACTURERS SHOULD DEVELOP THEIR OWN BRANDS: TAITRA HEAD

TEXT.P: Taiwan manufacturers should develop branding for their own products, the chairman of the Taiwan External Trade Development Council (TAITRA) said Saturday.
Hsu Chih-jen said in an interview with CNA that Taiwan has demonstrated its excellence as an original equipment manufacturer (OEM).
However, he suggested, Taiwan companies should develop their own brands in the face of decreasing profits from the OEM and increasing international competition.
Taiwan can not compete with mainland China on price but is able to vie for market share with Japan and the United States on quality products, he explained.

The establishment of the non-profit Taiwan Design Center in last year was aimed at helping domestic manufacturers develop their own brands by integrating the public and private resources in the research and development and the designing of products, Hsu added.

DOC.HEADLINE: EVENT LISTING FOR JAN. 2 IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The following are important events scheduled to take place Sunday, Jan. 2:
10: 00, A news conference on the promotion of legislation to protect labor rights of the unemployed will be held at the Taipei Guest House.
10: 00, The 2005 Kaohsiung International Ice Lantern Exposition will open at the city's Po-Er special artistic zone.
11: 00, The disaster-damage-survey mission will hold a news conference at the Ministry of Foreign Affairs after returning from tsunami-hit nations.
15:00, The oath-taking ceremony of new president, directors and supervisors of Taiwan Junior Chamber will be held at National Tsinghua University in Hsinchu, northern Taiwan.
19: 00, President Chen Shui-bian will attend a "Peace and Love" concert at the Sun Yat-sen Memorial Hall in Taipei.
19: 20, Former President Lee Teng-hui will return to the Chiang Kai-shek International Airport from his visit to Japan.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Sunday, Jan. 2, or the 22nd day of the 11th month of the Year of the Monkey according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1492: The Spanish army captures Granada, the last Spanish Muslim stronghold, from the Moors, ending 700 years of Arab rule in Spain.
1727: James Wolfe, the British general who played a major part in fighting the French in Canada, is born.
1788: Georgia becomes the fourth state in the United States by ratifying the U.S. Constitution.
1882: John D. Rockefeller becomes the most powerful American outside the White House by gaining a stranglehold on the fast-growing oil industry.
1900: The first electric omnibus begins running in New York City.
1900: U.S. Secretary of State John Hay announces the U.S. open door policy on China.
1905: Russians surrender the Manchurian city of Lushun (Port Arthur) to the Japanese after the outbreak of the Russo-Japanese War.
1913: Taiwan's first bus begins operating in Taipei City, running between the train station and Yuanshan.
1930: The Taiwan Civilian Party, which would remain active until the surrender of Japan at the end of Word War II, files a suit at the League of Nations in Geneva against Japanese rulers in Taiwan for the Japanese policy of allowing people to smoke opium.
1932: Japanese rulers install a puppet regime known as Manchukuo after capturing Chingchou, in China's Liaoning Province.
1942: Chinese expeditionary forces enter Burma.
1942: Japanese forces capture Manila as Gen. Douglas MacArthur starts evacuating Allied forces from the Philippines.
1942: Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek assumes command of the China Theater of War.
1943: German forces begin their withdrawal from the Caucasus.
1952: Pope Pius XII declares that television is a threat to family life.
1957: The Republic of China Air Force carries out the biggest airdrop since 1949 over the communist-held mainland, distributing food, medicine and propaganda almost to the outskirts of Beijing, 1,700 miles north of Taiwan.
1965: Under President Sukarno, Indonesia quits the United Nations.
1966: Taiwan's first meteorological radar station is inaugurated in Hualien, eastern Taiwan.
1969: A China Airlines C-47 domestic plane crashes south of Mount Tawu in Pingtung, killing 24 people.
1970: U.S. Vice President Spiro T. Agnew and his mission arrive in Taipei for a visit on behalf of President Richard M. Nixon. A member of his mission presents a lunar rock to President Chiang Kai-shek as a gift.
1980: U.S. President Jimmy Carter suggests that the Senate not ratify the SALT nuclear arms treaty with the USSR until the Soviets withdraw from Afghanistan.
1996: Kamal Ganzouri is appointed prime minister of Egypt, succeeding Atef Sedki, who had been prime minister for nine years.
1996: U.S. government dietary guidelines acknowledge for the first time that consuming some alcohol can be healthy.
2000: China Airlines, Taiwan's largest civil aviation company, wins the top award at an international float show held in Pasadena in suburban Los Angeles.
2001: The 4,700-ton Tai Ma, a passenger vessel carrying a 500-member delegation from the islands of Matsu, becomes the first ship to complete a legal direct voyage from Republic of China territory to mainland China in over five decades.
2001: The Emerging Stock Market (ESM), a place for the trade of those stocks unlisted on the Taiwan Stock Exchange or the over-the-counter market, becomes operational in Taiwan, with an inauguration ceremony presided over by Premier Chang Chun-hsiung.
2001: The Bank of Taiwan issues bills with a denomination of NT$200 for the first time in the history of Taiwan.
2002: The Emerging Stock Market (ESM) became operational in Taiwan.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "A wise man who leaves his moral character is no longer entitled to the name of a wise man. A wise man never for one single moment in his life loses sight of a moral life; in moments of haste and hurry, as in moments of danger and peril, he always clings to it."

DOC.HEADLINE: VICE PREMIER SAYS WANG COULD HELP CROSS-STRAIT RELATIONS

TEXT.P: Vice Premier Yeh Chu-lan said Sunday she will be pleased to see Legislative Yuan President Wang Jin-pyng assist in breaking the lingering stalemate across the Taiwan Strait.
Yeh made the remarks after Wang said that if he is re-elected legislative speaker, he is willing to visit mainland China to get cross-strait relations moving forward.

Noting that peace and stability in the Taiwan Strait has been one of the government's top policy goals, Yeh said she believes President Chen Shui-bian will be happy to see Wang contribute his wisdom and energy to the issue.

Wang said during a new year countdown gathering with a group of local reporters that if he is re-elected legislative speaker, he will push the new legislature to pass a resolution to create a special task force to work for cross-strait reconciliation and will lead its members to visit mainland China.
The new legislature will be inaugurated Feb. 1. According to constitutional provisions, new lawmakers will elect among themselves a speaker and deputy speaker on the legislature's first day.

Wang, a vice chairman of the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) , is widely seen to have a good chance of retaining his current post as the KMT and its ally -- the People First Party -- will jointly control a slim majority in the new legislature elected on Dec. 11, 2004.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT: Los Angeles Times: Bush Boosts U.S. Aid Tenford. President Bush announced a tenfold increase in U.S. aid to victims of the Indian Ocean tsunami, pledging $350 million to address an "epic disaster" that he said could require still greater sums.

DOC.TEXT:
