DOC.HEADLINE: CAL FLOAT WINS INTERNATIONAL TROPHY AT ROSE PARADE
DOC.DATELINE: Los Angeles, Jan. 1 (CNA) (By L. S. Chu and P. C. Tang)

TEXT.P: A float decorated by the team representing China Airlines (CAL) won the International Trophy of the 2005 Rose Parade in Pasadena, California, Saturday.
This is the 14th time that a CAL float has been awarded at the parade since it began to participate in the activity in 1987.
The parade has been held in Pasadena in suburban Los Angeles on New Year's day since 1890.
Judges for the event said that CAL's float won because it was the best entry outside the United States and matched the theme of this year's parade, "celebrate family."
CAL won the International Trophy each year from 1998 to 2002.

The 165-member marching band from the Taipei First Girls' Senior High School, one of two foreign bands invited by the organizer of the event, also performed and received a warm welcome from spectators along the parade route.
A total of 104 participants, including floats, equestrian units, marching bands and honor guards took part in the parade.
The organizer of the parade estimated that more than one billion TV viewers in various parts of the world watched the event.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN MEDICAL TEAM STARTS TO TREAT VICTIMS IN ACEH PROVINCE
DOC.DATELINE: Banda Aceh, Indonesia, Jan. 2 (CNA) (By S. J. Kan and P. C. Tang)

TEXT.P: An ROC medical team has begun to help victims of the 9.0 earthquake and tsunamis on the Indonesia island of Sumatra.

The team, which arrived in Banda Aceh, the capital of Aceh Province Saturday, has already set up a temporary medical station at an overseas Chinese-owned abandoned factory in Lhok, a village located some 12 kilometers from Banda Aceh.

Several of the team's members have jointly diagnosed and treated 63 victims in the village and according to them, most suffer psychological effects from the disaster, others have external injuries and illnesses related to having consumed bad food and water.
Reports said that about 700 to 800 of the 1,400 inhabitants of Lhok were killed by the devastating tsunami triggered by the strong earthquake.
Some local people also said that the death toll at a nearby military camp stood at 7,000 and that 5,000 people who lived near the village were also killed.
The ROC medical team was scheduled to pay courtesy calls to the village's only hospital and international medical organizations later in the day to better understand the situation.

According to experts sent by Taiwan's Center for Disease Control of the Department of Health, there could be an outbreak of diseases, including malaria, due to the deteriorating sanitation and the overwhelming size of the catastrophe.

The death toll in Aceh province has exceeded 80,000 and the total dead in south Asia is nearing 140,000 with officials saying that the final number may never be known as people taken out to sea may never be recovered. At least five million people have been forced to leave their homes.

DOC.HEADLINE: PFP STILL AGAINST U.S. ARMS PURCHASE PLAN: AIDE

TEXT.P: The opposition People First Party (PFP) will remain opposed to the plan to purchase arms from the United States as long as the Ministry of National Defense is unwilling to give detailed explanations of the plan and cannot ease public concerns over the high cost, a ranking PFP member said Sunday.

Chang Hsien-yao, head of the PFP's policy-planning center, who made the comments in response to media questions, also said that the government's arms purchase plan should be dealt with by members of the new legislature. The new legislators elected on Dec. 11, 2004 will assume their posts Feb. 1.
The Executive Yuan has proposed a special budget of NT$610.8 billion to buy six Patriot PAC-3 anti-missiles batteries, eight diesel-fueled submarines and a squadron of 12 anti-submarine aircraft.

Touching on reports saying that some PFP legislators would support a bill authorizing the arms purchase plan and that the Ministry of National Defense would propose a new special budget for the plan after the adoption of the bill, Chang said that this is not the PFP's position.

PFP Chairman James Soong reiterated before departing for the United States a few days ago to visit his family that his party would support a reasonable and necessary arms purchase plan to protect the nation, but would never support a plan that includes paying the United States an exorbitant amount for the weaponry, Chang said, adding that this stance has not changed and that the party will not change it position.

Pointing out that the Ministry of National Defense has never given a clear explanation to the people on its decision-making process, the reasons for the high price and details of the procurement items of the arms purchase plan, the PFP aide said the party will urge the ministry to be transparent on these issues.

Noting that the PFP will oversee the arms purchase plan carefully since it could be the island's most important weapons purchase in the next 10 years, Chang said that as the current legislature has no time to deliberate on the plan, the members of the new legislature will be entrusted with dealing with the plan.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN EXPECTED TO BE GLOBAL LEADER IN MICROCHIP FOUNDRIES BY 2006

TEXT.P: Taiwan is expected to have the most microchip foundries in the world by 2006, Minister of Economic Affairs Ho Mei-yueh said Sunday.

Ho said that currently there are four 12-inch wafer plants in Taiwan, in addition to six under construction and two others planned to be built soon, adding that the island will have 10 12-inch microchip foundries by 2006, more than the United States' seven, Japan's five, South Korea's two.
Coupled with the existing 20 eight-inch, eight six-inch and three five-inch wafer plants, the competitiveness of Taiwan's semiconductor industry is expected to remain strong, Ho pointed out.

According to statistics released by the Ministry of Economic Affairs, the production value of Taiwan's IC design sector hit NT$190.2 billion (US$5.97 billion) in 2003, with the global market share reaching 28 percent, second only to the United States.

The outsourced production of silicon wafers amounted to NT$470.1 billion, accounting for 70.8 percent of the global market, the world's number one, while the global market share of IC packaging and assembly also ranked first globally, the tallies indicated, adding that the production value for each item in 2004 was higher than the previous year's level.

Noting that Taiwan's semiconductor industry enjoys a perfect vertical division of labor and integration ranging from designing, outsourcing, manufacturing to package and testing, Ho said she is confident that the industry's global competitiveness will remain strong.

The minister also reiterated that the government will only permit domestic semiconductor manufacturers to set up eight-inch wafer plants in mainland China for the moment, with only three factories to be built by 2005. As a result, she stressed, the policy will have a limited impact on the island's industrial development.

DOC.HEADLINE: MERGING TAIWAN'S BANKS WILL HELP BOOST COMPETITIVENESS: REPORT
DOC.DATELINE: New York, Jan. 1 (CNA) (By Lilian Lin & Luis Huang)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's government should speed up mergers of domestic banks to upgrade the global competitiveness of the island's financial sector, according to a research report quoted by the Wall Street Journal Sunday.

The report issued by the consultancy company McKinsey & Co. pointed out that an oversupply of financial institutions in Taiwan will adversely affect the country's long-term banking development, although the island's financial service industry ranks fourth in Asia in terms of business turnover.

As an island country with a population of only 23 million, Taiwan has 49 banks and more than 300 financial institutions dealing with loans, the report said, adding that it is difficult for domestic banks to expand their business as supply has outstripped demand.

In Taipei City alone, there are 3.4 bank branches offering services to an average of 10,000 people, much higher than the 1.9 branches in Hong Kong and the 1.3 branches in New York, the international consultancy company said.
If Taiwan wants to enhance the global competitiveness of its financial industry, it must do everything possible to accelerate the merger of domestic banks.

McKinsey suggested in its report that financial institutions on the island be reduced to 15 at most, including one or two loan banks with international competitiveness, five large-scale domestic banks and several small-sized banks operating at a profit.

Conscious of the importance of merging domestic banks, Taiwan's government officials in charge of financial affairs have been working actively to push for the merger of financial institutions over the past years, the report indicated.

However, the merger plan has not been carried out as scheduled because of strong pressure from the opposition-controlled legislature and trade unions, the report went on. It also called on the government to play a more active role in pushing for bank integration.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP LEGISLATIVE CAUCUS CALLS FOR SPEEDY PASSAGE OF 2005 BUDGET BILL

TEXT.P: The legislative caucus of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) said Sunday that rational discussions must be held among political parties so that the 2005 general budget bill can clear the legislative floor as soon as possible.

Legislator Tsai Huang-lang, who also serves as secretary-general of the DPP legislative caucus, made the appeal on the eve of a cross-party negotiation on the central government's 2005 budget proposal to be held Monday in the Legislative Yuan.

Since the legislative caucuses of the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) and the People First Party (PFP) are planning to review the general budget plan in a stricter way, Tsai urged lawmakers from the two parties to be rational when they go over the bill.

"I am hopeful that the general budget proposal will clear the legislature before it goes into recess Jan. 21; otherwise, the executive branch will have trouble in carrying out various administrative affairs," Tsai told reporters.

As to a media report that the KMT and the PFP have decided to slash the proposed government expenditures and revenues for the new fiscal year by NT$100 billion (US$3.15 billion) , Tsai said that if budget cuts are reasonable, the DPP caucus will accept them so that the budget proposal will be approved by the legislature as scheduled.

Meanwhile, Legislator Huang Teh-fu, also a secretary-general of the KMT caucus, and Legislator Liu Wen-hsiung, who also serves as chief convener of the PFP caucus, reiterated unanimously that the two parties will closely cooperate in reviewing the central government's budget bill.

"KMT and PFP lawmakers will strictly review the general budget plan submitted by the Executive Yuan for the new fiscal year, " they pointed out, adding that they will insist that unreasonable budget items be removed during the deliberation process.

For his part, Chen Chien-ming, deputy convener of the legislative caucus of the opposition Taiwan Solidarity Union, said that his party will support the speedy passage of the general budget plan but will push for the government to cross out those budget items which are inadequately listed.

DOC.HEADLINE: JOB-CREATION PROJECT HELPS LOWER 2004 UNEMPLOYMENT RATE

TEXT.P: The overall unemployment rate for 2004 is expected to be 4.5 percent thanks to the government's program begun two years ago to create jobs, a government official said Sunday.

Taiwan followed South Korea's model and offered jobs in the public service sector to boost employment in early 2003 to help curb the growing jobless rate, said the official with the Cabinet-level Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD).

According to official statistics, the short-term job-creation program offered nearly 46,000 opportunities to jobless people for a period of six months last year, which the official said will help bring down Taiwan's jobless rate for 2004 to 4.5 percent.
As of June last year, there were about 21,000 applicants hoping to find work under the program, with about 10,000 of them being placed with employers, the statistics showed.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN OFFERS US$50 MILLION IN RELIEF AID TO TSUNAMI-HIT COUNTRIES

TEXT.P: The Republic of China government will offer US$50 million in relief to countries stricken by a devastating earthquake and ensuing tsunamis last week, Vice Premier Yeh Chu-lan said Sunday.

Yeh made the announcement after presiding over an inter-departmental meeting to discuss how to help with post-disaster relief work in a dozen tsunami-hit countries around the Indian Ocean, including Indonesia, Sri Lanka, Thailand and India.
Yeh said the aid package will include food aid, medical supplies and community reconstruction.

Noting that the scope of damage caused by the Dec. 26 earthquake beneath the Indian Ocean was much more serious than originally reported, Yeh said the government has decided to boost its aid offer from US$5 million to US$50 million, including US$20 million worth of rice, US$15 million worth of medical supplies and US$15 million in community and harbor reconstruction.

Yeh also urged individual citizens to donate funds to help quake and tsunami victims in South and Southeast Asia. A special bank account opened by the Ministry of Foreign Affairs had received NT$40 millio in donation from the private sector. Many local charitable organizations have also launched fund-raising drives. If private donations are calculated, relief aid from Taiwan will reach US$60 million, government sources said.

According to tallies compiled by foreign wire services, Taiwan will rank eighth in the world in terms of aid to the quake- and tsunami-hit South and Southeast Asian countries. Taiwan's pledged donation is equivalent to NT$1.6 billion, which is equivalent to NT$70 for each person in Taiwan.
Council of Agriculture Chairman Lee Chin-lung said the government will donate 2,000 tons of rice and 500,000 cases of cooked rice, which are worth US$20 million at market prices.

Department of Health (DOH) Minister Chen Chien-jen said his department has organized a 200-member medical team and 3,000 tons of medical supplies. Moreover, Chen said, the DOH plans to set up 50 medical service centers in disaster zones in various quake- or tsunami-hit countries.

Kuo Yao-chi, chairwoman of the Public Construction Commission, said that so long as host countries can provide plots of land and infrastructure facilities, Taiwan can build three residential communities in two months for surviving victims, with each community accommodates 300 housing units capable of sheltering 1,500 people, a school and a medical service station.
"We have learned a lot in post-disaster rehabilitation from the 921 earthquake that left more than 2,400 local people dead and tens of thousands homeless in central Taiwan in 1999," Kuo said.

Cabinet spokesman Chen Chi-mai said the aid for the quake- and tsunami-hit countries will be raised by relevant ministries. If necessary, Chen said, the Cabinet's second reserve fund will be used to finance the aid package.
More than 150,000 people are feared dead and about five million were left homeless in the affected countries.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT OUTLINES 3 PRINCIPLES FOR PROMOTING CROSS-STRAIT CHARTER FLIGHTS

TEXT.P: The opposition Kuomintang reiterated its three principles Sunday for promoting the opening of direct charter flights across the Taiwan Strait during the upcoming Chinese New Year holiday for Taiwan business people working in mainland China.
KMT spokesman Chang Jung-kung claimed that the KMT will mainly play the role of communicator, not negotiator, in the proposed cross-strait charter flight services.

The KMT's three principles are that both mainland and Taiwan carriers should be allowed to operate cross-strait charter flights during the period, those flights should be non-stop and three mainland destinations -- Shanghai, Beijing and Guangzhou -- should be include in the package.
Chang said the KMT package can be carried out without prior cross-strait negotiations.
"With the consent of relevant government authorities, the proposed two-way, non-stop, cross-strait charter flights can kick-start," Chang claimed.

He urged the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) administration to accept the KMT-proposed formula to benefit a large number of Taiwan businesspeople working on the mainland, commonly known as "taishang," intending to return to spend the lunar new year holiday.
If the KMT-initiated charter flights package can be implemented, Chang claimed, it can also help defuse cross-strait tension.

Chang said representatives from the KMT legislative caucus and six local carriers will travel to the mainland to discuss with mainland Chinese air carriers to pave the way for the proposed holiday charter flights.

With Beijing's consent, six Taiwan carriers operated special charter flights between Shanghai and Taipei/Kaohsiung via Hong Kong/Macau during the 2003 Chinese New Year holiday. The services were not offered the following year because Beijing insisted that mainland carriers also be allowed to provide the same flight services but refused to negotiate the necessary technical details with Taiwan.

Huang Teh-fu, KMT legislative whip, said mainland Chinese carriers can commission private organizations to apply with Taiwan authorities for permission to operate the proposed cross-strait charter flights just like what mainland news organizations have been doing in the past few years in applying for approval to post reporters in Taiwan.

"If the DPP administration agrees to this formula, bilateral negotiations are not necessary for the opening of special cross-strait charter flights during the upcoming Chinese New Year holiday," Huang claimed.
Huang said he and his KMT colleagues will pay a visit to the Mainalnd Affairs Council (MAC) -- Taiwan's top mainland policy planning agency -- again on Monday to seek its support for the KMT package.
MAC Vice Chairman Liu Teh-hsun said Friday that the proposed cross-strait charter flights could be modeled after the 2003 formula.

Liu said that the MAC has repeatedly urged the mainland side to negotiate the holiday charter flight issue, but to no avail. With only a little more than one month before Chinese New Year Day, which falls on Feb. 9, Liu suggested using the 2003 model in which only Taiwan carriers operated the special charter flight service.
If "taishang" believe that more mainland cities should be included in the services, Liu siad the MAC is willing to consult with air carriers to expand the services to Guangzhou and Beijing.

Should mainland air carriers want to apply for operating similar flight services, Liu said, the two sides must consult to come to terms because such operations involve the exercise of public authority and complex technical details for safety reasons.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TO DELIVER LARGE AMOUNT OF MEDICAL SUPPLIES TO PHUKET

TEXT.P: Taiwan will send eight doctors and epidemiologists to the Thai resort island of Phuket Tuesday to assist in post-disaster medical aid and disinfection work, a Department of Health (DOH) official said Sunday.

On the same day, the official said, a large amount of medical supplies to be donated by Taiwan, including surgical gloves, disinfection equipment, antibiotics, painkillers and anti-inflammation drugs, will also arrive in Phuket, one of the hardest-hit areas in the Dec. 26 tsunami catastrophe triggered by a magnitude-9.0 earthquake off the northern Indonesia island of Sumatra.

As of Sunday, the official said, 13 Taiwan medical professionals have arrived in Medan, Indonesia to offer post-disaster medical aid. The non-government organization Taiwan Roots Medical Peace Corps has also send a 42-member medical team to work in Sri Lanka.

Chang said the DOH will organize various medical teams to take turn in working in quake- and tsunami-hit South and Southeast Asian nations, including Indonesia, Sri Lanka and Thailand. Each team will work at various host countries for two weeks.
Earlier in the day, Vice Premier Yeh Chu-lan announced that the government will offer US$50 million in relief to countries stricken by the devastating earthquake and ensuing tsunamis last week.
Yeh said the aid package will include food aid, medical supplies and community reconstruction.

Noting that the scope of damage caused by the Dec. 26 earthquake beneath the Indian Ocean was much more serious than originally reported, Yeh said the government has decided to boost its aid offer from US$5 million to US$50 million, including US$20 million worth of rice, US$15 million worth of medical supplies and US$15 million in community and harbor reconstruction.

Yeh also urged individual citizens to donate funds to help quake and tsunami victims in South and Southeast Asia. A special bank account opened by the Ministry of Foreign Affairs had received NT$40 million in donation from the private sector. Many local charitable organizations have also launched fund-raising drives. If private donations are calculated, relief aid from Taiwan will reach US$60 million, government sources said.
Council of Agriculture Chairman Lee Chin-lung said the government will donate 2,000 tons of rice and 500,000 cases of cooked rice, which are worth US$20 million at market prices.

DOH Minister Chen Chien-jen said his department has organized a 200-member medical team and 3,000 tons of medical supplies. Moreover, Chen said, the DOH plans to set up 50 medical service centers in disaster zones in various quake- or tsunami-hit countries.

Kuo Yao-chi, chairwoman of the Public Construction Commission, said that so long as host countries can provide plots of land and infrastructure facilities, Taiwan can build three residential communities in two months for surviving victims, with each community accommodates 300 housing units capable of sheltering 1,500 people, a school and a medical service station.
More than 150,000 people are feared dead and about five million were left homeless in the affected countries.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER PRESIDENT WRAPS UP JAPAN VISIT

TEXT.P: Former President Lee Teng-hui returned to Taipei Sunday after a seven-day private visit to Japan, which has drew strong protests from mainland China.

Lee told more than 1,200 supporters who turned up at Chiang Kai-shek International Airport to greet him that his Japan visit amid Beijing's protest indicates that relations between Taipei and Tokyo are close.
In his view, Lee said, Taiwan-Japanese relations have been advancing quietly.
Despite Beijing's loud protests, Lee said most Japanese people welcomed his visit, adding that his visit indicates that Taiwan-Japanese ties are in the best shape in history.

In the new year, Lee said all local people should redouble efforts to reinforce Taiwan's national identity, speed up the campaign to rectify the name of Taiwan and continue democratic reform to make Taiwan a "normal and complete" democratic country.
Minister of Foreign Affairs Tan Sun Chen and lawmakers from the Taiwan Solidarity Union of which Lee is the spiritual leader greeted Lee at the airport.

On Sunday morning, Lee visited the Kiyomizu Buddhist temple and paid his tribute to the grave of the late Ryotaro Shiba, a Japanese author of historical novels on modern Asia. Shiba had interviewed Lee in Taipei when he was the Republic of China president.

Before leaving the ancient Japanese capital of Kyoto for Kansai International Airport near Osaka, western Japan to take a flight for home, Lee issued a brief statement, expressing his gratitude for the hospitality he had received during his visit.
"I want to thank the Japanese government and people for their warmth and hospitality. I've learned a lot from this journey, " Lee said.
Lee further said the trip could be viewed as successful "if I was able to serve as a quiet yet firm link between both sides."

During his trip, Lee, 81, managed to meet with his 98-year-old Japanese Sukekata Kashiwa who was Lee's professor when Lee studied at the agroeconomics department of Kyoto University in the early 1940s. Taiwan was then a Japanese colony.
It was their first reunion in nearly 60 years as they had lost contact for decades and did not get in touch against until three years ago with the assistance of Lee's Japanese friends.

However, Lee was denied entry to Kyoto University last Friday. He was turned away at the door because Beijing authorities have pressured the Japanese government and Kyoto University not to allow Lee to visit his alma mater. As a result, 10 Kyoto University professors and doctors had to meet with Lee at a restaurant in downtown Kyoto.

Lee told Taiwan reporters later that day that he did not feel regret over his inability to enter the campus of his alma mater. "I only feel that my alma mater became very strange to me, " he said calmly while visiting Ginkakuji Temple that afternoon.

Lee said his trip has helped him come to a better understanding of the Japanese way of thinking. He said Japan is an advanced and orderly country from which Taiwan can learn much. Lee was accompanied by his wife and other family members on his rare Japan trip.

Lee riled Beijing during his 12 years in office from 1988-2000 when he campaigned to raise Taiwan's international profile. He redefined the island's ties with the mainland in 1999 as a "special state-to-state" relationship, causing Beijing to break off fence-mending talks which remain suspended to this day.
Japanese officials said Lee is visiting as a private citizen and as such, had no basis for turning down his visa application.
Lee last traveled to Japan in April 2001, when he had treatment for a heart condition.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Monday, Jan. 3, or the 23rd day of the 11th month of the Year of the Monkey according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
106BC: Marcus Tullius Cicero, Roman statesman and orator, is born.
1777: George Washington leads troops to defeat the British at the Battle of Princeton.
1868: Japanese Emperor Meiji seizes power from the Tokugawa Shogun, ending 700 years of military rule.
1924: British archaeologist Howard Carter discovers the tomb of Tutankhamen in Egypt's Valley of the Kings. The pharaoh's tomb was filled with treasures, including a solid gold sarcophagus, a gold death mask, jewelry, and other artifacts.
1932: The Chinese Communists set up a Soviet-style regime in Kan Hsien in Kiangsi Province.
1933: The Japanese imperial army, navy and air force conduct a joint attack on Shanhaikwan, a fortress located at the eastern end of the Great Wall. All the Chinese defenders, including battalion commander An Teh-hsing, die in the ensuing battle.
1939: A group of Chinese generals, including Chen Cheng, Lung Yun, and Hsueh Yueh, cable their support for Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek in the War of Resistance Against Japan and for sanctions against Wang Ching-wei, a high-ranking Nationalist official who advocated peace talks with Japan.
1940: Kao Chung-wu and Tao Hsi-sheng, right-hand men of Wang Ching-wei, flee Shanghai for Hong Kong after opposing the secret treaty signed by Wang and the Japanese which saw Wang installed as the head of a puppet government of the Japanese in Nanking.
1947: Yu Pin assumes his post as archbishop of the Nanking area.
1956: Mainland Chinese pilot Fan Tien-cheng commits suicide after failing in an attempt to fly a MIG fighter jet to Taiwan.
1956: The Soviet Union extends technical assistance to Communist China.
1959: Alaska becomes the 49th and largest state of the United States.
1961: The United States severs diplomatic relations with Cuba.
1962: President Sukarno of Indonesia proclaims West New Guinea an independent province.
1963: Chu Chia-hua, former president of Academia Sinica, dies in Taipei at the age of 71.
1973: Vice President C.K. Yen leaves for a week-long trip to the United States to attend memorial services for U.S. President Harry S. Truman.
1974: A technical cooperation agreement signed between the ROC and Malawi the previous November is approved by the Executive Yuan.
1975: The Republic of China and Jordan sign a provisional aviation accord under which their airlines will exchange freight and passengers at an intermediate point between Taipei and Amman.
1977: The International Monetary Fund lends nearly US$4 billion to Britain to bolster its currency.
1980: The U.S. government informs the ROC government that it will resume arms sales to the ROC after a one-year suspension.
1993: U.S. President George Bush and Russian President Boris Yeltsin sign an arms control treaty to reduce nuclear weapon stockpiles by two-thirds.
1994: Negotiations between Communist China and Britain on the future political system of Hong Kong come to a standstill.
1996: The ROC and the Republic of Senegal resume full diplomatic relations, increasing to 31 the number of nations with which the ROC maintains official diplomatic ties.
2000: The Shang Yi Airport on the offshore island of Kinmen is turned over to the Civil Aeronautics Administration by the ROC Air Force, ending more than four decades of military administration of the airport.
2001: Su Hsiu-ying, a 103-year-old female cancer patient who underwent surgery at Chang Gung Memorial Hospital-Linkou in late December, is discharged from the hospital.
2002: Chinese Taipei Olympic Committee (CTOC) President Huang Ta-chou is re-elected to the four-year post at a meeting of the CTOC's Executive Committee.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "Men's faults are characteristic. By observing a man's failings, you can judge his moral character."

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING UNVEILS FORMULA FOR HOLIDAY CROSS-STRAIT CHARTER FLIGHTS

TEXT.P: Mainland China has finally agreed to work toward the opening of direct charter flights across the Taiwan Strait during the upcoming Chinese Lunar New Year holiday for Taiwan business people working in mainland China.

Beijing's official Xinhua news agency's online edition quoted the spokesman of the Taiwan Affairs Office as saying late Sunday that mainland authorities will do their utmost to open the special cross-strait charter flight services under the formula of "joint participation, multiple destinations, direct flights and two-way passenger transport services."

For various reasons, the spokesman said, cross-strait negotiations cannot resume at the moment. Nevertheless, the spokesman suggested that air carriers from both sides be authorized to negotiate technical details to pave the way for the special cross-strait flight services during the lunar new year holiday.

"We believe our suggestion is pragmatic and feasible, " the spokesman said, adding that Taiwan's elected representatives and airline executives are welcome to travel to the mainland to discuss the proposed charter flight services.

With Beijing's consent, six Taiwan carriers operated special charter flights between Shanghai and Taipei/Kaohsiung via Hong Kong/Macau during the 2003 Chinese Lunar New Year holiday. The services were not offered the following year because Beijing insisted that mainland carriers also be allowed to provide the same flight services but refused to negotiate the necessary technical details with Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: SEF CHAIRMAN C. F. KOO DEAD AT 88

TEXT.P: Taiwan's top negotiator with mainland China, Koo Chen-fu, died of renal failure at Cheng Hsin Rehabilitation Hospital in Taipei Monday morning. He would have been 88 on Jan. 6.

Koo, a business tycoon who acted as cross-strait negotiator, went to the United States in 2002 for treatment of pyelotic cancer, during which his right kidney, gallbladder and pancreas were removed. Koo's cancer relapsed this passing October, forcing him to check into Cheng Hsin Hospital where he received dialysis and was sometimes aided to breath by a respirator.
Koo was appointed by the government to be the chairman of the quasi-official Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) in March 1991.

Soon afterward the Beijing-based intermediary body, the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS) , was set up. Both the SEF and ARATS, thus, were established to handle cross-strait exchanges in the absence of official ties.

Koo met with ARATS Chairman Wang Daohan in Singapore April 27-29, 1993, marking a landmark rendezvous of government-appointed negotiators from Taiwan and mainland China after a five-decade hiatus of relations across the Taiwan Strait.

Although the diplomatic tug-of-war between the two sides of the Strait continued unabated, Koo traveled to the mainland April 14-19, 1998, where he met with mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin, Vice Premier Qian Qichen and his Beijing counterpart, Wang Daohan, for talks.

This trip marked an attempt to break the ice that had formed since 1995, when then-President Lee Teng-hui made a groundbreaking trip to the United States, which Beijing considered to be a move to promote Taiwan independence and consequently suspended all scheduled interchange activities.

Official exchanges across the Taiwan Strait ended completely in July 1999 when SEF and ARATS stopped talking to each other after President Lee said that relations across the Strait ought to be thought of as "state-to-state" in nature.
A senior adviser to President Lee, Koo was also Taiwan's top envoy, taking part on occasion in the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation forum's informal leadership summit on behalf of the president.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT'S TRIP TO SOUTH PACIFIC MAY MOVE AHEAD CABINET RESHUFFLE

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian is scheduled to visit the ROC's allies in the South Pacific in late January, and the naming of a new premier and the formation of a new Cabinet will be moved ahead, a source from the Presidential Office said Monday.

Media reports said President Chen is scheduled to leave Taiwan Jan. 28 and return on Chinese Lunar New Year's Eve Feb. 8. The president will initially visit Palau, the Marshall Islands and the Solomon Islands.

Premier Yu Shyi-kun said earlier that he will lead his Cabinet to resign en masse before the current legislature ends on Jan. 21. If the president's trip is finalized, then details related to forming a new Cabinet will be delayed.

Chen Wen-tzung, director of the Department of Public Affairs of the Presidential Office, stressed that the president takes overseas trips every year, and he has long expressed his intention to visit the ROC's allies in the South Pacific.

A team from the Presidential Office has traveled to the countries in the South Pacific to prepare for the president's visit. The itinerary will be announced after all preparations are complete, he said.

Taiwan's allies in the South Pacific include Palau, the Marshall Islands, the Solomon Islands, Kiribati, and Tuvalu. Except for Palau, which is suitable for large passenger planes, the airport facilities in other countries may pose some problems.
Vice President Annette Lu is also scheduled to visit El Salvador and Nicaragua in mid-February before returning on Feb. 23.

DOC.HEADLINE: KOO CHEN-FU 'IRREPLACEABLE': FORMER MAC CHAIRWOMAN TSAI ING-WEN

TEXT.P: Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) Chairman Koo Chen-fu was an important asset to the nation and will be hard to replace, former Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Chairwoman Tsai Ing-wen said Monday.
Koo died of renal failure Monday morning at the age of 87. He would have been 88 on Jan. 6.

Expressing her sympathies to Koo's family, Tsai said that Koo, Taiwan's top negotiator with mainland China and a man who achieved much in developing cross-strait relations, was "unprecedented and is irreplaceable."

Koo, a business tycoon with an enviable family background and skilled in various cultural activities, including writing poetry and singing Chinese opera, was appointed by the government to be the chairman of the quasi-official Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) in March 1991.

Soon afterward the Beijing-based intermediary body, the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS) , was set up. Both the SEF and ARATS, thus, were established to handle cross-strait exchanges in the absence of official ties.

Koo met with ARATS Chairman Wang Daohan in Singapore April 27-29, 1993, marking a landmark rendezvous of government-appointed negotiators from Taiwan and mainland China after a five-decade hiatus of relations across the Taiwan Strait.

Although the diplomatic tug-of-war between the two sides of the Strait continued unabated, Koo traveled to the mainland April 14-19, 1998, where he met with mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin, Vice Premier Qian Qichen and his Beijing counterpart, Wang Daohan, for talks.

Tsai, who was on Koo's 11-member team during that trip in her capacity as an SEF adviser, said that it was really an "eye opener" to watch how Koo dealt with the Beijing leadership and conducted the groundbreaking talks with them.

The former top charter of mainland policy said that the last time she met with Koo was prior to the Dec. 11 legislative elections for a brief talk, during which Koo expressed grave concern over the development of cross-strait relations. Tsai is now a legislator of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party.

Meanwhile, Kao Huei, director of the Institute of Mainland Studies at Chinese Culture University, said that the passing of Koo is tantamount to the death of the symbolic significance of cross-strait relations, given that the two sides have been at a complete political impasse since July 1999 after then-President Lee Teng-hui said that relations across the Strait ought to be thought of as "state-to-state" in nature.

Against this backdrop of such icy relations, cross-strait detente would have come to nothing were it not for Koo and his Beijing counterpart, ARATS Chairman Wang, and their tacit understanding of each other, Kao said.
Also memorializing Koo was former MAC Chairman Su Chi, who said that Koo was without parallel in cross-strait history.

Koo went to the United States in 2002 for treatment of pyelotic cancer, during which his right kidney, gallbladder and pancreas were removed. Koo's cancer relapsed this passed October, forcing him to check into Cheng Hsin Hospital where he received dialysis and was sometimes aided to breath by a respirator.

A senior adviser to both former President Lee Teng-hui and incumbent President Chen Shui-bian, Koo was also Taiwan's top envoy, taking part on occasion in the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation forum's informal leadership summit on behalf of the president.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Washington Post: Indonesians Start to Pick Up the Pieces; Markets Reopened, Roads Cleared In Devastated Aceh.
A week after a tsunami devastated the western end of Sumatra island, the streets of this provincial capital are beginning to show a semblance of rejuvenation, with markets reopening, power and water restored to nearly half the city and a paralyzing fuel shortage ended, the paper said.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP WHIP RECOMMENDS SOONG TO SUCCEED SEF CHAIRMAN KOO

TEXT.P: A legislator from the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) suggested Monday that opposition People First Party (PFP) Chairman James Soong succeed Koo Chen-fu as chairman of the quasi-official Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF).
Lee Chun-yi, a DPP party whip at the Legislative Yuan, said that the DPP's condolences go out to Koo's wife and family. Koo died of renal failure Monday morning.

Lee said that it is inappropriate right now to talk about the details of choosing a successor to Koo, but he thinks that Soong would be a suitable candidate given his widely known efforts in actively championing cross-strait peace.

In addition, Lee said that the opening of the SEF chairmanship offers a chance for parties from across Taiwan's political spectrum to come together to talk about the succession issue since the SEF is an intermediary arm governed and overseen by the government as well as by the legislature.
Koo, who had been Taiwan's top negotiator with mainland China as SEF chairman since March 1991, died of complications of kidney cancer in Taipei at the age of 87. He would have been 88 on Jan. 6.
Soong was instrumental in the writing of a cross-strait "peace safeguarding draft bill" aimed at securing peace across the Taiwan Strait for the next 30 to 50 years, Lee said.

The bill envisaged by Soong and PFP lawmakers would be conducive to facilitating cross-strait peace talks and helping secure a breakthrough in the current cross-strait political stalemate, PFP lawmakers said. The draft bill was submitted to the Legislative Yuan late last year for discussion.

Meanwhile, Chiu Tai-san, vice chairman of the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) , which supervises the operations of the SEF, said that Johnnason Liu, SEF vice chairman and secretary-general, has been appointed as acting chairman.
Koo's successor will be determined at an opportune time after the MAC consults with opinion leaders from various sections of society, Chiu added.
Meanwhile, the SEF wrote the Beijing-based Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS) Monday to inform its mainland counterpart about the death of Koo, Liu told the media.
The SEF will continue to spare no efforts to foster good relations across the Taiwan Strait on the solid foundation that Koo has laid, Liu added.

DOC.HEADLINE: AIRLINES ASSOCIATION AUTHORIZED TO NEGOTIATE CHARTERS WITH CHINA

TEXT.P: The Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) has authorized the Taipei Airlines Association (TAA) to negotiate with mainland China on the launch of cross-Taiwan Strait charter flights during next month's Chinese Lunar New Year holiday, MAC Vice Chairman Chiu Tai-san said Monday.

Chiu made the announcement after a spokesman of mainland China's Taiwan Affairs Office said in an interview with the Xinhua News Agency on Sunday that Beijing would facilitate the charter services in light of the transportation needs of Taiwanese business people in mainland China.
The unnamed Chinese official proposed that airlines from both sides consult each other directly on the technical and operational details concerning the services.

Chiu said the TAA has been charged with the mission of coordinating with the six Taiwanese airliners so that they can file their applications for operating the charter services with Beijing in a proper way and at an appropriate time.
Chiu urged Beijing authorities to finalize the flight schedules soon to make it more convenient for Taiwanese businesses to arrange their trips during the holiday.

Chiu said the government is sincere in promoting the charter services and would be happy to negotiate with mainland China on its requests for "joint participation, direct flights and two-way passenger transport services."

With Beijing's consent, six Taiwanese airliners operated charter flights between Shanghai and Taipei/Kaohsiung via Hong Kong/Macau during the 2003 Chinese Lunar New Year holiday. The services were not offered the following year because Beijing insisted that Chinese carriers also be allowed to join the services but refused to negotiate the necessary technical details with Taiwan.

Meanwhile, Chiu said the Ministry of Economic Affairs is accepting applications from Taiwanese business people with operations in mainland China to travel between the two sides during the holiday via the ferry services between the outlying islands of Kinmen/Matsu and mainland China's Xiamen/Fuzhou, known generally as the "mini three-links."

Also, the Ministry of Transportation and Communications will coordinate with related airlines to arrange for the launch of extra flights to transport Taiwanese business people in mainland China's Guangdong area who travel by ship to Hong Kong for a flight back to Taiwan during the holiday, Chiu added.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Japan Times: A week after disaster, hope for finding tsunami survivors fade Pledges of relif from around world jump to $2 billion BANDA ACHE.
Hopes of finding more survivors on Indonesias shattered Sumatra Island faded Sunday, one week after killer tsunamis swept across South Asia, as food, water and other relief supplies trickled into the disaster zone. The death toll stands at more than 124,000, and is still climbing.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Times: Aid starts to flow into the lands laid to waste.
Millions of starving, injured and homeless people in tsunami-hit regions began their second week without aid yesterday as Kofi Annan, the UN Secretary-General, promised to speed supplies to stricken areas.
Financial Times: Britain to press for G8 aid package for tsunami disaster.
Britain will this week promise to use its presidency of the G8 group of industrialised nations to clinch an international deal on debt relief for the countries affected by the Asian tsunami.
The UK treasury is confident that by working with its foreign counterparts it will be able within weeks to announce an agreement on a long-term package of assistance.

DOC.HEADLINE: DEFENSE MINISTRY CONSIDERING WHETHER TO MOTHBALL SOME JET FIGHTERS

TEXT.P: The Ministry of National Defense has been considering whether to mothball some of the nation's jet fighters for assorted reasons, although the plan is still in the pipeline, Vice Minister of National Defense Tsai Ming-hsien said Monday.

Tsai said that the defense ministry has talked with the French aircraft manufacturer Dassault Aviation, which has sold 60 Mirage-2000s to Taiwan over the past decade, about having some of them mothballed for a number of reasons, including Taiwan's climate and environment, which are harmful to cutting-edge jet fighters due to the high humidity and high concentration of salt in the air, the high maintenance costs, and a defense budget that has been falling yearly.
Mothballing the Mirage-2000s would help lengthen the life expectancy of the French-made jet fighters and would help reduce maintenance costs, Tsai said.

The mothballing would not affect Taiwan's air defense capability, even if in the event of a military invasion, Tsai said, adding that many countries in the world, including the United States, keep jet fighters and war ships in storage.

Tsai made the remarks during an interpellation session at the Legislative Yuan, where opposition legislators asked him for an explanation about a news report saying that some of the country's jet fighters are to be mothballed, including the Mirage-2000s and some IDFs.

Meanwhile, Tsai noted that the air, army and navy branches of the ROC military are on stand-by to dispatch their personnel and supplies to tsunami- and earthquake-affected countries in South Asia based on humanitarian needs.

Currently, the navy is readying a 8,400-ton transport frigate, while the air force is preparing six crews and seven C-130 transport planes, and the army is gathering emergency and relief supplies, including sterilization materials and equipment, as well as power generators, Tsai noted.
He said that the military personnel and supplies will be ready to go whenever the Ministry of Foreign Affairs reaches a consensus with the governments of the South Asian countries on what is needed.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN SHARE PRICES CLOSE SLIGHTLY HIGHER

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange closed slightly higher Monday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, edging up 3.43 points to close at 6,143.12.
The bourse opened at 6,166.39 and fluctuated between 6,183.15 and 6,129.28 during trading. A total of 4.21 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$75.16 billion.

Six of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with cement issues moving up 1.9 percent; foodstuff issues up 2.5 percent; plastics and chemicals up 1 percent; textiles up 2.4 percent; paper and pulp issues up 0.6 percent construction stocks up 1.4 percent.
In contrast, banking and financial shares edged down 0.1 percent and machinery and electronics shares declined 0.4 percent.
Gainers outnumbered losers 429 to 317, with 134 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: US DOLLAR DIPS ON TAIPEI FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar dipped against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Monday, giving up NT$0.072 to close at NT$31.845.
A total of US$838 million changed hands.
The greenback opened at the day's high of NT$31.966 and dipped to a low of NT$31.722.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES LOWER ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were lower Monday as the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for January lost 14 points to close at 6,174, with 20,319 contracts changing hands.
TAIEX Index futures for February moved down eight points to finish at 6,177, with 343 contracts traded, while March futures gained one point to finish at 6,162, with seven contracts traded.
June futures gained five points to finish at 6,155, with 51 contracts traded, while September futures moved down 20 points to close at 6,060, with five contracts traded.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Monday at 6,188 for January, 6,185 for February, 6,161 for March, 6,150 for June and 6,080 for September.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were higher.

January TE futures dropped 1.50 points to close at 229.40, with 2,711 contracts traded, while February TE futures dropped 1.20 points to finish at 229.20, with 35 contract transactions. March TE futures dropped 0.70 points to close at 228.6, with two contracts traded.
No transactions were recorded for June and September.

January TF futures dropped 0.2 points to finish at 1,045.8, with 3,222 contracts changing hands, while February TF futures gained 3.4 points to end at 1,046.0, with 62 contracts traded. March TF futures dropped 0.4 points to finish at 1,042.6, with one contract changing hands.
No transactions were recorded for June or September.

DOC.HEADLINE: 'MINI LINKS' BETWEEN KINMEN, XIAMEN INCREASINGLY POPULAR: NPA

TEXT.P: The direct trade and transport links between the Taiwan-held island of Kinmen and Xiamen City in mainland China's Fujian Province are becoming more and more popular, evidenced in the record number of passengers who used the service to travel between Taiwan and the mainland last year, according to government tallies.

Statistics compiled by the Bureau of Immigration under the National Police Administration (NPA) show that a total of 404,363 people -- 203,164 outbound and 201,199 inbound -- sailed between the two sides in 2004, a more-than 1.5-fold growth compared to the 2003 level of 160,103.

In 2002, a total of 53,681 travelers made voyages via the links, up from 21,377 in 2001, when the "three mini links" were initiated on the first of that year to compensate for the lack of such links between Taiwan proper and the mainland due to political rifts between the two sides.
Bureau officials on Kinmen attributed the increase to various government policy openings that have allowed a broader range of people to travel via the links.

The establishment of the links were first aimed at facilitating homebound trips for Taiwan businessmen based in Fujian, and the links were made available to other Taiwan businessmen operating farther afield than Fujian since March last year, they explained

The links were also opened to Taiwan residents with household registration on Kinmen of over six months and to family members of retired serviceman and Taiwan citizens' spouses from Fujian, they said, adding that more than 70 percent of the "mini links" passengers are Taiwan businessmen.

The Fujian authorities' decision late last month to permit Fujian residents to travel to Kinmen and Matsu islands via the links for tourism provided a fresh boost to the links, with shippers highly optimistic about a marked jump in traveler numbers and planning to increase two-way voyages from the current eight per day to 12, according to the officials.

Political relations between Taiwan and mainland China remain deadlocked since 1949, when the Kuomintang retreated to Taiwan after losing a civil war to the Chinese communists in the mainland. Contacts between the governments on the two sides of the Taiwan Strait have been absent until now.

DOC.HEADLINE: NATIONAL, POLITICAL LEADERS MOURN SEF CHAIRMAN'S DEATH

TEXT.P: Taiwan national and political leaders extended their condolences Monday upon the death of Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) Chairman Koo Chen-fu.
Koo died of renal failure at the Cheng Hsin Rehabilitation Hospital in Taipei earlier in the day. He would have been 88 on Jan. 6.

President Chen Shui-bian and Vice President Annette Lu expressed shock and deepest mourning, describing his death as a great loss for the country, according to a statement released by the Presidential Office.
Koo was a learned man who witnessed the reforms, development and progress of Taiwan for more than half a century and played a key role in Taiwan's economic development, the statement said.

He also attended major diplomatic events overseas on behalf of the head of state to help the country promote its foreign affairs, and committed himself to promoting cross-Taiwan Strait peace, stability and development, it added.
Chen later visited a mourning hall set up for Koo in the Taiwan Cement Corp. building in Taipei to pay his last respects.
Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng said he regrets the loss of a great contributor to cross-strait relations.
Praising Koo as a gentle, learned and generous man, opposition Kuomintang Chairman Lien Chan said Koo's status in cross-strait relations is irreplaceable.
Opposition People First Party Chairman James Soong, who is on a visit overseas, expressed through his aides his deepest mourning and sadness on hearing of Koo's death.

Soong said Koo should get much of the credit for the success of the landmark talks between him and his mainland Chinese counterpart, Wang Daohan of the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait, in Singapore in 1993.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER TIGHTLIPPED ON CABINET RESHUFFLE

TEXT.P: Premier Yu Shyi-kun said Monday that a date for the resignation of the entire Cabinet has yet to be determined.
Yu was responding to media reports that the planned Cabinet reshuffle will come ahead of schedule because of President Chen Shui-bian's overseas travel plans.

According the reports, Chen is scheduled to leave Taipei Jan. 28 for official visits to the Republic of China's diplomatic allies in the South Pacific, including Palau, the Marshall Islands and the Solomon Islands. As the visit will last for 12 days, the reports said Chen will not return until to Taipei until Chinese Lunar New Year's Eve Feb. 8
Yu said he is still not aware of the president's travel plans but he reiterated that he and his Cabinet will resign after the current legislative session concludes Jan. 21.
As for the exact date, Yu said, the Central Personnel Administration is still mulling the issue and has yet to make a final decision.

In the past, Cabinet members have usually tendered their resignations en masse at one of the Cabinet's weekly meetings. The last weekly Cabinet meeting before the inauguration of the new Legislative Yuan Feb. 1 is scheduled for Jan. 26. Cabinet sources said the Cabinet is also likely to call a provisional meeting in advance to facilitate its resignation.

Asked about his views on widespread speculation that Kaohsiung Mayor Frank Hsieh is likely to succeed Yu as premier, Yu said Hsieh is erudite, competent and experienced enough to assume any government post.

"I would congratulate him no matter which post he is assigned to but I'm not in a position to make any comment on the choice of a new premier because the power to appoint the premier rests with the president," Yu added.

In the southern port city of Kaohsiung, Hsieh said that to the best of his understanding, Chen has so far not made a definite choice. He added that Chen is expected to determine who the next premier will be before Feb. 1.
Hsieh canceled his originally scheduled meeting with the Kaohsiung and Pingtung county magistrates that morning and instead flew to Taipei to attend a high-level meeting presided over by Chen.

Hsieh said the meeting focused on Taiwan's future political developments. As reporters repeatedly asked Hsieh about the possibility of him serving as the next premier, Hsieh finally said many variables could affect the choice of premier at the moment. "To talk about such a sensitive issue would only enhance embarrassment, " he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: NUMBER OF MENTAL INSTITUTIONS INCREASES TO 339: DGBAS

TEXT.P: The number of mental institutions in Taiwan had increased to 339 as of the end of September 2004, up 45 from the year-earlier level, according to a report released Monday by the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS).

The government has continued to funnel national resources and offer incentives to encourage the private sector to expand mental hospital wards in order to upgrade the medical facilities for mental patients, the report said.
There were a total of 27,000 hospital beds for mental patients as of the end of September 2004, up 7.5 percent over the same period of 2003, it said.
The number of mental health workers had also increased 4.1 percent to 7,223 people as of the end of September 2004, which included 6,555 full-time workers and 668 part-time workers, it added.

DOC.HEADLINE: EXECUTIVE YUAN SPOKESMAN LAUDS LATE SEF CHIEF AS NATIONAL ASSET

TEXT.P: Koo Cheng-fu, the chairman of the Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) who died Monday, was a valuable asset for the country and his death is an irreplaceable loss for the Taiwan people, Executive Yuan spokesman Chen Chi-mai said Monday.

Chen Chi-mai said business tycoon Koo, who had headed the SEF in its dealings with Beijing on behalf of the government since 1990, was still worrying about the tension between Taiwan and mainland China even in his final days of a long illness, which Chen said is especially admirable.
He lauded Koo for leading Taiwan's historic ice-breaking journey to Singapore in April, 1993 to meet with Beijing's chief negotiator with Taiwan, Wang Daohan and concluded four agreements with him.
Chen said that trip ended half-a-century of severance of all contacts between Taiwan and the mainland and opened a new page in bilateral ties.
Koo visited the mainland in October 1998 and met with Beijing's then-President Jiang Zemin, as well as Wang, improving the ties between Taiwan and the mainland, Chen said.

In addition to being a successful businessman, Koo also served as head of the Chinese National Federation of Industries and of the Chinese National Association of Industry & Commerce, and contributed greatly to the country's economic development, Chen went on.
He also acted as the country's envoy to the informal summit of the Asia Pacific Economic Cooperation forum from 1995 to 1997.
Koo died of renal failure in a local hospital at the age of 88, according to his family.

DOC.HEADLINE: REFORM PROGRAM AIMED AT GLOBALIZATION, NOT DE-SINICIZATION: PREMIER

TEXT.P: Premier Yu Shyi-kun said Monday that the government's decision to reform the format of official documents is aimed at facilitating globalization, not at de-sinicization.
Yu made the remarks while presiding over a ceremony marking the launch of a new style of official documents and government gazettes.

From now on, Yu said, text in official documents will run from left to right horizontally instead of the traditional style in which the Chinese characters run from right to left and from top to bottom.
He noted that the new format complies with the general world trend and said the move has nothing to do with de-sinicization.

Whether official documents should adopt the horizontal style caused heated debate more than three decades ago. At that time, Yu said, the then-Kuomintang administration decided to stick to the traditional vertical right-to-left style mainly because mainland China had adopted the horizontal left-to-right text style.

Nowadays, Yu went on, such an argument is no longer justifiable. In the face of ever-growing global competition, he said, the government has to implement various reform programs to upgrade operational efficiency and overall national competitiveness.

Starting this year, all government notices have also been integrated and posted on the Internet for local citizens to collect first-hand information about government policies regardless of whether they are at home or abroad.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT DOES NOT TOUCH ON CABINET LINEUP IN HIGH-LEVEL MEETING

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian held a meeting with high-level officials Monday to exchange views with them on some points in his New Year's message, but did not talk about the lineup of the new Cabinet, a Presidential Office spokesman said later that day.

Chen Wen-tzung, director of the Department of Public Affairs under the Presidential Office, made the remarks after the president met with Vice President Annette Lu, Premier Yu Shyi-kun, Presidential Office Secretary-General Su Tseng-chang, Kaohsiung Mayor Frank Hsieh, ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Secretary-General Chang Chun-hsiung and DPP caucus whip Ker Chien-ming at the Presidential Office.
Yu is expected to lead his Cabinet to resign before the current legislature ends Jan. 21. According to the Constitution, the president will appoint a premier and a new Cabinet will then be formed.

The spokesman said that the president exchanged views with the officials on how to promote cooperation and coordination between the ruling and the opposition parties on policies and bills that the public are concerned about, a topic he raised in his New Year's address.

The spokesman stressed that the meeting also discussed how to carry out the "four ifs" in his New Year's address. The president said Jan. 1 that if something benefits the stability of domestic politics, the welfare of the people, harmony among ethnic groups, and cross-strait peace, it can be open to reconciliation or cooperation between the governing and opposition parties.

Since the meeting, the president has begun to think about how to engage in dialogue between political leaders and how to learn from the experience of cooperation between political parties, with the hope of promoting cooperation with the opposition and stabilizing the domestic political situation, the spokesman added.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER PRESIDENT PERSUADES HOPEFUL TO DROP OUT OF TSU CHAIRMAN RACE

TEXT.P: Lee Teng-hui, former president and so-called "spiritual leader" of the opposition Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) , has persuaded an aspirant for the TSU chairmanship to drop out of the by-election race, acting TSU Chairman Huang Tzung-yuan said Monday.

Huang made the remarks after meeting with the former president to report to him that three hopefuls -- Su Chin-chiang, secretary-general of the National Cultural Association, TSU Legislator Lo Chih-ming and at-large Legislator Kuo Lin-yung -- had registered to vie for the party chairmanship.

The by-election became necessary after Huang Chu-wen stepped down to take responsibility for the party's worse-than-expected performance in the Dec. 11 legislative elections. The TSU garnered only 12 out of the 225 legislative seats, one less than it got in the previous elections.

The TSU had originally planned to hold a drawing for the three aspirants Monday, but the party's central executive committee formed a seven-member screening team that day and decided to hold a meeting Friday. The draw will have to wait for the result of the screening next Monday.

TSU Acting Secretary-General Chen Chien-ming said the party will communicate with the three hopefuls individually, hoping that there will be mutual respect and harmony during the process, although it is still hoped that there will be only one candidate.
Huang noted that Lee had called Lo to ask him to withdraw from the race, saying that he should support Su in consideration of party unity.
As for Kuo, since he was nominated by the former party chairman, the latter should resolve that question, Huang said.
He stressed that those who won the Dec. 11 legislative elections know very well that they were elected because of the full support of the former president.
"Since Lee is in favor of Su's taking over the chairmanship, the legislators should accept his choice," he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN MEDICAL TEAM TO WITHDRAW FROM INDONESIA OVER SAFETY FEARS
DOC.DATELINE: Singapore, Jan. 3 (CNA) (By Charles Kang and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: A medical team dispatched by Taiwan to Indonesia in the aftermath of the Dec. 26 tsunami disaster has decided to pull out because of Jakarta's failure to guarantee the safety of the team members, sources said Monday.

While most of the team members have been ordered by Taipei to leave Indonesia, a few will stay until 1.5 tonnes of medical supplies arrive and handed over to the Taiwan-based Tzu Chi Foundation charity group in Indonesia, the sources said.
The date of the pullout will be known Tuesday at the earliest after the team contacts the foundation, they said.

Although Taiwan is most willing to provide Indonesia with medical services and help with the prevention of outbreaks of infectious diseases, Taipei has to made the decision to bring its people out as the Indonesian government cannot assure the physical safety of Taiwan medical workers posted in Aceh Province -- the worst-hit area -- and cannot offer them protection from attack by rebels, they said.

According to some team members, the Tzu Chi Foundation is currently the only organization with the ability to coordinate with the Indonesian military to transport relief supplies to the disaster areas in Aceh.

Experts from Taiwan's Center for Disease Control said diseases such as typhoid, dysentery, cholera, malaria and dengue fever could break out at any time in light of the bad sanitary conditions in Aceh after the disaster.
More than 90,000 people in Indonesia, mostly in Aceh, have been confirmed killed by the tsunami that were triggered by a 9.0-magnitude earthquake off the west coast of Sumatra Dec. 26.
The Taiwan medical team arrived in Indonesia last Thursday.

DOC.HEADLINE: PROPER POLICY NEEDED TO BREAK CROSS-STRAIT DEADLOCK: LEGISLATIVE HEAD

TEXT.P: An adequate policy must be crafted to improve deadlocked ties between Taiwan and mainland China, an issue more important than the question of who might serve as the key negotiator, Legislative Yuan President Wang Jin-pyng said Monday.

Claiming that a well forged policy is much more important then the person chosen to deal with Taiwan's sensitive relations with the mainland, Wang said that it would be all the same regardless of who might head the Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) if Taiwan lacks an adequate policy to create a favorable climate for reopening negotiations with the other side of the Taiwan Strait.

Should it be possible to commission a legislative task force to hold talks with the mainland, the ad hoc group, no matter who leads it, must be capable of serving the country's needs, gaining the people's consent, acquiring the legislature's approval and conducting negotiations with the mainland on an equal footing, he said.
According to Wang, the Legislative Yuan is in a more flexible position to engage with the mainland than the executive branch.

If a cross-strait peace draft proposed by the opposition People First Party (PFP) clears the legislature and a task force is set up, it will provide the Legislative Yuan with a legal framework to carry out bilateral exchanges and there will be ample room for such a legislative team to play a prominent role in cross-strait relations, he added.
Wang made the remarks in a meeting with local reporters after SEF Chairman C.F. Koo, Taiwan's chief negotiator with mainland China, died of renal cancer earlier the same day.

The semi-official SEF was set up in 1991 to handle cross-strait exchanges in the absence of contacts between the governments on the two sides. Headed by Wang Daohan, the Beijing-based Association of Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS) is its mainland counterpart.
Commenting on the options for the SEF chairmanship, he said that opposition People First Party (PFP) Chairman James Soong would be the right person as long as Soong himself is willing.

Like the ruling party, the opposition camp also has a responsibility to help the administration stabilize the cross-strait situation that has turned sour in recent months, he said, adding that most of the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) members would also be happy to see Soong take over the SEF chairmanship.

Wang is one of the six vice chairmen of the KMT. The "pan blue" alliance of the KMT and the PFP have succeeded in retaining a majority at the 225-member Legislative Yuan after the Dec. 11 general elections.

Meanwhile, the ARATS sent a message to the SEF to express its condolences over Koo's death. It also called for an early resumption of the systematic negotiations between the two sides based upon the consensus reached in 1992.
Koo and Wang met for the first time in 1993 in Singapore, marking the first contact between Taiwan and mainland China in nearly 50 years after the two sides split in 1949 following a civil war.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TO SEND TEAM TO PHUKET TO HELP WITH EPIDEMIC-PREVENTION WORK

TEXT.P: The Department of Health (DOH) will send a 17-member team to the Thai island of Phuket Tuesday to help with epidemic-prevention work there over the next three months.

The DOH noted that one week after lethal tsunami triggered by a magnitude-9.0 earthquake hit Phuket Dec. 26, the need for urgent medical care is no longer there but the specter of an epidemic outbreak is emerging.
The team, comprised of epidemic prevention experts and medical personnel, will bring with them 1.5 tons of health and hygiene equipment and medicine, with the focus on public health.
The DOH said that in the next three months, they will continue to send personnel to Phuket who will work there on a rotational basis.
The DOH earlier sent a 13-member delegation to Banda Aceh, capital of Aceh Province on the Indonesian island of Sumatra, which was worst-hit by the earthquake and the ensuing tsunami.
Two members of the team will return to Taiwan Tuesday and the remaining 11 members will assess whether to return too or transfer to other areas hard-hit by the worst natural disaster in a century.

DOC.HEADLINE: SENIOR SINGAPOREAN OFFICIALS MOURN SEF CHAIRMAN'S DEATH

TEXT.P: Two former Singaporean prime ministers -- Lee Kuan Yew and Goh Chok Tong -- have sent condolence letters to the family of Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) Chairman Koo Chen-fu, who died of renal failure early Monday at the age of 88.
In a condolence letter to Koo's wife, Lee, who is now minister mentor of Singapore, praised Koo for his "balanced and realistic appraisal" of the cross-Taiwan Strait situation.
Lee further said Koo played a valuable role in helping to stabilize cross-strait relations.

As Taiwan's top negotiator with mainland China, Koo held a landmark meeting with his mainland counterpart, Wang Daohan, president of the Beijing-based Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS), in Singapore in April 1993, marking the first high-level cross-strait rendezvous since 1949.
Goh, who is now Singapore's senior minister, said in his condolence letter to Koo's wife that he was deeply saddened to learn of Koo's passing.

He recalled that he got to know Koo through various meetings of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum. Known for his diplomatic acumen, Koo attended the annual APEC summit meeting on behalf of former ROC President Lee Teng-hui on three occasions.

"We used to sit next to one another I know him to be upright, sincere and thoughtful gentleman who cared for his friends. I also know he cared deeply about cross-strait peace and stability," Goh said in the letter.

Goh said Koo will be remembered for his contributions. For many years, he said, Koo played a significant role in bringing both sides of the Taiwan Strait together. "Unfortunately, circumstances did not allow him to do more," Goh added.
Koo died at Taipei's Cheng Hsin Medical Center, where he had been treated since October for complications from kidney cancer, doctors at the hospital said.

In 1991, Koo became SEF chairman when the quasi-official organization was set up to handle Taiwan's prickly relations with Beijing. He also led a proud and prosperous extended business family, the Koo's Group, which includes banking, cement, petrochemicals and television.

Besides the 1993 Koo-Wang meeting in Singapore, Koo also made an ice-breaking visit to Shanghai and Beijing in 1998. During that trip, he met with then-mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin and then-Vice Premier Qian Qichen.
Since that trip, long-standing political squabbles over Taiwan's status have blocked follow-up cross-strait discussions.

Koo was well versed in Chinese poetry, literature and arts. Although he suffered from kidney problems and other ailments, the diplomat, banker and industrialist kept his job as Taiwan's top negotiator with the mainland even after Chen Shui-bian, a former opposition leader, was elected president in 2000.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT TO HELP ARRANGE CROSS-TAIWAN STRAIT CHARTER SERVICE

TEXT.P: The main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) will send a delegation to mainland China this week to help the private sector arrange direct charter flights across the Taiwan Strait for mainland-based Taiwan businessmen wishing to spend the coming lunar new year holiday at home, a KMT official said Monday.

Tseng Yung-chuan, executive-general of the KMT's Central Policy Committee, made the remarks after learning that the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) has authorized the Taipei Airlines Association (TTA) to hold technical talks with the mainland to pave the way for cross-strait charter services for homecoming Taiwan businessmen during the holiday period.

The MAC move came after a Beijing official said earlier the same day that the mainland is willing to cooperate on the issue under the condition that the round-trip flights be conducted by carriers from both sides without a stop in a third country or area. MAC Vice Chairman Chiu Tai-san responded that Taiwan would be happy to talk with the mainland under that condition.

The charter service plan would very possibly fail if the government were to insist that negotiations must be government-level, Tseng warned, adding that it must be held accountable should that happen.

Meanwhile, Taiwan carriers displayed their willingness to provide the services in line with government policy and pointed out that non-stop two-way flights will help reduce costs and that they will file their applications to offer the services as soon as related details are worked out.

However, they also expressed worry that it is already too late to start arranging the special flights, as many Taiwan businessmen and their families have already bought tickets for their new year homecoming at the beginning of February.

DOC.HEADLINE: INT'L CONFERENCES ON AID TO SOUTH ASIA SHOULD INCLUDE TAIWAN: OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: A spokesman for the Ministry of Foreign Affairs urged the international community Monday not to exclude Taiwan from any international conferences organized to coordinate relief efforts in South Asia in the wake of the Dec. 26 earthquake and subsequent tsunami.

Michel Lu said Taiwan has promised to provide considerable aid to countries ravaged by the 9.0-magnitude earthquake in Indonesia and the ensuing tsunami and thereby should not be excluded from any international relief conferences for political reasons.
He made the remarks after wire services reported that a relief meeting sponsored by the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) will be held Thursday in Jakarta.

In addition to ASEAN leaders, the conference will also bring together leaders from Japan, Australia and mainland China, as well as U.N. Secretary-General Kofi Annan and U.S. Secretary of State Colin Powell.
The U.N. will hold another meeting in Geneva Jan. 11 of countries that have donated money and provided relief to the disaster areas.
Lu said Taiwan has not yet been invited to either of the two meetings but was trying to get the chances to take part in them through its overseas representative offices.

The Executive Yuan decided the previous day to raise its donation from its original promise of US$5 million to US$50 million. Vice Foreign Minister Michael Ying-mao Kau said that figure would put Taiwan among the top-10 donors and would considerably enhance the country's international profile.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT DECIDES TO ENGAGE IN DIALOGUE WITH OTHER PARTIES VIA DPP

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian has decided to start dialogue with other political parties through the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) , DPP acting Chairman Chen Chien-ming said Monday.

Chen said the president huddled with top officials from his administration and the ruling DPP in his office to study the way to follow through his promises of replacing confrontation between the DPP and the opposition parties with dialogue and reconciliation in his second term.
The consensus that emerged from the meeting is that the dialogue should be conducted regularly by the DPP with the opposition, Chen Chien-ming said.
The Taiwan Solidarity Union, the DPP's political ally in the Legislature Yuan, welcomed the decision and said they will support the president's idea.

Meanwhile, Chang Hsien-yao, an official from the opposition People First Party, said his party believes party-to-party dialogue is the right way for democracy but it seemed that the president hasn't yet come up with any concrete plan to carry out the promises he made in his New Year address thus far, except for empty words.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. EXPRESSES CONDOLENCES ON SEF CHAIRMAN'S DEATH
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Jan. 3 (CNA) (By Oliver Lin and P.C.Tang)

TEXT.P: The U.S. State Department on Monday expressed its condolences on the death of Koo Chen-fu, chairman of the quasi-official Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF).
Koo, 87, a business tycoon who acted as Taiwan's chief negotiator with mainland China, died of renal cancer at Cheng Hsin Rehabilitation Hospital in Taipei the same day.
Commenting on Koo's death in response to media questions raised at a daily briefing, the State Department said: "We extend our sympathies to Koo's family and the people of Taiwan."

Pointing out that Koo was a respected business person and a generous philanthropist, the department further said that as a strong advocate for cross-Taiwan Strait dialogue and reconciliation, he was respected in mainland China, Taiwan and internationally.

"Mr. Koo's distinguished record as the Chairman of Taiwan's Straits Exchange Foundation and his role in the historic talks with former mayor of Shanghai Wang Daohan on cross-Strait issues are part of a legacy for promoting peace and stability in that area of the world," the department said.

1877: Cornelius Vanderbilt, U.S. transportation promoter and financier who amassed a great fortune through railroad and shipping interests, dies in New York at the age of 83, leaving a fortune estimated at US$100 million.
1896: Utah becomes the 45th state of the United States.
1917: Tsai Yuan-pei assumes his post as president of National Peking University.
