Confucius' lesson of the day: "When a man has learned wisdom in the morning, he may be content to die in the evening before the sun sets."

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. REP. CONCERN OVER STATE DEPT. REACTION TO 'ANTI-SECESSION LAW'
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Jan. 3 (CNA) (By Oliver Lin and P. C. Tang)

TEXT.P: A member of the U.S. House of Representatives has sent a letter to a senior official of the State Department to express his concern over the department's weak reaction to mainland China's proposed anti-secession law that might lead to a unilateral change of the status quo in the Taiwan Strait.

Rep. Tom Tancredo (R-Colorado) , who sent the letter Dec. 23 to Paul Kelly, assistant secretary for legislative affairs, has been the first U.S. congressman to openly voice his strong opposition to the "anti-secession law" that mainland China hopes to enact.

Expressing his concern over the State Department's failure to adequately condemn Beijing for threatening to unilaterally change the status quo by possibly enacting such a law, Tancredo said in his letter: "Despite Beijing's assertions that the law is designed to foster "peaceful reunification, " I believe it is clear to even the most casual observer that this move is little more than a thinly veiled attempt by Beijing to create a 'legal framework' for starting a war with Taiwan."

Noting that Beijing's efforts to enact such a law is "a clear-cut, belligerent, provocative and dangerous step toward a military attack of a peaceful and democratic ally of the United States," the representative said with great regret that the strongest and most direct rebuke to Beijing that Richard Boucher, spokesmen of the department, could muster in response to the move was that "...we think it's important for both sides to focus on dialogue."

"I wonder, would the State Department response have been as timid were the shoe on the other foot with the Legislative Yuan in Taipei debating the enactment an 'anti-annexation' law," he further said.
Tancredo also said that he would like to know what Beijing must do in order to draw the kind of strong public rebuke the state department has grown accustomed to delivering to Taipei.

"Beijing's routine and public threats to use military force against Taiwan clearly haven't drawn such a rebuke, neither has the PRC's deployment of 600 missiles pointed directly at Taiwan's 23 million residents. "
"Is it that Mr. Boucher, Mr. Ereli [Adam Ereli, State Department deputy spokesman] and others are waiting for the PRC to actually attack Taiwan before they issue a stern warning," Tancredo asked.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CHEN TO VISIT SOUTH PACIFIC ALLIES: FOREIGN MINISTER

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian will visit the Republic of China's diplomatic allies in the South Pacific later this month if all goes smoothly, Minister of Foreign Affairs Tan Sun Chen said Tuesday.
According to media reports, President Chen is scheduled to leave Taipei Jan. 28 to attend the new Palau president's inauguration and visit the ROC's other allies in the region.
The foreign minister said President Chen's itinerary has yet to be finalized.

"We are still negotiating technical details with relevant authorities and President Chen's travel schedule has yet to be set, " the minister said, adding that if all goes well, the president is likely to start his South Pacific journey in late January.
It will be President Chen's first trip to the South Pacific since he assumed the presidency in May 2000.
The ROC has five diplomatic allies in the South Pacific, namely: Palau, the Solomon Islands, the Marshall Islands, Kiribati and Tuvalu.
Asked if President Chen would visit all of the five South Pacific allies, the foreign minister said: "Of course, if it is feasible."

Some technical issues must be evaluated and resolved before the president's travel itinerary can be drawn up, Minister Chen said, adding that airport facilities in some countries may not be suitable for landing and takeoff of large commercial aircraft.

Chen Wen-tzung, director of the Department of Public Affairs of the Presidential Office, said a day earlier that a team from the Presidential Office has traveled to the countries in the South Pacific to pave the way for the president's visit. The president's travel schedule will be announced after all preparations are complete, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT: Los Angeles Times: Navy Airlifts Supplies to Ravaged Coast. Hilicopers from USS Abraham Lincoln flew repeated relief missions along the nearby shoreline of Indonesia, delivering food, water and medical supplies to thousands of survivors stranded along the west coast of Aceh province after last week's devastating tsunami.

DOC.HEADLINE: 'PARTY-TO-PARTY CONSULTATIONS BETTER THAN NOTHING': WANG JIN-PYNG

TEXT.P: Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng said Tuesday that party-to-party consultation will definitely contribute to political stability.

Wang, who concurrently serves as a Kuomintang (KMT) vice chairman, was referring to an olive branch for party reconciliation offered by President Chen Shui-bian in his new year's address for the sake of political stability.
After the Dec. 11 legislative elections, the opposition "pan-blue alliance" of the KMT and the People First Party (PFP) maintained a majority in the 225-seat Legislative Yuan.
"Party-to-party consultations are better than nothing, " Wang said.
However, he also said that whether the atmosphere for holding such talks can be created will hinge on if the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) is sincere.
The DPP legislative caucus offered Tuesday to cooperate with all other political parties, but the opposition "pan-blue alliance" quickly dismissed it as an attempt to split the alliance.
Ker Chien-ming, acting DPP chairman and party whip in the legislature, said that the DPP can discuss issues with any party, including such topics as specific governmental appointments.

Ker said that for the sake of political stability, the DPP will not only consult with the PFP, it will also consult with the KMT, the Taiwan Solidarity Union and even the Non-Partisan Solidarity Union because party-to-party consultations as envisaged by President Chen are just beginning to take shape.

On the KMT's part, Huang Teh-fu, KMT caucus whip in the legislature, said that President Chen shouldn't dictate to the party and the administration, saying that there already exists a consultation mechanism in the legislature and there is no need to establish another channel.

PFP Legislator Liu Wen-hsiung said that cooperation between the ruling and opposition parties will depend on which policies and issues are at stake, and that there is no specific need for party-to-party consultations.
If the DPP is unwilling to give up Taiwan independence in its party charter, then it is out of the question for the PFP to be a part of a DPP coalition Cabinet, Liu said.

He was referring to media reports that high-ranking officials in the Presidential Office will let someone from the PFP serve as vice premier to display the DPP's sincerity in seeking reconciliation between the ruling and the opposition parties.

Liu urged the DPP to refrain from making frivolous remarks, referring to reports Monday that at least one DPP official had recommended PFP Chairman James Soong as being a suitable candidate to take over as chairman of the quasi-official Straits Exchange Foundation. The previous head of the organization that deals with mainland China affairs died Monday.
Liu said that Soong told him that he had dismissed the idea as "pure nonsense."

DOC.HEADLINE: KOO-WANG TALKS CREATED VISION OF CROSS-STRAIT PEACE: VP LU

TEXT.P: The landmark talks between Taipei and Beijing led by the late Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) Chairman Koo Chen-fu and his Beijing counterpart, Wang Daohan, in 1993 gave birth to a "vision of peace" across the Taiwan Strait, Vice President Annette Lu said Tuesday.
Lu said the vision, which has yet to become a reality, will depend on a new generation of leadership on both sides of the Strait to come up with a new way of thinking.
The vice president made the comments while paying her last respects to Koo, who died of renal failure a day earlier, three days before his 88th birthday.

Saying the historic Koo-Wang talks were one of the most remarkable achievements Koo made during his lifetime, Lu expressed the hope that cross-strait peace can be achieved under the leadership of President Chen Shui-bian.
Meanwhile, former SEF Vice Chairman and Secretary-General Chiao Jen-ho said the Koo family is planning to hold a memorial service for Koo in late January or early February.
Chiao said the date for his funeral has yet to be decided and that the family hopes to have a simple ceremony.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT HOLDS CLOSED-DOOR MEETING WITH LEE TENG-HUI

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian spoke privately for over two hours with former President Lee Teng-hui at the Presidential Office Tuesday in their first meeting following Lee's return from his recent sightseeing trip to Japan.
Su Tseng-chang, the president's chief of staff, said Chen invited Lee to the Presidential Office. Su said Lee also ate lunch with the president.

However, Su would not divulge any details about what was said during the meeting. Su was speaking at the headquarters of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) during a weekly meeting of senior party officials.
Presidential Office sources said Chen and Lee exchanged views on the domestic political situation and Lee's just-concluded visit to Japan.
Some have speculated that the upcoming Cabinet reshuffle was touched upon by the two.

In line with constitutional precedent, Premier Yu Shyi-kun and all Cabinet members are expected to resign en masse after the current Legislative Yuan concludes its final session on Jan. 21. Rumors have circulated for the last couple of weeks about the possibility of Chen naming a new premier and forming a coalition Cabinet with opposition parties. Senior government officials, including Yu himself, have been tightlipped about the imminent Cabinet reshuffle.
It remains unclear whether Lee, who is the spiritual leader of the Taiwan Solidarity Union -- a DPP ally - has made recommendations regarding the makeup of the new Cabinet.

Upon his return from Japan Sunday, Lee told a large crowd of supporters who turned up at Chiang Kai-shek International Airport to greet him that his Japan visit, in spite of Beijing's opposition, shows that relations between Taipei and Tokyo are close.

Despite Beijing's opposition, Lee said most Japanese people welcomed his visit. Noting that Taiwan-Japanese relations have been advancing quietly, Lee said bilateral ties are now in the best shape since the two countries severed formal diplomatic relations in 1972.

Prior to his departure for home, Lee told Japanese reporters that his trip could be viewed as successful. "I was able to serve as a quiet yet firm link between both sides, " he said while thanking the Japanese government and people for their warmth and hospitality.

During his seven-day visit, Lee, 81, met with 98-year-old Sukekata Kashiwa, who was Lee's professor when Lee studied at the agroeconomics department of Kyoto University in the early 1940s. Taiwan was then a Japanese colony.

However, Lee was denied entry to Kyoto University last Friday. He was turned away at the door because Beijing authorities pressured the Japanese government and Kyoto University not to allow Lee to visit his alma mater.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI SHARE PRICES END LOWER

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange opened low and closed lower Tuesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving down 82.66 points to close at 6,060.46.
The bourse opened at 6,117.87 and fluctuated between 6,129.38 and 6,053.18 during trading. A total of 3.21 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$58.34 billion (US$2.59 billion).

The Times: British death toll soars as Thais call off search.
The number of Britons feared killed by the Asian tsunami finally emerged last night as the Government disclosed that 199 people, including about 25 children, were probably dead.
Most British victims of the enormous wave that crashed into beach resorts nine days ago died in Thailand.
But any lingering hopes of the bodies of those still missing there being recovered were dashed last night when the authorities announced that they were calling off the search for those unaccounted for.
Financial Times: Aid groups given freer hand to help Aceh tsunami victims.
The Indonesian government is handing more responsibility to international aid groups in the tsunami-stricken province of Aceh, in a bid to speed the delivery of relief, food and medicine.
The move is a big step forward for a country that has long been wary of aid groups in Aceh and is one of the first political repercussions from the disaster. The province has been kept largely shut to the outside world and is the scene of an 18-month-old military campaign against separatist rebels that has attracted criticism from human-rights groups.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOST TAIWAN WOMEN UNAWARE THAT LUNG CANCER IS TOP KILLER OF WOMEN

TEXT.P: Most women in Taiwan are unaware that lung cancer is the disease that kills the most women in the country each year, a survey found Tuesday.
The survey was recently conducted by the Formosa Cancer Foundation and a food company on 1,067 Taiwan women aged 25 to 65.

The survey showed that 80 percent of Taiwan women are not aware that lung cancer is the No. 1 killer, 59 percent did not know what early symptoms to look for and 48 percent had no idea how the disease could be prevented.

Lai Kee-ming, executive director of the foundation, said that every day, six women in Taiwan die from lung cancer; moreover, many women who don't smoke and who lead a normal life have suddenly found themselves in the terminal stage of lung cancer.
The rate of surviving for five years after being diagnosed with lung cancer is less than 15 percent, he said.

Lai pointed out that half of lung cancer cases have no definite cause, leading many researcher to believe that the disease may be genetically influenced. However, around 40 percent are affected by second-hand smoke, and only 10 percent are smokers themselves.

Lai said that Taiwan women exposed to second-hand smoke will increase their odds of contracting lung cancer five fold. The survey also found that nearly half of Taiwan women live with members of their family who smoke. Two out of every three Taiwan women don't know the hazard posed by exposure to second-hand smoke.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEARLY 90% OF ENTERPRISES TO GIVE YEAR-END BONUSES: SURVEY

TEXT.P: Nearly 90 percent of enterprises said in a survey released Tuesday that they will give out year-end bonuses, but only 65 percent of employees said they expect to receive one.
The survey was conducted by an online human resources company Dec. 23-27, collecting 1,139 effective samples and having a margin of error of 3 percent.
The survey showed that 88.6 percent of the enterprises said they will give out year-end bonus before Chinese Lunar New Year, which falls on Feb. 9, compared with only 6.7 percent who said they won't.
The figures were a drastic contrast to the 29.8 percent of the employees who said they don't expect a bonus, and 64.4 percent who said they are expecting the extra money.
Not only that, enterprises expected to give an average of 1.51-month bonus, compared with only 1.21-month bonus expected by employees, the survey also showed.
Analysts said that employees have become more conservative after four consecutive years of an economic slump, and they tend to lower their expectations for year-end bonuses.

The survey found that year-end bonuses for all sectors averaged 1.51 months in 2004, up 0.08 months from the previous year. Those who are in the financial and securities sector will receive the most in year-end bonuses, averaging 2.19 months, followed by those in the trading or traditional manufacturing sectors at 1.65 months, and those in the construction and real-estate and information technology sectors at 1.48 months.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN-PRODUCED HEAD LETTUCE MAKING INROADS IN JAPAN

TEXT.P: Total head lettuce exports to Japan in 2005 are estimated to earn net profits of about NT$40 million (US$1.26 million), officials of the Council of Agriculture said Tuesday.
The officials said 770 tons of Taiwan-produced fresh head lettuce were exported to Japan last year and existing orders from Japanese businesses for the vegetable in 2005 has reached 3,500 tons.
In the past, Japan has imported most of its head lettuce from the United States and Australia.

The yearly harvest of lettuce from other countries is in April and November; however, since the growing season in Taiwan is staggered from November to March, there is space in the Japanese market for Taiwan lettuce.

Moreover, thanks to Taiwan's geographic position, head lettuce from the island enjoys a reputation of freshness and high quality in the neighboring market, the officials said, adding that the council will continue to assist local farmers to build an efficient production and transportation system to expand their exports.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC-HAITI TIES SOLID: ENVOY
DOC.DATELINE: Panama City, Jan. 4 (CNA) (By Ramon Huang and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Relations between the Republic of China and Haiti are solid, outgoing ROC Ambassador Hsieh Hsin-ping said Tuesday.

Hsieh, who is scheduled to return to Taipei to work at the Ministry of Foreign Affairs later this month, said now is a good time for Taiwan to change its ambassador to Haiti because bilateral relations are in good shape.

In a telephone interview with the Central News Agency, Hsieh said he has assured the Haiti government that the ROC will always be Haiti's best friend and will do its utmost to help the Caribbean country resolve problems and promote national development.

Hsieh's successor, Yang Cheng-ta, is scheduled to arrive in Haiti late this month to assume his new post. Hsieh said he believes that Taiwan-Haiti relations will be further expanded on the basis of current foundations after Yang assumes office.
Hsieh asked for a job transfer last May because he has been suffering from a skin allergy. After a half-year wait, the foreign ministry has finally agreed to his request.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN RESEARCHERS ISOLATE MULTIPOTENT CELLS FROM HUMAN PLACENTA

TEXT.P: A group of researchers in Taiwan announced Tuesday that they have successfully isolated a population of multipotent cells from human placenta, which could be a new source of stem cells other than embryonic stem cells and adult stem cells.
Adipose, bone and neuro cells were differentiated from the placenta-derived multipotent cells after culture, the researchers said.
The achievement was made by a team of researchers from the National Health Research Institute (NHRI), National Taiwan University Hospital and Cathay General Hospital.
A report on the achievement has been published in the latest issue of the Stem Cells journal and the team is applying for a patent for the technology.

According to Chen Yao-chang from the NHRI's Stem Cell Research Center, although the differentiation potential of placenta-derived multipotent cells is slightly lower than that of embryonic stem cells, it does not involve the ethical concerns surrounding embryonic stem cell research.
In addition, the placenta, which weighs 700 grams to 800 grams, is a high-yield source of stem cells compared with cord blood, which is only 80 grams to 90 grams in a newborn, Chen said.

Compared with bone marrow stem cells, placenta-derived multipotent cells carry a higher differentiation potential, and it does not involve an invasive procedure such as extracting bone marrow, Chen said.
Theoretically speaking, he said, the placenta-derived multipotent cells could be applied in the treatment of patients with neural damage or bone fracture.
However, the research is still premature and will only enter the human application stage in 10 years, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN GIVES ADDITIONAL US$30,000 TO MALAYSIA FOR TSUNAMI VICTIMS
DOC.DATELINE: Kuala Lumpur, Jan. 4 (CNA) (By Y.P. Chen and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's representative to Malaysia presented an additional US$30,000 to Malaysia Tuesday for relief of people in tsunami-affected areas.

Wu Wen-ya, director of the Taipei Economic and Cultural Office in Malaysia, said that Taiwan was hard hit by the devastating magnitude 7.6 earthquake of Sept. 21, 1999, and received assistance from Malaysia and other countries at that time.
The Taiwan government and people emphasize with those in South Asia who suffered tremendously in the tsunami triggered by a magnitude 9.0 earthquake in Indonesia's Sumatra Dec. 26, Wu said.
He said the US$30,000 is an expression of concern from Taiwan for the people in the affected areas.
The Taiwan government has already donated US$50 million for the relief of tsunami-affected areas in South and Southeast Asia.

DOC.HEADLINE: KAOHSIUNG TO SET UP 2009 WORLD GAMES FOUNDATION TO PROMOTE CITY

TEXT.P: The Kaohsiung city government is planning to establish a 2009 World Games foundation to help promote the city, officials of the southern Taiwan port city said Tuesday.

The officials said that since Kaohsiung won its bid to stage the World Games in 2009, the city government has been preparing for the games, hoping to enhance the profile of Taiwan and Kaohsiung through the sponsorship of the games.
The city government has commissioned commercial and city image ads and other brochures to advertise to the world that the games will be staged there.
The foundation is expected to be established Jan. 15 with initial funding of NT$5 million (US$156,250).

DOC.HEADLINE: SEF CHAIRMAN'S MEMORIAL SERVICE SET FOR FEB. 2

TEXT.P: A memorial service for Taiwan's top negotiator with mainland China, Koo Chen-fu, who died Monday, has been set for Feb. 2 at the National Dr. Sun Yat-sen Memorial Hall in Taipei, an official of the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council said Tuesday.

Chang Liang-jen, a spokesman for the funeral affairs of the late chairman of the semi-official Straits Exchange Foundation, noted that the Koo family will invite relatives and friends to take part in the ceremony.
Details of the ceremony have yet to be decided, Chang said.
Koo died of renal failure at Cheng Hsin Rehabilitation Hospital in suburban Taipei. He would have been 88 on Jan. 6.

DOC.HEADLINE: ECONOMISTS EXPECT TAIWAN CURRENCY, INTEREST RATES TO GO UP IN 2005

TEXT.P: Economists are of the general expectation that the Taiwan currency and interest rates will go on rising in 2005, citing the central bank's concern over a continued influx of foreign capital.

Hsu Chen-ming, a professor of economics at National Taiwan University, forecast that rate hikes by the Central Bank of China (CBC) will be unavoidable in 2005, mainly to maintain consumer product prices and the value of the new Taiwan dollar.

According to Hsu, the key rate increases by a quarter of a percentage point in September last year -- the first after 14 interest rate falls initiated by the CBC -- presaged the end of a low interest rate period.

The CBC again lifted interest rates by 0.125 percentage points late last month, pushing up its re-discount rate to 1.75 percent, its one-year short term rate to 4 percent and rates on accommodation with collateral to 2.125 percent.
A persistent inflow of foreign hot money will keep increasing inflationary pressure at home, despite the fact that a stronger local unit will help offset part of the pressure, he pointed out.

In a bid to recover the economy, the CBC had since the second half of 2003 adopted a low interest rate policy and had tried to keep the new Taiwan dollar at a relatively low value by buying into large amounts of foreign exchange, largely increasing its foreign reserves and making it able to release its reserve currencies into the market, resulting in continued drops in interest rates, he explained.
During the second half of 2003, inter-bank overnight interest rates were maintained at around 1 percent, with the ratio further declining to even lower levels in the first half of 2004, he noted.

In addition to watching economic changes in the domestic market, he said that the central bank has also had to pay heed to international factors, such as the monetary policy of the U.S. Federal Reserve (Fed)

Executives of Citibank, the Hongkong and Shanghai Banking Corporation and Standard Chartered Bank also contended that the Fed will go on with its gradual rate increase policy this year and next year and forecast that the CBC will follow suit but in a narrower range and at a slower pace.
The Fed raised its key interest rates five times last year, lifting key rates to an average of 2.25 percent.
National Chengchi University Chu Hau-ming said that the CBC will follow in the Fed's footsteps and pointed to the course of the U.S. dollar and mainland China's renminbi as additional key factors.

If the United States fails to improve its fiscal and trade deficits this year, the greenback is set to continue its current depreciation, prompting Asian currencies upward, bankers said, adding that the local unit will also continue to strengthen should the CBC decide not to interfere.
They predicted that the new Taiwan dollar will reach a value of 30.5 to the U.S. dollar in the first half of this year.

The local currency ended at 31.846 against the U.S. unit Tuesday in the Taipei foreign exchange market, losing a slight NT$0.001 to Monday's finish. It stood at 31.917 against the U.S. currency last Friday, underpinned by a rising Japanese yen.
The new Taiwan dollar gained by about 6 percent in value aginst the U. S. dollar over the past year.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN WORKING ON POSITION PAPER TO SEEK U.S. FTA SUPPORT

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) is working on a position paper to solicit wide support from the United States for a free trade agreement (FTA) between Taiwan and the United States.

The Bureau of Foreign Trade (BOFT) said the position paper will make the case that the signing of an FTA between Taiwan and the United States would be a win-win situation for both sides and that the U.S. would be able to make inroads into East Asia from Taiwan in view of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) plus mainland China, South Korea and Japan situation.

The BOFT will sponsor publicity campaigns in U.S. cities this year in the hope that Congress, the media, think tanks, and businesses there will understand the benefits of signing an FTA with Taiwan, and that the United States will consider an FTA with Taiwan as a priority.

Taiwan has in recent years been promoting the signing of FTAs with its allies, and signed one with Panama last year. It expects to complete others with Nicaragua and Guatemala by August this year, and FTA consultations on with Paraguay, the Dominican Republic and Honduras are also in progress.
BOFT Director-General Huang Chi-peng said Tuesday Taiwan is still eyeing the United States, New Zealand, Japan and Singapore for FTAs.

Huang noted that talks on a trade and investment framework agreement between Taiwan and the United States were resumed last year, and that Economic Affairs Minister Ho Mei-yueh conveyed Taiwan's wish to sign a FTA with the United States during a recent visit.
Although Taiwan has yet to obtain any promises from the United States, it will continue to work hard toward the goal, Huang said.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT, FORMER PRESIDENT MEET

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian invited former President Lee Teng-hui to a meeting at the Presidential Office Tuesday and the two huddled over lunch for nearly three hours, an aide to the president said Tuesday.

Chen Wen-tsung, director of the Department of Public Affairs under the Presidential Office, said Lee, who returned from a trip to Japan Monday, described his trip to Chen and exchanged views with him on Chen's promises to step up dialogue between the ruling and opposition parties.
Chen Wen-tsung said that the issue of the new Cabinet lineup was not raised during the discussion.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN LOOKS FORWARD TO ATTENDING TSUNAMI RELIEF SUMMIT AS OBSERVER

TEXT.P: Taiwan looks forward to attending an emergency meeting of world leaders to be held in Jakarta Thursday to discuss relief operations in the wake of a massive earthquake off Indonesia and subsequent tsunami, a senior official said Tuesday.
Minister of Foreign Affairs Tan Sun Chen said Taiwan should at least be allowed to attend the disaster relief summit as an observer.

Senior leaders of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) took the initiative to organize the meeting to coordinate relief efforts in coastal areas in Southeast and South Asia devastated by the magnitude-9.0 earthquake and subsequent tsunamis.

U.N. Secretary General Kofi Annan, U.S. Secretary of State Colin Powell and senior leaders from Japan, Australia and mainland China will attend the Jakarta summit. Basically, only U.N. members have been invited to attend the meeting.
However, Chen said that although Taiwan is not a U.N. member, it should not be shut out of the global disaster relief summit.

"Disaster relief work is borderless and shouldn't be subject to political meddling," Chen said, adding that Taiwan has been active in providing relief goods, cash aid and medical assistance to tsunami-ravaged countries since the catastrophe occurred.
Noting that Taiwan's humanitarian aid has received recognition from Indonesia, Chen said he hopes the Indonesian government can recommend Taiwan's participation in the summit.
Because of Beijing's ubiquitous diplomatic suppression, Taiwan has been shut out of the United Nations and many other major international organizations.
Chen said the government is still seeking the opportunity to take part in the Jakarta summit through various channels.

The government has promised to offer US$50 million in relief aid to the quake- and tsunami-hit Southeast and South Asian countries, including Indonesia, Thailand and Sri Lanka. In addition, Chen said, cash donations from private citizens had exceeded NT$180 million (US$5.72 million) as of Tuesday.

Moreover, private organizations have also donated a large amount of medical supplies, foodstuffs and tents. Chen said the Ministry of Foreign Affairs will hold a meeting Thursday to discuss how to deliver the goods to the disaster zones as soon as possible.

Taiwan has also sent several medical teams to the hardest-hit disaster zones, including the Indonesian province of Aceh, Sri Lanka and the Thai resort island of Phuket, to assist in emergency medical treatment and disinfection operations.
On Tuesday, a team of 17 disease control experts left for Phuket, carrying with them 1.5 tons of medical supplies to help curb possible disease outbreaks there.
The team was sent by the Department of Health to the resort island of Phuket which was among the worst-hit areas.
"We will send more people in the following three months to collaborate with the World Health Organization in its relief efforts," Center for Disease Control director Kuo Hsu-sung said.

DOC.HEADLINE: FUND-RAISING DRIVES CONTINUE IN TAIWAN TO HELP TSUNAMI VICTIMS

TEXT.P: Various organizations in Taiwan continued their efforts Tuesday in raising funds for victims of the Dec. 26 tsunami disaster.
According to official statistics, donations from the private sector have reached NT$180 million (US$5.63 million).
Further adding to this amount, the state-run Chinese Petroleum Corp. (CPC) announced Tuesday that it will donate NT$100 million and is encouraging its staff to make donations.

In addition, the CPC will set up donation boxes in 1,700 gas stations islandwide from Jan. 5-11, and the money will be designated for post-tsunami relief efforts by World Vision Taiwan, CPC officials said.
On Kinmen, County Magistrate Lee Chu-feng encouraged civil servants on the outlying island to donate one day's pay to help the tsunami victims.
In Hsinchu City, the Armed Forces Hsinchu Hospital held a charity art sale for the cause, and Hsinchu Mayor Lin Jung-tzer spent NT$5,00O on a calligraphic work to show his support for the sale.
The Red Cross Society of the Republic of China, Azio TV and Era Group are set to jointly hold a fund-raising event in Taipei Saturday that will be broadcast live on Azio TV.
A number of noted local entertainers are expected to attend the event and the organizers said they hope to raise at least NT$100 million.
The National Symphony Orchestra said it will donate the income from a Sunday concert, amounting to NT$500,000, for the post-tsunami relief efforts.

The Huafan University in Taipei County's Hsintien launched a campaign to urge each student to donate NT$100 in an effort to raise NT$1 million to buy medical and daily supplies for delivery to Sri Lanka, one of the tsunami-hit countries.
Meanwhile, officials at World Vision Taiwan said the organization has received a lot of small-amount donations since the Dec. 26 disaster.
Among the donors, a five-grader in Hualien donated her NT$5,000 savings and an aboriginal woman donated NT$20,000 originally intended for the living costs of her family, the officials said.

More than 130,000 people have been reported dead and millions are left homeless in nearly a dozen countries around the Indian Ocean after the tsunami, which was triggered by a 9.0-magnitude off the coast of Indonesia's Sumatra island.

DOC.HEADLINE: HISPANIST MEETING TO BE HELD AT TAMKANG UNIVERSITY

TEXT.P: The fifth meeting of the Asian Association of Hispanists will be held Friday and Saturday at Tamkang University in suburban Taipei, organizers said Tuesday.

Around 100 hispanists from home and abroad, including Spain, Argentina, Chile, Germany, Japan, mainland China, the Philippines, South Korea, Thailand and the United States will take part in the conference, with its theme centering on hispanist studies and globalization, according to university officials.

Participants will discuss cultural, language and historic problems for worldwide hispanists arising from globalization and possible countermeasures in a gathering that will be open to the public, they said.
The Asian Association of Hispanists was set up in 1985 in Seoul. It has held three meetings in Seoul, Manila and Tokyo.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TO HELP TSUNAMI-HIT NATIONS BUILD HEALTH CENTERS

TEXT.P: Taiwan is planning to help countries affected by the Dec. 26 tsunami disaster to build health centers in addition to providing them with emergency aid, Center for Disease Control (CDC) Director-General Kuo Hsu-sung said Tuesday.
Kuo said such a long-term plan is necessary because a lot of infrastructure in the tsunami-hit areas has been destroyed.
Besides offering US$50 million in relief for the affected countries, Taiwan has also sent medical teams to some of the worst-hit countries.
Also Tuesday, the Department of Health announced that it will donate 10 shipments of emergency medical supplies to the World Health Organization for delivery to the disaster areas.

DOC.HEADLINE: ENVIRONMENTALISTS CALL FOR HALT TO NUCLEAR PLANT OVER TSUNAMI CONCERN

TEXT.P: Local environmental activists urged the government Tuesday to stop construction of the island's fourth nuclear power plant because it sits on an earthquake- and tsunami-prone location.

They made the appeal at a public hearing organized by Legislator Chao Yung-ching of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party after a massive earthquake off the Indonesian island of Sumatra Dec. 26 and subsequent tsunami wreaked havoc in a dozen Southeast and South Asia countries. The death toll from the catastrophe has approached 150,000, according to media reports.

Lee Chao-hsing, dean of the College of Natural Science of National Oceanic University, said undersea earthquakes, explosions of undersea volcanoes, undersea avalanches and falling meteorites can cause devastating tsunami.

Noting that Taiwan is located in an earthquake-prone area, Lee said Taiwan's terrain is unstable and has many faults. The site of the fourth nuclear power plant on the island's northeastern coast is adjacent to the connecting area of the Philippine and the Eurasia tectonic plates, where earthquakes are common.
Lee said a powerful earthquake off the northern Taiwan port of Keelung in 1867 triggered tsunami that resulted in serious devastation of the region.

Speaking on the same occasion, the president of the Taiwan Environmental Protection Union, said there are active volcanoes beneath the waters surrounding Kueishan Island off the northeastern Taiwan coast.
"We are worried whether the fourth nuclear power plant can withstand thundering tsunami setting off by an undersea volcano eruption or an undersea earthquake," Chen said.
Against this backdrop, Chen said she hopes the government will stop construction of the controversial nuclear power plant to avoid a deadly disaster.

DOC.HEADLINE: SMALL ENTERPRISES TAIWAN'S BIGGEST EMPLOYERS: DGBAS

TEXT.P: Taiwan's small businesses still provide most jobs for domestic workers, with the sector hiring as much as 77.6 percent of the country's employees as of the end of 2003, the government reported Tuesday.

According to statistics compiled by the Cabinet-level Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS), the ratio was slightly down from previous levels due to a larger number of jobs offered by large businesses and the government's public service employment-boost plan.

There were 1.146 million small companies in Taiwan at the end of December 2003, absorbing 7.43 million workers, an increase of 70,000 over the previous year's level, the tallies show. There were about 924,000 companies in the service industries and some 134,000 in manufacturing, up by 42,000 and down by 124, respectively, from the year-earlier level.
Taiwan's small enterprises conducted business worth a total of NT$8.7 trillion (US$272 billion) in 2003, marking an annual growth rate of 16.2 percent.

Some 84.7 percent of the business was digested by the domestic market, up by 2.7 percentage points over the 2002 level, mainly due to their role changes from exporters to parts providers for large companies, DGBAS officials explained.
At the same time, 37.7 percent of the small companies failed to make a profit in 2003 as a result of weaker demand in the home market, they pointed out.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI MAYOR REGRETS HONG KONG VISA SNUB

TEXT.P: Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou said Tuesday he has been forced to cancel a plan to visit Hong Kong from Jan. 11-13 because the Hong Kong government would not grant him a visa.

Ma, who was born in Hong Kong in 1950, said he was bewildered when his Hong Kong hosts informed him earlier in the day that they had been unable to obtain a visa for him from the Hong Kong authorities.
Given the close civilian exchanges between Taiwan and Hong Kong, Ma said he could not understand why the Hong Kong government would deny him a visa.

"There are 43 commercial flights between Taiwan and Hong Kong per day and Taiwan people make 3 million to 4 million visits to Hong Kong annually. Hong Kong is an area ruled by law. When I received an invitation to a speaking tour of Hong Kong, it never occurred to me that the Hong Kong authorities might snub my visa application, " Ma said.

Ma was originally invited to deliver a speech on the rise of Chinese urban development from Taipei's perspective at the University of Hong Kong Jan. 11 and to attend a Taipei tourism promotion activity and seminar at the Hong Kong University of Science and Technology Jan. 12.

Ma said the Hong Kong government's denial of his visa application for such a cultural journey has prompted him to think that Taiwan-Hong Kong relations are regressing. Such a development is counterproductive to relations across the Taiwan Strait, he added.

Ma recalled that during a visit he made to Hong Kong four years ago, he held a 90-minute meeting with Hong Kong Chief Executive Tung Chee Hwa. "And now I cannot even secure a permit to enter Hong Kong. What a big change in our bilateral relations," Ma said.

DOC.HEADLINE: IMPORTED PRODUCTS CONTAINING MEAT TO BE INSPECTED

TEXT.P: Imported products with meat ingredients must be declared and inspected by the Bureau of Animal and Plant Health Inspection and Quarantine under the Council of Agriculture from the beginning of this year, an agricultural official said Tuesday.
The anonymous official said the measure was taken to protect Taiwan from epidemics prevailing in other regions.

Noting that Taiwan entered the World Trade Organization in 2002 and is opening its market wider than ever to overseas products, the official said the island is at a greater risk of bringing in harmful insects and other organisms.
To address the risk, the bureau began from this year to inspect any imported products containing meat, the official said.

Under the regulations, importers of products containing meat must show health inspection certificates issued by the relevant authorities to prove the products come from areas that are free from epidemics.

Manufacturers of products made of meat from areas with foot and mouth disease or avian flu must prove with the proper documents that the meat was heated during the manufacturing process to kill any virus present.
Food made of ruminant-based products and originating from countries affected by mad cow disease will be subject to more stricter inspections before being allowed into Taiwan, the official added.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN SEEKING TO JOIN MORE OECD COMMITTEES: BOFT

TEXT.P: Taiwan is seeking to join more committees under the umbrella of the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD) in an effort to step up ties with the world body and help explore foreign trade, a government official said Tuesday.

Huang Chih-peng, director-general of the Bureau of Foreign Trade under the Ministry of Economic Affairs, said Taiwan will apply to enter the OCED's financial, investment, fishery and marine committees as an observer later this year, representing fresh efforts after the country won status at its Competition Committee and became an ad hoc observer of its Trade Committee.

According to Huang, Taiwan will submit applications in the second half of the year as soon as the various committees have worked out relevant rules in spring to broaden relations with non-member countries -- a package agreed upon last year by OECD member nations to enhance international links.

The Paris-based OCED now groups 30 full member states, including Austria, Canada, Belgium, Holland, Italy, Japan, Germany, Switzerland, the United Kingdom and the United States. It provides governments with a setting in which to discuss and develop economic and social policies.

DOC.HEADLINE: EXECUTIVE YUAN BLAMES MAINLAND CHINA FOR DENYING VISA TO TAIPEI MAYOR

TEXT.P: The Executive Yuan blamed mainland China Tuesday after the Hong Kong Special Administrative Region denied a visa to Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou.
Chen Chi-mai, a spokesman for the Executive Yuan, said the visa snub contradicts Beijing's 1997 promise to allow Hong Kong keep its capitalist system unchanged for 50 years.
Ma was invited to visit Hong Kong from Jan. 11-13, but was forced to canceled the trip after his local host told him the Hong Kong authorities had denied his application for a visa.

Ma was originally invited to deliver a speech on the rise of Chinese urban development from Taipei's perspective at the University of Hong Kong Jan. 11 and to attend a Taipei tourism promotion activity and seminar at the Hong Kong University of Science and Technology Jan. 12.

DOC.HEADLINE: AIDE DENIES PRESIDENT WOULD BUY OFF OPPOSITION WITH GOVERNMENT POSTS

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian's promises of consulting the opposition on major policies do not mean he would offer government positions to opposition politicians in exchange for their support, an aide to the president said Tuesday.

The anonymous aide made the statement in an apparent attempt to put paid to speculation in Taipei that Chen might name James Soong, chairman of the opposition People First Party (PFP) , as chairman of the Straits Exchange Foundation to deal with Beijing on behalf of the government.

The aide said Chen is keen to promote cooperation between the ruling and opposition parties, stabilize the political situation and push for his legislative agenda, but will not try to buy the opposition off by offering government posts to their leaders.

Citing the president's promises in his New Year address that the DPP will reconcile and cooperate with the opposition on anything as long as it improves the political stability, the welfare of the people, the harmony between the various ethnic groups, and the peace with mainland China, the aide dismissed as groundless speculation the reports about who will be named to what posts in the president's new administration.

Meanwhile, DPP legislative whip Ker Chien-ming said his DPP caucus will start negotiations with other party caucuses at the legislature to create an amicable atmosphere for the proposed party-to-party dialogue.

Noting that Chen met with former president Lee Teng-hui, the so-called "spiritual leader" of the opposition Taiwan Solidarity Union, earlier that day, Ker said the party-to-party negotiations with the TSU have already begun.
Also Tuesday, main opposition Kuomintang spokesman Chang Jung-kung urged Chen to seek the opposition's opinion in selecting a new premier.

This should go before any party-to-party negotiations, given that the Cabinet is set to resign en masse before the next legislature is sworn in Feb. 1, Chang said, adding that the KMT has not yet been approached by the president for any meeting of political party leaders as promised by Chen in his New Year address.

When asked what the KMT will do if Chen starts negotiations first with the PFP, which was a firm KMT ally but fell out because of the two parties' competition against each other in the Dec. 11 legislative elections, the KMT spokesman said "I don't believe this could happen."

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP CHIEF CALLS CHARTER FLIGHTS INDICATION OF CROSS-STRAIT TIES

TEXT.P: The acting chairman of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) said Tuesday that charter flight services between Taiwan and mainland Chinese cities, if arranged successfully during the Chinese New Year holiday, will bode well for a breakthrough in the impasse between Taiwan and the mainland.

Speaking after a weekly meeting of DPP Central Standing Committee, Ker Chien-ming urged the mainland to jump at the chance offered by president Chen Shui-bian in a Nov. 10 statement to start Chinese New Year charter flights.

Chen said in his statement that Taiwan would like to negotiate with the mainland on the flight services that would not travel via a third place and that would be open to mainland carriers as required by Beijing.
If the charter flights can be launched successfully, Ker said it could be the beginning of a resumption of dialogue between Taiwan and the mainland.
Beijing severed contacts with Taiwan in 1999 after then-president Lee Teng-hui branded the relationship between Taiwan and the mainland as "a special state-to-state relationship."
The acting DPP chairman also condemned Beijing for "pretending to be an arbitrator" in its dispute with Taiwan by trying to enact an anti-secession law to apply to Taiwan.
This law, once enacted, would provide Beijing with a convenient excuse to annex Taiwan by force and further alienate the Taiwan people, Ker said.

Turning to Taiwan's opposition parties, Ker called on them to reconcile with the ruling party and work together with the DPP to stabilize the domestic political situations and bring about a rapprochement with the mainland.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOEA TO HELP PRIVATE SECTOR SEEK TO HOST INTERNATIONAL FAIRS

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) will set up an ad hoc office to help the private sector seek to host international conferences and exhibitions in Taiwan, a MOEA official said Tuesday.

Tu Tzu-jun, director-general of the MOEA's Department of Commerce, said that the office will offer assistance and subsidies to private groups that want to vie for the right to host international events in Taiwan.

Given that the service industry is becoming a main driving force of Taiwan's economy and that the organizing of international conventions and expositions is considered the industry's locomotive, the government will make more efforts in this field, Tu noted.

Following a target set by the Executive Yuan for 2008, the Department of Commerce has worked out a project for promoting the conference and exposition service industry's development that is worth NT$180 million (US$5.625 million), he went on.

Under the project, Tu continued, his department will push forward the creation of a friendly environment for international conventions and expositions, help domestic firms achieve higher value-added businesses, cultivate their ability to form a core information center for their respective industries, develop skills of organizing international conferences and expositions, cultivate skilled personnel and solicit international events to be held in Taiwan.

The project sets a target of holding at least six international conferences and expositions and at least eight conferences of conglomerates and organizations in Taiwan in the coming four years, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Wednesday, Jan. 5, or the 25th day of the 11th month of the Year of the Monkey according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1066: Edward the Confessor, the English king renowned for his piety, dies at the age of 63. His reign was marked by political conflict between the Normans and the English.
1818: The first regular transatlantic passenger service begins between New York and Liverpool.
1876: Konrad Adenauer, the first chancellor of West Germany, is born. Under his stewardship, West Germany began economic reconstruction and became a member of NATO and the Common Market.
1896: German physicist Wilhelm Roentgen demonstrates what he calls the X-ray, a form of high-energy radiation which allows one to see through solid objects. He made the discovery the previous year, quite by accident.
1917: An earthquake hits Nantou County in central Taiwan, killing 50 people, injuring more than 50 others and destroying more than 500 houses.
1919: Adolf Hitler founds the National Socialist Party in Germany.
1925: Prime Minister Benito Mussolini, who led a new movement called Fascism, reforms his Cabinet and rules Italy as a dictator.
1925: Nellie Taylor Ross of Wyoming becomes the first woman governor in the United States.
1930: Joseph Stalin collectivizes Soviet farms, forcing wealthy peasants off their land.
1933: Calvin Coolidge, the 30th president of the United States, dies at the age of 61. A strong supporter of business, he encouraged speculation that led to a booming stock market in the 1920's, followed by economic collapse with the 1929 crash.
1949: Gen. Chen Cheng is sworn in as governor of Taiwan.
1959: The Soviet Union successfully launches a satellite into orbit around the moon.
1961: Taiwan's Executive Yuan approves a project submitted by the Ministry of Education for the establishment of National Chunghsing University.
1964: Pope Paul VI meets the Ecumenical Patriarch of Constantinople in Jerusalem, the first meeting between the heads of the Roman Catholic and Orthodox churches in 500 years.
1970: An earthquake measuring 7 on the Richter scale hits areas south of Kunming in mainland China's Yunnan Province.
1971: The ROC severs diplomatic relations with Chile.
1974: A nine-foot statue of Confucius is shipped to La Paz, the capital of Bolivia, as a gift from the Taipei City Government.
1976: The ROC government begins a sample survey of farmers and fishermen in Taiwan and the offshore islands of Kinmen and Matsu.
1984: The Chitsin tunnel in Kaohsiung, the first under-sea tunnel in Taiwan, is inaugurated.
1987: Mainland Chinese students burn hundreds of copies of the Peking Daily to protest the government newspaper's harsh criticism of student demonstrations.
1994: The United States announces that North Korea has agreed to allow international inspections of seven nuclear sites, easing fears of a nuclear arms race in Northeast Asia.
1995: The Executive Yuan Council approves a plan to develop Taiwan into an Asia-Pacific Regional Operations Center.
1996: Japanese Prime Minister Tomiichi Murayama resigns.
2000: A research team from Taiwan's Academia Sinica successfully develops the world's first genetically modified laboratory mouse which can be used to study spinal muscular atrophy.

Confucius' lesson of the day: "It is useless to speak to a gentleman who wants to give himself up to serious studies and who yet is ashamed because of his poor food or bad clothes."
