DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING SAID BEHIND HONG KONG'S DECISION TO DENY TAIPEI MAYOR ENTRY
DOC.DATELINE: Hong Kong, Jan. 5 (CNA) (By Lin Yu-kuo and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: Several Hong Kong newspapers said on Wednesday that Beijing was behind the decision by Hong Kong authorities to deny Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou a visa to visit the former British colony.

The Ming Pao Daily, the Oriental Daily News, Sing Tao daily and Apple Daily all reported prominently that the mayor was denied a visa to visit Hong Kong Jan. 11-13. Reports also said that his opposition to a proposed mainland Chinese "anti-secession law" was a factor. The elements of the law will be reviewed at the full National People's Congress in March.
Ma was born in Hong Kong in 1950.

The Ming Pao Daily put it bluntly by quoting a member of the Chinese People's Political Consultative Conference versed in Hong Kong and Taiwan affairs as saying, "Do you think that it was a decision by the Hong Kong Special Administrative Region?" adding that Beijing has stipulated clearly that all official contact between Hong Kong and Taiwan needs prior approval.

The proposed "anti-secession law," which was passed by a standing committee of the National People's Congress last month, has been criticized by Ma. He said Beijing's approach was unnecessary and unwise, and that it would lead Taiwan people to think that Beijing is again attempting to intimidate Taiwan. Ma urged Beijing to back away from the "edge of a precipice."

A senior researcher of the Chinese Academy of Social Sciences, in a telephone interview with the Ming Pao Daily, said that given the fact that Ma most likely has his sights set on running for president in 2008, it makes sense that he would be against the passage of an "anti-secession law."

However, the researcher continued, Beijing has now drawn a clear line between supporters and opposers of the "anti-secession law," and couldn't possibly allow Ma to come to Hong Kong, especially at such a sensitive time between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait.

Ma was originally invited to deliver a speech on the rise of Chinese urban development from Taipei's perspective at the University of Hong Kong Jan. 11 and to attend a Taipei tourism promotion activity and seminar at the Hong Kong University of Science and Technology Jan. 12.

The Hong Kong government subsequently "suggested" that the University of Hong Kong postpone the seminar to April because, according to the newspaper reports, the controversial bill is expected to be passed by that time.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TO TALK WITH 10-ODD WTO MEMBERS ON SERVICES

TEXT.P: Taiwan is scheduled to engage in bilateral consultations with more than 10 member countries of the World Trade Organization (WTO) in mid-February on issues mainly in the service sector, the Bureau of Foreign Trade (BOFT) reported Wednesday.

The proposed bilateral consultations are part of efforts to speed up the pace of talks pertaining to the "July Package" -- a key segment of the Doha Round Talks agreed upon on Aug. 1, 2004 in Geneva by all 148 WTO member countries -- said BOFT Director-General Huang Chih-peng.
Accelerating the "July Package" talks to settle relevant issues as much as possible will also be taking place prior to a WTO ministerial meeting scheduled for December in Hong Kong, Huang said.

Huang, who will lead a Taiwan delegation to Geneva for the talks, said that Taiwan is expected to submit a report in May, making Taiwan's position known concerning further opening of its service markets and related issues.

The "July Package" stipulates a set of rules on a broad range of issues related to wider liberalization of the agriculture, industry and service sectors and advocates trade facilitation. BOFT officials said that the new measures will have a profound impact on the future development of Taiwan's economy.

In late February, representatives of WTO member countries are also expected to meet in Geneva for talks on the issue of anti-dumping. BOFT officials said that some countries have raised the issue against major exporting countries, forming another kind of trade barrier.

Taiwan will consult shortly with other "victim countries" of the anti-dumping accusation that share common ground on the issue to jointly work out policies to cope with the forthcoming anti-dumping talks, the officials added.

Meanwhile, the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) and Taiwan's permanent representative corps in Geneva are scheduled to hold a three-day Doha Round Talks meeting in Taipei Jan. 7-9 to further exchange views among the government and the private sector on Taiwan's stance in the world trade regulatory body as well as strategies on related issues.

Taiwan's permanent representative to the WTO headquarters Yen Ching-chang, Minister of Economic Affairs Ho Mei-yue and other officials are expected to preside over various discussion panels during the meeting.
WTO member countries initiated the talks in November 2001 in Doha, the capital of Qatar, but the talks ground to a halt after the collapse of negotiations held September last year in Cancun, Mexico.

MOEA statistics show that 94 percent of the world's foreign trade in 2003 was conducted in compliance with the regulations of the world trade regulatory body. Taiwan officially joined the WTO at the beginning of 2002.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP WANTS INTER-PARTY TALKS TO START WITH TSU

TEXT.P: The acting chairman of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) said Wednesday that inter-party talks will begin soon with its ally Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) as a precursor to expanded discussions with other parties.

Ker Chien-ming made the remarks as President Chen Shui-bian met with high-ranking officials and former President Lee Teng-hui in closed-door meetings over the past two days to exchange views on the current political situation.

Ker said that the basic view was that there must be an end to the bickering between the ruling and opposition parties via some form of reconciliation, and pointed to President Chen's new year's address to the nation where he entreated all political parties to come together for the benefit of Taiwan.

The president said that if something benefits the stability of domestic politics, the welfare of the people, harmony among ethnic groups, and cross-strait peace, then it can be discussed between political parties for further cooperation to achieve positive results.

Ker said the DPP will maintain a "parallel and equidistant" relationship with the TSU, the Kuomintang (KMT) and the People First Party (PFP) , and will begin to communicate with them as soon as possible.
Since the DPP has cooperated with the TSU more in the past, it will consult with it first, Ker said, adding he will contact TSU acting-chairman Huang Tzung-yuan to set up a time to meet.
Huang replied that he was happy to begin discussions about cooperation and said that the KMT and the PFP also need to come to the table for the sake of political stability.

Meanwhile, Huang Teh-fu, a KMT caucus whip in the legislature, said Wednesday that political parties can talk among themselves and that the president only needs to step in if there is a bottleneck in communications.
Huang Teh-fu said that as president of all the people, Chen should not interfere with DPP party affairs.

He also said that he hoped that the offer to better communicate was not being used as a facade to hide the real goal of the DPP -- driving a wedge between the opposition "pan-blue alliance" of the KMT and the PFP. Reports have said recently that the DPP will allow the PFP to have some of its officials placed in the new Cabinet.

In line with constitutional precedent, Premier Yu Shyi-kun and all Cabinet members are expected to resign en masse after the current Legislative Yuan concludes its final session on Jan. 21. Rumors have circulated for the last couple of weeks about the possibility of Chen naming a new premier and forming a coalition Cabinet with opposition parties. Senior government officials, including Yu himself, have been tightlipped about the imminent Cabinet reshuffle.

DOC.HEADLINE: DOH HEAD DENIES HEALTH INSURANCE PREMIUMS TO BE RAISED THIS MONTH

TEXT.P: Minister of Health Chen Chien-jen denied news reports Wednesday that national health insurance premiums will be raised by 5 percent or more before the end of this month.

Both Chen and Bureau of National Health Insurance (BNHI) Director-General Liu Chien-hsiang said that changes in national health insurance premiums is a topic that will be discussed during a public forum on Jan. 22, after which officials will make an informed decision.

Admitting that the national health insurance program, a mammoth enterprise, has been operated deeply in the red, Chen said that even if premiums are raised to help offset the mounting financial pressure, they will not come into effect for at least three months because of bureaucratic procedures.

Chen added that a consensus on what to do ought to be reached at the public forum and that the BNHI will come up with a finance plan afterward. If the plan is approved by the Department of Health (DOH), it will then be submitted to the Executive Yuan for approval prior to being forwarded to the Legislative Yuan. The whole process will be completed in three months in accordance with the regulations of the Legislative Yuan, Chen noted.

Chen claimed that the rights of and medical care for patients, particularly those in emergency rooms or critical care wards, will not be compromised regardless whether or not national health insurance premiums are raised.

DOH officials quoted an actuarial assessment report as indicating that the national health insurance program can be operated at breakeven for two years if premiums are raised by 5.01 percent, with in-the-black operations expected to stay healthy for five years if premiums are raised by 5.11 percent.
Meanwhile, BNHI Director-General Liu said that the health insurance bureau is assessed ways to address an expected "sink hole" in funds this March or April due to a fall in the reserve fund.

BNHI officials are asking everyone who has used the national health insurance scheme to support revisions to the system. They said that the program can be maintained for two to five more years if each person chips in an extra NT$50 to NT$100 per month.

According to the BNHI, health insurance premiums have only been raised once during the 10 years since the program was started in 1995. Premiums were raised from 4.25 percent to 4.55 percent in September 2002.

Meanwhile, the legislative caucus of the Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) , an ally of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party, said Wednesday that the party will support the DOH's plan to raise premiums.

However, TSU party whip Huang Tsung-yuan said that the TSU will support the increase only after the BNHI reviews its expenditure protocols and makes sure that the money is not going to be spent inappropriately.

The opposition People First Party (PFP), on the other hand, came out against any increase in premiums, saying that costs in various sectors of society are rising, while the average person's income has not kept pace.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI MAYOR SAYS HONG KONG UNWISE TO DENY HIM ENTRY

TEXT.P: Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou said Wednesday that if mainland China's decision to deny him a visa to visit Hong Kong was because of his opposition to Beijing's "anti-secession law," the move was an unwise one.

Talking to reporters after attending a weekly Cabinet meeting, Ma said Hong Kong is regarded as "the showcase of one country, two systems" and is supposed to be different from mainland China, which does not allow freedom of speech.

Ma made the comment in response to reports by Hong Kong media that the Special Administrative Region government had denied him entry to Hong Kong because he had spoken against Beijing's plan to introduce the law.
Ma had previously criticized Beijing's move as unnecessary and unwise, saying it will further alienate Taiwan from mainland China and worsen cross-Taiwan Strait relations.

Ma had originally planned to visit Hong Kong next week, with his itinerary including giving a speech at the University of Hong Kong, attending a Taiwan tourism promotion event, and holding a forum with students at Hong Kong University of Science and Technology.
The University of Hong Kong Tuesday said it planned to postpone the speech to April since Ma was not issued a visa in time to make the scheduled date.
However, Ma said he does not think he will be available in April because the Taipei City Council will have opened its session by then.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER ACCEPTS DONATION FOR ASIAN TSUNAMI RELIEF PROGRAM

TEXT.P: Premier Yu Shyi-kun accepted on behalf of the government a NT$16.9 million (US$531,446) donation from a private realtor Wednesday for post-disaster relief programs in Southeast and South Asian countries.

The gesture from the Sinyi Realty Group was the biggest private donation received by the government since a magnitude-9.0 earthquake off Indonesia and subsequent tsunamis wreaked havoc in a dozen countries around the Indian Ocean less than two weeks ago.
Yu said the donation shows the humanitarian concern and the warmth of the people of Taiwan. By making the generous donation, he added, Sinyi Realty has set a good example.
Sinyi Realty Chairman Chou Chun-chi said his company arrived at the donation amount by multiplying the number of employees in the company by NT$10,000.
"We hope our move can inspire other local enterprises to join the aid campaign to help the tsunami victims," Chou said.
Premier Yu said the Republic of China government has pledged to donate US$50 million in relief aid to earthquake- and tsunami-ravaged countries, making Taiwan the world's 11th-largest donor.
Nevertheless, Yu said post-disaster relief requires not only cash but also comprehensive and circumspect planning so that each aid package can be wisely used to help survivors.
Yu said the Cabinet has so far held two rounds of inter-departmental emergency meetings to work out short-term relief aid plans as well as mid- and long-term reconstruction aid programs.
Moreover, Yu said, the government is actively negotiating with tsunami-affected countries to sponsor full reconstruction programs in a specific disaster zone.

"If the ongoing consultations can generate positive results, we'll be able to contribute our experiences in fighting severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS) outbreaks and in post-921 earthquake reconstruction," Yu said.

In the future, Yu said, Taiwan will actively participate in relevant international relief conferences and pool its resources in the public and private sectors to facilitate relief operations in tsunami-ravaged countries.
As of Tuesday, cash donations from private citizens to a special account opened by the Ministry of Foreign Affairs for aid to tsunami-hit countries had exceeded NT$180 million (US$5.72 million).
Major charitable organizations have also launched fund-raising drives for similar purposes.

Taiwan has also sent several medical teams to the hardest-hit disaster zones, including the Indonesian province of Aceh, Sri Lanka and the Thai resort island of Phuket, to assist in emergency medical treatment and disinfection operations.
On Tuesday, a team of 17 disease control experts left for Phuket, carrying with them 1.5 tons of medical supplies to help curb possible disease outbreaks there.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI SHARE PRICES END LOWER

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange opened low and closed lower Wednesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving down 72.09 points to close at 5,988.37.
The bourse opened at 5,999.47 and fluctuated between 6,030.19 and 5,988.37 during trading. A total of 2.84 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$51.97 billion (US$1.63 billion).

All eight major stock categories lost ground, with foodstuff issues moving down the most at 2.2 percent, followed by textile stocks at 1.7 percent, banking and financial shares at 1.3 percent, plastics and chemicals shares at 1.2 percent, machinery and electronics shares and cement stocks both at 1.1 percent, construction issues at 0.5 percent and paper and pulp issues at 0.4 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 643 to 123, with 116 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN RANKS 27TH IN GLOBAL ECONOMIC FREEDOM SURVEY
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Jan. 4 (CNA) (By Jorge Liu and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan ranks the 27th in a global economic freedom survey, seven notches up from 34th the previous year, according to the Heritage Foundation/Wall Street Journal 2005 index of economic freedom, which was published Monday.
Hong Kong was No. 1 for the 11th consecutive year, while mainland China made headway to rank 112th, 16 notches up from 128th the previous year.
Also rounding out the top 10 were Singapore, Luxembourg, Estonia, Ireland, New Zealand, Great Britain, Denmark, Iceland and Australia, in that order.

The 2005 Index of Economic Freedom measures 161 countries against a list of 50 independent variables divided into 10 broad factors of economic freedom. Low scores are more desirable. The higher the score on a factor, the greater the level of government interference in the economy and the less economic freedom a country enjoys.

These 50 variables are grouped into the following categories: trade policy, fiscal burden to the government, government intervention in the country, monetary policy, capital flows and foreign investment, banking and finance, wages and prices, property rights, regulations, and informal market activity.
The Heritage Foundation and Wall Street Journal have jointly formulated the index of economic freedom since 1995. This year, they based their assessment of 161 countries on the 10 categories.
On a scale of one to five, with one being the highest freedom, Hong Kong scored 1.35, Taiwan 2.29, and mainland China 3.46.

The report said that Taiwan has experienced slower growth in gross domestic product as its economy has matured. The March 20, 2004 re-election of President Chen Shui-bian gave new momentum to a popular consensus supporting economic reforms.

Relaxed rules on foreign investment in the transportation, power supply, financial and telecommunications sectors have attracted capital. Laws easing financial mergers have begun to show results as Taiwan's non-performing loan ratio has dropped to its lowest level since the Asian financial crisis of 1997.

An economic upturn in the United States was reflected both in annualized GDP growth of over 6.28 percent by mid-2004 and in all-time high trade figures. By June 2004, foreign exchange reserves had swelled to US$229 billion.

Taiwan's unemployment had fallen to a three-year low of 4.36 percent. The U.S. Trade Representative's June 2004 Special 301 report noted that Taiwan has steadily improved its intellectual property rights enforcement and successfully reduced the production of pirated optical media. The government also continues to ease restrictions on Taiwan businesses that trade and invest in mainland China.

Taiwan's fiscal burden on the government score was 0.1 point worse this year, and its government intervention score was 0.5 point worse; however, its capital flows and foreign investment score and banking and finance score were 1 point better. As a result, Taiwan's overall score is 0.14 point better this year.

Taiwan's scores in various categories were as follows: trade policy (2.0) , fiscal burden of the government (3.4) , government intervention in the economy (3.0), monetary policy (1.0), capital flows and foreign investment (2.0), banking and finance (2.0), wages and prices (2.0) property rights (2.0), regulations (3.0), and informal market activity (2.5).

DOC.HEADLINE: RED CROSS LAUNCHES FUND-RAISING DRIVE TO HELP TSUNAMI VICTIMS

TEXT.P: The Red Cross Society of the Republic China launched a month-long fundraising campaign Wednesday in cooperation with the FamilyMart convenience store chain to help countries affected by the Dec. 26 earthquake/tsunami disaster.
The campaign asks for a fixed amount of NT$200 (US$6.25) for each donation, which will be accepted at any FamilyMart store islandwide.

Red Cross Society of ROC Secretary-General Hau Lung-bin said the amount is a small one to most people in Taiwan and that they will be able to help the victims by giving less than the cost of a movie ticket.
Hau said the donations will be used to support the relief operations of the International Committee of the Red Cross in the tsunami-hit countries.
Hau said his organization aims to raise NT$300 million to provide placement for 200,000 homeless victims for six to eight months.
Hau said the Red Cross Society of ROC has before this raised NT$180 million, NT$100 million of which has been distributed to the worst-hit areas in Indonesia, Sri Lanka and India.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAYOR'S VISA SNUB SIGNALS DOWNTURN IN TAIWAN-HONG KONG RELATIONS

TEXT.P: Relations between Taiwan and Hong Kong would have to be re-labeled as "regressing" if reports saying that Hong Kong authorities have denied Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou a visa to the former British colony are true, a Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) spokesman said Wednesday.

MAC Vice Chairman Chiu Tai-san said that the MAC has asked officials from the Chung Hwa Travel Service -- Taiwan's de facto liaison office in Hong Kong under the MAC's supervision established in the absence of formal relations between Taiwan and Hong Kong -- to verify the reports by contacting the Hong Kong authorities.

Chiu urged the Hong Kong Special Administrative Region's authorities to handle the visa issue in an even-handed manner to avoid having the international community question Hong Kong's democratization and to salvage the "one country, two systems" formula from bankruptcy.

Noting that people have gone back and forth between Taiwan and Hong frequently and in large amount over the years, Chiu stressed that regardless of who is denied a visa, this sort of treatment is definitely a blow to the development of bilateral ties between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait.

Ma was originally invited to deliver a speech on the rise of Chinese urban development from Taipei's perspective at the University of Hong Kong Jan. 11 and to attend a Taipei tourism promotion activity and seminar at the Hong Kong University of Science and Technology Jan. 12.
Ma was informed by his Hong Kong activity sponsor Tuesday about the visa snub, although other members who had planned to travel with the mayor were given visas.

Hong Kong media on Wednesday said the reason Hong Kong authorities did not issue Ma a visa was because of his opposition to a proposed mainland Chinese "anti-secession law." The elements of the law will be reviewed at the full National People's Congress in March.

The Hong Kong government subsequently "suggested" that the University of Hong Kong postpone the seminar to April because, according to Hong Kong newspapers reports, the controversial bill is expected to be passed by that time.

DOC.HEADLINE: DOCTOR RETREATS TO ABORIGINAL VILLAGE TO CARE FOR NEEDY
DOC.DATELINE: Taitung, eastern Taiwan, Jan. 5 (CNA) (By Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: A physician who used to practice in major medical centers in Taipei has chosen to give up a highly paid career to move with his family to a tiny mountainous village in eastern Taiwan to take care of aboriginal people.
Dr. Kao Tien-tsi has been running his clinic at the Bunun tribal village of Hongshih located in Haijui rural township of Taitung County for more than six months, serving fewer than 50 households.

According to the locals, Kao, a pediatrician, technically charges nothing for his treatment. He does not care whether his patients pay his clinic's NT$10 registration or not. The minimum registration fee is normally NT$50 for clinics in Taiwan.
Kao, who is camera-shy, turned down an interview with a CNA reporter and instead let his aide speak for him.

Kao not only treats the aboriginal villagers, he also offers consultations to the Bunun people, most of whom, particularly the elderly ones, suffer from chronicle diseases such as liver complaints that are caused by their lifestyle, the aide said.
The aide said that Kao initially decided to charge the villagers nothing for registration but later decided on NT$10 for fear of provoking another clinic in the village.
Now the clinic is the talk of the town simply because it is a "NT$10 hospital," the aide said.
Kao and his family, none of whom are aboriginal, have taken to village life like ducks to water.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES LOWER ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were lower Wednesday as the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for January lost 67 points to close at 6,013, with 25,857 contracts changing hands.
TAIEX Index futures for February moved down 69 points to finish at 6,014, with 784 contracts traded, while March futures lost 71 points to finish at 6,013, with 19 contracts traded.
June futures lost 58 points to finish at 5,999, with nine contracts traded, while September futures moved down 90 points to close at 5,900, with 30 contracts traded.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Wednesday at 6,080 for January, 6,083 for February, 6,084 for March, 6,057 for June and 5,990 for September.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were lower.
January TE futures moved down 1.9 points to close at 222.9, with 2,511 contracts traded, while February TE futures lost 2.7 points to finish at 222.1, with 50 contract transactions.
No transactions were recorded for March, June and September.
January TF futures lost 8.6 points to finish at 1,026.8, with 3,323 contracts changing hands, while February TF futures moved down 10 points to end at 1,025, with 69 contracts traded.
No transactions were recorded for March, June and September.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN DEMANDS EXPLANATION FROM HONG KONG FOR DENYING MAYOR MA ENTRY

TEXT.P: The ROC government on Wednesday demanded an proper explanation from Hong Kong of its decision to reject a visa application by Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou.

Executive Yuan spokesman Chen Chi-mai pointed out that government officials from Taiwan have often had problems obtaining visas to Hong Kong during recent years, which he said has caused relations between Taiwan and Hong Kong to go regress.
The Special Administrative Region's government must take full responsibility for this situation, Chen said.
He said Taipei will lodge a strong protest to Hong Kong if no proper explanation is provided on its latest decision to turn down Ma's visa application.

According to reports by major Hong Kong media, the Special Administrative Region's government refused to issue Ma a visa because he had spoken out against mainland China's plan to enact an "anti-secession law."
Chen said Beijing is trying to change the status quo across the Taiwan Strait unilaterally by introducing the law and that the move is unacceptable to all people in Taiwan.
The denial of entry to Ma proves that Beijing's promise of "one country, two systems" is nothing but impractical, wishful thinking, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: OVER NT$3 BILLION IN LABOR INSURANCE PAYMENTS FOR INJURED WORKERS

TEXT.P: The government paid a total of NT$3.25 billion (US$100 million) in the first 10 months of 2004 in labor insurance compensation to workers killed or injured in the workplace, according to recent government statistics.

The figure involves some 44,000 cases and represents an annual increase rate of 9.1 percent in value, the tallies compiled by the Cabinet-level Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS) show.

Some NT$1.47 billion of the total figure was paid to workers' applications for government labor insurance subsidies for treatment of occupational injuries and sickness, NT$750 million of which went to 669 cases of death, DGBAS officials said. They noted that 5.4 workers out of every 1,000 were injured at work during the January-October period.

To protect worker interests and boost workplace safety and economic development, the government enacted the professional injury protection law in April 2002, providing various types of subsides for injured workers and their employers. Such government subsidies for business owners totaled NT$120 million during the same 10-month period.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER AIT CHAIRWOMAN ARRIVES IN TAIPEI FOR WEEKLONG VISIT

TEXT.P: Former American Institute in Taiwan (AIT) Chairwoman Therese Shaheen arrived in Taipei Wednesday for a weeklong private visit.

Shaheen, who resigned from the post as the top U.S. liaison officer with Taiwan in the absence formal diplomatic ties in April 2004, said after her arrival from Seoul that she is very happy to visit Taiwan again.
This is Shaheen's second trip to Taiwan since her resignation from the AIT chairmanship.
She is scheduled to meet with President Chen Shui-bian and Minister of Foreign Affairs Tan Sun Chen Friday to exchange views on the general international situation and Taiwan-U.S. relations.
"President Chen is a nice man," Shaheen said, adding that she has prepared a "mysterious" gift for Chen's newborn grandson.
Despite her departure from public service, Shaheen continues to maintain close contact with Taiwan's business and political communities.

Shaheen said she will take advantage of her visit to meet with Legislative Yuan President Wang Jin-pyng, a vice chairman of the opposition Kuomintang that together with its ally -- the People First Party -- controls a majority in the legislature, to exchange views on Taiwan's long-stalled NT$610.8 billion arms procurement package.

The opposition-controlled legislature has stonewalled the passage of the special statute and budget bill for purchasing eight diesel-electric submarines, a squadron of 12 P-3C Orion submarine-hunting aircraft and six PAC III Patriot anti-missile batteries from the United States.
Shaheen said she is worried the delay in the passage of the bill could affect the upgrading of Taiwan's defense capabilities in the face of mainland China's ever mounting military threat.
Asked whether she has brought with her any message from the U.S. government, Shaheen would not make a direct response but said cryptically that she has consistently told the truth.

Praising Taiwan as a "mature democracy," Shaheen said Taiwan has contributed much to the world and deserves more world recognition. Shaheen further said she has been impressed by the hospitality and warmth of the Taiwan people.
During her stay in Seoul, Shaheen said she had been informed of the passing of Straits Exchange Foundation Chairman Koo Chen-fu, Taiwan's top negotiator with mainland China.

Shaheen said she was saddened to learn of Koo's death. She lauded him as a kind and thoughtful gentleman who made outstanding contributions to Taiwan, particularly in helping promote rapprochement across the Taiwan Strait. Koo died of renal failure Monday at the age of 88.

During her last trip to Taipei in June 2004, President Chen Shui-bian presented an award of thanks to Shaheen in recognition of her contributions to promoting Taipei-Washington ties during her time as the top AIT officer.
At the decoration ceremony, Chen lauded Shaheen as one of Taiwan's best friends and a beautiful guardian angel of the people of Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TO SUPPORT 10,000 TSUNAMI-AFFECTED CHILDREN

TEXT.P: The Government Information Office (GIO) is planning to launch a sponsorship program to support 10,000 children in countries affected by the Dec. 26 tsunami disaster, GIO Director-General Lin Chia-lung said Wednesday.

Under the program, which will be carried out in cooperation with experienced child-care organizations, each child will be provided with NT$10,000 (US$313) per month over a three-year period, Lin said.
Lin said the GIO will hold a large-scale charity show Jan. 15 with a goal of raising NT$300 million to fund the program.

DOC.HEADLINE: MANDARIN AIRLINES OPENS KINMEN ROUTE

TEXT.P: Taipei-based Mandarin Airlines, a domestic flight operator, opened Taipei-Kinmen and Taichung-Kinmen routes Wednesday, becoming the fourth local air company to provide flight services between Taiwan and the outlying island.

A ceremony marking the inauguration of the new flights was held Wednesday at the Kinmen airport, which was presided over by Mandarin Airlines President Michael Lo and attended by Civil Aeronautics Administration Director-General Billy K.C. Chang, Kinmen Magistrate Lee Chu-feng, New Party Legislator Wu Cheng-tien, and various tourist industry representatives.

Far East Air Transport Corp., Trans Asia Airways and the UNI Airways Corp. already serve Kinmen, which is considered a golden egg for the air carriers after the number of the passengers on other domestic routes has shrunk in recent years.

Last year, the number of the travelers between Kinmen and Xiamen, in mainland China's Fujien Province, surged to a new high of 404,000, with over 80 percent of those travelers Taiwanese businessmen, according to Mandarin Airlines.

Mandarin Airlines offers three flights per day between the northern Taiwan city of Taipei and Kinmen and three daily flights between the central Taiwan city of Taichung and Kinmen, according to the company.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TO MONITOR BEIJING-WASHINGTON TALKS ON ANTI-SECESSION LAW

TEXT.P: An official of the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) said Wednesday that the government will closely monitor developments in mainland China's communications with the United States about its plan to enact an anti-secession law.

MAC Deputy Chairman Chiu Tai-shan made the remarks a day after Chen Yunlin, director of the Taiwan Affairs Office under Beijing's State Council, arrived in Washington to discuss with U.S. officials the details of the planned anti-secession law targeting Taiwan.

The mainland's plan to promulgate an anti-secession law is not only a tremendous provocation of Taiwan but also a unilateral move to change the status quo across the Taiwan Strait, Chiu told reporters.

Chiu said that the MAC, the top agency in charge of Taiwan's policies toward the mainland, has expressed on public occasions its strong opposition to the legislation aimed at legalizing Beijing's invasion of the country.
Stressing that Taiwan is not part of the People's Republic of China as the Beijing authorities claim, Chiu said this is also the feeling of a majority of the people of Taiwan.
Meanwhile, Michel Lu, spokesman of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, said that officials of the Republic of China representative office in the United States will keep a close eye on developments.
The government will also continue to express its opposition to the proposed anti-secession law, which, if passed, would offer a legal basis for Beijing to use force against Taiwan, Lu went on.
The Standing Committee of the National People's Congress (NPC) agreed in late December to submit the draft bill to a NPC plenary session for deliberation in March this year.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. DOLLAR RISES ON TAIPEI FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar rose against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Wednesday, gaining NT$0.214 to close at NT$32.060.
A total of US$953 million changed hands.
The greenback opened at NT$32.050 and was traded between NT$31.975 and NT$32.123.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Washington Post: Tragedy and Religion;In Angry Waves, the Devout See an Angry God.
Aceh's highly influential Islamic clerics have explained the giant wave that devastated this overwhelmingly Muslim region as a warning to the faithful that they must more strictly observe their religion, including a ban on Muslims killing Muslims, the paper said.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Times: The golden silence.
Britain will fall silent for three minutes at noon today in remembrance of the 150,000 people killed by the tsunami in South-East Asia while banks, global financiers and governments began to grapple with the scale of devastation.
Financial Times: Baghdad governor assassinated.
Insurgents shot and killed Baghdad's provincial governor and struck at the headquarters of an elite police unit on Tuesay in a series of attacks against Iraqi government targets aimed at disrupting the January 30 elections.

DOC.HEADLINE: CABINET, PRESIDENTIAL OFFICE AGREE ON REVISED DRAFT REFERENDUM LAW

TEXT.P: Premier Yu Shyi-kun said Wednesday there is a consensus between the Presidential Office and the Executive Yuan that a revised draft referendum law be submitted to the current legislature before it ends Jan. 21.
The premier made the remarks as the Executive Yuan passed a revised draft referendum law in a floor meeting.

Some media reports said the timing of the Cabinet's passing of the revised draft law is unfavorable to a proposed reconciliation between the ruling and opposition parties broached by President Chen Shui-bian, adding that the Presidential Office was caught off-guard by the move. Other reports speculated that the move was to counter mainland China's proposed anti-secession law, which is expected to be put to a full National People's Congress for reconsideration in March.

Yu explained that the revised draft law would have been submitted to the legislature in early December, but as some civic groups still had reservations on some articles, the Executive Yuan had to continue to communicate with them.

Minister without Portfolio Hsu Chih-hsiung said that the current referendum law is riddled with problems and conflicting articles, claiming that the referendum screening committee could be unconstitutional, that there is too high a threshold for signatures to be collected to establish a referendum issue.

The administration will have to make an overall review and amendment and submit it before the Cabinet resigns en masse and the new legislature is sworn in Feb. 1 according to constitutional precedent, Hsu said.
The opposition-dominated legislature rammed through the present Referendum Law in late November 2003.

Meanwhile, the ruling Democratic Progressive Party said that the revised draft law is an extension of an olive branch to the opposition parties that it hopes will ease confrontation and bring reconciliation to the rival parties.

Ker Chien-ming, DPP whip in the legislature, said the revised law lowers the threshold of the number of people required to establish or vote on a referendum issue, and deletes the public's right to initiate a referendum on issues concerning constitutional amendments, a section the ruling party initially wanted to include but which was opposed by the "pan-blue alliance" of the Kuomintang and the People First Party.

DPP Legislator Tsai Huang-liang said it does not matter that the initiation on issues related to constitutional amendments was not included in the revised draft law, saying that the DPP will write a new Constitution in 2006 that will close the loophole.

Tsai said that the revised draft law also expands the coverage of referendum to include changes of the national territory, which he said is a"pragmatic" approach that will confirm the current territory of Taiwan and will be in the interests of the people.

Tsai said he was baffled by Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou's remarks that it is "unconstitutional " to put to referendum the issue concerning the changing of the national territory, adding that the opposition party should not look at the revised draft law in a negative light.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TO PURCHASE OVER 400 HELLFIRE MISSILES
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Jan. 4 (CNA) (By Oliver Lin and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan will purchase more than 400 Hellfire missiles from the United States, worth a total of about US$50 million, American defense industry sources said Tuesday.
Lockheed Martin Corp. said in a news release that the company will produce over 600 AGM-114M and AGM-114K Hellfire missiles in line with its contract with the U.S. Army.

According to an agreement between Taiwan and the U.S. Army, the press statement said, 70 percent of those air-to-ground missiles will be sold to Taiwan. The statement further said that 5 percent to 10 percent of the Hellfire missiles will be delivered to Israel and the rest will be used by the U.S. Army.
Lockheed Martin Corp. said the company has begun producing the missiles and is scheduled to complete production in six months.

Mark Stenger, director of Lockheed Martin Corp.'s air-to-ground missile system planning department, said Hellfire missiles are accurate and that their efficacy has been verified in both Afghanistan and Iraq.
Noting that Hellfire missiles can be used to strike ships, light armored vehicles and buildings, Stenger said what Taiwan will acquire will be the world's best air-to-ground weaponry system.

Hellfire missiles can be installed on gunships such as Apache helicopters. With the acquisition of Hellfire missiles, Lockheed Martin sources said, Taiwan's armed forces can easily get in touch or conduct joint operations with U.S. overseas ground forces, marines and special service forces.

The Hellfire missile functions like a miniature aircraft, complete with its own guidance computer, steering and propulsion system. The payload is a high-explosive, copper-lined-charge powerful enough to burn through the heaviest tank armor in existence.

DOC.HEADLINE: SNIFFER DOG STATIONS IN KINMEN TO HELP INSPECTION WORK

TEXT.P: The Department of Health (DOH) sent a sniffer dog and his trainer to Kinmen Wednesday in a bid to step up inspection and quarantine work on the outlying island that lies closer to mainland China than to Taiwan.

Yeh Ying, vice director of the Bureau of Animal and Plant Health Inspection and Quarantine under the DOH, noted at a press conference that mainland Chinese people made over 200,000 visits to Kinmen last year using the direct transportation link channel.

As the mainland is reported to have rabies, avian influenza, coddling moth and other animal and plant infectious diseases and pests, the DOH has had to step up inspection and quarantine work on the outlying island to ensure the health of Taiwan's agricultural products and people.
Yeh said the sniffer dog, named Jack, will be responsible for detecting if arriving tourists are carrying contraband fruit, vegetables or meat.
The DOH has since October 2002 stationed four teams of sniffer dogs at CKS International Airport in Taoyuan and at Hsiaokang International Airport in Kaohsiung.

Jack served at Hsiaokang Airport for more than two years before being sent to Kinmen and has a detection record of over 90 percent accuracy. He is trained to detect more than 10 kinds of agricultural and poultry products, including citrus, mango, apple, chicken, beef and pork.
The dog detected one arriving passenger carrying mainland Chinese oranges and bananas in his luggage at Kinmen's Shuitou Wharf Wednesday.

Yeh told the public not to bring any agricultural or poultry products from the mainland and warned that those who do must submit them for inspection and quarantine. He also urged the public to inform on any violations through the toll free phone number 0800039131.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEARLY 70 PERCENT OF WORKERS PLANNING TO QUIT NEXT MONTH: POLL

TEXT.P: Nearly 70 percent of Taiwan's employees are planning to change jobs after the lunar new year holiday in early February, according to the results of a recent public opinion poll.

According to the results of the survey released Tuesday by the headhunting Web site www.104.com.tw, 31 percent of the respondents said that they are determined to find a new job after Chinese New Year, which falls on Feb. 9 this year, while 38 percent said they are still considering the issue and 15 percent said they do not plan to quit.

About 46 percent of the people polled said that they will change their jobs immediately if there is a good opportunity, regardless of year-end bonus, ahead of some 39 percent that will do so only after having got their bonus, the poll discovered. Only around 8 percent of the respondents said they will quickly quit upon finding that the current job does not suit them.

The roughly 66,000 people wishing to change jobs at this time of the year is apparently about 40 percent higher than the previous year's level, a Web site official said, ascribing the phenomenon to strong public assumption that the booming domestic economy will continue into this year.
He forecast that the number of job seekers will pick up after the lunar new year.

When asked the reason for their job change plans, 48 percent of the respondents expressed hope of finding a more promising company and 47.5 percent pointed to the lack of development at their current jobs, according to the survey. Low pay, no promotion opportunities and lax company prospects are among other factors cited.
Around 18 percent said that they would stay at their present company if they were offered a pay raise, followed by possibilities of learning and career development opportunities.
The public opinion survey was carried out by the Web site from Dec. 23-29, with 1,514 valid questionnaires recovered. It had a margin of error of 2.6 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN FOREIGN RESERVES HIT RECORD US$241.73 billion

TEXT.P: Taiwan's foreign reserves amounted to a record high of US$241.73 billion as of the end of 2004, according to statistics released Wednesday by the Taiwan-based Central Bank of China.
The amount was the world's third-highest after Japan and mainland China, the statistics show.
It was US$2.6 billion higher than the level registered at the end of November 2004 and US$35.1 billion higher than that of the end of 2003.

The increase was mainly due to the rise in the value of the euro and the British pound, which had appreciated 2.73 percent and 1.96 percent, respectively, against the U.S. dollar during the one month until Dec. 31, Central Bank officials said.
The inflow of foreign capital and investment yield from the foreign reserves also contributed to the increase, they said.

While the foreign reserves of Japan amounted to US$819.14 billion as of the end of November 2004, those of the mainland came in at US$514.53 billion as of the end of September 2004, according to the Central Bank.

The foreign reserves of South Korea and Hong Kong totalled US$198.17 billion and US$124.45 billion, respectively, as of the end of 2004, and that of Singapore stood at US$108.8 billion as of the end of November 2004.

DOC.HEADLINE: CONSUMER PRICE INDEX FOR DECEMBER UP 1.62 PERCENT

TEXT.P: Taiwan's consumer price index (CPI) for December stood at 101.34, representing an increase of 0.07 percent over the previous month's level, the Cabinet-level Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS) announced Wednesday.
The figure also represented a rise of 1.62 percent over the previous year's level, according to statistics compiled by the DGBAS.

For the whole year of 2004, the CPI growth rate was also 1.62 percent, lower than the originally estimated 1.8 percent, said a DGBAS official, who attributed the result to keen competition in commodity prices and drops in house rentals triggered by various preferential measures adopted by the government.
At the same time, the wholesale price index for December stood at 109.97, representing a monthly drop of 1.37 percent and an annual rise of 7.06 percent, the DGBAS tallies show.

The official said that the decrease in the December CPI index was mainly because of continued drops in prices for petrochemical materials, computers and related peripherals, as well as for electronic parts and components.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT TOUTS TAIWAN'S ACHIEVEMENTS IN ANIMAL DISEASE PREVENTION

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Wednesday that Taiwan will become a foot-and-mouth disease (FMD) -free country without the need for vaccination if no cases are reported by this May.
Chen made the remarks while meeting with Herbert Schneider, chairman of the World Veterinary Association, who is visiting Taipei.
The president said he was very happy to meet with the chief of the 142-year-old world veterinary organization on the eve of Taiwan's 33rd Veterinarians Day.

He told his guest that Taiwan was declared a vaccine-using FMD-free country in May 2003. So long as no FMD cases are reported by May, Chen said, Taiwan will be upgraded to the rank of a non-vaccine-using FMD-free country.
Over the past half-century, Chen said, the Republic of China government, veterinarians and ordinary citizens have made concerted efforts to combat animal diseases.

"In 1950, Taiwan managed to eliminate rinderpest or cattle plague, while rabies has been eliminated since 1959, " Chen said, adding that Taiwan has also made remarkable achievements in prevention of avian flu outbreaks, foodstuff hygiene inspection as well as plant and animal quarantine.

Taiwan joined the World Veterinary Association in 1986. "We have since played an active role in the organization and have participated in various international animal disease-control activities, " Chen said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN HOTELS TO PROVIDE CONDOMS TO PREVENT AIDS

TEXT.P: The Legislative Yuan's health, environment and social welfare committee finished Wednesday its review of a proposed amendment to the AIDS Prevention Act which will require local hotels and bath houses to provide condoms for their customers.
If they fail to do so, operators can be fined up to NT$150,000, according to the bill.

The bill also relaxes the restrictions on foreign AIDS/HIV patients and those from mainland China and Hong Kong wishing to visit Taiwan. They will be permitted to visit once every three months at the most and to stay for no more than 14 days during each visit.

If a foreign national contracts AIDS/HIV from his or her Taiwanese spouse in Taiwan, the authorities cannot use the infection as a reason to reject his or her application for visa or residency, the bill stipulates.
In addition, AIDS/HIV carriers have the obligation to disclose the source of their infection and contacts and to report their infection to health care workers, the bill states.
There are 6,762 AIDS/HIV recorded patients in Taiwan, 93 percent of whom are men and 7 percent of whom are women, according to the Department of Health.
Ninety-three percent of the patients are Taiwanese, compared with just 3 percent who are foreign nationals.
One-third of these patients, or 2,334 people, are homosexuals.

DOC.HEADLINE: POLL SHOWS LOW APPROVAL RATING FOR OUTGOING LEGISLATURE

TEXT.P: More than 60 percent of the people who responded to a recent opinion poll said they were dissatisfied with the performance of the outgoing fifth Legislative Yuan, private pollsters said Wednesday.

The Taiwan Thinktank, the Taipei Society and the Taiwan Bar Association jointly conducted the telephone survey from Dec. 21-23 to explore public opinion on the performance of the fifth legislature, whose tenure will conclude at the end of this month. A total of 1,084 valid samples were collected, with a margin of error of 3 percent.
According to the survey, 63 percent said they were dissatisfied with the legislature's performance, compared to 19 percent who gave a thumbs-up to its general performance.

Major problems in legislative operations as cited by the respondents included legislators' grandstanding (62%) ; corruption (46%); poor professionalism (42%) ; low legislative efficiency (40%); and bad work attitude (36%).

An overwhelming majority of 89 percent said lawmakers should be subject to supervision, with 26 percent saying private groups are most capable of supervising the legislature, 18 percent citing the media as the best supervisor, 14 percent naming the judicial authorities and 13 percent citing the Control Yuan.

Ninety-one percent said lawmakers should focus on public policy issues, while 74 percent said a law should be enacted to ban lawmakers from concurrently serving as CEOs of private profit-making businesses.
Fifty-six percent said the Legislative Yuan speaker should withdraw from party activities to maintain neutrality in legislative operations, while 22 percent said they thought otherwise.
Meanwhile, 54 percent said the legislature's four-month interpellation session for the premier and Cabinet ministers is too lengthy, but 29 percent did not agree.
Up to 84 percent said the premier and his ministers should be given an equally long time as the lawmakers to field questions and explain public policies.

Seventy percent said they support the launch of a TV channel to give live unedited broadcasts of legislative operations, but 21 percent said they oppose such a proposal, while 78 percent said such broadcasts could help the public better understand legislative operations and 14 percent said such broadcasts would not be helpful.

Asked if the legislature will form an impartial and objective commission to investigate controversial events, 68 percent said the commission should be formed by scholars and experts, compared to 14 percent who said the commission should be formed by party representatives in proportion to the number of seats controlled by the various parties.

As to interaction between the executive and legislative branches, 44 percent said they thought the legislature has the upper hand, while 24 percent said the Cabinet tended to adopt a tougher posture. Forty-two percent said the Cabinet is more efficient in promoting public policies, while 32 percent gave a higher mark to the legislature.

Asked which organ is most capable of supervising the executive branch, 24 percent cited the legislature, 20 percent named the media, 18 percent mentioned the Control Yuan and 12 percent cited judicial agencies.

DOC.HEADLINE: TSUNAMI IMPACT ON TAIWAN ECONOMY SMALL: CEPD

TEXT.P: The impact on the Taiwan economy of the Dec. 26 earthquake and tsunami that devastated countries in Southeast Asia and South Asia will be small, a spokesman for the Cabinet-level Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) said Wednesday.

The CEPD official made the comment on the grounds that economic ties between Taiwan and the member states of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) and India -- major victims of the appalling catastrophe -- are not very frequent or close.
As of the end of Sept. 2004, direct investment from Taiwan in ASEAN member countries and India totaled US$44.9 billion and US$110 million, respectively.

During the first 11 months of last year, Taiwan outbound shipments to ASEAN countries hit US$20.9 billion, while imports from that trade bloc reached US$18.6 billion, accounting for 13.1 percent and 12.2 percent, respectively, of the country's total volumes.

In the same 11-month period, Taiwan exports to countries in South Asia (India and Sri Lanka) were worth US$120 million, while inbound shipments from the two countries totaled US$800 million, making up 0.8 percent and 0.5 percent of the country's overall levels, respectively.

In view of the relatively low trade volumes, subsequent effects of the disaster on the domestic economy will be limited, the official claimed, pointing out that wintering tourists may in turn even flock to Taiwan and other countries such as Australia and New Zealand.

According to foreign wire services, the economic impact of one of the world's worst natural disasters is expected to be minimal in the Southeast Asia and South Asia regions in the long term. The earthquake and killer waves caused no major damage to the infrastructure of most of the affected countries, the reports added.
An economist was reported as saying that the overall impact would be slight, as no major industrial or infrastructure facilities were affected.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC ENVOY DEMANDS EXPLANATION FOR HONG KONG VISA SNUB

TEXT.P: Taiwan's top representative to Hong Kong asked the Hong Kong government Wednesday to explain why it rejected Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou's visa application.
Pao Cheng-kang, managing director of Chung Hwa Travel Service, said the Hong Kong authorities had yet to answer his question as of Wednesday afternoon.

As the Hong Kong government reportedly has suggested that Ma's local sponsor, the University of Hong Kong, postpone its invitation to Ma until April, Pao said there may still be a chance the Hong Kong authorities might change their decision. In any case, Pao said, the Republic of China government will make an appropriate response after receiving an explanation from the Hong Kong authorities.
Ma was originally scheduled to visit Hong Kong Jan.11-13, but the Hong Kong authorities declined to issue him a visa. The move drew broadsides from the Hong Kong media.
In Taipei, Cabinet spokesman Chen Chi-mai said that if the Hong Kong government fails to give a reasonable explanation, the ROC government will lodge a protest.
Pao said people in both Taiwan and Hong Kong want normal exchanges between the two sides. "We hope the Hong Kong authorities can explain its stance on the issue," he added.

Ma was invited to deliver a speech on the rise of Chinese urban development from Taipei's perspective at the University of Hong Kong Jan. 11 and to attend a Taipei tourism promotion activity and seminar at the Hong Kong University of Science and Technology Jan. 12.

Ma, who was born in the former British territory, said Wednesday that the Hong Kong government's denial of his visa application has prompted him to think that Taiwan-Hong Kong relations are regressing.

He recalled that during a visit he made to Hong Kong four years ago, he held a 90-minute meeting with Hong Kong Chief Executive Tung Chee Hwa. "And now I cannot even secure a permit to enter Hong Kong. What a big change in our bilateral relations," Ma said.
According to Hong Kong media reports, Ma was denied entry to Hong Kong probably because of his opposition to Beijing's "anti-secession law."

DOC.HEADLINE: INDONESIA REJECTS TAIWAN'S REQUEST TO ATTEND RELIEF CONFERENCE

TEXT.P: Indonesia has turned down Taiwan's request to take part in an international conference Thursday in Jakarta to coordinate relief efforts for the tsunami-hit nations around the Indian Ocean.

An anonymous official from Taiwan's representative office in Jakarta told CNA Wednesday that the conference organized by the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) , is open only to the member states of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) and the United Nations.

Since Taiwan is not a member of either body, Indonesia, which is hosting the conference, has no intention of inviting Taiwan despite the country's promise of generous aid to countries ravaged by a magnitude-9.0 earthquake Dec. 26 in Indonesia and the subsequent tsunami it triggered.

The Jakarta conference was initiated by Singapore Premier Lee Hsien Loong. In addition to ASEAN leaders, Japanese Prime Minister Junichiro Koizumi, Australian Prime Minister John Howard, mainland Chinese Prime Minister Wen Jiabao, New Zealand Prime Minister Helen Clark, South Korean Prime Minister Lee Hae-chan, U.S. Secretary of State Colin Powell and E.U. Commission President Jose Manuel Barroso will also attend the meeting.
Republic of China Foreign Minister Tan Sun Chen said in Taipei the previous day that his country would be content with a chance to sit in on the conference as an observer.

Noting that Taiwan, which has promised US$50 million in aid to the disaster-hit nations, is the world's eighth-biggest single donor thus far, Chen said Taiwan deserves a seat at the conference table, adding that he hopes Indonesia will help Taiwan get into the conference.

DOC.HEADLINE: CABINET TO RESIGN JAN. 24: OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: The Cabinet will resign during an extraordinary Cabinet meeting to be held Jan. 24 so that the new legislature can be inaugurated Feb. 1, an official of the Executive Yuan disclosed Wednesday.

As the fifth Legislative Yuan is scheduled to conclude its last session Jan. 31 and President Chen Shui-bian is planning to begin a visit to several Republic of China diplomatic allies in the South Pacific Jan. 27, Premier Yu Shyi-kun accepted the Central Personnel Administration-proposed date of Jan. 24 for the resignation of the Cabinet, the official said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TWO TAIWAN MEDICAL TEMAS ARRIVE IN TSUNAMI DISASTER AREAS

TEXT.P: Two medical teams organized by the Taipei Hospital under the Cabinet-level Department of Health (DOH) arrived on the Thai island of Phuket and in Sri Lanka Tuesday to help victims of the Dec. 26 tsunami disaster, a hospital spokesman said Wednesday.

Members of the medical aid mission to Phuket, led by Chen Hung, superintendent of the DOH's Bali Mental Hospital, headed for the disaster area of Phang Nga in the north of Phuket to offer their medical services shortly after meeting with the Phuket vice governor, according to the spokesman.

Quoting a report from the delegation chief, the spokesman said that nearly 4,000 people are feared dead and 4,000 are still missing, adding that DNA testing of the victims to ascertain identities is currently the most urgent job. The mission is scheduled to return to Taiwan next Monday.
The spokesman further said that the other mission to Sri Lankan took with them 1,000 kg of medicine and medical supplies to the disaster area where they will remain for six days.

DOC.HEADLINE: PFP CHIEF MIGHT CONSIDER HEADING PEACE-PROMOTION COMMITTEE

TEXT.P: People First Party (PFP) Chairman James Soong might consider leading a committee for peace across the Taiwan strait if a bill initiated by the PFP for that purpose is passed by the Legislative Yuan, a PFP lawmaker said Wednesday.

Lu Hsueh-chang, the co-convener of the PFP caucus at the Legislative Yuan, said the PFP-proposed bill for promoting peace across the Taiwan Straits would provide a platform for a resumption of dialogue between Taiwan and mainland China.
If it is passed before the Legislative Yuan goes into recess by the end of this month, Soong might consider heading such a peace-promotion committee, Lu said.
The PFP will make the similar proposal again in the new legislature if the bill fails to be enacted in this legislative session, Lu said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Thursday, Jan. 6, or the 26th day of the 11th month of the Year of the Monkey according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1066: Harold II, the last of the Anglo-Saxon monarchs, is crowned king of England. He succeeded Edward the Confessor and was killed fighting the invasion by William the Conqueror.
1412: Joan of Arc, the French heroine who fought to drive the British from France, is born.
1838: Samuel Morse, an American painter and inventor, demonstrates a revolutionary electromagnetic telegraph that promises to open up a new world in long-distance communication.
1884: Gregor Mendel, the Austrian monk and botanist who discovered the principles which govern the inheritance of characteristics in living things, dies at the age of 62.
1912: New Mexico becomes the 47th state of the United States.
1916: Dr. Sun Yat-sen orders Chen Chiung-ming to revolt in Kwangchow (Canton).
1919: Theodore Roosevelt, the American president who occupied the White House for two terms, dies at Oyster Bay after a life dedicated to politics, literature and adventure.
1925: Chiang Kai-shek, commandant of the Whampoa Military Academy, drafts a law governing the conduct of the National Revolutionary Army to smooth the process of the Northern Expedition.
1925: Kim Dae Jung, South Korean opposition leader and later president and Nobel Peace Prize winner, is born.
1930: The ROC's Examination Yuan is formally established, with Tai Chuan-hsien serving as president and Sun Fo as vice president.
1935: The Chinese Communists, who had rebelled against the Nationalist government, convene a political bureau meeting in Chunyi, Kweichow province.
1941: U.S. President Franklin D. Roosevelt defines the American goal of the "Four Freedoms" -- freedom of speech, freedom of worship, freedom from want, and freedom from fear.
1946: The headquarters of Gen. Douglas MacArthur, who accepted the surrender of Japan, declares that Ando Rikichi, the last Japanese governor of Taiwan, is a war criminal.
1946: Elections in the Democratic Republic of Vietnam result in Ho Chi Minh becoming the head of the government.
1950: The Republic of China severs diplomatic relations with Britain following Britain's recognition of the communist regime.
1961: At least 5,000 people die of hunger in Tibet.
1974: Rep. Benjamin A. Gilman, Republican from New York, and Rep. William Clay, Democrat from Missouri, arrive in Taipei for a weeklong visit.
1975: Col. Federico Castillo Yanes, El Salvador's deputy minister of national defense and public security, arrives in Taipei for a five-day visit.
1976: Taiwan suffers an islandwide power failure for the first time since the end of the war.
1977: The "Hai Kung" departs from Capetown, South Africa, to continue its voyage of exploration to the South Pole.
1991: A memorandum is signed between the ROC and Saudi Arabia for the mutual establishment of representative offices in their capital cities.
2000: Nasir Ahmed Sooro, listed as the world's tallest (236.2 cm) person by the Guinness Book of World Records, meets with Taiwan's shortest (67.5 cm) man, Lin Yu-chih.
2001: Ali Alatas, former Indonesian foreign minister under Suharto and B.J. Habibi, says in Singapore that the proposed ASEAN plus-three forum should be expanded to include Taiwan, Hong Kong, Australia, and New Zealand.
2001: The Taiwan Electrical and Electronic Manufacturers Association urges the government to open direct shipping links with mainland China as soon as possible.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "A wise man, in his judgment of the world, has no predilections or prejudices; he is on the side of what is right."
