DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
Manila Bulletin: World leaders converge in Jakarta
BANDA ACEH, Indonesia (AFP) -- World leaders headed Wednesday to Indonesia to see first-hand the massive operation to save millions of tsunami victims as the United Nations suggested the catastrophe could end up being one of the deadliest natural disasters ever recorded.
The Philippine Daily Inquirer: 50 Filipinos working in Burmese resort safe
SOME 50 Filipinos working in a coastal entertainment spot in Burma (Myanmar) were safe following the deadly tsunamis that struck countries along the Indian Ocean, Foreign Secretary Alberto Romulo yesterday said.
The Philippine Star: Gov't appeals Piatco ruling
The Office of the Solicitor General asked the Pasay City regional trial court (RTC) yesterday to reconsider its ruling ordering the government to pay an initial $62 million as "just compensation" to the Philippine International Air Terminals Co. (Piatco), builder of the Ninoy Aquino International Airport Terminal 3 (NAIA-3).
The Manila Times: Baguio declares 'meningo' calamity
Baguio City: The city government has declared a state of calamity following the sharp rise in meningococcemia cases, a disease city officials thought had been contained.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
Los Angeles Times: Social Security Battle Likely.
Two groups of prominent Democratic centrists plan to oppose the centerpiece of President Bush's proposal to restructure Social Security, potentially dimming administration hopes of building bipartisan support for its top domestic priority.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA TO FOLLOW LEGISLATIVE RESOLUTION IN NAME-CHANGE PROGRAM

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs will not begin a program to include the word "Taiwan" in the names of the country's overseas missions and state-owned enterprises until the Legislative Yuan approves, ministry spokesman Michel Lu said Thursday.

Lu said that the foreign ministry will follow a resolution passed by the Legislative Yuan Wednesday stipulating that the foreign ministry must obtain consent from the legislative committee of foreign and Chinese affairs as well as the entire Executive Yuan prior to making the changes.
Lu added that the foreign ministry must also get the consent of the governments of the countries where such changes could take place before altering any designations.

President Chen Shui-bian advocated late last year that the word "Taiwan" be included in the names of the nation's overseas missions and state-owned enterprises to highlight a separate national identity from mainland China.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. REITERATES SUPPORT FOR PEACEFUL RESOLUTION OF CROSS-STRAIT ISSUES
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Jan. 5 (CNA) (By Oliver Lin and P. C. Tang)

TEXT.P: The U.S. State Department on Wednesday reiterated its long-standing position in support of a peaceful resolution of differences between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait.

According to the State Department, Deputy Secretary of State Richard Armitage met with Chen Yunlin, director of the Taiwan Affairs Office under Beijing's State Council, the same day and had a candid, informative and constructive discussion on various cross-strait issues, including mainland China's proposed "anti-secession law."
"We conveyed the long-standing position of the United States that the two sides [of the Taiwan Strait] should engage in dialogue to peacefully resolve their differences," the State Department said.
It also said that "neither side should do anything that unilaterally changes the status quo or complicates management of this sensitive issue."
The purpose of Chen's visit in Washington, D.C. was to explain Beijing's proposed "anti-secession law" to U.S. authorities, although he did not bring the draft of the law with him.

Taiwan's ranking officials in charge of mainland affairs have said that mainland China's plan to promulgate such a law is not only a provocation of Taiwan but also a unilateral move to change the status quo across the Taiwan Strait.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT OFFICIALS TO GO TO MAINLAND FOR TALKS ON HOLIDAY CHARTER FLIGHTS

TEXT.P: The opposition Kuomintang (KMT) will send a delegation to Beijing shortly to help the private sector arrange direct charter flights across the Taiwan Strait during the upcoming Chinese Lunar New Year holiday for mainland-based Taiwan business people, KMT spokesman Chang Jung-kung said Thursday.

Chang said that he, KMT Central Polity Committee CEO Tseng Yung-chuan and KMT Legislators John Chang and Chu Feng-chih will accompany representatives from six Taiwan airlines to Beijing, hopefully prior to Jan. 15, to meet officials from the Civil Aviation Administration of China for talks.

Chang Jung-kung stressed that the KMT will mainly play the role of "conduit" to accelerate the charter flight arrangements. There is just over a month before new year's day, which falls on Feb. 9 this year.

Mainland authorities earlier demanded that both mainland and Taiwan carriers be allowed to operate cross-strait charter flights to three mainland destinations -- Shanghai, Beijing and Guangzhou. Given the time constraint and the need to make the necessary arrangements, it is likely that not all of the mainland's demands can be met, Chang Jung-kung said.

Therefore, he said that the most feasible way of implementing the program would be to model it after the system used in 2003 in which only Taiwan carriers operated the special charter flight services and only to Shanghai.
He said that there is some hope that Beijing will assent to the proposal and add on Beijing and Guangzhou to the flight list, adding that making the routes truly non-stop would be a bonus.

The service that was in place in 2003 was "direct" only in name as flights had to stop first in either Hong Kong of Macau; however, unlike regular flights where passengers had to change planes in these third places, the "direct" flights allowed passengers to remain on the same plane they had boarded, the stopover being more of a formality than a necessity.
The KMT claimed Jan. 2 that with the consent of relevant government authorities, non-stop, two-way, three-destination cross-strait charter flights could start "at any time."

The 2003 Chinese Lunar New Year holiday services were offered by six carriers from Taiwan, but were discontinued the following year because Beijing insisted that mainland carriers also be allowed to provide the same flight services but refused to negotiate the necessary technical details with Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: PUBLIC URGED TO DONATE BLOOD TO MAKE UP FOR SEASONAL SHORTAGE

TEXT.P: Taiwan Blood Services Foundation on Thursday appealed for the public to donate blood, saying that all six of the island's blood banks are running low.

Foundation Chairman Lin Kuo-hsin made the appeal at a news conference to announce the beginning of a month-long blood donation drive starting Friday. A letter from President Chen Shui-bian urging the public to donate blood was also read.
Lin noted that blood banks in Taipei, Hsinchu, Taichung, Tainan, Kaohsiung and Hualien have less than a one-week safe supply each. The blood bank in Taipei has less than a five-day stock.

Lin said the public donated 2.33 million units (one unit equals 250 cc) in 2004, which met medical needs. But he said that there is always a seasonal supply and demand imbalance, adding that blood shortages often occur during the Chinese Lunar New Year holiday.

Chang Ying-er, chief executive officer of the foundation, said that with the declining birth rate, the reform of compulsory military service and the busy schedule of students, young people are less inclined to donate blood, a shortfall that will have to be make up by the general public. He said that "new blood" is urgently needed.

In line with the blood donation drive, E.Sun Bank has announced that it will give points to blood donors which they can redeem for gifts, while Noble Family steakhouse and a dumpling restaurant also said that they would give discounts or coupons to those who donate blood.

DOC.HEADLINE: WANTED MAN EXTRADITED TO TAIWAN TO FACE CHARGES OF FRAUD

TEXT.P: A man wanted in Taiwan for fraud since August 2003 was escorted back to the country from Palau, sources from the Ministry of Justice Investigation Bureau (MJIB) said Thursday.
Chiang Kuang-yeh was escorted by police back to Taipei from the South Pacific island country around noon Thursday and was immediately taken into custody by the MJIB.

According to MJIB investigators, Chiang began to run advertisements in major daily newspapers in Taiwan to attract investments in the Palau Evergreen International Hotel, which the ad claimed to be a failsafe investment with investors enjoying ownership of units in the hotel and having guaranteed regular returns on their investment.

An unknown number of investors around Taiwan discovered that they had been conned after the hotel ran an ad several months later to announce that the hotel had never authorized Chiang to raise money in Taiwan nor contracted him to be a sales manager.
Chiang fled Taiwan and was reported to have been living mainly in Palau.
The amount of money involved is not known.

After the Taipei District Prosecutors' Office issued a warrant for Chiang's arrest on Aug. 23, 2003, the Palau government expressed its willingness on Oct. 19 of the same year to help Taiwan police round up Chiang.

The cooperative efforts in successfully having Chiang returned to Taiwan to face justice were made by officials from the two sides in charge of affairs of the Asia Pacific Group on Money Laundering, in which both Taiwan and Palau are full members.

Taiwan and Palau, which have formal diplomatic relations, are also shortly expected to sign an agreement on cooperation for the exchange of intelligence related to money laundering and terrorist financing, MJIB officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT COULD COME TO THE TABLE IF DPP IS SINCERE: LEGISLATIVE SPEAKER

TEXT.P: The opposition Kuomintang (KMT) is willing to discuss issues with the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) if it is sincere in its offer of party-to-party talks, KMT Chairman Lien Chan was quoted by Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng Thursday as saying.

Wang met Lien Wednesday to talk about the speaker's upcoming meeting with President Chen Shui-bian and to exchange views on current political affairs and possible cooperation with the KMT and the People First Party.
The DPP asked after the Dec. 11, 2004 legislative elections that political bickering end and that parties come together and consult on important issues facing Taiwan.
Wang, also a KMT vice chairman, said that no one knows the true reaction of the KMT to the offer of cooperation.
He said that Lien had kept abreast of the situation, but has made no decision on the matter. However, according to Wang, Lien did say that he was amenable to the idea if the DPP was sincere.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI SHARE PRICES END LOWER

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange closed lower Thursday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving down 6.25 points to close at 5,982.12.
The bourse opened at 5,988.72 and fluctuated between 6,002.52 and 5,971.58 during trading. A total of 2.38 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$45.04 billion (US$1.4 billion).
Only one of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with banking and financial shares moving up at 0.4 percent.

Seven other major stock categories lost ground, with textile stocks moving down the most at 1 percent, followed by cement stocks and machinery and electronics shares, both at 0.3 percent, and foodstuff issues, plastics and chemicals shares, paper and pulp issues and construction issues, all at 0.1 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 429 to 280, with 172 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CHEN TO VISIT NATIONS IN SOUTH PACIFIC

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian will visit ROC allies in the South Pacific later this month and attend the inauguration ceremony of the president of Palau, officials of the Presidential Office said Thursday.
The officials said that President Chen will leave Taiwan Jan. 27, to attend the inauguration ceremony of Tommy Remengesau, Jr. on Jan. 28, and then go to one or two allies in the South Pacific.
During his trip, the president's plane could refuel in either Guam or Saipan.

The officials said that the president will visit all five allies of Taiwan in the South Pacific -- Palau, the Solomon Islands, Tuvalu, Kiribati and the Marshall Islands. If this is not possible, he will probably visit the remaining countries in the latter half of the year.

The officials said that the president should be able to visit one or two other allies in addition to Palau, saying that a working team is currently in the South Pacific to assess and arrange for the visit, and the countries th president will visit will be finalized after the team's return.
The team reported that Tuvalu could be difficult as it has a small airport, and only one hotel with 30 rooms, and couldn't possibly accommodate the large entourage of the president.
Most of the airport facilities of ROC allies in the South Pacific cannot accommodate takeoffs and landings of large aircraft, so China Airlines will use a 737 passenger plane for the trip.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER PRESIDENT SUPPORTS PARTY-TO-PARTY TALKS

TEXT.P: Former President Lee Teng-hui Thursday offered his full support for President Chen Shui-bian's proposal to set up a mechanism for party-to-party consultations.

The spiritual leader of the opposition Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) told a group of TSU legislators and legislators-elect that the party must support such a mechanism for the sake of the country's political stability, according to TSU legislative caucus convener Wang Tzung-yuan.
Lee said the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) will have the support of the TSU regardless of which party the DPP plans to cooperate with.
The TSU will also respect President Chen's power to appoint the premier and will not ask for any positions in the government, Lee said.
President Chen proposed in his new year's address to start party-to-party consultations to end the confrontation between the ruling and opposition parties.

DOC.HEADLINE: DEATH BY OVERWORK CRITERIA LOWERED BY LABOR COUNCIL

TEXT.P: The criteria for deciding when a death or a physical breakdown has come about as a result of overwork has been lowered now that the Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) has revised pertinent regulations.
After taking complaints from private organizations and suggestions from specialist groups into account, the CLA amended the existing regulations regarding occupational diseases and deaths.

An official with the CLA's Department of Labor Safety and Health said that the standard for reaching a verdict of death by overwork, known in Japan as "karoshi, " and serious medical conditions, such as a stroke, will not be based solely on work hours now and that other occupational factors will also be included when such a case is judged.

Other occupational factors include irregular work times and work patterns; abnormally long working hours; frequently on business trips; work based on shifts; nighttime jobs and highly intensive work over long periods of time, the official said.
The CLA considers a death to have been caused by overwork when the victim had worked more than 100 hours on extra work during the month prior to his death or if he or she died on the job.
Several private groups protested to the CLA in April last year against the government's harsh standards for judging when death is the result of overwork.

A spokesman for the Taiwan Association for Victims of Occupational Injuries (TAVOI) said that it is unacceptably harsh that the CLA regulates that a verdict of death by overwork can only be applied when an employee has worked for 24 hours continuously before dying or has worked for over 16 hours every day one week before dying.

A spokesman for the Confederation of Taipei Trade Unions also pointed out that the CLA criteria was too narrow, as they relate largely to diseases as the cause of death, but barely mention any reasons concerning working conditions and other social and psychological factors that could be involved.
Many causes of death, including heart attack, stroke and suicide, can be the result of pressure from overworking, but were excluded from the CLA criteria, the spokesman said.

DOC.HEADLINE: COAST GUARD SEARCHES FOR FIVE MISSING CREW AFTER PENGHU SHIPWRECK

TEXT.P: Patrol officers from the Coast Guard Administration (CGA) were searching Thursday for five fishermen who went missing after an overnight shipwreck off the Penghu archipelago.

The 99-ton fishing boat "Tzuhsingman No. 16" from Kaohsiung County was operating off the southwest coast of Chimei, Penghu when the vessel caught fire and started to sink at around 9 p.m. Wednesday, CGA officials said.
All five crew members, who included a mainland Chinese worker, jumped into the sea to try to escape and are missing, they said.
Several patrol ships were dispatched to continue to search for the five men but to no avail as of Thursday afternoon, they added.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES MOSTLY HIGHER ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were mostly higher Thursday as the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for January gained four points to close at 6,017, with 14,673 contracts changing hands.
TAIEX Index futures for February moved up 19 points to finish at 6,033, with 478 contracts traded, while March futures lost five points to finish at 6,008, with five contracts traded.
June futures lost five points to finish at 5,983, with nine contracts traded, while September futures moved up seven points to close at 5,923, with nine contracts traded.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Thursday at 6,013 for January, 6,014 for February, 6,013 for March, 5,988 for June and 5,916 for September.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were mixed.

January TE futures moved down 0.4 points to close at 222.5, with 1,566 contracts traded, while February TE futures gained 0.35 points to finish at 222.45, with 32 contract transactions. March TE futures lost 1.6 points to close at 220.2, with one contract traded.
No transactions were recorded for June and September.
January TF futures gained 7.8 points to finish at 1,034.6, with 1,908 contracts changing hands, while February TF futures moved up 4.8 points to end at 1,029.8, with 43 contracts traded.
No transactions were recorded for March, June and September.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. DOLLAR RISES ON TAIPEI FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar rose against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Thursday, gaining NT$0.119 to close at NT$32.179.
A total of US$941 million changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at NT$32.110 and fluctuated between NT$31.970 and NT$32.184.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Washington Post: In Indonesia, Overrun Hospitals Battle to Save Injured.
Tens of thousands of Acehnese are stranded on the western end of Sumatra island, but the Indonesian military hospital is one of only two functioning hospitals that can receive them in Banda Aceh. The hospitals are overflowing with the wounded, sick and homeless. Doctors vow they can make room when necessary, but teeming wards and backlogged operating tables have restricted their efforts, the paper said.

DOC.HEADLINE: BLOOD DONATION GROUP DROPS "CHINESE" FROM NAME

TEXT.P: The private Chinese Blood Services Foundation has adopted as its new name the "Taiwan Blood Services Foundation" in support of a campaign promoting name-changes for organizations bearing a name similar to those in mainland China, foundation officials said Thursday.
The officials said blood donation in Taiwan is non-paying, self-sufficient and safe, which they said is totally different from the situation on the mainland.
While it costs very little for a civic organization to change its name, the move is very helpful in avoiding confusion, they said.

The pro-independence Alliance to Campaign for Rectifying the Name of Taiwan, supported by former President Lee Teng-hui, has for several years been promoting name-changes for organizations whose names bear the word "China" or "Chinese."
President Chen Shui-bian said last month that the government plans to change the names of Republic of China overseas missions and state-run enterprises to include the word "Taiwan" within two years.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Times: Labour's bickering shatters the silence.
Fresh squabbles broke out yesterday between the rival camps surrounding Tony Blair and Gordon Brown, even as the rest of Britain fell silent for victims of the Asian tsunami. The Prime Minister and the Chancellor were accused of seeking to outbid each other with ever more extravagant promises of aid and international development. Government advisers acknowledged that there was a tug of war between Downing Street and the Treasury over"ownership"of flagship policies for helping the world's poor, as well as control over Labour's election manifesto.
Financial Times: Drug groups to make pledge on disclosure of trials data.
The world's top pharmaceutical companies will today undertake to publish more data about clinical trials of their drugs, in an effort to reassure patients about the safety of their medicines. The move, which is also designed to head off legislation demanding disclosure, comes as fresh allegations surface that US scientists manipulated trials of an anti-Aids drug to make it seem more effective, thereby endangering patients' lives.

DOC.HEADLINE: MEDICAL TEAM DEPARTS FOR INDONESIA TO HELP TSUNAMI VICTIMS

TEXT.P: A three-member medical team from the Taichung Hospital under the Cabinet-level Department of Health departed Thursday for Medan, Indonesia, according to officials of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs.

The medical team, including a doctor and two medical workers, will set up a medical station to help victims of the tsunami spawned by the Dec. 26 earthquake under the Indian Ocean, the officials said.
The medical team, formed through coordination between the ministry and the Department of Health, is scheduled to remain there for seven to 10 days, they said.
The ministry has already contacted the Taipei Economic and Trade Office in Jakarta to make sure it helps the team, they added.

DOC.HEADLINE: CLA CALLS FOR HELP FOR FOREIGN WORKERS FROM TSUNAMI-HIT COUNTRIES

TEXT.P: The Cabinet-level Council for Labor Affairs (CLA) has called for help for foreign workers from countries affected by the recent tsunami, urging Taiwan employers to aid those of their employees who are in need.

The Dec. 26 earthquake and ensuing tsunami have hit many countries in South and Southeast Asia and the CLA called on domestic business owners and brokers to do their best to offer assistance to needy workers introduced from countries devastated by one of the world's worst natural catastrophes.
India, Sri Lanka, Indonesia and Thailand were hit the hardest.

According to Taiwan labor brokerages, they have so far not received any appeals for help or assistance from workers from the affected countries, as most of Taiwan's alien workers from Southeast Asia are not from the damaged areas, which include the island of Sumatra in northern Indonesia and southern regions of Thailand.
Indonesian workers in Taiwan mainly come from Java, while Thai workers mostly come from northern parts of the country, they explained.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI MEDICAL TEAM TO LEAVE FOR INDONESIA FOR TSUNAMI RELIEF

TEXT.P: A medical team organized by the Taipei city government is set to leave for Indonesia Friday to help victims of the Dec. 26 earthquake and tsunami disaster.
The 16-member team led by Ko Ming-chung, head of the Taipei Municipal Chung Hsing Hospital, will fly first to Medan on the island of Sumatra and then go to worst-hit Aceh province.
The team plans to stay there for one week.
Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou Thursday expressed hope that the team members will serve as Taiwan goodwill ambassadors and provide relief to the tsunami victims.

He pointed out that rescue teams from 38 countries came to Taiwan after the disastrous earthquake of Sept. 21, 1999 and added that Taiwan must not sit idly when a disaster has occurred in another country.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAINLAND CHINA CARRIERS TO BE ALLOWED TO RUN NEW YEAR CHARTER FLIGHTS

TEXT.P: To be on par with their Taiwan counterparts, mainland Chinese carriers are in principle allowed to offer special lunar new year charter flight services for Taiwan businessmen wishing to return to Taiwan for the holiday period, a government spokesman said Thursday.
Chen Chi-mai, spokesman for the Executive Yuan, said that mainland-based aviation companies will be allowed to offer the flights as long as the two sides can reach a final agreement in this regard.

Chen added, however, that Taiwan has yet to receive any formal applications by mainland airlines seeking to offer the special flights between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait, nor has the government been informed of the situation by the Civil Aviation Administration of China.

Chen's remarks came after local media reported that Xiamen Airlines has gained approval from Hong Kong to operate Xiamen-Taipei and Xiamen-Kaohsiung charter flights for homebound and returning Taiwan businessmen and their dependents in the new year holiday season early next month.
According to the Cabinet spokesman, Taiwan and the mainland have forged much common ground on the model for "non stop, round trip" flights by carriers on both sides."
The Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) has commissioned the Taipei Airlines Association to hold technical talks with the mainland side to clear the way for the service, he noted.

The special flights were launched for the first time in 2003 using only Taiwan carriers, but the service failed to proceed in 2004 due to the mainland's insistence on mainland carriers being allowed to also offer flights and its refusal to hold technical talks on the issue as a result of cross-strait tension.

There have been no direct trade, transport and postal links between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait since 1949, when the now-opposition Kuomintang lost a civil war to communist forces and fled to Taiwan.

To compensate for the absence of the links, the Kinmen and Matsu islands held by Taiwan initiated direct trade and transport services with the Xiamen and Mamei ports in mainland China's Fujian Province on a trial basis starting from Jan. 1, 2001 -- commonly known as the "three mini links."

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT TO VISIT PALAU, SOLOMON ISLANDS

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian will visit Palau and the Solomon Islands -- two of the Republic of China's allies in the South Pacific -- later this month, Foreign Affairs Minister Tan Sun Chen said Thursday.
Chen said the president will leave Jan. 27 for the visit and will visit three other ROC allies in the South Pacific at a later date.

Chen made the remarks on the sidelines of a donation ceremony in Taoyuan, northern Taiwan, of relief supplies by 16 non-governmental organizations bound for the tsunami-affected areas in South Asia and Southeast Asia.

Chen said the president had originally wanted to visit all five allies in the South Pacific -- which also include Kiribati, Tuvalu and the Marshall Islands -- but out of consideration of the imminent Cabinet reshuffle and various other factors, he was unable to.
This will be his second official overseas visit since he assumed his second term as president May 20. He visited the Central American states of Panama and Belize in early September.
The foreign minister said that Chen will attend the inauguration ceremony of President Tommy Remengesau, Jr. Jan. 28 before going on to the Solomon Islands.

In line with constitutional precedent, the premier and Cabinet must resign before a new Legislative Yuan is sworn in. Premier Yu Shyi-kun said Wednesday that he and his Cabinet will bow out Jan. 24. The new legislature will be sworn in Feb. 1.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER AIT CHAIRWOMAN URGES TAIWAN TO SHOW RESOLVE TO DEFEND ITSELF

TEXT.P: Visiting former American Institute in Taiwan (AIT) Chairwoman Therese Shaheen urged Taiwan Thursday to show the world its resolve to defend itself by speeding up its NT$610.8 billion (US$18.23 billion) arms procurement deal with the United States.
Shaheen said the deal is one of the crucial factors in Taiwan-U.S. relations.

It upsets Washington to see Taipei keep issuing inflammatory rhetoric that is likely to intensify tension across the Taiwan Strait when the budget bill for the arms procurement is being shelved by the Legislative Yuan, Shaheen said.
The arms procurement package includes eight diesel-electric submarines, a squadron of 12 P-3C Orion submarine-hunting aircraft and six Patriot PAC-3 anti-missile batteries.
In what has raised much discussion in Taiwan, U.S. Deputy Secretary of State Richard Armitage said last month that Taiwan is "probably the biggest landmine" in Washington-Beijing relations.

Armitage also said that the Taiwan Relations Act requires the United States to maintain sufficient force in the Pacific to be able to deter attack but does not require the country to defend Taiwan should it come under attack from the mainland.

There has been speculation that Armitage's remarks were related to the delay of the arms procurement package by Taiwan's opposition and announcements by President Chen Shui-bian that he plans to hold a referendum in 2006 for a new constitution and to change the names of Republic of China overseas missions and state-run enterprises in two years.
Shaheen, who resigned in April 2004 from the AIT post as the top Washington liaison officer with Taipei in the absence of diplomatic ties, arrived in Taiwan Wednesday for a weeklong private visit.
This is her second trip to Taiwan since her resignation.

DOC.HEADLINE: FM REGRETS TAIWAN'S EXCLUSION FROM TSUNAMI RELIEF SUMMIT

TEXT.P: Minister of Foreign Affairs Tan San Chen voiced his regret Thursday over Taiwan's exclusion from a world tsunami relief summit to be held in Jakarta, saying that his ministry will try to talk separately with each of the attending countries afterward.
Chen made the comment after taking part in a charity activity in northern Taoyuan County to aid tsunami refugees in South and Southeast Asia.

Strongly lamenting Taiwan's absence from the international meeting organized by the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN), Chen said that the Foreign Ministry will continue to express the country's keen desire to participate in the global relief efforts.
In addition to the ASEAN member states, Australia, Japan, mainland China, New Zealand, South Korea, the European Union and the United States are also involved in the cross-border aid campaign.
According to Chen, Taiwan has asked the United States to help seek consent from the participating countries for its participation in the drive, but no concrete response has been given so far.
Indonesia turned down Taiwan's request to attend the meeting as an observer prior to its start, saying reason that ASEAN includes no observers.

Taiwan is the world's 8th-largest donor toward the disaster relief, having promised to contribute US$50 million in aid to countries hit by the Dec. 26 earthquake and ensuing tsunami -- one of the world's worst natural catastrophes that has killed nearly 160,000 people so far.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The New York Times: World Leaders Vow to Aid Tsunami Victims.
World leaders pledged Thursday to work together to help tsunami-shattered regions recover from the worst natural disaster in living memory, saying it was a race against time to get aid to survivors before they succumb to disease.
Wall Street Journal: At Jakarta Summit, the U.N. Asserts Control of Tsunami Aid Efforts.
The U.N. asserted its control over the massive humanitarian effort to help victims of the tsunami, asking the U.S. to take a supporting role, as world leaders met at an emergency summit in Jakarta.

DOC.HEADLINE: ECONOMIC AFFAIRS MINISTER INSPECTS YUNLIN INDUSTRIAL PARK

TEXT.P: Economic Affairs Minister Ho Mei-yueh expressed hope Thursday that Formosa Plastics Group (FPG) and the state-run Chinese Petroleum Corp. (CPC) can engage in positive competition as she inspected an industrial park in Yunlin County, southern Taiwan.
Ho made the remarks as both domestic giants have expressed keen interests in the park, which is built on land reclaimed from the sea.

CPC wants to build a petrochemical science park that will require 1,800 hectares of land and an investment of NT$370 billion (US$11.56 billion), while FPG has announced that it intends to invest NT$130 billion to build a steel refinery requiring 600 hectares.

As the land eyed by both groups overlaps, the economic affairs minister, Industrial Development Bureau (IDB) Director-General Chen Chao-yih, and Legislators Hsu Su-po and Chiu Tsui-tseng went to the industrial park Thursday for an inspection.
The petrochemical park planned by the CPC would have complete upper-, middle- and down-stream sectors to naphtha cracker plants, and the private sector is interested in the project, sources said.
Ho therefore invited representatives of both CPC and FPG for a consultation in the hope that both projects can be carried out through a series of land adjustments.

Ho also noted that the IDB has commissioned consultants to analyse the possibility of both projects, hoping that both groups will not vie for the same land. If this is impossible, the ministry will have to resort to the timing of the applications to give priority, or putting the land to a bid to settle the dilemma, she added.

Reports have said that the Yunlin park has become suddenly "hot" mainly because the Kyoto Protocol will take effect in February and the government will have to start to monitor CO2 emissions, which will present uncertainties to energy-consuming big investment projects.
The Yunlin industrial park has already completed its environmental impact assessment a long time ago, which will dramatically shorten the needed time of interested parties to build factories there.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT'S TOP AIDE SOLICITS SUPPORT FOR DPP CHAIRMAN BID

TEXT.P: The secretary-general of the Presidential Office started an islandwide trip in Taichung, central Taiwan, Thursday to solicit support for his unopposed bid for the chairmanship of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP).

The election of the party chairman will be held Jan. 30 and although Su Tseng-chang is the sole candidate in the by-election, he decided to travel around the island at the suggestion of the DPP Central Standing Committee to display his sincerity by meeting with grassroots party members, as well as to solicit their support and increase his votes.

Su is not relying on the party machinery to assist him in the islandwide get-out-the-vote drive but instead has adopted a low profile and will mostly meet the members of DPP local branches at a series of year-end banquets.

The by-election became necessary after President Chen Shui-bian, who concurrently served as party chairman, stepped down to take responsibility for the party's worse-than-expected performance in the Dec. 11 legislative elections. The DPP garnered 89 seats, less than the original estimate of more than 100 seats in the 225-member Legislative Yuan.

DOC.HEADLINE: 'LOVE FROM TAIWAN' DONATIONS FOR TSUNAMI VICTIMS READY TO BE SHIPPED

TEXT.P: Sixteen non-government organizations delivered to Minister of Foreign Affairs Tan Sun Chen Thursday some 60 tons of materials and NT$110 million (US$3.71 million) in cash that they have collected in Taiwan for shipment to the tsunami victims in South Asia and Southeast Asia.

Speaking at a ceremony held at a warehouse near the Chiang Kai-shek International Airport in Taoyuan, northern Taiwan, Chen praised the civic organizations for their benevolence in terms of disaster relief and told them that the government will arrange for the goods to be shipped as soon as possible.
All of the donated materials will bear a "Love from Taiwan" sticker to allow their recipients to feel the sincere good wishes and regards from Taiwan, the minister added.

Various civic organizations have launched fund-raising drives for the victims of the Dec. 26 tsunami disaster that affected the Indian Ocean rim nations and has so far claimed more than 160,000 lives in addition to incalculable property damage and losses.
The government has announced that it will offer US$50 million aid to the affected nations.

DOC.HEADLINE: POLICE CALL FOR PUBLIC AWARENESS OF SMUGGLED ANIMALS AFTER TSUNAMI

TEXT.P: Out of serious concern over a possible massive breakout of contagious disease in the wake of the Dec. 26 tsunami in South Asia and Southeast Asia, police urged the Taiwan people Thursday not to buy smuggled and unquarantined animals, in order to secure public hygiene.

Police authorities made the call after agents of the Criminal Investigation Bureau and the Kaohsiung Harbor Bureau broke a smuggling case in the early hours of that day involving more than 1,000 rare birds and dogs worth millions of new Taiwan dollars.
Police launched the operation acting on a tip-off that criminal rings were sneaking in large numbers of dogs and protected birds from countries in Southeast Asia via fishing or cargo vessels.

Police arrested a 61-year-old man, surnamed Tong, in the raid, as the man was preparing to leave in a small truck after having successfully taken delivery of the animals outside a wharf at the harbor.
A total of 40 boxes containing the birds and dogs were intercepted by police on the spot.

Tong acknowledged in a statement to police that a man nicknamed "A Chi" provided him with the animals. According to Tong, "A Chi" got the animals on board his boat from an "unknown fishing boat" anchored off Kaohsiung Harbor.
An initial police investigation shows that the animals were smuggled in from Southeast Asian countries.

Without having been quarantined by Taiwan customs, they could be carriers of many different contagious diseases, police said, urging the public to refrain from purchasing smuggled pets or animals from abroad at the current time of high alert.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT MEETS WITH CHIEFS OF LEGISLATIVE, EXECUTIVE BRANCHES

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian met with the chiefs of the legislative and executive branches Thursday but did not broach the question of who will be asked to form the new Cabinet, according to Chen's aide and Legislative Yuan President Wang Jin-pyng.

According to a phone message issued by the Public Affairs Department of the Presidential Office, Chen exchanged views with Wang on the progress of certain bills pending in the Legislative Yuan and sought his opinion about the political atmosphere in the new legislature that will be sworn in Feb. 1.

Noting that the president has promised to reconcile with the opposition parties in the Legislative Yuan through dialogue, the message said Chen would like to know the opposition's response to his promises.

The president also called in Premier Yu Shyi-kun for a meeting, which is a regular weekly working meeting between the two, the message said, adding that the question of who will succeeded Yu as the next premier was not brought up in either meeting.
The message was confirmed by Wang, who said the president told him he had not yet picked a new premier.
As the chief of the Legislative Yuan, Wang said, he is not in a position to give the president advice on his search for a premier.
Wang said the president exchanged views with him on 10 urgent bills pending in the Legislative Yuan.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER AIT CHAIRWOMAN MEETS WITH LEGISLATIVE YUAN PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: Visiting former American Institute in Taiwan (AIT) Chairwoman Therese Shaheen met with Legislative Yuan President Wang Jin-pyng Thursday.

The closed-door meeting lasted for about 90 minutes, during which they exchanged views on a wide range of topics, including Taiwan's arms procurement from the United States, interaction between the two sides during Shaheen's term as AIT chairwoman, Taiwan-U.S. relations and their personal lives, Wang said after the meeting.

He declined to give further details but said he told Shaheen about the process and progress made by the legislature on a special bill for a proposed NT$610.8 billion (US$18.23 billion) arms procurement deal with the United States.
The arms procurement package includes eight diesel-electric submarines, a squadron of 12 P-3C submarine-hunting aircraft and six Patriot PAC-3 anti-missile batteries.
Shaheen told him that Washington will respect any decision made by Taiwan on the arms deal and that Taiwan should judge if it has sufficient defensive and deterrent forces, according to Wang.
Shaheen, who resigned in April 2004 from the AIT post as the top Washington liaison officer with Taipei in the absence of diplomatic ties, arrived in Taiwan Wednesday for a weeklong private visit.

DOC.HEADLINE: CONSENSUS NEEDED PRIOR TO APPROVAL OF ARMS PURCHASE BUDGET

TEXT.P: As long as a consensus can be reached between the ruling and opposition parties on the substantial parts of the government's arms purchase budget, the passage of the budget and a special statute for the arms purchase will cruise through the legislature, Legislative Yuan President Wang Jin-pyng said Thursday.

Wang, who met with President Chen Shui-bian for one hour earlier that day, said Chen expressed concern about the legislature's debate over the controversial NT$610.80 billion arms purchase budget and urged the Legislative Yuan to act on the issue as soon as possible.

Wang said he told the president that as long as the ruling and opposition parties can agree upon the items and prices in the deal, the budget is sure to be passed before the legislative session finishes at the end of this month.

The opposition parties that control the Legislative Yuan boycotted the budget on the grounds that it was listed as a special budget and therefore was not governed by the law on government budgets. The opposition also complained about the price of the deal, branding it unreasonably high.
The proposed purchase includes Patriot missiles, submarines and anti-submarine aircraft.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Friday, Jan. 7, or the 27th day of the 11th month of the Year of the Monkey according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1558: France seizes Calais, the first and last foothold of British invaders, fulfilling Joan of Arc's ancient dream of ousting the English from French shores.
1610: Galileo Galilei, Italian mathematician, scientist and astronomer, announces his discovery of the four moons circling Jupiter.
1789: George Washington, hero of America's Revolutionary War, is unanimously elected as the first president of the United States.
1830: The first railroad station in the United States opens in Baltimore.
1895: Korea proclaims its independence from China's Ching court.
1927: The Harlem Globetrotters basketball team is founded.
1932: U.S. Secretary of State Henry Stimson declares that the United States will not recognize any treaty that violates the Open Door Policy.
1945: Allied forces complete the construction of the new Burma Road, a vital supply line into China after the old Burma Road was closed by Japanese troops.
1946: Government and communist representatives hold their first truce meeting with Gen. George Marshall, who was despatched as mediator by U.S. President Harry S. Truman.
1947: Gen. Douglas MacArthur, who accepted the surrender of Japan, announces the completion of the repatriation of some 3 million Japanese troops and Japanese people residing in China.
1947: Gen. George Marshall, who was able to negotiate several cease-fires during 1947, issues a report in his capacity as a mediator to help end the fighting between the Chinese government and the communists, whose pattern of non-cooperation soon escalated into open conflict.
1953: Truman announces that the United States has developed the hydrogen bomb.
1959: The Chinese Communists fire 33,000 artillery rounds at ROC-held Kinmen Island in the Taiwan Strait.
1967: Chinese workers fight with communist Red Guards in Nanking.
1972: India grants diplomatic recognition to mainland China.
1976: President Yen Chia-kan receives British parliamentarians Sir John Rogers, Edward Lucas Gardiner, George Grant and Robert Parry.
1976: Vice Adm. Thomas Hayward, commander of the U.S. Seventh Fleet, arrives in Taipei for a four-day visit.
1979: Vietnamese troops capture Phnom Penh after a two-week invasion and overthrow the Khmer Rough regime under Pol Pot.
1989: Emperor Hirohito of Japan, who advocated the Japanese government's unconditional surrender that ended World War II in 1945 and renounced his divine status in 1946, dies after a 62-year reign.
1990: The leaning Tower of Pisa is closed to the public as its degree of tilt accelerates.
1991: French Minister of Industry and Territorial Development Roger Fauroux participates in the seventh ROC-France Economic Cooperation Conference in Taipei.
1997: Vice President and Premier Lien Chan departs for Nicaragua to attend the Jan. 10 inauguration of President Arnoldo Aleman.
1999: The U.S. Senate opens the impeachment trial of President Bill Clinton, the first of its kind in more than 130 years.
2000: Opposition Democratic Progressive Party presidential candidate Chen Shui-bian says if he wins the presidency, he will adopt the "German model" of investigation to probe the ruling Kuomintang's huge party assets.
2001: A National Economic Conference ends a two-day discussion and suggests that the government should start consultations with mainland China on cross-Taiwan Strait transportation issues.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "A wise man regards the moral worth of a man; a fool only his position. A wise man expects justice; a fool expects favors. If you always look only to your own advantage you will be sure to make many enemies."

DOC.HEADLINE: RENEWED U.S. BEEF IMPORTS TO TAIWAN KEY: AGRICULTURE SECRETARY NOMINEE
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Jan. 6 (CNA) (By Jorge Liu and P.C. Tang)

TEXT.P: U.S. Secretary of Agriculture nominee Michael Johnns pledged Thursday that he will do all he can to get Taiwan and Japan to lift their import bans on U.S. beef imports if the U.S. House of Senate approves his nomination.

Johnns made the pledge in response at a hearing held by the house to examine his nomination to a senator's question regarding whether he is capable of urging Taiwan and Japan to reopen their markets to U.S. beef.

According to the senator, the ban imposed by many countries, including Taiwan and Japan, on imports of U.S. beef since the appearance of a case of mad cow disease in the United States in December 2003 has jeopardized the interests of the U.S. livestock industry and related sectors.

Although the ROC and Japan governments have promised to consider opening their market to U.S. beef imports since Washington agreed to guarantee the quality of U.S. beef and beef products, the two countries have done nothing about the matter, the senator said.
Johnns said that he would prioritize upgrading U.S. meat safety standards and re-opening the international market to U.S. beef imports.

Japan was the largest importer of U.S. beef before it imposed a ban in 2003, with annual beef imports from the United States of more than US$1.4 billion, or more than 30 percent of total U.S. beef exports.
Taiwan was the sixth-largest importer of U.S. beef, with annual imports from the United States of US$325 million in 2003.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC WOMEN JUDGES ASSOCIATION CELEBRATES 10TH ANNIVERSARY

TEXT.P: Judicial Yuan President Weng Yueh-sheng lauded the Republic of China Association of Women Judges Friday for its achievements in helping boost Taiwan's relations with the world judicial community.
Weng made the commendation at a ceremony marking the 10th anniversary of the ROC women judges association.

Through concerted efforts of its members, Weng said, the association has managed to join the International Association of Women Judges (IAWJ) and made outstanding contributions to the prestigious world organization.

IAWJ President Jane Mathews, an Australian judge, Arline Pacht, a retired U.S. judge who was IAWJ's founding president, and several other IAWJ executives are in Taipei to attend the ROC association's 10th anniversary.

The IAWJ is a non-governmental organization founded in 1991 to group women judges in different judicial systems to promote social justice and rule of law. The organization now has more than 4,000 members in 86 countries.

The ROC women judges association was founded in 1995. As its designation bears the ROC's national title, its members have repeatedly encountered mainland China's interference and have closed them out of the biennial IAWJ meetings. The association later reached an agreement with the IAWJ to change its designation to the "Taiwan Chapter of the IAWJ" in the world organization.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWANESE OPEN THEIR HEARTS TO SEND 3 SICK BOYS TO U.S. FOR TREATMENT
DOC.DATELINE: Kaohsiung, southern Taiwan, Jan. 7 (CNA) (By Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Answering a father's cry for help over the Internet to save his three sons suffering from the rare disorder called adrenoleukodystrophy (ALD) , citizens of Taiwan responded overwhelmingly by donating NT$64 million (US$1.98 million) in just three days.

Astounded by what he said was "an unbelievable outpouring of empathy and compassion" by the people of Taiwan, Chang Ming-hui, an official with the Kaohsiung City Government in charge of laws and regulations, wept on his knees at a news conference at his home Thursday, saying that he owes more than a debt of gratitude to everyone and that he hopes that one day no one in Taiwan will fall victim to the fatal genetic disease that specifically targets boys.

Chang and his wife, schoolteacher Su Ting-chu, called for people from around the island to stop sending them money since they now have not only enough to allow their 13-year-old eldest son to go to the United States for treatment, but also the other two younger sons, all of them hoping to be cured by the so-called Lorenzo's oil.

Chang and Su previously planned to seek some NT$5 million to only allow the 13-year-old Chien-hsuan to receive treatment, mainly a bone marrow transplant, in the United States after the eldest son began recently to show early symptoms, including staggering, that were similar to those displayed by their second son, Po-chun, nearly two years ago.

Twelve-year-old Po-chun is now believed to be in the late stage of ALD, with his body "shrinking" quickly after suffering complete paralysis and losing the ability to speak as a result of the disease.
ALD is still not fully understood even in the most advanced medical centers in the United States.

Taking Chien-hsuan and the youngest son, five-year-old Sen-ning, to the Veterans General Hospital in Taichung for examinations several months ago, Chang and Su only found that the first and third sons have dysadrenia, a possible precursor to progressive degenerative myelin disorder, meaning that myelin, the "insulation" around nerves, breaks down over time.

The five-member Chang family applied for visas Friday to travel to the state of Minnesota in hopes that they can reach the medical center of Minnesota State University prior to the end of January to have all three boys treated.
Kaohsiung Mayor Frank Hsieh visited the Changs at their home Thursday. Giving Chang an envelope containing one month of his salary of NT$170,000 (US$5,247).
After seeking medical help around the island, Chang was told to contact Dr. Hugo Moser of the Kennedy Krieger Institute in Baltimore, Maryland, who was portrayed in the movie Lorenzo's Oil, for help.

The Changs were told by Moser to first have the eldest boy receive a bone marrow transplant at the Minnesota State University Medical Center, which would cost US$500,000. The eldest son would have an 80 percent chance of being cured after receiving the transplant.
Chang will give part of his marrow to Chien-hsuan for the transplant.
Moser presented the results of a long-term study on the preventive efficacy of Lorenzo's oil in September 2002.

While admitting that Lorenzo's oil can normalize the level of very long chain fatty acids, the metabolite accumulating in ALD, most doctors in the U.S. medical community have denied for many years its therapeutic value.

Dr. Augusto Odone, one of the two inventors of Lorenzo's oil, has forging ahead with The Myelin Project. If it is successful, it will help not only the children with leukodystrophies, but also adults who suffer from multiple sclerosis in whom the myelin sheath is similarly destroyed.

DOC.HEADLINE: WAN HAI DONATES NT$18 MILLION TO TSUNAMI CHILD SPONSORSHIP PROGRAM

TEXT.P: The Wan Hai Lines Ltd. on Friday donated NT$18 million (US$560,258) to a sponsorship program launched by the Government Information Office (GIO) to help children in countries affected by the Dec. 26 earthquake and tsunami disaster.
GIO Director-General Lin Chia-lung said the donation is the largest amount received by the government and he hope the private sector will continue to contribute to the cause.
The GIO plans to support 10,000 children under the program, with each child to be provided with NT$1,000 per month over a three-year period.
Of the total of NT$360 million that the program requires, NT$180 million will be provided by the government and the rest will be raised from the private sector, Lin said.

He said the GIO will send workers to solicit donations in public facilities such as railway stations and department stores in major cities islandwide on Jan. 14 and will hold a charity bazaar and charity concert at Taipei's Sun Yat-sen Memorial Hall on Jan. 15.
Meanwhile, the public donations received by the Red Cross Society of the Republic of China and World Vision Taiwan had reached NT$250 million and NT$110 million, respectively, as of Thursday.

Red Cross Society of ROC Secretary-General Hau Lung-bin said it costs about NT$1,000 to supply clean water, food and medical services to one tsunami victim for six to eight months and that his organization hopes to help as many victims as possible.
World Vision Taiwan leader Tu Ming-han said World Vision International has dispatched 3,000 workers to tsunami-hit countries, with 200,000 families having received help.

While the relief efforts prioritize the supply of clean water, food and medical services at present, long-term living assistance such as reconstruction of homes and schools will be the main concern in the next stage, Tu said.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER AIT CHAIRWOMAN MEETS WITH FOREIGN MINISTER

TEXT.P: Visiting former American Institute in Taiwan (AIT) Chairwoman Therese Shaheen met with Minister of Foreign Affairs Tan Sun Chen Friday for wide-ranging talks.
Chen said after his hour-long talk that Shaheen is very supportive of Taiwan and promised to bring more foreign friends to Taiwan to help them better understand Taiwan.

"Shaheen told me that many foreign people have never been to Taiwan and tend to perceive Taiwan as a stark and barren place where 'birds cannot lay eggs, '" Chen said, adding that he agrees with Shaheen's views that if more foreign people visit Taiwan, they will become more supportive of Taiwan.
Asked whether they had discussed Taiwan's NT$610.8 billion arms procurement plan and relations across the Taiwan Strait, Chen said no.

Instead, Chen said Shaheen had told him that many foreigners do not understand Taiwan and that frequent bickering between Taiwan's ruling and opposition parties has inevitably affected foreign people's views about Taiwan.

Shaheen, who resigned in April 2004 from the AIT post as the top U.S. liaison officer with Taiwan in the absence of diplomatic ties, arrived in Taipei Wednesday for a weeklong private visit. This is her second trip to Taiwan since her resignation.
Speculation has it that her visit might be related to lobbying Taiwan's legislature to pass the budget bill for the huge arms procurement.
Shaheen said Thursday that Taiwan should show the world its resolve to defend itself by speeding up its NT$610.8 billion (US$18.23 billion) arms procurement deal with the United States.
Shaheen said the deal is one of the crucial factors in Taiwan-U.S. relations.

It upsets Washington to see Taipei keep issuing inflammatory rhetoric that is likely to intensify tension across the Taiwan Strait when the budget bill for the arms procurement is being shelved by the Legislative Yuan, Shaheen said.
The arms procurement package includes eight diesel-electric submarines, a squadron of 12 P-3C Orion submarine-hunting aircraft and six Patriot PAC-3 anti-missile batteries.

Legislative Yuan President Wang Jin-pyng said after a closed-door meeting with Shaheen Thursday that he had briefed Shaheen on the process and progress made by the legislature on the critical arms procurement budget bill.
"Shaheen told me that Washington will respect any decision made by Taiwan on the arms deal and that Taiwan should judge if it has sufficient defensive and deterrent forces," Wang said.

DOC.HEADLINE: RULING PARTY TO COMMUNICATE WITH PFP ON CROSS-STRAIT BILL

TEXT.P: The acting chairman of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) said Friday that the party is sincere in wishing to cooperate with the opposition People First Party (PFP) on a cross-strait draft bill proposed by the PFP.

Ker Chien-ming, who is also DPP caucus whip in the Legislative Yuan, made the remarks against the backdrop of President Chen Shui-bian working to end intra-party disagreements since the Dec. 11 legislative elections in which the DPP and its ally, the Taiwan Solidarity Union, failed to gain a majority in the 225-seat legislature.

Amid reports that although it is unlikely that a partnership between the pro-independence DPP and the pro-unification PFP would coalesce, Ker said the PFP has recently made meaningful gestures as a sign that it could work with the DPP in the legislature on a party assets bill proposed by the DPP.
Likewise, the DPP has no reason to block a draft bill proposed by the PFP next Monday when it is reviewed in a legislative committee, Ker added.

He noted that President Chen made it clear in his new year's address that if something benefits the stability of domestic politics, the welfare of the people, harmony among ethnic groups, and cross-strait peace, then that notion can be open to talks between the ruling and opposition parties.

Ker cited President Chen's meeting Thursday with Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng, who concurrently serves as a vice chairman of the Kuomintang (KMT) , as an example. The meeting indicated that the president also wanted to talk with the KMT to foster a stable political environment, he added.

On whether PFP Chairman James Soong will serve as the convener of a cross-strait peaceful development committee proposed by President Chen, Ker said the president made it known earlier that he would invite one of the two leaders of the opposition "pan-blue alliance" of the KMT and the PFP to serve in that post.

Ker also flatly dismissed reports that he was sent to the United States for a secret meeting with Soong in a bid to seek rapport with the PFP. Soong is currently visiting the U.S. but is reportedly to cut short his visit and return home next Tuesday.
Ker said that he is "only an acting DPP chairman, and I had no contact with Soong."

But Ker lauded Soong's statement before his departure to the U.S. when the latter said, "The PFP will engage in healthy competition with the KMT to see who better fosters reforms, but will not rule out the possibility of cooperation with other parties," praising Soong as a person who really knows the political situation.

Meanwhile, a DPP legislator said Friday that the DPP must drop its Taiwan independence platform and the PFP must cast away its advocacy of an eventual unification under "one China" if the two are to cooperate.

Lee Wen-chung said that DPP supporters can't accept the ideas of "one China" and "a future unification with mainland China," while PFP supporters cannot tolerate a party with Taiwan independence in its platform.

Lee also said that the DPP must stick to its resolution passed in May 1999 in which it said that Taiwan is a sovereign, independent country, and changes to this status quo would require a national referendum of the people on Taiwan.
On the other hand, a KMT spokesman said that DPP-PFP cooperation is only idle talk spread by the DPP to drive a wedge between the alliance of the KMT and PFP.
Chang Jung-kung said that the KMT still believes Soong's promise that "KMT-PFP cooperation will remain unchanged."

Chang said the KMT has only just learned about the possibility of cooperation between the DPP-PFP and that Soong serving as a convener of a proposed cross-strait committee is not something that can be commented on until the facts can be substantiated.
