DOC.HEADLINE: SHU CHIN-CHIANG EXPECTED TO TAKE OVER TSU CHAIRMANSHIP

TEXT.P: National Cultural Association Secretary-General Shu Chin-chiang, the sole contestant in the race for chairman of the opposition Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU), passed the party's candidate qualification review on Friday.
If everything proceeds smoothly, the TSU's Central Executive Committee is expected to approve Shu's appointment during its next meeting set for Monday, party officials said.
The TSU's chairmanship became vacant after Huang Chu-wen stepped down last month over the party's failure in the Dec. 11 legislative elections.

In addition to Shu, sitting legislator Lo Chih-ming and legislator-elect Kuo Lin-yung had registered for the chairmanship race but they were later talked out running by former President and TSU spiritual leader Lee Teng-hui.

According to TSU rules, no election by party members will be held if only one candidate enters the race. The candidate will be proclaimed elected by the Central Executive Committee through a majority vote.

DOC.HEADLINE: CROSS-STRAIT CHARTER FLIGHTS MOVING IN POSITIVE DIRECTION: MAC

TEXT.P: Both sides of the Taiwan Strait have displayed goodwill and sincerity in bringing about charter flights to address the needs of Taiwan business people in mainland China during the Chinese Lunar New Year holiday, and the matter is moving in a positive direction, a spokesman of the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) said Friday.
MAC Vice Chairman Chiu Tai-san said that the flights must be based on the principles of "joint participation, two-way services and no-stopovers in a third place."
The government will also not rule out adding new destinations, hoping that the "results satisfy everyone."

Meanwhile, a representative of Taipei-based EVA Airways in mainland China said Friday that with the fast approach of Chinese New Year, which falls on Feb. 9, he is hoping that both sides can complete talks on charter flights soon.
"We need a clear answer on whether the charter flight services will be launched to make the necessary arrangements, " Chou Pao-yu said.

Taiwan airliners operated charter flights in 2003 between Shanghai and Taipei/Kaohsiung via Hong Kong/Macau during Chinese Lunar New Year holiday. The services were not offered the following year because Beijing insisted that Chinese carriers also be allowed to join the service but refused to come to the negotiating table to discuss the necessary technical details with Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN SHOULD BE EQUIPPED WITH TSUNAMI MONITORING SYSTEMS: EXPERTS

TEXT.P: Taiwan, located on a seismically active stretch of the Pacific basin, should devise an early tsunami warning system of its own, experts from the Central Geological Survey (CGS) said Friday.

CGS specialists said that although some government officials said last week that the chances of Taiwan being hit by tsunamis are low because of the deep waters to the east of the island, there is always the possibility that Taiwan could be affected by a major quake originating in the Pacific Ocean, which could in turn cause a tsunami, particularly in coastal areas in Taiwan's northeastern and southwestern parts where the coastlines are shallow.

Looking at historical records, CGS experts said that the southern port city of Kaohsiung was hit by a devastating tsunami in 1781, and the Keelung-Chinshan area in northeastern Taiwan experienced another deadly tsunami in 1867.

If an earthquake of magnitude of 9.0 and tsunamis like the ones that occurred in South Asia Dec. 26, 2004 hit Taiwan, the island would certainly be affected, with the eastern parts of Taiwan, where coastal waters have a depth of several thousand feet, being particularly susceptible, the experts said.

Taiwan is near the border of the Philippine and Eurasian plates, which have a long history of tectonic movement. In addition, the northeastern part of the island is within the 2,000 km area of the Okinawa Trough where rift breaks are brisk, the experts said.
This is the reason why Taiwan should cooperate with Japan and the Philippines to jointly monitor earthquakes and tsunamis and deepen research, they noted.
Meanwhile, the experts added that Taiwan should also have earthquake monitoring systems installed underseas to check earthquakes from offshore.
Currently, Taiwan only has similar detectors installed around Taiwan proper.

The experts made the suggestions in the light of the massive earthquake offshore Western Indonesia and the ensuing tsunamis that have killed an estimated 150,000 people and caused unprecedented damage in many countries in the region.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. DOLLAR DIPS ON TAIPEI FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar dipped against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Friday, losing NT$0.041 to close at NT$32.138.
A total of US$750 million changed hands.
The greenback opened at the day's high of NT$32.283 and slid to a low of NT$32.090 during the day's trading.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Times: Blair bares his teeth.
Tony Blair told Gordon Brown to play a full part in Labour's manifesto and election campaign as fresh evidence emerged of policy differences between the two. A senior Downing Street source conceded last night that the Chancellor felt excluded from the planning process. He insisted that Mr Blair wanted Mr Brown totally involved but added: "It clearly is not well understood and accepted by everybody."
Financial Times: Blair in poll pledge to Brown.
Tony Blair was on Thursday night struggling to keep Gordon Brown at the heart of Labour's strategy for this year's general election - amid growing signs that the chancellor believes he has been excluded from any role in devising the party's manifesto. In a gesture designed to settle a serious outbreak of tension between the two men ahead of polling day, Mr Blair pledged that the chancellor would be "right at the centre" of the party's efforts to get a third term in government.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES LOWER ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were lower Friday as the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for January dropped 52 points to close at 5,965, with 37,209 contracts changing hands.
TAIEX Index futures for February moved down 64 points to finish at 5,969, with 1,327 contracts traded, while March futures dropped 58 points to finish at 5,950, with 11 contracts traded.
June futures lost 16 points to finish at 5,975, with eight contracts traded, while September futures dropped 56 points to close at 5,867, with 16 contracts traded.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Friday at 6,017 for January, 6,033 for February, 6,008 for March, 5,991 for June and 5,923 for September.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were lower.

January TE futures moved down 2.75 points to close at 219.75, with 4,512 contracts traded, while February TE futures lost 2.95 points to finish at 219.5, with 89 contract transactions. March TE futures lost 5.45 points to close at 216.1, with one contract traded.
No transactions were recorded for June and September.

January TF futures lost 8.6 points to finish at 1,026, with 4,185 contracts changing hands, while February TF futures moved down 4.8 points to end at 1,025, with 326 contracts traded. March TF futures dropped 11.6 points to finish at 1.020, with three contracts traded. September TF futures dropped 11.6 points to close at 1015.2, with one contract traded.
No transactions were recorded for June.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI SHARE PRICES CONTINUES DOWNWARD STREAK

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange continued their downward trend Thursday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving down 6.25 points to close at 5,935.99.
The bourse opened at 5,990.78 and fluctuated between 6,007.34 and 5,934.83 during trading. A total of 2.99 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$57.28 billion (US$1.79 billion).

All of the eight major stock categories lost ground, with cement and paper stocks both moving down 1.9 percent; foodstuffs down 1.5 percent; textiles down 1.2 percent; machinery and electronics down 0.9 percent; financial and banking issues down 0.5 percent; construction stocks down 0.3 percent; and plastics and chemicals down 0.2 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 625 to 127, with 130 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINA AIRLINES OFFERS FREE SERVICES FOR TSUNAMI RELIEF

TEXT.P: Taiwan's China Airlines on Friday flew another 45 rescue workers and 14 tons of relief supplies free of charge to Phuket in Thailand and Medan on the Indonesian island of Sumatra, company officials said.
The company has since Dec. 28 offered free services to Taiwan's relief missions to countries affected by the Dec. 26 earthquake and tsunami disaster, the officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TO DONATE US$30,000 TO U.S. MUSEUM
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Jan. 06 (CNA) (By Wennie Chi and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: The Taipei Economic and Cultural Representative Office in the United States will donate US$30,000 to the Smithsonian Museum of National History in Washington, D.C. in an attempt to promote cultural exchanges between the two countries, an official said Thursday.
The donation ceremony is set for Jan. 26, according to Republic of China representative to the United States David Ta-wei Lee.
The donation will be designated for a "Taiwan foundation" set up under the museum by a group of Taiwanese expatriates in the United States last year to promote Taiwan-U.S. cultural exchanges.
Such exchanges will help the American people better understand Taiwan's culture, officials at the representative office said.

DOC.HEADLINE: NPSU URGES REVIEW OF PROPOSED CHANGES TO LEGISLATIVE ELECTORAL SYSTEM

TEXT.P: The Non-partisan Solidarity Union (NPSU) Friday urged a review of a series of constitutional amendments concerning the halving of the number of legislative seats and changes to its electoral system because it feels such moves would stifle the existence of smaller parties.

The NPSU noted in a press release that the Legislative Yuan passed the constitutional amendments last August, which will be put to review by a 300-member "functional" National Assembly, an ad hoc body that will be formed before May 26 for the specific mission of approving the constitutional amendments and will then be dissolved.

The NPSU said that the chaos in the Legislative Yuan can be traced to the quality, not the quantity, of the legislators, adding that if the current multiple-seat in a bigger constituency is changed into a "single seat, two votes" system and the 225 seats are cut by half, then legislative elections will be only beneficial to the bigger parties.
"The smaller parities will be seriously squeezed and the voice of minor parties will not be heard in the new system," the NPSU claimed.

It also said that if the constitutional amendments are approved by the "functional" National Assembly, then "Taiwan will be left with the voices of the `pan-green camp' of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party and its ally Taiwan Solidarity Union and the opposition `pan-blue alliance' of the Kuomintang and the People First Party.
The NTSU said it expects that the bickering between the "pan-blue alliance" and "the pan-green camp" will worsen and that the chaos in the legislature will be exacerbated.

DOC.HEADLINE: MEDICAL SECTOR CALLS FOR 2ND THOUGHTS ON OVERSEAS TREATMENT

TEXT.P: The medical sector Friday urged a family planning to send their three sons to the United States for treatment of the rare disorder adrenoleukodystrophy (ALD) to have a second thoughts on its plan, claiming that they can be treated just as well in Taiwan.

Chang Ming-hui, an official with the Kaohsiung city government in charge of laws and regulations, and his schoolteacher wife Su Ting-chu, are planning to accompany their three sons to the state of Minnesota so that the boys, aged from five to 13, all of whom suffer from ALD, can receive treatment.
The family applied for visas Friday to travel to the United States in the hope that they can get the boys into hospital prior to the end of January.
Their move was prompted by the successful raising of funds after the public answered the family's cry for help over the Internet to save the boys.
The public responded overwhelmingly, donating NT$64 million (US$1.98 million) in just three days.

Astounded by what he said was "an unbelievable outpouring of empathy and compassion" by the people of Taiwan, Chang wept on his knees at a news conference at his home Thursday, saying that he owes more than a debt of gratitude to everyone and that he hopes that one day no-one in Taiwan will fall victim to the fatal genetic disease that specifically targets boys.

Chang and his wife called for people from around the island to stop sending them money since they now have not only enough to allow their 13-year-old eldest son to go to the United States for treatment, but also the other two younger sons, all of whom hope to be cured with the use of Lorenzo's oil.

Chang and Su previously planned to seek some NT$5 million to only allow the 13-year-old Chien-hsuan to receive treatment, mainly a bone marrow transplant, in the United States after the eldest son began recently to show early symptoms, including staggering, that are similar to those displayed by their second son, Po-chun, nearly two years ago.

Twelve-year-old Po-chun is now believed to be in the late stage of ALD, with his body "shrinking" quickly after suffering complete paralysis and losing the ability to speak as a result of the disease.
ALD is still not fully understood, even in the most advanced medical centers in the United States.

Taking Chien-hsuan and the youngest son, five-year-old Sen-ning, to the Veterans General Hospital in Taichung for examinations several months ago, Chang and Su found that only the first and third sons have dysadrenia, a possible precursor to progressive degenerative myelin disorder, meaning that myelin, the "insulation" around nerves, breaks down over time.
After seeking medical help around the island, Chang was told to contact Dr. Hugo Moser of the Kennedy Krieger Institute in Baltimore, Maryland, who was portrayed in the movie Lorenzo's Oil, for help.

The Changs were told by Moser to first have the eldest boy receive a bone marrow transplant at the Minnesota State University Medical Center, which would cost US$500,000. The eldest son would have an 80 percent chance of being cured after receiving the transplant.
Chang will give some of his marrow to Chien-hsuan for the transplant.

In response to the plan, however, Lin Hsiu-chuan, director-general of the Bureau of Health Promotion under the Department of Health, said that the Chang brothers can receive treatment at home in Taiwan given that this disease had been successfully tackled in Taiwan and the treatment is covered by the national health insurance program.

Lin said that with so much cash donations, the Changs can now afford the marrow transplant and doses of the expensive Lorenzo's oil, which costs NT$4,500 a bottle. The three brothers are expected to need 10 bottles of the medicine per month.

Dr. Lin Kai-hsin from National Taiwan University Hospital said that the NTUH assessed the Chang brothers' conditions about six months ago and found that only the 13-year-old is suitable for a marrow transplant, given that the 12-year-old is too sick to undergo a transplant, while the five-year-old has not yet shown any early symptoms of the disease. Some ALD patients remain non-symptomatic throughout their lives, Lin added.
Moser presented the results of a long-term study on the preventive efficacy of Lorenzo's oil in September 2002.

While admitting that Lorenzo's oil can normalize the level of very long chain fatty acids -- the metabolite that accumulates in ALD -- most doctors in the U.S. medical community have for many years denied its therapeutic value.

Dr. Augusto Odone, one of the two inventors of Lorenzo's oil, has forged ahead with the Myelin Project, which, if successful, will help not only the children with leukodystrophies, but also adults who suffer from multiple sclerosis in whom the myelin sheath is similarly destroyed.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEARLY 80 PERCENT OF OFFICE WORKERS TAKE PART IN 'ONE-DAY-INCOME' DRIVE

TEXT.P: Nearly 80 percent of the nation's office workers said Friday they responded to their companies' call to donate one-day's worth of income to help those in South Asia and Southeast Asian affected by devastating Dec. 26 tsunami triggered by the 9.0-magnitude earthquake in Sumatra, Indonesia, according to the results of a poll released Friday.
The poll, conducted by an online manpower company from Dec. 30-Jan. 6, collected 1,140 effective samples and had a margin of error of 2.9 percent.
The results show that 77.89 percent responded to the call and that they donated an average NT$1,199.32 (US$37.47) to help the tsunami victims.
The most heartwarming result is that 77.72 percent of office workers are also regular donors to various charity groups.

Asked how much they will donate to help the victims, those who answered NT$501-NT$1,000 accounted for the most (35.36 percent) , followed by NT$101-NT$500 (29.05 percent) , and NT$1,000-NT$3,000 (20.50 percent).

In a multiple choice question, the office workers cited the reasons for donating as: The victims need aid and assistance (68.85%) ; religious belief (44.02%); support to charity groups (29.57%) ; and donate for aid following major natural disasters (17.83%).
Up to 78.33 percent of those polled said they donate money irregularly, and 13.32 percent said they donate money to charity every month.
The respondents also said in multiple choices that they most often donate money to international aid organizations (47.18%) , social welfare groups (44.70%), and religious groups (33.6%).

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The New York Times: Gonzales Speaks Against Tor ture During Hearing.
Alberto R. Gonzales denounced the use of torture against terrorism suspects and pledged to abide by all international law.
Wall Street Journal: Most Retailers Report Mediocre Holiday Sales.
Holiday sales were ho-hum for most retailers, as price-conscious shoppers put off purchases until the last minute and scoured stores for post-Christmas bargains.

DOC.HEADLINE: CRIMINAL CODE UNDERGOES BIGGEST REVAMP IN 70 YEARS

TEXT.P: The Criminal Code has undergone the biggest revamp since it took force in 1935 after a revision covering two thirds of its articles passed its third reading at the Legislative Yuan Friday.
Vice Justice Minister Shih Mao-lin told a news conference that work on the revisions code started in 1974 and was finished in September 1989.
After being presented to the Legislative Yuan in 1990 for enactment, however, the revision was bogged down in the legislature, which returned it to the Ministry of Justice for review in 1996.
It took a panel under the Ministry of Justice another six years to finish the review and present it to the Legislative Yuan in July 2002, Shih said.

The revision is aimed at reconciling the criminal law with reality, Shih said, adding that the revised code gives prosecutors greater leeway in deciding against prosecuting offenders of misdemeanors, or using suspended prosecutions to cut down the number of cases going before the court.

Citing statistics compiled by the Ministry of Justice, Shih said the percentage of cases resulting in a prosecution against the entire number of cases investigated by prosecutors had dropped from 25.3 percent in 1999 to 16.3 percent in the first ten months of 2004.
This reflects the fact that more offenders are being spared jail, which eases the strain on the country's jail system, Shih said.

The revised law also gives more flexibility to the probation program by relaxing its requirements, while raising from 15 years to 25 years the time a prisoner sentenced to life must serve before being eligible for probation, and toughening the probation requirements for rapists and felons for the third time, Shih went on.
The revised Criminal Code will go into effect July 1, 2006 and will not be applied to cases tried by the court before that time, Shih said.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAINLAND CHINA'S TAIWAN AFFAIRS CHIEF TO MEET WITH KMT DELEGATION

TEXT.P: The top mainland Chinese official in charge of Taiwan affairs will meet with a delegation from Taiwan's main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) next Monday to exchange views on the launch of direct charter flights across the Taiwan Strait during the upcoming Chinese Lunar New Year holiday, official sources said Friday.
Chen Yunlin, director of the Taiwan Affairs Office under mainland China's State Council, will meet with the KMT delegation at the Diaoyutai Guest House in Beijing Jan. 10, the sources said.
Senior officials from Beijing's Civil Aviation Administration of China (CAAC) will also meet with the KMT delegation earlier that same day, the sources added.

Members of the KMT delegation will include Tseng Yung-chuan, chief executive of the KMT's policy coordination department; Huang Teh-fu, the KMT legislative whip; KMT spokesman Chang Jung-kung; and KMT legislators John Chang and Chu Feng-chih.

The sources said the Taipei Airlines Association (TAA), which has been authorized by the Republic of China government to negotiate terms for direct cross-strait charter flights during the holiday period, will also send a delegation to Beijing to discuss technical details of the flights.

Meanwhile, aviation industry sources said that whether the special holiday charter flights can be launched will depend on the results of the negotiation between the TAA and the relevant mainland authorities.

Media reports from Taipei said TAA President Lo Ta-hsin had already met Friday in Macau with Pu Zhaozhou, director of the CAAC's Taiwan affairs department, to discuss the holiday charter flight terms.

In Taipei, Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Vice Chairman Chiu Tai-san said Friday that both sides of the Taiwan Strait have displayed goodwill and sincerity to make the much-anticipated holiday charter flights a reality for the convenience of a large number of Taiwan business people operating on the mainland China intending to return for family reunions.

Chiu said the flight services will be operated on the principles of "joint participation, two-way services and no-stopovers in a third place." He further said things are going on in a positive direction.

With Beijing's consent, six Taiwan carriers operated lunar New Year charter flights in 2003 between Shanghai and Taipei/Kaohsiung via Hong Kong/Macau. The services were not offered the following year because Beijing insisted that Chinese carriers also be allowed to join the service but refused to come to the negotiating table to discuss the necessary technical details with Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: CAKE MUSEUM TO OPEN IN TAOYUAN

TEXT.P: Taiwan's first cake museum is set to open in Taoyuan County Jan. 21, according to the Yuan Ze University, which is in charge of the museum's operations.

Hsieh Teng-wang, head of the university's Department of Sociology, who has been appointed curator of the museum, said the facility will provide baking courses and will organize various art and cultural activities after its opening.
A giant cake decorated with sugar flowers will be exhibited at the entrance of the museum during the opening, Hsieh said.
This will be yet another non-traditional museum featuring a unique theme after the gold museum in Taipei County and the coffee museum in Yunlin County.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT MEETS WITH FORMER AIT CHAIRWOMAN

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian hosted a luncheon at the Presidential Office Friday in honor of visiting former American Institute in Taiwan (AIT) Chairwoman Therese Shaheen.

Shaheen, who resigned in April 2004 from the AIT post as the top U.S. liaison officer with Taiwan in the absence of diplomatic ties, arrived in Taipei Wednesday for a weeklong private visit. This is her second trip to Taiwan since her resignation.
James Huang, deputy secretary-general of the Presidential Office, who was present at the luncheon, said Chen and Shaheen are old friends.
"They exchanged New Year greetings and had a happy conversation on many interesting topics, " Huang said, adding that they did not touch on Taiwan's long-stalled arms procurement plan.
Huang said Shaheen presented a beautifully designed gold necklace to Chen as a souvenir to his newborn grandson. Chen also presented Shaheen with a small gift.

Several senior officials were also present at the luncheon, including Presidential Office Secretary-General Su Tseng-chang, National Security Council Secretary-General Chiou I-jen and Minister of Foreign Affairs Tan Sun Chen.
After the luncheon, Huang said, Shaheen had brief talks with Chiou.
Upon her arrival at the Presidential Office, she first talked with Vice President Annette Lu and then ate the lunch with Chen.

Earlier in the day, Shaheen had a closed-door meeting with the foreign affairs minister, who said afterward that Shaheen is very supportive of Taiwan and that she promised to bring more "foreign friends" to Taiwan to help them better understand Taiwan.

"Shaheen told me that many foreign people have never been to Taiwan and tend to perceive Taiwan as a stark and barren place where 'birds cannot lay eggs, '" Chen said, adding that he agrees with Shaheen's views that if more foreign people visit Taiwan, they will become more supportive of Taiwan.
Speculation has been rife that the purpose of her visit is to lobby Taiwan's legislature to pass the budget bill for a huge arms procurement deal.
Shaheen said a day earlier that Taiwan should show the world its resolve to defend itself by speeding up its NT$610.8 billion (US$18.23 billion) arms procurement deal with the United States.
Shaheen said the deal is one of the crucial factors in Taiwan-U.S. relations.

It upsets Washington to see Taipei keep issuing inflammatory rhetoric that is likely to intensify tension across the Taiwan Strait when the budget bill for the arms procurement is being shelved by the Legislative Yuan, Shaheen said.
The package includes eight diesel-electric submarines, a squadron of 12 P-3C Orion submarine-hunting aircraft and six Patriot PAC-3 anti-missile batteries.

Legislative Yuan President Wang Jin-pyng said after a closed-door meeting with Shaheen a day earlier that he had briefed Shaheen on the process and progress made by the legislature on the critical arms procurement budget bill.
"Shaheen told me that Washington will respect any decision made by Taiwan on the arms deal and that Taiwan should judge if it has sufficient defensive and deterrent forces," Wang said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TO BENEFIT MORE FROM CROSS-STRAIT TRANSPORT LINKS: TYCOON

TEXT.P: Formosa Plastics Group Chairman Wang Yung-ching said Friday that he told President Chen Shui-bian the previous day that Taiwan would benefit more than mainland China from the opening of direct transportation links across the Taiwan Strait.
"President Chen nodded in agreement with my views, " Wang told journalists reporting on his Thursday talks with Chen at the Presidential Office.

Wang said he hopes the two sides of the Taiwan Strait can reach agreement on the opening of direct cross-strait shipping and air links as soon as possible but added that he did not suggest any timetable for launching the much-anticipated direct cross-strait transport services.

"I only told the president that as more Taiwan people visit the mainland than vice versa, direct cross-strait transportation links would bring more benefits to Taiwan than to the mainland, " Wang explained.
During their 30-minute talks, Wang said the economy dominated the agenda.

"I told the president that as Taiwan has limited natural resources, it should be pragmatic and realistic in drafting national development plans, " Wang said, adding that he hopes the public can work diligently to boost domestic economic development.

The Chen-Wang meeting came at a time when the Cabinet is expected to undergo a reshuffle ahead of the opening of the new Legislative Yuan on Feb. 1. Observers have speculated that Chen might seek Wang's opinions about the imminent Cabinet reshuffle and feasible ways to break the deadlocked relations between the ruling and opposition camps. However, Wang said Chen did not bring up any political topics such as the choice of new the premier, the new Straits Exchange Foundation chairman and the improvement of inter-party relations.

DOC.HEADLINE: CABINET READY TO QUIT JAN. 24: PREMIER

TEXT.P: Premier Yu Shyi-kun said Friday his Cabinet is ready to quit Jan. 24 to make room for a new administration that will be led by an as-yet unannounced premier.

As to cooperation between the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) and the opposition parties, Yu said it is the common desire of the people and that the DPP considers it to be the party's unescapable duty.

Yu said the DPP caucus at the Legislative Yuan is approaching the opposition parties in the hope of getting their support for a number of urgent bills mired in the legislature, and President Chen Shui-bian is contemplating how to follow through on his New Year promise to meet with the opposition leaders.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT URGES PUBLIC TO DONATE TO TSUNAMI-AFFECTED PEOPLE

TEXT.P: Noting that three brothers in Kaohsiung who suffer from a rare disease were inundated with donations totaling NT$64 million (US$2 million) in just three days, President Chen Shui-bian urged the public Friday to extend aid to people in countries devastated by the Dec. 26 tsunami in South Asia and Southeast Asia with the same passion.

The president said the story of the three brothers proves that Taiwan people have a great deal of compassion and added that he hopes they will show the same compassion for the people who suffered in the tsunami disaster.

The three brothers suffer from a disease called adrenoleukodystrophy, one of a group of genetic disorders called leukodystrophies that cause progressive stiffness, weakness or paralysis of the lower limbs and deterioration of the brain.
Their parents wanted to send the oldest one to the United States for treatment but were stymied by the estimated US$500,000 medical bill.

A newspaper published a story about the family's misery Tuesday and the donations flooded in. The parents had to come forward Thursday to ask the public to stop giving them money, saying it is more than they need and that they are shocked by the public generosity.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI CITIZEN URGED TO DISBAND COMMUNIST GROUP

TEXT.P: The Ministry of the Interior has ordered a Taipei citizen to disband his self-styled "communist organization, " ministry officials said Friday.

The ministry issued the order after Dai Chung published an announcement late last year in local media that he had established a Chinese Communist Party Taiwan provincial council in Taipei to advocate communism and recruit party members, the officials said.

The order is based on the Civic Organization Law and the National Security Law, both of which stipulate that civic groups are prohibited from advocating and promoting communism or secessionist activities, they explained.
Also, Dai did not present a report on the establishment of his group to the authorities as stipulated by law, thus further violating the regulations, the officials went on.

Dai should dismiss his group within seven days of receiving the ministry's order and should neither conduct operations nor organize activities under the group's name, otherwise he will be punished with administrative fines, the officials added.

DOC.HEADLINE: EVENT LISTING FOR JAN. 8 IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The following are important events scheduled to take place Saturday, Jan. 8:
09: 00, The results of a survey on the cross-Taiwan Strait "mini-three links" will be issued at the National Taiwan University Alumni Hall.
10: 30, The Falun Dafa Society in Taiwan will hold a news conference at the Chiang Kai-shek Memorial Hall compound in Taipei.
11: 10, Premier Yu Shyi-kun will visit the Human Rights Memorial Park on Green Island, off the eastern Taiwan county of Taitung.
14: 05, Premier Yu Shyi-kun will inspect a highway tunnel in Hualien, eastern Taiwan.
14: 30, Minister of Finance Lin Chuan will deliver a speech on Taiwan's financial reforms at the Ketagalan Institute.
14: 30, The ruling Democratic Progressive Party will hold a tea party at the Huashan Special Artistic District in Taipei.
19:00, A fund-raising party for the tsunami victims will be held at Nankang 101 in Taipei.

DOC.HEADLINE: VISA SNUB WILL NOT AFFECT FRIENDSHIP BETWEEN TAIWAN, HK: TAIPEI MAYOR

TEXT.P: Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou said Friday that the Hong Kong government's decision not to grant him a visa will not affect the friendship between the people of Taiwan and Hong Kong.
Ma made the remarks while meeting with a group of Hong Kong volunteers dedicated to helping the mentally and physically challenged.
Ma was forced to cancel a plan to visit Hong Kong Jan. 11-13 after the Hong Kong authorities refused to issue him a visa, a move that has drawn broadsides from the Hong Kong media.
Ma said he is hopeful that he can visit the former British colony in the future.

According to a report by the Yazhou Zhoukan, a Hong Kong-based Chinese-language weekly, Hong Kong Chief Executive Tung Chee Hwa sent a secret envoy to Taipei to try to persuade Ma to reject the speaking invitation from the University of Hong Kong to spare the Hong Kong government possible trouble from turning down his visa application.

Ma said two groups of Hong Kong friends have indeed been to Taiwan in the past few weeks. They told Ma that the invitation might be changed, probably because of his recent public criticism of Beijing's so-called anti-secession legislation.
Ma said he was not sure whether they were Tung's secret envoys. According to Ma, the visitors were friends that he and Tung have in common but he declined to identify any of them.

"The Hong Kong visitors advised me to politely turn down the invitation to make a speaking tour of Hong Kong, using my busy work schedule as an excuse. I was surprised by the suggestion and as I had already set up my travel itinerary with the University of Hong Kong, I decided not to back away from my promise on the pretext of my busy schedule," Ma said.

Ma was invited to deliver a speech on the rise of Chinese urban development from Taipei's perspective at the University of Hong Kong Jan. 11 and to attend a Taipei tourism promotion activity and seminar at the Hong Kong University of Science and Technology Jan. 12.
The Hong Kong government reportedly had suggested that Ma's local sponsor, the University of Hong Kong, postpone its invitation to Ma until April.
Meanwhile, Taiwan's top representative in Hong Kong said Friday that his office has lodged a protest to the Hong Kong government over its rejection of Ma's visa application.
"We have expressed our strong dissatisfaction and protest over the issue, " said Pao Cheng-kang, managing director of the Chung Hwa Travel Service.

While the Hong Kong authorities reiterated their established policy of not explaining their decisions on individual visa applications, Pao said, Hong Kong officials have assured him that they are willing to promote civic exchanges between Taiwan and Hong Kong.
The Hong Kong authorities have also reaffirmed that Ma has not been put on a "blacklist" of persona non-grata, Pao said.

DOC.HEADLINE: MND TO HELP TRANSPORT RELIEF SUPPLIES TO TSUNAMI-AFFECTED NATIONS

TEXT.P: The Ministry of National Defense has assigned six cargo planes to help transport relief supplies to tsunami-affected nations in South Asia and Southeast Asia, Premier Yu Shyi-kun said Friday.

The government is negotiating with countries on related flight routes to arrange the shipments and the relief supplies will be distributed by Taiwan's overseas missions and Taiwanese businessmen to the Dec. 26 disaster victims once they arrive at their destinations, Yu noted.

With regard to the recent global relief summit held in Jakarta that Taiwan was not invited to take part in, Yu said that U.S. officials will brief the Taiwan authorities on the decisions made at the meeting so that the country knows what part it can play in the international relief efforts.
Also, he went on, Taiwan's overseas missions will make contact with the governments of their host nations to collect information on materials needed.

Both the government and private sector have launched various campaigns to collect relief funds and materials for the victims of the 9.0-magnitude earthquake-triggered tsunami that affected the Indian Ocean rim nations and has so far claimed more than 160,000 lives in addition to incalculable property damage and losses.
The government has also announced that it will offer US$50 million-worth of aid to the affected nations.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT PULLS OUT BIG GUNS TO LAMBASTE CHINA'S ANTI-SECESSION LAW

TEXT.P: The Executive Yuan brought out three senior government officials Friday to lambaste mainland China's attempt to enact an anti-secession law.

The three officials -- Foreign Minister Tan Sun Chen, Mainland Affairs Council Chairman Joseph Wu and Vice Minister of National Defense Tsai Min-hsien -- fired a volley at the mainland in a news conference called by the Government Information Office and appealed to the international community to preempt Beijing's attempt to unilaterally alter the status quo across the Taiwan Strait and stop it from enacting the law.

Wu told about 40 journalists posted to Taiwan by foreign media that the mainland is deliberately ignoring the existence of the Republic of China by crafting a law to justify its possible invasion of Taiwan.

The international community is virtually encouraging the mainland to continue and intensify its military bullying of Taiwan by remaining silent while Beijing tries to disrupt the status quo in terms of its ties with Taiwan, Wu claimed.

Taiwan has never deviated from its policy of building up mutual trust with the mainland through the normalization of ties, but Beijing's enactment of the anti-secession law will inevitably block Taiwan's efforts and raise the tension across the Taiwan Strait, Wu went on.

Chen said Beijing's anti-secession law is founded on the false assumption that there is only one China of which Taiwan is a part and that the mainland's eventual taking over of Taiwan is an internal affair in which foreign powers are not supposed to interfere.
By formulating this law, Chen claimed, the mainland is trying to take into its hands the power to define what is right and what is wrong regarding the cross-strait situation.
It will strip Taiwan people of their right to choose their own future and will threaten Taiwan's democracy, said Chen.

Tsai said Beijing's anti-secession law is aimed at justifying a possible attack on Taiwan and he added that Taiwan will strengthen its military power to defend itself and deter the mainland from invading.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Saturday, Jan. 8, or the 28th day of the 11th month of the Year of the Monkey according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1642: Galileo Galilei, the Italian astronomer and physicist who was an outspoken advocate of Copernicus' theory that the earth rotates around the sun, dies at the age of 78 at Arcetri.
1654: Ukraine joins Russia
1806: Britain occupies Cape of Good Hope.
1815: U.S. forces led by Maj. Gen. Andrew Jackson crush an invading British army at New Orleans.
1889: Dr. Herman Hoolerith of New York patents the first computer.
1921: For the first time ever, a professional baseball team from the United States arrives in Taipei to play teams from Taiwan.
1926: Ibn Saud becomes king of Hajaz and changes the name of the kingdom to Saudi Arabia.
1937: Elvis Presley, the first American rock'n'roll icon, is born.
1941: Robert Baden-Powell, founder of the Boy Scout Movement, dies.
1941: Russian winter forces German forces to begin retreating from Leningrad.
1959: General De Gaulle, leader of free France during World War II, becomes president of France.
1969: An archaeological team from National Taiwan University unearths cultural artifacts from the stone age at Pashientung in Taitung County.
1974: The first Ivory Coast Products Exhibition opens at the Far East Department Store in Taipei.
1975: The Reverend Thomas White arrives in Taipei as the newly appointed charge d'affaires of the Holy See.
1975: Edward H. Barr, publisher of the International Press Journal in Canada, arrives in Taipei for a 10-day visit.
1976: Zhou En-lai, former mainland Chinese premier, dies in Beijing at the age of 78.
1979: Vietnamese troops occupy Phnom Penh, the capital of Cambodia.
1985: The Hong Kong Affairs Task Force under the Republic of China Executive Yuan decides to simplify exit and entry application procedures, relax controls on foreign exchange and adopt incentives to encourage large enterprises and monetary institutions in Hong Kong to move to Taiwan.
1992: U.S. President George Bush, suffering from a stomach ailment, collapses to the floor at a state dinner in Tokyo.
1996: Francois M. Mitterrand, the French politician who became president of France in 1981 and was reelected in 1988, dies of cancer at the age of 79.
1998: The stock market in Indonesia collapses as rumors about its president and the economy damage the rupiah and affect stocks throughout Asia.
2000: Jacques Edouard Alexis, prime minister of the Republic of Haiti, arrives in Taipei for an eight-day official visit.
2000: The President Cup International Croquet Championship opens in Changhua, central Taiwan, pitting teams from Japan, Singapore, New Zealand and Taiwan.
2001: Visiting Gambian President Yahya Jammeh reaffirms the close and solid relations between the Republic of The Gambia and the Republic of China, saying that his country will never betray the ROC.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "He who can rule a country by real courtesy and good manners will find no difficulty in doing it. But for a ruler who has no real courtesy and good manners, of what can the mere rules of etiquette and formality avail him?"

Manila Bulletin: GMA leads Day of Prayer, Mourning
President Gloria Macapagal Arroyo yesterday led an ecumenical prayer vigil for the thousands of tsunami victims in South Asia and Africa that included some Filipinos, as well as a thanksgiving that the Philippines was spared from the catastrophe.
The Philippine Daily Inquirer: 16 terror suspects fall POLICE on Friday arrested 16 suspected Islamic militants planning a weekend suicide bomb attack on a Roman Catholic procession in the capital, officials and reports said.
The Philippine Star: JI plot to bomb Quiapo procession thwarted
Security forces foiled yesterday an alleged plot of the al-Qaeda linked Jemaah Islamiyah terror group to bomb tomorrow's feast of the Black Nazarene in Quiapo, Manila with the arrest of 16 suspected militants.
The Manila Times: Police foil plot to bomb Quiapo fiesta
Police said Friday they have foiled a plot to bomb Sunday's celebration of the feast of the Black Nazarene in Quiapo with the arrest of a group of suspected Islamic militants assembling bombs at abuilding in Ermita.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
: The Straits Times: Rebuilding of Aceh begins.
First of 24 relocation centres is underway to house 500,000 people as UN chief flies inTHE rebuilding of Aceh has begun, as the first of 24 relocation centres is built to eventually house about half a million people made homeless in the tsunami disaster.
Six centres will be built in Banda Aceh, the provincial capital, and the rest in such ravaged areas as Meulaboh on the south-western coast, said Mr Alwi Shahib, the coordinating minister for people's welfare in Aceh, yesterday.
The Lianhe Zaobao:S'pore sends mobile air control tower.
Singapore has sent a mobile air traffic control tower to Banda Aech Airport to enable more flights carring aid supplies to come in and out of the province.
Indonesia civil aviation authorities requested it after the airport's own control tower was partially damaged by the earthquake and tsunami, reducing the number of flights it could handle.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW ROC REPRESENTATIVE TO BRITAIN ARRIVES IN LONDON TO ASSUME POST
DOC.DATELINE: London, Jan. 7 (CNA) (By N. K. Han and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: Lin Chun-yi, new Republic of China representative to Britain, arrived in London from Gambia to assume his post Friday.
Lin was greeted warmly by Taiwanese expatriates residing in Britain and the staff of the Taipei Representative Office in the U.K. at Heathrow International Airport.

The new representative will be briefed by office staff to learn about the operations and call on related government agencies, parliament, think tanks, industrial and financial sectors starting next Monday.

Lin holds a Ph.D. in biology from Indiana University of the United States and was a professor at Tunghai University and an Environmental Protection Ministry minister before serving as ambassador to Gambia for the past three years.

Attorney General nominee Albert R. Gonzales conceded that he had participated in Bush administration discussions about the outer bounds of the use of torture, but asserted that it wasn't his job as the president's lawyer to develop the policies that have triggered severe criticism.
