DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN BUSINESSMEN IN CHINA POSITIVE ABOUT 'MINI THREE-LINKS'

TEXT.P: Taiwan businessmen operating in mainland China are mostly positive about the direct trade and transportation links between the Taiwan-held islands of Kinmen and Matsu with mainland China, according to a poll released Saturday.

The poll, conducted by Ming Chuan University at Kinmen's Shuitou Wharf on Taiwan businessmen plying the direct route between Kinmen and Xiamen between Oct. 17 and 23 in 2004, collected 329 effective questionnaires out of 400 issued.

The poll was released in tandem with the fourth anniversary of the direct trade, postal and transportation links, or commonly known as the "mini three-links, " between the two outlying islands with mainland China's Fujian province.
The poll showed that Taiwan businessmen think direct links save time and money, and gave an overall assessment of 75.7 points out of 100 points on the policy, which they think is in their interests.
The poll also found that nearly 40 percent of Taiwan businessmen have plied the route more than 10 times, showing that the route provides a cheap and convenient channel for Taiwan businessmen.

But Taiwan businessmen also pointed out that there is room for improvement in the policy, citing insufficient facilities at the Shuitou Wharf, not enough flights from Taiwan to Kinmen and too few ferries between Kinmen and Xiamen, as well as the lack of duty free shops.

Taiwan businessmen also said that when they shuttle between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait via Kinmen, they most often buy Kung Candy -- a peanut candy -- as a souvenir, spending an average of NT$1,000 (US$31.25) . One-eighth of Taiwan businessmen also said they spend nothing while transferring through Kinmen.
The institute also released a poll on residents of Kinmen and Matsu to learn about their attitude toward the "mini three-links."
If 60 points is the passing grade, residents in Kinmen only gave the "mini three-links" 51.8 points, while Matsu residents gave it 58.29 points.
The residents of the two outlying islands couldn't give a passing grade because the policy doesn't meet the needs of the residents there, the university explained.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S INTERNATIONAL TRADE HIT RECORD HIGH IN 2004

TEXT.P: Taiwan's international trade set a new record high in 2004, although its trade surplus of US$6.14 billion in the same year was the lowest since 1999, an official of the Ministry of Finance said Saturday.
Hsu Kuo-chung, chief statistician of the ministry, attributed the hike in the country's exports and imports to the global economic expansion that started in late 2003.

Citing statistics compiled by his office, Hsu said Taiwan's exports and imports experienced double-digit expansion for the whole of 2004, with exports registering an annual growth of 20.7 percent and imports 31.9 percent.
As imports grew more significantly than exports, Hsu said the trade surplus shrank.

Taiwan's trade with mainland China and Hong Kong increased in line with the country's expanding international trade and also set a record high, with its exports to those areas rising by 28.8 percent to US$63.84 billion and imports up by 48.8 percent to US$18.77 billion, according to Hsu.

He predicted that the growth of Taiwan's international trade will slow in 2005 in light of the fact that U.S. economic growth is forecast by the London-based Economist Information Unit to slide to 3.1 percent next year because of its tight monetary policy and the wearing out of the effect of its financial stimulation policy.

The depreciation in the value of the U.S. dollar and the scaling down of mainland China's economic growth will also make a dent in Taiwan's economy this year, according to Hsu. (By Maubo Chang) EDNITEM/mw

DOC.HEADLINE: VICE DEFENSE MINISTER CALLS FOR SUPPORT FOR U.S. ARMS PROCUREMENT

TEXT.P: Vice Minister of National Defense Michael Tsai on Saturday called on the people to support the government's arms procurement from the United States, saying Taiwan must beef up its counterattack capability in the face of mainland China's continued military buildup.
Tsai made the remarks while giving a speech on "national defense, trade and cross-Taiwan Strait relations" in the central city of Taichung.
Tsai pointed out that the international community generally agrees that there are three regions of crisis in the world: the Middle East, the Korean Peninsula and the Taiwan Strait.

While mainland China's defense budget is enjoying double-digit growth every year, the number of missiles deployed by the Chinese military targeting Taiwan has risen to more than 600 and is increasing by 60 to 70 per year, Tsai said.

With defense spending as a share of the national budget declining year after year, the Ministry of National Defense has put forth a special budget proposal for the NT$610.8 billion (US$18.23 billion) arms procurement, Tsai noted.

Tsai argued that Taiwan must keep its military capability strong to maintain cross-strait peace and that the military balance across the Strait in the past managed to deter mainland China from invading Taiwan.

However, mainland China is bullying Taiwan now that the island's defense budget has decreased, barring Taipei's bids to take part in international organizations and even planning to enact an "anti-secession law," Tsai said.

President Chen Shui-bian has over the past year put forth various proposals to avoid the outbreak of war across the Strait, which include building a framework of peace and stability, establishing a military confidence-building mechanism, setting up a military buffer zone and establishing a cross-strait code of conduct, he noted.
He promised that Taiwan will not launch an attack but will counterattack in case mainland China takes military action against the island. He also urged the people to support the arms procurement.

The government plans to purchase six Patriot PAC-III anti-missile batteries, eight diesel-electric submarines and a squadron of 12 anti-submarine aircraft, but the budget bill for the procurement has been stonewalled in the legislature by the opposition "pan-blue alliance" of the Kuomintang and People First Party, which believes the spending is unnecessary and a waste of taxpayers' money.

DOC.HEADLINE: NO CONFIRMATION OF LEE YUAN-TSEH AS ENVOY FOR BUSH INAUGURATION

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs won't confirmed an evening newspaper report Saturday that Lee Yuan-tseh, president of the Academia Sinica, will be President Chen Shui-bian's envoy to the second inauguration of U.S. President George W. Bush.
Michel Lu, a spokesman for the ministry, said the delegation to the inauguration is still being put together, and its members will be announced when the process is completed.
The China Times Express said Lee will lead the delegation to Washington on Jan. 17. In his entourage will be Joseph Wu, chairman of the Mainland Affairs Council.
The newspaper said Lee and Wu will exchange views with U.S. officials on issues of mutual concern on the sidelines of Bush's Jan. 20 second inauguration.

DOC.HEADLINE: EPA TO SEND DISINFECTION TEAM TO INDONESIA

TEXT.P: The Environmental Protection Administration (EPA) will send a team to tsunami-hit areas in Indonesia Sunday to help disinfect.

EPA Minister Chang Juu-en said Yuan Shao-ying, vice director-general of the EPA's Department of Environmental Sanitation and Toxic Substance Management, will lead a three-member team and bring disinfection equipment and pesticides.
The team will show volunteers and residents in Indonesia how to disinfect.

They will also donate 200 units that can dispense disinfectant. The EPA is also planning an additional assistance of NT$30 million (US$937,500) to provide sprayers, pesticides, disinfectants and other protective gear as needed, he added.
As long as there is the need, the EPA will ask Taipei city and county to send between 50 and 100 disinfection professionals so that residents can more quickly recover.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINESE PETROLEUM TO BUILD FOUR LNG TANKERS

TEXT.P: Taiwan's state-run Chinese Petroleum Corp. (CPC) is planning to build four tankers to deliver liquefied natural gas (LNG) from Qatar to the Taiwan Power Company's Tatan power plant, CPC officials said Saturday.
The tankers are estimated to cost US$600 million and the CPC will invite tenders from shipbuilders later this year, the officials said.
In addition to the CPC, the LNG supplier in Qatar has expressed an interest in the project, they said.

The CPC, the LNG supplier and the shipbuilder winning the tender will form a partnership that will be in charge of building the ships, arranging the shipping schedule as well as managing and maintaining the ships, they added.

DOC.HEADLINE: NO WORD YET OF FATE OF NEW YEAR CHARTER FLIGHT SERVICE: MAC

TEXT.P: Both Taiwan and mainland China are sincere in quickly working out the details for the special charter flight service prior to the coming Chinese Lunar New Year, but the government has not yet received any response on the issue from its negotiator, a government official said Saturday.

Chiu Tai-san, vice chairman of the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC), made the comment to dismiss a media report that Taiwan and mainland China have reached agreement on the arrangement for mainland-based Taiwan businessmen wishing to spend the lunar new year holidays early next month at home by taking charter flights.

According to Chiu, the MAC has not received any information from Lo Ta-hsing, chairman of the Taipei Airlines Association commissioned by the MAC to hold technical talks with representatives of the Civil Aviation Administration of China (CAAC) in Macau Friday.

Regarding the media report that Taiwan and the mainland have reached agreement in Macau on the model for "non-stop, round-trip, multi-destination flights by carriers on both sides, " Chang Jung-kung, spokesman for the opposition Kuomintang (KMT), called that only a technical detail which does not necessarily mean that the charter flights across the Taiwan Strait are ready.
The KMT will also organize a mission to Beijing to help with the issue due to the sensitive cross-strait situation.
The KMT delegation will depart for Beijing as scheduled on Sunday to hold talks the next day with officials of the Taiwan Affairs Office under the State Council and the CAAC.

The delegation will be headed by Tseng Yung-chuan, director of the KMT's Central Policy Committee, and will include KMT lawmakers John Chang and Chu Fong-chih, and People First Party lawmaker Li Hong-jyun.

The special Chinese Lunar New Year charter flights were first launched in 2003, involving only Taiwan carriers. But the service failed to proceed in 2004 as a result of the mainland's insistence upon mainland carriers being allowed to also offer flights.

Despite frequent and close trade and economic exchanges between Taiwan and mainland China, direct trade, transport and postal links have been absent between the two sides, which have been at odds since 1949, when the now-opposition KMT lost a civil war to communist forces and retreated to Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP, PFP COOPERATION GOOD FOR POLITICAL STABILITY: FORMER PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: Former President Lee Teng-hui said Saturday that if the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) can cooperate with the third-largest opposition party, the People First Party (PFP), it will help the stability of Taiwan politics.
Lee made the remarks while golfing in Taoyuan, northern Taiwan, with his friends and political figures, who gathered to celebrate his upcoming 84th birthday Sunday.

Asked by reports about the DPP cooperating with the PFP, Lee said, "That would be good and would be very helpful to stabilize the political situation in Taiwan. After all, Taiwan has been suffering for years."
He did not say if President Chen Shui-bian had asked his opinion on the impending Cabinet reshuffle during a meeting earlier this week.

Reports about the seemingly unlikely partnership between the pro-independence DPP and the pro-unification PFP emerged after President Chen offered to engage in party-to-party consultations in his New Year's Day address. The DPP garnered a worse-than-expected 89 seats in the Dec. 11 legislative elections, not enough to form a majority in the 225-seat legislature even with its ally, the Taiwan Solidarity Union, which won 12 seats.

Lee also said that he and his wife were concerned about the safety of their granddaughter, Lee Kun-yi, who recently flew to Italy to study the arts after finishing her Executive MBA degree at the London School of Economics and Political Science.

Lee said that he encountered a great number of inconveniences due to the interference of mainland China while he was traveling in Japan recently, and he worried that his granddaughter might encounter similar harassment during the long flight to Italy.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Times: Thousands missing as British death toll passes 400.
Around 2,000 Britons are still unaccounted for in countries worst hit by the Boxing Day tsunami, the police casualty bureau said yesterday. The number whose whereabouts is causing concern was disclosed as the full impact on Britain became clearer. The number of British dead is expected to reach 440 and to continue rising.
Financial Times: Peace hope hit as police blame IRA for bank robbery.
Hopes of securing a lasting political settlement in Northern Ireland received a serious blow on Friday when the province's police chief held the IRA responsible for one of the UK's biggest bank robberies.

DOC.HEADLINE: FUNDRAISING EVENTS LINED UP FOR TSUNAMI VICTIMS IN SOUTH ASIA

TEXT.P: The tsunami disaster in South Asia has brought out the best in the people of Taiwan, with various fundraising events held around the island Saturday to rally aid for the victims.
The Republic of China Red Cross will hold a charity concert in Taipei Saturday from 7 p.m. to 10 p.m.
The concert, covered by the local Dong Fong television station, will feature many famous musicians and well-known TV variety show hosts.
In Chiayi, southern Taiwan, a charity bazaar was held Saturday by World Vision in Taiwan to raise money for tsunami victims. Twenty-eight businesses donated their products to the bazaar.
An organizer of the bazaar said International World Vision hopes to raise US$50 million for the tsunami victims, and the Taiwan branch's share is NT$100 million, or US$3.12 million.
In Taichung City, a group of junior high school students sang at a local restaurant to raise funds for the tsunami victims.
Meanwhile, the Ministry of the Interior cautioned the public to be on the lookout for people who line their own pockets posing as volunteers collecting money for the tsunami victims.
According to the ministry, only 18 private organizations have informed the ministry that they will raise funds for the disaster zones in South Asia.

DOC.HEADLINE: ACADEMIA SINICA HEAD CONFIRMS HIS TRIP TO U.S. FOR BUSH INAUGURATION

TEXT.P: Academia Sinica President Lee Yuan-tseh confirmed Saturday that he will lead a delegation to Washington, D.C. to attend the second inauguration of U.S. President George W. Bush on Jan. 20.
Lee made the remarks on the sidelines of a meeting at the Academia Sinica, the highest research institute in Taiwan.
Lee said he will act as President Chen Shui-bian's envoy, but he will first attend an international meeting in Santa Barbara, California before going on to Washington, D.C. around Jan. 18.
The respected Nobel laureate in chemistry said that he is going for no other purpose but to be an envoy at the inauguration.

Lee said he will leave discussions on Taiwan-U.S. relations and related issues to other members of his delegation, which is said to include the nation's top mainland China policy planner -- Mainland Affairs Council Chairman Joseph Wu -- and lawmakers from various political parties.
"I don't know about this part, " he said, addressing the question on which issues concerning Taiwan-U.S. relations will be discussed during the visit. Lee will leave Washington D.C. Jan. 22.

DOC.HEADLINE: SUCCESS OF NEW YEAR CHARTERS HELPFUL TO EXPANDING FUTURE SERVICES: MAC

TEXT.P: It would be helpful to the expansion of cross-Taiwan Strait charter flight services in the future if passenger charter flights are successfully launched during next month's Chinese Lunar New Year holiday, Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Vice Chairman Chiu Tai-san said Saturday.

While cargo charters could be launched after that, passenger charters could be provided during other holidays, such as the Dragon Boat Festival and the Mid-autumn Festival and to other mainland Chinese destinations besides Shanghai and Beijing, Chiu said.

Chiu said both Taiwan and mainland China have shown a high degree of goodwill and sincerity in facilitating the new year's charter flights to transport mainland-based Taiwanese businessmen home for the holiday.
Everything has been developing in a positive direction so far, Chiu said.

Local media reports said that Lo Ta-hsing, chairman of the Taipei Airlines Association, authorized by the MAC to negotiate with Beijing authorities on the issue, had reached an agreement in principle with Civil Aviation Administration of China representatives in Macau Friday to allow non-stop, two-way, multi-destination flights operated by carriers on both sides.
But Chiu earlier said that he has yet to receive any information from Lo.

Chiu said this time around would involve a more complicated arrangement than in 2003 if mainland airliners are to join the operations and that the MAC needs to consult with the Ministry of National Defense on details such as the routes and time of the flights for security reasons.
The Chinese Lunar New Year charter flights were first launched in 2003 between Shanghai and Taipei/Kaohsiung via Hong Kong/Macau, with only Taiwanese carriers allowed to operate the services.
The flights were not provided last year mainly because Beijing insisted that mainland carriers be allowed to join the services but refused to negotiate with Taipei on the technical details involved.

DOC.HEADLINE: ECONOMICS MINISTER CALLS FOR MULTILATERAL TRADE COOPERATION

TEXT.P: To assuage concerns that Taiwan might become an outcast due to mainland China's economic expansion in conjunction with neighboring countries, Minister of Economic Affairs Ho Mei-yueh called Saturday for multilateral trade cooperation and free trade agreements (FTAs) with key economic partners to address the situation.
Ho made the remarks in an exclusive interview with the Central News Agency.

Claiming that Taiwan will confront fierce challenges if it fails to overcome flow-on effects from the mainland's economic integration with the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN), she pointed to the multilateral trade mechanisms under the framework of the World Trade Organization (WTO) and the establishment of FTAs with friendly countries as effective means to minimize the impact.

Products going between mainland China and the 10 ASEAN member states will all be customs duty free by 2010, when the mainland-ASEAN FTA inked in July last year is slated to come into effect. Meanwhile, Japan and South Korea have also started FTA talks with ASEAN. East Asia in general is moving toward setting up the world's largest single free trade market.

Taiwan's economy will brace for much greater difficulties should the ASEAN plus three (mainland China, Japan and South Korea) bloc be formed, she warned, adding that Taiwan must be prepared in advance, since Taiwan's hope of joining the current economic integration drive in the region seems extremely slim.
To offset the losses of being left out of the world's potentially largest market, Taiwan will do all it can to forge an FTA with the United States and other countries, she noted.

The United States would be highly symbolic in terms of Taiwan's FTA talks with other countries, while Taiwan would be a good option for the United States when seeking a good supplier in the region to the mainland Chinese and ASEAN markets, she said.

The Ministry of Economic Affairs is planning to draw up various position papers to explain the benefits of the issue to U.S. think tanks and the private sector to clear the way for Taiwan's FTA talks with the U. S. government, she added. "The road is long, but it is one that we must walk," she said.

DOC.HEADLINE: OVERSEAS CHINESE TO STAGE ANTI-CHINESE COMMUNIST MARCH IN WASHINGTON
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Jan. 7 (CNA) (By Wennie Chi and Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: About 30 Chinese groups in the United States will stage a anti-Chinese Communist march in Washington, D.C. Sunday, urging Chinese around the world to end communism.

The march, staged to show solidarity with a campaign to end communism initiated by 60 private and human rights groups around the world, is aimed at encouraging Chinese Communist members to desert their party.
Organizers of the march said the campaign of deserting communism was triggered by nine anti-communism articles published on an online Chinese-language weekly, the Epoch Times.
They claimed the articles has prompted a "communism-deserting wave" in mainland China to the alarm of Chinese leaders.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN HELPS TRANSPORT RELIEF SUPPLIES TO SRI LANKA
DOC.DATELINE: New York, Jan. 7 (CNA) (By Eric Tseng, Wu Hsien-kuang and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: Under the coordination of a Republic of China official in New York and a United States congressman, Taiwan's shipping company, Yang Ming Marine Transport Corp., shipped the first of three containers of relief materials and supplies collected by a Buddhist temple in Queens, New York to Sri Lanka for free.

Andrew Hsia, director of the Taipei Economic and Cultural Office in New York, U.S. Congressman Gary Ackerman as well as officials from the borough of Queens and Yang Ming Marine Transport Corp. attended the donation and shipping ceremony of the relief supplies with volunteers continuing to put clothes, food rations, drinking water, pharmaceuticals, batteries, toys and stationery into the container.

Hsia said that he received a call from Ackerman's office two days ago, saying that New York Buddhist Vihara, a Buddhist temple in Queens presided over by a Sri Lankan, received a great number of donated materials, but had no money to transport them, and asked for assistance.
After contacting Yang Ming Marine Transport Corp., the latter generously gave its consent for the free transportation, Hsia said.

He added though Taiwan is not a member of the United Nations, it is still a member of the international community, and that the government has donated US$50 million for tsunami-relief in South and Southeast Asia, and the private sector is also responding actively to the donation drive. Donation drives to assist the victims of the tsunami disaster will also continue among Taiwanese expatriates in the U.S., he said.

Meanwhile, a relief association formed by Taiwanese expatriates in Ottawa, Canada is urging generous donations to help the tsunami victims. A number of donations kiosks were set up in Chinatown streets Friday.
An association official said all donations will be passed to the charity organizations specified by the donors in Canada, but if unspecified, all the money will go to Red Cross Society in Canada.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER PLEDGES TO DO A GOOD JOB AS LONG AS HIS TERM LASTS

TEXT.P: Premier Yu Shyi-kun pledged Saturday during a trip to eastern Taiwan that he will do a good job as long as his term lasts.

Yu made the remarks in response to questions from the press as to whether he will be replaced or re-appointed premier after his Cabinet resigns en masse on Jan. 24 in preparation for a reshuffle in line with the formation of a new legislature on Feb. 1.
Yu was on an inspection trip to eastern Hualien and Taitung counties, which was described by the press as his "graduation tour."

Yu said the tour is unrelated to his possible career change and that he will ensure the government is working and will continue to supervise the progress of every major construction project as long as he is in the position.

In addition to inspecting the Yuchang highway project connecting Hualien's Yuli township and Taitung's Changpin township, Yu also visited the Human Rights Memorial Park on the outlying Green Island, where Taiwan's political prisoners used to be jailed.
According to Yu, besides culture and natural ecology, the history of Taiwan's human rights development should be one of the essential elements in Green Island's tourism industry.

DOC.HEADLINE: 60% OF WOMAN WORKERS BELIEVE BEING FAT AFFECTS JOB APPLICANTS: POLL

TEXT.P: Being overweight and looking for work could be a bad combination, according to about 60 percent of woman office workers in Taiwan.

The results of a poll, conducted by the Pan-Asia Human Resource Company between Dec. 20 and Jan. 4, found that 58.98 percent of the respondents considered that a job applicant being overweight would surely or probably have a negative impact on the interviewer and 41 percent believed it did not make a difference.
Of those responding to the poll, 44.68 percent said weight affects promotions and pay raises; 41.39 percent said it was "probably not" an issue and 13.93 percent said it was "definitely not."
In terms of working performance, 78.5 percent said it was "probably not" an influence.
Just over 2 percent said that being overweight affects interpersonal relationships, 15.02 percent said "probably not" and 82.84 percent said "absolutely not."

As for interactions between supervisors and subordinates, 43.17 percent considered that supervisors treat woman office workers with a good figure the same as others, while 56.83 percent thought that supervisors treated them better than others.
Faced with the cruel reality brought by being overweight, 85.65 percent cherished the idea of slimming, while 14.35 percent did not.

As for self-assessing their figure, 17 percent of the respondents said they were too thin, 43.37 percent believed they were slim or in the middle, 30.67 percent replied that they were overweight and 8.55 percent thought they were obese.
A total of 84.08 percent responding to the poll admitted they had tried to lose weight, while 15.92 percent said they had not.
Of those who had dieted, 28.49 percent succeeded, while 33.15 percent failed probably due to lack of persistence, with most of them ending up gaining back the weight.
A total of 5,937 valid responses were collected in the poll of randomly selected woman office workers islandwide. The survey had a margin of error of plus or minus 1.27 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP CAN COOPERATE WITH PFP OR KMT: TOP AIDE TO PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: Su Tseng-chang, secretary-general of the Presidential Office, said Saturday that if beneficial to the country, the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) can cooperate with the People First Party (PFP) as well as the largest opposition party, the Kuomintang (KMT).

Su made the remarks in the northern Taiwan city of Keelung, one of many stops of his islandwide trip in a get-out-the-vote drive to solicit support for his bid to run for DPP chairmanship in a by-election Jan. 30.

Asked about inter-party cooperation for the formation of a new Cabinet, Su said that President Chen Shui-bian has said clear that the public is tired of the forever bickering between the ruling and opposition parties, which stalled the nation's development during his first term, and is aspiring for a national reconciliation.

The president has said the time for party-to-party consultations has come, Su noted, echoing the president's words that anything that is beneficial to stability in domestic politics, the welfare of the people, harmony among ethnic groups and cross-strait relations can be open for discussion and consultations between parties.

The DPP is a responsible party and will not trade positions for political gains, Su said, adding that the DPP hopes to cooperate with the PFP, and could also discuss anything that is beneficial to the country with the KMT.

The DPP failed in its bid to gain a majority in the Dec. 11 legislative elections. It garnered a worse-than-expected 89 out of 225 seats and couldn't pass the threshold of a majority of 113 seats even with the 12 seats of its ally, the Taiwan Solidarity Union.

Su, the sole candidate in the DPP chairman by-election, also said the post of chairmanship is not an easy one, as there will be elections coming in the next two years and the chairman has to shoulder heavy campaigning responsibilities.

Su noted that there will be mayor and magistrate elections at the end of this year, as well as city and county councilmen elections next year. There will even be an election to select the members of a "functional" National Assembly, whose 300 members will be elected in proportion to various political parties. The ad hoc body will be charged with the mission of approving a series of constitutional amendments passed by the Legislative Yuan last August, and then dissolve itself.

Though assured of victory in the Jan. 30 chairman election, Su nevertheless went out of his way to travel islandwide, hoping that party members could come out to vote so that he can get a "not too bad" score sheet.
He citied the example of Kaohsiung Mayor Frank Hsieh, who was also a sole candidate in a party chairman election before only managed to attract 10 percent of voters to cast ballots.

DOC.HEADLINE: LIEN WILL MEET PRESIDENT ONLY IF SOONG COMES ALONG: KMT OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: Opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan is willing to meet President Chen Shui-bian if People First Party (PFP) Chairman James Soong is also present, a KMT official said Saturday.

KMT Legislator and Central Policy Committee Executive Director Tseng Yung-chuan also noted that if the president shows enough sincerity to ask Soong to organize a coalition Cabinet, the KMT, a close ally of the PFP, will be happy to see Soong be the country's next premier.

Tseng was commenting on recent reports indicating that the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) has taken steps to seek inter-party negotiations and possible cooperation between the DPP and PFP, part of the so-called "pan-blue alliance" of the KMT and PFP, which won a legislative majority in elections late last year.

Tseng, however, warned Chen not to play games to try to break the two main opposition parties apart, stressing that the KMT and PFP enjoy the same political ideas, and that only when Chen delivers invitations to both Soong and Lien for a joint meeting will the KMT leader agree to take part in such a gathering.
Meanwhile, echoing Tseng's comments was Liu Wen-hsiung, convener of the PFP caucus in the Legislative Yuan, who said that his party is not opposed to a possible Chen-Soong-Lien meeting.

However, Liu said that only on the condition of the president defending the existence of the Republic of China and that of the DPP giving up its party plank concerning the promotion of Taiwan independence would Soong be likely to agree to meet Chen for talks.
Also, such a meeting would have to be "public and transparent, " Liu said.
At DPP headquarters, however, a top official blasted the KMT's suggestion of allowing Soong to serve as premier, saying that the KMT's move was aimed at disturbing possible DPP-PFP cooperation.
Acting DPP Chairman Ker Chien-ming said that President Chen is willing to meet Lien and Soong first separatedly.
Following a protocol in international negotiations, Ker said, there should be first bilateral talks and then multilateral talks, Ker stressed.

In line with constitutional precedent, Premier Yu Shyi-kun and all Cabinet members are expected to resign en masse after the current Legislative Yuan concludes its final session on Jan. 21. Rumors have circulated for the last couple of weeks about the possibility of Chen naming a new premier and forming a coalition Cabinet with opposition parties. Senior government officials, including Yu himself, have been tightlipped about the imminent Cabinet reshuffle.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOEA EYEING TO MAKE TAIWAN INDUSTRIES 'ECO-SYSTEM': HO

TEXT.P: Taiwan must seek to transform its industry into an "eco-system" to help maintain the country's sustainable development, Minister of Economic Affairs Ho Mei-yueh said Saturday.

Speaking in an exclusive interview with the Central News Agency, Ho said that the government's leading task to achieve that goal is to create a favorable environment in which all sectors can progress continuously.
The government should first help promising businesses keep sustainable development and second, assist them in expanding, Ho said.

In her viewpoint, the government should further promote the industries with an annual production value of more than NT$100 billion (US$3.1 billion) and help competitive small businesses to grow to mid-scale. "Only through adequate adjustments and replacements can Taiwan's industry survive to become an "eco-system" amid robust foreign competition," she said.
According to the economics minister, many Taiwan industries actually possess an advantageous position in the intensively competitive world market.

Currently, the domestic semiconductor and panel display industries yield an output value of about NT$1.14 trillion and NT$662 billion per year, respectively, while the biotech and digital content industries post a production value of NT$214 billion and NT$450 billion, respectively. The four industries are the key hi-tech industries included in the Cabinet's "two-trillion, two-star" program to transform Taiwan into a technology-intensive island.

She said that the government plans to advocate the semiconductor, panel display, petrochemical, steel and telecommunications industries to have a production value worth over NT$1 trillion by 2008 and help the textile, electronics parts, automobile, machinery equipment and foodstuff industries create an output value of more than NT$500 billion by that time, in addition to another 14 with NT$100 billion.
To push for an overall industrial upgrading for the country, the government is perfectly aware of the fact that "all eggs should not be put in the same basket," she explained.

The government is fully responsible for ironing out fair and just rules for industries in which all types of businesses are encouraged to expand and make profits, she said, adding that once such a competition system is set up across the board, market forces will eventually have a say in many issues.

TEXT.P: The following are important events scheduled to take place Sunday, Jan. 9:

08:50, A delegation of opposition Kuomintang's legislative caucus will leave for mainland China via the Chiang Kai-shek International Airport to discuss cross-strait charter flight services with Beijing authorities.

10: 00, President of the Association of Former Canadian War Prisoners in Taiwan Micheal Hurst will start a commemorative tour of the Kaohsiung Port in southern Taiwan.
10:30, An album of former President Lee Teng-hui's photos will be issued at the Civil Service Development Institute in Taipei.
14: 00, An exposition of Taipei City's small- and medium-sized enterprises will be held at the Taipei Youth Activity Center.

DOC.HEADLINE: EARTHQUAKE ROCKS EASTERN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: An earthquake with a preliminary magnitude of 4.3 on the Richter scale rocked eastern Taiwan Saturday. No casualties were reported.

Central Weather Bureau officials said that the epicenter of the quake was located 16.6 kilometers northwest of the Peinan seismic station in Taitung County and 8.9 kilometers below the earth's surface.
The quake, which occurred at 11:27 a.m., had an intensity of 4.0 in Chulu, 3.0 in Peinan and 2.0 in Taitung City, they added.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Sunday, Jan. 9, or the 29th day of the 11th month of the Year of the Monkey according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1719: France declares war on Spain.
1792: Russia ends war with Turkey.
1799: Prime Minister William Pitt the Younger introduces income tax in Britain at two shillings on the pound (10 percent). The unpopular move is to raise cash for the even more unpopular war against Napoleonic France.
1806: Horatio Nelson, the heroic British naval commander who defeated French and Spanish naval forces at the Battle of Trafalgar where he was mortally wounded, is buried at St. Paul's Cathedral in London.
1811: The first women's golf tournament takes place in Scotland.
1913: Richard Nixon, the former U.S. president who resigned in disgrace after the Watergate scandal, is born.
1920: Alexander Fleming pioneers the use of penicillin at St. Mary's Hospital in London.
1929: The world's first training center for guide dogs for the blind is established in Nashville, Tennessee.
1932: U.S. Secretary of State Henry Stimson declares that the United States will not recognize any treaty that violates the Open Door Policy.
1933: Students of a Japanese girl's college commit suicide en masse at Mt. Mihara on Oshima Island. Up to the end of that year, a total of 804 male and 1,104 female students throughout the country followed suit.
1945: American forces invade the Philippine island of Luzon.
1947: A smallpox epidemic breaks out in the Taiwan counties of Taichung and Kaohsiung.
1957: Mainland Chinese Premier Zhou En-lai accepts an honorary doctorate from Moscow University.
1957: Anthony Eden, the British prime minister who decided to go to war over the Suez Canal, resigns.
1962: The United States and Japan sign an agreement for Japan to pay US$290 million in settlement of its debt for post-war U.S. aid.
1966: A group of mainland Chinese naval servicemen on a landing ship (LCM) from Foochow defect and land on Republic of China-controlled Matsu Island. They are later killed when a plane taking them to Taiwan is shot down by mainland Chinese planes.
1971: Construction of the Chingshan power plant, the largest hydroelectric power plant in Taiwan, is completed.
1972: The "Queen Elizabeth," once the greatest of all trans-Atlantic liners, sinks in Hong Kong after a mysterious fire.
1974: The Australia-Free China Society opens its Taipei office.
1976: ROC Premier Chiang Ching-kuo visits the U.S. Seventh Fleet flagship at the invitation of Vice Admiral Thomas Hayward.
1978: Islamic revolution erupts in Iran.
1980: Saudi Arabia announces that 63 of the Shiite extremists who seized the Great Mosque in Mecca the previous November have been executed.
1996: A Russian-made cargo plane of Zaire Airlines crashes into a crowded market in Kinshasa City, killing nearly 300 people.
2000: Sao Tome and Principe Prime Minister Guilherme Posser da Costa and several government officials arrive in Taipei for a six-day visit.
2001: The Control Yuan clears the name of late army chief Gen. Sun Li-jen based on a report by Chu Hung-yuan, an Academia Sinica historian. Sun, a U.S.-trained officer who had been a prominent military leader during the ROC's eight-year war against Japan, was fired from his post as personnel chief-of-staff to late President Chiang Kai-shek in 1955 when one of his former confidants was allegedly found to be spying for Beijing.
2002: The Retribution Act for Bandits, a harsh criminal code legislated in 1944 during wartime while the Republic of China government was ruling mainland China, is formally abolished to better protect human rights in Taiwan.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "Be not concerned for want of a position; be concerned how to fit yourself for a position. Be not concerned that you are not known, but seek to do something to deserve a reputation."

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN DISINFECTION MISSION DEPARTS FOR INDONESIA

TEXT.P: A three-member team from the Environmental Protection Administration (EPA) departed Taipei Sunday for the earthquake and tsunami-hit area of Medan, Indonesia, to help bolster post-disaster disinfection work there.

Team leader Yuan Shao-ying, vice director-general of the EPA's Department of Environmental Sanitation and Toxic Substance Management, said at Chiang Kai-shek International Airport that the team is bringing a number of automatic disinfectant dispensers to Medan and will look into how efficiently the Indonesian authorities have been using 100 semi-automatic sprayers and 50-kg condenser disinfectants that Taiwan sent there last week.
An additional 200 dispensers are ready to be sent if they are needed, Yuan said.
The EPA is also planning an additional assistance of NT$30 million (US$937,500) to provide sprayers, pesticides, disinfectants and protective gear, he added.
Yuan's team members are Chang Chih-ying, a disinfection professional, and Lin Hsi-chin, an official with Taipei city government's Environmental Protection Bureau in charge of disinfection affairs.

Taiwan has continued to send cash aid, medical supplies and relief goods to Indonesia since Dec. 26, even though the Indonesian government turned down Taiwan's request to take part in an international conference held in Jakarta Jan. 6 to coordinate relief efforts for the tsunami-hit nations around the Indian Ocean.

Indonesia was the hardest-hit nation in the Dec. 26 magnitude 9 earthquake offshore its western city of Banda Aceh and the ensuing tsunami. More than half of the estimated 150,000 people around the Indian Ocean that were killed in the devastation were in Indonesia. The tsunami also caused unprecedented damage in many other countries in the region.
Taiwan, which has promised US$50 million in aid to the disaster-hit nations, is the world's eighth-biggest single donor thus far.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT DELEGATION DEPARTS FOR BEIJING TO DISCUSS CHARTER FLIGHTS

TEXT.P: A delegation of the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) left Sunday for Beijing to meet with mainland Chinese officials responsible for Taiwan and aviation affairs to discuss issues relating to the possible operation of Lunar New Year cross-Taiwan Strait charter flights.
The delegation consists of four members, including KMT legislators Tseng Yung-chuan, John Chang and Chu Feng-chih, and KMT spokesman Chang Yung-kung.
Legislator John Chang said before departure that Taipei and Beijing still need to discuss many details about the launch of the charter flights.
The legislator had successfully pushed for the launch of Lunar New Year charter flights across the Taiwan Strait for the first time in 2003.

Pointing out that launching charter flights in 2005 had originally been seen by many as a hopeless matter, the legislator said that the KMT hopes it can successfully push for the matter again this year, following the 2003 method.

He claimed that the chances of success are 70 percent, with the other 30 percent subject to talks with Beijing, adding that the Mainland Affairs Council and President Chen Shui-bian will have to make a decision if the delegation can reach an agreement in Beijing.
Expressing the hope that the current cross-strait tension can be eased by a successful launch of the charter flights, Chang also said that the Taiwan government should not neglect the people's will.
Meanwhile, delegation chief Tseng said that the delegation, along with Taiwan airlines representatives, will discuss with mainland officials and airlines the specifics of the charter flights.
He said the KMT hopes that the mainland will agree to use Beijing, Xiamen and Guanchou as departure and destination cities for the flights.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAITRA TO SET UP MORE FOOTHOLDS IN ASEAN COUNTRIES

TEXT.P: The Taiwan External Trade Development Council (TAITRA) said Sunday it will open 10 new overseas offices in the next three years to cope with regional integration-oriented international economic development trends.

Four of the new offices will be located in member states of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) because emerging markets in Asia are the focus of global competition, TAITRA officials said.

Noting that ASEAN countries are developing import-substitute and export-oriented industries, the officials said, Taiwan's machinery, electronics and information-technology products and auto parts and components are highly competitive and suitable for export to ASEAN countries.

As ASEAN is also endeavoring to forge free trade agreements with mainland China, Japan and South Korea, the officials said TAITRA has stepped up efforts to help local companies make inroads into the vast ASEAN market.

In the coming three years, the officials said, TAITRA will open new offices in four ASEAN countries -- Thailand, Indonesia, Malaysia and Singapore -- to strengthen services for Taiwan companies and help them explore joint venture opportunities.

Moreover, the officials said, TAITRA will also set up new offices in Chicago, Chile, Spain, Romania, Ukraine and South Africa in the near future to offer better services for Taiwan enterprises in their global business expansion drives.
In 2005, the officials said, TAITRA will focus on promoting exports to nine countries -- Vietnam, Thailand, India, Japan, South Korea, Brazil, Argentina, Russia and Bangladesh.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP TO REVISE SOVEREIGNTY-DEFENDING RESOLUTION: PARTY WHIP

TEXT.P: The ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) is willing to revise a proposed sovereignty-defending resolution in an attempt to facilitate consensus between the DPP and the opposition on efforts to safeguard the sovereignty of the Republic of China, a DPP legislator said Sunday.

Tsai Huang-liang, party whip of the DPP caucus at the Legislative Yuan, said the DPP leadership will meet Monday to work out a revision to the proposed sovereignty-defending resolution based on the principles of seeking cross-Taiwan Strait peace, maintaining the status quo in the strait and upholding ROC sovereignty.

The DPP will then fax copies of the revised draft bill to the major opposition parties in the hope that the resolution will be passed soon as an effective counterattack to Beijing's so-called "anti-secession law," Tsai noted.

President Chen Shui-bian in his New Year address delivered Jan. 1 condemned Beijing's attempt to enact an anti-secession law, calling it an effort to seek justification for a military invasion of Taiwan, and therefore constituting a unilateral change of the status quo in the Taiwan Strait and posing the biggest-ever threat to regional stability and world peace.
The DPP submitted the proposed resolution to the Legislative Yuan for debate last week but it was ignored by the opposition parties.
Tsai said that a revised resolution draft will be submitted again next Tuesday to the Legislative Procedure Committee for debate and screening.

Tsai noted that opposition lawmakers are welcome to jointly author the content of the sovereignty-defending resolution so long as three principles -- seeking cross-strait peace, maintaining the status quo in the Taiwan Strait and upholding the ROC's sovereignty -- are observed.

In the original copy, the DPP says that the ROC is a sovereign state existing as a separate political entity to the mainland, that this status quo should not be changed unless approved by all the people of Taiwan via a nationwide referendum, and that the existence of the ROC should be respected by the international community, including the mainland.

Attempts, particularly attempts to use force, by any country in the world to challenge the above-mentioned reality, regardless of whether by legislation or policy-making, will be relentlessly condemned and opposed by the people of Taiwan, the resolution says.

Responding to Tsai's call for support from the opposition parties, Chen Chien-ming, a party whip of the legislative caucus of the Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU), an ally of the ruling DPP, said the TSU will temporarily withhold its support until the DPP has clearly defined ROC sovereignty.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S TEXTILE TRADE SURPLUS MIGHT HIT US$10 BILLION IN 2004

TEXT.P: The trade surplus of Taiwan's textile industry in the first eleven months of last year amounted to US$9.1 billion, an increase of 5 percent over the figure for the same period of the previous year, and is expected to reach US$9.9 billion or US$10 billion for the whole of 2004.

According to preliminary statistics released by customs, Taiwan's total trade in the first eleven months of last year amounted to some US$311 billion, or an increase of 27.4 percent compared with the amount for the same period of 2003, with a surplus of US$7.27 billion.

The statistics also show that during the first eleven months of 2004, the total amount of Taiwan's textile trade was US$14.025 billion, marking a growth of 8.3 percent over the previous year's level and creating a trade surplus of US$9.1 billion, or an increase of 5 percent over the year-earlier figure.
Taiwan's textile exports amounted to U$11.56 billion in the first eleven months of last year and it only imported US$2.46 billion-worth of textile products during the same period.

DOC.HEADLINE: 'ANTI-SECESSION LAW' AIMED AT MAKING EXCUSE FOR INVADING TAIWAN
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Jan. 8 (CNA) (By Wennie Chi and Deborah Kuo )

TEXT.P: Prominent mainland Chinese dissident Wei Jingsheng, who has lived in exile overseas in recent years, said Saturday that Beijing's proposed anti-secession law is a scheme to seek legal justification for a military invasion of Taiwan.
Wei was in Washington, D.C. Saturday to attend an anti-Chinese communist rally staged by about 30 Chinese groups in the United States calling for Chinese around the world to end communism.

In light of Beijing's drafting of the anti-secession law, Wei said cross-Taiwan Strait relations are now even more jittery than during 1996, when China test-fired live missiles and held live-ammunition war games in the Taiwan Strait.

Wei said that some politicians in Taiwan thought that after Hu Jintao replaced Jiang Zemin as the mainland Chinese president, Beijing's attitude toward Taiwan would become milder. As a matter of fact, he said, the "true colors" of the communists have surfaced once again, demonstrated by the recent planning of the anti-secession law.

Invading Taiwan is a "big deal" and there have been many voices opposed to the notion around the mainland in the past. However, Wei said, it is increasingly noticeable in recent years that the mainland leadership is attempting to "cook" the mainland people's patriotism by taking advantage of rising pro-independence sentiment within Taiwan.
To pave the way for the communists to teach Taiwan a lesson militarily, the Beijing leadership has thought about enacting the anti-secession law, Wei added.

Meanwhile, Wei said some people in Taiwan believe the mainland will not attack Taiwan militarily based on economic considerations. Wei urged these people not to harbor such beliefs any longer, saying that the communists, as a whole, are basically a daring group willing to take risks. Citing history as an example, Wei said that some 50 years ago, the communists managed to defeat the Nationalist forces and take control of the whole of the mainland simply because they "dared to."

Believing that Beijing's passing of the anti-secession law is an irreversible trend, Wei suggested that Taiwan first adjust its foreign policy to strengthen bilateral exchanges with the United States and other countries so as to win their support.

At the same time, he said, Taiwan should also improve publicity toward the mainland people. Showing goodwill to the communist rulers is useless, Wei claimed, adding that it is more important to win the hearts and souls of the mainland people rather than their rulers.

Wei, who once said that maintaining Taiwan's interests is tantamount to maintaining a source of hope for democratization in mainland China, has also claimed that the United States will not come to Taiwan's rescue under any circumstances.
Wei was imprisoned for 18 years on the mainland for his pro-democracy activities and criticism of the Beijing authorities.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT EYES WUCHIU ISLET FOR NEW TOURISM, RELIGION HUB

TEXT.P: The Executive Yuan is eyeing the Republic of China-held tiny outlying islet of Wuchiu -- located between Matsu and Kinmen islands -- as a new tourist attraction, as well as a religion hub for followers of the goddess Matsu across the Taiwan Strait.

With its beautiful coastline and surrounding blue seas, Wuchiu, which is under the acting jurisdiction of the Kinmen county government, could be turned into a tourist attraction, especially because of its streets of stone cabins built in unknown years by unknown people, Chang Ching-sen, an Executive Yuan official in charge of promoting tourism in offshore island areas, said Sunday after making a field trip to Wuchiu Jan. 4.

Wuchiu, with its unique military bastion and related buildings, could also be remodeled into a recreational center for young people interested in picking up combat skills and playing war games, Chang said.
The tiny island of just 1.2 square kilometers could also be turned into a religion hub, given its proximity to Fujian Province's Meizhou City, where Matsu is said to have originated, Chang said.
Thousands of Taiwan worshippers of Matsu would see their annual pilgrimages to the mainland greatly shortened if they could proceed to Meizhou City via Taichung and Wuchiu, Chang added.

Wuchiu's name hit the front pages of local newspapers in recent years after it was chosen by Taiwan Power Company (Taipower) as a dump site for Taipower's nuclear waste. The plan was aborted after opposition by the locals as well as the central government.
Currently, about 500 soldiers and officers are posted on the islet. Only about 50 civilians live there.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. HAS BRIEFED TAIWAN ON 'ANTI-SECESSION LAW' TALKS WITH BEIJING

TEXT.P: U.S. officials have briefed the Republic of China's representative office in Washington, D.C. on their recent talks with a senior mainland Chinese official in charge of Taiwan affairs, a Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) official said Sunday.

Chen Yunlin, director of the Taiwan Affairs Office of mainland China's State Council, visited the United States last week. His visit came amid reports that the mainland's rubber-stamp legislature -- the National People's Congress -- will pass an anti-secession law in March. As the proposed legislation will create a legal pretext for Beijing to use military force to unify Taiwan, Chen's visit was believed to be aimed at dissuading the Bush administration from opposing the so-called anti-secession law.

The MOFA official, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said the ROC government has come to know about the content of Chen's talks with relevant U.S. authorities through Taiwan's representative office in Washington.

Meanwhile, MOFA spokesman Michel Lu said President Chen Shui-bian has named Academia Sinica President Lee Yuan-tseh to head a delegation to Washington to attend the Jan. 20 second inauguration of U.S. President George W. Bush.
Lee will attend the inauguration as Chen's special envoy, Lu said, adding that the MOFA has informed the U.S. authorities of the roster of delegation members.
The MOFA will publicize the delegation member list when all administrative formalities are completed, Lu said.
MOFA sources said the nation's top mainland policy planner -- Mainland Affairs Council Chairman Joseph Wu -- will be among the mission members.

Other delegates will include legislators from the ruling and opposition parties -- Kuo Cheng-liang of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party, Sun Kuo-hua of the Kuomintang, Sun Ta-chien of the People First Party and Wu Tung-sheng of the Taiwan Solidarity Union. A research fellow from Academia Sinica, the nation's foremost research body, will also join the delegation.
As the Legislative Yuan is busy screening several critical bills and the central government's 2005 budget plan, the sources said, the mission roster may still be subject to changes.

According to the sources, Lee, a co-winner of the 1986 Nobel Prize in chemistry, will first attend an international meeting in Santa Barbara, California before going on to Washington around Jan. 18, and is scheduled to return to Taipei two days after Bush's inauguration.
In line with past precedent, the delegation is expected to meet with U.S. administration officials and congressional members as well as think tank scholars during the visit.

But Lee said a day earlier that he is going for no other purpose but to be Chen's envoy at the inauguration. He said he will leave discussions on Taiwan-U.S. relations and related issues to other members of his delegation.

MOFA officials said the delegation members will have different itineraries after attending the inauguration. While Lee and some delegation members will return first, others will stay for talks with American officials, scholars and experts. Topics expected to be addressed will include Beijing's anti-secession legislation, Chen Yun-lin's just-concluded U.S. visit, Taiwan's long-stalled NT$610.8 billion arms procurement package and President Chen's plan to form a special commission to promote peaceful developments on both sides of the Taiwan Strait.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI, BEIJING REACH TACIT AGREEMENT ON HOLIDAY CHARTER FLIGHTS: DPP

TEXT.P: The Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) has reached a tacit agreement with Beijing civil aviation authorities about the basic principles for the launch of direct charter flights across the Taiwan Strait during the Lunar New Year holiday, a legislator of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) disclosed Sunday.

Legislator Tsai Huang-liang, who also serves as secretary-general of the DPP's legislative caucus, made the remarks after a delegation from the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) headed for mainland China earlier in the day to help the aviation sector arrange direct cross-strait charter flights to be operated during this year's holiday period.

Tsai told reporters that the MAC, the top agency in charge of charting Taiwan's policies toward the mainland, and Beijing's Civil Aviation Administration of China (CAAC) have reached a tacit agreement that the proposed cross-strait charter flight services will be offered by carriers on both sides under the principle of "two-way, multi-destination, non-stop flights."

Representatives from the Taipei Airlines Association (TAA) , authorized by the MAC to negotiate with the Beijing authorities on the issue, have contacted the CAAC to help arrange cross-strait holiday charter flights for Taiwanese businessmen operating on the mainland, Tsai pointed out.

Although the planned charter flight services can be achieved through negotiations between the civil aviation sectors of both sides, Tsai went on, the DPP's legislative caucus is happy to see the KMT delegation traveling to the mainland to negotiate with the Beijing authorities on the issue.

As for the criticism by some pro-independence activists that the proposed "no-stopover in a third place "is tantamount to direct air links between Taiwan and the mainland, Tsai explained that this is an expedient move aimed at making the much-anticipated holiday charter flights a reality for the convenience of the large number of mainland-based Taiwanese businessmen wishing to return for family reunions.
"It is acceptable in principle for the charter flights exclusively for the Lunar New Year holiday to fly over the aviation information zone of a third country," Tsai said.

However, he stressed that the issue of future direct air links involves the country's sovereignty and is different from the holiday charters, so they must be negotiated by the Taipei-based Straits Exchange Foundation and the Beijing-based Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait.

Meanwhile, Chen Chien-ming, convener of the legislative caucus of the opposition Taiwan Solidarity Union, said that his party supports the planned holiday flight services, but added that such flights should be operated under the principles of safety, dignity, equality and reciprocity.

With the consent of the Beijing authorities, six Taiwan carriers operated Lunar New Year charter flights in 2003 between Shanghai and Taipei/Kaohsiung via Hong Kong/Macau. The services were discontinued the following year because Beijing insisted that mainland carriers also be allowed to join the service but refused to come to the negotiating table to discuss the issue with Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: UNIFICATION VS. INDEPENDENCE SHOULD BE SET ASIDE: PFP LAWMAKER

TEXT.P: A senior legislator of the opposition People First Party (PFP) called on the ruling and opposition parties Sunday to set aside the unification versus independence debate in order to reach reconciliation among domestic political parties as soon as possible.

Legislator Liu Wen-hsiung, who is also chief convener of the PFP caucus in the Legislative Yuan, made the appeal against the backdrop that President Chen Shui-bian has been seeking to end long-term inter-party disagreements and bickering since the Dec. 11 legislative elections, in which the "pan-green camp" failed to gain a majority in the 225-seat legislature.

Although it is impossible for the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) to give up what Liu described as its pro-independence ideology at present, he claimed that setting aside the unification versus independence debate is the consensus of opinion of a majority of the people of Taiwan.

Only when the DPP expresses willingness to freeze its "Taiwan independence platform" in a certain period of time and signs a formal statement on a public occasion will the gateway to inter-party reconciliation be opened, according to Liu.

Touching on a recent proposal by the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) that KMT Chairman Lien Chan and his PFP counterpart, James Soong, meet Chen to exchange views on national affairs, Liu said that Soong has no intention of discussing with Chen issues concerning the formation of the new Cabinet or inter-party negotiations.

The PFP will stick to its stance of defending the existence of the Republic of China while opposing Taiwan independence, and will not make inter-party cooperation an exchange of personal posts or interests, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: CIVIC GROUPS STAGE DEMONSTRATION IN FRONT OF CHINESE EMBASSY IN U.S.
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Jan. 8 (CNA) (By Chi Chin-ling and Luis Huang)

TEXT.P: A group of pro-democracy activists from mainland China and members of local human rights groups and Taiwanese expatriate communities in the United States staged a demonstration in front of the Beijing Embassy in Washington, D.C. Saturday, urging the international community to join forces to defend human rights in the new year.

Representatives from about 40 different groups, including the Free China Movement, gathered on the avenue in front of the mainland Chinese embassy to participate in the demonstration staged by the Epoch Times, waving placards that read "Say bye-for-good to China."

Wei Jingsheng, an exiled mainland Chinese pro-democracy activist, who lives in exile, said it is time for the Chinese people to wake up and say goodbye to the Chinese Communist Party. He added that the communist regime has been persecuting the people on the mainland for many years.
Nieh Sen, director of the branch office of the Epoch Times in Washington, D.C., said that the activity was organized to echo a joint campaign launched by more than 60 civic groups around the world.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENTIAL OFFICE REBUTS 'CLOUDED LEOPARD' ARMORED VEHICLE REPORT

TEXT.P: The Presidential Office debunked a media report Sunday that the military has spent a huge sum of money producing a new eight-wheel armored vehicle for emergency use by President Chen Shui-bian and his family.

"The report is an outrageous distortion of facts, " Presidential Office Deputy Secretary-General James Huang, said, adding that the Presidential Office deeply regrets the report that he described as "deliberately distorted."
Huang stressed that the military has developed the vehicle mainly to cope with Taiwan's special terrain and to upgrade the military's overall combat capabilities.

The so-called Clouded Leopard vehicle development project has nothing to do with the Wanchun Plan, which refers to a program related to vehicles to be used by the president under emergency circumstances, Huang said.
"The new armored vehicle is not designed to meet the president's special needs. It is designed to grapple with Taiwan's topography and upgrade the military's combat prowess," Huang added.
An evening newspaper claimed Sunday that the military has spent NT$60 million producing the eight-wheel armored vehicle for emergency use by the first family.
The report said Chen will preside over the commissioning of the vehicle at a military-run factory in the central county of Nantou Jan. 11.

The new vehicle, which was developed under a project code-named Clouded Leopard, will be able to carry eight people, the report said, adding that the new vehicle is bigger than an armored vehicle in use at present.
The report further said the locally produced vehicle is only about one-quarter of the cost of a U.S.-built armored vehicle.

DOC.HEADLINE: DEFENSE MINISTRY REFUTES ARMORED VEHICLE REPORT

TEXT.P: The Ministry of National Defense (MND) refuted a media report Sunday that the military has spent NT$60 million manufacturing a new eight-wheel armored vehicle for emergency use by President Chen Shui-bian and his family.

"The military has just completed research and development of a new armored vehicle style which has not been put into mass production, " the MND's Office of Military Spokesman said in a press statement.

Stressing that the new-style armored vehicle, which has been developed under a project code-named Clouded Leopard, has just undergone initial testing, the MND press statement said it is premature to calculate the cost of each new-style armored vehicle.
The press release further said that local news media have recently often speculated on military defense affairs without bothering to verify their reports.

"We are hopeful that local media can exercise prudence in dealing with defense-related affairs to avoid endangering national security and violating existing national security regulations, " the press statement said.
An evening newspaper claimed Sunday that the military has spent NT$60 million producing an eight-wheel armored vehicle for emergency use by the first family.
The report said President Chen will preside over the commissioning of the vehicle at a military-run factory in the central county of Nantou Jan. 11.
The new vehicle will be able to carry eight people, the report said, adding that the new vehicle is bigger than an armored vehicle in use at present.
The report further said the locally produced vehicle is only about one-quarter of the cost of a U.S.-built armored vehicle.
The Presidential Office already dismissed the report as false and misrepresenting.

"The report is an outrageous distortion of facts, " Presidential Office Deputy Secretary-General James Huang, said, adding that the Presidential Office deeply regrets the report that he described as "deliberately distorted."
Huang stressed that the military has developed the vehicle mainly to cope with Taiwan's special terrain and to upgrade the military's overall combat capabilities.

The so-called Clouded Leopard vehicle development project has nothing to do with the Wanchun Plan, which refers to a program related to vehicles to be used by the president under emergency circumstances, Huang said.
"The new armored vehicle is not designed to meet the president's special needs. It is designed to grapple with Taiwan's topography and upgrade the military's combat prowess," Huang added.

DOC.HEADLINE: 1,338 PHOTOS PUBLISHED FEATURING EX-PRESIDENT'S CAREER, FAMILY LIFE

TEXT.P: Former President Lee Teng-hui said Sunday at a ceremony to mark the launch of a collection of 1,338 photos documenting his career and family life that he has never wavered on his basic political ideal of doing things based on the stance of the people of Taiwan.

"My opponents have branded me as a fickle politician. They blamed me for intending to 'terminate' the Republic of China of which I was once a president. Their critique is superficial and frivolous. Since I joined politics, I have never changed my determination to do things for the well-being of the people of Taiwan," Lee told his supporters present at the ceremony.

During his 12-year presidency, Lee spared no efforts to promote Taiwan's international profile and riled Beijing by defining cross-Taiwan Strait relations as "state-to-state" in nature. Since he stepped down as the ROC head of state, Lee has become even more vocal in promoting Taiwan's identity separate from China's.
Lee said his ideology has never changed. "But now, as a private citizen, I have more freedom to do what I think I have to do." he added.
The photo collection was published in coincidence with Lee's 84th birthday on the lunar calendar.

The collection contains many treasurable photos featuring Lee's interaction with the late President Chiang Ching-kuo, including a 1975 photo showing Lee accompanying Chiang on an inspection tour of the frontline island of Matsu in his capacity as a minister-without-portfolio.

Although Lee's relations with two current opposition leaders -- Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan and People First Party Chairman James Soong have soured, the album contains a number of photos featuring Lee's previous interactions with them. Lee used to be KMT chairman for 12 years, but was expelled from the party over Taiwan's identity issues.

Photos featuring Lee and his running mate Lien in the 1996 presidential election as well as those featuring Lee campaigning for Soong in the run-up to the 1994 Taiwan provincial governor election were documented in the collection.
Meanwhile, the album contains a 1995 photo featuring Lee paying a visit to then-Taipei Mayor Chen Shui-bian at the Taipei City Hall. Chen is now ROC president.

The book also documents Lee's family life, including photos taken during his formative years in the Japanese colonial rule era as well as his wedding photo, those taken with his parents and children and those featuring his recreational activities.

DOC.HEADLINE: HK OFFICIAL FETES TAIWAN BUSINESS EXECUTIVES IN RARE GESTURE
DOC.DATELINE: Hong Kong, Jan. 9 (CNA) (By Mandy Wong and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Stephen Lam, director of Hong Kong's Constitutional Affairs Bureau, hosted a dinner Friday in honor of senior executives of a Taiwanese trade association in Hong Kong.
It marked the first time that a senior Hong Kong official has ever feted Taiwan business executives in the former British colony.

Lam's rare goodwill gesture came after the Hong Kong government rejected a visa application by Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou, a move that has drawn a strong protest from the Republic of China government and broadsides from the Hong Kong media.
A total of 17 board members of the Association of Taiwan Commerce and Industry in Hong Kong attended the dinner hosted by Lam.
During the dinner, Lam was quoted as having said that the Hong Kong government will reinforce dialogue and communications with Taiwan through major Taiwan business groups.

Lam said Taiwan is Hong Kong's fourth largest trading partner, with bilateral trade growing at an annual rate of 20 percent. In 2004, Taiwan companies launched 400 investment projects in Hong Kong. Lam said HOng Kong has consistently attached great importance to relations with Taiwan's business community.
During the meeting, the association members suggested that the Hong KOng government set up a Taiwan school for children of Taiwan business people working here so as to attract more Taiwan investors.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW HIV CARRIERS UP MORE THAN 70 PERCENT IN 2004

TEXT.P: A total of 1,513 new HIV carriers were discovered in Taiwan last year, up more than 70 percent from the 2003 level, the Department of Health (DOH) reported Sunday.
DOH officials said the figure marked a five-fold growth from the average growth rate recorded in the past decade.
It also marked the first time that the number of new HIV carriers increased by more than 1,000 in a single year. Of the new cases, 116 were female victims and 50 percent of them were drug addicts.

Among the news cases, 859 involved Taiwan citizens, up 76 percent from the number of new cases confirmed in 2003. The 2004 growth rate was five times the average 15 percent growth recorded for the past 10 years.
DOH tallies also showed that more than 400 of the new carriers of HIV, the virus that causes deadly AIDS, were drug addicts.
DOH officials said most drug addicted HIV carriers aged between 20 and 49.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Monday, Jan. 10, or the first day of the 12th month of the Year of the Monkey according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1806: A British fleet defeats Dutch colonists at the Battle of Blaawberg, capturing the strategic Cape of Good Hope.
1870: William and John D. Rockefeller found the Standard Oil Company of Ohio.
1901: The world's largest oil deposit is found in Texas.
1904: Wireless communication between Nagasaki in Japan and Keelung in Taiwan is inaugurated.
1914: President Yuan Shih-kai formally disbands the National Assembly in China.
1919: Charlotte Adelaide succeeds her sister Marie Adelaide of Nassau to become the ruling grand duchess of Luxembourg, one of Europe's oldest and smallest independent countries.
1920: The League of Nations is inaugurated in Geneva.
1938: Japanese forces invade Tsingtao, northern China.
1942: Japanese troops enter the Dutch East Indies during World War II.
1943: Lai Ho, a noted Taiwanese novelist, dies of a heart attack at the age of 50.
1946: The Nationalist government issues a cease-fire order in fighting against Chinese communists.
1946: The first United Nations meeting opens in London.
1946: The Political Consultative Conference opens in China.
1953: The Legislative Yuan adopts the Land-to-the-Tiller Act.
1953: ROC Minister of Foreign Affairs George Yeh meets with Japanese Prime Minister Shigeru Yoshida and Foreign Minister Okizaki to discuss related issues between the two countries.
1955: More than 100 mainland Chinese planes attack and drop more than 300 bombs on Nationalist-defended Tachen Island, while two of the invading planes are shot down by the defenders.
1957: Sir Harold Macmillan replaces Sir Anthony Eden as Prime Minister of Britain.
1960: Luo Chin-tang of National Taiwan Normal University becomes the first doctor of literature in Taiwan.
1968: The unmanned spacecraft U.S. Surveyor 7 lands on the moon.
1970: The U.S. State Department announces the sale of 18 F104 jet fighters to the Republic of China.
1976: More than 500,000 young people take part in winter activities sponsored by the Chinese Youth Corps.
1989: The Republic of China and the Commonwealth of the Bahamas establish diplomatic relations.
1990: Beijing lifts martial law, imposed after the June 1989 Tiananmen Square massacre.
1994: President Bill Clinton announces a deal under which the Ukraine will give up its nuclear arsenal, the third largest in the world.
2000: Premier Vincent Siew confers the Order of Brilliant Star with Special Grand Cordon on visiting Haitian Prime Minister Jacques Alexis in recognition of his contributions to the promotion of bilateral ties.
2001: The Civil Aeronautics Administration begins using a newly built long-distance radar system at Santiao Chiao and Oluanpi in southern Taiwan.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "A wise man sees what is right in a question; a fool, what is advantageous to himself."

DOC.HEADLINE: SIX RAPID TRANSIT OFFICIALS DISCIPLINED FOR ESCALATOR ACCIDENT

TEXT.P: Six high-ranking officials with the Taipei Rapid Transit Corp. were disciplined Sunday and Monday for a New Year's Eve escalator accident that injured five passengers at an MRT station in Taipei.

Tsai Hui-sheng, general manager of the rapid transit corp., a company run by the Taipei City Government, received a major demerit by the city government's Department of Transportation for the accident, in which one woman fell and got her hair caught in the moving stairs, tearing off part of her scalp.
The rapid transit corporation was also fined NT$400,000 by the department.
Five other rapid transit officials in charge of supervision, transportation and management were given minor demerits Monday.

The transportation department made the ruling after a probe into the escalator accident conducted by transportation department officials, officials from the Ministry of Transportation and Communications, and academics from three universities in Taipei.
Tsai and the rapid transit officials have been under mounting criticism since the Jan. 1 accident despite repeatedly apologizing to the injured and their families.
In response to the disciplinary action, Tsai said Monday that he fully accepts the punishment and will review his and the rapid transit corporation's ability to react to accidents on the MRT.
