DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN EXPORTS TO MAINLAND EXPAND GREATLY

TEXT.P: Taiwan's exports to mainland China, including Hong Kong and Macau, increased to 37.11 percent of the island's overall export trade in the third quarter of 2004, making mainland China the largest export outlet for Taiwan products, government statistics showed Monday.
Officials from the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS) said 2003's Q3 mainland export level was 8.81 percent, marking a jump of a whopping 28.3 percent.
Taiwan exports to the United States, however, declined by 2 percentage points to 16.63 percent in the same quarter, DGBAS officials said.

Meanwhile, Taiwan's imports from Japan rose to 26.39 percent of the island's entire import trade in Q3 2004, from 24.62 percent posted in the corresponding quarter of 2003, making Japan the largest import source of Taiwan.
Manufactured products made up the bulk, or 98.5 percent, of Taiwan's overall exports in Q3 2004, while the remaining 1.5 percent were agricultural products, DGBAS officials said.

The officials attributed the increased amount and value of the exports of industrial products mainly to the fact that Q3 is traditionally strong for exports of electronics and telecommunications products and because of a surge in steel prices on the international market.

They attributed the increased amount and value of the imports of capital equipment and agricultural as well as industrial raw materials mainly to the fact that major investment and development projects around Taiwan have begun and costs for most kinds of raw materials have been raised in international markets.
By comparison, they added, the import of consumer products declined by 1.1 percentage points to 8.05 percent of the island's overall imports in Q3 2004.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP COMMUNICATING WITH PFP: KAOHSIUNG MAYOR

TEXT.P: Kaohsiung Mayor Frank Hsieh confirmed on Monday that the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) is communicating with the second-largest opposition People First Party (PFP) on party-to-party cooperation and the DPP will announce any breakthroughs.
Hsieh also said communicating with the PFP is for the sake of political stability, and that PFP Chairman James Soong has not made any demands for the party to hold any specific government positions.

The mayor spoke as the pro-independence DPP and the pro-unification PFP -- parties at the opposite ends of the political spectrum -- are appearing to move toward a partnership amid reports that they could even form a coalition government.
Hsieh said that the president's effort to build bridges of trust between parties is not limited to only the PFP and could also include the Kuomintang (KMT).

Asked whether the new cooperative spirit will start with the election of the next speaker of the new Legislative Yuan on Feb. 1, Hsieh said reconciliation between parties should not be about who gets what post so that the process does not get mired in political horse-trading.

Instead of haggling over trading posts, Hsieh said party-to-party cooperation is about sharing responsibility and divvying up the work. However, he said that it is only natural that some positions be assigned according to a deference to political affiliation.

The former DPP chairman also said that the president stated clearly in his new year's speech that anything can be discussed between parties that is beneficial to the stability of domestic politics, creates harmony between ethnic groups, increases public welfare and improves cross-strait relations.

Meanwhile, a DPP party whip in the Legislative Yuan echoed Hsieh's words, saying that President Chen's advocacy of party-to-party dialogue is for the sake of domestic politics and "to try to unify a splintered country."
It is by no means an attempt to drive a wedge between the "pan-blue alliance" of the KMT and the PFP as reports quoting KMT high-ranking officials have said, Lee Chun-yi said Monday.
Lee also said that the KMT is getting nervous about the possibility of a DPP-PFP alliance and is trying to block such cooperation.

Although the "pan-blue alliance" maintained its majority in the Dec. 11 legislative elections, the KMT, which won 79 seats in the 225-seat legislature, will find it impossible to dominate the legislature without the support of its ally, the PFP, which now has 34 seats. The DPP is still the largest party in the legislature with 89 seats.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT VOWS TO FOSTER CLIMATE FOR INTER-PARTY RECONCILIATION

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Monday he will do his utmost to foster an atmosphere conducive to reconciliation between the ruling and opposition parties to facilitate political reform and national development.
Chen made the pledge while meeting with Taiwanese expatriate community leaders from various Central American countries.

Noting that global competition has become ever more intense in the 21st century, Chen said Taiwan should consolidate internal unity and redouble efforts to upgrade its overall competitiveness and retain market niches.
"At the moment, putting an end to the 'war of attrition' between the ruling and opposition parties and streamlining the chaotic domestic political situation are our most important tasks, " Chen said.
As the nation's leader, Chen said he is determined to make every possible effort to create a stable environment for rational and sincere party-to-party dialogue and consultations.
"We'll do whatever we can to promote inter-party reconciliation to usher in a new era of dialogue and consultations for accelerated political reform and national development," Chen added.

During his talks with Taiwanese community leaders from Central America, Chen also expressed his desire to attend the fifth summit meeting between the ROC and its Central American allies to be held in Central America later this year. The exact venue and date for the summit meeting has not been set.

"Central America is our diplomatic stronghold, with many of our allies located in the region. I have fond memories of each of my trips there, " Chen said, adding that he is grateful for the whole-hearted support of Taiwanese expatriates in those countries for the ROC's diplomatic cause over the past years.

Later in the day, Chen received Paraguayan House of Representatives Speaker Oscar Ruben Salomon Fernandez and conferred him with a decoration in recognition of his contribution to the promotion of ROC-Paraguay relations.

Chen told Salomon that he hopes he can travel to Paraguay this year to meet with Paraguayan President Nicanor Duarte and sign a free trade agreement (FTA) between the two countries. Taiwan-Paraguayan FTA negotiations have been proceeding smoothly, he added.

Financial Times: Blair and Brown try to paper over cracks.

But although the chancellor on Sunday night issued a robust call for Labour to unite in the run up to polling day, there was no sign that fundamental diferences with the prime minister over the organisation of the election campaign have been resolved.

DOC.HEADLINE: FOREIGN MINISTRY DENIES ALL RELIEF GOODS STUCK AT AIRPORT

TEXT.P: The spokesman for the Ministry of Foreign Affairs denied media reports Monday that all of Taiwan's relief goods meant to be sent to South Asian countries are stuck at Chiang Kai-shek International Airport because of diplomatic barriers.

Michel Lu said that as of Sunday, more than 20 metric tons of relief goods, medical supplies and disinfection materials have been airlifted by China Airlines to Indonesia, the hardest-hit country by the Dec. 26 earthquake-tsunamis.
Lu assured that relief goods are getting through and there has been no political interference to interrupt Taiwan's humanitarian aid.

The 20-odd tonnes of relief goods have been handed to members of the Buddhist Compassionate Relief Tzu Chi Foundation, the Taiwan Businessmen's Association and the Taiwan Alumni Society in Indonesia for distribution, Lu added.

The foreign ministry hopes that military transport planes can be allowed to join Taiwan's relief goods transport fleet so that the relief goods currently stockpiled can be airlifted to South Asia in the shortest possible time, Lu said, adding that hopefully the countries earmarked to receive the aid will agree to this.

Lu also denied that the Ministry of Foreign Affairs has told private charitable organizations not to send relief goods to other South Asia countries, such as Sri Lanka and the Maldives, where Taiwan does not have liaison offices.

The private group of Taiwan Roots Medical Peace Corps has contacted the Sri Lankan government which has agreed to take 1,000 tonnes of rice from Taiwan. However, he pointed out, the bags of rice bear the Republic of China national flag.
If that turns out to be a problem, Lu said, the foreign ministry will ask that the rice be repacked to facilitate delivery to Sri Lanka.
So far, there is no plan yet to send relief goods to the Maldives since having been asked of their needs, representatives of the country have not replied, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP HAS NO PLAN TO CHANGE PARTY PLATFORM: DPP SECRETARY-GENERAL

TEXT.P: Ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Secretary-General Chang Chun-hsiung affirmed Monday that the party has no plan to revise its platform.

Chang made the remarks in the wake of a recent proposal by DPP Legislator Lee Wen-chung that the party revise its "pro-independence platform" to facilitate its cooperation with the pro-unification opposition People First Party (PFP).

Senior PFP Legislator Liu Wen-hsiung has expressed his approval to Lee's proposal, saying that many things are negotiable between the DPP and PFP if the DPP freezes its "pro-independence platform" for five to 15 years.
In a statement, however, Chang said the DPP sees no need for revising its platform because the document reflects the historical fact of the path the DPP has taken.

The various resolutions and campaign manifestoes adopted by the party, which include the resolutions on Taiwan's self-determination, economic development and ethnic multiplicity, are what guide the DPP's policies at present, Chang said.

The resolution on Taiwan's self-determination passed in 1999 outweighed the party platform that pursues the foundation of the "Republic of Taiwan." The resolution states that Taiwan is an independent, sovereign state whose official name is the Republic of China and that any decision to change the status quo must be made by the people through a national plebiscite.
Chang said all the advocacies put forth by the DPP are pragmatically idealistic and have the potential to become the consensus of Taiwan society.
Chang said as the ruling party, the DPP has the responsibility to meet people's expectations for political stability, inter-party cooperation and political reconciliation.
Despite the differences in their positions, there should be room for cooperation between political parties as long as national interests are prioritized over partisan interests, he suggested.
Over the past 18 years since the DPP's foundation, the party has followed the core values of Taiwanization, democracy, justice and sustainable development, he said.

On a report that said that the government plans to extend the service life of the three existing nuclear power plants from 40 years to 60 years, Chang noted that the DPP is promoting the development of alternative sources of energy and is against building any new nuclear power plants.

He said building a non-nuclear country to protect the sustainable development of Taiwan is a long-standing aim of the DPP and was also a consensus reached between the ruling and opposition parties in 2002.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. DOLLAR RISES ON TAIPEI FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar rose against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Monday, gaining NT$0.125 to close at NT$32.263.
A total of US$580 million changed hands.
The greenback opened at NT$32.209 and was traded between NT$32.193 and NT$32.275 during the trading sesion.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange closed higher Monday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 6.86 points to close at 5,942.85.
The bourse opened at 5,950.12 and fluctuated between 5,962.64 and 5,929.11 during trading. A total of 2.4 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$44 billion (US$1.36 billion).

Five of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with cement stocks moving up the most at 1.4 percent, followed by foodstuff issues at 0.4 percent, machinery and electronics shares at 0.3 percent and paper and pulp issues and banking and financial shares both at 0.1 percent.
Three other major stock categories lost ground, with construction issues moving down at 2.1 percent and plastics and chemicals shares dropping at 0.4 percent.
Textile stocks remained unchanged.
Losers outnumbered gainers 449 to 262, with 176 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT DELEGATION CLAIMS CROSS-STRAIT CHARTER FLIGHTS FINALIZED
DOC.DATELINE: Beijing, Jan. 10 (CNA) (By Stanley Cheung and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: A visiting opposition Kuomintang (KMT) delegation from Taiwan claimed Monday that Lunar New Year charter flights for Taiwan businessmen operating in mainland China have been finalized.
The delegation made the claim after a one-hour meeting with Chen Yunlin, director of Beijing's Taiwan Affairs Council.
KMT Legislator Tseng Yung-chuan issued a statement after the meeting that the mechanism for cross-strait charter flights during the holiday period was "officially inaugurated" Monday.
"The three principles that we insisted upon, including joint participation in the two-way, multi-point flights with no stopovers in third countries or areas have won Chen's consent," Tseng said.
Tseng claimed the services are finalized and that other technical issues will be left for discussion among the various carriers wishing to offer the flights.

KMT Legislator John Chang, another delegation member, described Monday's talks as important and said Beijing has agreed that the mainland flight departure points be extended from Shanghai to Beijing, Guangzhou, Shenzhen, Fuzhou and Xiamen.

Cross-strait charter flights were inaugurated on a trial basis during the 2003 Chinese New Year holiday with Taiwan carriers operating between Shanghai and Taipei/Kaohsiung, with transfers via Hong Kong or Macau. Charter flights were not offered during the 2004 Chinese New Year holiday because Beijing wanted mainland carriers to also be allowed to offer flights but refused to discuss technical details with the Taiwan authorities.

However, a legislator from the ruling Democratic Progressive Party said a day earlier that the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) had already reached a tacit agreement with Beijing civil aviation authorities about the basic principles for the launch of direct cross-strait charter flights during the Chinese New Year holiday.

Tsai Huang-liang, DPP whip in the Legislative Yuan, said that the Taipei Airlines Association, which was commissioned by the MAC to talk with Beijing in Macau, had already reached agreement on the issue.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES MOSTLY HIGHER ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were mostly higher Monday as the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for January gained 22 points to close at 5,987, with 14,801 contracts changing hands.
TAIEX Index futures for February moved up 14 points to finish at 5,983, with 618 contracts traded, while March futures gained 23 points to finish at 5,973, with nine contracts traded.
June futures lost seven points to finish at 5,940, with one contract traded, while September futures moved up 19 points to close at 5,885, with two contracts traded.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Monday at 5,965 for January, 5,969 for February, 5,950 for March, 5,947 for June and 5,866 for September.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were higher.

January TE futures moved up 1.55 points to close at 221.3, with 1,946 contracts traded, while February TE futures gained 1.7 points to finish at 221.2, with 35 contract transactions. March TE futures gained 4.9 points to close at 221, with one contract traded.
No transactions were recorded for June and September.

January TF futures gained two points to finish at 1,028, with 1,764 contracts changing hands, while February TF futures remained unchanged at 1,025, with 297 contracts traded. March TF futures lost three points to finish at 1,020.4, with one contract changing hands.
No transactions were recorded for June and September.

DOC.HEADLINE: CABINET DENIES REPORT OF LONGER SERVICE LIFE FOR NUCLEAR POWER PLANTS

TEXT.P: A spokesman for the Executive Yuan denied Monday a report that the government plans to extend the service life of the three existing nuclear power plants to cope with the problem of a global energy shortage.
Chen Chi-mai described the report as false after verifying the situation with the Ministry of Economic Affairs and the state-run Taiwan Power Company (Taipower).

In a front-page story Monday, the Liberty Times claimed that Taipower has recently been ordered to plan on extending the service life of the three nuclear power plants from 40 years to 60 years, based on a proposal by Academia Sinica President Lee Yuan-tseh, who is the top technological adviser to the Executive Yuan.
The government's goal of making the island nuclear free would have been delayed to 2050 as a result of the extension, according to the report.
Chen reaffirmed that the government's ultimate goal of building a nuclear-free country, which he said is a consensus of the ruling and opposition parties, remains unchanged.

With climate change having become the most important environmental issue in the world, every country is obliged to do its part to reduce the release of gases that could worsen global warming, Chen said.

Taiwan shares a responsibility, even though it is not a member of the United Nations, Chen said, noting that Premier Yu Shyi-kun appointed a panel to work on measures to reduce global greenhouse gases in October last year.
He said the Executive Yuan hopes the Legislative Yuan will pass a law aimed at promoting the goal of a nuclear-free country as soon as possible.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN INVESTMENT IN MAINLAND CHINA EXCEEDS US$40 BILLION: MOEA

TEXT.P: Taiwan's private sector channeled some US$40.47 billion into mainland China for a total of 32,990 investment projects over the 13 years between January 1991 and November 2004, the Investment Commission under the Ministry of Economic Affairs reported Monday.

From January 2002, mainland-bound investment has exceeded 50 percent of Taiwan's overall investment overseas annually, making the mainland the top receiving country in terms of Taiwan overseas investment, officials from the Investment Commission said.
In the first 11 months of 2004, government-approved investment projects on the mainland totaled 1,839, worth some US$6.16 billion, the officials added.
Jiangsu, Guangdong, Zhejiang, Fujian and Hebei are the top five mainland provinces in terms of Taiwan investment.

The top five domestic industries involved in mainland-bound investment were electronic and electrical goods, basic metal, chemicals, plastics and precision instrument manufacturing, according to the Investment Commission.

The government has been making decisions on mainland-bound investment based on three principles -- if the proposed investment project is conducive to sharpening Taiwan industry's competitiveness and helpful to the island's global business operations, the project tends to be approved immediately; those "sunset" manufacturing industries that can be revived only if they are relocated to the mainland will be green-lighted without problems; and those high-technology industries for which mainland relocation might lead to the transfer or loss of core technologies will probably not be approved.

As far as high-technology industries are concerned, the officials said, only Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Corp. has been approved to invest in the mainland for low-end IC chip foundry operations, while the TFT-LCD industry is allowed to head to the mainland for down-stream panel manufacturing.
The Taiwan authorities have not allowed the petrochemical industry to establish naphtha cracking plants on the mainland so far, they added.

According to statistics released by the mainland authorities, Taiwan investors agreed to channel some US$75.44 billion into the mainland for a total of 62,674 investment projects during the Jan. 1, 1991-November 30, 2004 period.
Only US$38.64 billion of the agreed-upon investment has been spent on the 62,674 investment projects, according to the mainland statistics.

DOC.HEADLINE: POLICE TO BEEF UP LAW AND ORDER AHEAD OF LUNAR NEW YEAR HOLIDAY

TEXT.P: The police authorities are set to launch a 40-day operation starting Tuesday to beef up law and order in the weeks leading up to the Chinese Lunar New Year holiday and during the holiday.
During the first stage, which will run from Jan. 11-25, the operation will prioritize preventing drunken driving, theft, burglary and robbery, according to police.

During the second stage, which will run from Jan. 26 to Feb. 19, the operation will focus on improving public order and ensuring smooth traffic flow to ensure people have a happy Lunar New Year holiday, they added.

DOC.HEADLINE: TSU WANTS TO PLAY ACTIVE ROLE IN POLITICS

TEXT.P: The new chairman of the opposition Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) said Monday that as long as it is beneficial to Taiwan, the party is "willing to play an active role in politics so that President Chen Shui-bian can focus on national development."

But Su Chin-chiang also said that although the TSU is an ally of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party, it will maintain its independent status and will have "different operations than other political parties." He did not elaborate.

Su made the remarks after he was unanimously approved by the TSU Central Executive Committee to take the helm of the party. Former TSU Chairman Huang Tzu-wen stepped down from the post to take responsibility for the worse-than-expected performance of the party in the Dec. 11 legislative elections. The TSU garnered just 12 of the 225 seats in the legislature.

Su said that serving as the TSU chairman was not in his career plan, but former President Lee Teng-hui, the so-called "spiritual leader" of the TSU, told him he should not only focus on himself but should concentrate on the whole country.

Su, who reportedly was favored by Lee for the chairmanship despite two other aspirants who later were persuaded to bow out of the running, said the party will move even closer to Taiwan's land and its people, and will defend the nation's security.

On the key posts in the party, Su said he will follow through on the resolutions passed by the Central Standing Committee to recruit younger talent and that he hopes to finalize the lineup within a week.
He also said that the TSU will make an overall planning and will not be absent from the year-end mayoral and magistrate elections.

DOC.HEADLINE: TSU URGES MAC TO PUNISH KMT FOR CHARTER FLIGHT TALKS WITH BEIJING

TEXT.P: The opposition Kuomintang (KMT) should be punished for holding unauthorized talks with Beijing on the launch of direct cross-Taiwan Strait charter flights during the upcoming Chinese New Year holiday, opposition Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) legislative whips said Monday.

Huang Chung-yuan, convener of the TSU legislative caucus, said that since the government has already authorized the private Taipei Airlines Association (TAA) to negotiate with Beijing on the proposed holiday cross-strait charter flights, the KMT is not in a position to discuss the issue with the mainland.
Huang was referring to the KMT's sending of a delegation to Beijing Sunday to meet with mainland officials to discuss the holiday charter flight issue.

"The KMT is just a private political group. Without government authorization, the party does not have any legitimate position to negotiate charter flight issues with Beijing. Otherwise, other private associations, such as the General Chamber of Commerce of the ROC and the National Association of Industries could also send delegations to negotiate the issue," Huang said, pointing out that if the terms reached between the KMT delegation and the mainland authorities cannot be implemented under Taiwan law, the predicament will not be resolved.

Speaking on the same occasion, Chen Chien-ming, deputy convener of the TSU legislative caucus, said the KMT's move violates Article 4 of the Statute Governing the Relations Between the People of the Taiwan Area and the Mainland Area, which bans private groups from negotiating with the Beijing authorities without the government's authorization.
Chen urged the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council to penalize the KMT for its rule-breaking move in holding unauthorized talks with the mainland.
Chen further said he is worried that the pro-unification KMT might compromise Taiwan's interests in its engagements with the mainland.

Responding to the TSU criticism, Legislative Yuan President Wang Jin-pyng, who is also a KMT vice chairman, claimed that he did not know the details of the KMT's contacts with Beijing. Nevertheless, he stressed that the KMT move was mainly aimed at pushing for realization of the holiday charter flight plan.

Meanwhile, the ruling Democratic Progressive Party's (DPP's) legislative caucus said it is regrettable that the KMT has failed to respect the government's stance and has unilaterally negotiated with Beijing.
Lee Chun-yi, a DPP legislative whip, said the government will not recognize the KMT's negotiation results because it has not received the MAC's authorization.

Stressing that national interests supercede any partisan interests, Lee said the KMT should keep in mind Taiwan's overall interests in its engagements with the mainland. "No Taiwan party should give room for the mainland to drive wedges to hurt our national unity and interests, " Lee said, adding that the KMT delegation should avoid becoming a tool for the mainland to propagate its so-called anti-secession law aimed at creating a legal pretext to use military force to take Taiwan.

Cheng Wen-tsan, director of the DPP's information and publicity department, said that as no single political party can represent the country, the KMT should not try to "usurp" the government's power or authority.

"It is not bad if the KMT intends to help clear the way for the launch of Lunar New Year charter flights for the convenience of Taiwan businessmen working on the mainland. But the KMT should not try to 'usurp' the government's power," Cheng said.

As a matter of fact, Cheng added, the legally authorized TAA has already almost completed negotiations with the relevant mainland authorities over the holiday charter flight terms, making the KMT attempt somewhat irrelevant.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP OPENS ARMS TO INTER-PARTY COOPERATION: CAUCUS WHIP

TEXT.P: To achieve inter-party cooperation and parliamentary stability, the ruling Democratic Progressive Party is willing to compromise in the upcoming election for president and vice president of the Legislative Yuan, a DPP legislative caucus whip said Monday.

Tsai Huang-liang explained that his party will act on the results of the party-to-party negotiations that the DPP has recently been pushing for, and that it may support a nominee of the opposition People First Party to take the post of president of the Legislative Yuan if the talks lead to such a result.

He noted that his party would probable vote for a Kuomintang candidate to head the new opposition-controlled legislature, or even give the posts of president and vice president of the Legislative Yuan to the PFP, with which the DPP has been trying to bolster party cooperation, if such an arrangement would benefit political stability.
The DPP official made the remarks while answering questions from reporters on his party's recent move to promote inter-party talks and cooperation.
He said that the DPP has no predetermined position on the matter.

DOC.HEADLINE: PROGRESS OF CHARTER SERVICE TALKS BOOSTS CROSS-STRAIT TIES: PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: The recent breakthrough in arrangements for Lunar New Year charter flight services between Taiwan and mainland China is an essential foundation for the normalization of cross-Taiwan Strait relations, President Chen Shui-bian said Monday.
Chen was referring to the negotiations underway between the two sides on the issue, which he said is a "historic, crucial moment" for cross-strait relations.
The president made the remarks during a meeting with a visiting delegation of the Committee of 100, an organization of Chinese Americans.

Unlike last year, when the mainland authorities refused to negotiate with Taiwan on the matter, Taipei Airlines Association Chairman Lo Ta-hsiung, with the authorization of Taiwan's Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) , reportedly held talks with Civil Aviation Administration of China representatives in Macau Friday.

Reports said that the two sides have agreed in principle to allow two-way, non-stop, multi-destination flights operated by carriers on both sides. The MAC, however, has been tightlipped on the development of the talks.

Pointing out that he expressed hope in his Jan. 1 New Year address for achieving stability via consultation and dialogue, Chen said consultations and dialogue are not only required between different political parties in Taiwan but also between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait.
Chen said the most precarious era is also the era with the most opportunities and that the most difficult time is also the most hopeful.
He said he hopes there will be good developments this year in terms of Taiwan's relations with both the United States and the mainland.

However, he expressed regret that Hong Kong rejected a visa application by Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou, who originally had planned to attend the Greater China annual meeting of the Committee of 100 to be held in the Special Administrative Region.
Hong Kong reports said that Ma was denied entry because he had spoken out against Beijing's plan to enact an "anti-secession law" targeting Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC HOPES BEIJING WILL START CHARTER FLIGHTS BASED ON AGREED MODEL

TEXT.P: The Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) said Monday that it hopes mainland China will honor its words and use talks between Taiwan and Hong Kong on air transport in 2002 as a model for launching cross-Taiwan Strait charter flights during the Lunar New Year holiday.

The MAC made the remarks in a press release after a Taiwan delegation led by opposition Kuomintang (KMT) officials met with Chen Yunlin, director of the Taiwan Affairs Office in Beijing Monday to discuss flight services to facilitate the return of Taiwan people on the mainland during the holiday.
According to the KMT delegation after the meeting, Chen accepted the principles of "joint participation in the two-way, multiple-destination flights with no stopovers in third countries or regions."

Chen reportedly agreed that Taiwanese with travel documents to the mainland, and not confined to Taiwan businessmen operating on the mainland only, will be able to board the charter flights. He also said Taipei Airlines Association representatives and air carriers can travel to the mainland as soon as possible to discuss related technical details with the mainland side.

The MAC said in the press release that it is gratified that Beijing responded positively to Taiwan's suggestion for the charter flights, and that the MAC also noted that a spokesman for the Taiwan Affairs Council said Oct. 27 that air transport negotiations between Taiwan and Hong Kong in 2002 can serve as a model for talks.
The air transport talks were completed successfully because they were conducted by the private sector, with government officials acting as advisers.
The MAC expressed hope that the mainland will honor its words and seize the opportunity to embark on consultations in a way acceptable to both sides.

The MAC said in the press release that the policy of promoting the charter flights during the Chinese New Year period has been the long-standing policy of the government and that the government has long expressed that both sides could make appropriate arrangements concerning the "joint participation of two-way, non-stop flights" principles demanded by Beijing.
The government stated last November that Taiwan is willing to base negotiations on Taiwan-Hong Kong air transport negotiations that took place in 2002, the MAC said.
The MAC also commissioned the Taipei Airlines Association to go to Macau earlier this month to help discuss the matter after Beijing responded positively to Taiwan's appeal.
Meanwhile, the Ministry of Transportation and Communications said it has already completed the planning on technical details for the charter flight services.

DOC.HEADLINE: ECONOMY CONTRIBUTES TO LOW BIRTH RATE: POLL

TEXT.P: Economic problems and worries about social instability are the two major causes of local people's low interest in having children, pollsters said Monday.

The Taipei-based Mother and Baby magazine conducted a survey between August and September last year to explore local people's willingness to have children. A total of 3,158 valid replies were collected.

According to the survey results, men are less likely to want children than women, with nearly 35 percent of male respondents saying they did not want to have children, while only some 19 percent of female respondents said so.

The survey found that 25.8 percent of female respondents said they intend to have only one child, 27.6 percent said they want two, 19.1 percent said they want three, 9.1 percent said they hope to have more than three, and 18.9 percent said they do not want any children.

In comparison, 31.5 percent of the males said they intend to have only one child, 15.6 percent said they would prefer two, 13.2 percent said they hope to have three, 5.1 percent said they want more than three, and 34.6 percent said they do not want any children.

Major reasons cited by male respondents for their reluctance to have children included economic problems or inability to afford the cost of raising children (35.4 percent) , worries about social instability (31.8 percent) and fear of losing personal freedom.

For female respondents, worry about inability to afford children was the top cause (45.6 percent) , followed by fears about social instability (31.7 percent) , fears of losing personal freedom (15.6 percent) and fear of birth pain or loss of figure (11.2 percent).

Chiang Kuei-hsiang, editor-in-chief of the magazine, said the economy and social instability were major reasons for both men and women being reluctant to have children. And the fact that more women than men cited fears of losing personal freedom as a cause for their reluctance to have children indicates that child-rearing remains mostly a woman's responsibility, Chiang said, adding that some women have chosen late marriage and late childbirth or even no marriage and no children so that their career development will not be affected.
Taiwan's birth rate has been on a steady decline, with one woman giving birth to an average of 1.24 children in 2003.

DOC.HEADLINE: KINMEN PASSENGER SERVICE CENTER INAUGURATED

TEXT.P: Part of a newly built passenger service center at a Kinmen harbor was inaugurated Monday to meet the needs of passengers intending to travel via the "mini three links route, " according to Kinmen Harbor Bureau Director Chang Kuo-tu.

The links refer to direct transportation services between Taiwan-held Kinmen and Matsu islands and mainland China's ports of Xiamen and Mawei in the absence of direct links between the mainland and Taiwan proper, Chang said.

To keep the center working properly, the Kinmen police authorities have made a number of arrangements, including mapping out the traffic lines of people and vehicles, stepping up traffic controls and rezoning waiting areas for taxis, Chang said.
Chang also said a floating wharf and a passage connecting the wharf and the service center are scheduled to be inaugurated in late June to increase the convenience of the "mini three links."

From Feb. 1, 12 ferries will head for Xiamen every day, compared with the eight plying the route at present, Chang said, adding that during the Chinese New Year holiday period between Feb.3 and 16, the harbor will accept applications for additional ferries to serve the route.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN URGED TO REVIVE MUTUAL TRUST WITH U.S.

TEXT.P: Taiwan must step up communications with the United States and revive mutual trust between the two countries,
according to a report released Monday by the Institute of International Relations of National Chengchi University.
The institute compiled the 2004 assessment report on develop ments in the international community and in mainland China.

The report notes that seven international events have affected Taiwan in the last year -- the re-election of U.S. President George Bush, the mainland's proposed anti-secession law, the exchanges between Taipei, Washington and Beijing, the signing of a free trade agreement between the Association for Southeast Asian Nations and the mainland, Singapore Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong's visit to Taiwan before he assumed his post, the fast expansion of the mainland's economic might and the importance of securing energy resources, and the new defense initiative promulgated by Japan.

The report says that how Bush defines Washington's Asia policy will be crucial to both Taiwan's external relations -- especially since Bush's political decisions will shape developments -- and how Taiwan can regain mutual trust with the United States, which has been undermined since President Chen Shui-bian's insistence on holding a national referendum prior to the March 20 presidential election, as well as his advocacy of a new constitution.

The report also says that exchanges between Washington and Beijing have been close over the past year and that both sides think a tilt by Taiwan toward independence could change the status quo, so that they have both started trying to nip the Taiwan independence movement in the bud.

The report says that an anti-secession law planned by the mainland that will be put to the full National People's Congress review and approval in March, has cast uncertainty on the already strained cross-Taiwan Strait situation.

The report also says that the mainland's expanding economic might has been translated into economic diplomacy, with officials from East Asia, Latin America and Singapore speaking out against Taiwan internationally.

Faced with the growing anti-Taiwan independence campaign launched by Beijing, as well as its use of economic and diplomatic might to isolate Taiwan, the government has to adopt new strategies on the diplomatic and strategic fronts, according to the report.
Taiwan should also increase its cooperation with the United States and Japan, with which Taiwan shares common interests, and develop multilateral cooperation mechanisms, the report suggests.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT HOPES TO TRAVEL TO PARAGUAY TO SIGN FTA THIS YEAR

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian expressed hope Monday that he can travel to the Paraguayan capital of Asuncion this year to sign a free trade agreement (FTA) with Paraguayan President Nicanor Duarte Frutos.
Chen made the remarks when he bestowed the Order of Brilliant Star with Special Grand Cordon upon visiting speaker of the Paraguayan House of Representatives Oscar Ruben Salomon Fernandez.

The president also expressed appreciation for Duarte's attendance of his second-term inauguration May 20 last year, saying that he was the first leader of a Republic of China ally to visit since he won re-election.
He and Duarte pledged at that time to promote the signing of an FTA between the two countries, Chen said.

The medal-conferring ceremony was also attended by the Paraguayan Lower House's First Deputy Speaker Juan Bartolome Ramirez, Paraguayan Ambassador to the Republic of China Ramon Antero Diaz Pereira, Presi dential Office Vice Secretary-General James Huang and Vice Foreign Minister Francisco Hwang.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT MEETS MALAWI COUNTERPART IN TAIPEI

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian met his Malawi counterpart Bingu Wa Mutharika Monday at the Presidential Office and said that the Republic of China will eventually become a member of the United Nations and obtain observer status in the World Health Assembly with Malawi's support and assistance.

Chen told his guest, who arrived in Taipei earlier that same day for a five-day official visit, that he based his confidence on the U.N.'s principle of universality and the idea that health has no boundaries, while Malawi has repeatedly spoken for the ROC's unsuccessful bids for membership in those organizations.
Chen thanked Mutharika for the support and assistance his country has extended to the ROC in the international arena.

He also expressed appreciation for Mutharika's firm support for Taiwan's successful bid to become a member of the World Trade Organization in January 2002, when he served as secretary-general of the Common Market of Southeast Africa.

Accepting an invitation extended by Mutharika during the meeting, Chen said he was proud to become the first ROC president to visit Malawi when he toured the African ally in July 2002 and that he is willing to visit Malawi again at an opportune time.
For his part, Mutharika said Malawi is keen to learn about Taiwan's experience in transforming from a developing country to a developed one.

Malawi supports Taiwan's membership of international organizations because it believes Taiwan's experience can be shared by other nations only when it becomes a member of such international groups, he said.
Minister of Foreign Affairs Tan Sun Chen and Presidential Office Secretary-General Su Tseng-chang were also present at the meeting.

DOC.HEADLINE: VICE PRESIDENT ASPIRES TO MOVING TOWARD E-GOVERNMENT WITH PARAGUAY

TEXT.P: Vice President Annette Lu expressed hope Monday that Taiwan and Paraguay can step up exchanges of talent so as to move toward a common goal of e-government.
Lu made the remarks when she received Salomon Fernandez, Paraguay's speaker of the House of Representatives.
Lu congratulated her visitor for being conferred the Order of Brilliant Star with Special Grand Gordon earlier at the Presidential Office.

The vice president also spoke of what she called "the three features of Taiwan people" -- diligence, thriftiness amd belief in education -- which she said has enabled Taiwan to overcome poverty and reap its present achievements.
For his part, Salomon expressed hope that both countries can strengthen exchanges based on their close relations.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING URGED TO ENGAGE IN PRAGMATIC CONSULTATIONS ON CHARTER FLIGHTS

TEXT.P: The government welcomes mainland China's positive response to Taiwan's proposal for charter flights during the Chinese New Year holiday and has expressed the hope that both sides can engage in pragmatic consultations in a way acceptable to both sides, a spokesman for the Executive Yuan said Monday.

Chen Chi-mai made the remarks after the mainland's Taiwan Affairs Office reportedly announced the inauguration of a cross-strait charter flight service mechanism for the Lunar New Year holiday after a meeting earlier that day with a visiting delegation of opposition Kuomintang (KMT) officials.
Chen said most of the public would disagree with the claim by the KMT that it was instrumental in making the cross-strait charter flight service consultations a reality.

He noted that Beijing's Taiwan Affairs Office said as far back as October that it would be feasible to use Taiwan-Hong Kong air transport negotiations that took place in 2002 as model for charter flight service talks, whereupon President Chen Shui-bian expressed willingness to engage in pragmatic consultations based on that model.
Taiwan has repeatedly said that it will make appropriate arrangements with regard to demands by Beijing on "joint participation on two-way flights with no stopovers in third countries or areas."

When Beijing responded positively to Taiwan's appeal Jan. 3, the Mainland Affairs Council then commissioned the Taipei Airlines Association to talk with the mainland authorities in Macau, showing that Taiwan has displayed sincerity and flexibility in bringing about the cross-strait charter flight services.

Meanwhile, Chiu Tai-san, MAC vice chairman, said that from Beijing's remarks on the cross-strait charter flights, the council has confirmed that both sides have reached consensus on the principles of "two-way, multiple destination, no stopover" charter services.
Chiu said that the two sides will engage in a second stage of dialogue to reach consensus on the model for bilateral consultations and on the teams that will participate in the discussions.

DOC.HEADLINE: EVENT LISTING FOR JAN. 11 IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The following are important events scheduled to take place Tuesday, Jan. 11:
09:00, The Legislative Yuan will start its session for the day.
10: 00, President Chen Shui-bian will attend the designation ceremony of a newly developed eight-wheel armored vehicle at the Combined Logistics Command.
10: 00, The Peacetime Foundation of Taiwan will hold a news conference on Taiwan's participation in the GPRAC at the National Taiwan University Alumni Hall in Taipei.

10:00, The Industrial Technology Research Institute will sign an accord with U.S.-based Telcordia on the establishment of an optical telecommunication certification center in Hsinchu City, northern Taiwan.
10: 30, The Ministry of Foreign Affairs will hold a news conference at the ministry's headquarters.
12: 00, Representatives of the Chinese-American Committee of 100 will visit Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou at Taipei City Hall.
13: 30, The ruling Democratic Progressive Party will hold its weekly Central Standing Committee meeting at the party's headquarters.
14: 30, President Chen Shui-bian will accompany his Malawi counterpart Bingu Wa Mutharika on a visit to the Tantze Export Processing Zone in Taichung, central Taiwan.
16:00, The Banking Bureau of the Financial Supervisory Commission will hold a news conference at the commission's headquarters.
16:00, The Ministry of Economic Affairs will hold a routine news conference at the ministry's headquarters.
16:30, The Ministry of Finance will hold a news conference at the ministry's headquarters.
18:30, President Chen Shui-bian will host a state banquet at the Splendor Hotel Taichung to entertain his Malawi counterpart Bingu Wa Mutharika.

DOC.HEADLINE: VP URGES HI-TECH INDUSTRY TO SHOULDER MORE RESPONSIBILITIES

TEXT.P: Vice President Annette Lu called on the country's hi-tech industry Monday to shoulder more responsibilities for the country.

Giving a speech at the 7th National Science and Technology Conference, Lu said the hi-tech industry should improve the people's livelihoods, upgrade culture, strengthen national defenses and help the country's diplomacy and economy.

Noting that the added-value produced by the hi-tech industry decreased from NT$718.9 billion (US$22.46 billion) in 2000 to NT$604.6in 2004, Lu said it is alarming that the figure has decreased by 15.9 percent in the last three years.

Furthermore, the vice president said, the hi-tech industry, whose fixed investment accounts for 13.4 percent of the country's whole fixed investment, creates about 6.4 percent of the country's jobs and provides only 1.4 percent of the country's indirect revenues, which are not commensurate with its huge investment.

She urged the country's hi-tech firms to realize their responsibility for the country's safety, claiming that their investment in mainland China will inevitably upgrade the mainland's power to the detriment of Taiwan.

The hi-tech industry can help the country in the diplomatic field by exercising its influence with multinational hi-tech companies and draw the world's attention to the mainland's threat to Taiwan, which, according to Lu, would force Beijing to mend its ways.

DOC.HEADLINE: GIO LAUNCHES CAMPAIGN TO SPONSOR 10,000 TSUNAMI-AFFECTED CHILDREN

TEXT.P: Government Information Office (GIO) Director-General Lin Chia-lung urged the public Monday to take action to help children in countries hit by the Dec. 26 tsunami.
Lin said that his office has launched a fund-raising drive for up to 10,000 children in the tsunami-affected countries and has so far collected NT$48.2 million (US$1.5 million).
However, he said, the amount still lags far behind the GIO's target of NT$360 million to support 10,000 children for one year.
The GIO will organize a fund-raising party Jan. 15 to collect more charity money, he added.
In addition, he continued, the GIO has set up an account at the Huanan Commercial Bank -- a/c No. 100361000088 -- to receive donations for the campaign titled "The Day after Tomorrow, 10,000 Hopes."

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Tuesday, Jan. 11, or the second day of the 12th month of the Year of the Monkey according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1807: Ezra Cornell, the American founder of Cornell University, New York, is born.
1815: Sir John Alexander Macdonald, Canadian politician and the first prime minister of the Dominion of Canada, is born. He is considered the architect of the Canadian confederation, established in 1867.
1904: British troops kill 1,000 Islamic priests in British Somaliland.
1917: An explosion at a coal mine run by a Japanese railroad company in Fushun, in northern mainland China's Liaoning Province, kills 917 miners.
1922: Insulin is used for the first time with success in the treatment of diabetes.
1942: The Japanese invade the Dutch East Indies' Kalimantan and enter Kuala Lumpur, the capital of Malaysia.
1943: The new Sino-British Treaty and the new Sino-American Treaty are signed in Chungking and Washington respectively, marking the end to the unequal treaties China was forced to sign with foreign countries.
1946: The Republic of China celebrates its first Judicial Day.
1946: Albania becomes a republic after King Zog, or Ahmed Zogu, who seized power in 1925, is dethroned.
1950: The U.N. Security Council rejects a Soviet proposal for the immediate expulsion of the ROC delegation. The Russian delegation walks out.
1952: The ROC Control Yuan impeaches Vice President Li Tsung-jen in absentia for violating the laws of the nation and other dereliction of duty.
1957: Wellington Koo is elected as a judge to the International Court in the United Nations' 18th international judges elections.
1966: Indian Prime Minister Lal Bahadur Shastri dies at the age of 61. Indira Gandhi, daughter of Jawaharlal Nehru, becomes the first woman prime minister of India.
1966: The ROC Legislative Yuan approves the agreement on the status of U.S. forces in Taiwan.
1973: Japan sets up an embassy in Beijing with Ogawa Heishiro as its first ambassador.
1973: ROC Vice President C.K. Yen returns from the United States after attending memorial services for late President Harry S. Truman.
1974: "Go" Meijin (champion) Lin Hai-feng leaves for Tokyo after a two-week home visit.
1976: The ROC Ministry of Education awards a social education medal to Dr. Leung Shau-ya, chairman of the Chinese Community Church in Washington.
1979: The ROC Executive Yuan approves the Taipei Feitsui Reservoir construction project.
1981: Wen Rei-an and Fang Er-chen, writers from Malaysia, are sentenced to a reformatory for three years by a military court for setting up an organization to spread pro-Beijing propaganda.
1988: The ROC Legislative Yuan passes the Law on Assembly and Parades during the Period of National Mobilization for Suppression of the Communist Rebellion, which outlines three fundamental principles and specifies areas that are off-limits to demonstrators.
1989: President Ronald Reagan bids farewell to the American people after two terms in office.
1994: The ROC Consumer Protection Law goes into effect, making manufacturers responsible for harm to consumers even if negligence or intent to do harm are not found to be factors.
1996: ROC Vice President Li Yuan-zu leaves for the Republic of Guatemala to attend the inauguration of President Alvaro Enrique Arzu Irigoyen, traveling via Los Angeles.
2000: ROC Vice President Lien Chan makes an inspection tour of Tungsha (Pratas) Island in the South China Sea as part of the government's efforts to reaffirm that there is no change in its policy on defending the remote island.
2001: American Institute in Taiwan Chairman Richard Bush calls on ROC Defense Minister Wu Shih-wen to exchange views on cross-strait security, the Asian-Pacific regional situation and the "mini three links."
2002: The second F-16 tactical wing of the Republic of China Air Force is inaugurated at the Hualien airbase, with Air Force Commander-in-Chief Chen Chao-min presiding over the ceremony.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "When we meet with men of worth, we should think how we may equal them. When we meet with worthless men, we should turn into ourselves and find out if we do not resemble them."

DOC.HEADLINE: LOCALLY DEVELOPED EIGHT-WHEEL ARMORED VEHICLE UNVEILED

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian presided over the christening ceremony for a locally developed eight-wheel armored vehicle Tuesday, naming the new vehicle as "Clouded Leopard" for its high speed and mobility.
The christening ceremony for the CM-32 armored vehicle took place at a military equipment maintenance center in the central county of Nantou.
A military research team began to develop the new armored vehicle in 2002. The vehicle has completed initial testing.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Straits Times: EDB exceeds target for investments.
Unexpectedly strong investment pledges from foreign and local investors last year, including $8.3 billion for Singapore's factories, look set to produce a bumper crop of 21,800 new jobs.
New figures, which have confounded sceptics' doubts, show that the Economic Development Board (EDB) lifted investment commitments to the key manufacturing sector by a strong 11 per cent from 2003, beating the EDB's own forecast.
Even more impressive was a 20 per cent jump to $2.3 billion in total business spending, a yardstick for measuring investment in service industries, such as the information communications and media services sectors.
The Lianhe Zaobao:S'pore's GDP will increase S$10 billion and create 20 thousand new jobs this year.
The Economic Development Board (EDB) expects to see a drop in manufacturing investments this year because of the softening in the global electronics sector.
But the EDB says Singapore will still attract some S$8b worth of manufacturing investments, dipping some 3.6% from 2004.
And these investment commitments, when realised, are expected to create 21,800 new jobs,and the GDP will increase S$10 billion.

DOC.HEADLINE: LOCALLY DEVELOPED ARMORED VEHICLE CHRISTENED 'CLOUDED LEOPARD'

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian presided over the christening ceremony for a locally developed eight-wheeled armored vehicle Tuesday, naming the new vehicle "Yunpao" meaning "Clouded Leopard" for its agility and mobility.

At the ceremony held at a military equipment maintenance center in the central county of Nantou, President Chen signed his name on a prototype armored vehicle next to a plaque showing the name "Yunpao."

Chen lauded the military research team responsible for developing the CM-32 eight-wheeled armored vehicle as a "warrior of life" for its ability to complete research and development of the new armored personnel carrier in two years at a very low cost.

The president also explained that the vehicle got its name because it could move agilely over rough terrain just as the Formosan clouded leopard -- a species said to be endemic to Taiwan, although the animal is almost never seen.
Chen said the military will transfer technological know-how to private companies to produce the new armored vehicle.

"We believe that the 'Yunpao' development project will create business opportunities worth billions of dollars for the private sector, including production, material supplies, maintenance and repair, " Chen said, adding that the project will help realize the goal of creating a "win-win" scenario for both national defense and economic development.

Chen also took advantage of the occasion to rebut a media report that the military has spent NT$60 million manufacturing a single "Yunpao" armored vehicle for emergency use by the president and his family.

"The report was a ill-motivated smear, " Chen said, adding that neither he nor his family would ever use the new armored vehicle, which he said will only be used for defending Taiwan and all of its people.

Military sources said the new armored vehicle can travel at a maximum speed of over 100 kilometers per hour and will be armed with a 25mm gun and a 7.62mm machine gun. Its fire power will surpass any armored personnel carriers now in service in the ROC armed forces.

According to sources, each CM-32 armored vehicle will be able to carry a crew of three and six other fully armed soldiers. Moreover, sources said the carrier can be converted into a platform for various kinds of weapons. The military research team began to develop the new armored vehicle in 2002. The vehicle has completed initial testing and mass production is scheduled to start in 2007.
Military sources said the locally produced vehicle is only about one-quarter of the cost of a U.S.-built armored vehicle.
Tuesday's ceremony included demonstrations of the vehicle climbing a steep hill and driving over low walls. President Chen also embarked on the vehicle to get a ride.
The Ministry of National Defense said Sunday that the new armored vehicle was developed to cope with Taiwan's special terrain and upgrade the military's overall combat capabilities.

DOC.HEADLINE: PFP OFFICIAL DENIES REPORT OF DPP-PFP COOPERATION

TEXT.P: A senior opposition People First Party (PFP) legislator Tuesday denied a report claiming that the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) is close to finalizing a deal to cooperate with the PFP.
Dismissing the report as mere rumor, PFP legislative caucus convener Liu Wen-hsiung said neither PFP Chairman James Soong nor any PFP politicians have had any contact with the DPP.
A local daily ran a story Tuesday saying that a cooperation deal between the DPP and PFP is nearly complete and that Soong is likely to meet with President Chen Shui-bian soon.
The report said that the two parties are inclined to cooperate in the race for Legislative Yuan speaker and vice speaker and that some PFP politicians may also enter the Cabinet.

Liu said the PFP's fundamental policies of "defending the Republic of China and opposing Taiwan independence" remain unchanged, affirming that the party will never trade its party stance for power or positions in the government.
Liu said a lot of political rumors are being circulated by different people with different motives.

While some stories say acting DPP Chairman Ker Chien-ming has recently met Soong in the United States, others say the DPP is offering the PFP a number of different positions including Straits Exchange Foundation chairman, premier, vice premier as well as Legislative Yuan speaker and vice speaker, Liu pointed out.
Huang Teh-fu, head of the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) legislative caucus, accused the DPP of using the media to spread rumors to try to divide the alliance between the KMT and PFP.
Ker admitted that it is premature to jump to the conclusion that a DPP-PFP cooperation deal is near before President Chen and Soong meet each other.
Ker said he hopes Soong will hold talks with Chen on issues concerning Taiwan's political stability, economic development and cross-Taiwan Strait peace after he returns from the United States.
Ker said there is a need for the DPP to sit down for talks with opposition leaders to seek reconciliation and that the talks are not exclusively for the PFP but also include the KMT.
Also on Tuesday, a group of protesters drove 10 campaign trucks around the Legislative Yuan in opposition to the PFP's alleged plan to cooperate with the DPP.
The protesters urged people to participate in a demonstration set for Jan. 15 at PFP headquarters to "rescue the PFP from turning green," the color representing the DPP.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING INVITES TAIPEI FOR FURTHER TALKS ON CHARTER FLIGHT SERVICES
DOC.DATELINE: Beijing, Jan. 11 (CNA) (By Stanley Cheung and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: A mainland Chinese aviation official has sent a letter to the head of the Taipei Airlines Association (TAA) , inviting him to further discuss the details of charter flights during the Chinese Lunar New Year holiday for Taiwan businessmen operating in mainland China.

Pu Zhaozhou, executive director of the China Civil Aviation Association, asked TAA head Michael Lo to lead a delegation of Taiwan airlines executives to visit the mainland to talk about technical and operational details of the cross-strait charter flights. The meeting place has yet to be set.

Pu said that with less than one month before the Chinese Lunar New Year, which falls on Feb. 9 this year, Taiwan needs to produce a list of names in the delegation and suggest a possible venue for the meeting soon so that arrangements can be made.

This will be the follow-up to a secret meeting between Pu and Lo earlier this month. Lo, at the commission of the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) , went to Macau where he and Pu reportedly reached an agreement on the charter flights.

Pu, who is also the director of the Office of Taiwan, Hong Kong and Macau Affairs under the Civil Aviation Administration of China, sent the letter through a news release of the Taiwan Affairs Office of the State Council.

In Taipei, an MAC official reaffirmed Tuesday that it is the long-standing policy of the MAC to promote the charter flights for the holiday period, and that negotiations should take into account the existing Taiwan-Hong Kong aviation agreement.

MAC Vice Chairman Liu Teh-shun made the remarks after meeting with a delegation from the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) , which returned from the mainland after meeting with Chen Yunlin, director of the Taiwan Affairs Office, in Beijing Monday. Chen agreed to the principles of "joint participation, multiple-destinations and two-way flights without stopovers in third countries or areas" for the charter flights.

Liu pointed out that the Taiwan Affairs Office said in October that following the model used to get negotiations on track to create the existing Taiwan-Hong Kong aviation agreement would be feasible, although the KMT delegation said that the insistence of this model would almost certainly stop the flights before they even got off the ground because the Taiwan-Hong Kong talks involved participation by government officials, something that Beijing will not accept in this situation.

TAA head Lo was also commissioned by Taiwan to head Taiwan's delegation during the talks to create the accord on Taiwan-Hong Kong flights in 2002, but the MAC and Civil Aeronautics Administration officials also came to the negotiating table to act as advisers for the TAA.

Legislator John Chang, a member of KMT delegation, said after meeting with Liu that if the MAC insists on the Taiwan-Hong Kong model for further talks with Beijing, then the matter "could fall through."

He noted that Taiwan Affairs Office Director Chen had said clearly that whether being commissioned by the government or not, the private aviation operators must consult with each other as soon as possible. Chen said that both sides of the Taiwan Strait are talking about "charter flights," not about aviation rights or agreements.
Chen also said that in view of the strained relationship between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait, it is out of the question to have official-to-official talks, according to Chang.
Chang expressed the hope that the government will be more flexible and that mainland China show some leeway so as not to complicate a simple issue.

According to EPA officials, the seminar is a cooperative project between the EPA and the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency and is being coordinated by Tsay Si-chee, a senior scientist at the U.S. National Aeronautics and Space Administration (NASA).
In addition to Tsay, who will be one of the keynote speakers, the participants will also include several other American and Australian scientists, the officials said.

The EPA has since 2003 cooperated with the Central Weather Bureau to monitor air pollution by analyzing data from NASA satellites, and satellite technology is especially helpful in the monitoring of cross-border pollution, they said.
