DOC.HEADLINE: SEF CHIEF'S DEATH MARKS BEGINNING OF NEW ERA OF CROSS-STRAIT TIES
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Jan. 10 (CNA) (By Wennie Chi and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: The recent death of Taiwan's top negotiator with mainland China has brought about a new era in cross-Taiwan Strait relations, a noted mainland Chinese dissident said Monday.

Wei Jinsheng recalled the significance of a historic 1993 meeting between Koo Chen-fu, chairman of Taiwan's Straits Exchange Foundation, and his counterpart Wang Daohan, chairman of Beijing's Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait, marking the first high-level contact between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait after a five-decade hiatus.

Wei said the event was historic because the meeting would not have been possible with Koo's efforts alone, noting that the mainland was isolated in the international community following the Tiananmen Square massacre of 1989 and was more willing to negotiate, while Koo had the full authorization of Republic of China then-President Lee Teng-hui.
But with the changing times, cross-strait relations are now facing a new era, Wei said.

The dissident-in-exile said that the United States had hoped to solicit support from the mainland in the war against Iraq and the North Korea issue, a situation that seemed to be not in Taiwan's favor.

But now that the situation has changed, Wei said, he has heard U.S. State Department officials and friends in U.S. think tanks complaining lately that Beijing has been dragging its feet on many international issues, including North Korea and nuclear arms inspections in Iran.

Wei noted that after Hu Jintao took the helm of mainland China, the United States and many European countries were hoping for a more moderate and friendly China, but the expectations have fallen through as a result of Hu's recent deeds and policies.
Taiwan should make good use of the situation to strengthen its international relations, he said.

Wei said that Taiwan should adjust its diplomatic approach and strengthen its relations with Western countries such as the United States to solicit wider support. On the other hand, it should improve its publicity drive toward the mainland people to win their hearts, adding that it is futile to extend olive branches to the Beijing authorities.

DOC.HEADLINE: ARMS PROCUREMENT STATUTE AGAIN FAILS TO GET ONTO LEGISLATIVE AGENDA

TEXT.P: A draft statute governing major arms procurements failed again Tuesday to be included on the Legislative Yuan's agenda.
The bill was once again blocked by the majority "pan-blue alliance" of the opposition Kuomintang and People First Party in the procedures committee, which schedules the agenda of the legislature.

The "pan-blue alliance" has demanded that the Executive Yuan withdraw its budget proposal for a NT$610.8 billion (US$18.23 billion) arms procurement package from the United States as a condition for clearing the way for the statute.

The alliance, which thinks the United States is overcharging for procurement package, has also demanded that the Executive Yuan cut the amount at least by half before it submits the budget bill to the legislature again, after the special statute is passed.

Tsai Huang-liang, a leader of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party's legislative caucus, said there is little chance of the statute being passed before the legislative session closes Jan. 21, since it has not even been included on the agenda.

Also excluded from the agenda are President Chen Shui-bian's request for the legislature to exercise its consent on Control Yuan appointments, a proposed resolution defending the Republic of China and a proposed amendment to the Land Taxes Act.
Priority items on the legislative agenda for next week include the 2005 central government budget bill and a draft law governing National Assembly elections.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Times: Monuments to the missing in schools across the globe.
Painting smocks belonging to those who died hang unclaimed as a symbol of the tragedy in a classroom at Ban Bang Muang School in southern Thailand. When, in the wake of nature's wrath, communities try to put together some semblance of a normal life, it is suddenly and painfully obvious which pieces of the jigsaw are missing. Nothing could tell a sharper tale of tragedy than empty hatpegs in a school cloakroom. The hopes for the next generation have been washed away. The Namahal Vidyalayam School in Galle, southern Sri Lanka, is only one among many to have been hurt to its core. Of its 313 pupils, 150 are known to have died and 11 more are still missing. Across the Indian Ocean in the Thai village of Ban Bang Muang, the school had 687 pupils aged from three to 16 on its register. Here it is the unclaimed smocks hanging on the pegs that tell the story.
Financial Times: NHS reform hit by new delay.
Ministers are to restrict their flagship National Health Service reform radically for fear that it will lead to financial turmoil ahead of the general election. The reform aims to establish a system of "payment by results" in which health service funds follow the patient and hospitals receive a fixed sum for each course of treatment.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI MAYOR HOSTS LUNCH FOR COMMITTEE OF 100 MEMBERS

TEXT.P: Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou hosted a luncheon Tuesday at the Taipei World Trade Center for several members of the Committee of 100, a high-profile Chinese-American organization, after he was denied a visa by the Hong Kong authorities to attend a meeting on urban development organized by the group.

The mayor had been scheduled to present a speech at the Committee of 100's first Greater China Conference that will run from Jan. 12-14 in Hong Kong until his visa application was rejected. Because of this, he met in Taipei with 19 members of the Committee, including San Francisco-based Unison International Chairman C.B. Sung.
During the lunch, Ma expressed regret at not being able to meet them in Hong Kong.

Although his planned itinerary in Hong Kong did not include any official activities, the authorities refused to open the door for him, he said. He claimed, however, that the incident has drawn "worldwide media attention."

He said there are about 89 press reports, including stories in the Asia Wall Street Journal and the South China Morning Post, on the incident, while the Hong Kong authorities have also been criticized by the U.S. consulate in Hong Kong.

The non-political Committee of 100 was founded in 1990 by a group of Americans of Chinese descent to bring an Asian-American perspective to U.S-China relations and to address the concerns of Chinese-Americans.
Each of its members, including renowned cellist Yo Yo Ma and architect I.M. Pei, enjoy positions of leadership in the United States in a broad range of professions.

A Taipei city official in charge of arranging Ma's overseas visits said that the mayor was scheduled to leave for Hong Kong Tuesday and to fly from there to Brisbane on Thursday before heading to Bangkok Jan. 18.
The official said the mayor will still visit Australia and Thailand.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN GROUPS JOIN GPPAC TO PROMOTE NORTHEAST ASIAN PEACE

TEXT.P: Some 10 non-government groups from Taiwan have joined the Global Partnership for the Prevention of Armed Conflict (GPPAC) to help promote peace in Northeast Asia, a spokesman for the Peacetime Foundation of Taiwan said Tuesday.

Chien Hsi-chieh, executive director of the Peacetime Foundation, said his foundation and several other private groups, including the Taiwan Security Research Center (TSRC), will join GPPAC operations to help prevent armed conflict and maintain peace in Northeast Asia.

The groups will organize a joint delegation to attend a GPPAC conference to be held in Japan next month to craft action guidelines for safeguarding Northeast Asian regional security and peace, Chien said.

Yang Yung-ming, a National Taiwan University professor who concurrently serves as TSRC director, said GPPAC is a worldwide peace movement aimed at averting armed confrontation. The GPPAC has 15 chapters in different parts of the world and each chapter groups countries in its specific region to seek peaceful solutions to disputes without resorting to military force.

Noting that GPPAC provides a forum for civic groups in the region to conduct in-depth discussions on measures to resolve regional disputes by peaceful means and to avert armed conflict, Yang said GPPAC can serve as a conduit for people from both sides of the Taiwan Strait to exchange views and forge friendship.

Meanwhile, Chien said the upcoming GPPAC conference will bring together delegates from Taiwan, mainland China, North and South Korea, Hong Kong, Mongolia, Russia and Japan to discuss feasible measures to prevent armed conflict in the region.
Akira Kawasaki, a leading member of the GPPAC Northeast Asian Steering Group, was also present at a ceremony to mark the Taiwan groups' participation in the GPPAC.

Kawasaki said the cross-strait and North Korea issues are the most important security concerns in Northeast Asia. The upcoming GPPAC meeting will enable civic delegates from North and South Korea, Japan, the mainland and Taiwan to discuss disarmament and prevention of armed conflict, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: OVER 74% OF POLL RESPONDENTS SUPPORT CROSS-STRAIT PEACE COMMITTEE

TEXT.P: More than 74 percent of the respondents to a recent poll support President Chen Shui-bian's plan to set up a Committee for Cross-Strait Peace and Development to seek national consensus on the government's policy toward mainland China, according to the results of the survey released Tuesday by the Cabinet-level Research, Development and Evaluation Commission.
The figure compares with 7.1 percent who are against the idea, the survey shows.
The survey was conducted from Jan. 4-5 among 1,083 adults, with a margin of error of 3 percent.

On the most suitable candidate to head the committee, 4.9 percent of the respondents named opposition People First Party Chairman James Soong, 4.3 percent favored Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou and 3.5 percent named former Mainland Affairs Council Chairwoman Tsai Ing-wen.
Academia Sinica President Lee Yuan-tseh gained 2.4 percent support, while former Premier Vincent Siew and Control Yuan President Fredrick Chien both won 1.8 percent support.
However, 70.5 percent of those polled did not answer the question.
A total of 75.1 percent of the respondents agreed that the new Cabinet should strengthen the function of consultations and dialogue, compared with 4.5 percent who disagreed.
While 60.1 percent of the respondents said they favor Chen's proposal to meet with opposition leaders to discuss major policies and legislation, 4.2 percent said they are against the proposal.

Meanwhile, 41 percent of the respondents said the Legislative Yuan should pass the budget for the government's NT$610.8 billion (US$18.23 billion) arms procurement package from the United States as soon as possible, compared with 35.2 who do not think so.
In addition, 56.4 percent said the legislature should pass a law soon to deal with the ill-gotten assets of the opposition Kuomintang, with 14.6 percent disagreeing.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN-U.S. TECHNOLOGY, INDUSTRY FORUM TO BE HELD IN TAIPEI

TEXT.P: The Taiwan-U.S. Technology and Industry Forum is scheduled to be held in Taipei Jan. 13-14, officials of the Taiwan Industry Technology Promotion Association (TITPA) said Tuesday.

The two-day event, co-organized by the TITPA and the North American Taiwanese Engineers' Association (NATEA) , will bring together 150 technology experts from the Industrial Technology Research Institute, the Institute for Information Industry (III), National Chiao Tung University, the National Center for High-Performance Computing and various science-based industrial parks around Taiwan, the officials said.

The purpose of the forum is to conduct an exchange of viewpoints on the semiconductor, display, digital content and biotechnology industries, which have been dubbed the "two-trillion, two-star" project in Taiwan.

On the first day of the forum, digital content creation, transmission and display technology and business opportunities will be discussed, with Bill Anker, vice president of Activision, Chen Yen-kuang, a senior researcher of Intel Corp. and Chung Pin-jung, a manager of Intel Corp. making keynote speeches.

Huang Kuo-chun, vice chief executive officer of the III is scheduled to deliver a keynote speech on business opportunities created by Taiwan's digitalization process, and many senior members of the NATEA will offer advice regarding the digital content industry.

On the second day, Vice President Annette Lu, at the invitation of the organizing committee, will give a speech and present the "Golden Root Awards" to enterprises that have kept their business roots in Taiwan while investing in other countries, while Wu Maw-kuen, chairman of the Cabinet-level National Science Council, and Lin Ferng-ching, a member of the Science and Technology Advisory Group under the Executive Yuan, will make keynote speeches.

DOC.HEADLINE: ELDERLY WOMEN HEALTH ISSUES IMPORTANT AS POPULATION GRAYS: SCHOLAR

TEXT.P: As Taiwan's population is graying quickly, the number of elderly women will jump rapidly due to their longer life expectancy, a situation that the government should address, according to a scholar.
Wu Shu-chiung, a professor at National Taiwan University, made the suggestion while giving a keynote speech on the gender gap in the country's demographic policy at a recent seminar.

Calling on the government to draw up an adequate policy capable of dealing with the long-term health care needs of elderly women, she said the country's population policy has apparently ignored the issue and she called for a shift in attitudes toward dealing with a graying society dominated by women.

Citing the latest statistics compiled by the Cabinet-level Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) , Wu said that elderly people will account for one quarter of the country's total population by around 2031, as the elderly population is expected to grow from 2.46 million in 2011 to 5.66 million by that time.
Currently, the number of Taiwan nationals aged over 65 years totals around 2.14 million.
According to Wu, women will outnumber men among the elderly. "There will be more women in the more advanced age groups," she pointed out.

In 2000, the number of Taiwan's male population aged over 80 years was only 90 percent that of the female population, she reported, adding that the ratio is estimated to fall to 73 percent in 2020 and 68 percent in 2030.
The gap will further widen along with age increases, underscoring the seriousness surrounding health care and medical treatment of elderly women, she said.
Statistics show that some 65 percent of Taiwan's disabled men aged over 65 years have spouses, ahead of 32 percent of elderly and disabled women.

Generally speaking, about 80 percent of Taiwan's elderly men are taken care of by their wives or sent to nursing institutions, well above the percentage of their female counterparts who are as fortunate.

According to the Cabinet-level Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS) , Taiwan is the only one of the major countries around the world that has a larger percentage of men aged over 60 years than women.

DGBAS officials ascribe the phenomenon to the large number of male immigrants to Taiwan in 1949, when the now opposition Kuomintang retreated to Taiwan after losing a civil war to the Chinese communists in mainland China.
Citing CEPD tallies as evidence, they said that in 2000, the number of Taiwan's male population aged over 65 was 1.11-fold that of females.

In most Asian countries except Japan, parents traditionally prefer sons to daughters, they said, adding that in Taiwan and South Korea, there are an average 110 male newborns for every 100 females, while the figures are 109 and 108 in mainland China and Singapore, respectively.

However, due to the longer life expectancy of women, the numbers of elderly female citizens in Japan, Singapore, South Korea, the United States and European countries are usually higher than those of elderly men, they said.
For instance, there are fewer than one man among every three elderly citizens aged over 80 in France, Germany, Japan and South Korea, they noted.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN MILITARY DISPLAYS NEW ARMORED VEHICLE

TEXT.P: A new armored vehicle developed by the military made its debut in central Taiwan Tuesday.

The eight-wheeled CM-32 vehicle was christened "Puma" by President Chen Shui-bian during a ceremony held at a maintenance and repair service center of the Combined Logistics Command under the Ministry of National Defense in Nantou County.
According to Chen, the mobility, swiftness and power of the vehicle is just like that of the puma.
The vehicle is equipped with 25-mm automatic cannons and 7.62-mm machine guns and has a top speed of more than 100 kph, military officials said.
The vehicle, which the military started to develop in 2002, has recently completed preliminary testing and assessment and is expected to enter mass production in 2007, the officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The New York Times: CBS Dismisses 4 Over Broadcast on Bush Service.
CBS yesterday dismissed four of its top journalists, including a high-ranking news executive, after an independent panel concluded that a September report that raised questions about President Bush's Vietnam-era National Guard service never should have been broadcast.
Wall Street Journal: Indonesian authorities warned aid workers.
The Indonesian authorities warned aid workers safe for foreigners, as the military claimed that rebels were trying to rob aid convoys.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN, JAPAN TO STEP UP COOPERATION IN AVIAN FLU PREVENTION

TEXT.P: A seminar between Taiwan and Japan on the prevention and control of avian influenza closed Tuesday with participants from both countries pledging to step up cooperation in research into major contagious diseases in animals.
Around 180 experts and scholars from Taiwan and Japan took part in the two-day seminar sponsored by the Animal Health Research institute of the Council of Agriculture.

The participants also agreed that they will step up development of early diagnosis of disease in land and marine livestock, research into related contagious diseases, as well as the research and development of vaccines for animal disease.

Participants from Taiwan reported their method of diagnosing avian flu and Taiwan's experience in dealing with the H5N2 virus, a milder form of avian flu that affected Taiwan chicken and duck farms, requiring the slaughter of the affected poultry.
The Japanese experts reported on a project to combat avian flu and the outbreak of a more lethal H5N1 virus and the decimation of the affected fowl.

The participants will convene a similar seminar in Japan next year to discuss avian flu and other human-animal transmitted diseases, as well as to exchange information on migratory birds carrying avian flu.

DOC.HEADLINE: BUSH ADMINISTRATION URGED TO REASSESS ONE CHINA POLICY
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Jan. 11 (CNA) (By Oliver Lin & Huang Kwang-chun)

TEXT.P: The Bush administration should conduct a thorough review of its "one China" policy to resolve the stark contradictions between Taiwan's democratization and mainland China's continued repression, a U.S. think tank suggests in a recently published book.

The Heritage Foundation claims in the book titled "Mandate for Leadership" that any attempt by the United States to facilitate a resolution of the mainland-Taiwan dispute must face the reality that Taiwan is a vibrant, prosperous and friendly Asian democracy while the mainland remains the world's largest tyranny.
President Chen Shui-bian's re-election in March 2004 demonstrated that formal separation from the mainland has become a mainstream sentiment in Taiwan's political debate, it claims.
Meanwhile, an increasing stridency in the mainland's military threats since the election has injected an urgency into efforts to deepen U.S.-Taiwan defense coordination, it adds.

The Bush administration has shown a new willingness to be blunt with the Chinese communists on the Taiwan issue, according to the foundation, which cites remarks by White House spokesman Scott McClellan in response to a statement issued by Beijing May 17 to warn against the emergency of a new Taiwanese national identity.
Threats to "crush" Taiwan or drown it in a "sea of fire" have no place in civilized international discourse, McClellan said.

The Bush administration still has no idea of how to define the "status quo" in the Taiwan Strait and only a vague idea of its strategic objectives in the Western Pacific or how the mainland and Taiwan fit into them, it claims.
If the existing confusion in China policy is to be cleared up, these issues must be clarified within the bureaucracy, it says.

DOC.HEADLINE: ITRI SIGNS COOPERATIVE PACT WITH TELCORDIA

TEXT.P: The Industrial Technology Research Institute (ITRI) and Telcordia Technologies Inc. signed a cooperative venture Tuesday, with Telcordia agreeing to help the ITRI set up a testing and certification center for telecom equipment and devices -- the first of its kind anywhere in Asia.

Liu Jung-sheng, director of the ITRI's Opto-Electronics Systems Laboratories, said that the accord helps create a mutually beneficial situation for both sides and for the domestic telecom industry as a whole, a boost that will enable Taiwan to play a more prominent role in the global market.

The center will help Telcordia expand its business into Asia, shortening the time-to-market cycle and improving customer satisfaction, according to Liu. At the same time, Taiwan-based telecom companies will be provided with quick technology support at world-class levels and at reasonable cost, he added.

Under the terms of the accord, Telcordia will help train local personnel and carry out technology transfers, he said, explaining that the ITRI will be able to offer top-class professional consulting and testing services for clients.

Lin Bao-shuh, director of the ITRI's Computer and Communications Research Laboratories, which is also taking part in the cooperative project, hailed the venture as proof of Taiwan's outstanding status in the international telecom industry at a time when Asia has increasingly become the world's production base and research and development hub of telecom facilities.

Hsu Ming, head of the task force under the Industrial Development Bureau in charge of promoting the ITRI-Telcordia deal, said that the government is keen on helping Taiwan companies and research units forge cooperative ventures with world-class businesses and concerns in an effort to sharpen Taiwan's competitive edge.

The non-profit ITRI was set up in 1973 to help foster Taiwan's high technology, while the U.S.-based Telcordia is devoted to helping communications companies around the world expand their networks and services.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINA'S ANTI-SECESSION LAW AIMED AT TAIWAN LEADERS: OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: The anti-secession law to be enacted by Beijing will provide for trials of Taiwan officials and military leaders before a special court after mainland China takes Taiwan in a war, Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Chairman Jaushieh Joseph Wu warned Monday.

In an interview with local media, Wu said the anti-secession law, which is to be deliberated by Beijing's National People's Congress in March, would provide Beijing with the legal means to put Taiwan's civic and military leaders on trial should they lead their country into war with the mainland.

Citing information from unnamed sources, Wu said the law also stipulates that Beijing leaders who unwittingly prompt Taiwan into declaring independence through their inaction should be charged with dereliction of duty.

Under the law, Wu said, Taiwan would be considered a part of mainland territory and any action contributing to Taiwan independence would be a punishable crime, which means Taiwan businessmen operating on the mainland would run the risk of being jailed, rather than just having their books audited by the Beijing authorities, for their support for the Republic of China.

As the members of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party and the opposition Taiwan Solidarity Union have been branded by the mainland as supporters of Taiwan independence, they face the possibility of being prosecuted and taken to the mainland should they visit countries that do not recognize Taiwan, while international groups who support Taiwan might be deemed as interfering in China's internal affairs, Wu went on.

By enacting the law, Wu said, the mainland is intent on defining its ties with Taiwan on its own terms and pre-empting other countries support for Taiwan under the pretext that it is meddling in China's domestic affairs. This could alter Washington's view of the dispute across the Taiwan Strait to Taiwan's detriment and could rob the United States of its right to interpret the dispute in its own way.

Wu will be a member of the entourage of Lee Yuan-tseh, president of the Academia Sinica, when he visits Washington as President Chen Shui-bian's envoy to attend the second inauguration of U.S. President George W. Bush later this month.

He said he will make a case for Taiwan's opposition to the mainland's attempts to enact the law during his visit to Washington by stressing the law's disturbing effects on the stability across the Taiwan Strait.
In order to force the mainland to give up its attempt, Wu said, Taiwan will do all it can to bring international pressure to bear on the situation.

DOC.HEADLINE: NAVY GROUNDS CHOPPERS AFTER CRASH LANDING

TEXT.P: The Navy General Headquarters announced Tuesday that it had grounded all of its 500MD helicopters after one of them crash landed in Kaohsiung County that morning.

The helicopter was on a regular training flight from Tsoying naval base to Chishan, both in the greater Kaohsiung area, when its engine developed problems and the pilot was forced to bring it down in an orchard. The helicopter suffered minor damage but all three crew members were unscathed, according to the announcement.
The chopper was taken back to the Tsoying naval base where a team began investigating the cause of the mishap.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN WORLD'S 17TH-LARGEST SPENDER ON OUTBOUND TRAVEL IN 2002: DGBAS

TEXT.P: Taiwan was the world's 17-largest spender in terms of overseas travel in 2002, the Cabinet-level Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS) reported Tuesday.
According to the DGBAS report, Taiwan people spent a total of US$7 billion on outbound travel in 2002 and the country earned US$4.2 billion in tourist income for the same year.

The world's No. 1 tourist spender in 2002 was the United States, with expenditure amounting to US$58 billion, followed by Germany with US$53.2 billion, Britain with US$40.4 billion, Japan with US$26.7 billion and France with US$19.5 billion, DGBAS officials said, adding that the five countries accounted for 42 percent of the global spending.

The United States also ranked as the top earner in terms of tourist revenue in 2002 with a total income of US$66.6 billion, ahead of Spain with US$33.6 billion, France with US$32.3 billion, Italy with US$26.9 billion and mainland China with US$20.4 billion. The five states earned 38 percent of the world's overall tourist dollars.

The world's largest tourist destination for that year was France, attracting more than 770 million visitors. Spain came second with 517.5 million, ahead of the United States with 418.9 million, Italy with 398 million and the mainland with 368 million. The five countries absorbed 38 percent of the world's tourists.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT DECORATES MALAWIAN COUNTERPART

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian decorated his Malawian counterpart Bingu Wa Mutharika Tuesday in recognition of Mutharika's contribution to the promotion of Republic of China-Malawi relations.

The conferring ceremony was held at a state banquet Chen hosted in Mutharika's honor in Taichung, central Taiwan, in which Chen bestowed the Order of Brilliant Jade with Grand Cordon on the Malawian president.
Chen thanked Mutharika for the support and assistance his country has extended to Taiwan in its bids to join the United Nations, the Worth Health Organization and other international organizations.
Chen told his guest that Malawi is a "real friend" to Taiwan and that "the people of Taiwan will remember forever" the friendship between the two nations.
Chen also affirmed that Taiwan will not reduce its contribution to the international community as a result of political interference.

The government has adopted a pragmatic idea of diplomacy through increasing humanitarian aid and promoting the value of democracy and the efficiency of governance, Chen explained, adding that Taiwan will not fall short in any international assistance programs, even in those countries that do not maintain diplomatic ties with the ROC.

From international anti-terrorism activities to the reconstruction of Afghanistan and the relief operations for recent tsunami victims in Southeast Asia and South Asia, Chen went on, Taiwan has never been absent nor has reduced its offers to the international community due to political interference.
Taiwan will eventually be recognized by the international community because of its insistence on doing the right thing, Chen said.

Sharing Chen's views, Mutharika said that Taiwan has every right to join the U.N. and other international organizations. Malawi will continue to speak for Taiwan in the international arena regardless any adverse oppression, he pledged.
Taiwan should be allowed to enter the U.N. as soon as possible because there is no reason to shut it out, Mutharika said.
At Chen's invitation, Mutharika arrived in Taiwan Monday for a five-day visit.
On Tuesday he toured the Tantze Export Processing Zone in Taichung in Chen's company.
He expressed the hope after the visit that Taiwan's experience in economic development will be introduced to his country and that Taiwan businesses will invest there.

DOC.HEADLINE: NUMBER OF MOTOR VEHICLES IN TAIWAN INCREASES

TEXT.P: The number of motor vehicles in Taiwan had increased to 19.18 million as of the end of last year, an annual growth of 3.7 percent, according to statistics released Tuesday by the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS).
The number means there were 84.4 motor vehicles for every 100 people in Taiwan, DGBAS officials said.
Of the total, they added, 12.79 million were motorcycles and 6.39 million were automobiles.
The authorities had issued a total of 22.28 million driving licenses as of Nov. 30, 2004, of which 11.66 million were for motorcycles and 10.62 million were for automobiles, the tallies show.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN CONTINUES TO PUMP AID INTO TSUNAMI-AFFLICTED COUNTRIES

TEXT.P: The Chunghwa Post Office offered to deliver relief materials free Tuesday as the country's private groups continued their efforts to ship aid to countries ravaged by the Dec. 26 tsunami in the Indian Ocean.

The Post Office said aid materials sent by mail to a Lienchang transportation company in Taoyuan that is designated by the government as the depot for relief materials will be delivered free from Wednesday until the end of the month.
Packages intended for this free service should not exceed 30 kg, the Post Office said.

The company also halved the postage fees for packages sent home by Taiwan's foreign expatriates from Indonesia, Thailand, Malaysia, Sri Lanka and India -- the five countries hardest-hit by the tsunami.
To claim this privilege, these foreign expatriates have to show their passports when they take their packages to the post office, the Post Office said.
Also Tuesday, the Veterans Affairs Commission under the Executive Yuan announced that its seven tourist farms and parks will donate their admission fee income for Jan. 15 to the tsunami victims.
Mega Financial Holding Company pledged Tuesday to chip in NT$20 million (US$625.000) in aid for the victims.

Taiwan Root Medical Peace Corps promised to donate 1,000 tons of rice to tsunami victims in Sri Lanka. The rice will be shipped by the Evergreen Marine Corp. and the Yang Ming Marine Transport Corp. free of charge, according to a spokesman for the corps.

Foreign Ministry spokesman Michel Lu said the government and the private sector in Taiwan had raised cash donations of NT$600 million in addition to 160 tons of relief supplies for tsunami-hit countries thus far.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Wednesday, Jan. 12, or the third day of the 12th month of the Year of the Monkey according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1809: Ludwig van Beethoven, German composer and the greatest composer of his day, is given a guaranteed yearly income by three Viennese noblemen, on the condition that he stays in Vienna.
1893: Hermann Goering, commander of the German Air Force during World War II, is born.
1899: Paul Hermann Muller, the Swiss chemist and Nobel laureate who discovered the effectiveness of DDT as an insecticide, is born.
1904: Henry Ford, automobile engineer and race car driver, achieves a new land speed record of 91.37 mph in his "999" car on frozen Lake St. Clair outside Detroit.
1908: A telecommunications station atop the Eiffel Tower in Paris begins its first long-distance wireless communications service.
1945: U.S. planes from aircraft carriers sink 25 Japanese ships off the Indo-China Peninsula.
1945: German troops retreat in disorder during the Battle of the Bulge in Belgium during World War II.
1956: The Taiwan Provincial Government promulgates the rules for the enforcement of the Statute on Urban Land Reform.
1957: U.S. President Dwight D. Eisenhower urges the Soviet Union to agree to a ban on space warfare.
1960: A MIG-15 jet fighter from mainland China crashes after a failed forced-landing attempt in Nanau, Ilan County, killing the pilot.
1962: Construction of Paihe Reservoir begins in Tainan County.
1964: The Sultan of Zanzibar is banished, and the country becomes a republic.
1967: Mainland China's army pledges support for Mao Zedong during the disorder triggered by the Cultural Revolution.
1969: The ROC Consumers' Foundation is established.
1969: The Taiwan Power Company sets up its Power Research Institute.
1970: The first trans-Atlantic flight from New York to London by a Boeing 747 jumbo jet is made.
1972: East Pakistan is separated from West Pakistan and becomes the independent nation of Bangladesh.
1976: Thailand's Cabinet collapses with the resignation of Prime Minister Kukrit Pramoj.
1984: The ROC Cabinet approves a plan to build a synchrotron research center within five years.
1989: Former Ugandan leader Idi Amin is expelled from Zaire and takes refuge in Senegal.
1990: Romania outlaws the Communist Party, becoming the first Warsaw Pact member to do so.
1991: The U.S. Congress grants President George Bush authority to use military force to drive Iraq out of Kuwait.
1994: The Republic of China and Lesotho sever diplomatic relations.
1998: Nineteen European nations sign an accord to prohibit the cloning of human beings.
2000: The ruling Kuomintang Central Standing Committee approves the establishment of a task force on entrusting the party's assets, with party Secretary-General Huang Kun-huei appointed as its convenor.
2001: After 11 years of planning, officials in southern Taiwan's Kaohsiung City break ground for a rapid transit system for the island's second-largest city.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "In serving his parents, a son should seldom remonstrate with them; but if he is obliged to do so, and should find that they will not listen, he should yet not fail in respect nor disregard their wishes; however much trouble they may give him, he should never complain."
