DOC.HEADLINE: SEVEN HOSPITALS DENY ADMISSION TO BEATEN CHILD: INVESTIGATION BEGINS

TEXT.P: A badly beaten four-year-old girl was refused treatment in Taipei Tuesday after seven hospital emergency rooms reportedly would not accept her because there were no empty beds.
The girl was finally driven by ambulance nearly 200 kilometers to Taichung for treatment early Tuesday morning, where she remains on the edge of death.

The girl, allegedly beaten and smashed into a wall by her drunk father, was taken first to Jen Ai Hospital at 1: 55 a.m. Tuesday but was not admitted because no bed was available in the neurosurgery department.

At that point, the Taipei Emergency Operations Center tried in vain until 4: 18 a.m. to find an emergency room in Taipei that would take the child for treatment, finally giving up after being rejected at six locations.

It was then decided that the girl should be driven to Tungs' Taichung MetroHarbor Hospital in Wuchi, Taichung County in central Taiwan. By the time the child reached Tungs' Hospital's operating room, it was past dawn Tuesday morning.

Surgeons at Tungs' Hospital immediately preformed surgery to remove a blood clot from the girl's brain and a second operation to try to relieve swelling was done later at around midnight of the same day. Doctors say they are not very optimistic about the child's chances for survival.

The Taipei District Prosecutors' Office is questioning the Taipei emergency center and the hospitals involved as to why they failed to find a bed for the girl in Taipei. The prosecutors said that some people must bear the responsibility for the negligence.

Meanwhile, a doctor with Jen Ai Hospital's Neurosurgery Department and a head nurse working the Monday night shift were disciplined Wednesday for negligence, the first two people punished in the incident.
Minister of Health Chen Chien-jen said Wednesday that it was "extremely pitiful" that the young girl had been treated like a "hot potato" during the emergency.
Chen said that the medical sector's coordination system failed badly and is to blame for the situation.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINA MUM ON SHUTTING TAIWAN OFFICIALS OUT OF CHARTER FLIGHT TALKS

TEXT.P: An official of mainland China's Taiwan Affairs Office on Wednesday stopped short of saying whether Taiwan's civil aviation officials can take part in talks over cross-strait charter flights during the Chinese Lunar New Year holiday.

He Shizhong, director of the Economics Bureau of the Taiwan Affairs Office, made the remarks when he was asked if Billy K.C. Chang, director-general of Civil Aeronautics Administration of Taiwan, who is also an adviser to the Taipei Airlines Association (TAA), will be allowed to participate in a follow-up meeting between Beijing and Taipei on the matter.

He stopped short of saying whether Chang would be allowed to attend the meeting, but he stressed that to avoid unnecessary political interference, officials from mainland China's Taiwan Affairs Office and its quasi-official Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait cannot take part in the discussions between air carriers from both sides.
It would be "inappropriate, impractical and insincere" if someone should suggest that Taiwan's Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) and the Straits Exchange Foundation take part in the talks, He added.

Pu Zhaozhou, executive director of the China Civil Aviation Association, sent a letter to Taipei Airlines Association head Michael Lo Tuesday to arrange for further talks on the technical and operational details of the charter flights during the Chinese Lunar New Year holiday. The two held a secret meeting in Macau earlier this month and reportedly reached agreement on the issue.

Although Beijing and Taipei agreed to the principles of "joint participation in two-way, multiple-destination, non-stop" charter flights during the Chinese Lunar New Year holiday, the MAC has said that further talks on the matter have to be based on the model of aviation agreement negotiations between Taiwan and Hong Kong in 2002 in which TAA head Lo headed Taiwan's delegation, but officials from the MAC and the CAA also came to the negotiating table in the capacity of TAA advisers to work behind the scenes.

Meanwhile, an official from the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) said Wednesday that the KMT has completed the finishing touches on establishing the foundation for the service, and if the charter flights don't get off the ground, the ruling Democratic Progressive Party should bear full responsibility for the failure.

Legislator Tseng Yung-chuan, a member of the KMT delegation who called on Chen Yunlin, head of the Taiwan Affairs Office in Beijing Monday, said in the beginning, while the matter was in the hands of the DPP-led government, no headway was made and the MAC had all but given up on the prospects for the flights; however, the KMT promoted the flight service for the sake of Taiwan businessmen operating on the mainland. Tseng pointed to the fact that Chen had announced preparations for the cross-strait flights only after the meeting with the KMT delegation.
Legislator John Chang, another member of the KMT delegation, also urged the government to be "swift and simple" to help the charter flight services get underway.

DOC.HEADLINE: FIRST QUARTER IS CRUCIAL POINT FOR CROSS-STRAIT RELATIONS: ANALYST

TEXT.P: The first quarter of this year is a crucial point that will decide whether cross-Taiwan Strait relations will temper, a local analyst on mainland China studies said Wednesday.

According to Tamkang University Professor Andy Chang, incidents that will guide the development of cross-strait relations include the special cross-strait Chinese Lunar New Year charter flights, which both sides are trying to arrange; Beijing authorities' statement to be released in late January to mark the 10th anniversary of an "eight-point overture" offered by former mainland President Jiang Zemin; and an "anti-secession law" which the mainland's National People's Congress is expected to pass in March.
Chang said the negotiations and dialogue between Taiwan and the mainland will become more pragmatic and flexible if the charter flight services are successfully launched this year.
However, there will be little prospect of both sides opening talks on the launch of direct shipping and air links if the charter flight negotiations fail, Chang said.
He proposed that Taiwan and the mainland seek to normalize the charter flights and make the services available during other holidays such as the Dragon Boat Festival and Mid-autumn Festival.
Chang made the remarks at a news conference held by the Peacetime Foundation of Taiwan for the release of a report on cross-strait peace.

Chien Hsi-chieh, executive director of the foundation, said the "anti-secession law" will not help solve any problems in cross-strait relations but will only cause antipathy among the Taiwanese people towards the mainland.
By trying to solve a political problem through legal means, Beijing will undermine the flexibility in dealing with relations with Taiwan, Chien added.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP WILL RETAIN IDEALS FOR INTER-PARTY COOPERATION: DPP LEGISLATOR

TEXT.P: Inter-party cooperation is the aspiration of the public and the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) has not turned its back on its ideals, a DPP legislator said Wednesday.
Tsai Huang-liang, DPP party whip in the legislature, was responding to criticism by the Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU), an ally of the DPP, earlier in the day.

Chen Chien-ming, deputy convener of the TSU in the Legislative Yuan, said that the DPP, in a bid to woo the People First Party (PFP) into its fold, has placated the PFP and suspended its call to change the name of overseas missions and a revised referendum law. The TSU cannon accept "such a betrayal of ideals," Chen said.
Tsai said that the public approves of inter-party cooperation and that the DPP, as the ruling party, must show more goodwill and avoid touching the controversial issues.

He said the name-change drive for overseas missions of the nation cannot be successfully carried out without inter-party cooperation and national consensus. Creating an environment conducive for cooperation between the ruling and opposition parties will also pave the way for realizing ideals, Tsai said, dismissing the TSU's complaints as a "big misunderstanding."
Meanwhile, DPP acting chairman Ker Chien-ming said the DPP and PFP have yet to make the first step toward cooperation despite reports, adding that the wild speculation is not correct.

Ker said that the best time for starting cooperation would be between Jan. 21, when this Legislative Yuan's session will end, and Jan. 27, when President Chen Shui-bian will leave for a visit of two allies in the South Pacific, and the timing will be more crucial closer to February.

"Everything will hinge on talks between President Chen and PFP Chairman James Soong, " Ker said. Soong, who is currently in the United States, "holds the key to history" regarding whether the DPP-PFP can cooperate.

PFP Legislator Chou Hsi-wei said that this cooperation has until now been only seen in reports, adding that unless President Chen gives a clear idea to the script and roles of such cooperation, the public "need not dance to the tune of reports."
Chou's words came after a group of PFP supporters rallied at the Legislative Yuan the previous day, urging Soong not to tilt toward the DPP.

Huang Teh-fu, caucus whip of the Kuomintang (KMT) in the legislature, also said that the DPP is sounding out the public response by spreading reports about possible post-sharing with the PFP, which he said is an attempt to drive a wedge between the "pan-blue alliance" of the KMT and the PFP, and the KMT will no longer respond to such reports.
Saying that the KMT and the PFP have a solid base for cooperation, he said communications between the two parries are close, including those between KMT Chairman Lien Chan and PFP Chairman Soong.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CHEN VOWS TO UPHOLD 'THREE INSISTENCES'

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Wednesday that he and the ruling Democratic Progressive Party have made some changes in policies after the legislative elections in accordance with the opposition's advice, but he said that the "three insistences" that he has been talking about will remain firmly unchanged.

Chen told a group of Taiwanese civil engineers from North America at an audience at the Presidential Office that his insistence on the progress of Taiwan's democratic reforms, on making "Taiwan first" -- mainstream concept in the nation's diplomatic efforts -- and on shaping Taiwan into a wholesome, progressive and great country will never change under any circumstance.
Noting that Taiwan's per capita income was US$13,995 in 2004, Chen said that the figure hopefully will top US$15,000 this year should economic growth reach 4.65 percent as expected.
If the country tries even harder, per capita income may exceed US$15,000 for 2005 to mark a record all-time high, Chen added.

He told his guests that to sharpen Taiwan's international competitiveness, the government has designated the semiconductor manufacturing industry, image and display industry, as well as the telecommunications industry and services as the backbone of the country's industrial development, envisaging that all three sectors will churn out production worth over NT$1 trillion (US$30.86 billion) in the years ahead.

Under a national development plan, the semiconductor manufacturing industry posted production worth NT$1.58 trillion in 2004, constituting a whopping annual growth of 28.9 percent over the year-earlier level, Chen said.
He added that the image and display industry as well as the telecommunications industry and services are expected to reach the NT$1 trillion goal by the end of 2006 and 2008, respectively.

Chen reiterated that Taiwan's rising competitiveness in the international community and better performance on international scoreboards in recent years are the direct results of the government's strenuous efforts to push for reforms and bolster economic development.

DOC.HEADLINE: PFP DEMANDS FOR CABINET POSTS SHEER SPECULATION: MAYOR HSIEH

TEXT.P: Kaohsiung Mayor Frank Hsieh said Wednesday that reports about the opposition People First Party (PFP) asking the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) for a share of Cabinet posts are all speculation and may wreck possible cooperation between the two parties.
Hsieh made the remarks in Taipei where he was recording an album of his ocarina playing.

Noting that the DPP is communicating with the PFP on inter-party cooperation, Hseih said that the PFP has never proposed any post-sharing in the Cabinet, and there is no horse-trading going on between the two; all reports to that effect are wild speculation and could even possibly wreck future cooperation, Hsieh said.
He said that the pro-independence DPP and the pro-unification PFP have in the past attacked each other vehemently, and have no experience of cooperation.
He believed that supporters of the PFP can't accept such a partnership right now, and the DPP is now under tremendous pressure to explain the current state of affairs to their supporters.

"Everything will have to depend on whether the PFP is willing to play a key role in creating a new political landscape in Taiwan, " he said, referring to his perception that the public has grown tired of the continual bickering between the "pan-green camp" of the DPP and its ally, the Taiwan Solidarity Union, and the "pan-blue alliance" of the Kuomintang and the PFP.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The New York Times: Indonesia Puts Curbs on Relief in Rebel Areas.
The restrictions will enable the military to assert control over relief operations in the countryside, where the rebels are strongest.
Wall Street Journal: Intel Posts Jump In Sales of 10%, Gives Rosy Outlook.
Intel Corp. reported a 10% jump in fourth-quarter revenue, reflecting solid demand for technology products, though profit was 2% below the year- earlier period.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Moscow Times: Putin's Reforms Duma's Priority.
The State Duma, which reconvenes Wednesday after the holiday break, will delve into hundreds of bills, including steps to clamp down on terrorism, moonshine and nudity on television, but it will give priority to President Vladimir Putin's controversial political reforms, Speaker Boris Gryzlov said Tuesday.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. EXPRESSES SERIOUS CONCERN ABOUT ANTI-SECESSION LAW TO BEIJING
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Dec. 11 (CNA) (By Oliver Lin and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Senior U.S. officials have expressed grave concern to mainland China over its proposed anti-secession legislation, two visiting Taiwan lawmakers said Tuesday.
Legislators Sun Guo-hua of the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) and Hsieh Ming-yuan of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (PFP) made the remarks after meeting with U.S. State Department officials.

Sun and Hsieh quoted State Department officials as having told them that Deputy Secretary of State Richard Armitage and Deputy National Security Adviser Stephen Hadley had conveyed U.S. concern about Beijing's so-called anti-secession law while meeting with Chen Yunlin, director of mainland China's Taiwan Affairs Office, who visited Washington, D.C. last week.

According to State Department officials, both Armitage and Hadley told Chen that the proposed anti-secession law would only escalate cross-Taiwan Strait tension and be counterproductive to cross-strait relations. They also told Chen that Taiwan would not accept such legislation.
Chen did not bring with him the content of Beijing's proposed anti-secession law, the State Department officials were quoted as having said.

"State Department officials think Beijing's reluctance to divulge the text of its draft anti-secession law probably shows that the content has not been finalized and that the mainland authorities might revise certain clauses in terms of reactions from various quarters," Sun said.

Sun said the U.S. government is not expected to explicitly express its official stance on the anti-secession law until after the National People's Congress, mainland China's rubber-stamp parliament, formally passes the legislation.

"The U.S. officials also said they think the period of 2005 and 2006 is critical to cross-strait relations. They said they believe the period is a 'window of opportunity' for cross-strait ties. Neither side of the Taiwan Strait should miss this opportunity. They said the two sides should conduct 'quiet diplomacy' and hold direct, candid talks to resolve bilateral disputes," Sun said, adding that the United States is willing to assist in pushing for cross-strait dialogue, but the responsibility for realizing it rests with Taiwan and the mainland.
As for Taiwan's constitutional re-engineering plan, the State Department officials said they attach great importance to President Chen Shui-bian's "four noes" pledge.

"If Chen's administration upholds the 'four noes' promise, they said the U.S. government will tell Beijing that Taiwan's constitutional reform program will not have an adverse impact on cross-strait ties. As for Taiwan's plan to change its five-branch central government framework to a three-branch one, the U.S. officials said they have no opinion," Sun said.

According to Sun, the U.S. government is closely watching the developments in ongoing cross-strait talks about the launch of special direct cross-strait charter flights during the upcoming Lunar New Year holiday.

"The U.S. officials have also asked us about Taiwan's possible Cabinet reshuffle in the wake of the Dec. 11 legislative elections and expressed their hope that the legislature can approve the stalled budget bill for the NT$610.8 billion arms procurement package, " Sun said.

Sun and Hsieh visited Washington, D.C. and New York. In addition to meeting with State Department officials, they have also met with staff of Taiwan's representative offices in the two cities and scholars of major U.S. think tanks.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Times: Children face danger of mobile phones tumours.
Children under the age of eight should not use mobile phones, parents were advised last night after an authoritative report linked heavy use to ear and brain tumours and concluded that the risks had been underestimated by most scientists. Professor Sir William Stewart, chairman of the National Radiological Protection Board (NRPB), said that evidence of potentially harmful effects had become more persuasive over the past five years.
Financial Times: US, EU to talk on air subsidies.
The US and the European Union on Tuesday agreed to return to the negotiating table to curtail aid to Boeing and Airbus, calling a truce over the biggest dispute in the history of the World Trade Organisation. The two sides launched their trade dispute in October in an effort to end what each said were illegal subsidies to the world's two largest aircraft makers.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES DOWN ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market nosedived Wednesday, as Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index futures for January moved down 102 points to close at 5,901, with 38,093 contracts changing hands.

TAIEX Index futures for February dropped 112 points to finish at 5,900, with 3,253 contract transactions, while March futures decreased 115 points to close at 5,890, with 25 contracts traded. June futures moved down 55 points to finish at 5,920, with 13 contract transactions, while September futures dropped 100 points to close at 5,815, with 29 contracts traded.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Wednesday at 6,003 points for January, 6,012 points for February, 6,005 points for March, 5,975 points for June and 5,915 points for September.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were also lower.

January TE futures dropped 4.30 points to close at 217.6, with 3,980 contracts changing hands, while February TE futures moved down 3.95 points to finish at 217.85, with 312 contract transactions. March TE futures decreased 4.45 points to close at 216.50, with two contracts traded. No transactions were recorded for other months.

January TF futures moved down 21 points to finish at 1,009.4, with 4,328 contracts changing hands, while February TF futures dropped 18.8 points to close at 1,010, with 861 contracts traded. March TF futures decreased 21 points to finish at 1,006, with six contract transactions. June TF futures dropped 24 points to finish at 1,000.4, with one contract transaction, while September TF futures moved down 20.4 points to close at 1,000.2, with one contract traded.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. DOLLAR DOWN ON TAIPEI FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar moved down against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei foreign Exchange Wednesday, losing NT$0.094 to close at NT$32.028.
A total of US$553 million changed hands.
The greenback opened at the day's high of NT$32.170 and slid to a low of NT$31.976 during the trading session.

DOC.HEADLINE: FOREIGN WORKERS CALL FOR LENIENT, PRAGMATIC LABOR POLICY

TEXT.P: A group of around 40 foreign workers lodged a protest in front of the Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) Wednesday demanding lenient and pragmatic labor policies to prevent them from being deported before a management-labor dispute is settled.

The foreign workers, all of whom worked at a factory in Taipei County and have been laid off because the management suspended the factory's operations recently, said the CLA should revise the existing employment service law so as to bar employers and labor brokers from having the workers deported prior to the solution of management-labor disputes.

According to officials from the Taiwan International Workers Association, which accompanied the foreign workers at the protest, 125 foreign workers were put out of work with three months of salary unpaid by Fametech Electronic Co. after the company shut down its operations late last year.
The Fametech management agreed Jan. 3 to issue documents proving the closure of the company and to settle the outstanding salaries with the foreign workers.
However, the company has reneged on its promise, leaving the 125 foreign workers in limbo, with no documents to prove the company's closure and their legal departure date, nor their due salaries.
Without such papers, the workers said, they cannot seek other employment in Taiwan.
According to the existing employment services law, the foreign workers will be deported if they leave their first employment but fail to obtain a second job in 14 days.
Wu Ching-ju, director-general of the Taiwan International Workers Association, said that the 125 workers represent only one of many similar cases around Taiwan.

In the past, Wu said, many foreign workers who have been victims of physical abuse by their Taiwan employers, of workplace accidents, or have not been paid, have been deported before their disputes were settled.
Wu suggested that Taiwan companies or labor brokers who have illegally had foreign workers deported before disputes were solved be dealt with under the law, including having their licenses revoked.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES DOWN ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Shares prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) opened low and closed even lower Wednesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving down 96.58 points to close at 5,879.08.

The bourse opened at 5,957.9 points and fluctuated between 5,978.41 and 5,878.39 during trading. A total of 2.90 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$51.74 billion (US$1.63 billion).

All eight major stock categories lost ground, with construction stocks moving down the most by 4.4 percent, followed by textile shares by 2.4 percent, foodstuff issues by 2.1 percent, machinery and electronics, as well as paper and pulp shares by 1.9 percent, banking and financial stocks by 1.7 percent, cement shares by 1.6 percent, and plastics and chemicals issues by 0.2 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 733 to 69, with 90 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEGOTIATION PROBLEM WILL NOT BLOCK CHARTER FLIGHTS: CABINET OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: Differences between Taiwan and mainland China on the participants of Lunar New Year charter flight negotiations can be resolved through consultations, Executive Yuan spokesman Chen Chi-mai said Wednesday.

Chen said the problem is not going to impede the launch of the services since both sides have reached a high degree of consensus on the major principle of facilitating jointly operated two-way, non-stop flights across the Taiwan Strait during the holiday period.
Chen said he believes the flights will be successfully operated if both sides conduct the negotiations pragmatically.

In what has been hailed by Taiwan as a breakthrough in the charter flight arrangements, Taipei Airlines Association head Michael Lo, with the authorization of the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) , held talks with China Civil Aviation Association (CCAA) Executive Director Pu Zhaozhou in Macau last week and came to an agreement on principle.

The MAC has proposed that follow-up talks be carried out according to the model of the 2002 Taiwan-Hong Kong aviation talks, in which MAC and Civil Aeronautics Administration (CAA) officials took part in their capacities as advisers to the TAA.

However, He Shizhong, director of the Economics Bureau of the mainland's Taiwan Affairs Office, said Wednesday that it would be "inappropriate, impractical and insincere" to suggest that officials from the MAC and Straits Exchange Foundation take part in the talks.
He stopped short of saying whether CAA officials can take part in the negotiations.

He also proposed that in addition to Shanghai on the mainland and Taipei and Kaohsiung in Taiwan, the destinations of the charter flights be expanded to include Beijing, Guangzhou and Xiamen on the mainland and Taichung in Taiwan.

Reports said that potential CAA participants in the negotiations include CAA Director-General Billy K.C. Chang, who is an adviser to TAA, and Deputy Director-General Lee Chung-jung, who visited the mainland last year for exchange activities in his capacity as an adviser to the Air Traffic Controller's Association.
Both Chang and Lee said Wednesday they had no idea as to whether the MAC plans to have CAA officials take part in the negotiations.

DOC.HEADLINE: CONTROL YUAN CENSURES JUSTICE, INTERIOR MINISTRIES

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Justice and the Ministry of the Interior were censured Wednesday by the Control Yuan, the nation's highest watchdog body, for refusing to brief a commission formed to look into the March 19 shooting of President Chen Shui-bian.

Three members of the Control Yuan -- Lin Chiu-shan, Lin Chiang-tsai, and Lai Chien-nan -- jointly proposed to censure the Tainan Prosecutor's Office under the Ministry of Justice and the Criminal Investigation Bureau under the Ministry of the Interior.
The trio said that the commission, which was formed based on a "319 shooting investigation commission" statute that passed the legislature and was promulgated by President Chen Shui-bian.

Before the Council of Grand Justices issued its ruling on a request by the ruling Democratic Progressive Party for an interpretation of the constitutionality of the statute last year, all government agencies should have observed and implemented the law, and it was inappropriate for the Criminal Investigation Bureau to refuse to brief the commission members on its investigation of the case.

The Council of Grand Justices declared Dec. 15 that parts of Article 8 and Article 13 of the Organic Statute for the Truth Investigation Commission were unconstitutional and that they therefore ceased to be effective from the day the interpretation was handed down.

The three Control Yuan members said that prior to the ruling, the Executive Yuan and the agencies under its jurisdiction were all bound by the statute and that the Tainan Prosector's Office and the Criminal Investigation Bureau should have worked in accordance with the statute and briefed the commission.

The members also said that it was inappropriate for Interior Affairs Minister Su Jia-chyuan to say publicly Oct. 8 and Oct. 13 in the Legislative Yuan that public functionaries should have the right to refuse to cooperate with the commission.

The March 19 shooting took place in Tainan, southern Taiwan, when the president was aboard an open-topped jeep during a last-minute vote-canvassing rally. The opposition "pan-blue alliance" of the Kuomintang and the People First Party have claimed that the incident was a political scheme to win sympathy votes in the bitterly contested presidential election, although they have produced no evidence whatsoever to support their allegation.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
Washington, Jan. 12 (CAN) The Washington Post: Nominee Criticized Over Post-9/11 Policies.
Michael Chertoff, President Bush's nominee to be secretary of homeland security, is widely hailed for his intellectual heft and tireless work habits as a federal prosecutor and judge. But he also faces criticism as an architect of some of the most controversial elements of the Bush administration's domestic war on terrorism that followed the Sept. 11, 2001, attacks, the paper said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN CAPABLE OF TREATING 3 BROTHERS WITH RARE DISORDER: DOH

TEXT.P: The nation's top health official said Wednesday that a medial team at National Taiwan University Hospital is capable of treating three brothers suffering from a rare disorder called adrenoleukodystrophy (ALD).

Department of Health Minister Chen Chien-jen was responding to questions by Legislator Chiang Chi-wen of the opposition Kuomintang about the conditions of the three brothers from Kaohsiung, southern Taiwan.

Chiang said that Chang Ming-hui, the father of the three brothers, faced tremendous pressure about the legality of donations and tax issues after the public gave an enthusiastic response to his call for financial help to pay for his eldest son's treatment in the United States and donated a staggering NT$72 million (US$2.25 million) in just a few days. Chang's decision to seek treatment in the United States also shows a distrust of domestic medical standards, she added.
Chen pointed out that patients and their families have every right to choose medical treatment as they see fit, but said it is necessary to set up a better system for regulating donations.

Chen said that he will instruct Bureau of National Health Insurance to contact the Chang family to inform them of the latest developments in medical care in Taiwan and to discuss the pros and cons of the issue, but "will respect the decisions of the family."
Meanwhile, Chang Ming-hui confirmed Wednesday that the family will leave Taiwan Jan. 19 for the United States and is expected to stay there for between six months and one year.

Chang, an official with the Kaohsiung City Government in charge of laws and regulations, said that the operations and post-surgery care will take between three and six months, with a further six months for follow-up treatment, and that they will decide upon the date of their return only after seeing the progress of the three brothers.

Chang had originally hoped to take only the eldest son, 13-year-old Po-chun, to the United States for treatment, but the phenomenal amount of donations has enabled them to also take his two younger brothers.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT PLEDGES TO PROTECT OPPORTUNITIES FOR LOCAL ENTERTAINERS

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian ordered the Government Information Office (GIO) and related authorities Wednesday to study measures to protect the opportunities for local entertainers.

Chen issued the directive while receiving members of the Taiwan Culture and Performance Arts Association led by Yu Tien. GIO Director-General Lin Chia-lung and Council of Labor Affairs Chairwoman Chen Chu were also present at the meeting.
Chen said show business is an important part of the entertainment industry and is also the fundamental of the country's cultural and creative industry.

As the Taiwanese identity is being emphasized today, the voice of every performer should be appreciated, listened to and taken seriously because each performer represents an irreplaceable opinion in Taiwan's diverse society, according to Chen.
He noted that Taiwan's show business has developed under a historical background that is different to that of Hong Kong, mainland China, Japan and South Korea.
Therefore, he said, Taiwan cannot follow the successful experience of other countries and must tailor a favorable environment for itself.
Yu said both the quantity and quality of Taiwan movies, for example, have declined because of a lack of capital and he urged the government to help revitalize Taiwan's show business.

DOC.HEADLINE: PFP HEAD POSTPONES RETURN FROM U.S. AMID SPECULATION ABOUT DPP TIES
DOC.DATELINE: San Francisco, Jan. 11 (CNA) (By Chiang Ying and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Opposition People First Party (PFP) Chairman James Soong has decided to stay in the United States for one more week for "soul searching" amid speculation about the possibility of the PFP cooperating with the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), one of his friends said Tuesday.
Soong was originally scheduled to leave San Francisco for home Tuesday, but his friend said Soong had postponed his departure until Jan. 18.

Speculation about the formation of a seemingly unlikely PFP-DPP partnership has been rife since last December's legislative elections in which the DPP and its traditional "pan-green" ally, the Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) , failed to win a majority in the new Legislative Yuan to be inaugurated Feb. 1. Speculation about the PFP cooperating with the DPP in the Feb. 1 elections for legislative speaker and deputy speaker, or that Soong might serve as next premier, has been flying for days.
Soong has kept his distance from San Francisco Chinese-language news media and has ordered the PFP headquarters in Taipei to clarify the rumors instead.

His friend, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said the proposal of Soong serving as premier might offer him an opportunity to stage a political comeback. Nevertheless, such an offer could also make Soong the target of broadsides from core supporters of the "pan-blue alliance" of the PFP and the Kuomintang (KMT).

In Taiwan's political spectrum, the DPP and the PFP are at opposite ends, with the DPP leaning toward Taiwan independence and the PFP looking forward to eventual unification of the two sides of the Taiwan Strait.

Even though no concrete DPP-PFP cooperative projects have ever been confirmed, many "pan-blue alliance" supporters residing on the U.S. west coast have voiced strong opposition to any DPP-PFP ties in local call-in TV talk shows. They have almost unanimously urged the PFP -- originally a splinter group from the KMT -- to merge with the KMT as soon as possible.

Soong, a former Taiwan provincial governor who also once served as KMT secretary-general, narrowly lost a presidential bid in 2000 when he ran as an independent. He served as running mate of KMT Chairman Lien Chan in the 2004 presidential election and lost again. His ties with Lien and the KMT soured in the run-up to the Dec. 11 legislative elections over a combination of issues.

As the PFP will have 34 seats in the new legislature, DPP heavyweights, including acting DPP Chairman Ker Chien-ming and Kaohsiung Mayor Frank Hsieh, have reportedly been seeking to forge a partnership with the PFP to facilitate its reform agenda. The DPP and the TSU will jointly control 101 seats in the new legislature. Should the DPP manage to forge a coalition, it would control a working majority in the 225-seat legislature.

To the best of his knowledge, Soong's friend said, Soong is still contemplating his own political future as well as the PFP's development prospects. Against this backdrop, he said, Soong has decided to postpone his return to Taipei for a week or so.

In Taipei, Presidential Office Secretary-General Su Tseng-chang, who will soon become the new DPP chairman, noted that President Chen Shui-bian pledged in his New Year Day address to promote inter-party reconciliation and unify the "fractured country."

In line with the president's declaration, Su said, the DPP has been striving to forge rapprochement with the opposition parties, not only the PFP but also the KMT, which will have 79 seats in the new legislature.

Noting that politics is the "art of possibility, " Su said he hopes the DPP will be able to develop a viable working partnership with the opposition camp to kick-start many long-stalled reform projects and policy initiatives.

Earlier in the day, acting Ker said that whether a DPP-PFP partnership will become reality will hinge on Soong's decision. "Soong holds the key to the prospect of inter-party reconciliation and social harmony," Ker said, adding that a majority of local people are fed up with the inter-party wrangling and bickering.
Menawhile, Kaohsiung Mayor Frank Hsieh said he is worried that wild speculation about power-sharing or horse-trading could wreck possible DPP-PFP cooperation.

While the two parties are fostering communciation channels, Hsieh said neither side has ever proposed any power-sharing deals. Hsieh echoed Ker's view, saying that whether the two parties can succeed in forging a partnership will pin on the PFP's willingness to assist in creating a new political horizon in Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: NO TIMETABLE FOR NAPHTHA CRACKER PLANTS

TEXT.P: The issue of allowing Taiwan petrochemical companies to set up naphtha crackers in mainland China is a complex issue that needs in-depth negotiations and the government has not yet ironed out a timetable for such an opening, Minister of Economic Affairs Ho Mei-yueh said Wednesday.

Ho made the remarks while answering questions from reporters amid rampant speculation that the Formosa Plastics Group (FPG) has been preparing to set up on the mainland as soon as government policy allows. FPG is Taiwan's largest petrochemical company.

She said that her ministry is still exchanging views with other government agencies on the issue and pointed out that one condition must be heeded -- that such a go-ahead policy will not affect potential investment in other sectors at home.
For the time being, no timetable has been decided, nor has a decision been made on the number of companies that will be allowed to go to the mainland, she added.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEARLY 500 FOREST FIRES, INCIDENTS FOR 2003: DGBAS

TEXT.P: A total of 491 forest fires, cases of illegal logging and excessive cultivation in mountainous areas were reported in 2003 across the country, according to recent government statistics.

Tallies compiled by the Cabinet-level Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS) show that the figure represents a new high in nearly five years, with 291 cases of illegal logging and excessive cultivation in soil conservation areas making up the bulk.

In terms of the sizes of damaged areas, fires caused the largest amount of damage to forestry areas, DGBAS officials pointed out, adding that 2,440 and 4,352 hectares of forest was destroyed in 1999 and 2000, respectively.

In an effort to protect the country's natural environment, slope land and mountainous areas, the government has since 1996 advocated forestation by the private sector, the officials said, adding that from 2001, about 33,000 hectares of forest has been restored.

Although some 60 percent of Taiwan's territory is covered by forest, the officials said the scale of the country's forestry industry remains some way short of commercial production and that illegal logging must be stopped to guarantee a sustainable growth of nature and varied ecosystems.

As revenue generated by the forestry industry has been decreasing each year, the government is seeking to promote recreational businesses in forestal areas, they said, adding that the annual income from such establishments run by the Taiwan Forestry Bureau under the Cabinet-level Council of Agriculture grew to a new high of NT$580 million (US$18 million) in 2003 -- double the 1991 level.

The Cabinet-level Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) said that in the wake of the Dec. 26 earthquake and tsunami that hit countries in South Asia and Southeast Asia that it will swiftly put forth a draft bill governing the protection and restoration of national territory to the Legislative Yuan.

The bill calls for adequate measures to protect slope land, river systems, coastal and sinkage areas, a CEPD official said, citing the great importance of protecting the natural environment as the key for the country's sustainable development.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAINLAND CHINA'S RISE DOES NOT MEAN TAIWAN'S DOOM: LAWMAKER

TEXT.P: Mainland China's rise as an economic powerhouse does not necessarily spell Taiwan's doom, opposition People First Party Legislator Liu Yi-ju claimed Wednesday.
Liu said many Taiwan people have become pessimistic about Taiwan's future since the mainland has emerged as an economic powerhouse with much-faster-than-world-average annual economic growth.

"Such doomsday thinking is not correct. China's economic success does not necessarily mean that Taiwan's future is hopeless. Our nation's future hinges on our people's confidence, " Liu said while attending a ceremony to mark the launch of a new book on securities investment by a stock market analyst.
Liu, an economist-turned-lawmaker, said Taiwan's vitality lies in its people, who are known for their diligence and entrepreneurship.
Liu said she is convinced that so long as Taiwan's people maintain their confidence, Taiwan will definitely have a bright future regardless of whether the mainland is an economic powerhouse or not.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI CITY HOSPITAL HEAD LOSES CITY HEALTH DEPARTMENT POST

TEXT.P: Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou announced Wednesday that Chang Hang, director of the city's Department of Health and concurrently the superintendent of Taipei City Hospital, will lose his health department post, effective Feb. 1.

Ma made the remarks amid public uproar over an incident a day earlier in which an unconscious four-year-old girl who had been badly beaten by her drunk father was refused admittance to Taipei City Hospital's Jen Ai branch and no other city hospital would admit her because of no beds or necessary facilities. She was eventually taken by ambulance nearly 200 km to Taichung for treatment early Tuesday, where emergency surgery was performed. The child was later reported to be close to death.
Ma said that Chang's vacancy will be temporarily filled by his deputy, Teng Su-wen.

According to Ma, Chang is not stepping down, but is only undergoing an "adjustment of work" that will allow him to target the deficiencies in the 12 branches of Taipei City hospital and make the necessary reforms.

Ma said that Chang had reported to him that the incident was due mainly to a neurosurgeon who was supposed to have been on duty but who did not return to the hospital to see the patient, which Ma said is an issue involving discipline and medical ethics and is not a result of the Taipei emergency medical care system going wrong.
Ma expressed hope that reforms can be made in the medical care system, especially the number of beds available, which is frequently the butt of public criticism.

Doctors at the emergency room of the Jen Ai hospital reported that because there were no available beds at the hospital, while the 23 other hospitals in Taipei they contacted had either no beds or lacked the necessary facilities, they had to transfer the patient to a major hospital in Wuchi, Taichung County, which they claimed was in the best interests of the patient. Jen Ai Hospital also called Taipei Emergency Operations Center for assistance.

DOC.HEADLINE: MALAWI KEEN TO LEARN ABOUT TAIWAN'S AGRICULTURAL DEVELOPMENT

TEXT.P: Visiting Malawi President Bingu Wa Mutharika said Wednesday that his country is looking forward to learning from Taiwan's experience in developing agriculture.

Mutharik made the remarks while touring the Taoyuan District Agricultural Improvement Station (TDAIS) , an institute for agricultural research and development under the Cabinet-level Council of Agriculture.

Accompanied by officials from the Ministry of Foreign Affairs and TDAIS experts, Mutharik toured several greenhouses used for organic vegetables and flower cultivation, which greatly impressed the Malawi head of state.
Mutharik showed great interest in Taiwan's agricultural development and exchanged views with TADIS experts on how to set up greenhouses to cultivate quality plants.
Mutharik arrived in Taipei Monday at the invitation of the government for a five-day state visit aimed at boosting substantive exchanges between the two countries.

Mutharik has also met with President Chen Shui-bian to exchange viewpoints on issues of mutual concern and was decorated by his ROC counterpart in recognition of his untiring efforts to promote bilateral relations.

DOC.HEADLINE: CAL CITIED AS OUTSTANDING PERFORMER BY PHILIPPINES TAX AGENCY
DOC.DATELINE: Manila, Jan. 12 (CNA) (By Flor Wang and Emerson Lin)

TEXT.P: China Airlines (CAL) -- Taiwan's largest carrier -- has been cited by the Philippines Bureau of Internal Revenue (BIR) for its outstanding performance as a taxpayer.
During a recent ceremony, CAL Manila Branch General Manager Yu Chih received the citation from the BIR on behalf of the Taipei-headquartered aviation company.
CAL paid more than 90 million pesos (US$16.6 million) to the BIR in tax last year, making it the sixth-largest taxpayer in the BIR's Comprehensive Tax Reform Program.

DOC.HEADLINE: DOH TO INVEST NT$6 BILLION IN FLU VACCINE PRODUCTION

TEXT.P: The Cabinet-level Department of Health (DOH) will invest NT$6 billion in developing and producing influenza vaccines, a DOH official said Wednesday.

Speaking at a Legislative Yuan science and technology committee meeting, Hsu Hsu-mei, a DOH official in charge of scientific development affairs, said that according a World Health Organization assessment, about 1.2 billion people around the world are highly susceptible to influenza, but the global flu vaccine supply was only 263 million doses in 2002.
In view of a possible flu vaccine shortage, Hsu said, the DOH has come up with a self-sufficiency plan to address the situation.

According to the plan, the government will invest NT$6 billion in developing new vaccine production know-how and building a production facility to ensure a full supply of flu vaccine to meet domestic demand.

Initially, Hsu said, the DOH will spend NT$600 million developing new flu vaccine production technology over a three-year period. The production facility will be able to produce 20 million doses of flu vaccine.

The project has received the approval of the Council for Economic PLanning and Development, Hsu said, adding that an inter-department 13-member flu vaccine promotion task force will hold its first meeting Jan. 17 to work out strategies for realizing the plan as soon as possible. Kuo Hsu-sung, director of the DOH's Center for Disease Control, will serve as the task force's convener and the task force members will include six medical experts and scholars.

DOC.HEADLINE: 46,000 MIXED-RACE CHILDREN STUDYING AT LOCAL SCHOOLS: MOE

TEXT.P: A total of 46,000 children born to interracial couples are studying at elementary and junior high schools in Taiwan, the Ministry of Education (MOE) said Wednesday.
According to MOE tallies, 5,500 mixed-race children have been enrolled into junior high schools around the island and 40,500 mixed-race children are studying at elementary schools.

Six of the top 10 junior high schools in terms of mixed-race enrollments are located in Taipei County, which is also the island's most populous administrative district. Three are in Taoyuan County and one is in Taipei City.
Taipei County also has four elementary schools ranking among the top 10, Taoyuan County has two and one each is located in Kaohsiung City, Taipei City, Hsinchu County and Pingtung County.

MOE officials said the ministry will conduct an in-depth survey into those children's adaptability and study the situation in terms of the MOE tallies before drawing up package of measures to help them with their academic studies and social adaptability.

DOC.HEADLINE: COA TO EARMARK NT$100 MILLION FOR FACTORY IN PINGTUNG BIOTECH PARK

TEXT.P: Premier Yu Shyi-kun instructed the Cabinet-level Council of Agriculture (COA) Wednesday to earmark NT$100 million (US$3.1 million) to help investors set up standardized production facilities in the Pingtung Agricultural Biotechnology Park (PABP).
Yu issued the instruction after hearing a report concerning the establishment of agricultural biotechnology parks in the country delivered by a COA official during a financial and economic meeting.

The premier also asked the COA to assist local governments in developing the country's four other agricultural biotechnology parks so that the annual production value of Taiwan's agricultural biotechnology sector can hit the targeted NT$29 billion as soon as possible.

Noting that the PABP was the first agricultural technology park to be initiated by the central government, Yu said that since the inauguration of the park's preparatory office in October 2003, many manufacturers have expressed willingness to set up production facilities there.
If everything goes smoothly, several investors will be given the green light to start their plant construction projects in the park in March, Yu added.

DOC.HEADLINE: FREE TRADE ZONE AT KAOHSIUNG PORT SEEKING GREATER INVESTMENT

TEXT.P: The free trade zone at the southern port of Kaohsiung began operations on the first of this year and its administrator is keen on luring more investment to expand the port's role, officials said Wednesday.

The Kaohsiung Harbor Bureau has been courting more investment after the port gained approval from the Ministry of Transportation and Communications to run a distribution center, according to bureau officials.
Meanwhile, Yangming Marine Transport Corp. has leased a three-hectare lot behind the port's third container center, with plans to make it into a distribution hub, they said.

As 14 shipping and various warehousing companies are already operating in the port, the bureau hopes to help them turn into businesses exclusively compatible with the free trade zone in its initial development stage, they said, adding that three of them have already applied to join the plan.
Some other bureau officials have already forecast that Kaohsiung Port -- Taiwan's largest -- will enjoy more lucrative business with the start of its free trade zone operations.

Shipping firms using the Kaohsiung Port Free Trade Zone, in which goods, personnel and capital are allowed to move freely, will see their operating costs and tax rates go down, while they will also enjoy more speedy customs clearance, they said.

They estimated that more than NT$60 million (US$1.8 million) worth of red tape will be cut each year and that an extra 5 million tons of cargo can be handled by the harbor, bringing in business worth over NT$150 million and creating more than 400 jobs.
Kaohsiung Harbor dealt with 9.7 million containers in 2004 and it is expected to break the 10 million mark for this year.
Kaohsiung Harbor, along with northern Taiwan's Keelung Harbor, are the country's first two ports authorized by the central government to run free trade zones.
Kaohsiung Harbor is designated as a transshipment center between Taiwan and mainland China before full direct trade, transport and postal links are set up between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait.
Keelung Harbor -- Taiwan's second-largest port -- began free trade business in September last year.

Meanwhile, Taichung Harbor in central Taiwan and various economic processing and industrial zones across the country are waiting for government final permission to set up free trade zones, part of the government's drive to make Taiwan into a business operations hub in the Asia-Pacific region.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER TAIWAN MAC CHAIRWOMAN ARRIVES IN WASHINGTON

TEXT.P: Tsai Ing-wen, former chairwoman of Taiwan's Mainland Affairs Council (MAC), arrived in Washington, D.C. Tuesday to exchange views with U.S. officials and think tank experts on relations between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait and other issues of mutual concern.

Tsai, who is also a newly elected legislator-at-large of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), will attend a closed-door symposium to be held by the Brookings Institution Wednesday, during which she will discuss with U.S. officials Beijing's plan to enact an anti-secession law targeting Taiwan.

Tsai's arrival followed the departure of Chen Yunlin, director of the Taiwan Affairs Office under Beijing's State Council, who had just made a six-day visit to the United States to discuss with U.S. officials the planned anti-secession law.

About one month ago, Taiwan's Vice National Defense Minister Tsai Ming-hsien and DPP Deputy Secretary-General Lee Ying-yuan also planned to take part in a seminar on the future of Taiwan at the Brookings Institution's invitation, but they canceled the trip when the think tank canceled the symposium.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN RAISES NT$600 MILLION FOR TSUNAMI VICTIMS

TEXT.P: The public and private sectors in Taiwan have raised NT$600 million (US$18.82 million) in cash and 169 tons of relief materials for victims of the Dec. 26 tsunami in the Indian Ocean so far, a spokesman for the Ministry of Foreign Affairs said Wednesday.

Michel Lu said the Foreign Ministry will ask related government agencies to ship the materials, especially food that must be consumed before its expiration date, to the disaster zones as soon as possible.

He made the comment after the media expressed concern that medicine and food donated to the tsunami victims could be spoiled before they can be delivered unless the government speeds up its pace of shipping them to the victims.
Lu said the 169 tons of materials stored in a warehouse in Taoyuan include 60 tons of food, 30 tons of medical supplies, eight tons of sterilization equipment and 60 tons of daily necessities.
He said China Airlines will deliver two batches of materials weighing 20 tons and 15 tons, respectively to Indonesia Thursday and Saturday, with the food being given the top priority.

Meanwhile, Lu said, Sri Lanka has appealed to Taiwan for aid in the form of rice and the Foreign Ministry has asked the Taiwan Root Medical Peace Corps to ship 24 containers of rice to the country Jan. 20.
Of the 24 containers, 20 will contain uncooked rice and four will contain cooked rice stored in airtight bags.
Thailand has asked for 4,000 prefabricated housing units, Lu said, and the Foreign Ministry is contemplating providing 300 to 500 units.
In addition to relief materials, Lu said, Taiwan has sent 376 medical workers to the disaster areas.

In a related development Wednesday, more than 10 firms in the Taoyuan Industrial Zone in Taoyuan County donated NT$1.37 million in cash to the tsunami victims. Many of the donations came from foreign laborers who come from the tsunami-stricken countries.

National Taipei University in Taipei City held a charity bazaar Wednesday for the tsunami victims. A total of about 10 tons of oranges produced in Yunlin, central Taiwan were sold out in half an hour with a turnover of NT$106,000.
The charity bazaar was welcomed by orange growers because it helped dispose of some of their oranges, the price of which has been driven to a record low because of overproduction.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER PRESIDENT CALLS FOR FORMATION OF TAIWANESE CULTURE

TEXT.P: Taiwan should form a unique culture based on the culture of the indigenous people combined with those of the Hoklo, Hakka, the Japanese who ruled the island between 1895 and 1945 and the Chinese who moved to Taiwan after the Second World War, former President Lee Teng-hui said Wednesday.

Giving a speech at a seminar on the future of Taiwan's cultural development against the backdrop of globalization, the former president said Taiwan should shed its Chinese culture "which is nothing but a reincarnation" and is therefore "terrible."

Citing the words of Taiwanese centenarian calligrapher Chen Yun-cheng that "every place in Taiwan is beautiful during the spring and Taiwan's culture is refreshing every day," Lee said Taiwan should draw on the international community rather than China for nourishment of its culture.

Some people in Taiwan stress the importance of Chinese culture, but "we don't know what Chinese culture they are talking about, " Lee claimed, adding that Chinese culture has no new ingredients despite its long history.

Lee said the opposition Kuomintang (KMT), which ruled the island for five decades before losing power to the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), tried to implant Chinese culture into Taiwan, a move he described as dangerous because, he claimed, it makes Taiwanese identify with Chinese culture and more ready to embrace the culture shaped by the Chinese communists.

Now that the KMT has been deposed, it is very clear that the DPP administration should instill a Taiwanese mentality, including the history and geography of the country, into the Taiwan people, Lee went on.

Taiwan, which has been ruled by outsiders for the last 400 years, has never established its own identity. Now, Lee said, it is time for the island to form a culture of its own that is a vital part of its identity.

DOC.HEADLINE: CAA CHIEF CANCELS EUROPE TRIP AHEAD OF CHARTER FLIGHT TALKS

TEXT.P: Civil Aeronautics Administration (CAA) Director-General Billy K.C. Chang canceled a trip to Europe Wednesday amid reports that he might be asked to participate in forthcoming cross-Taiwan Strait negotiations over the launch of special charter flights during the Lunar New Year holiday.
Chang was originally scheduled to head for Holland via a China Airlines flight Wednesday to start a European market-survey tour.

Meanwhile, Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Vice Chairman Chiu Tai-san said the government had yet to decide on who will join the delegation to negotiate terms with mainland China for the holiday charter flights.

Noting that relevant government agencies must be allowed to participate in negotiations on issues regarding the exercise of public authority, Chiu said the makeup of the delegation cannot be determined until after Beijing comes up with a list of topics to be discussed.
Chiu said the Taipei Airlines Association (TAA) , a private organization authorized to negotiate holiday charter flights with the mainland, has not yet received any Beijing-proposed agenda.

Beijing officials said earlier in the day that officials from the MAC, which charts Taiwan's policy toward the mainland, and Taiwan's quasi-official Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF), should not be part of the delegation. In response, Chiu said the selection of members of the delegation will depend on the topics to be discussed. "We hope the mainland can determine the agenda as soon as possible to facilitate follow-up arrangements," Chiu said.
He also urged the mainland to uphold its previous promise and conduct charter flight talks in line with the principles of mutual respect and pragmatism.
Cabinet spokesman Chen Chi-mai also said that differences between Taiwan and the mainland on the participants in the talks can be resolved through consultations.
He said the problem is not going to impede the launch of the charter flight services, since both sides have reached a high degree of consensus on the major principles regarding the flights.
Chen said he believes the flights will be successfully operated if both sides conduct the negotiations pragmatically.

In what has been hailed by Taiwan as a breakthrough in the charter flight arrangements, Taipei Airlines Association head Michael Lo, with the MAC authorization, held talks with China Civil Aviation Association (CCAA) Executive Director Pu Zhaozhou in Macau last week and came to an initial agreement in principle.

The MAC has proposed that follow-up talks be carried out according to the model of the 2002 Taiwan-Hong Kong aviation talks, in which MAC and CAA officials took part in their capacities as TAA advisers.

However, He Shizhong, director of the Economics Bureau of the mainland's Taiwan Affairs Office, said Wednesday that it would be "inappropriate, impractical and insincere" to suggest that officials from the MAC and SEF take part in the talks. He stopped short of saying whether CAA officials can take part in the negotiations.

DOC.HEADLINE: EARTHQUAKE ROCKS CENTRAL TAIWAN

TEXT.P: An earthquake with a preliminary magnitude of 4.7 on the Richter scale rocked central Taiwan Wednesday. No casualties were reported.
Central Weather Bureau officials said that the epicenter of the quake was located 26.5 km southeast of the Yuchi seismic station in Nantou County and 9.8 km below the earth's surface.

The quake, which occurred at 9:30 p.m., had an intensity of 3.0 in Minchien, Nantou County; 2.0 in Touliu and Tsaoling in Yunlin County, Changhua City and eastern Hualien City; and 1.0 in Alishan, Chiayi County, Yuanlin of Changhua County, Taichung City, Techi in Taichung County and Chiayi City.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN MIGHT FREEZE IMPORTS OF VIETNAMESE LABORERS: LABOR CHIEF

TEXT.P: Taiwan might have to stop bringing in laborers from Vietnam if the Vietnamese government cannot help bring down the number of Vietnamese workers who abscond from their Taiwan posts, Council of Labor Affairs Chairwoman Chen Chu said Wednesday.

Noting that a Vietnamese labor official who visited Taiwan in December pledged to track down and send back to Vietnam at least 2,000 absconded Vietnamese workers by the end of December, Chen said that if the number of workers actually repatriated is too far from what was promised, further imports of Vietnamese workers might have to be suspended.

Chen said the Vietnamese authorities have asked for more time to track down the unaccounted for workers and have been given three extra months to meet their promise, but she added that Taiwan's patience is wearing thin.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TO PARTICIPATE IN AUSTRALIAN YOUTH OLYMPIC FESTIVAL

TEXT.P: An 89-member delegation from Taiwan organized by the Chinese Taipei Olympic Committee (CTOC) will head for Sydney Jan. 16 for the 2005 Australian Youth Olympic Festival, according to a press release issued by the CTOC Wednesday.

The delegation, to be headed by CTOC Vice Chairman Tsai Tsi-chue, will compete against 1,500 athletes from 30 countries in the festival, which is slated to take place Jan. 19-23, said the press release.

The biennial event for athletes aged from 14 to 19 from Australia and Oceania region features 14 sports and the Taiwan athletes will take part in five, including archery, judo, gymnastics, volleyball and weightlifting.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Thursday, Jan. 13, or the fourth day of the 12th month of the Year of the Monkey according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1813: The British fleet blockades Chesapeake and Delaware Bays in the United States during the War of 1812.
1893: James Keir Hardie forms the British Labour Party, an alliance of the British trade union and socialist movement.
1915: A major earthquake hits central Italy, killing 2,950 people.
1934: Nationalist government forces capture Foochow, Fukien province, dissolving the so-called "People's Revolutionary Government."
1946: The United Nations Security Council is created, with China as one of its five permanent members.
1967: President Chiang Kai-shek appoints Henry Kao as mayor of the Special Municipality of Taipei.
1967: Four Chinese Air Force planes shoot down two mainland Chinese MIG-19s over waters northeast of Kinmen (Quemoy).
1969: The Diver, a U.S. nuclear submarine, enters Yokosuka, a Japanese naval base, despite protests from Japanese leftist elements.
1972: The Republic of China severs diplomatic relations with the Republic of Cyprus.
1974: Wong Yi-ting, director of the Board of Foreign Trade, Ministry of Economic Affairs, leaves for Bangkok to discuss the purchase of maize.
1974: The world's largest airport is opened in Dallas, Texas.
1975: The International Symposium on Nuclear Power Technology and Economics opens in Taipei.
1976: President Yen Chia-kan receives Mohammed Toukan, the mayor of Amman, Jordan.
1976: Britain applies for credit of nearly one billion pounds from the International Monetary Fund.
1978: Hubert Horatio Humphrey, vice president of the United States under Lyndon Johnson, dies at the age of 67.
1982: An Air Florida jet plunges into the frozen Potomac River near the White House, killing 78 people.
1988: President Chiang Ching-kuo passes away of heart failure and hemorrhaging at the age of 79.
1988: Vice President Lee Teng-hui is sworn in as president of the Republic of China to complete the late President Chiang's second six-year term, which spans from 1984 to 1990.
1989: British computers are hit by a virus called "Friday the 13th."
1991: Soviet troops crack down on the Lithuanian pro-independence movement in Vilnius, killing at least 13 demonstrators.
1993: Erich Honecker, former East German leader, leaves a Berlin prison and flies to Chile after a court freed him because he is dying.
1994: Premier Carlos Ciampi of Italy resigns.
1999: Brazil throws world financial markets into turmoil with a surprise 8 percent devaluation of its currency.
2000: The 130th and last of the locally developed Ching-kuo Indigenous Defense Fighters rolls off the assembly line.
2001: The 31st Congress of the World League for Freedom and Democracy approves the nomination of Yao Eng-chi, president of the organization's ROC chapter, as president of the worldwide group.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "While his parents are living, a son should not go far abroad; if he does, he should let them know where he goes. A son should always keep in mind the age of his parents, as a matter for thankfulness as well as for anxiety."

DOC.HEADLINE: PFP CHAIRMAN NOT IN WASHINGTON, D.C.: PAN-BLUE OFFICE IN U.S.
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Jan. 12 (CNA) (By Oliver Lin and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: The representative office of Taiwan's opposition "pan-blue alliance" of the Kuomintang (KMT) and the People First Party (PFP) in the United States said Wednesday that PFP Chairman James Soong is not in Washington, D.C.

The representative office was responding to media reports that said that Soong is scheduled to meet with U.S. Deputy Assistant Secretary of State Randall C. Schriver Friday in Washington, D.C. along with the "pan-blue alliance" representative office director, Yuan Chien-sheng.

The report said that Soong was to talk with Schriver about the possible cooperation between the ruling Democratic Progressive Party and the PFP, a bill on the peaceful development between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait proposed by the PFP, and Taiwan's proposed arms procurement from the United States, which is still pending in the "pan-blue"-controlled legislature.

The report cited sources as saying that Schriver will explain to Soong that the military balance in the Taiwan Strait is tilting toward Beijing, hoping to solicit the support of the PFP to secure the speedy approval of the proposed arms procurement deal.
The representative office said that Soong was not in Washington, D.C. and it had no information indicating that he would come.

In Taipei, Liu Wen-hsiung, PFP caucus whip in the Legislative Yuan, could not confirm whether Soong would meet with Schriver. However, he said that Soong, having a doctorate in politics from Georgetown University, has many friends and teachers involved with U.S. politics, and "it is only natural that he might meet some political figures."

DOC.HEADLINE: DOCTORS MUST BE CHARGED IN CASE OF BEATEN GIRL: JUSTICE MINISTER

TEXT.P: The emergency room doctors at Taipei City Hospital's Jen Ai branch who had not treated an unconscious four-year-old girl who had been badly beaten should be charged with negligence, Minister of Justice Chen Ding-nan said Thursday.

The Taipei District Prosecutors Office began investigations into the case Tuesday while demanding the arrest of the girl's divorced and unemployed father, surnamed Chiu, who is alleged to have beaten the girl while under the influence of alcohol late Monday night, Chen said at the Legislative Yuan.

The four-year-old was sent to the Jen Ai Hospital's emergency room at 1: 55 a.m. Tuesday but was not treated due to a lack of beds in the neurosurgery section. The hospital then called the Taipei Emergency Operations Center for assistance.

At that point, the Taipei Emergency Operations Center tried in vain until 4: 18 a.m. to find an emergency room in Taipei that would take the child, finally giving up after being rejected at six locations.

It was then decided that the girl should be driven to Tungs' Taichung MetroHarbor Hospital in Wuchi, Taichung County in central Taiwan. By the time the child reached Tungs' Hospital's operating room, it was past dawn Tuesday morning.

Surgeons at Tungs' Hospital immediately preformed surgery to remove a blood clot from the girl's brain and a second operation to try to relieve swelling was done later at around midnight of the same day. Doctors say they are not very optimistic about the child's chances for survival.
The surgeons said that the situation ought to be clearer Thursday or Friday as to whether the child will survive.

Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou said Wednesday that he had been briefed by Chang Heng, director of the city's Department of Health and concurrently the superintendent of Taipei City Hospital. Chang told the mayor that the incident was due mainly to a neurosurgeon who was supposed to have been on duty but who was not at the hospital. Ma said the incident is an issue involving discipline and medical ethics, not a failure of the Taipei emergency medical care system.

Ma subsequently announced Wednesday that Chang Heng will be removed from his health department post effective Feb. 1, calling the move an "adjustment of work" that will allow Chang Heng to target the deficiencies in the 12 branches of Taipei City Hospital and make necessary changes. Chang's vacancy will be temporarily filled by his deputy, Teng Su-wen.

Meanwhile, Ma said, the neurosurgeon at the Jen Ai emergency room should have been on duty and performed an emergency operation on the girl immediately upon her arrival and left the issue of finding a bed for later.
Although not blaming the medical care system, Ma said improvements could be made, such as addressing the number of beds in facilities, an issue that many patients have complained about in the past.

The Taipei District Prosecutors' Office has questioned employees at the Taipei Emergency Operations Center and the hospitals involved as to why they failed to find a bed for the girl in Taipei. The prosecutors said that those found blameworthy will be dealt with accordingly.

Doctors from Jen Ai Hospital released a statement Thursday saying that the hospital had acted according to protocol and that one of the main issues was that the emergency room was not equipped to perform the kind of surgery that the girl needed, in addition to the issue of a lack of bed space in the intensive care unit.

DOC.HEADLINE: CABINET APPROVES TAICHUNG FREE TRADE HARBOR ZONE PROJECT

TEXT.P: Taichung Harbor will become the third free trade harbor in Taiwan after Keelung and Kaohsiung harbors, according to a decision at a coordination meeting Thursday.

Vice Premier Yeh Chu-lan convened the free trade harbor zone coordination meeting at the Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) under the Executive Yuan and gave her approval for the project.

CEPD Vice Chairman Yeh Ming-feng, Minister of Transportation and Communications Lin Ling-san, Council of Labor Affairs Chen Chu, as well as Vice Minister of Economic Affairs Chen Ruey-long also attended the meeting.
Yeh said the Taichung Harbor free trade zone will start operations in October.

DOC.HEADLINE: REPORTED MEETING BETWEEN PFP HEAD AND U.S. OFFICIALS POSITIVE: DPP

TEXT.P: If opposition People First Party (PFP) Chairman James Soong meets with U.S. officials in Washington, D.C., it will help the political development in Taiwan, the acting chairman of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) said Thursday.
Ker Chien-ming, also DPP caucus whip in the Legislative Yuan, made the remarks after media reports said that Soong will meet with U.S. Deputy Assistant Secretary of State Randall C. Schriver Friday.

The report said that Soong was to talk with Schriver about the possible cooperation between the DPP and the PFP on a bill on the peaceful development between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait proposed by the PFP, and Taiwan's proposed arms procurement from the United States, which is still pending in the opposition-controlled legislature.

"Soong's exchange of views with U.S. officials on cross-strait issues and the political situation in Taiwan indicates that he is pondering the nation's future political situation and is preparing his next move," Ker said, adding that "this is positive for Taiwan's political development."
Ker said that he does not know what Soong might say, but the fact remains that the United States has always been concerned about the pending arms procurement and Taiwan's political development.

The DPP is currently trying to woo the PFP to form a working majority in the 225-member Legislative Yuan after the DPP garnered fewer than expected seats in the Dec. 11 legislative elections. Speculation has been rife about the PFP possibly being given posts in the upcoming reshuffled Cabinet and cooperating in the election of the speaker and vice speaker of the legislature.
On the other hand, Lien Chan, chairman of the Kuomintang (KMT), dismissed media reports that Soong had called him recently over the PFP's possible cooperation with the DPP.

Lien made the remarks after he led several KMT vice chairmen to pay their respects to former President Chiang Ching-kuo at his temporary mausoleum in Touliao, Taoyuan, on the 17th anniversary of his death.
"There was no call from Soong from the United States," Lien said.
As for the reported meeting between Soong and U.S. officials, Lien said that the KMT's representative to the U.S. has said nothing to him on the matter.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER MAC CHAIRWOMAN MEETS WITH U.S. SCHOLARS IN WASHINGTON
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Jan. 12 (CNA) (By Oliver Lin and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Former Mainland Affairs Council Chairwoman Tsai Ing-wen told a group of U.S. think tank scholars in Washington, D.C. Wednesday that Taiwan's constitutional re-engineering plan will not touch on sensitive sovereignty issues.

Tsai, who will become a ruling Democratic Progressive Party legislator-at-large Feb. 1, has kept a low profile during her current U.S. visit. She would not talked to 10-plus Taiwan and Hong Kong reporters waiting outside the Brookings Institution after attending a closed-door symposium organized by the noted think tank.
Richard Bush, a former American Institute in Taiwan (AIT) chairman, who is now director of the Brookings Institution's Center for Northeast Asian Policy Studies, briefed the media on the symposium.

Bush said Tsai had delivered a report on Taiwan's major political developments over the past few months and its possible future policy directions during the seminar attended by some 40 U.S. scholars and experts.

Bush quoted Tsai as having said she supports President Chen Shui-bian's declaration in his May 20 second inauguration speech that his constitutional reform program will not address any sensitive sovereignty and territory issues.

During the seminar, Bush said topics regarding Beijing's proposed "anti-secession law" were also discussed, but he would not elaborate on the details. Bush said his personal view was that public comments on the proposed law should not be made until after the text of the legislation is unveiled.

Bush said two other former AIT chairmen, Nat Bellocchi and David Dean, as well as Prof. Harry Harding of George Washington University, and several research fellows with the Center for Strategic and International Studies, including Bates Gill, were among the participants. Also present was Rupert Hammond-Chambers, president of the U.S.-Taiwan Business Council.
Tsai arrived in Washington, D.C. Tuesday and is scheduled to head for New York Friday to attend a seminar on Taiwan's constitutional re-engineering plan.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT: Los Angeles Times: Skies Clear, But Storms' Toll Mounts. As skies finally began to clear over Southern California, rescue workers pulled more bodies from the muck and wreckage of La Conchita, a coastal community in Ventura County where a landslide one day earlier had scoured a path of destruction.

DOC.TEXT:
The Straits Times: President points the way forward for S'pore.
A place where everyone can work for a better life. Where all can lead a fulfilling life and be the best that they can be.
That's the vision of Singapore - a land of hope and opportunity - held out by President S R Nathan in his speech opening the second session of the 10th Parliament last night, just over a month after the House went into recess.
Mr Nathan was clear about the way forward for Singapore. He spelt out seven priorities that Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong's Government will focus on.
The Lianhe Zaobao:The President: People's faith is the element of success.
The President S R Nathan noted that Singapore's new leaders would have to build on the achievement of their predecessors, but more importantly develop new programmes to meet the challenges ahead.
He said government must make Singapore be a place where everyone can work for a better life. Where all can lead a fulfilling life and be the best that they can be.
And he also set out the way forward for Singapore, outlining key areas in international relations, security, the economy, human resource and youth.
That's the vision of Singapore - a land of hope and opportunity - held out by President S R Nathan in his speech opening the second session of the 10th Parliament last night, just over a month after the House went into recess.

Under Fire, Election Workers in Iraq Are Scared but Resolute
Iraq's election workers are surviving the frontlines of an insurgency determined to stop the electoral process.
