IPod Sales Shine Up Apple's Profit
Apple said its earnings more than quadrupled on a 74% sales surge. The results reflected strong holiday demand for Macintosh computers and iPod music players.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TEXTILE FEDERATION TO TAKE PART IN FIBER SHOW IN SOUTH KOREA

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Textile Federation (TTF) will organize a delegation to attend an international fiber show in Daegu, South Korea in March.

Federation officials said that "Preview In Daegu" slated for March 16-18 is the largest international show in South Korea with a great potential for business opportunity. The show in March 2003 attracted 210 manufacturers from 11 countries and 1.38 million potential buyers attended.
South Korea is one of the largest fiber exporters, and Daegu is its largest production base.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI SHARE PRICES END LOWER

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange opened up but closed lower Thursday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving down 25.14 points to close at 5,853.94.
The bourse opened at 5,899.76 and fluctuated between 5,922.26 and 5,828.09 during trading. A total of 3.12 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$59.88 billion (US$1.87 billion).

Five of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with textile stocks moving up the most at 1.6 percent, followed by plastics and chemicals shares at 1.1 percent, construction issues at 0.9 percent, paper and pulp issues at 0.8 percent and foodstuff issues at 0.6 percent.

Three other major stock categories lost ground, with machinery and electronics shares moving down the most at 1.1 percent, followed by banking and financial shares at 0.4 percent and cement stocks at 0.3 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 421 to 288, with 186 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: HOSPITAL REPRESENTATIVES CALL FOR HEALTH INSURANCE REFORM

TEXT.P: A group of hospital representatives demanded Thursday that the Department of Health (DOH) set up a committee in one week to monitor National Health Insurance reform and address the deficiencies in the medical system and its emergency care services.
Also, the representatives resolved to reform the medical sector and will publicize the financial reports of their hospitals to rebuild public confidence in Taiwan's medical services.

Hsieh Wen-hui, president of the Taiwan Community Hospital Association, said the recent incident in which a severely abused four-year-old girl was refused treatment in Taipei City and sent away to Taichung County is a blemish on the medical sector and has exposed the indifference and the lack of devotion and a sense of mission among medical workers.
Hsieh said the way the girl was kicked around like a hot potato reflected only the tip of the iceberg of deficiencies involving the National Health Insurance program.
While leading hospitals are always crowded with patients, less than 50 percent of the beds in community hospitals are occupied, Hsieh pointed out.

Chuang Yi-chou, an official from the Taiwan Hospital Association, said it is the DOH's priority to identify the capabilities of different medical institutions and clear up the connection between emergency care services and the entire medical system to ensure patients are given suitable treatment at a suitable hospital.

DOC.HEADLINE: DUTCH OFFICIALS CALL FOR AGRICULTURAL COOPERATION WITH TAIWAN

TEXT.P: A four-member delegation from the Netherlands Foreign Investment Agency (NFIA) paid a visit to the Tainan County Government in southern Taiwan Thursday to push for agricultural cooperation between Taiwan and the Netherlands.
NFIA Director Harry A.C. van Woerden said to Tainan County Deputy Magistrate Yen Tsun-chou that there is ample room for Taiwan and Holland to cooperate in agricultural development.
For instance, Woerden said the two sides can cooperate in development of new floral species and production technologies, particularly orchid cultivation.
Noting that the Netherlands' floral sales are worldwide, Woerden said the global flower market has a ferocious appetite for new floral species.
"Take orchids as an example. There are myriad strains. We can cooperate in new orchid species development," he added.

After touring an orchid biotechnological park and several other agricultural processing facilities in Tainan County, Woerden said the NFIA will send its farm trade staff to Taiwan in April or May to discuss possible bilateral cooperative projects.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI MAYOR MAY DELAY AUSTRALIA TRIP OUT OF CONCERN FOR ABUSED GIRL

TEXT.P: Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou said Thursday that he might delay his planned trip to Australia for a day or two to deal with the fallout after a four-year-old girl who was beaten nearly to death was turned away from a number of hospitals in Taipei. She is barely clinging to life in a hospital in Taichung.

Ma was originally scheduled to leave Thursday night for Melbourne to take part in the closing ceremony of the Deaflympics on Sunday as the representative of the host city of Taipei for the 2009 Deaflympics.

He said that as mayor of the host city, he must go to Melbourne to accept the event flag in line with international protocol, but considering the condition of the battered girl, he is now contacting Australia to try to change the schedule.

Ma noted that according to newspaper reports, the girl led a miserable life before she was allegedly beaten by her drunken father. Her condition has deteriorated since having to be moved by ambulance to a hospital in Taichung before getting a needed surgery for her severe head injuries in Taipei.

Hospitals that were contacted to see if they could take her at the time she went to the Jen Ai Hospital said they didn't have any free beds or lacked the necessary equipment to perform an operation of the kind the child needed.

As mayor, Ma said he feels that he owes it to the girl to keep informed, adding that he hopes to visit her in the next two days. Mayor Ma tried to visit the child in the Taichung hospital, but failed to see her because visiting hours were over.

The mayor on Wednesday asked Chang Hang, director of the city's Department of Health and superintendent of Taipei City hospital, to leave his health department post, and focus on reforming the 12 branches of the Taipei City Hospital after public uproar over the incident.

DOC.HEADLINE: EXPORT CONTROLs ON STRATEGIC HI-TECH COMMODITIES TIGHTENED

TEXT.P: The Bureau of Foreign Trade (BOFT) has stepped up export controls on strategic hi-tech commodities from this month in line with international efforts against terrorism and the proliferation of nuclear and biological weapons, BOFT officials said Thursday.
The measures will not undermine the competitiveness of Taiwan exporters because similar measures are being implemented by Asian competitors including Japan and South Korea, the officials said.

While export controls on these commodities has been enforced internationally for years, U.S.-led international export control organizations have expressed concern over the export of Taiwan-made precision instruments to Iran, Iraq, North Korea, Liberia and mainland China after the 911 terrorist attacks on the United States, they pointed out.

The BOFT will now punish any exporters who fail to make customs declarations as required and will put such exporters on a blacklist that will make all their exports subject to strict inspection, they said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI CITY LOSES LITIGATION OVER PREMIUM SUBSIDY DISPUTE

TEXT.P: The Taipei High Administrative Court announced Thursday that the Taipei city government has lost a suit over how city government subsidies to national health insurance premiums should be charged.

It means that the city will have to repay the NT$10.84 billion (US$324.55 million) that it did not pay to the Bureau of National Health Insurance between 1999 and 2002 in city governmental subsidies, and NT$9.95 billion (US$298 million) that it did not pay to the Labor Insurance Bureau between 1992 and 2000 in city governmental subsidies, judges from the Taipei High Administrative Court said.
The money, according to the Bureau of National Health Insurance and Labor Insurance Bureau, represents subsidies the city government should pay for the insurance premiums.

The city government filed a lawsuit with the Taipei High Administrative Court against the Bureau of National Health Insurance as well as the Labor Insurance Bureau several years ago, arguing that its subsidies for the insurance premium should be calculated according to the number of residents in the city, which is 2.63 million, rather than according to the number of employees hired by companies and firms headquartered in Taipei, which is 3.58 million.

This argument failed to convince the court, which said in its judgment that since none of the articles in the existing labor insurance statute and the national health insurance law stipulates that the city government should make the governmental subsidy payments based on individual insurance holders.

In response to the judgment, Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou said that the city government will discuss the matter with its lawyers and if necessary, the city government will file an appeal with the Supreme Administrative Court.

Chang Chiung-wen, a spokesperson for the Taipei High Administrative Court said that even if the city government files for an appeal with the Supreme Administrative Court, it will not bar the Labor Insurance Bureau nor the Bureau of National Health Insurance from executing their right to demand that the city government repay the money.

Welcoming the Taipei High Administration Court's rejection of the suit, Shih Chieh, director-general of the Labor Insurance Bureau, said that the judgment will serve as a strong legal arm to forcibly demand the city government to repay what it should have paid.

Lai Chin-hsiang, vice president of the Bureau of National Health Insurance, said that the bureau will not only recover the outstanding NT$10.84 billion for the period before 2002, the bureau will also seek that the city government repay the NT$11 billion for 2003 and 2004.

DOC.HEADLINE: NO WATER SHORTAGE FOR TAIWAN IN FIRST HALF OF 2005: WRA

TEXT.P: Water supplies for civic and industrial use in the first half of this year have been assured, as have supplies for irrigation for the first crop of the season, officials of the Water Resources Agency (WRA) under the Ministry of Economic Affairs said Thursday.

Major reservoirs and rivers across the country now contain large amounts of water and the weather in the coming three months is forecast to be largely normal, which means water supplies are ensured for both the general public and factories in Taiwan proper, WRA officials said.
They said a water shortage is not expected to occur in the first six months of this year, dousing public concerns over the drought that has afflicted parts of the country in the past few years.
At present, major reservoirs in northern Taiwan are nearly at full capacity, with the highest levels in recent years, while those in central and southern regions are at about 80 percent of capacity.
However, the officials were reserved about the situation in northern Taoyuan County beyond April, where water demand is particularly high due to heavy industrial consumption.
At the same time, there will be no water problems on the offshore islands of Kinmen and Matsu through the first six months, they said, although they pointed out that Matsu is an exception.

Matsu's Nankang area has been troubled by a water shortage, as local reservoirs contain only a combined 68,700 tons of water. Local residents are now provided with water on only two out of every three days.
The WRA is planning to ship a total of 190,000 tons of water to the remote island, some 8,500 tons of which has already been transported to meet demand.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORENSIC MEDICINE PERSONNEL DRAFT LAW PASSES FIRST READING

TEXT.P: The Judicial Committee of the Legislative Yuan passed Thursday the first reading of a draft law on forensic medicine personnel.
According to the draft, only people from graduate schools of forensic medicine of colleges and universities will be eligible to take the forensic medicine personnel examination.

The draft law stipulates that the examination and the licensing of forensic medicine personnel must be an independent system, drawing a clear line between them and physicians in the hope that it will help solve the problem of a shortage of forensic medicine personnel and upgrade the quality and standard of such personnel.

A forensic medicine specialist cannot work as a physician, while a physician wishing to specialize in forensic medicine will have to pass the necessary examination, unlike current practice, which has no such restrictions.
However, Legislator Chou Hsi-wei of the opposition People First Party said that even if the draft law is passed into law, it will not entice enough people to serve as forensic medicine personnel.

Minister of Justice Chen Ding-nan said that at present, a forensic medicine specialist can only earn around NT$100,000 (US$3,125) per month as a prosecutor, and added that he is mulling whether an adjustment is needed to entice talented people to do forensic work.

DOC.HEADLINE: PFP CONFIRMS CHAIRMAN WILL MEET WITH U.S. POLITICIANS IN WASHINGTON

TEXT.P: Opposition People First Party (PFP) Chairman James Soong will head for Washington, D.C. in the coming days to meet with U.S. officials and think tank scholars, a PFP official said Thursday.

Chang Hsien-yao, director of the PFP policy research center and also a legislator-elect, was responding to media reports that Soong, who has been in San Francisco for some time, will meet with U.S. Deputy Assistant Secretary of State Randall C. Schriver in Washington Friday.
Out of respect for "U.S. friends, " Chang said he could not divulge any specific U.S. politician with whom Soong will meet during his visit.

Chang said Soong will exchange views with U.S. political figures on the cross-Taiwan Strait situation and the PFP-proposed bill on promotion of cross-strait peace because these issues are related to U.S. interests.
Asked whether U.S. politicians will bring up issues regarding a proposed U.S. arms sale to Taiwan worth NT$610.8 billion (about US$18 billion), Chang did not rule out the possibility.
"Soong is an opposition leader. I think that U.S. officials will grasp the opportunity to communicate with him about the proposed arms deal," Chang said.

The special budget bill for the massive arms procurement package, which includes eight diesel-electric submarines, a squadron of 12 submarine-hunting P-3C Orion aircraft and six Patriot PAC-III anti-missile batteries, has been pending in the Legislative Yuan, which which is controlled by the PFP and its "pan-blue" ally, the Kuomintang (KMT).

Chang said that even if U.S. officials discuss the arms package with Soong, the PFP is not expected to soften its stance on the deal. He stressed that the special budget bill is unlikely to clear the legislative floor before the current legislative session closes Jan. 21.
Chang further said that Soong will definitely hold a news conference to explain the content of his talks with U.S. political figures. "There won't be any secret deal," he added.

Meanwhile, PFP legislative whip Liu Wen-hsiung said that as the leader of an opposition party, Soong has a certain level of influence, "so it's normal that foreign friends want to see him, " he added.

Soong reportedly is angry at the premature exposure of his planned meeting with Schriver. Party sources said only a few "pan-blue alliance" core members, including the alliance's representative in the United States Huang Chien-sheng, was aware of the planned meeting. PFP headquarters said it will investigate into how the information was leaked to the local media.
News of the planned Soong-Schriver meeting came amid reports that the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) is seeking to forge a seemingly unlikely partnership with the PFP.

DPP legislative whip Ker Chien-ming, who concurrently serves as acting DPP chairman, said he takes a positive view of Soong's upcoming meeting with Schriver. In his view, Ker said, such a meeting implies that Soong is contemplating Taiwan's future and his next move.
Ker said the DPP truly looks forward to forming a working partnership with the PFP. But he admitted that no DPP heavyweights, including himself, are clear on Soong's true intentions.

Ker said he is hopeful that Soong can return to Taipei soon and meet with President Chen Shui-bian to talk about inter-party reconciliation and cooperation to facilitate national unity, social harmony and economic development.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT'S SOUTH PACIFIC TRIP SCHEDULE YET TO BE SET: OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian's upcoming overseas travel itinerary has yet to be decided and will be announced by the Presidential Office when it is finalized, a spokesman for the Ministry of Foreign Affairs said Thursday.
Michel Lu made the remarks in response to media speculation that Chen is likely to make a stopover in Guam on his way back from a trip to the South Pacific later this month.

Asked whether Chen will meet with U.S. officials to exchange views on issues of mutual concern in Guam if he decides to make a stopover there, Lu said that judging from pragmatic viewpoints, it would be feasible for the president to do so.
A team from the Presidential Office is currently in a South Pacific country discussing the technical details concerning the president's visit.
Chen is scheduled to leave Taipei Jan. 27 to attend the inauguration of Palau's president followed by a visit to one or two other allies in the South Pacific.

Chen had originally wanted to visit all five allies of the Republic of China in the South Pacific -- which also include Kiribati, Tuvalu and the Marshall Islands -- but out of consideration of the imminent Cabinet reshuffle and various other factors, he was unable to.

This will be Chen's first trip to the South Pacific since he assumed the presidency in May 2000, and his second official overseas visit since he assumed his second term as president May 20. He visited the Central American states of Panama and Belize in early September.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES MOSTLY LOWER ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were mostly lower Thursday as the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for January lost 21 points to close at 5,880, with 33,987 contracts changing hands.
TAIEX Index futures for February lost 20 points to finish at 5,880, with 4,037 contracts traded, while March futures lost 51 points to finish at 5,865, with 34 contracts traded.
June futures gained eight points to finish at 5,880, with two contracts traded, while September futures moved down 31 points to close at 5,784, with nine contracts traded.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Thursday at 5,901 for January, 5,900 for February, 5,916 for March, 5,872 for June and 5,815 for September.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were lower.

January TE futures moved down 2.05 points to close at 215.55, with 4,779 contracts traded, while February TE futures lost 1.85 points to finish at 216, with 792 contract transactions. March TE futures lost 3.45 points to close at 213.5, with 32 contracts traded.
No transactions were recorded for June and September.

January TF futures lost one point to finish at 1,008.4, with 3,646 contracts changing hands, while February TF futures moved down 2.8 points to end at 1,007.2, with 973 contracts traded. March TF futures lost one point to finish at 1,005, with nine contracts changing hands, while June TF futures moved up 2.4 points to close at 1,004, with one contract transaction.
No transactions were recorded for September.

The Times: State schools top the table but private rivals cry foul.
The best state schools have overtaken their fee-paying rivals for the first time in league tables of examination results published today.
Financial Times: Sharp rise in US tade deficit hits the dollar.
The US trade deficit widened sharply in November to a record $60.3bn ( £32.1bn), renewing pressure on the ailing dollar and causing economists to scale back their forecasts for economic growth.
The gap between imports and exports grew by $4.3bn over the month and has now risen by almost $10bn since September.
The main culprits were a surge in the volume of imports of oil products and a decline in demand for US capital goods.

With just over two weeks until the Iraqi elections, the United States is lowering its expectations for both the turnout and the results of the vote, increasingly emphasizing other steps over the next year as more important to Iraq's political transformation, according to U.S. officials, the paper said.

The Moscow Times: Pensioners' Protests Spreading
The storm of pensioners' protests against the loss of Soviet-era benefits spread to new towns and cities Wednesday as several thousand people rallied outside regional government offices and blocked highways as far afield as Udmurtia and Penza.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORUM FOR LOCAL, FOREIGN BUSINESS COMMUNITIES SET TO OPEN FRIDAY

TEXT.P: The Bureau of Foreign Trade (BOFT) is scheduled to hold a forum that will bring together members of domestic and foreign business communities Friday to gather their opinions on the participation of the private sector in government-led international trade talks.

The foreign guests will be invited from among members of the Australian Chamber of Commerce and Industry, the American Chamber of Commerce, the British Chamber of Commerce and the Confederation of Asia-Pacific Chambers of Commerce and Industry, BOFT officials said.

Although Taiwan has now been a member of the World Trade Organization for three years, local civic organizations have little experience in cooperating with the government in international trade talks, the officials said.

In contrast, commerce and industry organizations in Europe and the United States have always been a major supportive force behind their governments in fighting for national interests in any international trade talks, they said.

The BOFT hopes to learn from the experience of foreign business communities to enhance cooperation between Taiwan's government and private sectors in terms of international economics and trade, they added.

DOC.HEADLINE: CROSS-STRAIT FREEWAY IS BEIJING'S POLITICAL PROPAGANDA: OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: Mainland China's proposal to build a Beijing-Taipei freeway is merely "political propaganda" and has no significance, a government spokesman said Thursday.

Executive Yuan spokesman Chen Chi-mai was responding to media reports that mainland China's Minister of Communications Zhang Chunxian said earlier in the day that a freeway network plan just unveiled also includes a Beijing-Taipei freeway. Although it might seem like an impossible mission at present, the mainland hopes to accomplish it by 2030, Zhang added.

Chen noted that tunnel engineers from both sides of the Taiwan Strait broached the idea of a cross-strait freeway several years ago and have even suggested several possible routes, although many scholars have said that with the existing technology, it will be impossible to overcome the problem resulting from the "Black Tide" and the marine trench in the Taiwan Strait.
Moreover, a long-distance tunnel would have to have safety as its top priority and would have to take into consideration possible incidents or major casualties, Chen added.
Other issues such as ventilation, maintenance and economic efficiency would also have to be assessed, he said.

Chen said that because of these insurmountable technical problems and the high risk factor, the mainland communications minister's promotion of a freeway is no more than a far-fetched exercise in political propaganda.
"If China wants to contribute to cross-strait development, we hope that it will address cross-strait issues in a pragmatic manner," Chen said.

The mainland could start with removing the obstacles marring the launch of cross-strait charter flights during the Chinese New Year holiday, facilitate cross-strait cargo transportation and bring about direct cross-strait trade, postal and transportation links, he added.

Meanwhile, the Taiwan Area National Expressway Engineering Bureau under the Ministry of Transportation and Communications said that cross-strait section of any Taiwan-Beijing freeway would pose a major challenge because there are no bridges or tunnels in the world that are as long as the Taiwan Strait is wide.

If political factors are not taken into consideration, building a tunnel on that section would be more feasible than a bridge based on pragmatic technical assessments, bureau officials said, although tunneling would also present the problem of geological changes.

The officials noted that there are two undersea tunnels -- the English Channel Tunnel linking Britain and France and Japan's Seikan Tunnel linking its main island of Honshu and the northern neighboring island of Hokkaido -- both of which are only about 50 km long and are railway tunnels -- compared with the Taiwan Strait, which is more than 100 km wide at its narrowest point.
If the bridge option were to be adopted, there would be massive difficulties in both construction and operation.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC PROPOSES CROSS-STRAIT CHARTER FLIGHT TALKS IN MACAU SATURDAY

TEXT.P: The Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) said Thursday it has commissioned Michael Lo, president of the Taipei Airlines Association (TAA) , to negotiate terms with mainland China in Macau Saturday for special charter flights during the upcoming Chinese New Year holiday.

The nation's top mainland policy planning agency said in a press statement that with a view to realizing the special charter flight plan, Taiwan has demonstrated the maximum of sincerity in proposing the negotiation delegates, the time and the venue.

"We have taken into account mainland China's difficulties and inconveniences, " the MAC said in the press release, adding that it hopes the mainland will honor its promise to facilitate the realization of the much-anticipated charter flight plan.

With less than a month before the Lunar New Year, the MAC urged the mainland to confirm the proposed schedule and venue and inform the TAA of the delegates it plans to send as soon as possible so that the negotiations can get underway.

According to the MAC press statement, Billy K.C. Chang, director-general of Taiwan's Civil Aeronautics Administration, will take part in the charter flight negotiations in his capacity as a TAA adviser.

Beijing officials said the previous day that officials from the MAC, which charts Taiwan's policy toward the mainland, and Taiwan's quasi-official Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF), should not be part of the delegation, but they stopped short of saying whether Taiwan's CAA officials can take part in talks in their capacities as TAA advisers.

Lo said Thursday that he has informed Pu Zhaozhou, vice president of the Cross-Strait Air Transport Exchange Commission under the Beijing-based China Civil Aviation Association, of the MAC-proposed schedule, venue and negotiation delegates.

Pu, who is also director the Civil Aviation Administration of China's Taiwan Affairs Office, met with Lo in Macau last week and came to an initial agreement in principle on the special charter flight services.
The two sides has basically agreed that the charter flights will be operated on the principle of "joint participation, two-way services and no stopovers in a third place."

With Beijing's consent, six Taiwan carriers operated Chinese New Year charter flights in 2003 between Shanghai and Taipei/Kaohsiung via Hong Kong/Macau. The services were not offered the following year because Beijing insisted that mainland carriers also be allowed to offer the service but refused to come to the negotiating table to discuss the necessary technical details with Taiwan.

This time around, the destinations on the mainland side may increase to include Beijing and Guangzhou. Beijing has also proposed that Taichung be included in the destinations on the Taiwan side, but Taiwan officials basically insist that only Taipei and Kaohsiung be included.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. DOLLAR PLUNGES ON TAIPEI FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar plunged against the new Taiwan dollar to four-year low on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Thursday, losing NT$0.160 to close at NT$31.868.
A total of US$749 million changed hands.
The greenback opened at NT$32.028 and was traded between NT$31.808 and NT$32.172.

DOC.HEADLINE: CABINET APPROVES PLAN TO SET UP FREE TRADE ZONE AT TAICHUNG HARBOR

TEXT.P: The Executive Yuan gave a green light Thursday to a plan to set up a free trade zone at Taichung Harbor in central Taiwan.
The free trade zone is expected to start services at the end of this year, officials said.

It will be the country's third free trade zone including one at northern Keelung Harbor, which started operations in October 2004, and another at southern Kaohsiung Harbor, which started operations earlier this month.
The zone will cover an area of 536 hectares, which will make it the largest of the three, according to officials from the Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD).

Situated near the Changpin Industrial Zone and the Tantzu and Chungkang export processing zones, as well as a planned international airport, the free trade zone is expected to become the hub for imports and exports in central Taiwan, the officials said.
The plan was approved during a meeting of the free trade zone coordination committee hosted by Vice Premier Yeh Chu-lan.

Also during the meeting, Yeh ordered the Council of Labor Affairs to study the feasibility of allowing the employment of foreign workers in the service sector in free trade zones and to submit a report on the issue in four months.
Meanwhile, CEPD officials said the government is planning to set a quota to control the number of foreign workers hired in free trade zones at 40 percent of the total new hires.

DOC.HEADLINE: BLIND PEOPLE CAN `CLEARLY SEE WORLD BY HEART': PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian encouraged visually impaired people Tuesday to "see the world by heart," claiming that in this way they will see it more clearly than sighted people.

Chen made the remarks while receiving John Lan, a visually impaired and otherwise physically challenged artist, at the Presidential Office. It was their ninth meeting since 1998, when Chen suffered a setback in his re-election bid for the Taipei mayorship.
Lan, 41, has overcome his disability to organize a band and has become a successful jazz drummer.
During the meeting, Lan presented a book titled "John Lan," which he dictated to Sung Fang-chi, while Chen repaid him with five words -- "a successful fighter for life."
Lan told the president that he will donate the royalties from 200 copies of his book to help three brothers from Kaohsiung who are suffering from a rare disorder called adrenoleukodystrophy (ALD).

Chen noted that the public have already donated NT$72 million (US$2.25 million) to the family in just a few days to help pay for the eldest son's medical treatment in the United States, showing the great love of the people of Taiwan.

In addition, the public and private sectors in Taiwan have also shown their great love to the victims of the Dec. 26 tsunami in the Indian Ocean by raising millions of dollars to help them, Chen went on.
The president also invited Lan's band to perform during a state banquet he will host in honor of a friendly nation's president in the near future.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAICHUNG HOPES TO BE INCLUDED IN LUNAR NEW YEAR CHARTER FLIGHTS

TEXT.P: Taichung Mayor Jason Hu and Taichung Magistrate Huang Chung-sheng jointly urged the central government Thursday to include Chingchuankang (CCK) Airport in the Lunar New Year charter flight services between Taiwan and mainland China.

They issued the call after reports that the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) might reject a proposal to include the central Taiwan airport in the special program designed to transport mainland-based Taiwan businessmen wishing to spend the Chinese New Year holiday early next month at home.

Claiming that national security issues cited by the MAC as a reason for excluding CCK Airport from the program can be overcome "technically, " Hu called on the central government to rethink its decision.

Taichung is located close to Xiamen in Fujian Province, where there is a large number of Taiwan businessmen from Taichung, Hu claimed, adding that the interests of citizens from central Taiwan must be heeded.
Passenger and cargo air transport services between the two sides, Huang said, are very important for both sides amid frequent and close trade and economic relations across the Taiwan Strait.
Air travel between Taichung and Xiamen would be time and cost effective for the many businessmen in Xiamen who come from central Taiwan regions, Huang said.
Should the central government include CCK Airport in the charter flight services, it would help boost the airport's aim of becoming an international airport, Huang said.

Both Hu and Huang claimed that the national security concerns highlighted by the MAC can be resolved by imposing a quota mechanism, setting a limit on the number of mainland carriers coming to Taichung.

Taiwan and the mainland have in principle agreed that carriers from both sides will take part in the charter flight services under the principle of "non-stop, round-trip, multi-destinations, " but concrete details have yet to be worked out.

Chinese New Year charter flights for Taiwan businessmen took off for the first time in 2003, involving Taiwan carriers only. The special service failed to take place in 2004 due to the mainland's demand that mainland carriers be allowed to take part and its refusal to discuss the issue with the Taiwan authorities.
Direct transport, trade and postal links between Taiwan and mainland China have been absent due to long-standing political feuding since 1949, when the two sides split after a civil war.

DOC.HEADLINE: CAL PLANE TAKES RELIEF AID TO MEDAN

TEXT.P: China Airlines (CAL) , Taiwan's largest carrier, dispatched a plane Thursday to transport relief materials to Medan on the Indonesian island of Sumatra, one of the regions hardest-hit by the Dec. 26 earthquakes and tsunami, according to a CAL spokesman.

Cookies, powdered milk and instant food are among the 15 tons of relief goods transported by the company to help the refugees, the spokesman said, adding that the aviation company will dispatch another charter plane to conduct a similar mission Friday.

In the wake of the catastrophe that has affected countries in South Asia and Southeast Asia, CAL has carried out five relief missions, transporting 65 medical personnel, rescuers and a total of 40 tons of aid materials to victims in the affected countries, as part of Taiwan's relief efforts.

In cooperation with CAL, Taiwan's postal authorities are also offering a 50 percent discount in rates for international parcel post for Indonesian, Thai, Malaysian, Sri Lankan and Indian passport-holders sending packages to their home countries.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.N. REPORT SENDS WARNING SIGNAL ABOUT TAIWAN'S CORAL REEFS

TEXT.P: A recent United Nations report on the status of the world's coral reefs sent a warning signal to the Taiwan authorities with the news that nearly 75 percent of them have been damaged or are seriously threatened.

The global report, titled Status of Coral Reefs of the World: 2004, attributed bleaching of coral reefs off Taiwan's coasts to a combination of factors, including overfishing, waste-water pollution, damage by recreational divers and nuclear power plant operations.

The report, issued by UNESCO, analyzes the coral reef status in 96 countries around the world, including Taiwan. According to the report, coral reefs exist in the waters surrounding Taiwan, except for the west coast.
Of the 32 Taiwan coral reef areas subject to the UNESCO study, 18 of them have lost up to 70 percent of their live coral colonies due to bleaching, the report said.

According to the report, aquaculture ponds, highway construction, recreational parks and farming in Taiwan's coastal regions, coupled with soil degradation and mudslides, have all hurt Taiwan's coral reef health.

In response to the UNESCO report, local scholars and environmentalists urged the government Thursday to address the problems and adopt effective measures to safeguard coral reefs. They also urged the government to revise its economy-oriented environmental development policy and strategies.

DOC.HEADLINE: OPPOSITION'S CONTACTS WITH U.S. OFFICIALS ARE COMMON: FM

TEXT.P: Minister of Foreign Affairs Tan Sun Chen described an upcoming trip by opposition People First Party (PFP) Chairman James Soong to Washington, D.C. for talks with U.S. officials as party diplomacy, saying it is very common in a democratic country.
Chen made the remarks during a meeting with reporters after signing an agricultural and medical cooperation treaty with his Malawian counterpart at the Ministry of Foreign Affairs.

According to media reports, Soong, who has been in San Francisco for some time, will head for Washington to meet with U.S. Deputy Assistant Secretary of State Randall C. Schriver and several think tank scholars Friday.

Chen said he is confident that Soong's plan to meet with Schriver is for the sake of Taiwan's best interests, adding that the U.S. government also looks forward to gaining a better understanding of the country 's political situation following the Dec. 11 legislative elections through a variety of channels.

Meanwhile, Chang Hsien-yao, director of the PFP's policy research center and a legislator-elect, confirmed Soong's planned meeting with Schriver, saying that they are expected to exchange views on the cross-Taiwan Strait situation and a PFP-proposed bill on the promotion of cross-strait peace.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT PLANS TO HOLD PARTY CONGRESS AUG. 17

TEXT.P: The main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) has tentatively decided to hold its 17th national party congress Aug. 17 to decide a change of party chairman, party sources said Thursday.
According to the party's plan, incumbent KMT Chairman Lien Chan will step down from the chairmanship on that day, which also marks his 70th birthday.
In line with the KMT's chairman election regulations, the KMT members must elect their chairman three months before its national party congress.

Liao Feng-teh, director of the KMT's organization and development department, said the party has tentatively scheduled to hold a party chairman election either May 14 or May 21 so that the new chairman will be able to assume office when the 17th national party congress is convened.
Liao said the party has yet to finalize a complete work schedule for the congress as many technical details must be settled first.

DOC.HEADLINE: NUMBER OF REAL ESTATE SHOPS TOPS 1,200 IN TAIWAN IN 2004

TEXT.P: The number of real estate shops in Taiwan totaled 1,217 as of the end of 2004 -- the largest number in six years -- Evertrust Rehouse Co., Ltd. reported Thursday.
The figure represents a 41 percent increase over the 2003 level, statistics compiled by the company show.
A total of 378 new shops -- including 325 in northern Taipei County -- were opened last year around the country by the leading eight companies in the trade, double the previous year's level.

Taipei County -- Taiwan's largest county in terms of populations -- also had the largest number of real estate shops last year, followed by Taipei City, Kaohsiung City, Taichung City and Taoyuan County. Some 86,000 deals were made in Taipei County alone in the first 11 months of the year, or 23 percent of the country's total.
Evertrust Rehouse analysts attributed the marked growth to the improved traffic infrastructure and the government's preferential loan policy and other incentives to buyers.

DOC.HEADLINE: ACTING DPP CHAIRMAN OPTIMISTIC ABOUT TIES WITH PFP

TEXT.P: Ker chien-ming, acting chairman of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) , said Thursday he is optimistic about the formation of a working partnership between his party and the second-largest opposition party, the People First Party (PFP).

Ker said he is convinced that when PFP Chairman James Soong returns to Taipei later this month after a trip to the United States, Soong will be determined to seek a place in Taiwan's history and play a critical role in helping stabilize the domestic political situation.
Ker said his optimism about succeeding in forging a seemingly unlikely DPP-PFP working partnership lies in his confidence in Soong's ability to sense Taiwan's mainstream public opinion.
"Local people are fed up with inter-party wrangling and are now yearning for inter-party reconciliation and cooperation," Ker said.

DOC.HEADLINE: HK SECURITIES EXECUTIVES TO ATTEND SEMINAR IN TAIPEI

TEXT.P: Executives from the Hong Kong Securities and Futures Commission (HKSFC) are scheduled to arrive in Taipei late next month to take part in a seminar organized by the International Organization of Securities Commissions (IOSCO), an official from the Cabinet-level Financial Supervisory Commission (FSC) said Thursday.

FSC Chairman Kong Jaw-sheng said that he met with HKSFC officials during a recent seminar held by the Investment Company Institute (ICI) in Hong Kong and that he invited them to attend the planned IOSCO seminar on emerging market development.
Kong disclosed that he also signed a memorandum of understanding on bilateral cooperation with the HKSFC during his visit to the former British colony.
In addition to Hong Kong, Taiwan should also seek to explore financial cooperation ties with other neighboring countries such as South Korea and Japan, Kong added.

DOC.HEADLINE: CULTURAL GOODWILL AMBASSADORS SOUGHT TO PROMOTE TAIWAN CULTURE

TEXT.P: The Council for Cultural Affairs under the Executive Yuan is seeking cultural goodwill ambassadors to develop and promote Taiwan culture, according to a set of guidelines issued by the council Thursday.

In a memorandum issued to the Ministry of Foreign Affairs and the cultural affairs bureaux of local governments, the council said the title of cultural goodwill ambassador is designed to honor people who advocate and spread Taiwan culture either at home or abroad.

Anyone who has contributed significantly to the improvement of Taiwan culture, supports international cultural exchanges, helps with Taiwan's cultural exchanges with international society, or has created significant artworks, are potential candidates for the title.

Overseas candidates for the title should be recommended by Taiwan's overseas agencies and domestic candidates should be recommended by the council or other government agencies, according to the guidelines.
There is no limit on the number of ambassadors and foreigners can also be named as candidates, according to the council.
Details about the system can be found at the council's Website, http://www.cca.gov.

DOC.HEADLINE: AVIATION CHIEF TO LEAD DELEGATION IN CHARTER FLIGHT TALKS

TEXT.P: Chang Kuo-cheng, director-general of the Civil Aeronautics Administration, will lead a four-member delegation to Macau Saturday to negotiate with mainland China on charter flight services between Taiwan and the mainland during the Chinese New Year holiday, anonymous government sources said Thursday.

Michael Lo, president of the Taipei Airlines Association (TAA) , who has been commissioned by the Mainland Affairs Council to negotiate terms with mainland officials, will also be a member of the delegation.
The two other delegates will be an official of the Civil Aeronautics Administration and a TAA secretary.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Friday, Jan. 14, or the fifth day of the 12th month of the Year of the Monkey according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1875: Albert Schweitzer, French theologian, organist and missionary surgeon who won the Nobel Peace Prize in 1952, is born.
1878: Alexander Graham Bell, the Scottish-born American inventor of the telephone, gives a demonstration of his new invention to Queen Victoria.
1905: Takeo Fukuda, Japanese prime minister from 1976 to 1978, is born.
1916: An express train connecting Berlin and Constantinople is inaugurated as the Orient Express.
1941: In China, the revolt of the New Fourth Communist Army is suppressed.
1943: U.S. President Franklin D. Roosevelt confers with British Prime Minister Winston Churchill in Casablanca to discuss strategies against the Axis, an alliance formed by Germany, Italy, and Japan.
1950: The United States recalls all consular personnel from mainland China.
1950: Ho Chi Minh proclaims Vietnam independence and announces the formation of the Democratic Republic of Vietnam.
1953: The Federal Chamber of Yugoslavia elects Josip Broz Tito as president of the Federal People's Republic of Yugoslavia.
1954: The Republic of China Executive Yuan approves the construction of Shihmen Reservoir.
1955: The ROC Legislative Yuan ratifies the Sino-American Mutual Defense Treaty.
1963: French President Charles de Gaulle says "non" to Britain's bid for membership of the European Economic Community.
1969: An explosion aboard nuclear-powered aircraft carrier USS Enterprise kills 26 people near Honolulu.
1972: ROC President Chiang Kai-shek appoints Mao Chi-hsien, Fang Chin-yen and Shu Mei-sheng as ambassadors to Guatemala, Nicaragua and Gambia, respectively.
1974: A seminar on environmental pollution opens in Taipei under the sponsorship of the National Science Council and the U.S. Science Foundation, with more than 30 Chinese and American scientists attending.
1974: The maiden flight of the first F-5A fighter assembled by the ROC Air Force takes place.
1974: Osamu Itagaki, chairman of the Interchange Association of Japan and former Japanese ambassador to the ROC, arrives to discuss the Taipei-Tokyo aviation agreement.
1975: The Asian Problems Research Institute is inaugurated.
1976: Malaysian Premier Tun Abdul Razak dies in London and is succeeded by Datuk Hussein Bin Onu.
1983: The Legislative Yuan passes a revision of the Trademark Law, stipulating prison terms for trademark infringements.
1990: ROC President Lee Teng-hui and President Prosper Avril of Haiti sign a joint communique calling for stronger bilateral cooperation.
1993: The ROC Legislative Yuan approves a US$12.47 billion budget for the purchase of 150 F-16 jet fighters from the United States and 60 Mirage 200-5s from France.
1997: ROC Vice President and Premier Lien Chan meets with Pope John Paul II and shares his views on world peace and humanitarian pursuits.
2000: Opposition Democratic Progressive Party Chairman Lin I-hsiung says that DPP presidential candidate Chen Shui-bian will not declare independence for Taiwan if he is elected.
2001: The Republic of China's first national-level rescue team leaves for El Salvador to assist in post-earthquake relief work after the Central American country was hit by a 7.6-magnitude earthquake.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "He who wants little seldom goes wrong."

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER MAC CHAIRWOMAN TO SPEAK IN NEW YORK ON ROC CONSTITUTION
DOC.DATELINE: New York, Jan. 13 (CNA) (By Eric Tseng and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Former Mainland Affairs Council Chairwoman Tsai Ing-wen will deliver the keynote speech at a seminar in New York Friday on the political implications of Taiwan's plan to revise the ROC Constitution.

Tsai, who will become a ruling Democratic Progressive Party legislator-at-large Feb. 1, will explain why it is necessary for Taiwan to adopt a new constitution, the process that will be followed to achieve this and what will likely be in the revised constitution. This will all be set against the backdrop of how the revised constitution will dovetail with international trends.

The seminar is sponsored by the New Century Institute, New York, a dual-nation think tank based in the United States and Taiwan established by Prof. Lung-chu Chen with the New York Law School. Chen, an adviser to President Chen Shui-bian, has championed efforts to get U.S. backing for Taiwan's entry into the United Nations.

Other prominent scholars who are expected to speak at the seminar include Richard Bush, a former American Institute in Taiwan (AIT) chairman, who is now director of the Brookings Institution's Center for Northeast Asian Policy Studies; Prof. Andrew Nathan with Columbia University and author of the book China's Transition; and Yeh Jiunn-rong, minister of the Research, Development and Evaluation Commission.
Tsai arrived in Washington, D.C. Tuesday where she attended a closed-door symposium organized by the Brookings Institution.

During that symposium, Tsai exchanged views with a group of U.S. think tank scholars on Taiwan's constitutional re-engineering plan and Beijing's plan to enact an "anti-secession law" targeting Taiwan, according to Richard Bush, host of the symposium.
