DOC.HEADLINE: YU SHYI-KUN SAYS HE WILL NOT STAY ON AS PREMIER

TEXT.P: Premier Yu Shyi-kun divulged for the first time Friday that he will not remain on as premier after the Cabinet resigns en masse Jan. 24.
Yu told reporters while making an inspection tour in central Taiwan that he has been at his current post for three years.
"It's long enough for me. I will be very pleased when somebody takes over my job in the upcoming Cabinet reshuffle. I want to take a rest to refresh my mind," Yu said

Noting that the government's work will not be affected by the departure of any single official, Yu said he is very confident of the competence and dedication of the administrative team led by President Chen Shui-bian.

In line with constitutional precedent, Yu and all Cabinet members will resign en masse Jan. 24 to pave the way for the formation of a new Cabinet ahead of the Feb. 1 inauguration of a new Legislative Yuan.
Asked who his successor might be, Yu refrained from making any comments.
"I'm not in a position to speculate because the appointment of premier rests with the president himself, not anybody else," Yu said.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
Tokyo, Jan.14 ( CNA) The Japan Times: NHK censored TV show due to 'political pressure'
NHK altered its 2001 documentary on a mock tribunal over Japan's wartime sexual slavery before it was aired because of'political pressure'from senior lawmakers in the Liberal Democratic Party, the TV program's chief producer said Thursday.

DOC.HEADLINE: STATE-OWNED ENTERPRISES REVIEWING NAME-CHANGE PLAN: OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: Vice Minister of Economic Affairs Chen Ruey-long said Friday that state-owned enterprises are currently reviewing the plan to change designations to avoid confusion with mainland China, but no assessments have yet been received from companies overseen by the ministry.
Chen said he doesn't think that changing the names of the Chinese Petroleum Corp. (CPC) and the China Shipbuilding Corp. (CSBC) will negatively affect their operations.
Chen was responding to media reports that said the Executive Yuan had asked the CPC and the CSBC to submit their name-change plan by the end of January and implement the changes by the end of June.
"If the Executive Yuan sets a deadline for the enterprises to complete the name changes, the Ministry of Economic Affairs will meet it," Chen said.

President Chen Shui-bian first broached the idea of changing the names of overseas missions and state-owned enterprises in the run-up to the Dec. 11 legislative elections. The idea is to drop the words "China, " " Chinese" or "Chunghwa" (Chinese) to underscore Taiwan's identity and avoid confusion with mainland China.

Premier Yu Shui-kun said recently that the name-change idea is still being actively pursued, with the CPC, the CSBC, Chunghwa Telecom, the International Commercial Bank of China, Chunghwa Post, and the Central Trust of China being the top priorities.

"It is necessary to make a name-change of state-owned enterprises, " the vice economic affairs minister said, adding that the CPC and the CSBC are now working on the matter, hoping to find the best way to mitigate the impact on their operations.

"As the two companies have yet to submit their reports to the ministry, I have no way of predicting the actual expenses, but as long as the name changes are helpful to future operations, the expense will be bearable, " he said.

Asked whether the name changes will cause losses to hard-earned reputations and brand competitive edges, Chen said the CPC is mainly geared toward the domestic market, and its cooperation with foreign companies in exploration will not be affected by the name change.
The exports of oil products will hinge on quality and price, Chen added.
The technology and the quality of the CSBC have also won recognition, Chen said, and its operations have been good in recent years with customers lining up to place orders, he said.
"The Ministry of Economic Affairs is confident that the operations of the CSBC will not be affected by the name change," Chen said.

DOC.HEADLINE: NUMBER OF PAROLEES DOWN 5.4% IN FIRST 11 MONTHS OF 2004

TEXT.P: There were 7,206 prisoners released on parole in the first 11 months of 2004, down 5.4 percent from the same period last year, according to statistics released by the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS) Friday.
In terms of offenses committed by the parolees, those who were in violation of drug prevention laws accounted for the most at 2,458, or 34.1 percent, followed by burglary at 793, or 11 percent.
During the same period, 1,682 people had their parole revoked, down 19.4 percent from the same period last year.

DOC.HEADLINE: 10 MAINLAND CHINESE ILLEGAL IMMIGRANTS ROUNDED UP
DOC.DATELINE: Keelung, northern Taiwan, Jan. 14 (CNA) (By Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Ten mainland Chinese citizens -- eight men and two women -- were rounded up in waters off Taiwan's northeastern cape of Lungtung Thursday night as they were trying to sneak into the country, Coast Guard Administration (CGA) authorities reported Friday.

Acting on tips, two teams of agents from the Keelung CGA and police from Juifang, Taipei County, began searching the Lungtung coast near Taiwan's northernmost tip of Pitouchiao around 7: 20 p.m. Thursday.

With the help of radar, police found the mainlanders jumping from a Fuchi Fishing Port-registered boat into a sampan, which had sailed about 350 meters off Lungtung to pick up the smuggled human cargo.
All of the mainlanders were brought to a nearby police station for questioning, while the skippers of the two Taiwan fishing vessels were ordered to sail to Auti Port in Juifang for questioning.

DOC.HEADLINE: OVER 70 PERCENT OF TAIWAN PEOPLE AGAINST TEACHERS GOING ON STRIKE

TEXT.P: More than 70 percent of Taiwan people, including teachers, think teachers should not be able to go on strike and are against legislation that would allow them to do so, the results of an opinion poll conducted recently by the Ministry of Education showed Friday.

Less than 10 percent of Taiwan people agreed that teachers should be thought of as belonging to "labor groups, " which would be entitled to establish their own union, the poll conducted several weeks ago found.

The Ministry of Education polled ordinary adult citizens by telephone who were chosen randomly islandwide Dec. 24-29 and received 2,025 valid responses. During the same period, the ministry surveyed the country's teachers from elementary schools as well as junior high schools via mailed questionnaires and received 1,424 valid replies. Both groups were asked the same questions.

The poll found that 87 percent of the public and 78 percent of teachers surveyed agreed that existing teachers' groups as being transformed into professional academic associations that are devoted to upgrading Taiwan's education and improving teaching quality.

A total of 76.8 percent of the public do not agree that teachers should be allowed to go on strike or suspend their teaching work en masse, compared with 46.6 percent of the teachers who also were disinclined to allow teachers to strike. About 32 percent of the teachers responding agreed with the strike notion.
Only 8.2 percent of the public and 5.8 percent of the teachers agreed that teachers' groups ought to be classified as "labor groups" instead of "professional groups."
Meanwhile, the poll found that more than 90 percent of the respondents think that teachers should be under regular professional monitoring and assessment.

About 60 percent said that school authorities or educational supervisory bodies have been "too lenient" toward teaching staff who have either abused their rights as teachers or who have been teaching improperly, the poll found.
The Ministry of Education conducted the poll prior to the Legislative Yuan debate over a draft bill that includes an article allowing teachers to form their own labor unions.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Washington Post: Iraq New Terror Breeding Ground; War Created Haven, CIA Advisers Report.
Iraq has replaced Afghanistan as the training ground for the next generation of "professionalized" terrorists, according to a report released yesterday by the National Intelligence Council, the CIA director's think tank, the paper said.

DOC.HEADLINE: VICE PRESIDENT UNVEILS TOWN-BUILDING PLANS FOR CENTRAL AMERICAN ALLIES

TEXT.P: Vice President Annette Lu spoke Friday of the government's plan to initiate town-building projects in Central America to boost the electronic integration of Taiwan's diplomatic allies in the region.

Addressing the closing ceremony of a seminar on the technological development outlook of Taiwan's industries, Lu said Taiwan will make use of its capacity and resources in information technology to help with the electronic integration of Central America.
The projects will involve the building of a "Taiwan park, " which will bring together local industries, in each Central American country with diplomatic relations with Taiwan, according to Lu.

While the Central American countries will provide land, manpower and long-term investment incentives, Taiwan will provide the technology and its experience in electronic integration, Lu said. Taiwan will also introduce its vocational training system into Central America to set up a Taiwan Institute in Central America.

Meanwhile, Lu noted that the Democratic Pacific Union is set to be established in Taipei on August 14 and that an "e-Pacific" project aiming at narrowing the digital gap will be put forth during the event.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT PREPARING FOR JAN. 27 TRIP TO SOUTH PACIFIC ALLIES

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian will leave Taipei Jan. 27 for a two-nation South Pacific state visit that will take him to Palau and the Solomon Islands, Deputy Presidential Secretary-General James Huang said Friday.
Chen will be the first Republic of China president ever to visit the nation's diplomatic allies in the South Pacific, Huang said.
"President Chen's Jan. 27-31 visit is aimed at demonstrating Taiwan's concern for South Pacific stability and its determination to help with the region's sustainable development," Huang said.

Chen will first visit Palau to attend the inauguration of President Tommy Remengesau Jr.'s second term on Jan. 28. On his way back from the Solomon Islands, Huang said, Chen will make a five-hour transit stop in the U.S. territory of Guam.

Huang said Chen will be accompanied by a small entourage on his upcoming South Pacific journey. Members of the entourage will include Minister of Foreign Affairs Tan Sun Chen, Chiayi County Magistrate Su Tseng-chang and Taitung County Magistrate Hsu Ching-yuan.

According to the itinerary unveiled by the Presidential Office, Chen will meet with Palau President Remengesau shortly after his arrival on the afternoon of Jan. 27. Later on, he will address the Palau Parliament. In the evening, Chen will host a dinner in honor of Taiwan expatriates there.

On Jan. 28, Chen will first attend Remengesau's inauguration for a second term. In the afternoon, Remengesau will personally steer a yacht to take Chen on a leisure voyage, including visiting a dolphin park. In the evening, Chen will attend Remengesau's inaugural dinner party.

Chen will leave Palau for the Solomon Islands Jan. 29. On that evening, Chen will view a qualifying match for the 2006 Oceania Youth Football Games in the company of the Solomon Islands prime minister and then attend a welcoming dinner in his honor.

On Jan. 30, Chen will meet with the ROC agricultural mission stationed in the Solomon Islands, attend the inaugural ceremony for a Taiwan-donated hospital and visit a children's hospital. In the afternoon, Chen will give interviews to news media. In the evening, Chen will host a "thank you" dinner in honor of Solomon Islands officials and staff of the ROC Embassy and the agricultural mission.

Chen will meet with Solomon Islands Governor-General Nathaniel Waena Jan. 31, deliver a speech at the country's parliament and sign a joint communique before leaving for a transit stop in Guam. Chen will meet with the administrative leader and other political figures during his five-hour stay in Guam. He will also attend a dinner to be given by Taiwan expatriates in his honor before leaving for home.
Chen is scheduled to return to Taipei on the night of Jan. 31 Taipei time.

DOC.HEADLINE: TWO INDONESIANS GET SCHOLARSHIPS AS PART OF TSUNAMI AID
DOC.DATELINE: Tainan, southern Taiwan, Jan. 14 (CNA) (By Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: National Cheng Kung University's (NCKU) IMBA school has given two Indonesian students full scholarships as part of tsunami relief efforts.

Ely Susanto and Sun Kuang-hsiung (Badri) were each awarded the scholarships by the NCKU Institute of Business Management, enabling them to continue their graduate studies free of charge, plus have the opportunity to work at the university to earn a monthly allowance.
A relief drive for the two was begun Jan. 11 and originally only solicited donations of clothing or other daily necessities.
Nevertheless, NCKU students and teaching staff responded to the activity so overwhelmingly that thousands of articles of clothing and other items were donated - far more than the two could use.

NCKU authorities then decided to transport the donated goods to the Indonesian province of Aceh, one of the closest population centers to the Dec. 26 magnitude 9.0 earthquake's epicenter. The killer jolt and resulting tsunamis have killed at least 160,000 people in countries surrounding the Indian Ocean. About half of the victims were in Indonesia.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Shares prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) opened low but closed higher Friday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 35.58 points to close at 5,889.52.

The bourse opened at 5,831.7 points and fluctuated between 5,895.35 and 5,813.15 during trading. A total of 3.1 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$56.84 billion (US$1.76 billion).

All eight major stock categories gained ground, with construction stocks moving up the most by 3.9 percent, followed by textile shares by 2.1 percent, paper and pulp shares by 1.5 percent, both cement shares and foodstuff issues by 1.1 percent banking and financial stocks by 1.0 percent, plastics and chemicals issues by 0.4 percent, and machinery and electronics stocks by 0.2 percent.
Gainers outnumbered losers 488 to 2559, with 156 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: BILL PUSHED TO ALLOW INDIVIDUALS TO POSSESS LAND OWNED BY GODS

TEXT.P: Looking to buy that prime piece of real estate in Taiwan? Better check first that it has not already been "deeded" to one of the many gods revered by Chinese.

Many lands around Taiwan, particularly off main streets and roads, are "owned" by gods and goddesses, including the god of the land, Emperor Guan Yu and Matsu, Goddess of Sea. After a long history of religious freedom in Taiwan since the island was under the Japanese colonial rules before 1945, Buddhist or other religion followers around Taiwan during the Japanese-occupied era tended to get together annually for ceremonies to worship their gods and bought property where the god icons were located and registered the lands under the ownership of "god societies."
Since "god societies" are not institutions or owned by anybody, the shrines as well as the surrounding lands were disowned, at least legally, the officials said.

Officials from the Department of Land Administration under the Ministry of the Interior said Friday that such issues can be solved if the cadaster streamlining draft bill is passed into law by the Legislative Yuan.

The cadaster streamlining draft bill, authored by the land administration department, stipulates that institutional organizations established by religious followers or a group of individual followers who have been taking care of the gods and their shrines can claim ownership of the land where the icons are located.
If the draft bill is passed into law, institutional groups or follower groups who have been taking care of the icons can apply to claim ownership, the officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT, PFP COOPERATION ON LEGISLATIVE LEADERSHIP ELECTION ON HOLD

TEXT.P: Cooperation between the "pan-blue alliance" of the Kuomintang (KMT) and the People First Party (PFP) on the election of the speaker and vice speaker of the Legislative Yuan and other issues will only be finalized after a meeting between the leaders of the two parties, a KMT official said Friday.

KMT Legislator and Executive Director of the KMT Policy Committee Tseng Yung-chuan made the remarks amid media reports that the KMT has reversed its original plan of a "KMT-KMT" ticket to a "KMT-PFP" ticket in the legislative leadership election on Feb. 1, and that PFP legislators will conduct a straw poll to choose a candidate for the vice speakership.

Reports said that although the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) is actively courting the PFP, and has reportedly sounded out the possibility of cooperation in various major posts, including Cabinet positions and the legislative leadership, most PFP legislators have reservations over the cooperation of the two parties, given that they are at opposite ends of the political spectrum with the PFP being pro-unification and the DPP pro-independence.
The suggestion of DPP-PFP cooperation is only still alive because the United States wants PFP Chairman James Soong to get involved in cross-strait affairs, the reports also said.
Tseng said that the KMT will throw its full support behind current Legislative Speaker Wang Jin-pyng for re-election, but has yet to decide who to support for vice speaker.
"Everything will have to wait until a meeting between KMT Chairman Lien Chan and Soong for a final determination to be made, " Tseng added. Soong is currently on a visit in the United States.

Asked about a reported KMT-PFP ticket for the legislative leadership, Wang said that he was not aware of the KMT and the PFP talking on the issue, but did say that media reports could have some "reference value."

Regarding which PFP legislator would be most suitable to serve as vice speaker, the incumbent speaker said that "as long as he or she is a candidate recommended jointly by the KMT and the PFP, that person will be the best choice."
Asked about the fate of the current vice speaker, Chiang Ping-kun, like Wang, a KMT vice chairman, Wang said that he is sure the KMT will make an "overall consideration."

On the other hand, Liu Wen-hsiung, PFP caucus whip in the legislature, said that the jury is still out on the reported KMT-PFP ticket, saying that the PFP caucus will meet next Monday to decide on the mechanism of electing the leadership of the legislature.
Meanwhile, a DPP legislator said that whether DPP-PFP cooperation can get off the ground will depend on Soong.
Tsai Huang-liang, DPP caucus whip in the legislature, was responding to other DPP legislators' questions about the progress of DPP-PFP cooperation.
Tsai said that what other PFP legislators say is irrelevant and only Soong can make the "right historic decision " for the sake of political stability.

Relations between the KMT and the PFP soured after the Dec. 11 legislative elections despite the alliance maintaining a majority in the 225-seat legislature, with the KMT garnering 79 seats, and the PFP 34 seats. The KMT added 11 seats, but mostly came at the expense of the PFP, which lost 12 seats.

The PFP was miffed because the KMT's "voter-allocation " mechanism failed to include the PFP legislative candidates and because it was displeased about the distribution of election subsidies over the "Lien-Soong" ticket in the 2004 presidential election.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market gained ground Friday, as Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index futures for January moved up 13 points to close at 5,893, with 31,644 contracts changing hands.
TAIEX Index futures for February rose 17 points to finish at 5,897, with 7,012 contract transactions, while March futures surged 28 points to close at 5,893, with 47 contracts traded.
June futures gained 21 points to finish at 5,884, with 12 contract transactions, while September futures increased 11 points to close at 5,795, with 18 contracts traded.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Friday at 5,880 points for January and February, 5,865 points for March, 5,863 points for June and 5,784 points for September.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were mostly higher.
January TE futures moved up 0.05 points to close at 215.6, with 3,605 contracts changing hands, while February TE futures dipped 0.70 points to finish at 215.30, with 1,242 contract transactions.
March TE futures decreased 0.20 points to close at 212.85, with two contracts traded. No transactions were recorded for other months.
January TF futures surged 5.8 points to finish at 1,014.2, with 4,000 contracts changing hands, while February TF futures gained 5.8 points to close at 1,013, with 2,406 contracts traded.

March TF futures increased 6.6 points to finish at 1,013, with eight contract transactions, while June TF futures rose 4.4 points to finish at 1,005, with one contract tradednsaction, and September TF futures moved up 6.2 points to close at 1,003, with one contract transaction.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC, MALAWI LEADERS CALL FOR RESOLVING DISPUTES THROUGH DIALOGUE

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian and Malawi President Bingu Wa Mutharika signed a joint communique Friday reaffirming their commitment to further promoting bilateral cooperation in various fields.

Chen and Mutharika expressed their sympathy for all those who were affected by the devastating Dec. 26 earthquake and subsequent tsunami in a dozen Asian and African countries around the Indian Ocean.

The two presidents also said in their joint communique that all countries around the world should resolve their disputes through dialogue based on the principles of sovereignty, independence and equality. They also called on world leaders to work for democracy, rule of law, human rights and global peace.

In the joint communique, Mutharika reiterated his country's support for the Republic of China's bid to join the United Nations, the World Health Organization and other major international institutions, while Chen reaffirmed the ROC's commitment to sharing its successful economic development experience with Malawi and assisting the southeast African ally in its national development.

Under a Taiwan-Malawi cooperative agreement, the joint communique said, the ROC government will finance Malawi's parliamentary building construction project, offer funds for some locomotives for its new railway and help with its e-government development plan, community development and fishery development. The ROC government also promises to encourage Taiwan's private sector to invest in building fertilizer plants in Malawi.
Later in the day, Chen presided over a ceremony with full military honors to bid farewell to Mutharika at the end of his five-day state visit.

DOC.HEADLINE: LUNAR NEW YEAR CHARTER FLIGHTS PRELUDE CROSS-STRAIT LINKS: ANALYSIS

TEXT.P: Charter flights for mainland-based Taiwan businessmen during the upcoming Lunar New Year holiday will be a prelude to direct transport links across the Taiwan Strait, according to an analysis by the international ratings agency Standard and Poor's (SP).
SP predicted that the special services will presage the opening of direct transport links between Taiwan and mainland China should the two sides reach agreement on the issue.
According to SP, there is little possibility of armed conflict across the strait and the most likely outcome in the region is "continued peace" despite rising tension between the two sides.

"Tighter economic links will continue to provide incentives to leaders on both sides to avoid any destabilizing military moves, while the very nature of deepening economic ties provides China with a newer, more subtle lever to influence Taiwan politics," it said.

Meanwhile, representatives from Taiwan and the mainland were slated to meet again Saturday in Macau to iron out technical issues related to the special charter services for homecoming Taiwan businessmen from the mainland during the holiday period in early February.
Share prices of aviation companies such as China Airlines, EVA Airways Corp. and Far East Air Transport Corp. surged Friday on the Taiwan Stock Exchange on the back of the new development.

Market watchers said the charter services issue will provide short-term leads for the market, but warned that this does not guarantee profits over the long term, because the entry of mainland carriers on cross-strait routes will not be overwhelmingly profitable for Taiwan competitors.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. DOLLAR RISES ON TAIPEI FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar rose against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Friday, gaining NT$0.151 to close at NT$32.019.
A total of US$751 million changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at NT$31.920 and fluctuated between NT$31.800 and NT$32.250.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMOSA PLASTICS ANNOUNCES BUILDING OF 1ST 12-INCH WAFER PLANT

TEXT.P: The Formosa Plastics Corp. announced Friday that Formosa Komatsu Silicon Corp. will invest NT$7 billion (US$220 million) in its industrial park in Mailiao, Yunlin County, to build the nation's first 12-inch silicon wafer plant.

Officials of the FPC, which holds a 24 percent share of Formosa Komatsu Silicon Corp., said the plant will produce 50,000 wafers per month in the initial stage, eventually increasing production to 100,000 wafers per month.

The production will supply the needs of Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co., United Microelectronics Corp. and other semiconductor manufacturers in Taiwan, as well as companies in mainland China, the officials said.
"In the future, the production capacity will continue to expand depending on the needs of the market," the officials added.
They noted that Formosa Komatsu Silicon Corp. is currently the largest eight-inch wafer producer and maintains the largest market share in Taiwan.

The officials estimated that Taiwan's demand for 12-inch wafers was around 100,000 units last year and they predicted that it will increase to 300,000 units monthly by 2006, or 20 percent of the global demand of around 1.5 million wafers per month.

They said the investment project falls into the category of a new strategic industry, enabling it to enjoy five-year tax-free incentive treatment, and that the industrial park also has other investment incentives, while its water and electricity are cheaper compared with other facilities in the same sector, making the project a highly competitive one.

DOC.HEADLINE: VICE PRESIDENT'S CENTRAL AMERICA VISIT POSTPONED

TEXT.P: A planned visit by Vice President Annette Lu to the Republic of China's diplomatic allies in Central America in mid-February will be postponed for a month or two, Deputy Presidential Secretary-General James Huang said Friday.

Lu was originally to head a delegation of local industry and commerce executives to visit Central American allies in mid-February to attend a regional development forum and survey the industrial development demands in those countries to serve as reference for the government in drafting technological cooperative programs.
Huang said Lu's travel plan has received enthusiastic response from the ROC's Central American allies.
"Many of our allies in the region have come up with new visions and new proposals for cooperation with Taiwan in developing their industries and economies," Huang said.

Against this backdrop, Huang said, preparatory work has to be adjusted. With a view to enhancing the visit's efficacy, Huang said, the government needs more time to prepare and will invite more suitable industrial leaders to join Lu's mission based on Central American allies' suggestions.
Huang said Lu's trip will be conducted at some point in the first half of this year.

DOC.HEADLINE: DRAFT LAW DUE TO STEM OUTFLOW OF CURRENCY IN EMERGENCIES

TEXT.P: Lawmakers of the ruling and opposition parties reached consensus and hammered out a bill Friday to deal with currency exchanges in cases of war or other catastrophe either at home or abroad.

Under the terms of the bill to govern foreign currency exchanges in cases of "natural disasters, war, military conflict and economic catastrophes at home or abroad that might greatly affect Taiwan's economic stability, " the Executive Yuan will be entitled to order banks to stop currency exchange services by wholly or partially freezing exchanges or depositing the money into appointed banks.
Banks that violate the mandate by the Executive Yuan in similar cases will be fined up to NT$3 million (US$93,800) and the exchanged money will be sequestered, according to the draft law.

DOC.HEADLINE: ECONOMICS MINISTRY CALLS FOR PRIVATE PARTICIPATION IN TRADE TALKS

TEXT.P: Vice Minister of Economic Affairs Chen Ruey-long urged the private sector Friday to take a positive part in government-led international trade talks.

While the opinions of commercial and industrial groups and non-governmental organizations (NGOs) have proved influential in the progress of World Trade Organization (WTO) talks, the government also needs the support of the commercial and industrial sectors when negotiating on free trade agreements with other countries, Chen said.
Chen made the remarks while addressing the opening of a seminar on the role of commercial and industrial organizations in international trade and economic affairs.

Representatives of foreign business groups including the American Chamber of Commerce, the British Chamber of Commerce and the Australian Chamber of Commerce and Industry were invited to the event to share their experience in taking part in international trade talks with members of the local business community.

Local groups attending the seminar included the Chinese National Federation of Industries, the General Chamber of Commerce of the ROC and the National Association of Small- and Medium-Sized Enterprises.

Chen pointed out that the importance of participation by commercial and industrial organizations and NGOs has been shown in the development of the Asia Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum, the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD) and the WTO.

For example, Chen said, anti-globalization demonstrations were staged by NGOs during the 1999 WTO ministerial meeting in Seattle and the 2003 meeting in Cancun, which successfully postponed the WTO timetable for globalization.
In the past, businessmen in Taiwan have generally thought that international trade talks are the government's business and have seldom participated in such talks, Chen noted.
However, Chen went on, the participation of the business community is very important to ensure that international trade regulations and measures adopted by the government are practicable.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S 1ST INTERNATIONAL-LEVEL CRASH TEST LAB INAUGURATED

TEXT.P: The first international-level car crash test lab in Taiwan and Southeast Asia was officially inaugurated Friday in Changhua, central Taiwan.

Premier Yu Shyi-kun presided over the inauguration ceremony of the lab, set up by the Automotive Research and Training Center (ARTC) . Also present were Minister of Economic Affairs Ho Mei-yueh, Kenneth K.T. Yen, chairman of the Taiwan Transportation Vehicle Manufacturers Association and Lin Hsin-i, chairman of the Industrial Technology Research Institute.

Yu noted that if Taiwan wants to compete with other countries, it must upgrade its industry by making up for its deficiency in research and development, as well as marketing. He added that the inauguration of the crash test lab marks a giant step forward in the nation's automotive industry.

Ho, noting that Taiwan has a big opportunity of development in the Asian automotive industry, expressed the hope that with the inauguration of the lab, Taiwan will not only develop car parts and components but complete cars and make inroads into the OEM market, as well as integrate the steel, machinery and module sectors related to the automotive industry.

ARTC Chairman Wu Hai admitted that the setup of the lab is a little late compared to American and European counterparts, but said Taiwan has had many technology exchanges with laboratories in America, Europe and Japan during its establishment period and has invited foreign collision experts to Taiwan for their onsite guidance.
The ARTC will pursue test standard comparisons with overseas laboratories of the same nature and will seek mutual certification with other countries, he said.
Yu then witnessed the first crash test in the lab and was briefed by the ARTC staff.

The ARTC, established by the Ministry of Economic Affairs in accordance with the Automotive Industry Development Policy in October 1990, aims at assisting the development and upgrading of automobile and related industries, as well as protection of driving safety and consumer rights by offering internationally credible services of inspection and testing of cars and related components and parts.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Times: Prince's sorry mess.
The Prince of Wales is refusing to bow to political pressure for Prince Harry to make a formal apology in public for wearing a Nazi uniform to a friend's party. The Queen was deeply concerned by Harry's actions, which have provoked an international outcry and resulted in damaging headlines around the world for the Royal Family.
Financial Times: DTI (Department of Trade and Industry) backs down on bribery rules.
Business is facing months of uncertainty over anti-bribery rules, after a legal challenge forced the government to retreat on its earlier plans to water down the regulations. Ministers on Thursday promised to open the issue of bribery in overseas contracts up to a full public consultation after an anti-corruption lobby group threatened a legal challenge that could have disrupted the export financing system.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN DIVORCE RATE REACHES RECORD HIGH IN 2004: COUNSELOR

TEXT.P: A spokesman for a private organization dedicated to helping broken families claimed Friday that "one out of every 2.09 local married couples" divorced in 2004, an all-time high in Taiwan's history.

Liu Ko-ming, chief executive of the Taiwan True Love Family Association, quoted statistics compiled by the Ministry of the Interior (MOI) as saying that 131,453 couples married in 2004, while 62,796 couples divorced.

"The figures mean that one out of every 2.09 married couples ended up in divorce or that 172 couples divorced each day last year," Liu claimed, although as he made no mention of the actual number of married couples in Taiwan during the period, it was unclear as to how he arrived at his figure.

The 2004 divorce rate was much higher than the year-earlier level, Liu went on. In 2003, one out of every 2.66 couples divorced for a 37.59 percent divorce rate. In 2004, according to Liu, the divorce rate surged to 47.84 percent.

Quoting the MOI's 2003 tallies, Liu said 54 percent of local divorced men and 17.9 percent of divorced women remarried. The figures indicate that about 20 percent of couples who married in 2003 were divorcees, he claimed.
Noting that a high divorce rate usually means that the number of reorganized families will increase, Liu claimed that Taiwan has the world's fourth-largest number of reorganized families.

According to Liu, the United States ranks first in terms of the number of reorganized families. Quoting the results of U.S. surveys, only 40 percent of divorcees enjoy successful second marriages, while more than half of second marriages end in divorce.
"The high failure rate indicates that maintaining a second marriage may not be easy, " Liu said, adding that children from previous marriages can add difficulties to reorganized families.

With a view to helping divorcees intending to marry again adapt to their new families, Liu said his organization has decided to open a new service center to provide counseling for members of reorganized families.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The New York Times: Baseball Players and Owners Set Tougher Policy on Steroid Use.
Baseball players agreed to a stricter policy for steroids and other drugs that will include more tests and tougher penalties.
Wall Street Journal: Boeing Plans to End Production Of Its 717 Jet liners.
Boeing Co. is poised to announce today that it will shut down its single-aisle 717 jetliner production line as soon as the remaining orders are filled, most likely in the spring of 2006.

DOC.HEADLINE: EVERGREEN TO SHIP TAIWAN-DONATED RICE TO SRI LANKA FREE OF CHARGE

TEXT.P: Evergreen Marine Corp. will transport 1,000 tons of rice donated by Taiwan to Sri Lanka free of charge to help those affected by the Dec. 26 tsunami in the Indian Ocean, a company spokesman said Friday.

Evergreen has prepared 50 20-foot containers to transport the rice donated by the Council of Agriculture at the request of two local charity groups -- the Hsintien Rotary Club and the Taiwan Roots Medical Peace Corps -- to help tsunami victims in Sri Lanka, one of the hardest-hit areas.
The ship is scheduled to leave Taichung Harbor in central Taiwan Jan. 18 and will arrive in the Sri Lankan capital of Colombo Feb. 5.

The spokesman said that since the tsunami catastrophe, Evergreen has offered assistance in post-disaster relief efforts in various tsunami-hit countries, including transporting relief supplies to Malaysia and offering refrigerated containers to Thailand.
As of Wednesday, the public and private sectors in Taiwan had raised NT$600 million (US$18.82 million) in cash along with 169 tons of relief materials for South and Southeast Asian tsunami victims.
In addition to relief materials, Taiwan has sent 376 medical workers to the disaster areas to assist in disinfection work and offer medical services.

DOC.HEADLINE: LEGISLATURE PASSES FRAMEWORK CONVENTION ON TOBACCO CONTROL

TEXT.P: The Legislative Yuan passed a Framework Convention on Tobacco Control Friday ahead of the scheduled implementation of an international convention by the World Health Organization (WHO) that will go into force Feb. 27.

Lawmakers said the passage of the convention is a step forward in tobacco control which signifies Taiwan is keeping pace with international norms and standards. They claimed the move will be favorable to the island's bid to join the WHO.

Lin Ching-li, head of the tobacco control section of the John Tung Foundation, which had lobbied for the passage of the convention, said all anti-smoking organizations in Taiwan have been waiting for a long time for the convention to be passed.
Following the convention's passage, the Tobacco Hazards Prevention Act, which has been in effect for seven years, will have to be amended, Lin said.
She pointed out that prices of tobacco products in Taiwan are very low compared with some other countries and that the number of teenage smokers is increasing.
Lin proposed that the law be changed to raise the prices of tobacco products and forbid advertising and promotional activities for tobacco products.
She said Taiwan is the 51st country and the only non-WHO member to have passed the convention.
John Tung Foundation Executive Director Huang Chen-tai is set to leave for Geneva Jan. 31 for a WHO meeting on details concerning the implementation of the convention, she said.
The WHO Framework Convention on Tobacco Control was adopted during the 56th World Health Assembly that took place in May 2003 in Geneva. (Y.F. Low)

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN MUST BE COMPETITIVE: AMCHAM

TEXT.P: Taiwan must crystallize its potential competitiveness into concrete action while confronting heated competition if it wants to prevent itself from being marginalized, an official of the American Chamber of Commerce (AmCham) in Taipei urged Friday.

Richard Vuylsteke, chief executive officer of AmCham in Taipei, made the call while giving a speech in a seminar sponsored by the Bureau of Foreign Trade (BOFT) to exchange experiences and viewpoints on international trade with domestic and foreign trade and economic groups.

As Taiwan moves toward becoming a mature economy, the country must realize that it should be able to challenge strong rivals to avoid turning into an outcast, rather than competing against weak players, Vuylsteke advised, adding that Taiwan is doomed to fail should it set its sights only on mediocre competitors.

Although Taiwan ranks high on world competitiveness surveys by international ratings agencies, he said that the country must seek to transform its potential advantages into concrete moves to maintain sustainable growth.

Future challenges lie in the service sector, and the transitional pain of the industrial upgrading process from a manufacturing-intensive economy -- rising unemployment -- is an inevitable accompanying phenomenon, he said.
The AmCham representative called for the government and enterprises to heed the issue and urged them to craft a clear-cut development strategy.
Citing WTO reports, he said that Taiwan should do its best to promote service-oriented businesses in the coming 18 months on the grounds that Taiwan lacks large-scale companies in that sector.

Taiwan has a pro-active government and its people are diligent and outstanding, he said, expressing his belief that the country will certainly succeed as long as both the government and the private sector do what they need to do to make money.

As long as Taiwan stands firm to keep its economic strength and create sound and updated law enforcement, foreign investment will flock in, regardless of whatever mainland China or other countries might do, he suggested.
AmCham in Taipei strongly supports Taiwan's globalization drive and is happy to offer creative and constructive information while seeking cooperation with local businesses, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA HAILS EUROPEAN PARLIAMENT RESOLUTION TO KEEP CHINA ARMS BAN

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) expressed a hearty welcome Friday to the latest European Parliament resolution asking the 25-member European Union (E.U.) to keep its ban on arms sales to mainland China.

The European Parliament, the E.U.'s legislative arm, passed a resolution on human rights conditions in Tibet Thursday in which it urged the European Commission -- the E.U.'s administrative body -- and all E.U. member states not to lift the ban on arms sales to the mainland.

The resolution said the arms ban should be maintained until after the E.U. legislates a binding code of conduct regarding arms exports and until the mainland adopts concrete measures to improve its domestic human rights conditions and fully respects the rights and interests of its minority ethnic groups.

It marked the fourth time that the European Parliament has passed a resolution to call for keeping the mainland arms sales ban. The parliament passed similar resolutions Dec. 18, 2003, Feb. 10, 2004 and Nov. 17, 2004.
The MOFA said in a news release that it welcomes the latest resolution and hopes that the European Commission the and E.U. member states will respect it.
The E.U. imposed the arms sales ban after the 1989 Tiananmen Square massacre in which a student-led pro-democracy demonstration was crushed by military forces.

DOC.HEADLINE: ECONOMICS MINISTER LEAVES FOR LOS ANGELES

TEXT.P: Minister of Economic Affairs Ho Mei-yueh left for Los Angeles Friday to attend a board meeting of the Taiwanese Chamber of Commerce of North America.

Ho will deliver a keynote speech at the meeting, which opened Jan. 13 and will run through Jan. 16, to explain to Taiwanese expatriates the country's economic developments and to encourage them to invest in their homeland, according to Ministry of Economic Affairs officials.
After concluding her visit, Ho will proceed to Japan Jan. 17 to explore opportunities for cooperation between the two countries, particularly in the information technology field, the officials added.
During her stay in Japan, Ho will visit various leading Japanese firms, they revealed.

Taiwan and Japan are very complementary in the information technology industry, given that Japan obtains many patents and advanced technologies while Taiwan has great ability in manufacturing, a good supply chain for IT products and experience in the research and development of new products, the officials noted.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI MAYOR TO VISIT AUSTRALIA, CANCELS TRIP TO THAILAND

TEXT.P: Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou will travel to Australia Saturday to take part in the closing ceremony of the 2005 Deaf Olympics in Melbourne.

Speaking to reporters at his office, Ma said that he will only participate in the event Sunday and will pay a visit to Melbourne Mayor John So the next day before flying back to Taiwan later that same day.
Ma said he had decided to cancel planned visits to Sydney and Bangkok, originally slated for Jan. 17 and Jan. 18-19, respectively.
The mayor's decision to shorten his visit came following news that a four-year-old Taipei girl remained seriously ill and in a coma over the past few days in a hospital in central Taichung County.

The girl, who had been beaten up by her drunk father, was forced to be transferred to Taichung for treatment after many hospitals in Taipei refused to treat her under the excuse of no available hospital beds.

The incident aroused outrage among the public, who are furious and blame the various municipal hospitals who were contacted by the Emergency Operations Center for the fiasco. The head of the municipal health bureau apologized and resigned.

Ma acknowledged that the incident has brought shame to Taipei City, which prides itself on its medical facilities and personnel. Meanwhile, The mayor's approval rate has dropped to 67 percent -- the lowest level since he assumed his second four-year term in 2002.

DOC.HEADLINE: BILL GOVERNING INTELLIGENCE WORK PASSED

TEXT.P: A law governing the country's intelligence work was approved by the Legislative Yuan Friday.
The National Intelligence Work Law puts the country's secret intelligence agencies under the supervision of the legislature and obliges intelligence workers to stay out of politics.

Among the intelligence agencies covered by the law are the National Security Bureau, the Military Intelligence Bureau and the Political Warfare Bureau under the Ministry of National Defense, the Investigation Bureau under the Ministry of Justice and the National Police Administration under the Ministry of the Interior.
The law obliges workers of these intelligence agencies to be politically neutral and prohibits them for working for any political parties, political groups or candidates for public office.

They should not abuse their office to persuade others to join or not join any political parties, should not provide aid to any political parties, should not set up cells of any political parties and should not spread the ideology of any political parties in their agencies.

In order to ensure that intelligence workers obey the law, it also provides for the legislature's supervision of intelligence work, including oral reports on their work by the chiefs of the various intelligence agencies to the Legislative Yuan every legislative session, in addition to written reports at the end of each year.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAINLAND CHINA MISSES CHANCE TO ENGAGE WITH TAIWAN: OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: Mainland China has missed a good chance to engage with Taiwan more positively by refusing to allow Taiwan officials to take part in talks on charter flight services between Taiwan and the mainland during the Chinese New Year holiday, an official from the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) said Friday.

MAC Vice Chairman and Spokesman Chiu Tai-shan claimed that the charter flight services, even if launched successfully, will not be better than the similar services provided in 2003 because of the absence of Taiwan's policy-making officials at the talks.

The mainland, which has refused contact with Taiwan since 1999 over political differences, rejected the participation of MAC officials or officials from the Straits Exchange Foundation at the charter flight talks poised to open in Macau Saturday.
Chiu said four Taiwan delegates, headed by Chang Kuo-cheng, director-general of the Civil Aeronautics Administration, will take part in the talks.

In order to bring about the charter flight services that will allow Taiwan businessmen residing on the mainland to come directly to Taiwan for the Chinese New Year and to return directly to the mainland after the holiday, Chiu said the government has gone to great lengths to accommodate Beijing's requirements about the venue and timing of the negotiations.

He said the Taiwan authorities have show maximum flexibility without compromising security to lure the mainland into the talks, and has worked out several options that will provide the most convenient flight services for the Taiwan businessmen.

Unfortunately, Chiu went on, the mainland insisted on downgrading the negotiations into business talks between air carriers from both sides of the strait and denying the appearance of any Taiwan officials at the talks.
However, he added, the charter flight negotiations prove that the mainland and Taiwan can shelve their political disputes and work together for the benefit of people on both sides of the strait.

DOC.HEADLINE: MORE AID FOR TSUNAMI VICTIMS

TEXT.P: More than two weeks after the Dec. 26 catastrophe caused by tsunami in the Indian Ocean, donations for the victims continues to stream into local charity groups, according to a statement issued by the Ministry of the Interior Friday.

Citing statistics compiled by the ministry, the statement said a total of NT$1.4 billion (US$44.4 million) has been raised by 27 charity groups that registered with the ministry to raise funds for the victims in countries struck by the tsunami.

The ministry said these charity groups should follow the ministry's regulations in raising and using the donations and should present a report to the ministry after completing the fund-raising activities and disposing of the funds.

According to the ministry's records, the three groups that have raised the most funds are the Tzu Chi Foundation, which has raised NT$450 million, the Red Cross Society of the Republic of China, which has raised NT$420 million and World Vision Taiwan, which has raised NT$250 million.
Meanwhile Minister of Foreign Affairs Tan Sun Chen said the warehouse designated by the government as the depot for relief materials for the tsunami victims has already been filled to capacity.

He promised that all the supplies will be transported to the disaster regions by Jan. 28, adding that the focus of the relief operation has now turned from urgent action to reconstruction, in which Taiwan will play an active role.

Also Friday, the leader of a 17-member medial team that had just returned from the tsunami-hit island of Phuket in Thailand Thursday said his team has helped with the prevention of contagious diseases on that island since its arrival Jan. 4.

Lin Tin, vice director-general of the Center for Disease Control and the leader of the team, said their work has been taken over by six Taiwan medical workers who arrived on Phuket Wednesday to replace them.

Noting that the Thai authorities have conducted a well-organized relief operation and that the relief teams from other countries have some good practices that are unknown to Taiwan, Lin said the Taiwan medical workers have learned many valuable lessons from their experience on Phuket.
Just as Lin shared his experiences with journalists in Taipei, around 30 medical workers in Kaohsiung were given a briefing about Indonesia by a health expert from that country.

The medial workers, brought together by the Health Department of the Kaohsiung city government from hospitals in the metropolitan Kaohsiung area, are expected to head for Indonesia Jan. 28 to help with the relief operation there.

DOC.HEADLINE: LEGISLATURE APPROVES AMENDMENT TO NATIONAL ASSEMBLY ELECTION LAW

TEXT.P: The Legislative Yuan approved Friday an amendment to the National Assembly Election Law stipulating that the future mission-oriented assembly will have 300 members.
According to the revised law, the National Assembly members will be elected proportionally based on the number of ballots that the political parties or electoral alliances garner in elections.

Political parties registered with the authorities and electoral alliances formed by 20 or more candidates can register their candidacy with the electoral authorities and the candidates nominated should be 23 or older, it states.

The National Assembly election should be called within six months of the promulgation of constitutional reform bills and laws for changing the national territory by the Legislative Yuan and three months after the legislature approves an impeachment motion against the president and vice president of the republic, it adds.
Of every four National Assembly members-elect nominated by political parties or electoral alliances, at least one should be female, while of every 30, at least one should be an aboriginal, it says.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Saturday, Jan. 15, or the sixth day of the 12th month of the Year of the Goat according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1759: The British Museum, the first great public assembly of antiquities, opens.
1878: Women receive degrees for the first time at London University.
1913: The first telephone line between New York and Berlin is inaugurated.
1918: Gamal Nasser, first president of the Republic of Egypt, is born.
1929: Martin Luther King Jr., U.S. clergyman and leader of the civil rights movement in the 1960s and winner of the Nobel Peace prize in 1964, is born.
1932: The League of Nations formally sets up a Manchuria investigation team after Japanese officers in Shenyang (Mukden) sabotage the Southern Manchuria Railroad and ambush northeastern Chinese troops.
1942: Chinese troops win the third Battle of Changsa against invading Japanese forces.
1943: Japanese forces are driven from Guadalcanal Island in the Pacific in World War II.
1945: Chinese expeditionary forces capture Namkhan in northern Burma.
1949: Tientsin falls to communist forces.
1951: Wu San-lien is elected mayor of Taipei after the Executive Yuan grants Taiwan the authority to carry out self-government by popular election in counties and cities.
1960: Republic of Vietnam President Ngo Dinh Diem arrives in Taipei for a five-day visit.
1962: The Republic of China establishes diplomatic relations with Chad.
1964: The Shihmen Reservoir's hydroelectric power plant begins operations.
1971: Egyptian President Anwar el-Sadat officially opens the Answan High Dam on the River Nile.
1973: U.S. President Richard Nixon orders a halt to the bombing of Vietnam by American warplanes as the Paris peace conference opens.
1976: John R. Hubbard, president of the University of Southern California at Los Angeles, and John Paul Schwada, president of the University of Arizona at Tucson, arrive in Taipei for a weeklong visit.
1986: Soviet Communist party chief Mikhail Gorbachev calls for ridding the earth of nuclear weapons within 15 years.
1988: The South Korean government announces the results of an investigation into the explosion of a Korea Airlines plane. Kim Hyon Hui, a North Korean woman who was operating as a secret agent, is said to have been involved in the incident.
1990: Bulgaria's parliament abolishes the Communist Party's monopoly on power.
1990: Thousands of furious East Germans tear apart the Berlin headquarters of the Stasi, the old regime's secret police and the machinery of postwar communist repression.
1993: ROC and Philippine officials sign an agreement in Manila, setting guidelines for transforming the former U.S. naval facility at Subic Bay into an industrial complex.
1994: Lee Yuan-tseh succeeds Wu Ta-you as president of Academia Sinica.
1998: Indonesian President Suharto reaches an accord with the International Monetary Fund on an austerity program to stop the country's economic meltdown.
2000: A special ROC delegation led by Judicial Yuan President Weng Yueh-sheng attends the inaugural ceremony of Guatemalan President Alfonso Portillo Cabrera.
2001: Taiwan's Council of Grand Justices rules that the Executive Yuan did not follow due process of law in halting construction of the Fourth Nuclear Power Plant.
2002: A sanctuary in hilly Maolin Township in southern Taiwan of the striped blue crow butterfly, the annual appearance of which has long been a spectacular feast to the eye for butterfly watchers, is officially opened to visitors.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "A wise man wants to be slow in speech and diligent in conduct."

The Straits Times: SIM to be Singapore's fourth university.
Singapore will have a fourth university, a privately-funded and privately-run institution, by next year.
The Singapore Institute of Management (SIM) , which already has 5,000 full-time students and 11,000 part-time students, including 5,000 on its open university programme, will be restructured into two arms.
SIM will continue to run degree programmes in partnership with overseas universities.
The other arm, which will be called SIM University, will be granted university status by the Education Ministry to award its own degrees from next year.

It announced yesterday that it had mandated the Singapore Red Cress(SRC) to set up a committee to coordinate relief efforts by the private sector here and disburse the money it has raised - over S$39 million so far - for tsunami disaster victims.
In a statement yesterday, the Ministry of Community Development, Youth and Sports also said the eight-member committee will be spearheaded by SRC chairman Winston Choo.

DOC.HEADLINE: SIGNIFICANT IMPACT EXPECTED IF TAIWAN EXCLUDED FROM ASEAN TRADE BLOC

TEXT.P: A significant impact is expected if Taiwan is excluded from the free trade bloc consisting of the member stats of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) , mainland China, Japan and South Korea, according to an assessment made by the Chung Hua Institution for Economic Research.

In the assessment made for the Ministry of Economic Affairs, the institution predicts that such a trade bloc will cause a 0.98 percent drop in Taiwan's gross domestic product (GDP) and will cut down the volume of Taiwan's international trade by 1.14 percent, drive down Taiwan's social welfare spending by US$4.33 billion and decrease Taiwan's industrial output by US$6.97 billion.

The textile industry will bear the brunt of the impact, suffering losses of US$1.95 billion, followed by the plastic and chemical industry, which will lose US$940 million and the electronics industry, which will lose US$710 million.
It will lead to a decrease of US$2.36 billion in the country's exports, including US$1.46 billion in the textile industry and US$630 million in the electronics industry.

Noting that the assessment is made according to 1997 data, which are the latest figures available, the institution said it has allowed for some margin of error but will not be far from the actual figures.
The impact would be much less if the ASEAN-centered trade bloc were to include only ASEAN states and the mainland, according to the assessment.
The institution predicts that in this scenario, Taiwan's GDP will be cut by 0.2 percent, international trade by 0.19 percent and social welfare spending by US$790 million.

Taiwan's combined industrial output will plunge by US$1.4 billion, with the textile industry suffering the most, losing US$325 million. Exports will shrink by US$446 million, with the electronics industry suffering the most, losing US$259 million. Employment will also suffer, with 14,154 jobs lost, mainly in the semiconductor industry, textiles and wholesale.
If the ASEAN trade bloc includes no countries other than its member states, the impact on Taiwan would be insignificant, according to the assessment.

It predicts that in such a case, the GDP will decrease by 0.1 percent, international trade by 0.08 percent, social welfare spending by US$360 million and industrial output by US$720 million, with the electronics industry bearing the brunt, giving up US$243 million, and a decrease of US$234 million in exports.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP REAFFIRMS INTENTION OF COOPERATING WITH PFP

TEXT.P: Acting ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Chairman Ker Chien-ming reaffirmed Saturday his party's intention to cooperate with the opposition People First Party (PFP) for the sake of political stability.

Ker said, however, that it is not suitable to disclose details of the cooperation plan between the two parties and that the situation will become clearer after PFP Chairman James Soong returns from the United States.

Addressing local media speculation that Kaohsiung Mayor Frank Hsieh will be appointed the next premier, while Soong will head the Committee for Cross-Strait Peace and Development, Ker said these are mere wild guesses and that it is still premature to speculate on the new Cabinet lineup.
The current Cabinet led by Premier Yu Shyi-kun is set to resign Jan. 24 in preparation for a reshuffle in line with the formation of a new legislature Feb. 1.
Meanwhile, PFP legislative caucus convener Liu Wen-hsiung said Soong will never accept an offer for him to head the Committee for Cross-Strait Peace and Development.
Although Soong has always been concerned about cross-Taiwan Strait issues, he can contribute his part as PFP chairman and does not need to become the head of the committee, Liu said.
Dismissing the media speculation as unfounded, Liu said the PFP has never received any information about any of its members being recruited to join the new Cabinet.
He reiterated that it is the PFP's policy to defend the Republic of China and oppose independence for Taiwan, and that it will not cooperate with other parties in exchange for power and position.

DOC.HEADLINE: INAUGURATION OF NEW TSU CHAIRMAN SET FOR JAN. 27

TEXT.P: Opposition Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) Chairman-designate Shu Chin-chiang is scheduled to be sworn in Jan. 27 during a special session of the party's national congress, TSU officials said Saturday.
Former Republic of China President and the TSU's so-called "spiritual leader" Lee Teng-hui will also attend the meeting, the officials said.
The TSU's chairmanship became vacant after Huang Chu-wen stepped down last month over the party's dismal showing in the Dec. 11 legislative elections.
The TSU's Central Executive Committee approved the appointment of Shu as party chairman earlier this week. He was the sole candidate.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP MUST STAY WITH PEOPLE, STRENGTHEN POLITICAL STATEMENT: OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: The ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) must keep in touch with the grassroots and strengthen its political statement with "grand prospects that will touch the hearts of the people," a DPP official said Saturday.
DPP Secretary-General Chang Chun-hsiung made the remarks when he attended a two-day policy seminar for DPP legislators-elect that opened that day.

In addition to Chang, President Chen Shui-bian, Vice President Annette Lu, Premier Yu Shyi-kun, Presidential Office Secretary-General Su Tseng-chang and Kaohsiung Mayor Frank Hsieh either spoke or attended the group meetings at the seminar, underscoring the importance the DPP attaches to the seminar.

Chang noted that in the Dec. 11 legislative elections, the DPP fared worse than expected, garnering only 89 of the 225 seats. Although it is still the largest party in the Legislative Yuan, it cannot form a stable majority with its ally, the Taiwan Solidarity Union.

The DPP failed because it is not fully in touch with the people, Chang said, noting that although the public has grown tired of the endless petty bickering and rivalry between the parties, it has not translated into solid support for his party.

The turnout rate for the legislative elections was just 59.16 percent, 6 percent down compared with the previous legislative election turnout. In a breakdown, votes for the opposition Kuomintang were down by more than 8,000 from the previous election, ballots for the TSU were down by 40,000 votes and those for the People First Party were down by 560,000 votes. In comparison, the votes for the DPP increased by 2.34 percent, or more than 20,000 ballots more than in the previous legislative elections.
This shows that although the people are apathetic to politics, they have nevertheless been positive in some degree to the DPP, according to Chang.

He urged the newly elected legislators to "listen to the voice of the people." As legislators of the ruling party, they should always be humble and broad-minded to help bring about reconciliation of the polarized ethnic groups and various parties.
He also stated that "if there is no cooperation, there will be no future, no stability and no harmony for Taiwan."
Ker Chien-ming, acting DPP chairman, also spoke to the legislators-elect about the operations of the legislature. He will serve his fifth term in the new legislature that will be sworn in Feb. 1.
Ker, a dentist-turned-politician, also expressed the hope that the new legislators will find their own roles to play and ways to survive so that they can contribute to the DPP team.

DOC.HEADLINE: NO BOTTOM LINE IN PROMOTING INTER-PARTY COOPERATION: DPP OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: There will be no bottom line in the ruling Democratic Progressive Party's (DPP's) promotion of inter-party cooperation, a party official said Saturday during a two-day seminar for the orientation of the DPP's legislators-elect.

DPP Secretary-General Chang Chun-hsiung was responding to media speculation that Kaohsiung Mayor Frank Hsieh is set to form a new Cabinet, while James Soong, chairman of the opposition People First Party (PFP), will serve as the chairman of a proposed committee for cross-strait peace and development under the Presidential Office.
To promote a DPP-PFP reconciliation, the DPP will also reserve at least two Cabinet-level posts for the PFP, the reports also claimed.
Chang refused to comment on the speculation, saying that he would respect President Chen Shui-bian's right to nominate a premier and the new premier's right to form the Cabinet.

He stressed that the DPP will pull out all the stops in promoting inter-party cooperation in the wake of the Dec. 11 legislative elections in which the DPP failed to reach its goal of forming a stable majority with its ally, the Taiwan Solidarity Union.
The DPP is hoping to cooperate with the PFP and other political parties to promote harmony between the legislature and the Cabinet.
Meanwhile, Hsieh also dismissed the media speculation, pointing out only that the media makes groundless speculation about possible candidates every day and prints it as "news."
He also said he is one possible candidate among "perhaps 100" that the president is mulling.

On whether the decision on the premiership could be linked to Soong with some reports claiming that the DPP could offer him the post to show its sincerity in pursuing inter-party reconciliation, Hsieh said only that the political situation changes every minute.

He said that there are still a lot of bills pending in the legislature, and the legislature is yet to confirm the members of the Control Yuan, the nation's highest watchdog body, nominated by the President. There are still "uncertainties," and President Chen is yet to decide on the new premier, he added.
The Cabinet will resign Jan. 24 to make way for the new Cabinet that will be formed after the new legislature is sworn in Feb. 1.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI, BEIJING OPTIMISTIC ABOUT CROSS-STRAIT CHARTER FLIGHT TALKS
DOC.DATELINE: Macau, Jan. 15 (CNA) (By S.F. Wang and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: Representatives from both sides of the Taiwan Strait in negotiations on cross-strait charter flights during Chinese New Year holiday said Saturday they were optimistic about the talks and expressed hope that an agreement can be reached quickly.

Pu Zhaozhou, Beijing's representative and executive director of the China Civil Aviation Association, said that both sides have so far displayed sincerity in bringing about the launch of the charter flight services.

He shied away from saying whether the talks will adopt the model of Taiwan-Hong Kong aviation agreement negotiations in 2002 in which Taipei Airlines Association (TAA) President Michael Lo headed a Taipei delegation made up of officials of the Mainland Affairs Council and the Ministry of Transportation and Communications (MOTC), who came as TAA advisers to work behind the scenes to realize the signing of the agreement.
" Any model that will solve problems will be good model," Pu said.

Taipei's representative, Billy K.C. Chang, director-general of the Civil Aeronautics Administration, said there should be no hitches in the talks and that he hoped to "have a result in the shortest possible time."

Chang, who was attending the talks in his capacity as a TAA adviser, said the talks will mainly be to confirm the multiple flight destinations and the licensing of the flight routes, and will be confined to the holiday charter flights.
Both sides of the Taiwan Strait have set the principles of "joint-participation, multiple-destination, and non-stop" charter flights for the holiday period.
Also on Taipei's delegation were Fang Chi-wen, an official of the MOTC's Department of Navigation and Aviation, TAA head Lo and TAA Secretary-General Su Hsien-jung.

DOC.HEADLINE: 1,000 MOUNTAIN GUARDIANS TO START SERVICE MAY 20: VICE PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: A team of 1,000 mountain guardians currently undergoing training are set to start service May 20 to help with rescue operations and ecological conservation in mountainous areas, Vice President Annette Lu said Saturday.
Of the 1,000 trainees, 500 are doing alternative military service, while the other 500 are residents of mountainous aboriginal communities, according to Lu.
The mountain guardians are expected to improve the government's response to natural disasters such as flooding and mudflows triggered by typhoons, Lu said.

In light of the fact that up to three-quarters of Taiwan are mountainous, Lu proposed that the country's administrative regions be re-mapped to set up a special mountainous administrative region directly under the control of the central government.
Meanwhile, she reaffirmed the government's plan to draw on its success in developing science-based industrial parks to help its diplomatic allies in Central America set up similar facilities.
Lu made the remarks while giving a keynote speech at a luncheon with legislators-elect of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party.

In response to questions from the press on the candidate for the next premier, Lu said President Chen Shui-bian is carefully considering the new Cabinet lineup and is accepting public suggestions on personnel arrangements.
The local media has speculated that Kaohsiung Mayor Frank Hsieh might replace Yu Shyi-kun as the next premier.

DOC.HEADLINE: LUNAR NEW YEAR CHARTER SERVICES HELP BREAK TABOO: AVIATION COMPANY

TEXT.P: The realization of charter flights for mainland China-based Taiwan businessmen wishing to spend the coming Lunar New Year holiday at home will help break political taboos between the two sides and have a far-reaching impact on bilateral ties, a source from the domestic aviation industry said Saturday.

Should representatives from Taiwan and the mainland succeed in reaching a final agreement over the issue, it will help break longstanding political taboos between the two sides, the sources said, adding that the charter flight services planned for the Chinese New Year holiday are much more complex than the previous such flights in 2003, when six Taiwan carriers were involved.
The charter services failed to take off in 2004 due to mainland China's refusal to negotiate its demand that mainland carriers also be allowed to take part in the services.

If carriers from both sides can conduct the special charter services negotiations this time under the "non-stop, round-trip,multi-destinations" principle as the mainland has insisted upon, it will be a significant breakthrough in cross-strait ties, they claimed.

However, they were reserved about the expected success of the charter flight services, although representatives from Taiwan and the mainland were holding technical talks over the issue in Macau with only about 20 days left until the Feb. 9 Chinese New Year.

With the holidays so close, many Taiwan businessmen and their families have already booked tickets for their homecoming and return trips during the festival season through regular channels, making it unlikely that there will be much demand for the highly-touted flights.

Meanwhile, Joseph Wu, chairman of the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC), told the Voice of Germany radio a day earlier in an exclusive interview that Taiwan and the mainland have agreed upon the model for the flights.
In an attempt to douse the concern of many international observers who are skeptical of the possibility of the charter flights, Wu claimed that those who bet on the issue are sure to win.

In a meeting with a visiting group of U.S. congressional assistants, Wu said Taiwan will continue to push for opening direct cargo service across the Taiwan Strait and hold talks over economic issues such as the establishment of a currency settlement and an investment guarantee pact, with the mainland.
The top mainland policy planner said Taiwan is willing to work out a framework under which the two sides can interact and conduct exchanges before peace is eventually built across the strait.
According to Lin Ling-san, minister of transportation and communication, many cross-strait technical matters need to be resolved through negotiations.

Touching on a request by Taichung Mayor Jason Hu and Taichung Magistrate Lin Chung-sheng that Chinchuankang (CCK) Airport also be included in the charter plan, Lin made it clear that the facility will not be part of the services on the grounds that it is also a military airport.

When talking about adding more destinations to the service, passenger numbers must also be considered, he said, noting that for the time being, Taiwan has agreed in principle to open Taipei and Kaohsiung for the charter services, connecting with the mainland cities of Beijing, Shanghai and Guangzhou.
