DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN, MAINLAND CHINA AGREE ON LUNAR NEW YEAR CHARTER FLIGHTS
DOC.DATELINE: Macau, Jan. 15 (CNA) (By S.F. Wang and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: Negotiators from Taiwan and mainland China reached an agreement in Macau Saturday to launch special charter flights from Jan. 29 to Feb. 20 to carry mainland-based Taiwanese businessmen and their families home for the Lunar New Year holiday.
The services will be jointly operated by six air carriers from each side between Beijing, Shanghai and Guangzhou on the mainland and Taipei and Kaohsiung in Taiwan, according to the agreement.

The details of the agreement were jointly announced after the first stage of the negotiations by China Civil Aviation Association Executive Director Pu Zhaozhou and Taipei Airlines Association President Michael Lo, the leading negotiators representing the two sides.
Pu described the atmosphere of the talks as "peaceful and highly efficient."

He said air carriers from Taiwan and the mainland will each operate 24 round-trip flights during the period and that both sides have reached consensus on details concerning the licensing and qualifications of flight crew.
Meanwhile, Lo said, the two sides agreed that the charter planes will not be required to land in a third area en route but will have to fly in a detour over Hong Kong's aviation zone.
Negotiators from both sides are engaging in another round of talks on other technical details.

DOC.HEADLINE: SEMINAR ON SOUTHEAST ASIAN CULTURE HELD IN KAOHSIUNG

TEXT.P: A seminar on Southeast Asian culture was held in Fengshan, Kaohsiung County Saturday to deepen local people's understanding of the people of the region.

A worker from the Eden Social Welfare Foundation, which organized the forum, noted that Taiwanese need to know more about Southeast Asia in light of the fact that more and more Taiwanese are marrying women from the region and that the children growing up in cross-cultural marriages pose special challenges for schoolteachers.

Wu Hui-ling, an Indonesian woman who married a man from Tungkang, Pingtung County five years ago, told the forum that she used to live with her sister-in-law in Tungkang until differences with her sister-in-law about how to educate her only daughter forced her and her husband to move to Kaohsiung six months ago.

Wu said she had studied at an Indonesia university for two years before marrying and moving to Taiwan but said she had difficulty accustoming herself to Taiwan culture, which is quite different to that of her homeland.

The differences are especially pronounced when it comes to children's education, she said, noting that her Indonesian cultural background predisposes her to be tougher with her child, which led to interfering by her sister-in-law, who spoils her children.

Wu's daughter, who was brought to the forum by her mother, can recite the multiplication table and the Three-Character Book, an ancient Chinese book for small children, which is a remarkable achievement for a four-year-old.
Wu complained that in Tungkang, many foreign women married to Taiwanese are forbidden by their Taiwanese in-laws to attend literary classes or enroll in adult education programs.
Kindergarten teacher Ke Chin-mei said a five-year-old boy in her kindergarten has difficulty speaking with his classmates because his Vietnamese mother can speak only a little Mandarin and Taiwanese.

Tseng Hung-chih, president of the Haiko Community Development Association, warned that a large number of children raised by foreign wives will begin to enter junior high school next year, when their difficulty in assimilating into local society will be brought to light more vividly.

DOC.HEADLINE: OFFICIAL PRESENTS TAIWAN RELIEF TO INDONESIAN RED CROSS
DOC.DATELINE: Jakarta, Jan. 15 (CNA) (By Yu Ko-tsang & Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's Representative to Indonesia Lin Yong-le presented a shipment of Taiwan relief goods, including nine tons of medical supplement, to the Indonesian Red Cross Friday to help the group's aid efforts in the earthquake and tsunami-hit area of Medan.
Deputy North Sumatra Governor Rudolf Pardede witnessed a ceremony marking the presentation at a relief center, according to officials of the Taipei Economic and Trade Office in Jakarta.
The relief goods arrived at the Medan airport the previous day, the officials said Saturday.
It has been estimated that some 110,000 people in Indonesia were killed by the 9-magnitude earthquake and subsequent tsunami that struck Dec. 26, making the country the worst-hit in the Southeast
Asian region by the biggest natural disaster in a century.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHARTER FLIGHTS HELP EASE CROSS-STRAIT TENSIONS: PRESIDENTIAL ADVISOR

TEXT.P: A Presidential Office advisor said Saturday that the agreement reached between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait on charter flights during the Chinese New Year holiday will contribute to the easing of the strained cross-strait situation.

Byron S.J. Weng, who is also a professor at National Chi Nan University, noted that the two sides of the Taiwan Strait have had no direct contact with each other since the meeting between the two top negotiators -- Koo Chen-fu, the late chairman of Taipei's Straits Exchange Foundation and his counterpart Wang Daohan, chairman of the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait -- in Shanghai in 1998.
Cross-strait relations soured after former President Lee Teng-hui described the situation between the two sides as a "special state-to-state relationship" in 1999.
Although the consultation between the two sides on Saturday in Macau was about charter flights during the Chinese New Year, Weng claimed that it was a "major breakthrough" in cross-strait relations.

Aviation representatives from Taipei and Beijing reached an agreement that six air carriers each from both sides will engage in 24 charter flights each between Beijing/Shanghai/Guangzhou and Taipei/Kaohsiung between Jan. 29 and Feb. 20.

DOC.HEADLINE: OFFICIALS TO VISIT U.S. TO DECLARE TAIWAN STANCE ON ANTI-SECESSION LAW

TEXT.P: Taiwan's top official in charge of mainland China affairs confirmed Saturday news reports that the Taiwan authorities will send a delegation to the United States to make clear of Taiwan's stance on Beijing's move to enact an "anti-secession" law.

Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council Chairman Joseph Wu told reporters that he will be a member of the planned delegation, whose visit to Washington, D.C. will be aimed at calling on friends in the U.S. Congress and think tanks there to talk about the mainland's proposed law targeting Taiwan.

Wu stressed that during the upcoming tour, he intends to give U.S. politicians and political scholars a clear explanation of Taiwan's stance and policies regarding Beijing's attempt to make an excuse to use force against the island.
The official did not mention any other details of the planned mission.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN HIGH SPEED RAIL TO BE INAUGURATED IN OCTOBER

TEXT.P: The Taiwan High Speed Rail (THSR) will be inaugurated on schedule in October, according to THSR Bureau Director Ho Hsuan-hsuan.

Ho made the remark Friday while braving the rain to examine a THSR construction site in Yangmei Township in the northern county of Taoyuan. So far, a total of 22 official examinations of the high speed railway have been carried out to ensure that it will be safe, Ho said.

Fifty-four percent of the overall construction and 99.69 percent of civil engineering projects have been completed, Ho went on, adding that although it is a bit behind schedule, the lag has been brought under control.

The 345-km, high-speed railway linking Taipei in the north and Kaohsiung in the south is Taiwan's first infrastructure project built under a build-operate-transfer (BOT) formula. At the cost of US$16.06 billion, the railway is designed to accommodate train speeds of up to 300 kilometers per hour, and the direct service between Taipei and Kaohsiung will take only 80 minutes.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT ENCOURAGES TAIWAN PARENTS TO HAVE MORE CHILDREN

TEXT.P: Taiwan's falling birth rate is provoking grave concern in the government, which has been working on measures to encourage parents to have more children.

Speaking at a recent public hearing jointly organized by representatives from the government and the private sector, attendees unanimously called on the government to build a favorable and healthy environment to make the younger generation willing to have more children.

To achieve that goal, the government should do its utmost to take pressure off people's lives by creating more jobs, stepping up the rule of law and providing better day-care and education for children, they said.
Chien Tai-lang, vice minister of the interior, said that the government is gravely concerned about negative growth in Taiwan's population, estimated to start by around 2022.

In an effort to help reverse the trend, the Ministry of the Interior will organize public hearings around the country to gauge public opinion to use as references in a "white paper" on countermeasures to be published in March, Chien said, adding that persuading parents to have more children is also a responsibility and a set policy of the government.

Citing academic studies, Chien reported that the number of citizens aged over 65 will account for 39 percent of Taiwan's total population by 2051 if the country's birth rate continues at the current low level. "By that time, all you will see in the streets are silver-haired old men and women," he said.

Statistics compiled by the Interior Ministry show that Taiwan's birth rate is one of the world's lowest. In 2003, Taiwan parents gave birth to an average of 1.24 newborns. The average in Italy and Sweden was 1.2 and 1.5, respectively, for the same year, while France and the United States recorded 1.9 and 2, respectively.

DOC.HEADLINE: CROSS-STRAIT CHARTER FLIGHTS HISTORICALLY SIGNIFICANT: ACADEMIC
DOC.DATELINE: Beijing, Jan. 15 (CNA) (By Stanley Cheung and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: The latest agreement between Taiwan and mainland China on the launch of special Lunar New Year charter flights this year will make possible the first legal landing in Taiwan by a mainland civilian plane in more than 50 years, which will be a historically significant event, a Beijing academic said Saturday.

Xu Bodong, a professor of Taiwan studies at the Beijing Union University, said in an interview with the Central News Agency that this is a "win-win" agreement that will help temper the tension across the Taiwan Strait.

However, Xu said the effect of the charter flight agreement, which he said is a special, isolated case, must not be overestimated and that the launch of the services does not mean that direct cross-strait shipping and air links will be realized any time soon.
He said there is still a long way to go before direct cross-strait transport links can be opened, due to the political confrontation between Beijing and Taipei.

Negotiators from Taiwan and the mainland reached an agreement in Macau Saturday to launch special charter flights from Jan. 29 to Feb. 20 to carry mainland-based Taiwanese businessmen and their families home for the Lunar New Year holiday.

Unlike the last cross-strait Lunar New Year charter services in 2003, which were operated solely by Taiwanese airliners between Shanghai and Taipei/Kaohsiung, this year's services will be jointly operated by six air carriers from each side between Beijing/Shanghai/Guangzhou on the mainland and Taipei/Kaohsiung in Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN BUSINESS LEADERS IN CHINA WELCOME CHARTER FLIGHT SERVICES
DOC.DATELINE: Beijing, Jan. 15 (CNA) (By Stanley Cheung and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: The leaders of several Taiwan businessmen's associations in mainland China welcomed Saturday an agreement reached between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait on the launch of charter flights for the Chinese New Year holiday period, although it came "a bit late."

Chen Kuo-yuan, secretary-general of the Taiwan Businessmen Association in Beijing, said that it is historically significant to have mainland civilian planes land legally on Taiwan soil for the first time in five decades.

Chen made the remarks after aviation representatives from Taipei and Beijing reached an agreement earlier that day in Macau that six air carriers each from both sides will operate 24 charter flights between Beijing/Shanghai/Guangzhou and Taipei/Kaohsiung between Jan. 29 and Feb. 20.
Chen said that his association will coordinate with related associations in Heibei and Tianjin to help Taiwan businessmen book tickets on the charter flights during the Chinese New Year holiday.
But he also said that "it was a pity that the agreement came a bit late, as most Taiwan businessmen have already booked their tickets" through existing channels.

Kuo Shan-huei, president of Taiwan Businessmen Association in Tungguan, said that with air carriers from both sides of the Taiwan strait offering the services, it will be an ice-breaking move and historically significant.
The agreement will be especially useful as one of the destinations is Guangzhou, where there is a heavy concentration of Taiwan businessmen.

Chang Han-wen, another association official, said that Taiwan businessmen in Guangzhou are in great need of charter flights, as a lot of them are in the manufacturing industry and the only time they can make a trip home is during the long Chinese New Year holiday. The direct charter flights will save them time and money as they will not have to route their journey via a third place such as Hong Kong or Macau.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHARTER FLIGHTS A STEP FURTHER IN CROSS-STRAIT EXCHANGES: KMT

TEXT.P: The agreement reached between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait on the launch of cross-strait charter flights during the Chinese New Year holiday period marks a step further in exchanges across the Taiwan Strait, an opposition Kuomintang (KMT) official said Saturday.

Tseng Yung-chuan, a KMT legislator and executive director of the KMT Policy Committee, claimed that it was the KMT that first promoted the idea, earning an enthusiastic response from the ruling Democratic Progressive Party.

Tseng said that the opposition parties still have a lot of room for participation in issues related to cross-strait relations and the general public, adding that the KMT likes to see positive developments in cross-strait relations. He said the launch of charter flights for the holiday is a model of cooperation between the ruling and opposition parties in pushing through major issues.

Tseng recently led a KMT delegation to the mainland to meet with Chen Yun-lin, director of the Taiwan Affairs Office of the State Council, on the issue. Chen announced after the Jan. 10 meeting that they had officially agreed that the charter flights would take place.
However, the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) said that Taipei and Beijing had already reached agreement in a secret meeting in Macau in early January.
"Even if the KMT seems to have been too nosey in the matter, it did help bring about a good result," Tseng claimed.

Aviation representatives from Taipei and Beijing reached an agreement earlier in the day that six air carriers from each side will operate 24 charter flights each between Beijing/Shanghai/Guangzhou and Taipei/Kaohsiung between Jan. 29 and Feb. 20, marking the first time Chinese civil aircraft will have landed on Taiwan soil in five decades.

The first cross-strait charter flights were inaugurated during the 2003 Chinese New Year holiday on a trial basis, but only Taiwan air carriers plied the route between Shanghai and Taipei/Kaohsiung via a third place such as Hong Kong or Macau.

DOC.HEADLINE: SCHOLARS WARN OF SERIOUS ENVIRONMENTAL DETERIORATION

TEXT.P: Serious environmental deterioration in Taiwan was the prime concern for many scholars and environmentalists in a public hearing held Saturday, who urged the government to quickly tackle the problem.

They issued the warning at the hearing sponsored by the Cabinet-level Council for Economic Planning and Development, pointing out that the problem is worsening at an alarming rate that will eventually take its toll on the people of Taiwan.

Chen Hung-yu, a geology professor from National Taiwan University, said that the number of Taiwan rivers prone to mudslides and rockslides has surged to an astonishing 1,420 since the devastating Sept. 21, 1999 earthquake hit Taiwan, in particular central regions. Today, he noted, 655 of the country's dangerous rivers are in central Taiwan.
There were only 485 such rivers around the country prior to 1996, with 134 in central regions, he added.

The worst quake to hit Taiwan in a century severely changed the country's topography, he said, pointing out that now only a third of the rainfall of the past average amounts before the 921 earthquake can easily trigger catastrophes anywhere in the country.

For instance, he explained, the more than 250,000 tons of debris brought down in just a few days by typhoon Mindulle in September last year was equal to a quarter of the total amount accumulated in the whole of the previous year.

Hsieh Cheng-lun, a marine science professor at National Chengkung University, suggested that the government spend its money on environmental protection rather than just dumping budget money into repairing the rivers.

That would be much more cost-effective because it is a mission impossible to have the government spend at least NT$140 billion (US$4.3 billion) to clean up the roughly 1,400 streams and rivers around Taiwan, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWANESE MAN CLAIMS TO BE ILLEGALLY DETAINED, MALTREATED IN MALAYSIA

TEXT.P: A local businessman who returned from Malaysia Friday claimed in Taichung Saturday that he was illegally detained for 43 days and maltreated by Malaysian police in Kuala Lumpur.

Chen Pao-chao, a businessman who sells oil used in religious worship, said he arrived in Kuala Lumpur Dec. 1 and was escorted by a Malaysian friend to a local hotel where he was to stay before going on to Penang the next day as he did in 10 previous business trips to Malaysia.

When he and his friend went out for dinner at a local restaurant that evening, they were arrested in the hotel's parking lot by eight police officers, who accused them of being drug dealers, threw them to the ground and beat them ruthlessly during the ensuing interrogation.
In order to force him into admitting his alleged crime, Chen claimed that he was badly beaten, tortured and denied a lawyer.

Although the police claimed they had been watching his friend for a while and knew all about their deals, they did not show any evidence that he was involved in anything illegal and refused to let him go, claiming that they can legally hold a suspect for up to two years without filing charges.
Thanks to the help of a secretary at the Taiwan representative office in Kuala Lumpur, Chen said he was released eventually and allowed to return to Taichung.
Waving a medical certificate issued by a hospital in Taichung, Wu claimed that his 43-day ordeal in Malaysian police custody has badly damaged his health.

He condemned the Malaysian police for trampling on his human rights. Meanwhile, Foreign Ministry spokesman Michel Lu said in Taipei that his ministry is looking into the case and will express its serious concern to the Malaysian authorities, despite the absence of diplomatic ties between Taipei and Kuala Lumpur.
Lu said his ministry helped members of Chen's family to visit him in Kuala Lumpur during his detention and helped him return to Taiwan after his release.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI MAYOR CANCELS TRIP TO AUSTRALIA

TEXT.P: Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou has canceled a planned visit to Australia for the closing ceremony of the 2005 Deaf Olympics in Melbourne, a city government official said Saturday.
Vice Mayor Pai Hsiu-hsiung was assigned to make the trip in his place, according to Taipei city government spokesman Yu Tzu-hsiang.

Ma had previously canceled a planned visit to Thailand in order to oversee damage control over a catalogue of errors by a municipal hospital earlier in the week that delayed the emergency treatment of aseverely abused four-year-old girl.

The Taipei City Hospital's Jen Ai branch refused to perform surgery on the girl, who had suffered serious brain injuries after being beaten up by her drunken father, and tried to transfer her to another hospital as it had no beds available. Another 23 Taipei hospitals offered the same excuse and the girl finally had to be taken almost 200 km to a hospital in Taichung County, where she remains in a coma.
Ma canceled the Australian trip following the city government's decision to renew an investigation into the responsibility of medical workers at the Jen Ai hospital.
Several hospital officials have been punished for their parts in the incident, while Chang Hang, head of the city's Department of Health, has also been removed from his post.

DOC.HEADLINE: EVENT LISTING FOR JAN. 16 IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The following are important events scheduled to take place Sunday, Jan. 16:
10: 00, The policy seminar for the ruling Democratic Progressive Party's legislators-elect will continue at Grand Hotel Taipei.

10: 30, The presentation of a joint EMBA class on business management and administration in the Asia-Pacific region at National Sun Yat-sen University, Chang Kung University and the Chinese University of Hong Kong will be held at Grand Hotel Taipei.
17:00, Vice President Annette Lu will attend a buddhist ritual to mark the anniversary of Sakyamuni's buddhahood at the Chiang Kai-shek Memorial Park in Taipei.
18: 00, A fund-raising party for the AIDS-care Red Ribbon Foundation in Taiwan will be held at the Taipei 101 Tower.
18: 00, Kaohsiung Mayor Frank Hsieh will attend an activity to promote the southern Taiwan port city's tourist night market.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Sunday, Jan. 16, or the seventh day of the 12th month of the Year of the Monkey according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1547: Ivan IV Vasilievich, who waged unsuccessful wars against Sweden and Livonia, terrorized the Russian aristocracy, and was known as "Ivan the Terrible," is crowned the first czar of Russia.
1778: France recognizes U.S. independence.
1920: The 18th Amendment to the U.S. Constitution goes into effect, banning the consumption of alcohol in the United States.
1937: The Du Pont Company patents a new fiber called Nylon, a revolutionary "miracle" yarn made entirely from chemicals.
1942: Carole Lombard, American actress and wife of Clark Gable, dies in a plane crash.
1944: General Dwight D. Eisenhower is appointed supreme commander of the Allied forces in Europe.
1962: The first phase of construction on the Taiwan's Southern Cross-island Highway begins.
1966: Joan Baez, the left-wing American singer, is among 124 anti-Vietnam War demonstrators arrested for blocking the entrance to a U.S. Army induction center in Oakland, California.
1970: Republic of China athlete Chi Cheng, who broke the women's 200-meter record in West Germany on July 12, 1970 with a time of 22.44 seconds, is chosen Asia's best athlete by a sports foundation.
1970: Colonel Muammar Gaddafi becomes chairman of the Revolutionary Command Council in Libya.
1973: The United States and South Vietnam declare a unilateral cease-fire in the hope of signing a peace pact with North Vietnam.
1973: Robert Page, vice president of United Press International, arrives in Taipei for a three-day visit.
1975: Angola gains independence from Portugal.
1975: The ROC Executive Yuan ratifies a provisional air agreement between the ROC and Jordan.
1975: Cambodian Khmer Rouge communists launch a full-scale war against the country's non-communist government. They take control of Cambodia in April 1975.
1976: A new radar control system is inaugurated at Kaohsiung International Airport in southern Taiwan.
1976: Gen. Yu Hao-chang, former ROC Army commander-in-chief, returns after more than a year of medical treatment in the United States.
1979: Mohammad Reza Pahlavi, shah of Iran, leaves Teheran for Egypt after mass demonstrations, strikes, and riots against his rule. Revolutionaries take control of the government the following month.
1985: Mother Teresa, the Albanian-born Indian nun who won the 1979 Nobel Peace Prize, arrives in Taipei for a visit.
1987: Hu Yaobang resigns as head of the Chinese Communist Party, accepting the blame for policy mistakes stemming from student turmoil.
1990: A new ROC law allows low-ranking government employees to visit relatives across the Taiwan Strait, and native Taiwanese who moved to the mainland before 1949 are allowed to visit relatives in Taiwan.
1991: Allied jets bomb Baghdad as the Gulf War breaks out.
1996: The ROC Legislature passes three telecommunications laws -- the Telecommunications Act, the Organizational Statute of the Directorate General of Telecommunications (DGT) and the Statute on Chunghwa Telecom Co., Ltd.
1997: ROC Vice President and Premier Lien Chan visits Ireland to attend an academic seminar.
2000: Destroyer Nanyang, originally named "John Thomason," is decommissioned at the southern Taiwan port of Kaohsiung after 25 years of service in the ROC Navy.
2001: Hsu Tsui-feng takes over as new warden of a detention center on the offshore island of Kinmen, becoming the first female prison warden in Taiwan.
2002: Taiwan's first nanotechnology center, under the sponsorship of the quasi-official Industrial Technology Research Institute (ITRI), is officially established to serve as a cradle for the island's next-generation high technology development.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "Moral worth is never left alone; society is sure to grow around him."

DOC.TEXT: The Japan Times: Probe touches down on Titan After a seven-year trip trough outer space,the Huyens space probe succesfully ompleted the last leg of its epic voyage to Titan on Friday, rele- asing initial images that brought tesrs to the eyes of the mission's scientists.

DOC.TEXT:
Manila Bulletin: 'I have returned' -- Estrada
A much healthier and leaner former President Joseph Estrada returned from a knee operation in Hong Kong to a big gathering of loyal friends and supporters, and was immediately reunited with his family at his detention home in Tanay, Rizal.
The Philippine Daily Inquirer: Estrada vows to lead RP to 'new dawn'
FORMER President Joseph Estrada arrived yesterday after a 19-day trip to Hong Kong, and pledged to lead the country to "a new dawn." He shot down talk of a destabilization plot and branded the administration of President Gloria Macapagal-Arroyo corrupt and an international pariah.
The Philippine Star: Court cases won't delay NAIA-3 opening -- Palace
President Arroyo is determined that court cases will not delay the opening of the Ninoy Aquino International Airport Terminal 3 (NAIA-3) by June this year, a Malacanang official said yesterday.
The Manila Times: Erap whisked to Tanay
Deposed President Joseph Estrada, who is on trial for plunder, returned to the Philippines Saturday after a knee operation in Hong Kong but was swiftly whisked back into detention.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CHEN SATISFIED WITH CROSS-STRAIT CHARTER FLIGHTS: MAC

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian is satisfied with the agreement reached by both sides of the Taiwan Strait on direct charter flights for the coming Chinese Lunar New Year holiday, according to Joseph Wu, chairman of the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC).
Wu said he briefed the president immediately after representatives of Taipei and Beijing agreed to landmark direct cross-strait charter flights after negotiations in Macau Saturday.
The agreement allows Chinese and Taiwanese airlines to fly into each other's territory from Jan. 29 to Feb. 20 to serve Taiwanese business people and their families based in mainland China.
The MAC head expressed the hope that the agreement will also serve as a foundation for further negotiations and an opportunity for positive interactions between Taiwan and the mainland in the future.

Wu said that the agreement is not perfect, but it is acceptable. He added that the success of the talks demonstrates that both sides of the Taiwan Strait can shelve their differences and can talk without preconditions, which bodes well for the future.
Both sides can jointly promote exchanges and activities that are mutually beneficial to create an atmosphere of shared trust, he said.

The MAC head also said that following the model used to establish these temporary flights, Taiwan and the mainland will gradually hold talks on other matters, including cargo charter flights, trade, legal issues, repatriation of stowaways and cooperation in fighting cross-strait crime.
MAC Vice Chairman Chiu Tai-san agreed that the manner in which the talks were conducted in Macau has set a good precedence for further negotiations between the two sides.

DOC.HEADLINE: PERMANENT DIRECT CROSS-STRAIT FLIGHTS COULD AFFECT HK AND MACAU
DOC.DATELINE: Hong Kong, Jan. 16 (CNA) (By Lin Yu-kuo and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Chinese Lunar New Year direct cross-strait holiday flights will have little impact on Hong Kong and Macau because they will be temporary, but should direct flights become the norm, the two mainland enclaves could be adversely affected, travel and media sources said Sunday.

"Direct" cross-strait holiday charter flights in 2003 were not direct at all; the only difference from regular commercial flights was that passengers, instead of having to change planes in Hong Kong or Macau to carry on into mainland China, were allowed to stay on the same plane they departed on as it touched down in one of the third places and then took off again. This year, both sides agreed that no landing in a third place will be required, but the charter planes must detour and fly over Hong Kong's air space en route to their final destinations.
The flights will be jointly operated by six air carriers from each side plying routes between Beijing, Shanghai and Guangzhou on the mainland and Taipei and Kaohsiung in Taiwan.

A spokesman for the Hong Kong-Macau Shuttle Bus Association estimated that bus transportation business during this year's flights is expected to decline 6 percent to 7 percent during the Chinese Lunar New Year period.

The spokesman said that about 100,000 Taiwan people travel via Hong Kong to the mainland to visit relatives or for family reunions during the Chinese Lunar New Year holiday every year. Of these, about 30,000 headed to Guangdong province by bus.

The impact is limited since the charter flights will only operate for 23 days, from Jan. 29 to Feb. 20; however, the spokesman said that the shuttle bus association will have to study its business strategies if the new agreement is extended to allow air carriers to operate direct flights in the long term.

Chiang Su-hui, a Hong Kong-based political observer and opinion leader, said that the landmark agreement between Taiwan and mainland China Saturday is a forerunner of overall direct transportation links across the Taiwan Strait. Hong Kong's entrepot role will be completely phased out once across- the-board direct air and shipping links across the Taiwan Strait are fully implemented, Chiang said.

Against this backdrop, Chiang said, Hong Kong should think about how to reposition itself in the triangular relationship among Taiwan, mainland China and Hong Kong. For example, she said, Hong Kong could strive to become the new center for cultural exchanges between Taiwan and mainland China.

However, Liu Yue-shao, a Hong Kong-based news commentator, said that Hong Kong's role as an entrepot will not be affected noticeably if the exchanges of direct charter flights between Taiwan and mainland China become a reality because Hong Kong is an international port city that already sees large numbers of international flights, cross-continent shipping and is a key transshipment center, among many other business aspects of the former British colony.
By comparison, Liu said, Macau stands to be much harder hit if direct links are to be opened as some 70 percent of the former Portuguese colony's daily flights are for transshipments.

The details of Saturday's agreement were jointly announced after the first stage of negotiations by China Civil Aviation Association Executive Director Pu Zhaozhou and Taipei Airlines Association President Michael Lo, the lead negotiators representing the two sides.

According to the agreement, the air carriers from Taiwan and the mainland will each operate 24 round-trip flights during the period with both sides having agreed on details concerning the licensing and qualifications of flight crews.

DOC.HEADLINE: TRANSPARENT MECHANISM NEEDED FOR INTER-PARTY TALKS: FRANK HSIEH

TEXT.P: An open and transparent mechanism for inter-party negotiations for reconciliation and cooperation among political parties would be welcomed, Kaohsiung Mayor Frank Hsieh said Sunday.

Hsieh, who many consider the likely top candidate to take over the reins as premier, made the remarks at a policy seminar for the ruling Democratic Progressive Party's legislators-elect held at the Grand Hotel in Taipei.

He was responding to opposition People First Party (PFP) Chairman James Soong's claims that the PFP is willing to closely cooperate with political parties on all economic issues while sticking to its stance of defending the existence of the Republic of China and opposing Taiwan independence.

Any inter-party cooperation should be transparent and reached through party-to-party negotiations lest it should be linked to tricks or political rewards because the public currently has little confidence in the government and political parties, Hsieh stressed.

Noting that an open and transparent mechanism for inter-party negotiations is essential to promote cooperation among political parties, Hsieh said that in addition to the PFP, the DPP will not rule out the possibility of seeking cooperation with other parties.

President Chen Shui-bian has been seeking to end long-term inter-party disagreements and bickering since the Dec. 11 legislative elections, in which the "pan-green camp" of the DPP and its ally, Taiwan Solidarity Union, failed to gain a majority in the 225-seat legislature.

According to media reports, Hsieh is likely to be appointed the new premier to face a new legislature, while Soong will serve as the chairman of a proposed committee for cross-strait peace and development under the Presidential Office.
However, Hsieh declined to confirm the report, saying that it is not he who appoints a new premier and that as Kaohsiung mayor, he will do his utmost to perform his duties well.

DOC.HEADLINE: ECONOMICS MINISTER ENCOURAGES MANUFACTURERS TO INVEST IN TAIWAN
DOC.DATELINE: Los Angeles, Jan. 15 (CNA) (By Tsu Lu-sheng and Luis Huang)

TEXT.P: Republic of China Minister of Economic Affairs Ho Mei-yueh encouraged Taiwanese manufacturers operating in foreign countries Saturday to use Taiwan as their business hubs in exploring Asian markets.

Ho made the appeal in Los Angeles while delivering a speech at a board meeting of the Taiwanese Chamber of Commerce of North America attended by more than 140 board members and representatives from overseas Taiwanese manufacturers associations.
Expounded Taiwan's economic developments during the three-day meeting, Ho said that the country's economic growth rate hit 5.93 percent in 2004, with imports and exports posting remarkable growth.

All sectors in Taiwan, such as computers and information technology, are expected to enjoy an impressive growth this year, Ho noted, adding that Asia's economy is forecast to grow rapidly in the next 10 years.

Claiming that Taiwan is especially suitable for overseas Taiwanese business people to investment in, Ho voiced the hope that they will set up production facilities in Taiwan and use it as a springboard to make inroads into Asian markets.

After concluding her visit to the United States, Ho will proceed to Japan Jan. 17 to explore more opportunities for cooperation between the two countries, particularly in the field of information technology. During her stay in Japan, Ho is scheduled to visit several leading Japanese companies.

DOC.HEADLINE: HOLIDAY CHARTER FLIGHTS OPERATION RULES TO BE FINALIZED SOON: CAA

TEXT.P: Operational procedures for the special direct charter flights across the Taiwan Strait during the Chinese Lunar New Year holiday will be finalized Tuesday at the earliest, Civil Aeronautics Administration (CAA) Director-General Billy K.C. Chang said Sunday.
The CAA will submit a draft of the procedures Monday to the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council for deliberation and approval, Chang said.

As soon as the CAA receives an approval letter from the Executive Yuan, it will begin to accept applications by domestic air carriers intending to offer the much-anticipated direct cross-strait charter flight services, Chang added.
Chang went on to say that regulations governing the flights should be announced Tuesday.

Negotiators from Taiwan and mainland China reached an agreement in Macau Saturday to launch direct charter flights from Jan. 29 to Feb. 20 to carry mainland-based Taiwanese business people and their families home for the holiday.

According to the agreement, the services will be jointly operated by six air carriers from each side between Beijing, Shanghai and Guangzhou on the mainland and Taipei and Kaohsiung in Taiwan, with the flights having to detour over Hong Kong's air space.

With the consent of the Beijing authorities, six Taiwan carriers operated Lunar New Year charter flights in 2003 between Shanghai and Taipei/Kaohsiung via Hong Kong/Macau. The services were discontinued the following year because Beijing insisted that mainland carriers also be allowed to join the service but refused to come to the negotiating table to discuss the issue with Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP STILL HOPES FOR INTER-PARTY COOPERATION: DPP SECRETARY-GENERAL

TEXT.P: The ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) is still looking forward to collaborating with opposition parties to promote harmony between the legislature and the Cabinet, DPP Secretary-General Chang Chun-hsiung said Sunday.

There will be no bottom line in the ruling party's promotion of inter-party cooperation, Chang said during a two-day orientation course for the DPP's legislators-elect. The new legislature is scheduled to be sworn in Feb. 1.

He stressed that the DPP will pull out all the stops in promoting inter-party cooperation in the wake of the Dec. 11 legislative elections in which the DPP failed to reach its goal of forming a stable majority with its ally, the Taiwan Solidarity Union.

The scope and scale of the inter-party cooperation, including cooperation over the passage of certain bills in the Legislative Yuan, will be finalized after President Chen Shui-bian meets with leaders of major opposition parties, regardless of the fact that President Chen recently stepped down from the DPP chairmanship, Chang added.

Chang said that the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) is no longer insisting on appointing a KMT member as the new premier, while opposition People First Party (PFP) Chairman James Soong also said that he would not seek to hold any post in the government, clearing the way for President Chen to nominate a premier, who will in turn form the Cabinet.

Chang added that Soong's remarks made in the United States Saturday -- namely that he will push to seek reconciliation across the Taiwan Strait, reconciliation among political parties in Taiwan and reconciliation among different ethnic groups -- are commendable.

Meanwhile, acting DPP Chairman Ke Chien-ming said that there is still ample room for DPP-PFP cooperation despite the fact that Soong has said that he will not seek the premiership and that he has no interest in chairing a presidential Committee for Cross-Strait Peace and Development and no PFP figures will be recruited to work in the DPP-run Cabinet.
Ke said that the DPP will continue to facilitate a meeting between President Chen and Soong.
The Cabinet will resign Jan. 24 to make way for the new Cabinet that will be formed after the new legislature is sworn in Feb. 1.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP MAY VIE FOR SPEAKERSHIP IF NO COOPERATION REACHED WITH PFP

TEXT.P: The ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) will not rule out the possibility of naming its own candidate to vie for the legislative speakership if it fails to strike a cooperative deal with the second-largest opposition party, an influential DPP lawmaker said Sunday.

The DPP has been seeking to forge a working partnership with the opposition People First Party (PFP) since the "pan-green camp" of the DPP and the Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) failed to win a majority in the Dec. 11 legislative elections.

However, PFP Chairman James Soong said in Washington, D.C. Saturday that his party will support incumbent Legislative Yuan President Wang Jin-pyng for re-election, the vote for which will be held Feb. 1 along with that for deputy speaker.

Wang is a vice chairman of the largest opposition party -- the Kuomintang (KMT) . As some PFP lawmakers have expressed interest in running for deputy speaker, Soong said he will listen to their opinions before making a decision on the party's stance toward that post. Soong will return to Taipei around Jan. 20.

Responding to Soong's remarks, Tsai Huang-liang, a DPP legislative whip, said the DPP will continue to woo the PFP to forge a partnership. If this goal cannot be realized, Tsai said the DPP may field a candidate to run for speaker.

As to who its candidate might be, Tsai said the DPP has yet to discuss this issue. Nevertheless, Tsai said he thinks incumbent DPP Secretary-General Chang Chun-hsiung, who will become a DPP legislator-at-large Feb. 1, is the top choice. Unless Chang explicitly declines to join the race for speaker, Tsai said, the DPP will not consider any other person. He further said the DPP will not field its own candidate for deputy speaker to retain leverage to make cooperative deals with other parties.
If the DPP can reach a cooperative deal with the PFP, Tsai said the DPP will not rule out the possibility of supporting a PFP candidate for speaker.
In related news developments, PFP legislative whip Liu Wen-hsiung dismissed as sheer speculation a media report that some PFP lawmakers may support a DPP candidate in the upcoming speaker election.
Liu said the PFP's top goal is to secure the legislative deputy speaker post.
The KMT reportedly will agree to support a PFP candidate in the election for deputy speaker if the PFP supports Wang in the speakership election.
Liu said when Soong return to Taipei, the PFP's candidate for deputy spekaer election will become clear.

In the new 225-seat legislature to be inaugurated Feb.1, the ruling DPP will remain the largest party with 89 seats, followed by the KMT with 79 seats, the PFP with 34 seats and the TSU with 12 seats. The remaining seats will be controlled by the Non-Partisan Solidarity Union and independents.

DOC.HEADLINE: PFP'S ANTI-TAIWAN INDEPENDENCE STANCE REMAINS UNCHANGED: SOONG
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Jan. 15 (CNA) (By Oliver Lin and P.C. Tang)

TEXT.P: Opposition People First Party (PFP) Chairman James Soong said Saturday that he has never wavered in his stance of opposing the independence of Taiwan and supporting the Republic of China.
Soong, who is currently visiting Washington, D.C., reiterated his long-standing stance while meeting with media at the PFP and Kuomintang representative office in the U.S. capital.

Pointing out that his party will push for cross-strait and political reconciliation and harmony among the people of Taiwan, the PFP head said that some people have questioned the PFP's idea of reconciling political parties and have worried about the stance of the party.

Noting that pushing for reconciliation does not represent a change in the PFP's position, Soong said: "The PFP's stance is stable and concerning issues regarding cross-strait relations, the independence of Taiwan is absolutely not an option."

Taiwan's independence would bring disastrous results to the island and opposition to independence is the PFP's firm and basic policy, he further said, adding that this policy and his party's stance supporting the Republic of China have never changed.

Saying that the results of last December's legislative elections demonstrated the failure of extremists of pro-Taiwan independence groups, Soong, however, said that this does not mean that the island needs to press for unification with mainland China, adding that maintaining the status quo has been the consensus of most people on the island.

He also said that Taiwan needs to have wisdom to prevent hardline mainland Chinese from making excuses for using force against the island and to allow moderate factions to have a reason for maintaining peace with Taiwan.

During his visit, Soong also met with U.S. political figures and local think tanks and exchanged views with them on the legislative election results and the enactment of a cross-strait peace-promotion law proposed by the PFP.

Emphasizing that the purpose of his visit is to exchange first-hand opinions with U.S. officials and scholars, Soong said that the lowest vote-casting rate registered in the legislative elections has demonstrated the dislike of the people for the desperate fight among political parties. According to Soong, a survey released recently in Taiwan showed that 68.7 percent of Taiwanese support a truce among the parties and are concerned only about issues relating to their well-being.

Touching on the PFP's proposal of enacting a law to promote cross-strait peace, Soong said that he had told U.S. officials and scholars that without stable cross-strait relations, Taiwan will be unable to stabilize its political and economic situation and mount effective competition with mainland China.
None of Taiwan's political parties can unilaterally take the initiative to handle cross-strait relations, and such relations must be dealt with in a transparent manner, Soong added.

DOC.HEADLINE: WORLD CENSUS OF BLACK-FACED SPOONBILLS TO BE FINALIZED JAN. 23
DOC.DATELINE: Tainan, southern Taiwan, Jan. 16 (CNA) (By Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: The world census of endangered black-faced spoonbills for 2004 is scheduled to be finalized Jan. 23 when all the survey data on the rare migratory birds are collected from around Asia, the Taiwan-based Happy Wild Bird Association said Sunday.

Census data of black-faced spoonbills will be mailed from South Korea, mainland China, Macau, Hong Kong, Japan, Taiwan, Vietnam and the Philippines to the Hong Kong Bird Watching Society in the next few days so that the total number of the rare migratory birds around the globe will be recorded for 2004.
The Hong Kong-based bird-watching group has conducted the annual census for years.

Taiwan's total figure of the visiting black-faced spoonbills as of Jan. 22 -- being compiled by four Tainan-based wild bird and wildlife conservation groups, including the Happy Wild Bird Association -- will also be mailed to the Hong Kong group Jan. 23, a spokesman said.
The 2003 world black-faced spoonbills census was finalized Jan. 17, 2004 with a total of 1,206 birds, 628 of them in Taiwan.

This year, the figure in Taiwan is expected to be a record high, since the number of black-faced spoonbills overwintering in Taiwan, particularly in the southern county of Tainan, surpassed 780 as of Jan. 9, 2005, the spokesman said.
The Chiku Wetlands sanctuary near the estuary of the Tsengwen River in Tainan County has been the world's major habitat for black-faced spoonbills and other Asian migratory species for years.

DOC.HEADLINE: MISSING TUNA FISHING BOAT LIKELY SAILING TOWARD INDONESIA

TEXT.P: A Kaohsiung-based fishing company said Sunday that its tuna fishing boat "Tongyi No. 668, " which was reported missing Jan. 12, is probably on its way to Indonesia or Singapore.

Based on information from the ship's satellite locator, the fishing vessel is likely to have sailed by the British Chagos Islands toward the two Southeast Asian countries, a spokesman for the fishing company said.

In addition to asking two deep-sea fishing boats from other fishing corporations to help search for the "Tongyi No. 668, " the spokesman said his company has asked the Ministry of Foreign Affairs to instruct Taiwan's representative offices in Indonesia and Singapore to offer needed assistance.
According to the spokesman, the 493-ton fishing vessel with 28 crew members aboard, lost communications Jan. 12 while fishing about 700 nautical miles off the west coast of the Maldives.

DOC.HEADLINE: DOH TO STEP UP MONITORING OF RU486 ABORTION PILL USE

TEXT.P: The Department of Health (DOH) will intensify auditing of the use of RU486 early abortion pills in the face of allegations of rampant abuse of the controversial drug, an official in charge of controlled drugs said Sunday.

According to DOH tallies, local women took an average of 7,711 RU486 pills, also known as Mifepristone, per month in 2002, which could be translated into 30,847 RU486-induced abortion cases for the whole year. The number of the average monthly RU486 use increased to 10,753 tablets in 2003 for an estimated 43,011 abortion cases during the year.
"The figures marked a 39 percent year-on-year growth in terms of the consumption of RU486 tablets," said Lee Jih-heng, director of the DOH's National Bureau of Controlled Drugs.
Worse still, Lee said, some local medical institutions or clinics have allegedly used smuggled RU486 pills from mainland China or other countries to save costs and dodge DOH supervision.
Noting that only those women less than seven weeks pregnant and confirmed to be free of ectopic pregnancy can use RU486, Lee said abuse of smuggled or unsanctioned RU486 could be very dangerous.

With a view to better protecting local women's health, Lee said the DOH will tighten monitoring of the use of RU486, step up safe sex publicity and revise relevant abortion regulations to cope with the changing social situation.

DOC.HEADLINE: GIO SUCCEEDS IN RAISING ENOUGH FUNDS FOR TSUNAMI-AFFECTED CHILDREN

TEXT.P: The campaign to raise funds to sponsor 10,000 children affected by the Dec. 26 tsunami catastrophe in South and Southeast Asia has been a big success, a senior official said Sunday.

"As of Sunday, more than NT$400 million (US$12.5 million) in cash has been raised, " Government Information Office (GIO) Director-General Lin Chia-lung said. The GIO launched the fundraising campaign, titled "The Day after Tomorrow, 10,000 Hopes" two weeks ago to sponsor 10,000 tsunami-affected children for one year.

The campaign came to a finale at an evening party Saturday, with many celebrities donating personal effects for auction to raise money. Lin said the fundraising campaign has come to a successful end, with donations exceeding the original target of NT$360 million.
Lin said the GIO will join with local news media in forming a trust fund to manage the money and ensure that the donations are used correctly and wisely.

According to the GIO's plan, Lin said local non-governmental organizations will be commissioned to plan how to use the funds. The donations will be taken to Indonesia and Sri Lanka, the two hardest-hit countries, after the Chinese Lunar New Year holiday, Lin said, adding that formal donation ceremonies will be held in those two countries.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CHEN GIVES PEP TALKS TO DPP LEGISLATORS-ELECT

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Sunday that diligence, justice and professionalism are key elements for an elected representative to become a successful and influential legislator.

Chen, a lawyer-turned politician who once served as a legislator for five years, made the remarks while addressing the closing ceremony for an orientation workshop for legislators-elect of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP).
Chen exhorted all DPP legislators-elect to put overall national interests above anything else and use broader perspective in dealing with public policy affairs.

"To be successful, respected lawmaker, you must be diligent and justice-minded. Professionalism is equally important. You must do research by yourself. You cannot just rely on your aides or read newspapers. You must conduct in-depth study by yourself if you want to be a trend-setter or inspire discussion or debate on major policy issues," Chen said.
Noting that politics is not a one-man show, Chen also encouraged all DPP legislators-elect to stand united in order to realize the party's major policy goals and reform agenda.
"You can have different views and opinions during internal discussions. But you should have only 'one voice' outside the legislative caucus," Chen added.

In his pep talks, Chen also stressed the importance of upholding the party's ideals of promoting democratic reform, boosting awareness of Taiwan's distinctive identity and making Taiwan a "normal, complete, progressive, beautiful and great" country.

"Even though our party fails to reach its goal of winning a majority in the Dec. 11 legislative election, we should not be daunted by the setback. We should not turn back on our party's ideals and missions simply because of the setback. We should instead make self-examination using the highest standards and redouble our efforts to overcome difficulties and achieve our ultimate goal," he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC CALLS FOR MORE CROSS-STRAIT TALKS

TEXT.P: Taiwan is ready to hold more talks with mainland China on a range of economic and legal issues after the two sides reached a landmark deal on non-stop charter flights during the Chinese Lunar New Year holiday, a senior official said Sunday.

Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Chairman Joseph Wu made the remarks a day after the two sides of the Taiwan Strait struck a one-off deal in Macau to allow for two-way, no-stopover charter flights during the upcoming Lunar New Year holiday to facilitate the return of a large number of Taiwan business people operating on the mainland and their family members for festival celebrations.

"We welcome the deal which has laid a very important base for future cross-strait engagements, " Wu said, adding that the Macau meeting marked the first time since 1998 that officials from both sides have sit down to talk.
"We believe that the success of the holiday charter flight talks will contribute much to future negotiations on many other substantial issues," Wu said.
The nation's top mainland policy planner further said the ROC government is hopeful that the smooth negotiations on New Year charter flights will be a turning point for positive interaction.

"The successful outcome of the discussions guided by the government and assisted by the private sector, had formed a basis for mutual trust between the two sides, " Wu said, adding that the MAC has prepared a list of topics to be negotiated with Beijing, including direct cross-strait cargo charter flights, various trade and economic issues, legal problems, repatriation of illegal immigrants and cooperation in fighting crime.

Wu said he hopes mainland China can interact with Taiwan in line with the spirit and principles prevailing in the just-concluded Macau talks to ease cross-strait tension and improve bilateral relations.

In a very short time, negotiators from both sides came to an agreement on the special holiday passenger charter flights. However, while the flights will be non-stop, they will still have to go through Hong Kong or Macau airspace.

Wu said the MAC will continue trying to persuade mainland China to agree to the use of other air routes, such as detouring through the South Korean or Japanese airspaces to save time and fuel costs. Beijing opposed the use of South Korean and Japanese airspaces to avoid giving the impression that the charter flights are international in nature. Beijing claims sovereignty over Taiwan.
Forty-eight flights will be allowed under the agreement, beginning on Jan. 29 and ending on Feb. 20.
The new agreement will permit flights from Beijing, Shanghai and Guangzhou on the mainland and Taipei and Kaohsiung in Taiwan, with each side allowed to select six airlines for the routes.
Taiwan carriers will include China Airlines (CAL) , EVA Airways Corp., Trans Asia Airways, Far East Air Transport Corp., Mandarin Airlines and UNI Airways Corp.

CAL will operate Taipei-Beijing-Taipei flight Jan. 29; Taipei-Shanghai-Taipei and Taipei-Guangzhou-Taipei flights Feb. 5 and Taipei-Beijing-Taipei Feb. 14. Flight schedules of other carriers will be announced later.
From the mainland, airline executives have listed Air China Ltd., China Southern Airlines Co. Ltd., Xiamen Airlines and China Eastern Air as possible candidates.

DOC.HEADLINE: JEN AI HOSPITAL DOCTOR CONFESSED TO LYING

TEXT.P: A Taipei Municipal Jen Ai Hospital neurosurgeon had confessed to lying in the previous investigations into a critically injured girl's hospital odysseys, Deputy Taipei Mayor Yeh Chin-chuan said Sunday.
Yeh said Lin Chih-nan had confessed that he didn't bother to examine the CAT scans of the four-year-old girl, surnamed Chiu, while insisting on transferring the brain-injured child to other hospital.

In the previous probes into the outrageous handling of the case, Lin claimed that he had examined Chiu's CAT scans on computer screens on the third floor of the hospital while Chiu was waiting for a brain surgery in the hospital's emergency room, Yeh said.
Latest investigations showed that Lin even didn't stay in the hospital's intensive care units (ICU) on the third floor between 2:05 a.m. and 4:27 a.m. Jan. 10 as he claimed previously, Yeh said.

Lin claimed previously that he was on-duty at the ICU ward in the third floor and had examined Chiu's CAT scans on computer before insisting that the girl be transferred to other hospitals for a surgery because Jen Ai's ICU ward was already fully occupied.
The girl ended up being transported to a hospital more than 100 kilometers away in the central county of Taichung for surgery. She is still in a critical condition.
Yeh said Jen Ai's another neurosurgeon Liu Chi-hua had assisted Lin in making false statement on the girl's medical records.
Yeh said the city government will come up with a complete investigative report and decide on how to discipline the two doctors Monday.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. WELCOMES CROSS-STRAIT CHARTER FLIGHTS AGREEMENT
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Jan. 16 (CNA) (By Oliver Lin and P.C. Tang)

TEXT.P: The U.S. State Department on Sunday welcomed the agreement reached by the two sides of the Taiwan Strait on the launch of direct charter flights for next month's Lunar New Year holidays.

"We welcome such an agreement as we believe that improving cross-strait economic ties, including cross-strait flights, serves the interests of both the People's Republic of China and Taiwan and is conducive to peace and security in the region, " a spokesman for the State Department said.

In negotiations held last Saturday in Macau, representatives from Taipei and Beijing reached an agreement that will allow Taiwanese and Chinese airlines to fly into each other's territory from Jan. 29 to Feb. 20 to serve China-based Taiwanese business people and their families.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Monday, Jan. 17, or the eighth day of the 12th month of the Year of the Monkey according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1706: Benjamin Franklin, the U.S. statesman and scientist who helped draft the Declaration of Independence, is born.
1773: James Cook's ship "Resolution" crosses the Antarctic Circle, becoming the first ship ever to do so. The British navigator and explorer commanded three major voyages of discovery, charting and naming many islands in the Pacific Ocean.
1781: American revolutionary troops under Daniel Morgan rout a British force in South Carolina.
1874: Chang and Eng, the famous Siamese twins who were born in Thailand of Chinese parents, die within three hours of each other at the age of 62. Joined at the hip, chest, abdomen and head, and even sharing some organs, they married sisters and fathered 10 and 12 children, respectively.
1893: Rutherford B. Hayes, the 19th president of the United States, dies at the age of 71. Winning the controversial election of 1876 by a single vote, he pacified the South by removing federal troops.
1912: A British expedition led by Robert Falcon Scott arrives at the South Pole, one month later than Norwegian explorer Roald Amundsen's successful journey to reach the earth's southernmost spot.
1933: The Chinese communists release a manifesto expressing their willingness to agree to an armistice to bring a halt to the country's civil war and to proceed with an all-out war against Japan.
1934: A "poor white" named Pohl finds a 500-carat diamond near Pretoria in South Africa.
1942: Muhammad Ali, American world heavyweight boxing champion three times over, is born as Cassius Clay.
1946: The Security Council of the United Nations holds its first meeting.
1959: French Sudan and Senegal agree to form the Republic of Mali.
1961: Patrice Lumumba, first president of the Democratic Republic of the Congo, is assassinated.
1966: A B-52 carrying four hydrogen bombs collides with a refueling tanker over Spain, killing eight and releasing the weapons into the Atlantic Ocean.
1971: Ceylon changes its national name to Sri Lanka.
1974: The Oriental Airlines Association begins its eighth flight safety subcommittee conference in Taipei with 20 participants from 11 airlines in the Asia-Pacific area participating.
1975: Lt. Gen. Kung Ling-sheng, newly appointed chief of the Republic of China's mission in the Khmer Republic of Kampuchea, leaves for Phnom Penh.
1976: Dr. Raul Pena, education minister of the Republic of Paraguay, arrives in Taipei for a week-long visit.
1979: The Shah of Iran is exiled and flees to Egypt. Spiritual leader Ayatollah Khomeini succeeds the Pahlavi dynasty to rule Iran.
1991: Iraqi Scud missiles hit Israel on the second day of the Gulf War.
1994: An earthquake rocks Los Angeles, killing more than 60 people.
1995: A disastrous earthquake measuring 7.2 on the Richter scale hits Japan's Osaka and Kobe area, claiming 5,500 lives and injuring more than 20,000.
1996: Silvio Berlusconi, former prime minister of Italy, goes on trial for corruption.
1998: U.S. President Bill Clinton faces Paula Jones and gives testimony in her sexual harassment lawsuit, becoming the first sitting president to give testimony in a U.S. court.
2000: President Lee Teng-hui confers the Medal of the Brilliant Star with the Grand Cordon on visiting Archbishop Paul Josef Cordes in recognition of his longtime support of the ROC in its advocacy of humanitarian work in the international arena.
2001: Legislative Yuan President Wang Jin-pyng leaves for Washington to attend the May 20 U.S. presidential inauguration as Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian's special envoy.
2002: Wang Chen-chih, konwn in Japan as Sadaharu Oh, manager of Japan's Daiei Hawks professional baseball club, receives a letter of appointment as a Republic of China ambassador-at-large.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "Plausible speech, fine manners and studied earnestness are things of which a friend of mine was ashamed; I am also ashamed of such things. To conceal resentment against a person and to make friends with him is also something of which my same friend was ashamed; I am also ashamed to do such a thing."

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC CLOSELY WATCHING SITUATION ON MAINLAND FOLLOWING ZHAO'S DEATH

TEXT.P: The Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) , Taiwan's top mainland policy planner, is closely monitoring the situation in mainland China to see whether the death of former Chinese Communist Party chief Zhao Ziyang leads to social or political unrest, MAC Chairman Joseph Wu said Monday.
Zhao, ousted from his post in 1989 for opposing the use of force against the Tiananmen Square democracy protestors, died in a Beijing hospital at around 7 a.m. Monday. He was 85.

Zhao had been suffering from respiratory and cardiovascular problems in recent weeks, and rumors abounded that he was near death, although Beijing officials denied these rumors, claiming that Zhao's condition was stable.
Wu made the remarks after Beijing's official Xinhua News Agency confirmed Zhao's death in a brief report Monday morning.

A human rights society from Hong Kong speculated Monday that Beijing will tighten up security controls in the next few days out of concerns that Zhao's death could spark widespread demonstrations by students and supporters similar to those that followed the death of former Chinese Communist Party chief Hu Yaobang in 1989.
Hu was removed from his post in 1987 for allowing pro-democracy student unrest, and was replaced by Zhao.

Following Zhao's ouster in the Tiananmen Square crackdown in 1989, he was placed under house arrest where he remained until his death Monday. The media had in recent weeks remained silent about the illness of the politically sensitive figure.
