DOC.HEADLINE: KMT, PFP WILL COOPERATE IN THE END: PFP VICE CHAIRMAN
DOC.DATELINE: San Francisco, Jan. 16 (CNA) (By Y. Chiang and P.C. Tang)

TEXT.P: Opposition People First Party (PFP) Vice Chairman Chang Chau-hsiung said Sunday that the PFP and the Kuomintang (KMT) will cooperate with each other in the end.

Chang, who is in San Francisco visiting his family, made the remarks while touching on recent media reports relating to various interactions among the ruling Democratic Progressive Party, the PFP and the KMT.

According to a report in the local Sing Tao Daily, Chang said the rumors that PFP Chairman James Soong would take the post as Taiwan's next premier or chairman of a commission for cross-strait peace and development are "absolutely nonsense."
Soong had said during his recent visit to Washington, D.C., that he and other politicians of his party will not join the DPP's government and will instead continue their cooperation with the KMT.

However, Chang reiterated the PFP's principle in dealing with cross-strait relations, saying that although the two opposition parties will eventually cooperate with each other, the PFP's long-standing position on cross-strait relations is still "to maintain the status quo and shelve differences."

Therefore, the PFP is really concerned about the remarks made by KMT Vice Chairman Wang Jin-pyng during the campaign for last December's legislative elections that "Taiwan independence is an option, " Chang noted, adding that the KMT should give an explanation for the remarks as well as its stance on the issue of party assets.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINA URGED TO ACCELERATE POLITICAL REFORMS

TEXT.P: Taiwan's top official in charge of mainland affairs on Monday urged the Beijing leadership to accelerate political reforms in mainland China so as to live up to international expectations of the modern Chinese society.

Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Chairman Joseph Wu called for the Beijing leadership to be enlightened by former Chinese Communist Party chief Zhao Ziyang who daringly showed leniency and understanding toward democracy-seeking student protesters in Tiananmen Square in 1989.
Wu made the remarks after learning about Zhao's death Monday morning.

Wu said that Zhao's leniency and understanding toward the protesters in 1989 has been highly recognized by the international community, which considers Zhao a pioneer of China's burgeoning democratization. Zhao was ousted from his post by the mainland leadership during the Tiananmen Square crackdown.
Wu said that China has vigorously pushed for liberalization and globalization in the economic sector over the past decade but has lacked concrete action in political and social reform.
Earlier in the day, Wu said the MAC is closely monitoring the situation in mainland China to see whether the death of Zhao leads to social or political unrest.
Zhao, ousted from his post in 1989 for opposing the use of force against the Tiananmen Square democracy protestors, died in a Beijing hospital at around 7 a.m. Monday. He was 85.

Zhao had been suffering from respiratory and cardiovascular problems in recent weeks, and rumors abounded that he was near death, although Beijing officials denied these rumors, claiming that Zhao's condition was stable.
The official Xinhua News Agency confirmed Zhao's death in a brief report Monday morning.

A human rights society from Hong Kong speculated Monday that Beijing will tighten up security controls in the next few days out of concerns that Zhao's death could spark widespread demonstrations by students and supporters similar to those that followed the death of former Chinese Communist Party chief Hu Yaobang in 1989.
Hu was removed from his post in 1987 for allowing pro-democracy student unrest, and was replaced by Zhao.

Following Zhao's ouster in the Tiananmen Square crackdown, he was placed under house arrest where he remained until his death Monday. The media had in recent weeks remained silent about the illness of the politically sensitive figure.

DOC.HEADLINE: TRANSPORT MINISTER AGREES TO CONSIDER EXTENDING MINI LINKS TO SKIES

TEXT.P: Transportation and Communications Minister Lin Ling-san agreed on Monday to study the feasibility of extending the "mini three links" from the sea to the skies to make cross-strait travel speedier.

The "mini three links" refers to direct trade, postal and transportation links between the outlying Taiwan-held islands of Kinmen and Matsu and the mainland Chinese ports of Fuzhou and Xiamen in Fujian Province.
Lin traveled to Kinmen Monday for a fact-finding tour mainly to inspect the "mini three links" operations there four years after they were implemented Jan. 2, 2001.

Lin was accompanied by Legislator Lee Sen-zong, convener of the Legislative Yuan Transportation Committee, and Legislator Wu Cheng-dian, elected from Kinmen, who suggested that the Ministry of Transportation and Communications consider opening the "air mini three links."

Prior to opening direct trade, postal and transportation links between Taiwan proper and mainland China, or the "direct three links, " the government should consider expanding the "mini three links" from the sea to the air, allowing passenger aircraft from Beijing and Shanghai to fly to Kinmen before heading to Taiwan, Wu noted.
Lin promised to consider Wu's suggestion but added that the "air mini three links" issue involves not only matters related to airports and facilities, but also other economic and political factors.
Besides, Lin argued, the "mini three links" have been operating smoothly and have lived up to the public's expectations by helping bolster transportation exchanges across the Taiwan Strait.

The "mini three links, " originally designed to serve only residents from Kinmen and Matsu and residents of Fujian Province, have also been used over the past two years for mainland-based Taiwanese businesspeople and their families heading home to Taiwan for family reunions during special holidays, Lin said.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Washington Post: Rice Goes From the Inside to The Front; State Nominee May Face Tough Transition.
If confirmed by the Senate to replace Colin L. Powell as secretary of state, National security adviser Condoleezza Rice would move from inside the White House to chief spokesman for U.S. foreign policy and may face a tough transition, the paper said.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING SHOULD LEARN FROM ZHAO'S MAGNANIMITY: EXECUTIVE YUAN

TEXT.P: Mainland China's current leadership should learn from the magnanimity of the purged Chinese Communist Party (CCP) chief Zhao Ziyang, Executive Yuan spokesman Chen Chi-mai said Monday.

Chen made the appeal after former CCP General Secretary Zhao, who was ousted in 1989 for opposing an army crackdown on the Tiananmen Square pro-democracy demonstrations, died in a Beijing hospital earlier in the day at the age of 85. Zhao spent the last 15 years of his life under house arrest.

Chen said most mainland Chinese people have given positive recognition to Zhao's contributions during his tenure as premier and CCP general secretary, particularly for his assisting the late mainland patriarch Deng Xiaoping in promoting market reform to allow mainland China to be integrated into the global economic system.

Noting that Zhao's showing of understanding and sympathy for pro-democracy students was impressive, Chen said mainland China's current leaders should learn from Zhao's lenience and magnanimity and step up pluralistic democratic reform.
Despite its fast economic growth over the past 15 years, Chen said, mainland China has failed to make similar progress in the political field.

"Mainland China has not only failed to promote freedom, democracy, human rights and the rule of law, but has even suppressed religious freedom and demonstrated a poor human rights record, " Chen said.

Zhao has remained a politically sensitive figure up to the present because his attitude toward the 1989 Tiananmen pro-democracy demonstrations differed from those of some other mainland leaders. Against this backdrop, Chen said, Zhao's death could spark a groundswell of protest and unrest on the mainland over how to define Zhao's historical status.
"We'll keep a close watch for any political impact in China from Zhao's death," Chen said.

Meanwhile, he urged Beijing to squarely face up to the Tiananmen crackdown in which mainland troops brutally crushed the student-led pro-democracy demonstrations on June 4, 1989, and clear the name of persecuted demonstrators.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange opened high and closed higher Monday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 55.75 points to close at 5,945.27.
The bourse opened at 5,955.62 and fluctuated between 5,969.03 and 5,940.06 during trading. A total of 3.18 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$59.12 billion (US$1.85 billion).

Six of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with machinery and electronics shares moving up the most at 1.7 percent, followed by cement stocks at 0.7 percent, foodstuff issues, paper and pulp issues and banking and financial shares all at 0.3 percent and plastics and chemicals shares at 0.2 percent.
Two other major stock categories lost ground, with construction issues moving down at 0.6 percent and textile stocks losing at 0.3 percent.
Gainers outnumbered losers 496 to 247, with 162 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES HIGHER ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were higher Monday as the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for January gained 61 points to close at 5,954, with 25,354 contracts changing hands.
TAIEX Index futures for February gained 68 points to finish at 5,965, with 11,416 contracts traded, while March futures gained 68 points to finish at 5,961, with 28 contracts traded.
June futures gained 83 points to finish at 5,960, with seven contracts traded, while September futures moved up 50 points to close at 5,860, with 12 contracts traded.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Monday at 5,893 for January, 5,897 for February, 5,893 for March, 5,877 for June and 5,810 for September.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were higher.
January TE futures moved up 3.4 points to close at 219, with 3,897 contracts traded, while February TE futures gained 3.35 points to finish at 218.65, with 2,274 contract transactions.
No transactions were recorded for March, June and September.

January TF futures gained 6.2 points to finish at 1,020.4, with 3,438 contracts changing hands, while February TF futures moved up 6 points to end at 1,019, with 2,964 contracts traded. March TF futures gained 4.2 point to finish at 1,016.2, with three contracts changing hands.
No transactions were recorded for June and September.

DOC.HEADLINE: VIOLENCE ERUPTS OVER ISSUE OF TEACHERS FORMING UNIONS

TEXT.P: Opponents and proponents of the notion that teachers being allowed to form their own labor unions and go on strike met violently at the Legislative Yuan Monday, with both sides swearing to fight to the end.

The Legislative Yuan began to debate, screen and negotiate over three amendment draft bills related to labor affairs Monday. An article in an amendment draft bill to the Labor Union Law calls for legislation allowing teachers to form labor unions and go on strike.
People on both sides of the issue began shouting and then fistfights broke out. Legislators had to call the police to calm the situation.

Sidelining the legislative debate, members of many labor unions jointly held a news conference at the Legislative Yuan to support the removal of sections of Article Four of the Labor Union Law prohibiting teachers from organizing labor unions. They said the section needed eliminated so that teachers can legally form unions to uphold teachers' human rights.

Chang Hsu-chung, chairman of the Chunghua Telecom Labor Union, said that allowing teachers to organize their own unions is a irreversible world trend. As a father of children attending elementary and junior high schools, Chang said that he supports teachers' rights to unionize.
Chang added that members of his union are monitoring which lawmakers are genuinely on the side of the working class.

Lu Hsiu-chu, chairwoman of the National Teachers' Association, said that should the legislators across the political spectrum fail to reach a consensus to allow teachers access to unions, her association will move to instigate a protest by teachers from around the island against the Legislative Yuan Jan. 20.

Lu said that the administration has tried every scheme to undermine the teachers' will, but teachers are people too who should be afforded human rights. If teachers are denied human rights, how could they teach the students about human rights, Lu said.

Ke Yi-hsien, chairman of the Taipei City Teachers Association, said that protecting workers' basic human rights is a pluralistic value, even a plank in the platform of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party.
Saying that Taiwan is a country that protects human rights, Ke appealed to all the lawmakers from different parties to support the amendment that allows teachers to organize their own labor unions.

Huang Yu-tech, executive director of the Federation of Industrial Association in Tainan County, said that teachers are professionals as well as employees. As such, all employees should have the right to unionize, Huang said, adding that teachers creating unions are not only doing so for the purpose of ensuring their rights and interests, but also for the wholesome development of the entire teaching sector.

Meanwhile, a group of students from the graduate schools of the prestigious National Taiwan University and National Cheng Chi University staged a rally in front of the Ministry of Education, calling for the ministry to face impartially the issue of teachers' rights to organize labor unions.

Chen Po-chien, a student from National Cheng Chi University's Institute of Labor Studies, said that President Chen Shui-bian promised during a Teachers' Day rally in 2003 to see to it that teachers be allowed to form their own labor unions.

However, Chen Po-chien said, the Ministry of Education "intentionally" made public results of a recent poll of public opinions to point out that less then 10 percent of people in Taiwan support the notion of allowing teachers to form unions and more than 70 percent of the people in Taiwan are against the idea.
Chen argued that if teachers are employees, they should have the same rights as those in any labor organization.

He added that the issue of teachers' organizing their own unions is not tantamount to teachers going on strike or ceasing teaching en masse. "They are two different issues that should not be mingled wrongly," he said.
On the opposite side, members of the National League of Parents' Associations also held a press conference at the Legislative Yuan to voice opposition to teachers' rights to form unions.
A spokesman for the league said that students' right to receive an education will inevitably be compromised if teachers are allowed to go on strike and unionize.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. DOLLAR DOWN ON TAIPEI FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar lost ground against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Monday, dropping NT$0.215 to close at NT$31.804.
A total of US$552 million changed hands during the day's trading.
The greenback opened at the day's high of NT$32.019 and hit a low of NT$31.780

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Japan Times: Japan moves to drill in East China Sea Project sure to draw Beijing's wrath.
Japan Petroleum Exploration Co. and Teikoku Oil Co. are in talks with the government on their plans to drill for natural gas in the East China Sea near areas claimed by both Japan and China, government sources said Sunday.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Moscow Times: Benefit Protests Bring Concessions.
As the biggest protests yet against the ending of Soviet-era benefits hit President Vladimir Putin's hometown of St. Petersburg, Health and Social Development Minister Mikhail Zurabov on Sunday promised nationwide help for pensioners with transport fares.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Times: £6bn tax cuts expected as Tories aim to halt poll slide.
Michael Howard will unveil a multibillion-pound tax cut promise today as he tries to revive Conservative election fortunes after the party suffered a double blow yesterday. The Tory leader put a brave face on the defection of a former minister to Labour and a poll suggesting that his party faces its worst election result since 1906. Mr Howard said that he had identified £35 billion in savings on Labour's spending plans, of which he would use £12 billion for tax cuts and reducing government borrowing. He is expected to say today that around £6 billion would be available for tax cuts. The remaining £23 billion would be reinvested in education, health, defence and international aid.
Financial Times: BoE boosts intelligence to spot market threats.
The Bank of England is strengthening its intelligence on financial markets by recruiting more staff to encourage whistle-blowers and pick up City gossip, in order to prevent another Barings-style collapse. The move is part of a "root and branch" review of the Bank ordered by Mervyn King, its governor, as he looks to stamp his mark on the institution by ridding it of the last vestiges of its gentlemen's club image and turning it into a premier professional monetary authority.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHARTER FLIGHT TALKS SIGNAL WARMING OF CROSS-STRAIT TIES: PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: The success of recent cross-strait charter flight talks in Macau between Taiwan and mainland China mark the beginning of normalization of bilateral ties, President Chen Shui-bian said Monday.
Chen made the remarks in a meeting with United States Congressman Tom Lantos at the Presidential Office.

Negotiators from Taiwan and mainland China reached an agreement in Macau Saturday to launch special charter flights from Jan. 29 to Feb. 20 to carry mainland-based Taiwanese businessmen and their families home for the Lunar New Year holiday.
The president said that there is nothing the two sides of the Taiwan Strait cannot achieve if their differences are put aside and goodwill is used to reach a consensus.
There now exists a good opportunity for resuming the long-stalled cross-strait talks this year, he emphasized.

The president reminded Lantos that his new year's day address, called " creating a new and stable environment for consultations and dialogue, " was aimed at encouraging not only domestic political forces but also those across the Taiwan Strait.
Chen also said that Taiwan would strive to protect human rights in line with international standards.

The Legislative Yuan should approve as soon as possible organic laws for the proposed National Human Rights Commission and a National Human Rights Memorial Hall, while making the International Human Rights Code a domestic one, he said.
During the meeting, Chen also decorated Lantos in recognition of his contributions to the promotion of Taiwan-U.S. relations.
Lantos arrived in Taipei Saturday for a four-day visit.

DOC.HEADLINE: TEN YOUNG PEOPLE HONORED AS 'RISING STARS'

TEXT.P: Ten young people were honored Monday in Taipei by the CNA as 10 of Taiwan's rising stars.
They were chosen by a jury of 10 university heads for their significant contributions to Taiwan's image on the international stage.
Following is a list of the 10 people and their remarkable achievements:

Ching-chun Lee, assistant artistic director of the Cloud Gate Dance Theatre of Taiwan, reached the pinnacle of her career when she became the first dancer ever to receive the National Award for Arts in 2004.

Rueibin Chen is a young pianist who won Taiwan's 2004 Golden Melody Award for best performer and best classical music album, and was a winner of the 10 Distinguished Young People awards in 2004 sponsored by the Taiwan Junior chamber.

Liu Jui-chi, an associate professor at the Institute of Art Studies, National Cheng Kung University, Tainan, is one of two university lecturers whose courses on general education were rated by the Ministry of Education as "excellent" in 2004 for the second consecutive year.

Liu also won the 2004 Academia Sinica Prize for Young Scholars and Researchers with her book "Feminine Masquerade, " which compiles essays she has written on female photographers over the last five years.

Solomon Chih-cheng Chen, a trained pediatrician, traveled halfway around the world to work in the remote African state of Malawi. He was inspired to help the underprivileged when he joined a volunteer medical service tour to Mozambique, Malawi and South Africa more than 10 years ago as a sixth-year student at National Taiwan University's Department of Medicine.

Brian Hsieh who majored in Environmental Engineering and Sanitation, is trained as a protector of the environment. He founded the Yen-Lan Environmental Protection Service Co., Ltd. which disposes of about 400,000 tons of waste a year, with revenue of NT$350 million.

Far from being complacent about his achievement, 28-year-old Hsieh has vowed to expand his firm into the country's biggest waste disposal company and the first of its kind to list its stocks on the local bourse.

Chung-chih Wu earned his doctorate in electrical engineering from Princeton in 1997 and returned to Taiwan to work as a researcher at the Industry Technology Research Institute in Hsinchu before joining the faculty of the NTU Electrical Engineering Department.
His research focuses on organic semiconductors for optoelectronic and electronic devices, as well as flat panel displays.

Jungkai Chen, an associate professor of mathematics at the National Taiwan University and a winner of the 2004 Academia Sinica Prize for Young Scholars and Researchers, has set his sights on becoming a world-recognized mathematician.

Tu Jia-jin started the System Integrated Pioneer Semiconductor Co., Ltd. (SIPS) with capital of just NT$1 million, producing systems-on-a-chip and soon captured the attention of world-renowned IC designers who have placed orders with SIPS, creating a thriving business that had bolstered the company's capital to NT$680 million as of the end of 2004.

A Ph.D. from Cambridge University, Wun-shaing Wayne Chang takes great interest and enjoyment in his work at the National Health Research Institute in Taiwan as a postal-doctorate researcher. He works 16-18 hours a day in his laboratory.

Wang Cheng-pang helped the ROC national team win a silver medal in the group archery division in the Busan Asian Games when he was just 15 and helped the ROC team bag a silver medal in the male group event in the 2004 Athens Olympics at the age of 17.

Wang, now a senior at the Hualien Physical Education High School, says he once planned to give up archery because of the tough and tedious training. "But I became determined to continue after thinking that I have been in this sport for so many years. I must redouble my efforts because my dream of winning a gold medal at the 2008 Beijing Olympic Games has yet to come true," he adds.

DOC.HEADLINE: DEAFLYMPICS WRAPS UP IN MELBOURNE WITH TAIWAN WINNING 16 MEDALS

TEXT.P: The 20th Melbourne Deaflympics ended Sunday after 12 days of competition with the team from Taiwan bringing home nine gold, four silver and three bronze medals, Chen Chuan-shou, chairman of the Cabinet-level National Council on Physical Fitness and Sports said Monday.
The result was Taiwan's best ever at the Deaflympics, Chen said.

A total of 3,200 athletes from 78 countries took part in 16 athletic events, with a 45-member Taiwan delegation showing their skills in track and field, swimming, table tennis, bowling, handball and cycling, Chen said.

Former Taipei Deputy Mayor Pai Hsiu-hsing, on behalf of the Taipei City Government, accepted the Deaflympic flag at the closing ceremony to symbolize that the games will be held next in Taipei, Chen said, adding that the council has authorized the Chinese Taipei Sports Association of the Deaf to map out plans to find athletes with great potential and offer them training in the hope that they could perform well at the 21st Deaflympics in 2009.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA EXPRESSES CONCERN OVER TAIWAN MAN ABUSED BY MALAYSIAN POLICE

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs has demanded an explanation from the Malaysian representative to Taiwan over a recent incident in which a Taiwanese businessman was allegedly detained by Malaysian police for 43 days without any evidence of his having committed a crime in Malaysia, Foreign Minister Tan Sun Chen said Monday.

Chen made the remarks while answering reporters' questions on the incident at MOFA headquarters. He noted that according to preliminary information the ministry has collected, the businessman has returned to his home in Taichung County, central Taiwan.

The Malaysian police must have good reason for arresting any Taiwanese citizen doing business in their country, Chen stressed, and indicated that if the Malaysian police have made a mistake in arresting the man, his ministry will demand an apology and compensation.

The victim, identified as Chen Pao-chao, 48, spoke of his ordeal Saturday at a news conference in Taichung, which he held along with Taichung County Magistrate Huang Chung-shen and several legislators.
During the news conference, Chen, who deals in oil used for religious purposes, claimed that he was arrested for alleged drug-dealing Dec. 1 soon after his arrival in Kuala Lumpur on a business trip.
He was detained for 43 days, during which period he was badly mistreated by the police during a series of interrogations, Chen told reporters.

Doctor Chen Kuo-tung of the Tung's General Hospital in Taichung, who examined the businessman Jan. 15, said at the news conference that the patient had lost 11 kilograms and had many bruises on his chest, as well as serious injuries to his genitals.
Chen returned to Taiwan on Jan. 14 upon his release when the Malaysian police could produce no evidence to show his involvement in criminal activity.

DOC.HEADLINE: CNA HONORS 10 RISING STARS

TEXT.P: The Central News Agency shone the spotlight Monday on 10 individuals who have achieved something remarkable and shown great promise for future development before reaching the age of 40.

The unsung heroes, also known as the 2005 Top 10 Rising Stars, were honored at a ceremony held at the Grand Formosa Regent Hotel in Taipei in which Vice President Annette Lu presenting them with trophies and recognized them as Taiwan's elite and pillars of society.

The 10 winners are Ching-chun Lee, Rueibin Chen and Liu Jui-chi in the culture and art category, Solomon Chih-cheng Chen in the public services category, Brian Hsieh in the social improvement and environmental protection category, Chung-chih Wu and Jungkai Chen in the science and technology category, Tu Jia-jin in the economy, finance and business management category, Wun-shaing Wayne Chang in medicine and Wang Cheng-pang in sport.
Praising the winners as elite members of the "post-Kaohsiung Incident generation," Lu said they symbolize Taiwan's bright future.
Lu also exhorted them to redouble their efforts to pursue excellence and inspire more talented young people to contribute to Taiwan's balanced and sustainable development.

"The award means an increase in duty. I hope all the winners will blend tradition and innovation, emphasize both localization and globalization and achieve a balance in their pursuit of personal fame and national interests," Lu said.

Speaking on the same occasion, CNA Chairman Su Tzen-ping said this year marks the first time CNA has sponsored the top 10 rising star selection to recognize outstanding young people who have worked in quiet obscurity and have dedicated themselves to the heart and soul of Taiwan.
"They are an inspiration for others. By bringing them to the notice of the public, society can learn from their accomplishments, perseverance and dedication and use them as role models," Su said.
"We hope the award will inspire more youths to emulate them so that the torch of patriotism and dedication to work will be passed down from generation to generation," Su said.
Noting that all 10 winners still have great potential for future prominence, Su said he believes they will continue to shine and will reach the pinnacle of their careers in the coming decade or so.

Chen Tsung-sheng, vice chairman of the National Youth Affairs Commission, said the selection of the 10 promising unsung heroes is very inspiring and meaningful. He also encouraged the winners to help improve the nation and society while pursuing their careers.
The award presentation was connected to the launch of the 2005 Chinese World Almanac, which CNA has published annually since 1990 to document major domestic and world events.
The success stories of the 10 rising stars were included in the 2005 world almanac.
The 10 rising stars in eight fields were recommended by community leaders from various quarters. CNA enlisted the help of 10 university presidents to choose the winners.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC CHIEF HEADS FOR U.S. TO ATTEND BUSH INAUGURATION

TEXT.P: Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Chairman Joseph Wu left for the United States Monday to attend the Jan. 20 inauguration of U.S. President George W. Bush for his second term.

Wu was accompanied by two other members of the Republic of China delegation the inauguration -- Hsu Su-chien, an Academia Sinica assistant researcher, and Lo Chih-cheng, executive director of the National Policy Research Institute.

The delegation is being led by Academia Sinica President Lee Yuan-tseh, who is aleady in the United States attending an international academic conference and will arrive in Washington, D.C. later. The other delegation member is Yang-Huang Mei-hsin, director of the Research and Planning Board of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, who will also head for Washington later.

Wu said he will meet with leading figures from various American quarters during his stay in Washington, including congressional leaders, think tank scholars and other U.S. friends, to exchange views on topics of mutual concern, including cross-Taiwan Strait relations and mainland China's so-called anti-secession law.

Asked whether the recent cross-strait agreement on the launch of special charter flights during the upcoming Lunar New Year holiday, Wu said that if the topic is brought up, he will be pleased to brief U.S. friends on the procedures and results of the cross-strait negotiations on all relevant technical details.

According to an agreement reached in Macau Saturday, six carriers from each side of the Taiwan Strait will operate 48 direct, non-stop charter flights during the period from Jan. 29 and Feb. 20 between Taipei/Kaoshiung in Taiwan and Shanghai/Beijing/Guangzhou in mainland China for the convenience of Taiwan businessmen operating on the mainland who wish to return for the Lunar New Year celebrations.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. CONGRESSMAN CONCERNED ABOUT TAIWAN'S DECLINING DEFENSE SPENDING

TEXT.P: A visiting United States congressman expressed concern Monday about Taiwan's declining defense expenditure, saying that it is contrary to the country's national interest.

Speaking at a roundtable meeting held at the American Institute in Taiwan's Taipei Office, Tom Lantos, who arrived in Taiwan Saturday for a four-day visit, cited the current issue of the London-based "Economist" showing that mainland China has continued to increase its percentage of gross domestic product (GDP) devoted to defense while Taiwan is decreasing its percentage. "I think this is inexcusable, " he said.

Taiwan is a wealthy society and has US$250 billion in foreign exchange reserves, Lantos went on, adding that despite this, it is apparently incapable of deciding whether to spend US$18 billion on its own defense.

Lantos was referring to a special arms procurement budget of NT$610.8 billion (US$18.23 billion) presented by the Executive Yuan to buy eight diesel-electric submarines, 12 PC-3 submarine-hunting aircraft and six Patriot PAC-3 anti-missile batteries from the U.S. over 15 years. The bill has been pending screening by the Legislative Yuan for several months.
The U.S. congressman said that a recent Zogby poll shows that the percentage of American citizens who would be prepared to defend Taiwan by military means should it become necessary is declining.
"It is declining because the American people feel that the U.S. is heavily engaged in both Afghanistan and Iraq," he explained.
He said, however, that "the American people are anxious and eager to help people to help themselves."
To have the country spend a diminishing proportion of its GDP on defense is a counter-productive policy, he stressed.
"I'm convinced the best way to secure peace is to have a capable defense establishment," he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NOT TREATED WELL BY INTERNATIONAL COMMUNITY: U.S. LAWMAKER

TEXT.P: Taiwan is not treated well by the international community, a visiting United States congressman said Monday.

Speaking at a roundtable meeting held at the American Institute in Taiwan's Taipei Office, Tom Lantos said that the so-called civilized world continues to treat Taiwan's leaders as second-class citizens, authorizing them only transit stops in their countries.
They should receive proper visas and should be allowed to enter the U.S. whenever and wherever they choose, he said.

With regard to Taiwan's bids to join international organizations, the American lawmaker said that he himself and others who are friends of Taiwan will continue to do their best to see that Taiwan is represented in these groups.
"My first priority is of course the World Health Organization, where Taiwan can make an enormous contribution," he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW YEAR CROSS-STRAIT CHARTER FLIGHT SCHEDULE UNVEILED

TEXT.P: The flight schedule for the 24 round-trip charter flights across the Taiwan Strait to be operated by six Taiwan carriers during the upcoming Lunar New Year holiday was unveiled Monday, with Guangzhou as the hottest service destination.

According to a landmark deal reached in Macau Saturday by negotiators from both sides of the Taiwan Strait, six carriers from each side will jointly operate 48 direct, non-stop charter flights during the period from Jan. 29 and Feb. 20 between Taipei/Kaohsiung in Taiwan and Shanghai/Beijing/Guangzhou in mainland China for the convenience of Taiwan businessmen operating on the mainland who wish to return for the Lunar New Year celebrations.
The six Taiwan carriers have worked out their flight schedules in line with the Macau agreement.
China Airlines (CAL) , Taiwan's largest carrier, will take the lead by arranging a flight from Taipei to Beijing at 4:05 a.m. Jan. 29.
As Beijing has only a limited number of Taiwan businessmen, only CAL and EVA Airways will operate a total of four Taipei-Beijing-Taipei flights.

Guangzhou will be the hottest destination, with six local carriers jointly operating a total of 11 round-trip flights between Taipei/Kaohsiung and Guangzhou, which boasts the largest number of Taiwan businessmen among all mainland cities.
TransAsia Airways will only operate Taipei-Guangzhou flights, with round-trip flights Feb. 4, Feb. 6, Feb. 14 and Feb. 15.
UNI Airways will operate two Kaohsiung-Guangzhou-Kaohsiung flights Feb. 6 and Feb. 14, and two Kaohsiung-Shanghai-Kaohsiung flights Feb. 7 and Feb. 15.
CAL will use a 400-seater Boeing 747-400 to make its maiden Taipei-Beijing-Taipei flight Jan. 29 and then offer another round-trip flight on the route Feb. 14.
EVA will also fly a round-trip Taipei-Beijing flight Jan. 29 and another Feb. 15.

There will be seven round-trip Taipei-Shanghai flights during the period, with CAL flying Feb. 5, both EVA and Far East Air Transport flying Feb. 7, Mandarin Airlines flying Feb. 11 and Feb. 12, Far East operating a second round-trip flight Feb. 14 and EVA offering a flight Feb. 15.

CAL and Far East will also operate one round-trip Taipei-Guangzhou flight each Feb. 5, Mandarin will operate Taipei-Guangzhou flights Feb. 12 and Feb. 13 and Far East will operate a flight between the two cities Feb. 14.

DOC.HEADLINE: PROSECUTORS END PROBE OF PFP CHAIRMAN OVER EMBEZZLEMENT ALLEGATIONS

TEXT.P: The prosecutors in charge of a probe into People First Party (PFP) Chairman James Soong over allegations that he embezzled Kuomintang (KMT) funds during his term as KMT secretary-general from 1989 to 1993, decided to close the case without filing charges Monday.

Lin Pang-liang, a deputy chief prosecutor of the Prosecutors' Office at the Taipei District Court said the three-year probe has failed to turn up any new evidence that would reverse the office's previous decision not to charge Soong.
Evidence presented by a lawyer who once worked for the KMT as grounds for re-opening the investigation was either evidence already examined or facts that would not justify charges being laid.

The decision, which was announced amid reports that the PFP will cooperate with the ruling Democratic Progressive Party in the Legislative Yuan gave rise to speculation that it is an olive branch offered by the ruling party to Soong.
Ker Chien-min, the DPP convener at the Legislative Yuan, denied that the decision has any political overtones and claimed that no-one can pull the strings behind the prosecutors' investigation.
Meanwhile PFP Legislator Liu Wen-hsiung said the decision has vindicated Soong's claim that he did not do anything wrong and although late, it is better late than never.

Lawyer Chuang Po-ling, who asked the Prosecutor's Office to re-open the investigation in 2001 despite a KMT decision to respect the prosecutors' decision not to pursue it further, called the prosecutors' decision not to proceed with the probe "incredible."

He said it is regrettable that the Prosecutor's Office, which is part of the administration, has decided to drop the case as an olive branch to the opposition in step with the ruling DPP's efforts to reconcile with the opposition parties.

He warned the opposition parties to wake up and resign themselves to the general public's desire for political harmony and threatened to come up with further new evidence to seek another re-opening of the case.
The case dated back to Dec. 30, 1999 during the leadup to the 2000 presidential race in which Soong competed against KMT candidate Lien Chan and President Chen Shui-bian, who ran on the DPP ticket.

KMT Legislator Chen Chao-nan filed a complaint that day with the Prosecutor's Office at the Taipei District Court claiming that Soong took NT$360 million (US$10.55 million at the time) from the KMT coffers and stashed it in bank accounts opened under the names of some of his relatives.
Soong argued that the funds were put in his charge by then-KMT Chairman Lee Teng-hui for political purposes and offered to return the funds to the KMT.

The case, which provided ammunition for Soong's rivals during the heat of the presidential election, died down after Chen won the election and the prosecutors decided not to pursue it Jan. 20, 2001. The KMT, led by Lien Chan at that time, decided not to appeal against the decision.
However, Chuang, claiming that he had new evidence against Soong, asked the prosecutors to re-open the investigation in March 2001.
His appeal was approved and the probe was reopened April 3, 2001.

DOC.HEADLINE: '319 REPORT' DISMISSED AS POLITICALLY MOTIVATED ABSURDITY

TEXT.P: The Presidential Office dismissed Monday a report on the March 19 shooting of President Chen Shui-bian, prepared by an unconstitutional investigative commission, as an absurd politically motivated assumption.

Chen Wen-chung, director of the Presidential Office's Public Affairs Department, made the remarks after the opposition-dominated "319 shooting investigation commission" issued its initial investigative report that claimed Chen's abdominal wounds were not caused by bullets discovered at the scene in the southern city of Tainan March 19 and that the incident was staged to "manipulate" the March 20 presidential election result. The report also suggests that the Legislative Yuan come up with a proposal to recall the president according to the law.
Chen said that as it stands, the "319 truth commission" is an unconstitutional body according to a Dec. 15 interpretation by the Council of Grand Justices.

Even before the constitutional interpretation was issued, Chen said, all administrative agencies had rejected the controversial commission's requests for access to official documents or evidence over fears that the commission was unconstitutional and illegal.
"This indicates that the commission arrived at its assumption without the support of any concrete documents or evidence. Its report is outrageous and completely unacceptable," Chen said.

Noting that the commission was formed by only nine or 10 representatives named by the opposition "pan-blue alliance" of the Kuomintang and the People First Party, Chen said its report was politically motivated and no more than an unfounded assumption by a few people.

Commenting on the report, Lee Chun-yi, a ruling Democratic Progressive Party legislative whip, said that if the opposition-controlled legislature accepts the controversial commission's suggestion to initiate a proposal to recall the president, he believes that more than one million local people will besiege the legislature to protest such an outrageous move.
Lee further said the 319 commission should stop operations immediately since the grand justices have already declared it as an unconstitutional body.

The March 19 shooting took place in Tainan, southern Taiwan, when the president was aboard an open-topped jeep during a last-minute vote-canvassing rally. The opposition "pan-blue alliance" claimed that the incident was a political scheme to win sympathy votes in the bitterly contested presidential election, although they have produced no evidence whatsoever to support their allegation. Chen narrowly wone re-election a day after the shooting.

DOC.HEADLINE: `319 TRUTH COMMISSION' RECOMMENDS RECALL OF PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: A commission conducting an investigation into the March 19 shooting of President Chen Shui-bian and Vice President Annette Lu recommended Monday that the Legislative Yuan recall the president for "manipulating the presidential election."

At a news conference called by the "319 Truth Investigation Commission, " commission spokeswoman Wang Ching-feng claimed that the wound Chen suffered in the shooting was not caused by the bullet found by the police at the shooting scene in Tainan City and that it is "reasonable to conclude" that the incident was a campaign scheme cooked up to influence the election.

Wang claimed the temperature of the lead-made bullets fired by an unknown gunman in the shooting were not hot enough to melt the jacket worn by the president and produce burning on the president's belly.

Furthermore, Wang said the commission also found there were no bullet holes in the president's jacket and no blood stains on his underwear, although the bullet was reported to have ended up between the president's clothes and his body.
Based on this finding, Wang said the commission determined that Chen's wound was not caused by the bullet alleged to have been used in the shooting.
As to the motive for the shooting, Wang claimed that the "only reasonable cause" was a campaign scheme.

She condemned the president, claiming that he ignored the Constitution and the law by instigating his administration to boycott the commission's investigation, resulting in a ridiculous case of government versus the law, and she urged the legislature to initiate a recall of the president and refer the government officials who blocked the commission's investigation to the Control Yuan for possible disciplining.

The mysterious shooting that took place on the eve of the March 20 presidential election has been at the center of a bitter political struggle between the Demoractic Progressive Party (DPP) and the two main opposition parties, the Kuomintang and People First Party, whose candidates on a joint ticket were beaten by DPP Chairman Chen Shui-bian by a narrow margin.

The two opposition parties, which control the Legislative Yuan, insisted on setting up the commission to look into the shooting by railroading a special statute through the legislature, but was stonewalled by the DPP administration, which refused to give the time of day to the commission after the Council of Grand Justices ruled that it was unconstitutional.

DOC.HEADLINE: GIO DENIES RUMORS OF PRESIDENT'S OVERSEAS DEPOSITS

TEXT.P: The Government Information Office (GIO) denied Monday a rumor circulating via the Internet that President Chen Shui-bian has a large sum of money deposited in overseas banks.

The GIO issued a statement after receiving reports from the public that according to the rumor, three U.S. television networks -- CNN, ABC and FOX -- quoted Nov. 26 a report posted on the Web site of the Washington Post that Chen has large deposits in overseas banks.
The GIO statement said that neither the three American TV networks nor any other mass media have ever made such reports or anything like them.
It is regrettable that someone would use such a fictional rumor to smear and insult the country's head of state, the GIO noted, warning that anyone caught committing libel will be brought to justice.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Tuesday, Jan. 18, or the ninth day of the 12th month of the Year of the Monkey according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1778: British Navy captain and navigator James Cook lands on the islands of Hawaii.
1849: Edmund Barton, statesman and first prime minister of the Australian commonwealth, is born.
1862: John Tyler, the 10th president of the United States, dies at the age of 72. He succeeded to office after the death of William Henry Harrison. His administration was marked by the annexation of Texas in 1845.
1871: Wilhelm of Prussia is proclaimed the first German emperor.
1892: Oliver Hardy, of the U.S. comedy duo Laurel and Hardy, is born.
1904: Hollywood star Cary Grant is born in England as Archibald Alexander Leach.
1911: Huang Hsing and other members of the Revolutionary Alliance arrive in Hong Kong to plan an uprising in Canton, China.
1911: Eugene Ely lands his Curtis Pusher biplane on the U.S. cruiser Pennsylvania in San Francisco Bay, becoming the first pilot to land an aircraft on a ship.
1913: U.S. actor and comedian Danny Kaye is born David Daniel Kaminsky.
1915: Japan presents its "21 Demands" to the Beijing government.
1919: The Paris Peace Conference opens with 27 nations attending. Germany is not allowed to attend.
1943: The Soviet Red Army breaks the 16-month siege of Leningrad and re-establishes land communications with the city, which since September 1941 has been subject to terrible air and artillery bombardment from German forces.
1945: British Prime Minister Winston Churchill urges Germany to surrender unconditionally.
1946: The Taipei County government is formed with Lien Chen-tung, secretary-general of the Taiwan Provincial People's Political Council, serving concurrently as chief of the new government.
1950: The Chinese communist government establishes diplomatic ties with the Democratic Republic of Vietnam (North Vietnam), the first government to recognize the communist state.
1955: Chinese communist troops invade Ichiangshan on ROC-controlled Tachen Island, opposite mainland China's Chekiang Province. Nationalist troops rout the attackers.
1964: A strong earthquake rocks the Chiayi area of southern Taiwan, killing 110 and injuring 452. Ten thousand houses collapse.
1974: Taiwan Power Co. decides to earmark US$1 billion for the construction of the island's third nuclear power plant near southern Taiwan's Kenting National Park.
1976: Lu Liang-huan wins the 10th ROC Open Golf Championship.
1982: The Asia and Pacific Council for Science and Technology is inaugurated to take charge of the nation's scientific cooperation with other Asian countries.
1991: 1,400 anti-Gulf War protesters across the United States are arrested, more than in any demonstration against the Vietnam War.
1995: Lamberto Dini becomes prime minister of Italy, succeeding Silvio Berlusconi.
1996: Costas Simitis becomes prime minister of Greece, replacing an ailing Andreas Papandreou.
1997: Austrian Chancellor Franz Vranitzky resigns.
2000: A seminar on earthquake monitoring and forecasting opens in Taipei with the participation of seismologists from the two sides of the Taiwan Strait.
2001: Two hundred and fifty-five mainland Chinese illegal immigrants are repatriated via the Republic of China-controlled offshore island of Matsu.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "I do not see now a man who can see his own failing or is willing to bring a suit against himself before his own conscience."

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA SPEAKS ON DELIVERING RELIEF ABROAD USING MILITARY AIRCRAFT

TEXT.P: Delivering relief goods to tsunami-hit countries by military aircraft is only one of the government's options in its overseas aid work, a Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) official said Tuesday.

MOFA spokesman Michel Lu was responding to media reports that Taiwan's military aircraft flew two sorties to Indonesia last week to deliver relief supplies by covering up the Republic of China's national emblem on the plane's fuselage and wing to avoid possible protests from mainland China.

Noting that delivery of relief goods is mainly aimed at demonstrating Taiwan's love and concern for tsunami victims, Lu said MOFA is only responsible for negotiating administrative measures with relevant foreign countries while actual delivery has to be carried out by the Ministry of National Defense (MND).
Lu said he is not in a position to comment on technical details regarding the relief supply delivery.

MOFA sources said the ministry has reached agreement with Indonesian authorities to allow ROC military aircraft to transport relief supplies to Indonesia, one of the hardest-hit countries from the Dec. 26 earthquake and tsunamis.

As Taiwan doesn't maintain formal diplomatic ties with Indonesia, the sources said, the government must adopt a pragmatic and flexible strategy to allow for speedy delivery of relief goods to disaster zones.

According to media reports, an ROC Air Force C-130H transport flew two sorties to Indonesia Jan. 14 to deliver relief goods donated by the ROC government and private groups. The plane reportedly made a stopover at Singapore's Changi Airport for refueling. A military aircraft spotter there reportedly took a picture of the plane. Media reports said although the ROC's national symbol on the transport's wing and fuselage had been covered up, it still could easily be recognized as a military aircraft from Taiwan.
Media reports said the military aircraft will also fly two sorties this week to transport relief goods to Indonesia. MND officials declined to make any comments on the reports.

DOC.HEADLINE: OFFICIAL CALLS FOR EQUAL EMPHASIS ON BIRTH AND IMMIGRATION

TEXT.P: The government must equally encourage childbirth and the formulation of constructive immigration policies to ensure that Taiwan is prepared to face changing population demographics, a senior official said Tuesday.
Yeh Jiuun-rong, chairman of the Cabinet-level Research, Development and Evaluation Commission, made the remarks at a seminar on Taiwan's new immigration policy for the 21st century.

Noting that the steady decline in the birth rate in Taiwan and the influx of migrant workers has given rise to very complicated social problems, Yeh said Taiwan must tackle these challenges because of their close relation to social, economic, environmental, medical and educational developments and resources distribution.
Quoting the latest official tallies, Yeh said that one local couple now gives birth to an average of 1.2 children, falling below the ideal number of two children per couple.

Moreover, Yeh said that one out of every eight babies were born to a couple with one spouse being a foreigner (including people from mainland China) ; one out of every three married couples involves a foreign spouse and one out of every three foreign spouses hails from mainland China.
In the 1950s, Yeh said, each local couple gave birth to an average of seven children. The number dropped to five in the 1960s and plunged to 2.1 in the 1970s.

If this rapid downward trend continues, Yeh said, Taiwan is expected to register negative population growth by 2025. Against this backdrop, he said, the government must adopt new strategies to cope with population issues if Taiwan wants to sustain its GDP (gross domestic product) growth.

In the past, Yeh said, the government's population policy focused on birth and death rates and upgrading of education quality while adopting a passive attitude toward immigration issues. The public has also tended to hold negative views on immigration, paying attention only to illegal immigrants and human smuggling operations.

From now on, Yeh said, the government must address the population issue with new vision and approaches. In addition to encouraging childbirth, he said, the government should simultaneously formulate constructive, forward-looking immigration policies.
In the future, Yeh said, the government must also spend more on research of major administrative issues, such as immigration and anti-drug trafficking, to upgrade the quality of public policies.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA SIGNS COOPERATIVE PACT WITH MERCY CORPS FOR TSUNAMI RELIEF

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) signed a memorandum of understanding with Mercy Corps Tuesday on cooperation in relief work in South Asian and Southeast Asian countries affected by the Dec. 26 earthquake and tsunami.
The agreement was signed by Chiang Kuo-chiang, vice chairman of the MOFA's NGO Affairs Committee, and Diana Tsui, chairwoman of Mercy Corps' Asia-Pacific chapter, on behalf of the two sides.

Under the terms of the agreement, MOFA will donate US$250,000 to the Indian Ocean Tsunami Emergency Relief Fund, which was set up by Mercy Corps to help tsunami victims in Indonesia, India, Sri Lanka and other tsunami-affected areas.

Mercy Corps is a noted U.S.-based non-government and not-for-profit organization dedicated to humanitarian aid and development activities. Taiwan previously cooperated with it in 2003 to help displaced war refugees in Iraq, Chiang said, adding that the Iraq cooperative program has achieved satisfactory results.
This time around, Chiang said, Mercy Corps has agreed to distribute relief goods donated by the Republic of China government and private groups for delivery to the hardest-hit disaster zones.
"By cooperating with Mercy Corps, we hope our humanitarian aid campaign can be integrated into the global tsunami relief programs, " Chiang said.
For her part, Tsui said Mercy Corps will use the Taiwan-donated fund wisely to help the tsunami survivors. Taiwan volunteers are also welcome to take part in future relief work, she added.

The Mercy Corps' Indian Ocean Tsunami Emergency Relief Fund will mainly finance middle- and long-term humanitarian aid programs in tsunami-affected regions, with 80 percent used for health and medical care, nutrition, drinking water, cleanup and sheltering programs, and the remaining 20 percent used for service and assistance to survivors' career-rebuilding, Tsui said, adding that in the next two to three years, Mercy Corps will launch 20 aid programs, including community reconstruction.

According to Tsui, major international relief organizations, such as the Red Cross Society, have all stopped accepting relief goods donation and now accept only cash donations to finance various aid projects.

As of Jan. 17, Chiang said, MOFA had received more than NT$158 million and US$100,000 in cash donations and 220 tons of relief goods for tsunami aid drives. Of the relief supplies, 180 tons have been delivered to disaster zones in Indonesia and Sri Lanka.
"MOFA is grateful for local individuals and non-government organizations for their enthusiastic response to the MOFA's fund-raising moves," he added.

DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Jan. 18 (CNA) (By Oliver Lin & Huang Kwang-chun)

TEXT.P: Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Chairman Joseph Wu arrived in Washington, D.C. Monday to attend the Jan. 20 inauguration of U.S. President George W. Bush for his second term.

Wu, who is a member of the Republic of China delegation to the inauguration ceremony, said upon arrival at the airport that he will meet with leading figures from various American quarters during his stay in Washington, including congressional leaders, think tank scholars and other U.S. friends, in addition to taking part in activities to celebrate Bush's inauguration for another four-year term.
He said, however, that he had not yet arranged meetings with any U.S. administration officials.
The ROC delegation is being led by Academia Sinica President Lee Yuan-tseh, who is already in the United States attending an international academic conference and will arrive in Washington later.

The other delegation members are Yang-Huang Mei-hsin, director of the Research and Planning Board of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, Hsu Su-chien, an Academia Sinica assistant researcher and Lo Chih-cheng, executive director of the National Policy Research Institute.

DOC.HEADLINE: OPPOSITION BLOCKS APPROVAL OF CONTROL YUAN MEMBERS

TEXT.P: The opposition in the legislature blocked the ruling party's attempts Tuesday to put President Chen Shui-bian's request to approve his nominees for members of the Control Yuan on the agenda of its last sitting of this session.
The opposition-controlled Rules Committee also voted against debating a bill on a controversial U.S. arms purchase bill at its last sitting, which is set for Thursday.
That means the legislature won't exercise its power of approval or act on the arms purchase bill until newly elect lawmakers are sworn in on Feb. 1.

Since the terms of the incumbent members of the Control Yuan expire at the end of January, the Control Yuan will have no members after Feb. 1, the first time such a situation will have arisen since the country's Constitution was adopted in 1946.

Lawmaker Tseng Yung-chuan, director of the opposition Kuomintang's (KMT) Policy Coordination Committee, blamed the president for nominating people who are so beneath the expectations of the public that lawmakers could not in good conscience vote for them.

As for the arms procurement bill, which will provide the legal framework for the country's NT$610.8 billion (US$18.23 billion) weaponry purchase from the United States, Tseng said his party doesn't take issue with the arms purchase, as such, but it can't agree with paying such an exorbitant price. The issue, Tseng added, is best tackled by the new legislature.

Lawmaker Tsai Huang-liang, the whip of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party Caucus at the Legislative Yuan, castigated the opposition for triggering a constitutional crisis by failing to approve the president's nominees before the deadline.

He also criticized the opposition for placing the country at risk by repeatedly obstructing the bill for the arms purchase, saying that Taiwan needs the weapons to protect itself should mainland China's military attack, and the chance to acquiring these arms is too valuable to miss.

DOC.HEADLINE: 'TAIPEDIA' WEB SITE LAUNCHED TO DOCUMENT TAIWAN'S DEVELOPMENT

TEXT.P: The Web site "Taipedia, " an online encyclopedia on Taiwan whose address is "taipedia.cca.gov.tw, " was launched Tuesday, with President Chen Shui-bian presiding over its inaugural ceremony.

Addressing the ceremony, Chen said the new Web site was built by the Council for Cultural Affairs (CCA) upon his instructions with a view to inviting local people to help document Taiwan's social tapestry and national development.

Chen said the "Taipedia" will offer an efficient search engine service for Web users to study all aspects of Taiwan, ranging from major historical events, folk customs, culture, lifestyle and natural ecology to resources and developments.

"Local people are welcome to provide entries concerning Taiwan to help enrich the online encyclopedia," Chen said, adding that the Web site will serve as a forum for new cultural discourse and public debate to help foster new civic consciousness and shape a distinct identity for Taiwan.
Chen said the ambitious project is also aimed at showing the world Taiwan's knowledge power and cultural strength.

The online version of the Taiwan Encyclopedia is scheduled to be finalized in 2008 along with the opening of a planned world exposition on the island, CCA officials said, adding that the Internet encyclopedia is expected to collect 30,000 to 40,000 entries concerning Taiwan, with a total of 24 million words.

The online encyclopedia will also be published in a printed version of 20 volumes, the officials said, adding that there will also be a condensed version catering to the need of teenagers and young adults as well as an online English edition.
Local people intending to submit entries can first register as "Taipedia" Web site members and their entries will be listed once they have passed screening by a jury of experts.

DOC.HEADLINE: VICE FOREIGN MINISTER VISITS GERMANY
DOC.DATELINE: Berlin, Jan. 18 (CNA) (By Lin Yu-li & Huang Kwang-chun)

TEXT.P: Republic of China Vice Minister of Foreign Affairs Michael Ying-mao Kau is visiting Germany to explain Taiwan's stance on mainland China's proposed anti-secession law and a proposal to lift an arms embargo against Beijing by the European Union, an anonymous diplomatic source said Tuesday.

Kao, traveling at the head of a ROC delegation comprising Mainland Affairs Council Vice Chairman Huang Wei-fong and Liu Shih-fang, a former secretary-general of the Executive Yuan, met figures from various German quarters Monday on a tight itinerary, the source said.
In a news conference, Huang told German journalists that the status quo of the Taiwan Strait is that there are two political entities, one on either side of the strait.
Mainland China's proposed anti-secession law, however, would unilaterally change the status quo because it defines the two sides as a unified nation, he pointed out.

Many polls have shown that an overwhelming majority of the people of Taiwan are opposed to the anti-secession law, Huang went on, warning that tension will increase in the Taiwan Strait if Beijing enacts the legislation in March. Taiwan might enact a countermeasure law if that happens, he explained.
Also, he continued, Beijing's hardliners may use the law to press mainland Chinese President Hu Jintao's regime to legalize the use of force to invade Taiwan.

With regard to the proposal to lift the arms embargo against the mainland, Huang said the E.U. would seem to endorse Beijing's Taiwan-targeting anti-secession law if it approves the proposal. It would be harmful to regional peace and stability, the deputy chief of the ROC's top mainland policy planning agency added.
Kao and his delegation visited Finland, Norway and the Czech Republic before arriving in Germany, the source said, adding that they will proceed to Luxemburg, France and Belgium in the coming days.

DOC.HEADLINE: BUSINESS TRANSACTIONS FOR HSINCHU SCIENCE PARK TOP NT$913 BILLION

TEXT.P: Business transactions for the Hsinchu Science Park reached NT$913.2 billion (US$28.63 billion) during the January to October period of 2004, Science Park Administration Bureau Director Lee Chieh-mu said Tuesday.

An economic rebound has contributed to the increase of the business transactions for six major industries -- semiconductors, computers and peripherals, telecommunications, optoelectronics, precision machinery and biotechnology -- with an annual growth rate of 34 percent, Lee said.

Business transactions for the precision machinery industry hit a production value of NT$7.3 billion, with an annual growth rate of 62 percent, Lee said, adding that the growth rate was the highest of all the six major industries.
Business transactions for the optoelectronics industry had a production value of NT$111.9 billion, up 54 percent over the same period of 2003.
Transactions in the biotechnology industry amounted to NT$2 billion, with an annual growth rate of 39 percent.

For the semiconductor industry, which is the most important industry in the science park, business transactions added up to NT$626.3 billion, representing 68.6 percent of the total transactions, up 39 percent over the same period of 2003. The business transactions for the IC design sector and the microchip production sector -- two sub-industries of the semiconductor industry -- hit NT$139.3 billion and NT$427.6 billion, respectively, up 30 percent and 42 percent, respectively, over the same period of 2003.
Business transactions for computers and peripherals reached NT$114.4 billion, representing 12.5 percent of the total business transactions, up 8 percent over the same period of 2003.
For telecommunications, business transactions amounted to NT$50.2 billion, up 14 percent over the same period of 2003.
According to Lee, it is expected that business transactions for 2004 will top NT$1 trillion and that business transactions for 2005 will also reach a record high.

During the January to November period, a total of 43 new companies were set up, including 18 in the semiconductor industry, 11 in the optoelectronics industry, two in the biotechnology industry, three each in the telecommunications, computers and peripherals and precision machinery industries. The investment capital added up to NT$41.8 billion, with an annual growth rate of 66 percent.

Thanks to the economic recovery, there were 381 high-tech companies at the end of November, with a total of 113,519 employees, up 12,339 over that of a year ago, or an annual growth of 12 percent, Lee said.

DOC.HEADLINE: NATIONAL HEALTH COMMAND CENTER INAUGURATED

TEXT.P: A national command center aimed at organizing rapid response to epidemic control, biological terrorism and emergency medical services was inaugurated Tuesday after nearly two years of preparation.
The National Health Command Center (NHCC) will integrate resources to enhance efficiency in epidemic control and post-disaster relief, Department of Health (DOH) officials said.

Kuo Hsu-sung, director of the DOH's Center for Disease Control, will concurrently serve as NHCC commander, the officials said, adding that the Cabinet might name a provisional commander in the event of a major natural disaster such as a serious typhoon or flood that could cause an epidemic or other public health threat.

The government decided to set up a national health command center after the severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS) epidemic gripped Taiwan between March and June of 2003. The fight against SARS highlighted the need for the government to set up an integrated command center to collect information, communicate opinions and coordinate rapid-response measures in the event of medical emergencies, the officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW AMCHAM PRESIDENT FOR 2005 ANNOUNCED

TEXT.P: The vice president of the San Fu Gas Co., an investment of Air Products Co. of the United States, will serve as president of the American Chamber of Commerce (AmCham) in Taipei, according to a statement issued Tuesday by the organization.

Tom Johnson moves up from the position of first vice president to fill the vacancy left by Andrew Houlberg, who has been transferred by his company, Gillette, to South Korea, according to the statement.

Johnson, who also serves as co-chair of AmCham's Chemical Manufacturers Committee, is a native of Philadelphia, Pennsylvania. He received a B.S. degree in Business Administration from Bloomsburg State University in 1975, an MBA from Temple University in 1979, and completed the Advanced Industrial Marketing program at the Wharton School of the University of Pennsylvania in 1992.

He has been with Air Products and Chemicals since 1979 and is on his second tour of duty in Taiwan. In 1999, he was posted to Taipei as director of the company's Electronics Division-Asia. He left in 2002 to become General Manager of the Division's Eastern U.S. operations but returned in 2003 to take his current position.

The other AmCham officers for the coming year are Jane Hwang, vice president and general manager of State Street Bank's Taipei Branch, as first vice president; Scott Williams, managing director of Federal Express as second vice president; Peter Chen, general manager of GE Financial Restructuring Group, as treasurer, and Christopher Fay, CEO of Saatchi & Saatchi Taiwan, as secretary.
"AmCham this year has an exceptionally strong board of governors and officer corps, so I expect that this will be an active and fruitful year for the chamber," said Johnson.
