DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TO DONATE RICE FOR INDONESIAN TSUNAMI VICTIMS

TEXT.P: The Council of Agriculture (COA) announced Tuesday that it will donate 30,000 tons of rice for Indonesian tsunami victims.

COA officials said that the donation will be made via the Buddhist Compassionate Relief Tzu Chi Foundation, which has presented an application to the council for the rice donation as part of its relief operation for victims of the devastating Dec. 26 tsunami in South Asia and Southeast Asia.
The Tzu Chi Foundation has listed Indonesia on its priority list for and plans to distribute the donated rice to the victims over the course of one year, the officials noted.
The first shipment of 2,000 tons of rice will leave for Sumatra Jan. 20 from the southern Taiwan port of Kaohsiung, they added.
It is estimated that the donation will benefit a total of 1 million tsunami victims, the officials went on.

The COA offers 100,000 tons of rice gratis every year for government agencies and civil charity groups to conduct overseas disaster relief operations as a means of assuming Taiwan's responsibilities as part of the international community, the officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: CRITICS CONTINUE TO FIRE BROADSIDES AT 319 COMMISSION REPORT

TEXT.P: Critics continued Tuesday to deliver broadsides at the report released the previous day by a commission formed to look into the March 19 shooting of President Chen Shui-bian.

Both the administration of President Chen Shui-bian and the ruling Democratic Progressive Party castigated the report of the 319 Truth Investigation Commission, which claimed that the shooting, which took place on the eve of the presidential election, was a scheme concocted to manipulate the election results.

The report also recommended that the Legislative Yuan initiate a recall of the president for what it described as the president's trampling of the Constitution and the law and for the Control Yuan to discipline officials who refused to help with the commission's investigation.

Huang Chih-fang, deputy secretary-general of the Presidential Office, said the conclusions reached in the report are so far-fetched and reckless that it gives rise to suspicion that the report could have been swayed by politics.

Noting that the Council of Grand Justices has ruled that part of the statute on which the commission was organized is unconstitutional, Huang said the administration refused to provide documents to the commission out of fear that doing so might also run against the Constitution, so it is understandable that the report is not well-based on fact.
He claimed that some of the report's conclusions are so outlandish that only political bias can account for them.

He denied that the president was upset by the report, claiming that the president has insisted on following the Constitution in terms of the commission's formation and function and will not concern himself with whatever conclusions the report might have reached.
Chen Chih-mai, the spokesman for the Executive Yuan, said that any reasonable man would have difficulty agreeing with the commission's report.

Noting that the commission has already been ruled as unconstitutional by the Council of Grand Justices, and pointing out that its conclusion contradicts the findings of the police and of U.S. forensic expert Henry Lee, Chen said it allows for only one explanation -- that the report is a politically charged move.

Citing the rule of the Council of the Grand Justices, Chen said the commission members should have been appointed by the speaker of the legislature after a resolution passed by the legislature. However, it was not set up through this procedure and is thereby unconstitutional.

As for the commission's recommendation that the president be ousted through a recall vote, Chen noted that the law forbids the recall of the president or vice president until one year after they have been sworn in, which means the president is immune from any recall attempts before May 20 of this year.
DPP heavyweights joined the two officials in lambasting the report Tuesday after a weekly meeting of the party's Central Standing Committee.
Frank Hsieh, the mayor of Kaohsiung City, said the commission's report is a deduction rather than a conclusion.

Su Tseng-chang, the secretary-general of the Presidential Office, dismissed the report as "absurd, " saying it only proves that the commission members have been blinded by their political bias and their anger toward the president.

Yang Si-ching, a lawyer who once served as chief of the country's bar association, said on a separate occasion Tuesday that the commission's report carries no legal force at all, as the commission has been ruled as unconstitutional.

DOC.HEADLINE: REPORT OF INVESTIGATION COMMISSION TO BE DISCUSSED AT LEGISLATURE

TEXT.P: The opposition-controlled Rules Committee of the Legislative Yuan decided Tuesday to put a report compiled by an unconstitutional commission formed to investigate the March 19 shooting of President Chen shui-bian on the agenda of Thursday's legislative sitting, to an outcry from the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP).

Acting DPP Chairman Ker Chien-ming said the decision is improper because the report was delivered to the Secretariat of the Legislative Yuan after the midday deadline for receiving possible items on the agenda for Thursday's sitting.

Noting that the Rules Committee has ruled out many urgent bills from the agenda of the session's last sitting while including the report from an unconstitutional commission, Ker said the decision is unacceptable.

He blamed Legislative Yuan President Wang Jin-pyng, who is a vice chairman of the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) , for setting a bad precedent by allowing the commission's report to jump the queue and be squeezed into Thursday's agenda ahead of other more important bills.

Dismissing as "absurd" the commission's recommendation to recall the president, Ker said no political party would ever endorse the idea and that the legislature should reject the report and put an end to what has become a "political farce."

Meanwhile, Legislator Liu Wen-hsiung, the convener of the opposition People First Party (PFP) , which helped the KMT to set up the commission, reserved his party's opinion on the commission's report, saying that the PFP will consult public opinion before responding.
However, he lauded the commission for soldiering on in defiance of the Council of the Grand Justices, which ruled the commission unconstitutional, and coming forward with its report.

"We will let the legal procedure run its course and let the next legislature address the problem of the commission's unconstitutionality, " Liu said, referring to the fact that the current legislative session is set to close before the end of this month.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT ASKS FOR EXTENSION OF LEGISLATIVE SESSION

TEXT.P: The Presidential Office is hoping that the Legislative Yuan will extend its current session and exercise its right to approve the president's nominees for members of the Control Yuan, Presidential Office Secretary-General Su Tseng-chang said Tuesday.

Noting that the legislature's failure to exercise its approval right will mean that the country will have no Control Yuan members after the incumbent members' terms fall due by the end of this month, Su said this will prompt a constitutional crisis.

The opposition-controlled Legislative Yuan, which will expire by the end of the month, refused to act on the president's nominees during its last sitting, claiming that they are so far beneath the expectations of the public that the lawmakers could not in good conscience approve their nominations.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Wednesday, Jan. 19, or the 10th day of the 12th month of the Year of the Monkey according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1736: James Watt, Scottish engineer and inventor who made fundamental improvements in the steam engine, resulting in the modern, high-pressure steam engine patented in 1769, is born.
1793: King Louis XVI of France is sentenced to the guillotine.
1798: Auguste Comte, French philosopher known as the founder of positivism, is born. He also established sociology as a systematic field of study.
1920: Javier Perez de Cuellar, Peruvian secretary-general of the United Nations from 1982 to 1992, is born.
1926: Chiang Kai-shek is appointed president of the Central Military and Political School which later becomes National Chengchi University.
1929: Liang Chi-chao, who together with Kang Yu-wei initiated a reform movement in China in 1898 after the success of the Meiji Reformation in Japan, dies in Peiping (Beijing) at the age of 57.
1942: Japanese troops invade Burma.
1953: A total of 110 members of the Taiwan People's Liberation Armed Defense Group, which was organized by the Chinese Communists, are arrested in Lukhushan near Hsichih, Taipei County.
1960: The United States signs a treaty of mutual security with Japan to set up relations of economic and military cooperation.
1966: Indira Gandhi becomes India's first female head of state and the second female prime minister in the world.
1967: Kuo Mei-chen (Hellen Quach), vice director of the New York Philharmonic and under Leonard Bernstein, wins the gold medal in a conducting contest in New York.
1968: The USS Forwarder, a nuclear-powered aircraft carrier, arrives in Sasebo, a naval base in Japan, for a five-day visit.
1968: The Legislative Yuan approves regulations governing the implementation of nine-year compulsory education.
1969: Jan Palach, a 21-year-old student, sets fire to himself in Wenceslaus Square in Prague in protest of the Soviet invasion of Czechoslovakia.
1972: Satellite communications between Taipei and Tokyo begin operating.
1973: The Republic of China severs diplomatic relations with Dahomey, now known as the Republic of Benin.
1974: Dr. Charles J. Hitch, president of the University of California at Berkeley, arrives in Taipei for a four-day visit under the Asian Foundation's Eminent Americans Abroad Program.
1974: Beijing expels five Russians, including a senior diplomat and two other members of the Soviet embassy staff, on espionage charges.
1975: A new constitution comes into effect in Communist China, replacing the one in force since 1964.
1976: The millionth resident of Kaohsiung is born.
1978: Minister of Economic Affairs Sun Yun-suan signs accords on industrial and agricultural cooperation with Ghazi Abdul Rahman Al-Gosaibi, Saudi Arabia's minister of industry and electricity, and Abdul Rahman Ibn Al-Sheikh, the Middle Eastern nation's minister of agriculture and water.
1980: David Dean, chairman of the American Institute in Taiwan, after arriving on Jan. 14, meets with Dr. Tsai Wei-ping, chairman of the Coordination Council for North American Affairs, to exchange views on ROC-U.S. relations.
1982: President Chinag Ching-kuo receives U.S. Senator Frank H. Murkowski (R-Alaska) and Congressmen Trent Lott (R-Miss), Richard T. Schulze (R-Penn) and William Carney (R-NY) and their wives at the Presidential Office.
1998: El Salvador signs an agreement with Honduras, ending a border dispute.
2000: ROC Vice President Lien Chan says that the ROC on Taiwan is now the world's 18th-largest economic power and 15th-largest trading country and that it should pursue a "mature economy."
2001: Taiwan's China Development and Industrial Bank announces a decision to form an assets management company with internationally renowned Morgan Stanley Deanwitter to buy poorly managed credits and assets.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "Be a good and wise man while you try to be an encyclopedic man of culture; be not a fool while you try to be an encyclopedic man of culture."

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN REMOVED FROM USTR'S SPECIAL 301 PRIORITY WATCH LIST
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Jan. 18 (CNA) (By Wennie Chi and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: The Office of the U.S. Trade Representative (USTR) removed Taiwan from its "Special 301 priority watch list" Tuesday in recognition of the island's efforts and progress in intellectual property rights (IPR) protection.
U.S. Trade Representative Robert Zoellick said that Taiwan's efforts in cracking down on commercial piracy and counterfeit products over the past year have been commendable.

Zoellick noted, however, that Taiwan can do a better job in protection of patent and innovation rights on pharmaceutical products and agrochemical products since the United States thinks that IPR threats still exist in those areas.

He said that IPR protection is one of the prime elements behind efforts to gear up the world's economic growth and that the United States strongly requires that its trade partners strengthen their laws to help maintain innovation in science and technology products.
The USTR announced the removal of Taiwan from the list in its out-of-cycle Special 301 report Tuesday. Taiwan had been on the "priority watch list" for four consecutive years dating back to 2001.
In the report, the USTR noted that Taiwan has made "significant progress" in cracking down on commercial piracy and passing IPR protection legislation over the past year.

The report pointed out that Taiwan authorities need to step up efforts in protection of patent and innovation rights on pharmaceutical products, further strengthen IPR laws pertaining to agrochemical products, and intensify the crackdown on Internet MP3 downloading and other commercial piracy.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT PUTS FORWARD INITIATIVE TO WELCOME FORMER MEMBERS BACK INTO PARTY

TEXT.P: The opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Central Standing Committee met Wednesday and reached a consensus on welcoming former members who left the party due to political differences back into the KMT.

The initiative, to be implemented by the KMT Organization Development Committee, has been interpreted as a move to welcome opposition People First Party (PFP) Chairman James Soong back into the KMT fold.

Soong was expelled from the KMT in 2000 after a fallout with the party leadership and then ran for the Republic of China presidency the same year. Chin Chin-sheng, Soong's top aide at the time, was also ousted from the party.

In a statement, the KMT Organization Development Committee said that over the past several years, many KMT members have left the party due to opposition to moves made by former KMT Chairman Lee Teng-hui. It's time for them to return to the KMT now that Lee has not been associated with the party for a long period of time, the committee officials said.
Commenting on the initiative, Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou, who is a vice chairman of the KMT, said that it could serve as "belated justice" for Soong, to whom the KMT at least owes an apology.
Meanwhile, PFP spokesman Hsieh Kung-ping called the initiative "appropriate and reasonable."

Liu Wen-hsiung, a PFP party whip at the Legislative Yuan, said the initiative is a "goodwill" gesture, but he added that the KMT must abandon "the Lee path" it has been following if it is serious about closer collaboration with the PFP.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI SHARE PRICES CONTINUE FALLING

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange dropped further Wednesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving down 38.22 points to close at 5,895.35.

The bourse opened at 5,952.59 and reached the day's high of 5,961.78 at one point before closing at the day's low of 5,895.35. A total of 2.66 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$50.32 billion (US$1.57 billion).

All of the eight major stock categories lost ground, with construction stocks moving down the most at 1.6 percent; followed by textiles and machinery/electronics stocks at 0.7 percent; plastics/chemicals shares and foodstuff stocks at 0.6 percent; and cement, paper and financial issues at 0.4 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 540 to 179, with 202 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN ENACTING LAW FOR PHARMACEUTICAL EXCLUSIVITY PROTECTION

TEXT.P: Taiwan is enacting legislation to further bolster the protection of pharmaceutical data exclusivity, officials from the Intellectual Property Office said Wednesday.

A draft bill authored by the Department of Health has been submitted to the Legislative Yuan for screening and passage, the officials said Wednesday upon news that Taiwan has "graduated" from the U.S. blacklist of trade partners for priority watch.

The Office of the U.S. Trade Representative (USTR) removed Taiwan from its "Special 301 priority watch list" Tuesday in recognition of the island's efforts and progress in intellectual property rights (IPR) protection.
U.S. Trade Representative Robert Zoellick said that Taiwan's efforts in cracking down on commercial piracy and counterfeit products over the past year have been commendable.

He noted, however, that Taiwan can do a better job in protection of data exclusivity for pharmaceutical products and agrochemical products, since the United States thinks that IPR threats still exist in those areas.

He said that IPR protection is one of the prime elements behind efforts to gear up the world's economic growth and that the United States strongly requires that its trade partners strengthen their laws to help maintain innovation in science and technology products.
The USTR announced the removal of Taiwan from the list in its out-of-cycle Special 301 report Tuesday. Taiwan had been on the "priority watch list" for four consecutive years dating back to 2001.

The report pointed out that the Taiwan authorities need to step up efforts in protection of data exclusivity for pharmaceutical products, further strengthen IPR laws pertaining to agrochemical products, and intensify the crackdown on Internet MP3 downloading and other commercial piracy.

Officials from the Intellectual Property Office under the Ministry of Economic Affairs said that the removal of Taiwan from the "priority" list to the ordinary watch list is welcomed, but they said that it is pitiful that Taiwan still remains on the U.S. 301 watch list.
The officials said that Taiwan's lack of protection of pharmaceutical data exclusivity is to blame for the island's not having been removed from the Special 301 watch list once and for all.
They said that the Department of Health completed a draft bill on the issue last year but the bill has remained on the Legislative Yuan shelf awaiting screening and passage.
The officials said that Taiwan's efforts in IPR protection will not relent, even though legislation has not yet been passed.
It is hoped that Taiwan will be removed from the Special 301 watch list altogether in April this year when the USTR conducts its annual review, the officials added.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TO TEMPORARILY SUSPEND IMPORT OF VIETNAMESE CAREGIVERS

TEXT.P: The Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) announced Wednesday that imports of Vietnamese caregivers will be temporarily suspended from Thursday because of the high absconding rate of this category of Vietnamese workers.
However, CLA officials said, the temporary import ban will not affect directly hired Vietnamese whose local employers agree to rehire them after their three-year work contracts expire.

The officials said the CLA was forced to impose the temporary ban because the number of runaway Vietnamese caregivers remains high. Although the Vietnamese representative office in Taipei has been assisting in tracking down absconded Vietnamese workers, the number of people captured has fallen short of the target.

According to the officials, Vietnamese authorities originally promised to track down 2,000 Vietnamese runaways by the end of last year. However, only some 900 had been seized as of the end of December.
In recognition of Vietnamese authorities' efforts, the officials said, the CLA will just close Taiwan's door to Vietnamese caregivers for the time being.

"We have avoided using the term 'freeze' to minimize the impact of the measure," a CLA official said, adding that the use of the term "temporary suspension" also marks the CLA's recognition of Vietnam's cooperation in tracking down runaways.

The official said Vietnam has come up with new plans for tracking down runaways and curtailing a further increase in absconding. The intensified search for absconders will continue through the end of March and if they generate satisfactory results, the official said, the temporary import ban can be lifted.

DOC.HEADLINE: MORE THAN 4 TAIWAN CHILDREN ABUSED TO DEATH PER MONTH: CHILD GROUP

TEXT.P: At least 4.13 children are abused to death by adults per month in Taiwan, according to the Taipei-based Child Welfare League Foundation.
The average was worked out by compiling the number cases reported by the media during the period from January 2004 to mid-January this year, a foundation spokesman said.
At least 56 children were abused to death by adults or driven to suicide by their parents during the last 13 months, reflecting an average of 4.13 each month,the spokesman said.

Citing statistics released by the Ministry of the Interior, he elaborated that there were 2,930 reported child abuse cases in the first half of 2004 alone, equal to some 55 percent of the 2003 total. He predicted that the number for the whole of 2004 will exceed the 2003 total as more cases are expected to have occurred during the peak season of July and August.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES LOWER ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were lower Wednesday, as Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index futures for January moved down 60 points to close at 5,885, with 19,517 contracts changing hands.

TAIEX Index futures for February dropped 53 points to finish at 5,904, with 33,858 contract transactions, while March futures decreased 42 points to close at 5,905, with 71 contracts traded. June futures moved down 44 points to finish at 5,899, with eight contract transactions, while September futures dropped 26 points to close at 5,825, with seven contracts traded.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Wednesday at 5,945 points for January, 5,957 points for February, 5,947 points for March, 5,943 points for June and 5,851 points for September.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were also lower.

January TE futures dropped 2.25 points to close at 216, with 2,766 contracts changing hands, while February TE futures moved down 2.65 points to finish at 215.75, with 3,538 contract transactions. March TE futures increased 0.05 points to close at 217.70, with two contracts traded. No transactions were recorded for other months.

January TF futures moved down 8.6 points to finish at 1,013, with 2,500 contracts changing hands, while February TF futures dropped 4.6 points to close at 1,013.8, with 3,487 contracts traded. March TF futures decreased 0.8 points to finish at 1,013.8, with only one contract transaction. September TF futures remained unchanged at 1,006.2 points, with only one contract traded. No transactions were recorded for other months.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Times: The Army's shame.
Bound, blindfolded and tied in a net, an Iraqi prisoner lies helpless on bare concrete at a British base near Basra. Crouching with a pool of water at his feet, he is powerless as a British soldier stands on him. Lance Corporal Darren Larkin appears to be pretending to surf on his victim, seemingly unaware that he is in a country where even the slightest contact with the soles of the feet is regarded as a grave insult. At least three comrades from the 1st Battalion The Royal Regiment of Fusiliers look on, two taking photographs. The image will cause outrage across the Arab world and severely undermine the reputation of the British Army. General Sir Mike Jackson, Chief of the General Staff, took the extraordinary step of issuing a personal statement to condemn any abuse by British soldiers. The photograph was one of 22 presented yesterday at the court martial of Larkin and two of his comrades who are accused of" shocking and appalling"abuse and sadistic maltreatment of Iraqi detainees.

DOC.HEADLINE: PACIFIC-RIM OUTRIGGER CANOE VOYAGE TO KICK OFF IN MAY

TEXT.P: An experimental voyage by outrigger canoe around the Pacific Rim is scheduled to begin from Indonesia in May in an attempt to revive the spirit of the Austronesian people who have plied the Pacific Ocean over the past several thousand years.

The Civilization Explorer Association of the Republic of China, in collaboration with a Japanese adventurer, launched the Navigation Plan to Rebuild Pacific Rim Communications Wednesday at a press conference in Taipei. They hope to complete the ambitious voyage over an 18-month period.

Outrigger canoes have been used for thousands of years by the Austronesian people all over the Pacific. A wooden structure fixed to the side of a small boat makes the craft sturdy enough to allow it to be navigated even in stormy conditions.

The voyage, considered to be a move toward a Pacific cultural renaissance, will be completed by six sailors from Taiwan, Japan, the Philippines, Indonesia, Malaysia and Tahiti, said Chen Chin-kuo, head of the association.
The project is also designed to verify the possibility of whether early Austronesians sailed eastward from Easter Island to South America, said Chen.

Taiwan is part of the huge Austronesian-language group, which probably underwent the widest physical dispersion of a single language family prior to the European colonial expansion following Columbus, from the island of Madagascar off the east coast of Africa all the way to the tiny, isolated Easter Island (Rapa Nui) and extending to Taiwan, Vietnam, Northern Australia, New Zealand and most of the Melanesian and Polynesian islands.
Nearly 300 million people are currently living in these areas.

According to a genome analysis, genes of the Japanese people during the prehistoric Jomon Era, the ancient Taiwanese aboriginal people and the ancient Incan people from South Africa and Peru are genetically identical. But so far, no historical archive have been found to prove that the Austronesian people ever sailed east all the way from Easter Island to South America, according to the Japanese maritime adventurer Yoshiyuki Yamamoto.

In addition to adding to the body of knowledge of Asian maritime history, the project is also aimed at consolidating an esprit de corps among the people around the Pacific Rim and heightening environmental protection awareness, particularly in the wake of the Dec. 26 magnitude 9 earthquake and ensuing tsunami that have killed at least 160,000 people in South Asia and Southeast Asia, Yamamoto said.

He said the most dangerous part of the voyage will be the sail from Tahiti via Easter Island to Peru and that the most challenging task could be forging teamwork among the six prospective crew members, who all speak different languages.

Tsang Chen-hua, director of the Taitung-based National Museum of Prehistory, said that Taiwan-based Austronesians began to cruise toward the south some 5,000 years ago, marking one of the largest exoduses in human history.

The Navigation Plan to Rebuild Pacific Rim Communication, Tsang said, will have four major perspectives -- verifying that the Austronesians moved south from Taiwan, reviving the Austronesians' navigation skills, re-living the early Austronesians' dreams of home-building, and demonstrating the Austronesian people's ability to live peacefully with the ocean.
An outrigger canoe about eight meters long designed in accordance with ancient designs is being built by a group of native shipbuilders on Sulawesi Island in Indonesia.
The plan is scheduled to be completed in August 2006 when the outrigger canoe returns to Taitung, eastern Taiwan, Tsang added.
In related news, the National Museum of Prehistory in Taitung acquired in December 2004 a new outrigger canoe built in Palau in an effort to enrich the museum's collections.
The seven-seat outrigger was built by shipbuilders appointed in person by Palau President Tommy Remengesau, said Tsang.

DOC.HEADLINE: SHANGHAI AIRLINES EXPECTED TO LAUNCH FIRST FLIGHT TO TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Shanghai Airlines is expected to be the first out of six mainland Chinese carriers to fly non-stop charter flights across the Taiwan Strait, with its first flight scheduled to take off from Shanghai for Taipei Jan. 29, a local newspaper reported Wednesday.

The Beijing-based China Daily quoted Fan Hongxi, president of the airline, as saying that the airline had sent the proposed take-off time, set for 8: 45 a.m., to the General Administration of Civil Aviation of China for approval.
Other airlines operating flights from Beijing and Guangzhou to Taiwan will fly later the same day.

The six mainland airlines providing charter flights for Taiwan businessmen and their families during the Lunar New Year are Air China, China Southern Airlines, China Eastern Airlines, Shanghai Airlines, Hainan Airlines and Xiamen Airlines.

Negotiators from Taiwan and mainland China reached an agreement in Macau Saturday to launch special charter flights from Jan. 29 to Feb. 20 for mainland-based Taiwanese businessmen and their families over the Lunar New Year holiday.

The services will be jointly operated by six air carriers from Taiwan and the mainland, each of which will offer 24 round-trip flights during the period between Beijing/Shanghai/Guangzhou on the mainland and Taipei/Kaohsiung in Taiwan, according to the agreement.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC PRESIDENTIAL ENVOY ARRIVES IN U.S. FOR BUSH INAUGURATION
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Jan. 18 (CNA) (By Oliver Lin and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Academia Sinica President Lee Yuan-tseh arrived in Washington, D.C. Tuesday to attend the Jan. 20 inauguration of U.S. President George W. Bush on behalf of President Chen Shui-bian.
Lee, a co-winner of the 1986 Nobel Prize in chemistry, said his main mission is to convey Chen's congratulations on Bush's re-election.
As for Taiwan-U.S. relations, Lee said he is not versed in relevant issues but he added that he thinks regular dialogue and communications are needed to boost bilateral ties.

Lee said he has met with Bush on several previous occasions and feels Bush to be an affable and charismatic person. Lee has attended the annual informal leadership meeting of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation forum on behalf of Chen for the past few years, where he has invariably held talks with Bush.

The Taiwan delegation to Bush's inauguration also includes Mainland Affairs Council Chairman Joseph Wu, Yang-Huang Mei-hsin, director of the Research and Planning Board of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, Hsu Su-chien, an Academia Sinica assistant researcher and Lo Chih-cheng, executive director of the National Policy Research Institute. The four delegates arrived in the U.S. capital Monday.

Unlike Lee, the four delegates have other missions besides attending Bush's inauguration ceremony. They will meet with U.S. congressional members and think tank scholars to exchange views on mainland China's proposed anti-secession legislation targeting Taiwan and other matters of mutual concern.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. DOLLAR DIPS ON TAIPEI FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar dipped against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Wednesday, losing NT$0.091 to close at NT$31.802.
A total of US$670 million changed hands.
The greenback opened at NT$31.893 and was traded between NT$31.780 and NT$31.936 during the trading session.

DOC.HEADLINE: INBOUND VISITORS UP 31.2 PERCENT IN 2004

TEXT.P: The number of inbound visitors reached 2.95 million in 2004, marking a whopping 31.2 percent increase from the year-earlier level, the Directorate-General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS) said Wednesday.

The steep rise could be attributed to the general economic recovery last year and a relatively low number of foreign visitors in 2003 due to outbreaks of severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS) between March and June that year, DGBAS officials said.
Japan remained the largest source of inbound visitors, with 887,000 Japanese citizens visiting Taiwan in 2003.

Meanwhile, Taiwan people made 7.78 million overseas visits in 2003, up 35 percent from the year-earlier level. Hong Kong was the most popular travel destination, with Taiwan people making 2.56 million visits to the former British colony for a robust 37 percent year-on-year growth.

DOC.HEADLINE: ARMS PROCUREMENT BUDGET TO BE ADJUSTED DOWNWARD: MINISTER

TEXT.P: The Ministry of National Defense will come up with a revised budget bill to be submitted by the new Legislative Yuan to be inaugurated Feb. 1, Minister of National Defense Lee Jye said Wednesday.

Lee made the remarks a day after the opposition-controlled outgoing legislature failed to put the defense ministry-proposed arms procurement budget bill on the agenda of its last plenary session scheduled for Friday.

"We have come to understand that the special arms procurement bill cannot clear the legislature during the current session. The defense ministry will adjust downward the amount required for the purchase of three advanced weapons from the United States and will refer the revised version to the new legislature for approval, " Lee said.

Thanks to changes in the currency exchange rate and the decision that the eight diesel-electric submarines will not be built in Taiwan, Lee said the budget required for the long-stalled arms procurement package will fall below previous estimates.

"We hope new legislators can support the amended arms procurement budget bill as early as possible to facilitate the military's arsenal renovation plan in the face of mainland China's ever-mounting military threat," Lee said.

Some opposition lawmakers have called for NT$150 billion to NT$200 billion to be cut from the defense ministry-proposed budget for the procurement package. Lee declined to make any comments on the proposal, saying that the time is not right to talk about any concrete figure.
The package includes the purchase of eight diesel-electric submarines, a squadron of 12 submarine-hunting P-3C Orion aircraft and six Patriot PAC-III anti-missile batteries.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN WILL KEEP LOW PROFILE IN POST-TSUNAMI RELIEF: PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Wednesday that since Taiwan is in a very difficult diplomatic situation, the nation will keep a low-profile while delivering relief materials to South and Southeast Asian countries affected by the Dec. 26 earthquake and resulting tsunamis.
Chen made the remarks while addressing an award presentation ceremony at the Tainan County Cultural Center, during which he presented "Phoenix Awards" to 30 outstanding fire fighters.

According to media reports, Taiwan's military aircraft flew two sorties to Indonesia last week to deliver relief supplies and covered up the Republic of China's national emblem on the plane's fuselage and wing to avoid possible protests from mainland China.

As the Beijing authorities spare no efforts to deter Taiwan from participating in international affairs, Chen pointed out that the government should keep a low profile in offering humanitarian aid to tsunami-hit countries.

Noting that love and humanitarian aid have no boundaries, Chen said that the government will try any feasible approach to deliver all relief goods donated by the public and private sectors to disaster zones to demonstrate Taiwan's love and concern for tsunami victims.
Chen voiced the hope that all 170 metric tons of relief material donated by the government and private groups will be transported to tsunami-affected countries by Jan. 28.

The president further said that Taiwan has promised to donate US$50.25 million to assist in post-tsunami reconstruction work in disaster regions and has dispatched about 400 relief workers to disaster zones since the Dec. 26 catastrophe. In addition, the nation will also sponsor 10,000 tsunami-affected children for one year, he said.

In related news, 20 groups of young students from domestic Buddhist institutions, led by Fokuangshan masters, will travel on foot in various parts of Taiwan starting from Thursday to raise money to help tsunami-affected children in South and Southeast Asian countries.

All duty free shops at the Chiang Kai-shek International Airport began a series of charity sales, which will run through Jan. 31, while Tungshih Senior High School in Chiayi County delivered all donations from its teachers and students for tsunami victims to World Vision Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT AIMS TO CREATE EXTENSIVE MOBILE COMMUNICATIONS BY 2008

TEXT.P: The government plans to make mobile communications networks ubiquitous in the country by 2008 under a project called "Mobile Taiwan, " according to officials of the Science and Technology Advisory Group (STAG) of the Executive Yuan.

The "Mobile Taiwan" project forms part of the "10 new major construction programs" initiated by the Executive Yuan to make Taiwan into a "green silicon island" within six years, the STAG officials said.

Lin Feng-ching, deputy convener of the STAG, said that the government hopes to transform the country by setting up the basic infrastructure needed to create a system whereby cellular phone network services, information technology computer platforms and broadband Internet links would be combined.

So far, the government has earmarked NT$7 billion (US$219 million) for the establishment of public WLAN (wireless local area networking) and application services, NT$30 billion for local authorities to build a total of 6,000 kilometers of broadband fixed Internet links and "10 mobile cities" plus "15 special mobile districts" around Taiwan by 2008.

The "10 mobile cities" plan will provide 8 million subscribers across Taiwan with easy access to the Internet through WLAN and their mobile phones anywhere in Taiwan, turning the nation into the world's fifth most competitive country in terms of e-business applications. This in turn, it is hoped, will boost tourism, help maintain public order and better manage traffic.

According to Lin, the result will be a "triple win" -- for consumers, the government and businesses -- and will help the government develop the telecommunications industry into a key sector, along with the semiconductor and panel display sectors, capable of yielding an annual production value of more than NT$1 trillion.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Washington Post: Car Bombs Kill at Least 26 in Baghdad; Four Separate Attacks Come Over 90-Minute Period.
At least 26 people died this morning in four separate attacks during a 90-minute convulsion of violence aimed at derailing Iraq's planned Jan. 30 elections, the paper quoted the U.S. military as saying.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The New York Times: Rice Sees Iraq Training Progress but Offers No Schedule for Exit.
Condoleezza Rice, President Bush's nominee for secretary of state, refused Tuesday to set any timetable for the withdrawal of American troops from Iraq, but declared that the United States was making " some progress" in training Iraqi security forces.
Wall Street Journal: J.P. Morgan Chase's Net Income Falls 11% in Fourth Quarter.
J.P. Morgan Chase & Co. reported that its fourth-quarter profit declined 11%, as charges related to its July acquisition of Bank One Corp. ate into the Wall Street giant's bottom line.

DOC.HEADLINE: THREE BROTHERS WITH ALD DISEASE HEAD FOR U.S. FOR TREATMENT

TEXT.P: Three brothers suffering from a rare degenerative disease known as adrenoleukodystrophy (ALD) left for the United States Wednesday for treatment after local people donated millions of dollars to cover their medical expenses.

Their parents, who accompanied their sons on the medical journey, posted a "thank you" letter on the Kaohsiung City Government's Web site prior to their departure, expressing their heartfelt gratitude for the more than 25,000 local people who have donated money to the family.
"Without your generous donations, this medical trip would have remained just a pipedream," the couple said in their online letter.

Chang Ming-hui, the three brothers' father who is a Kaohsiung City Government staff member, said he will regularly post his sons' medical expense receipts on the Internet to allow those who are concerned about his sons' situation to get the latest information.
Chang said previously the family would keep US$1 million to cover the medical expenses and use the remaining donations to set up a foundation to help other local ALD sufferers.

The three brothers will receive bone marrow transplants at Minnesota State University's medical center, Chang said, adding that his eldest son, Chien-hsuan, will receive the transplant first and then the youngest son. As to the timing for bone marrow transplant for his second son, who is already paralyzed, Chang said it will depend on the doctor's decision.
The Chang family is scheduled to stay in Minnesota for six months to a year depending on the progress of the treatment.

China Airlines sent staff members to assist the family in packing their luggage early in the morning. The Changs' relatives and friends as well as Chien-hsuan's teacher and classmates visited their home in Kaohsiung's Tsoying district to bid farewell and give their best wishes.

ALD is a rare genetic disorder, in which the fatty myelin "insulation" around nerves breaks down. The disease was brought to public attention largely thanks to the 1992 film "Lorenzo's Oil, " which was based on the true story of an American couple's search for a cure for their ALD-afflicted son.

DOC.HEADLINE: OPPOSITION REJECTS DPP'S CALL FOR EXTRA LEGISLATIVE SESSION

TEXT.P: The opposition Kuomintang (KMT) and People First Party (PFP) gave a cold shoulder Wednesday to the ruling Democratic Progressive Party's call for an extraordinary legislative session to approve President Chen Shui-bian's nominees for members of the Control Yuan.

One day after Chen urged the legislature to extend the session, Huang Teh-fu, secretary of the KMT caucus at the Legislative Yuan, said that even an extraordinary legislative session would not be able to approve the nominees before Jan. 31, when the terms of the incumbent Control Yuan members expire.

Noting that the Legislative Yuan is set to go into recess Jan. 22 before the terms of the lawmakers expire at the end of January, Huang said any extra session has to be crammed in between Jan. 22 and Jan. 30, so that the time is too short to finish the approval process.

Huang said the opposition parties refuse to exercise their approval rights, claiming that the president has disappointed the public and has raised the eyebrows of almost every political party by naming some unpopular politicians as candidates.

Huang said the president has only himself to blame, adding that while the opposition asked the president to withdraw the nominees before Jan. 10 and come up with a new list but, he brushed aside the request.
Huang urged the president to redraw his list and present it to the legislature when the new lawmakers gather for their first session in February.
Legislator Lu Hsuei-chang, PFP deputy caucus convener at the Legislative Yuan, said it is unnecessary to call an extraordinary legislative session for approving the nominees of the Control Yuan.

He rebutted the DPP's claims that the lack of new members of the Control Yuan after the current term expires will give rise to a Constitutional crisis, saying the national examination, which used to be supervised by the Control Yuan, can be put back for a while without compromising anyone's interests.
Only the DPP's political ally, the Taiwan Solidarity Union, supported the idea of an extraordinary session.

TSU caucus convener at the Legislative Yuan Huang Tsung-yuan said the lawmakers might vote against the president's specific nominees, whom they consider unfit for the Control Yuan, but should not shirk their duty of saying yes or no to his choices.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT ENCOURAGES ORCHID GROWERS TO INNOVATE

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian called on domestic orchid growers Wednesday to intensify innovation, research and development, and international marketing to make Taiwan a "kingdom of orchids."
Chen made the appeal while visiting an orchid exposition that opened at the Taiwan Orchid Biotechnology Park in the southern county of Tainan.

Innovation, research and development as well as international marketing are essential to increasing the global market share of Taiwan-cultivated flowers, especially after the nation's entry into the World Trade Organization, Chen said.
"Only by creating our own brands can we achieve the goal of building Taiwan into a 'kingdom of orchids, '" Chen stressed, adding that organizing expositions is one of the best marketing approaches.
Chen also thanked the Cabinet-level Council of Agriculture, the Tainan County Government and the private sector for their concerted efforts to push for the establishment of the orchid park.

Inspired by Taiwan's successful hosting of an Asia-Pacific orchid show last year, Chen voiced the hope that agriculture officials will do their utmost to bid for hosting the 2011 International Orchid Exposition in Tainan County.

DOC.HEADLINE: HOLIDAY CHARTER FLIGHTS CONDUCIVE TO CROSS-STRAIT EXCHANGES: MAC

TEXT.P: The successful negotiation for the special cross-Taiwan Strait charter flights during the upcoming Chinese Lunar New Year holiday has laid a good foundation for future cross-strait engagements, a senior mainland affairs official said Wednesday.

"The spirit of shelving disputes and demonstrating pragmatism and flexibility shown in the recent holiday charter flight negotiation is conducive to future cross-strait exchanges," Mainland Affairs Council Vice Chairman Chiu Tai-san said while addressing a meeting organized by a local business club.
If mainland China can uphold this spirit in interacting with Taiwan, Chiu said, cross-strait relations will improve greatly in the future.

According to a landmark deal reached in Macau last Saturday by Taiwan and mainland negotiators, six carriers from each side will jointly operate 48 direct, non-stop charter flights during the period from Jan. 29 and Feb. 20 between Taipei/Kaohsiung in Taiwan and Shanghai/Beijing/Guangzhou in mainland China for the convenience of Taiwan businessmen operating on the mainland who wish to return for the Lunar New Year celebrations.

DOC.HEADLINE: SHANGHAI AIRLINES APPLIES FOR CHARTER FLIGHTS WITH TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Shanghai Airlines has applied for Taiwan's permission to participate in the special charter flights for mainland-based Taiwan businessmen between destinations on the two sides during the coming Chinese New Year holidays, a government official said Wednesday.

According to Minister of Transportation and Communications Lin Ling-san, Shanghai Airlines has contacted the Civil Aeronautics Administration (CAA) through the Taipei-based EVA Airways Corporation (EVA Air) in regard to the charter flights on the Shanghai-Taipei route on Jan. 29, Feb. 5 and Feb. 17.
It was reported that the mainland's Air China, China Southern Airlines, China Eastern Airlines, Hainan Airlines and Xiamen Airlines will also take part in the services.

Meanwhile, the leading Taiwan carriers, China Airlines and EVA Air, are expected to be the first ones based in Taiwan to file applications with the CAA and the General Administration of Civil Aviation of China for the special charter services designated to operate from Jan. 29 to Feb. 20.
The service will be confined only to Taiwan business people and their families, a move that has upset many Taiwan students studying in the mainland.

Negotiators from the two sides of the Taiwan Strait reached a final agreement last Saturday in Macau, stipulating that six carriers from either side may fly to accommodate returning business people for the Feb. 9 Chinese New Year holiday on the model of "non-stop, round-trip and multi-destinations."
The carriers of each side will be permitted to offer 24 round trips between Taiwan's Taipei and Kaohsiung and the mainland's Beijing, Shanghai and Guangzhou via Hong Kong's airspace.
The ground-breaking agreement will see mainland carriers land on Taiwan soil for the first time in more than 50 years since the two sides of the Taiwan Strait split in 1949 after a civil war.

The cross-strait Chinese New Year charter flights took off for the first time in 2003, involving only six Taiwan aviation companies. But the service was not continued the next year as a result of Beijing's refusal to negotiate its demand that mainland carriers also be allowed to take part in the service.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN HOPING TO BECOME OFFSHORE TRADING CENTER: FSC CHAIRMAN

TEXT.P: Taiwan is looking forward to becoming an offshore trading center in the near future, an official from the Cabinet-level Financial Supervisory Commission (FSC) said Wednesday.

Speaking at the Foreign Correspondents Club, FSC Chairman Kong Jaw-sheng said that foreign investors or prominent corporations are welcome to raise funds in Taiwan by listing shares on the Taiwan Stock Exchange.
Kong said that a new shares trading system will be put into place March 1 and that the 7 percent fluctuation range for newly listed shares during the first five trading days will be lifted.
After conducting an evaluation of effects from the new measures, the government will study the feasibility of a further opening the domestic securities market, Kong said.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER PRESIDENT HOPES TO VISIT JAPAN AGAIN

TEXT.P: Former President Lee Teng-hui said Wednesday that he looks forward to visiting Japan again this summer.

Lee, who just concluded a seven-day private visit to Japan Jan. 2 despite strong protests from mainland China, spoke during a meeting with reporters from the Japanese daily newspaper Mainichi Shimbun.
"If I am in good shape this summer, I hope to make another trip to Japan," Lee said.
Lee said that substantive relations between Taipei and Tokyo can be further strengthened through cultural and economic exchanges although Taiwan doesn't maintain diplomatic relations with Japan.
Describing his recent visit to Japan as an indicator of Taiwan-Japan relations, Lee thanked the Japanese government again for granting him visas to visit that nation.

DOC.HEADLINE: EVENT LISTING FOR JAN. 20 IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The following are important events scheduled to take place Thursday, Jan. 20:
09:00, The Legislative Yuan will start its session for the day.
09:55, Premier Yu Shyi-kun will attend activities in celebration of the inauguration of the Kaohsiung Harbor Free Trade Zone in Kaohsiung City.

16:30, Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou will meet with the delegation of the New York-based National Committee on American Foreign Policy at the Taipei City Hall.

DOC.HEADLINE: '319 COMMISSION' DISSOLVES ITSELF CLAIMING MISSION ACCOMPLISHED

TEXT.P: The "319 Truth Investigation Commission" decided Wednesday to dissolve itself after a meeting of its members, claiming that it has completed its mission.
The commission said in a news release that it is now up to the Legislative Yuan to decide whether or how to continue the investigation of the March 19 shooting of President Chen Shui-bian.

The commission said it is regrettable that the only Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) member on the commission, Tsai Wen-ping, was stripped of his DPP membership for serving on the commission, claiming it proves that the DPP will do anything to scuttle the investigation.
Tsai had his DPP membership suspended by the party at the end of last year for joining the commission in defiance of the party's ban on its members doing so.
The DPP has warned Tsai that he would be kicked out of the party if he didn't quit after the commission was declared unconstitutional by the Council of Grand Justices.
The Council of Grand Justices ruled on Dec. 15, and the DPP followed through on its threat by expelling Tsai.
Tsai brushed aside the DPP's decision Wednesday, saying he wouldn't bother to appeal the decision as is his right according to DPP regulations.

The commission was formed on Oct. 4, 2004 according to a controversial statute crafted on the opposition's terms to look into the March 19 shooting, which the opposition strongly suspects was a political scheme concocted to help Chen win the March 20 presidential election.
The DPP not only forbade its members to serve on the commission, it also boycotted the commission's work by ordering its administration not to help with the investigation.

The commission, however, issued a report Monday, claiming that the shooting was a campaign scheme aimed to influence the result of the presidential election and the president should be recalled for "trampling on the Constitution and the law."

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN HOPES TO MINIMIZE IMPACT OF CLAIMS OF DUMPING VIA WTO

TEXT.P: To restrict the damage to Taiwan business interests arising from anti-dumping regulations by other countries, Taiwan will pay extra heed to anti-dumping issues in the coming rounds of Doha talks overseen by the World Trade Organization (WTO) , a government official said Wednesday.

Wu Shing-hua, deputy director-general of the Bureau of Foreign Trade (BOFT) under the Ministry of Economic Affairs, said that the government is poised to protect the interests of Taiwan's export-oriented economy.

According to WTO statistics, Taiwan was subject to anti-dumping measures by other countries in 138 cases over the past 10 years -- the fourth-most cited nation. India complained the most at 27 times against Taiwan, followed by the United States with 17.

Yen Ching-chang, Taiwan's permanent representative to the WTO, said that it will undoubtedly greatly benefit the country should relevant anti-dumping rules set by the world trade regulatory body be modified. He promised to do his best to promote Taiwan's trade interests in this field under the WTO framework.
Meanwhile, Taiwan and India are slated to hold talks in February in New Delhi to settle their anti-dumping disputes through WTO mechanisms.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN IS WORLD'S SECOND-LARGEST SUPPLIER OF METAL HAND TOOLS

TEXT.P: Taiwan ranked as the world's second-largest supplier of metal hand tools with exports valued at NT$72.84 billion (US$2.27 billion) in 2003, according to a recent government report.
The shipment of Taiwan-made hand tools accounted for 17.1 percent of the world market, the report said.
Taiwan's hand tools industry looks promising in spite of continuous relocation of domestic manufacturers to mainland China, government officials said.

The officials cited statistics compiled by the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS) explaining that the industry's exports enjoyed an average annual growth rate of 6.1 percent in the past 12 years.
The exports amounted to NT$59.18 billion in the first nine months of last year, up 9.5 percent from that of a year ago, they added.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI 101 OBSERVATION DECK OPENS NEW VISTAS FOR VISITORS

TEXT.P: They say that on a clear day you can see forever, and 2,256 people got the chance to test that old saw Wednesday as the first people to visit the newly opened observation deck on the 89th floor of the world's tallest building, Taipei 101.
The deck is 382.2 meters above the ground and riding the world's fastest elevator that goes up at nearly 60 kph, it takes only 38 seconds to get to the observation deck.
The air pressure in the high-speed elevator is computer-controlled to ensure that there is no ear-popping due to pressure changes.
Although the deck was open after 1 p.m., a line of visitors formed at the entrance of the building at 5 a.m., and a local visitor waited for about seven hours to buy the first ticket.
Through binoculars mounted on the deck, vistiors can see the coastline of Tanshui, a small town about 20 kilometers away at the estuary of the Tanshui River.

In the beginning, the deck will only be open between 1 p.m. and 7 p.m., and the number of visitors will be limited to ensure an uncrowded and laid-back atmosphere. Because of this, many visitors were turned away at the entrance Wednesday.
The visitors Wednesday spent an average of an hour and a half on the deck, with about a third of them foreigners.
Managers of the building predicted that more visitors will get the chance to use the deck after its opening time is extended to 10 a.m. to 10 p.m. on March 1.

DOC.HEADLINE: CONTROL YUAN CALLS FOR REMEDY OF FLAWS IN 'MINI THREE-LINKS'

TEXT.P: The Control Yuan asked the Executive Yuan Wednesday to fix what it calls the flaws in the direct shipping and trade links between the country's two frontline islands of Kinmen, Matsu and mainland China, the so-called "mini three links".

In a resolution, the Control Yuan said the Executive Yuan failed to inspect the quality of mainland foods and herbs funnelled into Taiwan via Kinmen and Matsu, putting the health of the public at risk.

Furthermore, the resolution said the products allowed by the Ministry of Economic Affairs to be imported from the mainland didn't meet the needs of the residents of Kinmen and Matsu, which has led to a booming contraband business.

The ministry's ban on transportation of materials needed by Taiwan businessmen residing on the mainland through the mini-links has resulted in a thriving underground transportation business across the Taiwan Strait, said the Control Yuan.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Thursday, Jan. 20, or the 11th day of the 12th month of the Year of the Monkey according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1736: James Watt, Scottish engineer and inventor who made fundamental improvements in the steam engine, resulting in the modern, high-pressure steam engine patented in 1769, is born.
1793: King Louis XVI of France is sentenced to the guillotine.
1795: French forces overrun Holland.
1798: Auguste Comte, French philosopher known as the founder of positivism, is born. He also established sociology as a systematic field of study.
1920: Javier Perez de Cuellar, Peruvian secretary-general of the United Nations from 1982 to 1992, is born.
1926: Chiang Kai-shek is appointed president of the Central Military and Political School which later becomes National Chengchi University.
1929: Liang Chi-chao, who together with Kang Yu-wei initiated a reform movement in China in 1898 after the success of the Meiji Reformation in Japan, dies in Peiping (Beijing) at the age of 57.
1942: Japanese troops invade Burma.
1953: A total of 110 members of the Taiwan People's Liberation Armed Defense Group, which was organized by the Chinese Communists, are arrested in Lukhushan near Hsichih, Taipei County.
1960: The United States signs a treaty of mutual security with Japan to set up relations of economic and military cooperation.
1966: Indira Gandhi becomes India's first female head of state and the second female prime minister in the world.
1967: Kuo Mei-chen (Hellen Quach), vice director of the New York Philharmonic and under Leonard Bernstein, wins the gold medal in a conducting contest in New York.
1968: The USS Forwarder, a nuclear-powered aircraft carrier, arrives in Sasebo, a naval base in Japan, for a five-day visit.
1968: The Legislative Yuan approves regulations governing the implementation of nine-year compulsory education.
1969: Jan Palach, a 21-year-old student, sets fire to himself in Wenceslaus Square in Prague in protest of the Soviet invasion of Czechoslovakia.
1972: Satellite communications between Taipei and Tokyo begin operating.
1973: The Republic of China severs diplomatic relations with Dahomey.
1974: Dr. Charles J. Hitch, president of the University of California at Berkeley, arrives in Taipei for a four-day visit under the Asian Foundation's Eminent Americans Abroad Program.
1974: Beijing expels five Russians, including a senior diplomat and two other members of the Soviet embassy staff, on espionage charges.
1975: A new constitution comes into effect in communist China, replacing the one in force since 1964.
1976: The millionth resident of Kaohsiung is born.
1978: Minister of Economic Affairs Sun Yun-suan signs accords on industrial and agricultural cooperation with Ghazi Abdul Rahman Al-Gosaibi, Saudi Arabia's minister of industry and electricity, and Abdul Rahman Ibn Al-Sheikh, the Middle Eastern nation's minister of agriculture and water.
1980: Motoh Shiina, a member of the Japanese Diet and son of Etsusaburo Shiina, late vice president of the Liberal Democratic Party, arrives in Taipei for a three-day visit.
1980: David Dean, chairman of the American Institute in Taiwan, after arriving on Jan. 14, meets with Dr. Tsai Wei-ping, chairman of the Coordination Council for North American Affairs, to exchange views on ROC-U.S. relations.
1982: President Chinag Ching-kuo receives U.S. Senator Frank H. Murkowski (R-Alaska) and Congressmen Trent Lott (R-Miss), Richard T. Schulze (R-Penn) and William Carney (R-NY) and their wives at the Presidential Office.
1995: Russian troops capture Chechnya's presidential palace from separatist fighters.
1998: El Salvador signs an agreement with Honduras, ending a border dispute.
2000: ROC Vice President Lien Chan says that the ROC on Taiwan is now the world's 18th largest economic power and 15th largest trading country and that it should pursue a "mature economy."
2001: Waters around Kenting National Park at the southern tip of Taiwan are polluted by heavy oil leaking from a Greek cargo ship that runs aground.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "Be a good and wise man while you try to be an encyclopedic man of culture; be not a fool while you try to be an encyclopedic man of culture."

DOC.HEADLINE: FO GUANG GROUP LAUNCHES FUND-RAISING WALK FOR TSUNAMI ORPHANS
DOC.DATELINE: Chiayi, southern Taiwan, Jan. 20 (CNA) (By Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Several educational institutes and groups under the Buddhist Foguangshan Monastery launched a one-day fund-raiser islandwide Thursday for South Asian children orphaned in the tsunami disaster in late December.
A total of 20 Fo Guang teams embarked on the fund-raising walk from 17 locations around the island at 9 a.m. Thursday, with the aim of raising at least US$50,000 by nightfall.
The Foguangshan Monastery will use the money to establish a foundation for the building of orphanages in areas affected by the tsunami tragedy.

In Chiayi City, a group of students and faculty members from Nanhua University, headed by university president Chen Miao-sheng, embarked on the fund-raising walk from a temple located in the downtown area. They plan to walk at least eight kilometers around the city during the day.

Chen said that although relief aid has poured into countries affected by the tsunami disaster, children orphaned in the tragedy need special care. He added that Taiwan should not be absent from this kind of relief effort.
The Fu Guang Group will build orphanages around the region to directly care for the children who were orphaned or displaced, he said.

According to Chen, the Fo Guang Monastery maintains affiliates in Thailand, Malaysia and India, so the funds that it raises in Taiwan can be directly channeled into these tsunami affected Asian countries without the help of any governmental organization.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHADIAN PRESIDENT TO VISIT TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Chadian President Idriss Deby is scheduled to arrive in Taipei Sunday for a three-day state visit, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) announced Thursday.

During his visit, Deby will exchange views with President Chen Shui-bian on various ongoing bilateral cooperative projects, African regional issues and the general international situation, the MOFA said in a press release.
The two heads of state will sign a joint communique at the conclusion of Deby's visit, according to the press statement.

Deby will travel to Kaoshiung to visit a marine base and Chinese Petroleum Corp.'s refinery in southern Taiwan. He will also visit major cultural and economic institutions in northern Taiwan and meet with local business and industry leaders.

MOFA officials said relations between Taiwan and Chad have been cordial since the two countries resumed full diplomatic ties in 1997. President Chen headed a large entourage to visit the central African ally in August 2000.

Deby has on many occasions spoken out in support of Taiwan's bid to join the United Nations, the World Health Organization and other major international organizations, the officials said. The upcoming visit will be Deby's third trip to Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: THREE CARRIERS APPLY FOR NEW YEAR CROSS-STRAIT CHARTER FLIGHTS

TEXT.P: Three airlines have applied to offer direct cross-strait charter flights for mainland-based Taiwan businesspeople during the upcoming Chinese New Year holidays, the Civil Aeronautics Administration (CAA) reported Thursday.

Mainland China's Shanghai Airlines and Taiwan's two leading carriers, China Airlines and EVA Airways, are the first three airlines to file applications with the CAA to offer special charter services for the Jan. 29-Feb. 20 period, CAA officials said.

Negotiators from the two sides of the Taiwan Strait reached an agreement Dec. 8 in Macau to allow a total of six carriers from either side to offer flight services to accommodate returning Taiwan business people for the Feb. 9 Chinese New Year holiday on the "non-stop, round-trip, multi-destinations" model.

The carriers will be permitted to offer a total of 24 roundtrip flights between Taipei or Kaohsiung in Taiwan and Beijing, Shanghai or Guangzhou in mainland China via the Hong Kong flight information zone.

Shanghai Airlines has applied through Taipei-based EVA Airways to operate four round-trip charter flights between Jan. 29 and Feb. 17 -- with three on the Shanghai-Taipei route and one on the Shanghai-Kaohsiung route, the CAA officials said.

China Airlines has also applied to operate four round-trip charter flights between Jan. 29 and Feb. 5 -- two on the Taipei-Beijing route, and one each on the Taipei-Shanghai and the Taipei-Guangzhou routes.
EVA Airways has applied to offer two round-trip charter flights connecting Taipei and Beijing and two connecting Taipei and Shanghai, between Jan. 29 and Feb. 7.
It was reported that the mainland's Air China, China Southern Airlines, China Eastern Airlines, Hainan Airlines and Xiamen Airlines will also apply to offer flight services.
The ground-breaking agreement will see mainland carriers land on Taiwan soil for the first time in more than 50 years since the two sides of the Taiwan Strait split in 1949 after a civil war.

The cross-strait Chinese New Year charter flights took off for the first time in 2003, involving only six Taiwan air carriers. However, the service was not continued the next year due to Beijing's insistence that mainland carriers be allowed to take part in the program.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA WELCOMES EP RESOLUTION AGAINST LIFTING OF ARMS EMBARGO

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) expressed welcome Thursday for the European Parliament's fourth resolution in just over a year opposing a lifting of the European Union's arms embargo against mainland China.

The European Parliament -- the legislative arm of the European Union -- passed the resolution in Strasburg, France last week, said Wang Yu-yuan, director of the MOFA's Department of European Affairs. It was the fourth such resolution since Dec. 18, 2003.
The latest resolution stipulates that the European Union should maintain its ban on arms sales to China until there is a satisfactory improvement in the country's human rights record.
Nevertheless, Wang said that the possibility of the European Union lifting its arms embargo against China is increasing given various developments.

Wang noted that British Secretary of State for Foreign and Commonwealth Affairs Jack Straw said in the House of Commons Jan. 12 that despite the United States' opposition, it is believed that the European Union will lift its 15-year arms embargo against China within six months.
Noting that Taiwan and the United States would be affected the most by a lifting of the embargo, Wang said the MOFA is closely monitoring related developments.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S SUCCESS IS AN ASSET TO THE U.S.: PRESIDENT CHEN

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Thursday that Taiwan's success is absolutely an asset to the United States and Taiwan will never become a liability for America.

Chen made the remarks while meeting with a delegation of the National Committee on American Foreign Policy (NCAFP) , a noted U.S. think tank. The delegation, headed NCAFP President George D. Schwab, is currently on a fact-finding visit in Taiwan.

As one of the best allies of U.S. values, Chen said Taiwan will not become a liability to the U.S. in the coming four years. Instead, he said, Taiwan's success story will always be an asset for the U.S.

"Myself and the Republic of China government and people will do whatever we can to safeguard our hard-won democratic achievements and economic prosperity as well as to defend the peace and status quo across the Taiwan Strait, " Chen said, adding that Taiwan will not only refrain from making any unilateral move to change the peaceful cross-strait status quo but will also do its utmost to prevent this status quo from being unilaterally altered.

As for what he said in his new year's day address that this is an era for dialogue and consultations, Chen said he is working to foster national healing and inter-party reconciliation after last year's bitterly divisive presidential election on the domestic front and simultaneously to push for resumption of the long-stalled cross-strait dialogue.

Chen said he was pleased to see the two sides of the Taiwan Strait get together to consult and finally succeed in striking a landmark deal last weekend on the launch of direct, non-stop cross-strait charter flights during the upcoming Chinese Lunar New Year holiday to accommodate returning mainland China-based Taiwan businessmen.
"I'm convinced that the successful charter flight negotiations mark a good start and opportunity for normalization of cross-strait relations," Chen said.
Chen also took advantage of the meeting to offer his congratulations on the Jan. 20 inauguration of U.S. President George W. Bush and Vice President Dick Cheney for a second term.

"I wish to offer congratulations on behalf of the ROC government and the 23 million Taiwan people on the Bush-Cheney ticket's second inauguration. God bless America, " Chen said, adding that he believes that the United States, under Bush's leadership, will bring permanent peace to the world and the Taiwan Strait.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI SHARE PRICES END LOWER

The bourse opened at 5,835.68 points and fluctuated between 5,918.33 and 5,835.68 during trading. A total of 3.15 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$64.48 billion (US$2.08 billion).

Six of the eight major stock categories lost ground, with cement shares moving down the most by 1.6 percent, followed by construction issues by 1.3 percent, paper and pulp stocks by 1.1 percent, foodstuff and textile shares by 1.0 percent, as well as banking and financial issues by 0.7 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: LAWMAKER THREATENS MAC BUDGET IF STUDENTS EXCLUDED FROM FLIGHTS

TEXT.P: Opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Legislator John Chang threatened Thursday to cut the budget for the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) if Taiwanese students studying in mainland China are not allowed to take the direct cross-strait charter flights during the upcoming Chinese Lunar New Year holiday.

Negotiators from the two sides of the Taiwan Strait reached an agreement Dec. 8 in Macau to allow six carriers from either side to offer flight services to accommodate returning Taiwan business people for the Feb. 9 Chinese New Year holiday on a "non-stop, round-trip, multi-destinations" model.

This landmark service, however, is to be confined only to Taiwan business people and their families, a move that has upset many Taiwan students studying on the mainland. Chang, a key figure in reaching the charter flights agreement, spoke at a news conference held at the Legislative Yuan, asking, "Aren't these students also Taiwanese people who need to take airplanes home?"

A former KMT secretary-general and a foreign minister during the time of KMT rule, Chang said that mainland authorities were not opposed to the notion of allowing Taiwanese students studying on the mainland to take the charter flights.

On the contrary, he said, it has been the MAC who is against allowing students on the flights because of the possibility that some students who are studying illegally in the mainland might try to use the service.

Chang said that there would be no problem in identifying these individuals. All it would take is a check of a person's "taibaozheng" -- the certificate for people from Taiwan issued by the mainland Chinese authorities -- and their student cards when they book their flights, he added.
This has nothing to do with whether or not Taiwan recognizes the academic degrees obtained in mainland China, Chang argued.
He urged MAC authorities not to confuse the two different issues.

Chang also said that if these Taiwanese students are not allowed to take the charter flights this year, he will push to reduce the NT$75 million budget for the MAC's Chunghua Fund for the new fiscal year in the next legislative session that begins Feb. 1.

Noting that the booking rate for the 2003 cross-strait Chinese Lunar New Year charter flights was only 69 percent, Chang said that if the students are allowed to participate, it will not only benefit the students, but will also help increase the air carriers' ticket bookings.
In response to Chang's remarks, MAC Vice Chairman Chiu Tai-san urged Chang later in the day not to complicate the hard-earned direct cross-strait flights by adding new problems.
The 2003 flights involved only six Taiwan air carriers. However, the service was not continued the next year due to Beijing's insistence that mainland carriers be allowed to take part in the program.
As of Thursday, three airlines have applied to operate the direct cross-strait charter flights, the Civil Aeronautics Administration (CAA) reported.

Mainland China's Shanghai Airlines and Taiwan's two leading carriers, China Airlines and EVA Airways, were the first three companies to file applications with the CAA for the Jan. 29 to Feb. 20 service, CAA officials said.
The carriers will be permitted to offer a total of 48 round-trip flights between Taipei or Kaohsiung in Taiwan and Beijing, Shanghai or Guangzhou in mainland China via Hong Kong's airspace.
