DOC.HEADLINE: 15 PEOPLE SINCE 1988 HIV-POSITIVE FROM TAINTED TRANSFUSIONS

TEXT.P: Fifteen people in Taiwan have tested HIV-positive after receiving tainted blood transfusions since 1988, with three cases being identified in the last year, the Center for Disease Control (CDC) under the Department of Health reported Thursday.
The CDC identified the 15th HIV-positive person Thursday.

The 15 people were believed to have received tainted blood from 12 or 13 anonymous blood donors who may or may not have been aware that they were HIV-positive, said Lin Ding, deputy director-general of the CDC.
Three people receiving tainted blood over the past year marks one of the worst years in terms of HIV infection among blood recipients, Lin said.
The Department of Health (DOH) will take legal action against HIV-positive blood donors, Lin said.
Nevertheless, the DOH has managed to sue only one of these HIV-positive blood donors because of the lack of hard evidence.
The man in question was found to have donated blood twice since July 2004. The blood that he donated the second time, last November, was identified to be HIV-positive.
Noting that individuals who knowingly donate HIV-positive blood face a jail term of up to seven years, Lin said that all future blood donors ought to think twice before deciding to give blood.

DOC.HEADLINE: 5.4-MAGNITUDE EARTHQUAKE JOLTS SOUTHERN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: An earthquake with a preliminary measurement of 5.4 on the Richter scale jolted southern Taiwan Thursday afternoon, according to the Central Weather Bureau.

Weather bureau officials said that the tremor struck at 3: 47 p.m., with its epicenter located 31 kilometers northeast of the Tsaoshan seismology station in the southern county of Chiayi at a depth of 13 kilometers.
The earthquake had an intensity of 4.0 in Chiayi, Yunlin, Nantou and Changhua; 3.0 in Tainan; 2.0 in Kaohsiung, Hualien, Taichung and Miaoli; and 1.0 in Taitung, Ilan, Punghu and Hsinchu.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT DELINKS CONSTITUTIONAL RE-ENGINEERING AND INDEPENDENCE
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, Jan. 20 (CNA) (By Perry Hsieh and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian has reiterated in an interview with a Japanese daily that his administration's constitutional re-engineering plan has nothing to do with promoting Taiwan independence.
In the interview with the Mainichi Shimbun daily Wednesday, Chen also said Beijing's proposed anti-secession legislation is detrimental to bilateral ties and would hurt Taiwan people's feelings.
Chen gave the exclusive interview during an inspection tour of the southern Taiwan county of Tainan. The Mainichi Shimbun published the interview in its Thursday edition.

The president told Mainichi Shimbun reporters that the people of Taiwan have yet to reach a consensus on such sensitive issues as to whether Taiwan should eventually unify with mainland China or declare independence.
Against this backdrop, Chen said, his administration is unlikely to address sovereignty and territory issues in its constitutional re-engineering plan.

Stressing that Taiwan is a pluralistic, democratic country, Chen said any constitutional reforms must be subject to public debates and cannot take effect without the approval of three-quarters of its people.

Therefore, Chen said, the scenario of Taiwan provoking a war in the Taiwan Strait will absolutely not happen during his tenure as the Republic of China president. Beijing has threatened to attack Taiwan if the island declares independence.
Through candid and extensive communications, Chen said the United States has come to a full understanding of his administration's constitutional reform stance.
During U.S. President George W. Bush's second term, Chen said his administration will continue to strengthen exchanges and cooperation with the United States.
Chen also panned Beijing's anti-secession legislation plan, saying that the move is aimed at suppressing Taiwan and legalizing its use of force against Taiwan.
Such a move would only hurt Taiwan people's feelings and be a disservice to cross-strait rapprochement, Chen said.

According to the Mainichi Shimbun report, Chen said in the interview that some Taiwan people have called for the enactment of an anti-annexation law to counter Beijing's anti-secession law. Some critics have even proposed the holding of a referendum to express Taiwan people's strong opposition to Beijing's anti-secession legislation, the report said.

The paper also quoted Chen as having said in the interview that the landmark deal reached by the two sides of the Taiwan Strait last week on the launch of direct, non-stop cross-strait charter flights during the upcoming Chinese Lunar New Year holiday to accommodate returning mainland China-based Taiwan businessmen is conducive to future development of cross-strait ties
The report said Chen hopes that the new year charter flights can lead to the resumption of the long-stalled regular cross-strait dialogue.

DOC.HEADLINE: LABOR GROUPS PROTEST AGAINST AMENDMENTS TO LABOR-RELATED LAWS

TEXT.P: Several labor groups demonstrated in front of the Legislative Yuan Thursday requesting the withdrawal of government-proposed amendments to three labor-related laws.

Arguing that the amendments initiated by the Council of Labor Affairs to the Trade Union Law, Collective Bargaining Law and the Law for the Settling of Industrial Disputes would seriously limit laborers' rights to take industrial action in case of their being laid off or if the employer failed to pay their salaries on time.
The revised laws would also prohibit laborers from resorting to industrial action in disputes over their severance, they claimed.

The legislature is set to discuss the revision on Thursday, but the ruling Democratic Progressive Party and the opposition can't see eye to eye on whether the country's teachers should be allowed to form a trade union or whether the employees of telecommunications companies should go through a 30-day cooling down period before going on strike.

DOC.HEADLINE: SCHOLARS DIVIDED ON PROPOSAL FOR UNIVERSITY CLASSIFICATION

TEXT.P: A proposal for universities to be classified into various categories that was put forward by the Higher Education Department (HED) under the Ministry of Education was debated heatedly Thursday at a panel discussion of the ongoing national conference of university heads.

The participants in the panel discussion, which was presided over by Mou Tsung-tsan, chairman of the Association of Private Universities and Colleges, were divided on the proposal, under which domestic universities would be classified into four categories -- teaching universities, research universities, professional universities and community universities.

Due to a great increase in the number of universities, Taiwan's university education has shifted from elite education to universal education, which has resulted in financial pressure, poor quality of higher education and low competitiveness, an HED official pointed out.

To iron out these problems, the HED proposed that universities be classified into the four categories in line with their characteristics and functions and that the government offer them funds based upon the categories into which they fall, the official said.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Moscow Times: Cabinet Offers $3.7Bln in Extra Cash.
Shaken by the continuing uproar over the cancellation of Soviet-era benefits, Cabinet ministers said Wednesday that the government would subsidize transport costs for pensioners and war veterans, while opposition parties called for a range of sanctions from dismissing the government, to firing the ministers who drew up the controversial reform.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN INVESTMENT IN MAINLAND CHINA INCREASES

TEXT.P: The Investment Commission under the Ministry of Economic Affairs approved last year more than 2,000 investment projects worth nearly US$7 billion to be made in mainland China by Taiwan businesses, an increase of 51.05 percent in terms of value over the previous year's level, commission officials said Thursday.

The officials said the commission gave the green light to a total of 2,004 such investment projects last year, up 9.09 percent year-on-year. The projects had a combined value of US$6.94 billion, they added.
In December alone, they went on, the commission approved 165 Taiwan businesses' mainland investment projects with a combined value of US$777.4 million.
The officials ascribed the increase to the value of mainland China's currency, the renminbi, which has not yet appreciated as the international market has long expected.
The investors might believe they will get profits from the difference of the renminbi's exchange rate by investing in the mainland prior to its appreciation, the officials explained.

They warned Taiwan investors of the risks they could encounter on the mainland, including Beijing's continual efforts to cool its overheated economy, a lack of power and water supplies and the impact of the renminbi's appreciation on the mainland's economic development.

DOC.HEADLINE: DIPLOMATIC LINKS WITH GRENADA STILL EXIST: FOREIGN MINISTRY

TEXT.P: Grenada has not yet severed diplomatic links with Taiwan, despite Grenadan Prime Minister Keith Mitchell announcing in Beijing earlier in the day that his country has resumed diplomatic ties with mainland China, a spokesman for the Ministry of Foreign Affairs said Thursday.
Taiwan will break off ties with Grenada only after it has been officially informed of the switch by the Grenadan authorities, the spokesman added.
Noting that Mitchell will leave for home at 12: 30 a.m. Friday Taipei time, Lu said the critical time will be early Friday morning.
The spokesman said Mitchell tried to play Beijing against Taipei in attempt to get the most mileage from the competition between Taiwan and the mainland.
He visited Beijing in mid-December last year in spite of Taiwan's protest and demanded unreasonably high amounts of aid from Taipei after that trip, Lu said.
Refusing to play into his hand, Lu said, Taipei snubbed Mitchell's "extortion" and withdrew its ambassador to Saint George in protest.
Lu said Taiwan would like to aid Grenada in accordance with a cooperation plan that exists between them, but will not engage in a bidding war with the mainland for diplomatic allies.

DOC.HEADLINE: TWO LATE PRESIDENTS SET TO BE INTERRED IN JULY

TEXT.P: The embalmed bodies of the late President Chiang Kai-shek and his son and successor Chiang Ching-kuo are scheduled to be interred at a military cemetery in Taipei County in July, a spokesman for the Ministry of the Interior (MOI) said Thursday.
The spokesman made the remarks after an MOI-organized inter-department meeting to discuss the preparatory work for the move.
According to the spokesman, the MOI will come up with a detailed draft plan for the Executive Yuan's review and approval in February.

Officials from the Presidential Office, the Executive Yuan, the Ministry of National Defense (MND), the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, the Ministry of Transportation and Communications and the Central Personnel Administration attended the meeting.
The spokesman said the MND has commissioned contractors to build tombs for the two late presidents and the graves are scheduled for completion in June.
If all goes well, the spokesman said, the interment ceremony will be held in July.

The Chiang family sent a letter to the MND last year asking it to help with the relocation of the two Chiangs -- who have been embalmed in interim mausoleums in Taoyuan, northern Taiwan -- to the Wutzushan military cemetery in Hsichih, Taipei County, for permanent interment.
With the consent of President Chen Shui-bian, the MND, the MOI and various other government agencies began to plan for the relocation and burial in line with the state funeral law.

The MOI spokesman said an ad hoc office will be set up to coordinate preparatory and interment work. The office is scheduled to become operational in March. The Presidential Office will announce relocation and interment procedures and rituals in April in accordance with the state funeral law.

Chiang Kai-shek fled to Taiwan in 1949 after losing the Chinese mainland to the Mao Zedong-led communist party in a bloody civil war. He died in 1975 and his remains were embalmed in a temporary mausoleum at Tzuhu in Taoyuan, awaiting a proper burial on the mainland.

Chiang Kai-shek ruled Taiwan with an iron fist, using martial law to suppress democracy. However, some view him as a hero for keeping the island out of reach of the Chinese communists and claim that it was he who fostered Taiwan's freewheeling market economy.

Chiang Ching-kuo is respected for ending martial law in 1987, shortly before his death, thus unleashing the democratic forces that broke his family's vice-grip on power and eventually ended the Kuomintang's half-century of rule over Taiwan.

Chiang Ching-kuo died in 1988 and his remains also lie embalmed in an interim mausoleum at Touliao in Taoyuan. His Russian-born wife died Dec. 15, 2004 and her cremated ashes, which are being kept at Chiang's mausoleum, will be buried along with her husband.

DOC.HEADLINE: LEGISLATURE PASSES BILL ALLOWING STUDENTS TO PARTICIPATE IN ELECTIONS

TEXT.P: The Legislative Yuan Thursday passed the third reading of an amendment to the Public Officials Election and Recall Law (POERL) , under which students and policemen will be entitled to take part in the election of public officials.

The amendment was adopted after the legislative caucuses of the ruling and opposition parties reached a consensus that various outdated restrictions on citizens' participation in elections of public officials should be lifted in line with democratic development.
After the passage of the amendment, all students and policemen that satisfy POERL requirements will be able to participate in such elections if they want to and will not face suspension.

DOC.HEADLINE: KAOHSIUNG HARBOR FREE TRADE ZONE BECOMES OPERATIONAL

TEXT.P: The Kaohsiung Harbor Free Trade Zone formally began operations Thursday, with Premier Yu Shyi-kun, Kaohsiung Mayor Frank Hsieh and Minister of Transportation and Communications Lin Ling-san jointly presiding over the inauguration ceremony.

Addressing the ceremony, Yu said the free trade harbor zone integrates transportation, communications, tourism and warehousing and will create NT$600 billion in annual production, contributing to Kaohsiung City's job opportunities and economic prosperity.

Hsieh for his part said 2005 marks the 120th anniversary of the opening of Kaohsiung Harbor. With the inauguration of the harbor free trade zone, Hsieh said, the harbor will attract more investors in sea-land transportation, warehousing and customs brokerage services to help boost the port city's economic development.

DOC.HEADLINE: IMPACT OF TSUNAMI CATASTROPHE ON ASEAN ECONOMIES LIMITED

TEXT.P: The impact of the Dec. 26 tsunami catastrophe on Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) economies is limited and the 10 member nations will enjoy an average growth rate of more than 4 percent this year, according to a think tank study released Thursday.

The study, conducted by the Chung-Hua Institution for Economic Research under the commission of the Cabinet-level Council for Economic Planning and Development, shows that the ASEAN financial markets have been normal in spite of enormous property losses suffered by some of the countries affected by the disaster.
Meanwhile, they added, the ASEAN manufacturing sectors and other economic infrastructure remain almost intact.
ASEAN members will have an average economic growth rate of 4.2 percent for the first half of this year and 4.5 percent for the second half of the year, the study predicted.

DOC.HEADLINE: FOREIGN INVESTMENT IN TAIWAN UP IN 2004

TEXT.P: Combined investments by overseas Chinese and foreign firms in Taiwan hit US$3.95 billion in 2004, up 10.55 percent from the previous year's level, the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) announced Thursday.
The MOEA Investment Commission approved a total of 1,149 investment projects filed by overseas Chinese and foreign firms last year, up 6.59 percent from the 2003 level.
An Investment Commission official attributed the increase to the recovery of the global economy and various measures adopted by the government to entice foreign investors.

According to the official, the electronic and electrical appliance manufacturing sectors absorbed 33.45 percent of the combined value of investment, followed by the financial and insurance sectors (20.47 percent) and the wholesale and retail sectors (15.24 percent).

Meanwhile, the Investment Commission gave the green light to 658 projects presented by local manufacturers to invest a total of US$3.38 billion abroad, representing a 7.84-percent and 14.78-percent decrease, respectively, from the previous year's level.

In December alone, the commission approved 110 investment projects worth US$653.84 million filed by overseas Chinese and foreign enterprises, the highest monthly level in 2004, while 54 projects worth US$350.13 million were approved to be carried out abroad.

DOC.HEADLINE: NO PLAN FOR ANTI-ANNEXATION LAW: MAINLAND AFFAIRS OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: The Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) has no plans to propose an anti-annexation law to counter Beijing's proposed anti-succession law, a MAC official said Thursday.

MAC Vice Chairman and spokesman Chiu Tai-san made the statement after being asked to comment on a wire service report that President Chen Shui-bian told Japanese daily the Mainichi Shimbun the previous day that Beijing's attempt to enact an anti-secession law to justify its possible absorption of Taiwan might force Taiwan to enact an anti-annexation law in response.

According to his understanding, Chiu said, the president is worried that Beijing's move might prompt a reaction from the Taiwan people, which could include a call for an anti-annexation law to repel Beijing's attempts.

The MAC has not contemplated enacting an anti-annexation law, but Chiu said Beijing's anti-secession legislation will serve no purpose other than to estrange the Taiwan people and further aggravate the cross-Taiwan Strait tension.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT THREATENS TO COUNTERACT BEIJING LAW WITH TAIWAN LAW

TEXT.P: Taiwan might be forced to respond to Beijing's attempts to enact an anti-secession law with an anti-annexation law or to organize a May 26 referendum to seek the country's permanent separation from China, President Chen Shui-bian was quoted as saying Thursday.

According to a press release issued by Chen's office, the president told the Japanese daily Mainichi Shimbun in an interview the previous day that his administration might be forced to take the above actions by public opinion angered by Beijing's anti-secession law, which purports to pre-empt Taiwan's attempts to pursue independence.
As the country is set to elect a national assembly May 26 to amend the Constitution, the president said there are already calls in Taiwan for a referendum in conjunction with the election.
"That would be the last thing I want to see, but it is up to Beijing," Chen was quoted in the press release as saying.

Branding Beijing's anti-secession law, which has yet to be enacted by the National People's Congress, as warlike move against Taiwan, Chen said it is an attempt to lay the legal groundwork for Beijing's possible invasion of Taiwan.
By this legislation, Beijing is trying to impose its view of Taiwan on the island and to dictate to Taiwan its solution of the cross-Taiwan Strait dispute, Chen said.
It is tantamount to an attempt to change the cross-strait status quo unilaterally, which will jeopardize the whole region, Chen said.

Although Beijing has snubbed the olive branch he said he had proffered to Beijing more than 30 times in the last four years, the president said he will wait patiently for Beijing to reciprocate his goodwill.

He lauded the charter flights to be launched between Taiwan and the mainland during the Chinese New Year holiday as a good start for positive engagement with the mainland that was unimaginable only a few months ago because of the tension between the two sides.
Chen said it proves that exchanges between Taiwan and the mainland can be improved as long as both sides pass over their political disputes.
He also vowed to deal with Beijing "following a firm and pragmatic line" and with "a slow pace without retrogression and a steady attitude without haste."

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT MEETS WITH PREMIER

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian met with Premier Yu Shyi-kun Thursday at the Presidential Office and exchanged opinions with him on political affairs, according to a government spokesman.
Chen Shi-mai, spokesman for the Executive Yuan, said the meeting was a routine one and that they did not discuss the future Cabinet line-up but exchanged views on general political affairs.
Yu also told Chen that his Cabinet is scheduled to resign Jan. 24, the spokesman added.

According to protocol, the Cabinet must resign prior to a new legislature being sworn in, to give the president a free hand to put together a new administrative team. The next legislature will be sworn in Feb. 1.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. DELEGATION MEETS WITH TAIPEI MAYOR

TEXT.P: A seven-member delegation from the National Committee on American Foreign Policy met with Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou Thursday to exchange views on relations between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait and other issues of mutual concern.

After the meeting, Ma told reporters that the U.S. delegation showed great interest in Taiwan's political situation, cross-strait relations and the successful negotiations for the special cross-strait charter flights during the upcoming Lunar New Year holiday.

As the delegation had visited Beijing before arriving in Taiwan, Ma said he asked them about Beijing's plan to enact an anti-secession law targeting Taiwan. According to Ma, the group did not disclose any details of the plan but said that the Beijing leadership stands firm on the proposed legislation.

Noting that the delegation visits Taiwan every year to gain a better understanding of cross-strait relations, Ma said he will maintain good relations with the delegation members to help boost Taiwan's relations with the United States.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Wednesday, Jan. 21, or the 12th day of the 12th month of the Year of the Monkey according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1790: Dr. Joseph Guillotin demonstrates in Paris his new invention called the "guillotine," a device consisting of a heavy blade held aloft between upright guides that, once dropped, beheads the victim below.
1793: Louis XVI of France, who has been found guilty of treason, is guillotined.
1824: Thomas Jonathan Jackson, the American general known as "Stonewall" who commanded Confederate forces in the United States' Civil War, is born.
1846: The first issue of The Daily News, edited by Charles Dickens, is published in London.
1897: The Japanese governor's office in Taiwan issues the "Taiwan Opium Decree," which establishes a monopoly on opium sales.
1909: Henry Pu Yi accedes to the throne and becomes Emperor Hsuan Tung of China, the country's last emperor.
1919: The Paris Peace Conference opens.
1924: Vladimir Ilyich Lenin, the father of the Russian Revolution whose agricultural policies caused a famine that claimed more than 5 million lives, dies at the age of 53.
1945: Chinese expeditionary forces in northern Burma and Chinese troops in western Yunnan join forces on the Yunnan-Burma border.
1949: Republic of China President Chiang Kai-shek announces his retirement from the presidency and leaves for Hangchow. Vice President Li Tsung-jen is empowered to exercise presidential powers temporarily.
1950: Eric Arthur Blair, pen-named George Orwell -- a British writer whose imaginative fiction, including "Animal Farm" and "1984," attacked totalitarianism and reflected his concern with social justice -- dies at the age of 47.
1951: Atomic bombs are tested in Nevada for the first time.
1954: The United States launches Nautilus, the world's first nuclear submarine.
1964: Maj. Gen. Chao Chih-hua, deputy commander of armed forces based in Hukuo, Hsinchu County, is foiled in an attempt to march his forces to the Presidential Office in Taipei.
1972: The port of Suao in Ilan County opens for commercial trade.
1974: Wu Ming-yueh returns from Manila with the Philippines' women's golf title.
1975: Tran Van Lam, president of the South Vietnamese Senate, arrives in Taipei to attend a World Freedom Day rally.
1975: Foreign Minister Shen Changhuan and U.S. Ambassador Leonard Unger exchange notes extending the Sino-American Scientific and Technological Agreement until Jan. 3, 1980.
1976: French and British Concorde jets make their inaugural commercial flights from Paris to Rio de Janeiro and from London to Bahrain.
1977: The ROC Government Information Office under the Executive Yuan announces the arrest of Wang Hsin-nan, who was allegedly involved in an explosion that injured the right hand of Taiwan Governor Hsieh Tung-min.
1979: Yu Teng-fa, former chief of the Kaohsiung County government, and his son Yu Jui-yen are arrested during an investigation into the Wu Chun-fa sedition case.
1981: American hostages held in Iran are returned to freedom as the 52 diplomats land safely in Algiers, ending 444 days of agony.
1998: Pope John Paul II leaves for Cuba for a historic visit.
2000: The 10th Chingchiang-class patrol vessel constructed by the state-run China Shipbuilding Corp. for the ROC Navy is christened the "Changchiang."
2001: President Chen Shui-bian presides over a ceremony marking the reopening of the Chichi railway in the central Taiwan county of Nantou.
2002: Kaohsiung Mayor Frank Hsieh meets with the winner of the 1998 Nobel prize for medical science, Ferid Murad, to exchange views on the island's biotechnology development.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "When the natural qualities of men get the better of the results of education, they are rude men; when the results of education get the better of their natural qualities, they become literati. It is only when the natural qualities and the results of education are properly blended, that we have the truly wise and good man."

DOC.HEADLINE: ANTI-SECESSION LAW A UNILATERAL ATTEMPT TO CHANGE STATUS QUO: CHEN

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian called for the nation Friday to seriously face Beijing's proposed anti-secession law which he said would undermine stability across the Taiwan Strait if enacted.
The president made the remarks while reviewing the operations and capability of an army unit in Pingtung, southern Taiwan.

Chen said that Beijing has been actively engaging in "psychological, legal and media warfare" in pushing to enact the anti-secession law, which he said is aimed at establishing a legal justification for a military invasion of Taiwan.
The National People's Congress (NPC) Standing Committee late last year placed the anti-secession bill on the agenda for the annual session of the NPC set for this March.

The president reiterated remarks he made in his New Year's address in which he condemned Beijing's plans to enact an anti-secession law as a unilateral attempt to change the status quo in the Taiwan Strait. Chen called the proposed law the biggest threat to regional stability and peace in the world.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN VISITORS TO MAINLAND SHOULD STAY ALERT: MAC

TEXT.P: The Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) called for Taiwan people Friday to carefully assess the risks before heading to mainland China and to stay alert while visiting there to reduce the risks to their personal safety.

Chiu Tai-san, vice chairman of the MAC -- the top government agency in charge of mainland China policy planning -- made the call at a time when large numbers of Taiwan tourists are planning to take sightseeing tours to mainland China during the Chinese New Year holidays.

More Taiwan people are expected to head to mainland China during this upcoming holiday than in previous years following the devastation to the tourism industry in South Asia and Southeast Asia caused by the Dec. 26 tsunami tragedy.

According to Chiu, Taiwan people make about 3 million trips to the mainland each year for tourism or for business activities, making mainland China one of the top destinations for Taiwan people traveling abroad. Despite this, Taiwan visitors have not been afforded due protection in mainland China, Chiu claimed.

He quoted a study conducted recently by an academic group as indicating that Taiwan tourists face 10 major problems in visiting China, including the lack of a tourism safety and security protection mechanism; overbooking of transport tickets; rampant circulation of counterfeit goods; widespread epidemic diseases; unauthorized changing of itineraries; forced visits to shops; unregulated tipping systems; and reneging on accommodation contracts.

The academics who sponsored the study suggested that authorities from across the Taiwan Strait join hands in efforts to regulate unlawful travel and tourism operators and exchange related information so that consumers' rights and interests can be better protected.
The academics reminded Taiwan holidaymakers not to be slack in their vigilance while touring the mainland just because the language is the same and the lifestyle is similar.
They also called for Taiwan tourists to be well prepared regarding travel information, to be aware of where to turn to in case of accidents and to buy insurance before setting foot on the mainland.

Chiu added that any Taiwan residents who need assistance while traveling in China can call the Straits Exchange Foundation at 8862-27129292, Chung Hwa Travel Service at 852-25258642, or the Taipei Economic and Cultural Center in Macau at 853-306282.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT SUSPENDS NEGOTIATIONS WITH RULING DPP AFTER LEGISLATIVE BOYCOTT

TEXT.P: The legislative caucus of the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) suspended negotiations with the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Friday in retaliation for the DPP's filibuster at the last session of the Fifth Legislative Yuan.

Huang Teh-fu, a KMT party whip at the Legislative Yuan, said that in the face of the DPP's "irrational" boycott, the KMT will not humble itself any longer and added that the party will in turn boycott all the bills authored and submitted by the Executive Yuan or the DPP caucus and close all negotiation channels with them.

Meanwhile, Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng, who is also a KMT vice chairman, said in an uncharacteristically stern voice that he was bitterly disappointed that the ruling DPP lawmakers obstructed the legislative process in a manner as if they were still the opposition party.

The DPP legislators were mainly trying to obstruct a national communications commission (NCC) organization draft bill from being passed into law. The draft bill was jointly submitted by the KMT and its ally, the People First Party (PFP).

DPP legislative party whip Tsai Huang-liang said that the DPP legislators were forced to adopt a "scorched earth policy" to bar the bill from being passed, saying that if what he describes as an "anti-reform, pork-barrel bill" is passed into law, it will seriously infringe on the administration's rights and directly take the painstaking efforts to simplify broadband channel systems right back to the starting point.

Meanwhile, Government Information Office Director-General Lin Chia-lung said that the KMT-PFP version of the NCC draft bill is absolutely unacceptable as it stipulates that NCC members should be party representatives whose numbers should be decided based on party proportional representation.

Lin ridiculed the opposition's justification of the NCC bill -- the centerpiece bill of the opposition camp in this final legislative session -- saying that the proposed establishment of a national communications commission is aimed primarily at streamlining Taiwan's major media regime and getting rid of political and military influences from the media.
This being the case, it would be absurd if the future NCC members are named in accordance with party proportional representation as the KMT wants, Lin claimed.

The DPP failed to reach its goal of forming a stable majority with its ally, the Taiwan Solidarity Union, in the Dec. 11 legislative elections, while the opposition "pan-blue alliance" of the KMT, PFP and the New Party, remains the majority.
No country in the world has an NCC whose members are composed in the way the opposition seeks, Lin said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI SHARE PRICES END LOWER

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange closed lower Friday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving down 39.19 points to close at 5,848.91.
The bourse opened at 5,877.31 and fluctuated between 5,898.86 and 5,846.95 during trading. A total of 2.48 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$46.07 billion (US$1.44 billion).

All eight major stock categories lost ground, with paper and pulp issues moving down the most at 1.3 percent, followed by foodstuff issues at 1.2 percent, plastics and chemicals shares at 0.8 percent, machinery and electronics shares and banking and financial shares both at 0.6 percent, textile stocks and construction issues both at 0.4 percent, and cement stocks at 0.1 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 581 to 157, with 203 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Japan Times: U.N. eyes lead role in tsunami alert system.
The United Nations will take the lead in developing an Indian Ocean tsunami early warning system by drawing on existing systems in the Pacific, U.N. delegates to the World Conference on Disaster Reduction said Thursday.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Washington Post: Bush Pledges to Spread Freedom; Global Focus On Rights Would Be a Shift in Policy.
George Walker Bush took the oath of office for a second term yesterday and laid out one of the most expansive manifestos ever offered from an inaugural podium as he dedicated his presidency to spreading democracy and freedom "with the ultimate goal of ending tyranny in our world," the paper said.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES MOSTLY LOWER ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were mostly lower Friday as the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for February lost 10 points to close at 5,869, with 28,331 contracts changing hands.

TAIEX Index futures for March lost 11 points to finish at 5,860, with 79 contracts traded, while June futures lost one point to close at 5,860, with 17 contracts traded. September futures remained unchanged at 5,795, with 15 contracts traded.
No transactions were recorded for December.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Friday at 5,879 for February, 5,871 for March, 5,861 for June, 5,795 for September and 5,793 for December.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were higher.
February TE futures moved up 0.2 points to close at 216.5, with 3,477 contracts traded, while March TE futures lost 0.6 points to finish at 216, with 22 contract transactions.
No transactions were recorded for June, September and December.

February TF futures gained 0.2 points to finish at 1,003.8, with 2,559 contracts changing hands, while March TF futures remained unchanged at 1,003.8, with 23 contracts traded. September TF futures lost 3.2 points to finish at 990.8, with one contract changing hands.
No transactions were recorded for June and December.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. DOLLAR RISES ON TAIPEI FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar rose against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Friday, gaining NT$0.038 to close at NT$31.913.
A total of US$410 million changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at the day's high of NT$32.025 and hit a low of NT$31.896.

DOC.HEADLINE: OUTCRY AS ADMINISTRATION LAMBASTES BUDGET CUTS

TEXT.P: The Executive Yuan lambasted the Legislative Yuan Friday for making major cuts in the 2005 general budget of the central government and the legislature, calling the result a major threat that will impede national development.
The Fifth Legislative Yuan wrapped up its final session Friday after passing many bills into law, including the 2005 general budget plan, which underwent the deepest cuts in three years.

Executive Yuan spokesman Chen Chi-mai said that the record budget cut not only threatens to drag down overall national development but will also seriously undermine operations in the administrative branch.
He said that the cuts in authorized revenues to be generated from the privatization of state-run enterprises will impede the enterprises' privatization process.

The budget cuts for special high technology development projects will definitely slow the upgrading of Taiwan's industrial structure, which will in turn adversely impact national development, Chen said.

In addition, he went on, the across-the-board axing of year-end performance bonuses for the 200,000 public functionaries threatens to sap morale in the civil service, which will in turn undermine administrative efficiency.
A 30 percent cut in budget for entrust and consignment plans to be conducted by various governmental offices and agencies will seriously obstruct administrative operations, he added.

The entire axing of subsidies for professional research and development for grand justices is obviously just political retaliation, Chen continued, adding that the motive behind the cut is an attempt to interfere politically in the independence of the judiciary.

Chen termed the entire axing of special allowances for Minister of Education Tu Cheng-sheng and Government Information Office Director-General Lin Chia-lung as taking public policy to the personal level.

In response to the swingeing cuts, Hsu Chang-yao, director-general of the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics, said that under these circumstances, the government will have to issue public bonds worth NT$255 billion in addition to using a balance of NT$81 billion accumulated from the previous fiscal year to fill up the budgetary sink-hole.
Even if this is the case, Hsu added, the government will still see a budgetary shortfall of about NT$1.2 billion for the following year, which can probably be filled by support from the Central Bank.

DOC.HEADLINE: RENMINBI APPRECIATION A TIME BOMB FOR TAIWAN: ECONOMIST

TEXT.P: A widely expected revaluation of the mainland Chinese currency will be a time bomb for Taiwan's economy, although it remains unknown exactly when the renminbi will go up in value, a noted economist said Friday.

Lee Kao-chao, an ex-vice chairman and now an advisor to the Cabinet-level Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) , said that a sharp renminbi appreciation will have a profound negative impact on the Taiwan's economic growth rate and consumer product prices.

Despite the fact that nobody knows when and to what extent the mainland authorities will loosen the renminbi's strict peg to the U. S. dollar, the move will unavoidably hinder the domestic economy in 2005, he predicted.

According to the former CEPD vice chairman, elements that might affect Taiwan's economy this year include fluctuating international oil prices, a rising interest rate and the mainland's measures to cool its high flying economy.

Judging from the country's major economic indexes, domestic economic expansion will slow in the coming months, he said, adding that most forecasting agencies have set their growth rate estimates for Taiwan from 4 percent to 4.6 percent for the whole of the year.
Regarding private sector investment, the machinery industry and real estate businesses will be most affected, he claimed.

The limitations on greenhouse gas emissions set by the Kyoto Protocol might dampen investment willingness in the machinery industry, while the property market is particularly sensitive to interest rates at a time when supply exceeds demand, he explained, noting that there were 130,000 houses built last year, outpacing the normal demand level of 100,000.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TO COOPERATE WITH U.S. IN PROMOTING DEMOCRACY: MAC CHIEF
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Jan. 20 (CNA) (By Oliver Lin and Luis Huang)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Chairman Joseph Wu said Friday that Taiwan is willing to cooperate with the United States in promoting democracy and freedom around the world.
Wu, a member of the Taiwan delegation to the Jan. 20 inauguration of U.S. President George W. Bush for his second term, made the remarks after hearing Bush's inaugural address.
Noting that Bush's speech focused on U.S. efforts to promote democracy and freedom, Wu said he was deeply impressed by Bush's remark that peace hinges on the expansion of democracy and freedom.
Taiwan has shifted from long-term authoritarian rule to democracy and during the transition, the country received great inspiration and support from the U.S. government and people, Wu pointed out.

"While cherishing its hard-earned freedom and democracy, " Wu said, "Taiwan, like the United States, should also take the responsibility of promoting freedom and democracy so that they may take root in many countries."

Wu further said that while testifying before the U.S. Congress last April, Assistant Secretary of State for East Asian and Pacific Affairs James Kelly suggested that Taiwan join hands with the United States to lead the cause of freedom and democracy, adding that officials from the two countries could meet to study how to carry out the plan.

Later in the day, the Taiwan delegation attended a cocktail party and other events to celebrate Bush's inauguration. The group is scheduled to hold a press conference and meet with representatives from the Taiwanese expatriate community.

The delegation, led by Academia Sinica President Lee Yuan-tseh, includes Yang-Huang Mei-hsin, director of the Research and Planning Board under the Ministry of Foreign Affairs; Hsu Su-chien, an Academia Sinica assistant researcher; Lo Chih-cheng, executive director of the National Policy Research Institute; and David Tawei Lee, Taiwan's representative to the United States.

DOC.HEADLINE: THREE YOUNG ALD PATIENTS ARRIVE IN U.S. FOR TREATMENT
DOC.DATELINE: New York, Jan. 20 (CNA) (By Eric Tseng & Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: The arrival in Minnesota Thursday of three Taiwanese youths suffering from a rare degenerative disease known as adrenoleukodystrophy (ALD) drew the attention of foreign and local media in the northern U.S. state, including the Minneapolis Star Tribune, a local newspaper, according to a Taiwan official stationed in Chicago.

Wang Pao-hsing, deputy representative of the Taipei Economic and Cultural Office in Chicago, told Central News Agency that U.S. reporter, along with reporters from four Taiwan press companies, covered the Changs' arrival.

Wang said that he, along with dozens of Taiwanese expatriates in Minnesota, as well as members of the Taiwan-based Buddhist Compassionate Relief Tzu Chi Foundation greeted the Changs at the airport upon their arrival.

The Star Tribune published Thursday a report on the Changs' conditions and their plan to receive bone marrow transplants at Minnesota State University's medical center. The report also noted that the family obtained a huge sum in donations from the Taiwan public, which will be used to cover their medical expenses.
Wang said the family is expected to stay in the state for between six months to a year, depending on the progress of the treatment.
The MSU medical center was expected to hold a news conference Friday to explain their planned treatment for the brothers, Wang added.

According to the father, Chang Ming-hui, his eldest son, Chien-hsuan, will receive the first transplant, followed by the youngest son. Doctor's had yet to decide wether it will be possible to perform a transplant on the second son, who is already paralyzed.

ALD is a rare genetic disorder in which the fatty myelin "insulation" around the nerves breaks down. The disease was brought to public attention largely thanks to the 1992 film "Lorenzo's Oil, " which was based on the true story of an American couple's search for a cure for their ALD-afflicted son.

DOC.HEADLINE: TRANSPORT MINISTER WISHES BEST FOR TAIWAN-MAINLAND CHARTER FLIGHTS

TEXT.P: Transport and Communications Minister Lin Ling-san offered his best wishes Friday for the special Chinese New Year charter flights between Taiwan and mainland China and wished all returning Taiwan businessmen a happy new year.
Lin made the remarks while taking part in a ceremony to mark the inauguration of a passenger waiting area at Chiang Kai-shek International Airport.

Stating that he is happy that all arrangements and preparations for the charter flights have proceeded smoothly on both sides, Lin said that he is confident that the service will kick off Jan. 29 as scheduled and run through Feb. 20.

Six airlines on either side of the Taiwan Strait will offer the service designed especially for Taiwan businessmen and their families operating on the mainland who wish to return for the Chinese New Year holiday on Feb. 9.
It was reported that the mainland-based Air China, China Southern Airlines, China Eastern Airlines, Hainan Airlines and Xiamen Airlines will take part in the flight service.

Speaking on the same occasion, Civil Aeronautics Administration Director General Chang Kuo-cheng said that he will call a meeting with representatives from the six carriers on the Taiwan side -- China Airlines, EVA Airways Corporation, Trans Asia Airways, Far East Air Transport Corp., UNI Airways Corp. and Mandarin Airlines -- to iron out relevant details.

As the service will be confined to Taiwan businessmen and their families, the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council and mainland-based Taiwan businessmen's groups will take charge of verifying the status of the passengers, Chang noted.

The Taiwan-mainland China lunar new year charter flights took off for the first time in 2003, involving only the six Taiwan aviation companies. But the service failed to proceed in 2004 owning to Beijing's refusal to negotiate its demand that mainland carriers also be permitted to offer the service.

DOC.HEADLINE: BASIC LAW PROVIDES AUTONOMY FOR INDIGENOUS PEOPLE

TEXT.P: The Basic Law for Indigenous People, which passed through the Legislative Yuan Friday, gives Taiwan's indigenous people the right to autonomy and protects their rights to their traditional land.
Under the law, indigenous people have the right of autonomy in their traditional territory and on land that is reserved for them.

The government must provide funds every year for the autonomy of the indigenous people and the local governments that govern the areas of indigenous people should have a special unit for indigenous affairs.

These local governments should also have special units to study and develop the languages of the indigenous people and should establish a system to test and certify the indigenous people's ability to speak their mother tongues.

These governments should also recruit government employees from among the indigenous people through public examinations in which the indigenous peoples' language ability must be tested. Within their areas, the indigenous people may hunt wild animals, gather wild plants and fungus, mine, dig and gather earth and rocks, and utilize water resources. The government should seek the indigenous people's consent before developing the land or exploiting natural resources in these areas and should allow them to take part in any such activities.

The government should seek the indigenous people's consent before establishing national parks or national scenic areas in the areas of indigenous people and should administer these parks and scenic areas together with the indigenous people.
The law also prohibits the storage of toxic materials in the area of indigenous people, and forbids the removal of indigenous people from their areas unless there are clear and immediate dangers.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN SHOULD HAVE RELIABLE DEFENSE FORCE: PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: It is important to have a reliable defense force while continuing to seek to resume cross-Taiwan Strait talks, President Chen Shui-bian said Friday.
The president made the remarks while reviewing the operations and capability of an army unit in Pingtung, southern Taiwan.

Given that mainland China has not yet abandoned the option of using force to settle disputes with Taiwan, it is necessary for Taiwan to have a reliable defense force, while continuing to seek the resumption of cross-strait dialogue, to deter possible military adventurism on the part of Beijing.

Taiwan is a peace-loving and democratic country and its people assert that disputes should be settled through dialogue, Chen said, adding that this is the reason why he concentrated his 2005 New Year's Day address on creating a new and stable environment for consultations and dialogue, which would also serve as a basic concept in promoting cross-strait talks.
"We will continue to actively seek the resumption of cross-strait talks, which we have tried to re-open over the last four years, " Chen said.

He pointed out, however, that Beijing has been sharply increasing its military buildup in recent years with a double-digit annual growth rate of military expenditures along with its economic expansion.
Mainland China's rapid military expansion poses a serious threat to regional stability and peace, he warned.

Beijing has been actively engaging in "psychological, legal and media warfare" in pushing to enact an "anti-secession law, " which he said is aimed at establishing a mainland-based legal justification for a military invasion of Taiwan.
He condemned Beijing's move as an attempt to unilaterally change the status quo in the Taiwan Strait.
The National People's Congress (NPC) Standing Committee late last year placed the "anti-secession law" bill on the agenda for the annual session of the NPC set for this March.

DOC.TEXT:
The Times: The second-term mission : to end tyranny on Earth.
Four years ago he was the Accidental President, scion of a ruling family propelled into the highest office more by genetics and duty than by political zeal and ideological mission. Victor, sort of, after a messy constitutional scrum left him in charge of a divided nation and holding a flimsy legitimacy, this apparently callow and unengaged new President seemed to match the times. Bush from frat-boy- made-good to solemn champion of an urgent messianic mission to transform the world was completed.

DOC.TEXT:
The Moscow Times: Yushchenko to Be Sworn Into Office on Sunday.
Parliament voted Thursday to hold President-elect Viktor Yushchenko's inauguration this coming Sunday, setting the stage for the transition to a new government for Ukraine following months of divisive political crisis.

DOC.HEADLINE: VP CONDEMNS BEIJING'S DIPLOMATIC BLOCKADE AGAINST TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Vice President Annette Lu blasted mainland China Friday for going to extremes in every instance to isolate Taiwan from the international community, saying that its actions are unacceptable to the international community.
Lu was responding to foreign wire reports that Taiwan's diplomatic ally -- Grenada -- has signed a joint comunique with Beijing to resume diplomatic ties with mainland China.

While meeting with Victor Manuel Sanchez Pena, the new Dominican Republic ambassador to the Republic of China, Lu said that Beijing authorities always try to tempt political leaders of Taiwan's diplomatic allies with large sums of money to forge diplomatic ties with China.

Lu said that the diplomatic policy of the new government led by President Chen Shui-bian is different from that of the former government, adding that Chen's administration attaches great importance to the principles of equality and national dignity while the former government paid much attention to the number of the nation's diplomatic allies and always made great concessions for the purpose of maintaining bilateral relations.

Stressing that Chen's administration cherishes the traditional friendship that is maintained with all its diplomatic allies, Lu called on the leaders of these ROC allies not to play Beijing against Taipei in a bid to make a profit out of the competition between Taiwan and the mainland.

Touching on Taiwan's relations with Central and South American states, Lu said that the government has worked out a set of projects aimed at promoting bilateral cooperation and substantive exchanges with Taiwan's diplomatic allies in that region.

The vice president also disclosed that she is working actively to push for a "new town-building program," under which Taiwan will help its Latin American diplomatic allies carry out various development projects in the fields of agriculture, fishery, energy and infrastructure.
In addition, the government has launched the Taiwan Scholarship Program for students from the nation's diplomatic allies to study in Taiwan, Lu went on.
During the meeting, Lu also said that Taiwan is willing to cooperate with the Dominican Republic in carrying out a farm development plan in that Caribbean state.
For his part, Sanchez said that Lu is welcome to make an official visit to his country to discuss details of the cooperation plan with relevant authorities.

DOC.HEADLINE: 2004 JOBLESS RATE BEATS GOVERNMENT EXPECTATIONS AT 4.44 PERCENT

TEXT.P: Taiwan's unemployment rate for 2004 was 4.44 percent, lower than the government's forecast of 4.5 percent thanks to December's figure of 4.09 percent -- the lowest single monthly level since May 2001, government statistics released Friday showed.

The Cabinet-level Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS) reported that the December 2004 jobless rate was down by 0.05 percentage points compared to the previous month's level and lower by 0.49 percentage points from the year-earlier level.

The 4.44 percent unemployment rate was lower than Hong Kong's 6.5 percent and Japan's 4.5 percent, but lackluster compared to Singapore's 3.4 percent and South Korea's 3.6 percent, according to DGBAS tallies.
In December, 422,000 workers remained jobless, 4,000 fewer than the November figure, or a fall of 0.05 percentage points.

An average of 9.786 million people were employed across the country in 2004, up by 213,000 over the 2003 level, the largest annual growth since 1993, thanks to a fast recovering industrial sector which absorbed the highest number of about 112,000 workers and lifted the total number of workers in the sector to more than 3.44 million.
At the same time, there were some 454. 000 jobless people for the whole of last year, down by 49,000 from the number a year ago -- a drop of 0.55 percentage points from the 2003 figure.

Liu Pei-chen, a deputy bureau chief at the DGBAS, said that senior high school graduates posted the largest unemployment rate of 4.59 percent for December, followed by junior high and elementary schoolers with 4.06 percent and college graduates and post-graduates at 3.57 percent.

In terms of age, 10.02 percent of those aged between 15 and 24 were without a job in December, sliding by 0.34 percentage points from November. The 25 to 44 age group recorded an unemployment of 3.72 percent, a slight rise of 0.07 percentage points month-to-month. Some 2.9 percent of the people aged between 45 and 64 were unemployed, down by 0.15 percentage points compared to the November level.

In December, jobless people were out of work for an average 30.7 weeks, 0.9 weeks longer than the November average. It took 32.9 weeks for first-time job seekers to find a job, an increase of 5.2 weeks.

Non first-time job seekers spent an average of 30.2 weeks to enter the workplace again in that same month, 0.1 weeks less than in November. They were jobless an average of 29.4 weeks last year, an improvement of 1.1 weeks.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOEA APPROVES BUDGETS FOR 17 PROJECTS UNDER SBIR PLAN

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) approved budgets totaling NT$28 million (US$875,000) Friday for 17 projects put forward by small companies to its Department of Industry Technology.

According to an official at the department, the small- and medium-sized companies to receive government subsides under the Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) plan are mainly in the domestic information technology, electronics, machinery and daily consumption sectors, which in turn will also spend NT$47 million and allocate at least 13,000 people to their research and development efforts.

The department has approved more than NT$3 billion in budgets for 1,365 innovation projects submitted by domestic small businesses since it initiated the SBIR plan in Feb. 1999. In response, the private sector spent nearly NT$6.5 billion in their R&D drives, the official said.

DOC.HEADLINE: UNIVERSITIES OF TAIWAN AND CHINA SIGN SISTERHOOD ACCORD

TEXT.P: National Cheng Kung University (NCKU) of Taiwan and Xiamen University of mainland China signed a sisterhood accord Friday to promote academic exchanges and cooperation.

The signing ceremony was held at the NCKU main campus in Tainan, southern Taiwan, with NCKU President Kao Chiang and his mainland Chinese counterpart inking the documents on behalf of their respective universities.
Speaking on the occasion, Kao said that the agreement offers a platform for the two sides to increase substantively academic exchanges and cooperation.

He expressed the hope that professors of the two universities will visit each other for research and studies in the future under the framework of the accord, while their students can take classes on either side and their credits can be recognized mutually.
He hoped also that the two universities can jointly organize academic seminars.

In efforts to promote international cooperation, the NCKU has since 1996 signed sisterhood accords or academic exchange and cooperation pacts with 16 overseas universities, including Case Western Reserve University of the United States, Central South University of Technology and Northwestern Politechnical University of mainland China, Kao revealed.

DOC.HEADLINE: JANUARY TO NOVEMBER AVERAGE SALARY INCREASES BY 2.03 PERCENT IN 2004

TEXT.P: The average salary for employees in the industrial and service sectors during the first 11 months of last year increased by 2.03 percent year-on-year, the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS) under the Executive Yuan announced Friday.
According to DGBAS statistics, the average salary for employees in the industrial and service sectors was NT$43,011 (US$1,348) during the January-November period.
The statistics also showed that the two sectors' employees worked an average of 182.6 hours each month in the first 11 months, up 2.5 hours from the previous year's level.

In terms of business sectors, employees in the real estate and lease sectors increased their working hours the most by 7.7 hours, followed by 4.2 hours in the wholesale and retail sectors and 3.2 hours in the transportation and telecommunication sectors.

In November, the average monthly working time for the industrial and service sectors was 188.2 hours, representing an increase of 5.2 hours in comparison with the previous month's level, or up 9.4 hours from the same period of 2003.
As of the end of November 2004, there were around 5.9 million employees in the two sectors, up 8,000 from the previous month's level, or an increase of 172,000 from the same period of 2003.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT VOWS TO CONTINUE TO SEEK INTER-PARTY COOPERATION

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian Friday reiterated his determination to continue to promote reconciliation and cooperation among political parties for the sake of Taiwan's political stability.

Speaking at a luncheon party he hosted in honor of legislators-elect and outgoing lawmakers of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) , Chen said inter-party reconciliation and cooperation are essential to the nation's political and economic development.
Chen stressed that for the sake of national interests, the ruling party will not give up any opportunity to seek cooperation with opposition parties.
He also encouraged all the DPP's legislators-elect to perform their duties well during the new legislative term that will begin Feb. 1.

Chen has been seeking to end long-term inter-party disagreements and bickering since the Dec. 11 legislative elections, in which the "pan-green camp" of the DPP and its ally, the Taiwan Solidarity Union, failed to gain a majority in the 225-seat legislature.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER CALLS FOR COOPERATION TO PROMOTE NATIONAL DEVELOPMENT

TEXT.P: Premier Yu Shyi-kun called on lawmakers of the ruling and opposition camps Friday to cooperate to promote national development.

Speaking at a farewell party for outgoing members of the fifth Legislative Yuan, whose terms will expire at the end of this month, Yu said that he assumed the premiership on the same day when the lawmakers were sowrn in nearly three years ago.

Thanks to the support and cooperation of the legislators as well as concerted efforts by the government and the people, Yu noted, Taiwan's unemployment rate decreased to 4.44 percent at the end of last year from the highest point of 5.3 percent over the past three years, while the nation's economic growth rate increased to 5.93 percent from a negative 2.22 percent.

However, he said, there still exists room for improvement and the ruling and opposition parties should set aside their rivalries and work together for the sake of the nation's sustainable development.

DOC.HEADLINE: LEGISLATURE ENDS TERM BY PULLING THE PLUG ON BUDGET ITEMS

TEXT.P: The general budget of the central government passed through the Legislative Yuan hours before the legislature went into recess Friday.

According to the approved budget, the government's revenue was set at NT$1.33 trillion (US$41.77 billion) , and the spending at NT$1.6 trillion (US$50.25 billion) which is NT$71.6 billion less than the original budget.
Notable among the agencies whose budget was cut was the organizing committee for a National Human Rights Memorial Hall under the Presidential Office. The entire NT$26 million was scotched.

The Government Information Office (GIO), which has tried to take away a channel used by a broadcast corporation of the opposition Kuomintang, saw its budget slashed by the opposition-controlled legislature by more than NT$400 million, including NT1.6 million in special funds for the use of the GIO chief and deputy chief.

The Grand Justices, who ruled against the opposition in a dispute about the constitutionality of the "319 Truth Investigation Committee" have seen their professional allowance, which was budgeted at NT$18 million or NT$89,000 per capita per month, as well as the subsidy for overseas trips, which was budgeted at NT$1.8 million, was completely eliminated.
The justices will retain their fixed salaries.
The Control Yuan's budget was cut by NT$12 million, which was intended for investigations and research costs for its members.

The NT$7 million budget for the Corruption Investigation Center under the Prosecutors' Office at the Taiwan High Court remained intact, although the opposition has threatened to do away with it on the grounds that the center was not formed on the basis of law.

The center's budget came to public attention the previous day after prosecutors from the center claimed that several opposition lawmakers, who were probed by the center in connection with corruption, threatened to kill the center's budget in revenge.

The examination of the general budgetary bill is the climax of the last day of this legislative session, which is the last sitting of the current lawmakers whose three-year terms are due to end at the end of this month.

Wang Jin-pyng, president of the Legislative Yuan, rounded off the sitting by saying that this legislature has approved 611 statutory and budgetary bills during its three-year term, a performance which is average for the law-making body.

He condemned the lawmakers of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) for occupying the president's podium to obstruct the deliberation of an opposition-proposed bill about a national communications commission during the sitting, calling it a dirty tactic unbecoming a ruling party.

On the other hand, DPP Secretary-General Chang Chun-hsiung decried the now ended legislature for being out of control and fragmented with partisan struggling the likes of which has never before been seen in the history of the country.

Chang said the opposition-controlled legislature had no respect for the Constitution as made clear by the way it railroaded through a statute to set up the "319 Truth Investigation Commission, " which was ruled unconstitutional by the Council of Grand Justices, its refusal to exercise its right to confirm the president's nominees for members of the Control Yuan, and for axing the government's budget arbitrarily to the detriment of the whole country.

He said he hopes different political parties will reconcile their differences and subordinate their partisan interests for the general benefit of the country in the next legislature, which will be sworn in on Feb. 1.

DOC.HEADLINE: INT'L INVESTMENT-SOLICITING CONFERENCE TO OPEN IN TAIWAN IN SEPT.

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Economic Affairs will organize an international investment-soliciting conference in Taipei in September.
The conference will focus on the application of nanotechnology, which is a field the country is concentrating its resources on developing, according to economics officials.

DOC.HEADLINE: LAW REVISED TO ALLOW ELECTRONIC MONITORING OF RELEASED RAPISTS

TEXT.P: Convicted rapists out on parole may be required to wear electronic tracking devices according to a revision to the Law for the Prevention of Sex Crimes passed by the Legislative Yuan Friday.
The revision gives prosecutors the right to order convicted rapists who are released on parole but have no regular residence and are deemed potential recidivists to wear the monitors.

DOC.HEADLINE: 6.0 TREMOR HITS TAIWAN: NO DAMAGE REPORTED

TEXT.P: An earthquake with a preliminary measurement of 6.0 on the Richter scale hit Taiwan at 10: 28 p.m. Friday, with no immediate reports of damage, according to the Central Weather Bureau.
The earthquake was centered at sea about 65.4 kilometers east of Ilan, eastern Taiwan and 84 kilometers underground. It was felt in the capital city of Taipei as 2.0, said the bureau.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Saturday, Jan. 22, or the 13th day of the 12th month of the Year of the Monkey according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1666: Shah Jahan, the mighty Mogul emperor of India who built the Taj Mahal as a mausoleum for his beloved wife Mumtaz-i-Mahal, dies at the age of 74.
1771: Spain agrees to cede the Falkland Islands in the South Atlantic to Britain.
1775: Andre Ampere, the French physicist and discoverer of electromagnets who gave his name to the "amp" as a unit of electricity, is born.
1901: After a 64-year reign, Queen Victoria, whose sense of duty and strict moral code had great influence on 19th-century British society, dies at Osborne House on the Isle of Wight at the age of 81.
1905: Tsarist troops fire salvo after close-range salvo into a crowd in St. Petersburg, Russia, leaving the snow red with the blood of at least 500 strikers.
1922: Pope Benedict XV, originally Giacomo della Chiesa, who sponsored World War I relief efforts and sought to mediate peace, dies in Rome. He was succeeded by Pope Pius XI.
1924: Ramsay MacDonald becomes Britain's first Labor prime minister, replacing Stanley Baldwin.
1935: After long negotiations, Japan pays 140 million yen for Soviet interests in the Chinese Eastern Railway, the last legal trace of Russian influence in Manchuria.
1944: Allied landings begin at Arizo, Italy, involving an estimated 50,000 U.S. and British troops.
1945: More than 500 U.S. warplanes launch air-raids on Okinawa and Taiwan.
1945: The land route to China -- the Ledo Road across Burma from India to China -- reopens.
1946: U.S. President Harry Truman orders the establishment of the Central Intelligence Agency.
1949: The guerrilla army of China's Mao Tse-tung marches toward Beijing after crossing the Yangtze River to defeat the Nationalist army at Huai Hai north of Beijing.
1955: Adm. Felix B. Stump, commander in chief of the U.S. Pacific Fleet, says that the United States will help defend Taiwan if attacked following the signing of the Sino-American Mutual Defense Treaty in Washington on Dec. 3, 1954.
1965: Peng Ming-min, a professor at National Taiwan University, and two students, are charged with subversion against the government by military prosecutors.
1973: Prince Tuipelehake, C.B.E., prime minister of the Kingdom of Tonga, arrives in Taipei for a one-week visit.
1973: Lyndon B. Johnson, the 36th U.S. president, who succeeded John F. Kennedy, dies of a heart attack in Texas at the age of 64.
1975: Nobutaka Shikanai, president of the Sankei Shimbun newspaper and the Fuji Television Corporation of Japan, arrives in Taipei for a five-day visit.
1979: Demonstrations are held at Kaohsiung railway station and Chiaotou township in southern Taiwan's Kaohsiung County against the arrest of Yu Teng-fa for sedition.
1980: Dr. Andrei Dimitrievich Sakharov, the Soviet physicist who helped develop the first Soviet hydrogen bomb, is arrested, stripped of his honor and banished to Gorky from Moscow. An outspoken advocate of human rights and nuclear disarmament, he won the 1975 Nobel Peace Prize.
1986: Typhoon Wayne blasts across central and southern Taiwan and the offshore island county of Penghu, killing 256 people and causing property losses estimated at NT$11.5 billion. The typhoon damage is the heaviest in 20 years, and the Executive Yuan allocates NT$1 billion to help the victims.
1987: ROC President Chiang Ching-kuo receives the chiefs of administrative branches under the Executive Yuan, and urges them and other government officials to persevere in discharging their duties and to endeavor to promote political reform.
1990: The Yugoslav Communist Party renounces its monopoly on power after 45 years of rule.
1996: The Pentagon announces for the first time the size of the U.S. chemical weapons arsenal, and says all 3.6 million weapons will be destroyed by 2004.
2000: Taiwan's Wei Yun-chieh shoots a five-under-par 67 to win the Chunghua Cup Women's Golf Tournament, the first leg of the 2000 Women's Asian Circuit, with a three-day total of 213.
2001: ROC Government Information Office Director-General Su Tzeng-ping conveys his congratulations to Ang Lee, a Taiwan-born director whose "Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon" won the 58th Golden Globe best director and best foreign film awards.
2002: U.S. Assistant Secretary of Commerce for Market Access and Compliance William H. Lash, III arrives in Taipei for a four-day visit.
2002: Republic of Chad Ambassador to the Republic of China Hissein Brahim Taha presents his credentials to President Chen Shui-bian.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "Those who know it are not as those who love it; those who love it are not as those who find their joy in it."

DOC.HEADLINE: OUTGOING JUSTICE MINISTER TO RUN FOR MAGISTRATE IN ILAN

TEXT.P: Minister of Justice Chen Ding-nan said Saturday that he will join the race for magistrate in his home county of Ilan in the year-end election.
Chen confirmed a report in a local newspaper Saturday that he will respond to calls from his supporters to run for the post he served in from 1981 to 1989.

Noting that he is set to leave his post in the Ministry of Justice when Premier Yu Shyi-kun and the rest of the Cabinet resign en masse Monday, Chen said it is regrettable that many projects he initiated at the Ministry of Justice have not yet been completed, but added that he can't sit idly by while his home county faces serious challenges brought on by the opening of the Beiyi Expressway scheduled for the end of this year.
The minister said he couldn't ignore the repeated appeals from his supporters at home for him to lead them in developing Ilan.
Chen said he would return to Ilan and gear up for the elections on Feb. 1.

The newspaper Liberty Times said Saturday that Chen has made his plan known to President Chen Shui-bian via a report relayed to the president on Jan. 18 by Premier Yu Shyi-kun and has won the president's endorsement.

DOC.HEADLINE: RECENT RISE IN OIL PRICES NOT A CAUSE FOR CONCERN: CEPD

TEXT.P: Officials from Taiwan's top economic planning agency said Saturday that there is no cause for concern about the surge in oil prices in recent days.

Hu Sheng-cheng, chairman of the Cabinet-level Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) , said that the rise in oil prices will only be short term and that the price of oil is very likely to drop to US$35 a barrel this year. He added that this will help stabilize the growth rate in consumer product prices at home at below 2 percent for 2005.
Foreign wire services reported that in early trading Friday on the New York Stock Exchange, light sweet crude for delivery in March jumped by US$1.39 to US$48.7 per barrel.

CEPD Vice Chairman Yeh Ming-feng said that rising oil prices won't last long, predicting that prices will drop after March when the weather begins to warm up. World oil prices have slid by some 20 percent from the peak in October last year.

Analysts at the Chung-Hua Institution for Economic Research, however, contended that oil prices are very likely to rise above US$50 a barrel in the near term, citing international concerns that oil production might be disrupted by terrorist attacks as the Jan. 31 elections in Iraq approach.

DOC.HEADLINE: CONFERENCE REJECTS IDEA OF HEALTH INSURANCE PREMIUM HIKE

TEXT.P: A conference held to get public input into how to remedy the debt-ridden national health insurance program on Saturday rejected the idea of hiking premiums.
The 20 participants in the three-day conference agreed unanimously that action should be taken to save the program from bankruptcy, but not through an increase in insurance premiums.
The conference was organized by National Taiwan University's Sociology Department at the request of the National Health Insurance Bureau.
The participants reached consensus that the health categories covered by the program should not be reduced to deal with the program's financial difficulties.
They suggested a change in how premiums are calculated, from a percentage of an insured's salary to a percentage of their total personal income, saying this would be a fairer system.

In order to raise funds to finance the program, they suggested levying a health tax on cigarettes and aggressively pursuing claims for damage on behalf of motor vehicle accident victims and against employers negligent in occupational safety.
Abuse and waste in the health insurance program should be curbed to decrease the program's costs, according to the conclusions reached by the conference participants.

Liu Chien-hsiang, general manager of the National Health Insurance Bureau, said the conclusions will be taken into account when the bureau works out its proposal for improving the financial health of the insurance program.

Noting that the bureaus' proposal will have to be approved by the Department of Health and the Executive Yuan before it can take effect and that the Legislative Yuan has passed a resolution forbidding the Executive Yuan from raising national health insurance premiums before the new legislature opens, Liu said his bureau will not cut corners in working out its proposal for revamping the program.

DOC.HEADLINE: HUALIEN, CHIAYI POST HIGHEST JOBLESS RATE FOR 2004: DGBAS

TEXT.P: The eastern county of Hualien and the southern county of Chiayi both posted the highest jobless rate in Taiwan for 2004 at 4.8 percent, according to the latest government statistics.

Hsinchu County in northern Taiwan had the lowest unemployment rate last year, at 3.8 percent, while Taipei registered a jobless rate of 4.2 percent, the tallies compiled by the Cabinet-level Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS) showed.

By region, eastern Taiwan had the highest unemployment rate, at 4.6 percent, while northern Taiwan had the lowest rate, at 4.3 percent. The rate for central Taiwan and southern Taiwan averaged at 4.5 percent.
The offshore island county of Penghu had the smallest number of employees of 34,000.

There were a total of 17.76 million people aged over 15 in Taiwan last year. Some 9.786 million people were employed, while 454,000 were jobless, marking a labor participation rate of 57.66 percent and an unemployment rate of 4.44 percent. The 4.44 percent jobless rate is the lowest since 2001.
