The Japan Times: Bush sworn in for second term U.S. president vows in inaugural address to export freedom.
U.S. president George W. Bush pledged to work to heal a country divided by the Iraq war and vowed to advance freedom.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN MUSIC CORPS TO PERFORM AT MUSICAL FESTIVAL IN SALZBURG

TEXT.P: A music-oriented goodwill corps formed to engage in cultural exchanges in the international community will take part in an international chorus and symphony festival in Salzburg, Austria in July at the invitation of the Austrian tourist bureau, according to a Taiwan musician who will head the group on the trip.

Dr. Lin Jong-teh, who has dedicated himself to teaching music to youths in Taiwan, said Saturday that the goodwill corps will be mainly comprised of members of a Kaohsiung youth chorus society, which is scheduled to stage a joint performance with the Salzburg Symphony Orchestra during the July festival.

Chuang Ya-fei, a Taiwan-born pianist living in the United States who has won first prize at the Cologne International Piano Competition, will give a solo performance at the festival, according to Lin.

Lin said he feels their upcoming participation in the major musical event in Salzburg, the birth place of musical genius Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart (1756-1791) , will be a good chance for the corps to conduct exchanges with musical groups from around the world.

DOC.HEADLINE: COMBINED MARKET VALUE OF LISTED COMPANIES DOWN FROM LAST WEEK

TEXT.P: The combined market value of listed companies in Taiwan hit NT$13.38 trillion (US$418.12 billion) at the close of trading Friday, down NT$86.45 billion, or 0.64 percent, over the previous week, according to statistics compiled by the Taiwan Stock Exchange Company (TSEC).
One of the main reasons for the drop was concerns about stock market declines in the United States.

The statistics also showed that excluding the automobile and electronics industries, the market value of listed companies in the top 20 major industries declined for the week. The market value for listed companies in the electric appliance and cable industry moved down the most at 6.4 percent, while the market value of listed companies in the transportation, construction and composite industries all showed declines of over 3 percent.

The weighted index, the key barometer of the Taiwan Stock Exchange, closed at 5,848.91 Friday, for a decrease of 40.61 points, or 0.69 percent, over the previous Friday's close, on a combined turnover of NT$266.3 billion for the week.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTELLECTUAL PROPERTY OFFICE TO SHIFT FOCUS TO INTERNET

TEXT.P: The Intellectual Property Office under the Ministry of Economic Affairs will shift its focus from cracking down on pirated compact discs to intellectual property rights infringements on the Internet, according to an official from the office.

Encouraged by the Office of the U.S. Trade Representative's decision to remove Taiwan from its "Special 301 priority watch list," the official said his office is planning to recruit a team of computer experts to crack down on Web sites that illegally provide copyrighted music and software for downloading.

The Office of the U.S. Trade Representative (USTR) removed Taiwan from its "Special 301 priority watch list" Jan. 18 in recognition of the island's efforts and progress in intellectual property rights (IPR) protection.
U.S. Trade Representative Robert Zoellick said at that time that Taiwan's efforts in cracking down on commercial piracy and counterfeit products over the past year have been commendable.

Zoellick noted, however, that Taiwan can do a better job in protection of patent and innovation rights on pharmaceutical products and agrochemical products since the United States thinks that IPR threats still exist in those areas.

DOC.HEADLINE: TSU WON'T BE ABSENT IN LOCAL GOVERNMENT HEAD ELECTIONS: OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) will not be absent in the various local government head elections slated for the end of this year, TSU Secretary-General Chen Chien-ming said Saturday.

Chen said that his party has decided in principle to nominate incumbent or former legislators as TSU candidates to run in the mayoral and county magistrate elections to be held around Taiwan in December. A total of 23 city and county government heads will be elected in the polls set for the final month of 2005.

The party will coordinate with the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) on the nomination of candidates for the elections, Chen promised, adding however that the TSU will absolutely not be absent in the elections.

Liu Yi-teh, director of the TSU Organization Department, said that participating in the elections is for the party's survival. The DPP, which together with the TSU forms the so-called "pan green camp, " should give its political ally a chance in some constituencies, he urged.

TSU Chairman Su Chin-chiang has engaged in a fact-finding tour around the nation since Jan. 10 when he assumed the party's helm. Su's move is widely seen as part of his efforts to consolidate the support of the party's grassroots in preparation for the year-end elections.
The TSU is the fourth largest party in the Legislative Yuan with 13 seats in the 225-member legislature.

DOC.HEADLINE: ECONOMICS MINISTER DEPARTS JAPAN AFTER 'FRUITFUL' VISIT
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, Jan. 22 (CNA) (By Amy Huang & Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: Republic of China Economic Affairs Minister Ho Mei-yueh said in Tokyo Saturday upon concluding her six-day visit to Japan that the trip was "fruitful."

Ho, who arrived in Japan on Jan. 17 at the head of a delegation consisting of officials from the Industrial Development Bureau and the Institute for Information Industry, told a news conference before her departure back to Taiwan that she had called on several firms, including Access, NEC, Sony, Olympus, Hitachi and NAMCO, during her visit to discuss cooperation between them and Taiwan.
Declining to go into detail, Ho said she could only mention that cooperation plans with these companies are in the works.

She pointed out that all of the companies she spoke with have confidence in Taiwan's investment environment and consider Taiwan firms to be valuable potential partners in exploring the mainland Chinese market.

In an attempt to address Japanese firms' concerns that Taiwan's economic prospects could be negatively affected by its exclusion from the emerging free trade bloc centered around the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) , Ho said Taiwan will explore every possibility of striking free trade agreements with other countries in the region and seek the support of the Japanese private sector in signing a free trade pact with Japan.

DOC.HEADLINE: QUANTA TAKES AIM AT 30% SHARE OF GLOBAL NOTEBOOK COMPUTER MARKET

TEXT.P: Quanta Computer Inc., Taiwan's largest notebook computer maker, is aiming at grabbing a 30 percent share of the world's market this year after cornering 25 percent of the market in 2004, according to Quanta President Barry Lam.
Lam said he is confident that the company can reach the target, which would see the company's production volume reach more than 130 million units, or up 20 millions units over the 2004 level.
In addition to notebooks, Lam said that cellular phones and liquid crystal display televisions will also be the company's major products this year.
Meanwhile, a Quanta research and development center is slated to open in Linkou, Taipei County in May this year, creating more than 7,000 jobs, Lam said.

Following booming business in the fourth quarter of last year, the notebook maker hopes to rack up revenue of over NT$400 billion (US$12.5 billion) for 2005, a Quanta executive said, adding that it chalked up NT$324.52 billion worth of business for the whole of 2004.

Quanta also makes servers, set-top boxes, monitors, optical storage products, mobile phones and liquid crystal display televisions. Apple, Dell, Gateway, Hewlett-Packard, Matsushita Electric Industrial and Sony are among its major customers. The group has set its total revenue target for 2005 at NT$500 billion.

DOC.HEADLINE: NATIONAL EXPOSITION OF EDUCATION KICKS OFF AROUND ISLAND

TEXT.P: The National Exposition of Education kicked off Saturday with activities in Taipei County, northern Taiwan; Taichung City, central Taiwan; Kaohsiung City, southern Taiwan; and Hualien County in eastern Taiwan.

The three-day nationwide exposition is being sponsored by the Ministry of Education (MOE) to display the results of the government's education reforms, Education Minister Tu Cheng-sheng said while presiding over an opening ceremony at the National Science and Technology Museum in Kaohsiung.

Although he admitted that there have been some flaws in the ongoing education reforms, the minister said the reforms have also born many fruits which need to be recognized by the people of the country.

The exposition centers around four main themes, namely a modern citizenry, a global perspective, the Taiwan entity, and social concern. Hundreds of activities, including artistic performances and exhibitions, will be held in cities and counties around the island during the event.

DOC.HEADLINE: GLOBAL CENSUS OF BLACK-FACED SPOONBILLS UNDERWAY
DOC.DATELINE: Tainan, southern Taiwan, Jan. 22 (CNA) (By Nick Hunag)

TEXT.P: The two-day annual global census of black-faced spoonbills kicked off Saturday in Asia, with preliminary counts showing 580 of the endangered birds in Tainan County, according to officials from the Taiwan-based Wild Bird Society (WBS).

The Hong Kong Bird Watching Society (HKBWS) , organizer of the annual event, will collect the survey data on the rare migratory birds from around Asia, including South Korea, Taiwan, Hong Kong, Japan, Vietnam, the Philippines and Macau, the officials said.

In Taiwan, the census is being conducted by the WBS, the Black-faced Spoonbill Conservation Society and the Happy Wild Bird Association, the officials said, adding that currently, the number of black-faced spoonbills counted in the Chiku Wetlands sanctuary near the estuary of the Tsengwen River stands at 430, with a further 55 by the Pachang brook, 43 in Tungyuwen, 35 at Peiyuwen, and 17 in Tingshan, the officials said.

In last year's census, a total of 1,206 black-faced spoonbills were counted worldwide, with about half wintering in Taiwan. This year, the number of the rare birds wintering in Taiwan surpassed 780 as of Jan. 9, the officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CALLS FOR BETTER CHILDREN'S CARE

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian urged relevant government agencies Saturday to thoroughly enforce laws and regulations on children's welfare and to provide youngsters with better health care and treatment.

Speaking at a garden party held in the compound of the Presidential Office to entertain physically challenged children, aboriginal children, orphans, and kids from poor families, Chen said that the relevant government agencies should formulate ways and means to offer subsidies to families who are not able to pay the premiums for their children's health insurance.

Some children have not enjoyed due medical care since the government implemented a medical treatment assistance program for children younger than three years old several years ago, because their parents cannot pay their health insurance premiums, he pointed out.

It is painful and regrettable to hear recent reports on the maltreatment of children and even cases of children being forced to commit suicide together with their parents, Chen lamented, adding that these tragedies are mainly due to poverty.
There still exist poor people in Taiwan even though the country's per capita income has surpassed US$14,000, the president noted.

In addition to the government's efforts, Chen promised that he will do his best to work together with domestic enterprises, mass media and social welfare organizations to raise charity funds for needy children to improve their health care and treatment.

DOC.HEADLINE: KINMEN, MATSU RESIDENTS KEENLY HOPE FOR AIR SERVICES VIA 'MINI LINKS'

TEXT.P: With the special cross-strait charter flights for the upcoming Chinese New Year holiday set to take off, the hopes of residents on the outlying islands of Kinmen and Matsu for the establishment of the air links seems to be fading again, local government officials said Saturday.

Although the two islands have maintained direct trade, postal and shipping links with Xiamen and Mawei ports in mainland China's Fujian Province since the start of 2001, the officials said that local residents have high expectations that air travel services could be added to the so-called "mini three links" to further boost economic and tourism development.

But the possibility seems extremely slim now that the direct cross-strait charter flights to serve mainland-based Taiwan business people returning home for the holiday are set to take off, the officials said, adding that all the local people can do now is to pray that the services will have a minimal impact on the "mini three links."

Despite the fact that the "mini three links" have been in place for over four years, Kinmen and Matsu residents are not satisfied with the operations because of the many restrictions and lack of air links.

Several recent polls have shown that most of the residents of the islands give a failing grade to the services, and the Control Yuan even asked the Executive Yuan earlier this month to remedy several major shortcomings of the links and enhance their functions.

Kinmen and Matsu residents have repeatedly called on the central government to set up air services via the "mini three links" to allow the islands to effectively serve as a transshipment hub between Taiwan and mainland China, but the government has repeatedly turned a deaf ear to their calls, the officials claimed.
The residents are deeply concerned that they will be even more negatively impacted if full links are set up between Taiwan and mainland China in the future, the officials said.

Due to the longstanding political feud between Taiwan and mainland China dating back to 1949 when the two sides split following the Chinese civil war, direct trade, transport and postal links have been absent across the strait.
The Taiwan authorities initiated the "mini three links" four years ago to help boost development on the two islands

DOC.HEADLINE: VIETNAMESE GRADUATES CONCLUDE STUDIES FOR MASTERS DEGREE IN KAOHSIUNG

TEXT.P: A total of 23 Vietnamese graduates obtained masters degree granted by National Kaohsiung University of Applied Science (KUAS) Saturday after concluding studies of a 32-month course.

KUAS President Lin Ren-yih presented diplomas to the Vietnamese graduates at a ceremony held at the KUAS main campus, in which were also present Executive Director of the Executive Yuan's Southern Taiwan Office Yu Hong, Director of Vietnam Economic and Cultural Office in Taipei Hoang Nhu Ly, Representative of Taipei Economic and Cultural Office in Vietnam Huang Nan-huei and other government officials.
The Vietnamese graduates were selected by Hanoi University of Business and Management for studying in Taiwan as a training program for the university's reserve teachers.
Speaking on the occasion, Yu extended congratulations to the graduates and encouraged them to serve as a main driving force in the promotion of Taiwan-Vietnam relations.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Sunday, Jan. 23, or the 15th day of the 12th month of the Year of the Monkey according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1556: An earthquake claims an estimated 830,000 lives and destroys many towns and villages in China's Shensi (Shaanxi) province.
1793: Poland is partitioned by Russia, Austria and Prussia.
1849: British-born Elizabeth Blackwell qualifies in New York as the first woman doctor in the United States.
1937: Seventeen communist leaders admit that they conspired with Leon Trotsky to undermine the Soviet regime of Joseph Stalin.
1946: The Allied supreme commander announces the establishment of the Far East International Military Court in Tokyo.
1949: Beijing falls as a "partial truce" agreement between the Chinese communists and Gen. Fu Chuo-yi, commander-in-chief of Nationalist forces in northern China, comes into force.
1950: Jerusalem becomes the capital of the new state of Israel.
1954: More than 14,000 communist Chinese POW's captured in the Korean War who refused to return to mainland China arrive in Taiwan.
1955: General Franco, Spanish dictator, decides to reinstate the monarchy, and Prince Juan Carlos is allowed to claim the crown.
1956: The ROC Ministry of Education approves the establishment of Shih Chien College.
1963: Five communist Chinese military personnel, including air force mechanic Chang Mu-yi and engineer Chang Mei-nan, flee mainland China to seek freedom in Taiwan.
1964: Indonesia and Malaysia agree to a cease-fire in their border war.
1968: North Korean patrol boats capture the Pueblo, a U.S. naval vessel, in the Sea of Japan, killing several of its crew.
1973: U.S. President Richard Nixon tells Americans that his government has achieved an agreement that will bring "peace with honor" and an end to the war in Vietnam.
1976: Some 3,000 persons attend the World Freedom Day rally at which ROC President Yen Chia-kan warns against communist peace talks. Other speakers at the rally include: US Representative Larry P. McDonald, Julio Cardinal Rosales of the Philippines, Congressman John Henry Okawanyo of Kenya, and Paul Vankerkhoven, president of the Belgian chapter of the World Anti-Communist League.
1979: Premier Sun Yun-suan in a speech given at the World Freedom Day rally held in Taipei warns against Chinese communist maneuverings in conjunction with the visit to the United States by Deng Xiao-ping, mainland China's vice premier.
1981: A total of 15 students are killed and more than 30 others are injured after Taipei Water Department workers accidentally open the sluice gates of a reservoir in Shihlin.
1983: Swedish tennis star Bjorn Borg, a wealthy man who made his professional debut at age 14 and won six French Open titles and five consecutive Wimbledon championships by 1981, retires at age 26.
1989: Salvador Dali, the Spanish surrealist artist known for his flamboyant personal style and his disquieting interpretations of fantastic images on meticulously rendered canvases, dies at the age of 84.
1996: Roh Tae Woo and Chun Doo Hwan, former presidents of South Korea, are charged with sedition in relation to events surrounding the 1980 army massacre of pro-democracy activists in Kwangju.
1996: Yigal Amir confesses in court to assassinating Israeli Prime Minister Yitzhak Rabin.
1996: An ROC Ministry of Education ad hoc committee decides that 452 works of art from the National Palace Museum in Taipei will be allowed to be sent on a 13-month exhibition trip to the United States, representing one of the largest bodies of Chinese national treasures ever to tour overseas.
2000: A funeral for opposition elder statesman Huang Hsin-chieh is held in Taipei, with government and opposition party officials attending the solemn ceremony.
2001: The Philippines' new administration begins a criminal investigation against ousted President Joseph Estrada.
2001: The Executive Yuan announces that the ROC government has renewed its technology and vocational training agreement with Malawi for another year.
2002: Ford Lio Ho Motor Company's Design, Research and Development Center is formally inaugurated in a ceremony attended by Vice Economics Minister Lin Yi-fu, Taoyuan County Magistrate Chu Li-lun and other officials.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "A man who wants to live a moral life must first be conscious within himself of a difficulty and have struggled to overcome that difficulty: that is the definition or test of a moral life."

DOC.HEADLINE: PROSPECTS GOOD FOR BETTER CROSS-STRAIT RELATIONS: MAC HEAD
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Jan. 22 (CNA) (By Oliver Lin and P.C. Tang)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's top official for mainland affairs said Saturday that he hopes that cross-Taiwan Strait relations will have a better development in the near future.

Joseph Wu, chairman of the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC), made the remarks while briefing media and local Taiwanese expatriates in Washington about his meetings with members of the United States Congress and think tank scholars.
Wu said he spoke on mainland China's proposed "anti-secession law" targeting Taiwan and other matters after attending the Jan. 20 inauguration of U.S. President George W. Bush.

Wu said that how to improve cross-strait relations concerns both the United States and Taiwan, and that the United States has been encouraged by the success of talks regarding direct cross-strait charter flights for next month's Chinese Lunar New Year holidays.

In negotiations held Jan. 15 in Macau, representatives from Taipei and Beijing reached an agreement to allow airlines from both sides to fly into each other's territory from Jan. 29 to Feb. 20 to serve China-based Taiwanese business people and their families.

Saying that Beijing intends to enact an "anti-secession law" at a time when the United States has its hands full with events in Iraq and other issues relating to Iran and North Korea, the MAC head noted that if enacted, the proposed law will not only destroy the status quo, but also endanger the security and stability in the Taiwan Strait as well as the interests of the United States and Japan. "Taiwan will not tolerate an 'anti-secession law,'" Wu added.

Pointing out that China has actively developed new weapons, including middle and long-range missiles, cruise missiles and nuclear submarines, Wu said that he told those in the United States that China intents to expand its sphere of influence in the world.
Wu said that the people he spoke with were aware of the situation and would speak up at an appropriate time.
Nevertheless, Wu is still optimistic about the future development of cross-strait relations, saying that he hopes things will improve with the new year holidays.

Accompanied by David Lee, Taiwan's representative to the United States, Wu, along with Academia Sinica President Lee Yuan-tseh, head of the island's delegation to President Bush's inauguration, and other members of the delegation, met with some 400 local Taiwanese expatriates at a dinner gathering.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT-PFP TICKET EXPECTED FOR LEGISLATIVE LEADERSHIP ELECTION

TEXT.P: The opposition Kuomintang (KMT) and the People First Party (PFP) are inclined to form a "KMT-PFP" ticket in the election of Legislative Yuan speaker and vice speaker scheduled for Feb. 1, a KMT legislator disclosed during an interview with CNA Sunday.

However, the cooperation of the "pan-blue alliance" in the race for the legislative speakership and vice speakership and other related issues will not be finalized until after a meeting between the leaders of the two parties, said Tseng Yung-chuan, who also serves as executive director of the KMT's Policy Committee.

Tseng said that Chang Hsien-yao, director of the PFP's policy research center, telephoned him Sunday morning and asked for an early determination of the KMT-PFP ticket so that a joint task force can be formed to campaign for the KMT-PFP ticket in the upcoming legislative speaker and vice speaker elections.

Noting that KMT officials also shared Chang's opinion, Tseng said that KMT Chairman Lien Chan will meet with his PFP counterpart James Soong to make a final determination for the issue immediately after he returns from the United States.

Once the KMT-PFP ticket is determined, the KMT will closely cooperate with the PFP under the principles of mutual respect and trust in order to win the legislative speaker and vice speaker elections, Tseng stressed.

He further said judging from recent close cooperation between the two parties in the deliberation of 2005 general budget plan and various draft bills, the KMT and the PFP still remain firm on their partnership although the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) is actively courting the PFP and has reportedly sounded out the possibility of PFP-DPP cooperation in various major issues.
Meanwhile, the PFP legislative caucus is scheduled to conduct a straw poll Monday afternoon to decide which legislator would be most suitable for running for the legislative vice speakership.

Three PFP legislators -- Chung Jung-chi, who has served as the party's secretary-general, Lee Ching-hua and Shen Chih-hui -- have expressed strong interest in vying for the vice speakership, according to sources close to the party.

The sources said that PFP Vice Chairman Chang Chao-hsiung, acting Secretary-General Chin Chin-sheng and even Soong himself will not get involved in the fierce competition, adding that everything will be up to the PFP legislative caucus.

In other related news, Huang Tsung-yuan, the chief convener of the legislative caucus of the opposition Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) , said that so far the party has not decided which ticket its lawmakers will vote for in the legislative speaker and vice speaker elections.

After the outgoing TSU chairman hands over his post to the newly elected chairman Jan. 27, the party's Central Executive Committee will call a meeting that day to decide which ticket to vote for, Huang pointed out.

For his part, Yen Ching-piao, the chief convener of the Non-Partisan Solidarity Union (NPSU) legislative caucus, said that it is too early to talk about which ticket the party will support as candidates of the ruling and opposition parties for the speakership and vice speakership have yet to be determined.

The fifth legislature formally went into recess Jan. 21, and legislators-elect from the ruling and opposition parties will elect new speaker and vice speaker of the sixth legislature to be inaugurated Feb. 1.
Incumbent Speaker Wang Jin-pyng, who is the KMT's No. 1 legislator-at-large, is actively seeking support from lawmakers from across the political spectrum for re-election.

In the new 225-seat legislature, the ruling DPP will remain the largest party with 89 seats, followed by the KMT with 79 seats, the PFP with 34 seats and the TSU with 12 seats. The remaining seats belong to the NPSU and independents.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC WATCHFUL OF PRC DELEGATION'S VISITS TO HAITI, DOMINICAN REPUBLIC
DOC.DATELINE: Panama City, Jan. 22 (CNA) (By M.H. Huang and P.C. Tang)

TEXT.P: Personnel from the Republic of China's embassies in Haiti and the Dominican Republic are closely watching the activities of a visiting delegation from Beijing to these two Caribbean countries.

Headed by Cai Wu, deputy head of the Chinese Communist Party's International Liaison Department, the delegation, which is in Port-au-Prince for a two-day visit, has met with Premier Gerard Latortue and Minister of Foreign Affairs Yvon Simeon of the Haitian provisional government.

According to a political attache of the ROC Embassy in Haiti, the main purpose of the Chinese delegation in this part of the world is to attend an annual international socialist conference held in various Caribbean and Central and South American countries.

The official also said that Haitian provisional President Bonniface Alexandre has refused to receive the delegation and that his embassy is trying to get a better understanding of the details of the meetings held between the delegation and high-ranking Haitian officials.

As to Xinhua News Agency's report on Simeon's comments that "lacking the establishment of diplomatic relations between China and Haiti will not last long, " the attache said that he does not believe that the Haitian foreign minister made the remarks, adding that basically, the Haitian provisional government has no power to establish or to severe diplomatic relations with other countries.

He also admitted that the ROC Embassy in Haiti could not prevent China from sending delegations to inspect its peacekeeping troops stationed in the Caribbean country, adding that Beijing Ambassador to the United Nations Wang Quang-yi also visited Haiti in mid-December last year.
Meanwhile, the ROC's new ambassador to Haiti is expected to arrive in the country Sunday and will probably present his credentials to the Haitian provisional president Jan. 27 or 28.

The delegation is scheduled to leave for the Dominican Republic Jan. 24 and during the visit will meet with leading members of main Dominican Republic political parties. According to the ROC Embassy in Santo Domingo, Beijing sent two delegations and a cultural group to visit the country earlier this month.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP TO DECIDE ON SPEAKER, DEPUTY SPEAKER CANDIDATES WEDNESDAY

TEXT.P: The legislative caucus of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) will hold a meeting Wednesday to discuss its ticket for the new Legislative Yuan's speaker and deputy speaker elections, acting DPP Chairman Ker Chien-ming said Sunday.
The new legislature will begin Feb. 1 when all the 225 newly sworn-in lawmakers will also elect among themselves a speaker and deputy speaker.
Ker said he is consulting leading figures of various DPP factions to seek their opinions about the party's candidates for the two top legislative posts.
"We hope to reach an intraparty consensus on the ticket through consultations. Otherwise, the DPP caucus will hold a primary vote to decide on the ticket," Ker said.

Theoretically, Ker said, incumbent DPP Secretary-General Chang Chun-hsiung, who will be a legislator-at large in the new legislature, is the party's top choice for the speaker post. Nevertheless, he said, Chang's candidacy is still pending the caucus' final discussion.
As to the candidate for deputy speaker, Ker said a primary vote by all caucus members may have to be held.

The DPP, which will have 89 seats in the new legislature, originally hoped to forge a working partnership with the opposition People First Party (PFP), which controls 34 seats, to facilitate the implementation of its reform agenda. Some DPP lawmakers previously proposed a DPP-PFP ticket for the speaker and deputy speaker elections. However, the hope for a DPP-PFP coalition has dimmed after the PFP caucus announced that it will cooperate with its traditional "pan-blue" ally of the Kuomintang (KMT), who has 79 seats in the new legislature in the speaker and deputy speaker elections.

The PFP caucus has thrown support behind the re-election bid of incumbent Legislative Yuan President Wang Jin-pyng, who is also a KMT vice chairman, but it has yet to decide on its candidate for deputy speaker.

DPP sources claimed that some KMT members are still hopeful that incumbent Legislative Yuan Vice President P. K. Chiang can remain at his post. If the "pan-blue alliance" cannot consolidate its internal unity, the sources said, the DPP still stands a chance of winning the deputy speaker post.
Tsai Huang-liang, a DPP caucus whip, said the DPP is continuing to woo the PFP to cooperate in the speaker and deputy speaker elections.

"We'll not give up our efforts until Jan. 31. We are even willing to support a PFP-DPP ticket, " Tsai said, adding that if the PFP is willing to cooperate, the DPP doesn't rule out supporting a PFP candidate for speaker.
Moreover, Tsai said the DPP is also seeking to cooperate with the Taiwan Solidarity Union and the Non-Partisan Solidarity Union in the deputy speaker election.

DOC.HEADLINE: ANOTHER SECTION OF KEELUNG RIVER DREDGING WORK COMPLETED

TEXT.P: Improvements along a stretch of the Keelung River in Sichi township in Taipei County have been completed to prevent flooding, with Premier Yu Shyi-kun presided over a completion ceremony Sunday.

Yu sang the praises of President Chen Shui-bian's ruling team, saying that this, the 11th stage of an ambitious program to prevent flooding along the Keelung River, highlights the effectiveness of Chen's administration.

The nation's sound civil service system has made it possible for the government to carry out various construction projects after the power transition from the Kuomintang (KMT) to the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) , Yu pointed out. Yu said if the ruling and opposition parties can cooperate on major projects such as this one, Taiwan's overall competitive edge will be enhanced.

The former KMT government failed to solve the flooding problems of the Keelung River, but the DPP administration earmarked a special budget of NT$31.6 billion (US$9.8 billion) in 2003 to complete the flood prevention project within two years, Yu added.
After the project is completed, it will prevent floods from the Keelung River in the greater Taipei area for up to 200 years, Yu claimed.

Also present at the ceremony were Su Tseng-chang, secretary-general of the Presidential Office; Ho Mei-yueh, minister of economic affairs; and Kuo Yao-chi, chairwoman of the Cabinet-level Public Construction Commission.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP TO NOMINATE BEST CANDIDATES FOR LOCAL GOVERNMENT HEAD ELECTIONS

TEXT.P: The ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) will nominate the best candidates to vie for local government heads as the year-end mayoral and magistrate elections are quite important for the party, Presidential Office Secretary-General Su Tseng-chang said Sunday.

Su's remarks came in response to media reports that President Chen Shui-bian is planning to invite several outgoing government officials in charge of administrative affairs to run in the elections for mayors and county magistrates after the Cabinet resign en masse Monday.

According to Su, nominating DPP candidates to participate in the upcoming mayoral and county magistrate elections will be one of his most important tasks after he takes up the DPP chairmanship. Su is the sole candidate in the by-election for DPP chairman to be held Jan. 30 after President Chen resigned from the post to assume responsibility for the party's worse-than-expected performance in the Dec. 11 legislative elections.
As for Chen's plan to encourage outgoing Cabinet members to run, Su said this will be up to whether these officials are accepted by local voters or not.

If the DPP's local chapters can recommend prominent candidates to run in the year-end elections, the party will respect their decisions, Su noted. For the constituencies where DPP candidates are relatively weak, the DPP will consider recruiting outgoing Cabinet members to join the year-end elections, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN LOOKS FORWARD TO CLOSER OIL COOPERATION WITH CHAD: PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Sunday the Republic of China looks forward to expanding petroleum exploration cooperation with Chad.
Chen made the remarks while holding talks with visiting Chadian President Idriss Deby at the Presidential Office.
Chad formally became an oil exporting country in October 2003 and has signed a memorandum of understanding with Taiwan on cooperation in oil exploration and petrochemical development.
Chen said he is hopeful that Deby can assist in furthering Taiwan-Chadian cooperation in petroleum exploration.
Deby arrived in Taipei earlier in the day for a three-day state visit. This is his third visit to Taiwan since assuming the Chadian presidency.

Before their meeting at the Presidential Office, Chen presided over a welcoming ceremony at the Chiang Kai-shek Memorial Hall complex in downtown Taipei in honor of Deby. The Chadian leader was accorded full military honors in the ceremony, including a 21-gun salute.

Addressing the ceremony, Chen said that Sunday happened to be Freedom Day in Taiwan. Deby's arrival on Freedom Day symbolizes that the cordial relationship between Taiwan and Chad is based on their shared values in freedom and democracy.
Chen also lauded Deby for his contributions to helping resolve armed conflicts in the Darfur region in Sudan to promote stability in Africa.

During his current visit, Deby will travel to Kaoshiung to visit a marine base and Chinese Petroleum Corp.'s refinery in southern Taiwan. He will also visit major cultural and economic institutions in northern Taiwan and meet with local business and industry leaders.

Relations between Taiwan and Chad have been cordial since the two countries resumed full diplomatic ties in 1997. President Chen headed a large entourage to visit the central African ally in August 2000.
Deby has on many occasions spoken out in support of Taiwan's bid to join the United Nations, the World Health Organization and other major international organizations.

DOC.HEADLINE: STUDY BIGGEST SOURCE OF STRESS FOR YOUNG STUDENTS: ANALYSIS

TEXT.P: Having to study is the biggest source of stress for school children on both sides of the Taiwan Strait according to children's paintings analyzed by the John Jung Foundation.

"This is the finding of a painting contest participated in by elementary school children in Taiwan's greater Taipei area and Ningpo City in mainland China's Zhejiang province, " said Huang Chen-tai, executive director of the John Tung Foundation, a non-profit group dedicated to promoting public health.

The foundation held the painting contest between July and October 2004, with entrants required to depict their mood and ways to ease their depression or ill feelings. The foundation collected 1,582 paintings by school children in Taipei City and Taipei County as well as 564 by their Ningpo counterparts.
It marked the first time that the foundation has held a cross-strait cooperative program to promote mental health education.
Analyzing the works, Huang said the entries demonstrated interesting cultural diversities resulting from different living environments, languages and lifestyles.

Nevertheless, he said, all the works indicated that academic study is the top source of stress for young students; followed by worries about being scolded by parents due to poor exam scores or having to learn various skills.

The contest also found that Taiwan students' paintings were more colorful and more imaginative, while mainland students' works were mostly in monotone and dull colors and more realistic in their expression.

DOC.HEADLINE: OUTGOING JUSTICE MINISTER FORMALLY ANNOUNCES BID FOR TOP ILAN POST

TEXT.P: Minister of Justice Chen Ding-nan formally announced his bid Sunday to run for the magistrate post in his home county of Ilan in the year-end election.
Chen made the announcement at a news conference held at the Ilan County Hall in the company of incumbent Ilan Magistrate Liu Shou-cheng whose second term will expire late this year.

The clean-image minister said he is determined to return to Ilan to prepare for the year-end election after he joins with Prime Minister Yu Shyi-kun and other Cabinet members in tendering resignations en masse Monday.
Chen said his decision is a response to calls from his supporters to run again for the post he served in from 1981 to 1989.

"I couldn't ignore the repeated appeals from my supporters at home for me to lead them in developing Ilan," Chen said, adding that Ilan will face great challenges with the inauguration of the Peiyi Expressway at the end of this year.

Noting that the expressway, which will shorten the driving time between Taipei and Ilan to about 40 minutes from the current more than two hours, will bring both opportunities and challenges to Ilan, Chen said he feels compelled to run for the county's top post again to lead it to a brighter future.

Chen has been in his current post for four years and eight months. As the general public do not fully understand the power and functions of the Ministry of Justice (MOJ) , Chen said some people have mistakenly taken him to task for many judicial and social problems.

In Taiwan, Chen said, the MOJ is just responsible for investigation of official corruption, vote-buying and criminal cases. The ministry is not empowered to try criminal suspects or maintain public order, Chen said, adding that he hopes his successor will no longer face the similar broadsides heaped on him.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. SCHOLARS CALL FOR WORLD ATTENTION TO TAIWAN PEOPLE'S ASPIRATION
DOC.DATELINE: Los Angeles, Jan. 22 (CNA) (By Lu-sheng Chu and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: A group of U.S. scholars said Saturday that the international community should not ignore Taiwan's nationalism simply because of the so-called "one China" policy.

The academics made the call at a "Taiwanese nationalism vs. Chinese nationalism" seminar, co-sponsored by the Taipei Economic and Cultural Office in Los Angeles and the Center for Chinese Studies at the University of California - Los Angeles.

It marked the first time that an American academic institution has ever organized a seminar to address the cross-Taiwan Strait issues in light of their people's feelings, sentiments, historical developments and contemporary national and social situations.

Richard Baum, director of Center for Chinese Studies, presided over the seminar held at the UCLA's Bunche Hall. The participants included Prof. Stanley Rosen of the University of Southern California, Prof. Edward Friedman of the University of Wisconsin and Prof. Peter Gries of the University of Colorado. Chang Mao-kuei, a research fellow at Academia Sinica, Taiwan's top research body, also traveled from Taipei to Los Angeles to attend the symposium.

The participants agreed that the international community should pay heed to Taiwan people's opinion and aspiration for freedom and democracy as well as their sense of Taiwanese identity separate from China's.

In the face of mainland China's plan to enact a so-called anti-secession law targeting Taiwan, Rosen said Taiwan should step up international publicity to let the world understand that Beijing's move could lead to regional instability.

DOC.HEADLINE: ABUSED GIRL DONATES ORGANS AFTER BEING PRONOUNCED 'BRAIN DEAD'

TEXT.P: The 4-year-old girl who was refused admission to a series of Taipei hospitals after being critically injured by her abusive father two weeks ago died at a Taichung County hospital in central Taiwan Sunday.

With the consent of her family, the girl, surnamed Chiu, donated her organs after being pronounced "brain dead" earlier in the day. Her kidneys were transplanted to a 55-year-old woman at Taichung Veterans Hospital, while her liver has been sent to Kaohsiung Chang Gung Memorial Hospital in southern Taiwan for transplant to any suitable patient.

The girl's body was transported back to Taipei under the escort of Chang Hang, director of the Taipei municipal health department, and Hsueh Cheng-tai, director of the municipal bureau of social affairs.
Chang said Chiu's ordeal highlighted many flaws and deficiencies in Taiwan's medical system and alerted the central and local governments to take necessary steps to plug the holes.

"We'll not let the girl die in vain. We have worked out 10 measures, including strengthening the hospital transfer network in the emergency medical system to prevent recurrence of a similar tragedy," Chang said.

The girl was first rushed to the Taipei Municipal Jen Ai Hospital Jan. 10, but a neurosurgeon didn't bother to examine her brain injuries while insisting on having the girl transferred to other hospitals for a surgery on the excuse that Jen Ai's ICU ward was already fully occupied.

The girl ended up being transported to a hospital more than 100 kilometers away in the central county of Taichung for surgery. After 14 days of intensive care, the condition of the comatose girl didn't improve and she was declared "brain dead" through a complicated medical procedures.
Chiu's ordeal had triggered an uproar which led to an investigation into why the 4-year-old was refused treatment when there were sufficient bed in Taipei hospitals.
The Cabinet-level Department of Health announced Friday that it would make changes to the existing system for patient transfers. The new system will take effect in June.

DOC.HEADLINE: KAOHSIUNG MAYOR TO BE NEW PREMIER

TEXT.P: Kaohsiung Mayor Frank Hsieh will be new premier after the current Cabinet resigns en masse, ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) sources said Sunday.

Premier Yu Shyi-kun will hold a provisional Cabinet meeting Monday when he will announce the Cabinet's resignation en masse to pave the way for the formation of a new Cabinet ahead of the inauguration of a new Legislative Yuan Feb. 1.

DPP sources said Hsieh will succeed Yu as premier. According to the sources, the Cabinet will be partially reshuffled and another round of reshuffle may take place around May 20 to coincide with the first anniversary of President Chen Shui-bian's second term.

Meanwhile, Presidential Office sources said President Chen is not expected to formally announce Yu's successor Monday. Chen may hold a news conference in the next couple of days to announce Hsieh's appointment as new premier, the sources said.

DOC.HEADLINE: KAOHSIUNG GIRL RECEIVES LIVER FROM ABUSED CHILD DECLARED BRAIN DEAD
DOC.DATELINE: Kaohsiung, southern Taiwan, Jan. 24 (CNA) (By Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: A 6-year-old girl in Kaoshiung successfully underwent liver transplant surgery Monday with a liver donated from the four-year-old child who died Sunday after being in a coma for two weeks following a severe beating from her father.

In a nearly seven-hour operation, surgeons at Kaohsiung Chang Gung Memorial Hospital transplanted the liver donated from the child, surnamed Chiu, who was declared "brain dead" after a complicated medical procedure Sunday. The liver recipient is now recovering in the hospital's intensive care unit.

The family of the 4-year-old Chiu agreed Sunday to donate her organs after the child was pronounced "brain dead" by the staff of the Tung's Taichung MetroHaror Hospital, where the abused child had been treated over the past two weeks after being refused admission to several hospitals in Taipei.
Chiu's father has been arrested on charges of child abuse, while a number of medical professionals and officials in Taipei have been disciplined for negligence.
Meanwhile, a 55-year-old woman at Taichung Veterans Hospital successfully underwent kidney transplant surgery with a kidney donated by the ill-fated child.

Chiu's body was escorted back to Taipei Sunday by Chang Hang, director of the Taipei City Department of Health, who resigned as a result of the public outcry over the abused child being denied admission to several hospitals in Taipei in the first crucial hours.
Chiu's ordeal highlighted the flaws and deficiencies in Taiwan's medical system and alerted the central and local governments to take necessary steps to plug the holes.
The tragedy triggered an uproar which led to judicial investigations into why the child was refused treatment when there were sufficient beds in the Taipei hospitals.

"We won't let the girl's death be in vain, " Chang said. "We have worked out 10 measures, including strengthening the hospital transfer network in the emergency medical system, to prevent a recurrence of this tragedy."
The Cabinet-level Department of Health announced last Friday that it would make changes to the existing system for patient transfers. The new system will take effect in June.
