The opposition leader was accused of desperation for his personal pledge to restrict immigration to Britain, to be presented in a speech today as a Tory vote-winner.
Financial Times: Centreal Banks shift funds away from US.
Central banks are shifting reserves away from the US and towards the eurozone in a move that looks set to deepen the Bush administration's difficulties in financing its ballooning current account deficit.
In actions likely to undermine the dollar's value on currency markets, 70 percent of central bank reserve managers said they had increased their exposure to the euro over the past two years. The majority thought eurozone money and debt markets were as attractive a destination for investment as the US.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC HEAD EXPLAINS TAIWAN'S MAINLAND POLICY ON C-SPAN PROGRAM
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Jan. 23 (CNA) (By Oliver Lin and P.C.Tang)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's top official for mainland affairs said Sunday that the agreement on direct cross-strait flights for the Lunar New Year holidays is significant, expressing the hope that Beijing would show similar flexibility to engage in cross-strait dialogue and to reduce tensions between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait.

Joseph Wu, chairman of Mainland Affairs Council (MAC), made the comments while explaining Taiwan's mainland policy in a call-in program that was broadcast live on C-Span, a public television channel with about 60 million viewers.

Wu, who is the first Taiwanese official to appear on the program in recent years, said that the Lunar New Year holiday cross-strait flights will represent the first time since 1949 for airlines from both sides of the Taiwan Strait to launch direct charter flight services across the strait.

In negotiations held Jan. 15 in Macau, representatives from Taipei and Beijing reached an agreement to allow airlines from Taiwan and the mainland to fly into each other's territory from Jan. 29 to Feb. 20 to serve China-based Taiwanese businesspeople and their families.

Asked why Beijing agreed to the launching of direct cross-strait flights, the MAC head said that Taiwan had invited the mainland several times since last October to hold negotiations on the launching of direct charter flights and that Beijing had eventually realized that such services would help reduce cross-strait tensions.

The requests by China-based Taiwanese businesspeople and their families who want to return to Taiwan during the Lunar New Year holidays and the encouragement by the United States to engage in a cross-strait dialogue were also factors that led Beijing to sign the agreement, Wu further said.

Touching on issues relating to the mainland's retaining of the option of the use of force against Taiwan, the MAC chairman said that Beijing has continued to try to intimidate Taiwan, including raising a proposal to enact an anti-secession.

Beijing also recently released a national defense white paper threatening to crush Taiwan, Wu continued, adding that therefore, cross-strait tensions remain high and that the best way to reduce such tensions is for the two sides to engage in dialogue and to increase mutual understanding.

DOC.HEADLINE: MANDATORY MILITARY SERVICE TO BE SHORTENED TO 18 MONTHS

TEXT.P: The Executive Yuan announced Monday that the period of mandatory military service will be shortened from the current 22 months to 18 months, effective July 1.

This was one of the new policies announced by the Executive Yuan at its last meeting before Premier Yu Shyi-kun led the Cabinet to resign en masse Monday ahead of the start of the new legislature Feb. 1.

During the meeting, Vice Minister of National Defense Tsai Ming-hsien announced that under a conscription system reform program, the mandatory military service period will be shortened and salaries for conscripts will be increased while recruitment of volunteer soldiers will be accelerated in the years to come.
Tsai said that under the program, the period of mandatory military service is expected to be further shortened to 12 months by 2008.
Under the program, he added, it is hoped that a ratio of three volunteer soldiers to two conscripts will be achieved in three years.

The minister said the Ministry of National Defense has been studying the feasibility of shortening the mandatory military service period in two stages in tandem with the gradual implementation of an all-volunteer military service system.
Meanwhile, Tsai said, the monthly salary for those doing their military service will be raised to an average of NT$35,000 (US$1,094) as the program is being implemented, Tsai said.

Currently, the monthly salary for those joining the trial voluntary military service program, which began to be implemented in 2003, is about NT$27,000, or about the same as that for any civilian beginning their first job, and therefore offers no incentive to young men to join the military. This is probably one of the reasons why the trial voluntary military service program has not been as popular as was expected.

The Ministry of National Defense will also assist these people to acquire professional training and obtain related certificates during the military service period so as to allow them to be well-prepared to enter the civilian job market when they leave the military, Tsai added.
Furthermore, Tsai said, the maximum age for mandatory military service will also be lowered from the current 40 to 35.

Tsai said that the planned shortening of the period of mandatory service will not undermine the military's overall combat capabilities as modern warfare stresses "beyond-vision" and "no-contact" combat strategies, adding that the military needs to recruit more professional or career soldiers instead of conscripts.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CHEN PUSHES FOR TAIWAN, PARAGUAY FREE TRADE PACT

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian once again expressed his eagerness Monday to see Taiwan and Paraguay sign a free trade agreement (FTA) to further bolster bilateral business ties between the two diplomatic allies.
Chen said that if necessary, he would travel to the Paraguayan capital of Asuncion in person to sign the FTA with Paraguayan President Nicanor Duarte Frutos.
The president made the remarks when he was meeting with visiting Paraguayan Vice President Luis Alberto Castiglioni Soria and his wife at the Presidential Office.
Chen expressed appreciation for President Duarte's support voiced at the United Nations last September for Taiwan's bid to join the organization and other world bodies.

Chen also expressed his admiration for President Duarte's attending his second-term inauguration May 20 last year, saying that Duarte was the first leader of a Republic of China ally to visit after he won re-election.
He and Duarte pledged at that time to promote the signing of an FTA between the two countries, the president said.

Chen expressed the hope earlier this month that he could travel to Paraguay this year to sign the FTA. The president voiced his hope when he bestowed the Order of Brilliant Star with Special Grand Cordon upon visiting speaker of the Paraguayan House of Representatives Oscar Ruben Salomon Fernandez.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHO JUNG-TAI TO SERVE AS CABINET'S SECRETARY-GENERAL

TEXT.P: Cho Jung-tai, deputy secretary-general to the Presidential Office, is expected to serve as the secretary-general of the Executive Yuan, an unidentified source close to the situation said Monday.
The source made the remarks after Premier Yu Shyi-kun led the Cabinet to resign en masse Monday with Kaohsiung Mayor Frank Hsieh expected to head the new Cabinet.
Cho's appointment came as no surprise as he is a protege of Hsieh and has experience as the deputy secretary-general of the Presidential Office.
It has yet to be decided who will take over the posts of vice premier and spokesman of the Executive Yuan.

The Cabinet reshuffle is not expected to be extensive, especially for those in the Cabinet who have been tapped as candidates of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) for the year-end magistrate and mayoral elections. They will remain in the Cabinet to stay in the public eye.

It is expected that only after the DPP completes nominating candidates for the year-end magistrate and mayoral elections in May that the political appointees will then resign to focus on campaigning. There will be a second reshuffle then and the scale is expected to be bigger.

DOC.HEADLINE: EIGHT AIR CARRIERS HAVE APPLIED FOR HOLIDAY CHARTER FLIGHTS

TEXT.P: As of Monday morning, eight air carriers from the two sides of the Taiwan Strait have applied to operate direct cross-strait charter flights during the Chinese Lunar New Year holiday, the Civil Aeronautic Administration said.

The air carriers are mainland-based Shanghai Airlines, Xiamen Airlines, China Southern Airlines, China Eastern Airlines, as well as Taiwan-based EVA Airlines, China Airlines, UNI Air, and Mandarin Airlines.

A charter flight from China Southern Airlines will depart from Guangzhou at 8 a.m. Jan. 29 and arrive at CKS International Airport at 9: 30 a.m., becoming the first charter plane from the mainland to arrive at the airport.

Meanwhile, TransAsia Airways, which is expected to apply for the flights but has yet to do so, is reportedly considering shifting some charter flight services from Guangzhou to Shanghai because of greater demand.
The charter flights will run from Jan. 29 through Feb. 20.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER YU TO TAKE UP PREVIOUS POST AS PRESIDENT'S CHIEF OF STAFF

TEXT.P: Outgoing Premier Yu Shyi-kun will serve as President Chen Shui-bian's chief of staff, a post that Yu once held before assuming the premiership Feb. 1, 2002, reliable political sources said Monday.

Yu and all Cabinet members resigned en masse Monday after holding the Cabinet's last meeting. The resignation paves the way for the formation of a new Cabinet ahead of the inauguration of a new Legislative Yuan Feb. 1.
The Presidential Office is scheduled to hold a news conference Tuesday to announce who will succeed Yu as premier. It is almost definite that Kaohsiung Mayor Frank Hsieh will get the nod.

Since Yu has been one of President Chen's confidants, political sources said Yu will return to the post as Chen's chief of staff, also known as the Presidential Office secretary-general, after stepping down from the premiership.

Yu won't be the first presidential chief of staff to return to the post after having served as premier, the sources said. During Taiwan's martial law era, Chang Chun served as then-President Chiang Kai-shek's chief of staff before becoming premier.

After leaving the premiership, Chang again served as Chiang's chief of staff, the sources said. To accommodate Chang, Chiang upgraded the post of the presidential secretary-general to the level of the premier and chiefs of the four other central government branches -- the Legislative Yuan, the Judicial Yuan, the Control Yuan and the Examination Yuan.

DOC.HEADLINE: CABINET RESIGNS EN MASSE

TEXT.P: Premier Yu Shyi-kun led his Cabinet in resigning en masse Monday, paving the way for a reshuffle in line with the formation of a new legislature on Feb. 1.

On tendering the resignation en masse in a special Cabinet meeting, Yu said this day marks the perfect conclusion for his three-year term and that it is his great honor to have had the chance to lead the Cabinet team in contributing to the country.

Yu noted that the efforts made by the Cabinet team helped the ruling Democratic Progressive Party and President Chen Shui-bian win last year's presidential election, saying the contribution of his Cabinet will be remembered in history.
Yu said Taiwan has survived a global economic recession and also endured an unprecedented period of political turmoil under the leadership of his Cabinet.

While the country's economic growth rate, foreign reserves and budget execution rate have been rising over the past three years, the unemployment rate, overdue loans of local banks and workplace fatalities have been declining, Yu pointed out.
For example, Yu said, the economic growth rate jumped from minus 2.22 percent in 2001 to the projected 5.93 percent in 2004, the highest level in seven years.
The unemployment rate, meanwhile, fell to 4.44 percent in 2004, the lowest since 2001, and the average working population also hit a 10-year high, Yu added.
Also, the country's overall competitiveness has continued to rise and this achievement has been recognized in various international assessments, he said.
In addition, Yu noted, his Cabinet has put forth a series of innovative plans such as the "challenge 2008" national development project and "10 major construction projects."
The meeting was attended by all Cabinet members with the exception of Minister of Foreign Affairs Tan Sun Chen and Mainland Affairs Council Chairman Joseph Wu.

After the meeting, a group photo was taken of the attending Cabinet members at the gate of the Executive Yuan and Yu gave a brief farewell speech in which he thanked his colleagues and the public for their support over the past three years.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI SHARE PRICES END LOWER

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange opened up but closed lower Monday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving down 77.43 points to close at 5,771.48.
The bourse opened at 5,859.89 and fluctuated between 5,862.62 and 5,763.84 during trading. A total of 2.61 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$47.07 billion (US$1.47 billion).

All eight major stock categories lost ground, with textile stocks moving down the most at 2.8 percent, followed by foodstuff issues at 2.4 percent, paper and pulp issues at 2.2 percent, construction issues at 1.9 percent, machinery and electronics shares at 1.5 percent, banking and financial shares at 1.4 percent, cement stocks at 1.2 percent and plastics and chemicals shares at 0.4 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 743 to 91, with 115 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: TUNA BOAT MAY HAVE BEEN COMMANDEERED BY MUTINEERS

TEXT.P: A Kaohsiung-based tuna fishing boat that was reported missing Jan. 12, is believed to have been commandeered by Chinese deckhands who mutinied.

A representative for Tongsong Fishing Company -- owner of the "Tongyi No. 668" -- who flew to Malaysia to look into the incident said Monday that the tuna fishing boat was intercepted by a Malaysian navy frigate Sunday because the ship was sailing erratically near Malaysian territorial waters.
The officers and crew of the "Tongyi No. 668" are currently being interrogated in Malaysia and further information is not known, the representative said.

According to the representative, "Tongyi No. 668" Captain Chen Kuo-ching telephoned the company and his family in Kaohsiung to tell them that he is safe, except for some minor injuries sustained during a struggle with the mutineers.
The representative said that his company is grateful to the Malaysian navy for intercepting the vessel before things got out of control.
He quoted Chen as saying that three other officers on board also sustained minor injuries during the incident, but they are all fine.
Twenty-four other deckhands on the tuna fishing boat are either mainland Chinese or Filipino nationals.
The 493-ton tuna fishing vessel with 28 crew members aboard lost communications Jan. 12 while fishing about 700 nautical miles off the west coast of the Maldives.
The "Tongyi No. 668" was spotted sailing by the British Chagos Islands Jan. 15 toward the two Southeast Asian countries of Indonesia and Singapore, according to a spokesman for the fishing company.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES LOWER ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were lower Monday as the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for February lost 64 points to close at 5,805, with 31,954 contracts changing hands.
TAIEX Index futures for March lost 55 points to finish at 5,805, with 247 contracts traded, while June futures lost 69 points to close at 5,795, with 30 contracts traded.
September futures lost 85 points to close at 5,710, with 25 contracts traded, while December futures moved down 83 points to end at 5,700, with seven contract transactions.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Monday at 5,869 for February, 5,860 for March, 5,864 for June, 5,795 for September and 5,783 for December.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were lower.

February TE futures moved down three points to close at 213.5, with 3,592 contracts traded, while March TE futures lost three points to finish at 213, with 44 contract transactions. June TE futures moved down 0.2 points to finish at 215.9, with 10 contracts traded, while September TE futures lost 1.75 points to close at 216.3, with 10 contract transactions. December TE futures moved down 3.05 points to end at 216.3 with 10 contracts changing hands.

February TF futures lost 13.2 points to finish at 990.6, with 3,326 contracts changing hands, while March TF futures moved down 12.8 points to finish at 990, with 140 contracts traded. June TF futures lost 9.6 points to end at 991, with 12 contract transactions, while September TF futures remained unchanged at 994, with 10 contract changing hands. December TF futures moved down 0.2 points to finish at 1,001, with 10 contract changing hands.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT EMPLOYEES TO GET 3 PERCENT PAY RAISE FROM JANUARY 1

TEXT.P: Government employees will receive a pay raise of 3 percent this year from Jan. 1, 2005, retroactively, government sources said Monday.

About NT$16.71 billion (US$522 million) will be required for the pay raise for fiscal year 2005 for all government employees in the country, which include armed forces personnel, public functionaries and teachers, said Lee Yi-yang, director-general of the Central Personnel Administration.

The raise rate was decided at 3 percent after the Central Personnel Administration examining financial and economic situations at home and referring to similar practices in various countries abroad, Lee said.

The pay raise marked the last "red envelope" that outgoing Premier Yu Shyi-kun awarded to the country's civil servants before leaving office. Yu led the Cabinet to resign en masse Monday ahead of the start of the new legislature Feb. 1.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. DOLLAR DOWN ON TAIPEI FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar lost ground against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Monday, dropping NT$0.083 to close at NT$31.830.
A total of US$502 million changed hands during the day's trading.
The greenback opened at NT$31.913 and fluctuated between NT$31.800 and NT$32.027.

DOC.HEADLINE: BOFT PLANS SEMINAR TO HELP TAIWAN COMPANIES EXPLORE MAINLAND MARKET

TEXT.P: The Bureau of Foreign Trade (BOFT) under the Ministry of Economic Affairs is slated to host a seminar Jan. 31 to help Taiwan companies explore the mainland's retail market, a bureau spokesman said Monday.

Legal experts will be invited to explain mainland China's relevant laws and regulations and to elaborate on the risks and details involved in the retail and distribution sectors. The seminar is open to domestic businesses interested in expanding into the promising market.

The BOFT move came after the mainland authorities allowed the establishment of foreign-owned enterprises in the two sectors and some specially authorized businesses since December of last year, an opening that is expected to yield many business opportunities for Taiwan companies, he said.
Backed by a high flying economy, mainland China surged to become the world's third-largest economy last year, with foreign trade of US$1.1 trillion, he added.

Two-way trade between Taiwan and the mainland is estimated to have been more than US$60 billion in 2004, with about 90 percent of the businesses centering on industrial goods and raw materials, he said, noting that Taiwan's shipment of daily consumer products to mainland China accounted for a very small percentage.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP LAWMAKER TRONG CHAI TO RUN FOR LEGISLATIVE SPEAKER

TEXT.P: Ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Legislator Trong Chai announced Monday his decision to run for the speakership of the Legislative Yuan.
Chai made public his bid after DPP Secretary-General Chang Chun-hsiung said earlier that day that he would not run for the post.
Chang, who has been a legislator for 17 years, will return to the Legislative Yuan on Feb. 1 when he will be sworn in as a legislator at-large in the new legislature.
Chai said as the largest party in the legislature, the DPP must vie for the speakership and that he will try to win the support of the DPP legislative caucus.
According to Chai, President Chen Shui-bian is aware of his plan to run for the speakership and did not stop him from going ahead.
Chai said he has started to lobby the support of legislators from the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) and People First Party (PFP) but he would not disclose further details.
With the support of the KMT and its ally, the PFP, which together enjoy a slim majority in the legislature, two-term Speaker Wang Jin-pyng from the KMT is likely to secure the next speakership.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Moscow Times: Yushchenko Hails Victory Over Tyranny.
Parliament voted Thursday to hold President-elect Viktor Yushchenko's inauguration this coming Sunday, setting the stage for the transition to a new government for Ukraine following months of divisive political crisis.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Washington Post: Militant Declares War on Iraqi Vote; Zarqawi Terms Democracy an 'Evil Principle'.
The most feared and wanted militant in Iraq declared a "fierce war" against democracy Sunday and repeated a threat to disrupt national elections scheduled for next Sunday, the paper said.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP SECRETARY-GENERAL NOT TO RUN FOR SPEAKER OF LEGISLATURE

TEXT.P: Chang Chun-hsiung, secretary-general of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) , announced Monday that he will not run for speaker of the Legislative Yuan.
Chang said that since cooperation between the DPP and the opposition People First Party (PFP) for the race has fallen short of expectations, the premise for him to run for the post no longer exists.
Chang said that he will now devote himself to the good of the nation as an at-large legislator in the legislature, and will not run for any posts in the DPP legislative caucus.

Noting that after the Dec. 11 legislative elections, the opposition "pan-blue alliance" of the Kuomintang (KMT) and the PFP maintained its majority in the legislature, and pointing out how President Chen Shui-bian responded to public calls for party-to-party cooperation, Chang stressed that his candidacy for speaker would have been for "inter-party cooperation and political stability."

He said that the DPP had originally sought cooperation from the PFP, and even suggested a "PFP-DPP" ticket after PFP Chairman James Soong said in the United States that he would support the present speaker, Wang Jin-pyng, who is also a KMT vice chairman, for re-election.

Chang said that the party will respect the decision of the DPP legislative caucus on the speaker and vice speaker elections in the legislature, adding that once the DPP decides on party candidates or cooperation with other parties, all DPP legislators will toe the party line.

Meanwhile, Tsai Huang-liang, DPP caucus whip in the legislature, stressed that the DPP will not be absent from the speaker and vice speaker elections Feb. 1, and will have its own candidates, but will also not rule out the possibility of cooperating with other parties.
Tsai said that the DPP could cooperate with the Non-Partisan Solidarity Union, the Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU), or a "PFP-DPP" ticket.
The legislative caucus will meet Wednesday to decide on how inter-party cooperation could work and then consider nominating candidates.
Tsai said that although the DPP is now in an inferior position, it will not give up till the last moment, adding that "everything could still change."
Tsai also dismissed the allegation by the KMT that the DPP is trying to buy votes with NT$100 million (US$3.15 million) , adding that KMT Secretary-General Lin Feng-cheng is "talking nonsense."
The DPP is currently the largest party in the legislature with 89 seats, while the KMT trails with 79 seats. The PFP has 34 seats and the TSU 12.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN RANKS FIFTH IN WEALTH OF DEVELOPING COUNTRIES RATINGS
DOC.DATELINE: Bangkok, Jan. 24 (CNA) (By Wu Hsieh-chang and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan ranks fifth in a national wealth rating of developing countries compiled by the World Paper and Money Matters Institute, up a notch from a year ago.

The Wealth of Nations Triangle Index has been issued annually since 1996. It measures the balanced development potential of 70 developing countries around the world in terms of three subindexes -- economic environment, social environment and information exchanges -- on the premise that sustainable growth is dependent on balance. With a total of 63 variables, 21 variables in each of the three subindexes are gauged.
In the newly released 2004 Wealth of Nations Triangle Index, Taiwan ranked fifth with a total score of 1,816, marking a notch up from the 2003 rating.

South Korea ranked top in the 2003 survey, but dropped two notches to third place in the 2004 rating. South Korea and Taiwan were the only two Asian developing countries to make the top 10 list for 2004.

Slovenia topped the 2004 rating followed by Israel, South Korea, the Czech Republic, Taiwan, Estonia, Hungary, the Slovak Republic, Lithuania, and Latvia, in that order. Seven of the top 10 nations were East European countries.

Mainland China ranked 27th, up seven notches from the 2003 rating. In terms of the economic environment index, mainland China ranked sixth, higher than Slovenia's and Taiwan's rankings, but its social environment rating was very low.

DOC.HEADLINE: TSU TO PUSH FOR AMENDMENT TO DOMESTIC VIOLENCE LAW

TEXT.P: Amending the Anti-Domestic Violence Law to better protect the citizens of Taiwan is a priority for the Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) in the upcoming legislature, a TSU official said Monday.

Citing Ministry of the Interior statistics, Chiang Yue-chin, who heads the TSU's department of women's affairs, said at a news conference at TSU headquarters that there have been over 30,000 cases of domestic violence each year in recent years.

Of these, the number of those concerning child abuse accounted for 6.3 percent, Chiang said. Moreover, she also cited other statistics released by private organizations concerning women's and children's welfare, saying that each year more than 18,000 children in Taiwan are victims of domestic violence.
The figures showed domestic violence has expanded into a serious social problem, to which the entire Taiwan community should pay close attention and seek resolutions, the TSU official said.
Chiang said that there is insufficient recourse for victims; for example, there is currently no special unit in most law enforcement agencies specifically tasked with dealing with the issue.
Therefore, Chiang said, the TSU will push to amend the existing Anti-Domestic Violence Law in the Legislative Yuan. The law was enacted on June 24, 1998.

On Sunday, a four-year-old girl, who was refused admission to a series of Taipei hospitals after being critically injured by her abusive father two weeks ago, died at a Taichung County hospital in central Taiwan. The tragedy raised a public outcry against domestic violence.

DOC.HEADLINE: COMPULSORY LANGUAGE TRAINING CALLED FOR FOREIGN SPOUSES

TEXT.P: Chinese language teachers in northern Taoyuan County have come to an agreement that the central government should impose compulsory language training on foreign spouses to help them better blend in with local society.

The teachers made the call last weekend at a meeting with education officials of Taoyuan County, suggesting that the central government take the step to help foreign husbands and wives strengthen their Chinese language abilities as a requirement for them to get Taiwan ID cards and get accustomed to their domestic lifestyles more quickly.
They claimed that doing so will help reduce waste of educational resources and would be good for foreign spouses to better deal with their children.

Statistics compiled this month by the Ministry of Education show that around 46,000 children born to mixed couples are receiving elementary and secondary education in Taiwan -- more than 40,000 in elementary schools and about 5,500 in junior high schools.
In Taoyuan County, there have been more than 35,000 foreign spouses, with over 2,000 children born to marriages of Taiwan nationals and foreigners per year.
Starting this year, the county authorities will offer more intensive language-learning classes and courses in history, geography, religion and folk customs for foreign husbands and wives.
The industrial-intensive Taoyuan is Taiwan's second-largest county in terms of population, only after neighboring Taipei County.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC MINISTERS EXPRESS CONCERN ABOUT SOCIAL ORDER IN SOUTH AFRICA
DOC.DATELINE: Johannesburg, Jan. 24 (CNA) (By Liu Cheng-ching and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: Republic of China Foreign Affairs Minister Tan Sun Chen and Overseas Chinese Affairs Commission Minister Chang Fu-mei have expressed concern over the worsening social order in South Africa.
The two ministers expressed their concern in messages sent to a two-day seminar sponsored by ROC missions in South Africa over the weekend on the safety of Taiwan expatriates in South Africa.
They urged Taiwan expatriates to work closely with the South African government and police to work out measures to better protect their own safety.

According to Chang, due to the widening gap between the rich and the poor, rising unemployment, the abolition of the death penalty and various other factors, the crime rate in South Africa in recent years has risen rapidly.

Chang said she feels sorry that Taiwan expatriates, while working hard overseas, have to worry about safety of their lives and property, adding that her commission convened a meeting last December to exchange views on the matter.

Foreign Affairs Minister Chen urged Taiwan expatriates to establish a regional safeguard network and an emergency notification system so as to provide support in the shortest possible time in case of incidents.

Nearly 150 Taiwan expatriates took part in the seminar, five of whom spoke about their own experiences as victims of crime. South African parliamentarians, police chiefs and criminology professors and counselling experts were also invited to give their views on the prevention of crime, as well as on how to deal with being victimized.
ROC Representative to South Africa Richard Shih said that his office will compile the views of the participants and pass the information to Taiwan expatriates for reference.

DOC.HEADLINE: DIGITIZED BUS SERVICES IN KAOHSIUNG CITY INAUGURATED

TEXT.P: The Kaohsiung city government inaugurated bus services with digitized operations Monday, according to officials in the southern port city.

The city government spent around NT$40 million (US$1.257 million) building up the country's first digitized bus services, including 130 bus stop signs offering digital information, TV monitors in 448 buses that will play real-time programming and a bus hotline offering information to passengers.

According to Mayor Frank Hsieh, the city government intends to curb the rapid increase of scooters and motorcycles in the future by issuing only 30,000 new license plates each year to users in the hope that more people will use public transport.

DOC.HEADLINE: VICE PRESIDENT CRITICIZES LEGISLATURE FOR DISDAINING CONSTITUTION

TEXT.P: Vice President Annette Lu criticized the opposition-controlled legislature Monday for holding the Constitution in contempt over its refusal to exercise its consent on Control Yuan nominations during the just-concluded legislative session.

The nominations put forth by President Chen Shui-bian were shelved by the legislature owing to objections from the opposition Kuomintang and People First Party. The move will delay the scheduled inauguration of the ombudsmen, originally set for Feb. 1.

Lu told reporters it is distressing that the legislature has ignored its constitutional duty to consider the Control Yuan nominations, thereby caused a serious hiatus in the constitutional operation of the nation's top watchdog body.

Lu further blamed the legislature for delaying the passage of major legislation until the final two days of a session, saying the legislature should keep a monthly schedule on which bills it plans to review.
Lu said she hopes the administrative and legislative branches will observe their respective duties after the new Cabinet and legislature are sworn in Feb. 1.

Meanwhile, Lu expressed her regret and grief over the death of a severely abused four-year-old girl two weeks after she went into a coma after being refused admission to various Taipei hospitals and sent nearly 200 km away to Taichung for treatment.
Lu said people should learn from the tragedy and try to put a stop to domestic and marital violence.
She said the incident also exposed problems in the emergency operations of the medical sector, which require a detailed review for improvement.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The New York Times: Pentagon Sends Its Spies to Join Fight on Terror.
The Pentagon has created battlefield intelligence units to work on tasks that had been largely the province of the C.I.A.
Wall Street Journal: For GM and Fiat, A Messy Breakup Could Be in Works.
Nearly five years into a partnership they once touted as made in heaven, General Motors Corp. and Fiat SpA are in tense talks about a possible breakup that could further batter their finances and reverberate across the auto industry.

DOC.HEADLINE: PFP NOMINATES CHUNG JUNG-CHI TO RUN FOR DEPUTY SPEAKERSHIP

TEXT.P: A legislator at large-elect representing the opposition People First Party (PFP) will run for the new Legislative Yuan's deputy speaker post, the PFP legislative caucus announced Monday.

PFP legislators-elect held an intraparty primary earlier in the day to decide on who should represent the party to vie for the deputy speaker post. Three hopefuls -- Chung Jung-chi, Shen Chih-hwei and Lee Ching-hua -- joined the race and Chung emerged as the winner.

The PFP, originally a splinter group from the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) , will have 34 seats in the new legislature to be inaugurated Feb. 1. The PFP will cooperate with the KMT, which controls 79 seats in the new legislature, in running for the deputy speakership.

Immediately after winning the PFP nomination, Chung paid a visit to KMT headquarters to meet with incumbent Legislative Yuan President Wang Jin-pyng, who is also a KMT vice chairman, and KMT Secretary-General Lin Fong-cheng, to discuss winning strategies.
Wang has been campaigning to retain his speaker post in the past few weeks, traveling around the island to court the support of re-elected and newly-elected legislators.

Wang said he is hopeful that KMT Chairman Lien Chan and PFP Chairman James Soong will meet as soon as possible to work out joint campaign strategies to ensure a double victory in the speaker and deputy speaker elections. Soong is expected to return from a visit to the United States in the coming days.
Wang suggested that Chung visit legislators-elect of the KMT and the Non-Partisan Solidarity Union as soon as possible to seek their support.

Party sources said Wang is almost certain to win re-election as the KMT and the PFP jointly control a majority in the new legislature. As for Chung's deputy speakership bid, the sources said, it will depend on whether the two parties can consolidate unity within the alliance.

There have been reports that some KMT legislators-elect would prefer to support the re-election of incumbent Legislative Yuan Vice President P.K. Chiang, who is also a KMT vice chairman and who once served as minister of economic affairs and chairman for the Council for Economic Planning and Development.

The "pan-green camp" of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) and the Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) , which controls a total of 101 seats, has yet to unveil its ticket for the upcoming speaker and deputy speaker elections.

While DPP Secretary-General Chang Chun-hsiung, who will be a legislator-at large in the new legislature, ruled out running for speakership earlier in the day, veteran DPP Legislator Trong Chai later announced his intention to run for the top legislative post.

The DPP legislative caucus is scheduled to decide on its ticket for the speaker and deputy speaker elections Wednesday. Some media reports said Chai may team up with acting DPP Chairman Ker Chien-ming for the upcoming speaker and deputy speaker elections.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC, CHAD PRESIDENTS SIGN JOINT COMMUNIQUE

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian and visiting Chadian President Idriss Deby signed a joint communique Monday in Kaohsiung, southern Taiwan.
The two leaders said in the joint communique that they are satisfied with bilateral cooperation projects in various areas and hope that such cooperation can be further expanded to other fields.
Deby expressed appreciation to Taiwan for helping his nation with various development projects and much-needed technical assistance, making Chad one of the models of African development.

Both leaders also expressed sadness over the tremendous losses in South Asia and Southeast Asia caused by the tsunami in the wake of the 9.0-magnitude earthquake in the Indian Ocean near Sumatra Dec. 26.

They also expressed worry about the threat to the international community posed by international terrorism, adding that the two countries will work with the international community to prevent terrorist activities.
Deby also invited Chen to visit Chad.

Accompanied by Chen and National Defense Minister Lee Jye, Deby earlier visited the Tsoying naval base in Kaohsiung, where the two leaders reviewed a marine force as well as a rapid deployment combat force, various missiles and heavy-duty amphibious vehicles.
A team of frogmen also impressed Deby with a display of martial arts.
Deby arrived in Taipei a day earlier for a three-day state visit. It is his third visit to Taiwan since assuming the presidency.

DOC.HEADLINE: LOCAL SCULPTOR PRESENTED WITH CULTURE PRIZE BY EXECUTIVE YUAN

TEXT.P: Prominent Taiwanese sculptor Ju Ming was presented Monday with the 2004 Executive Yuan culture prize.
Ju, who was born in 1938, learned traditional woodcarving from Lee Chin-chuan between 1953 and 1957 and studied with sculptor Yuyu Yang from 1968 to 1976.
He held his first exhibition at the National Museum of History in 1976 to great public acclaim and later held a number of exhibitions overseas, earning him an international reputation.
His international artistic prestige peaked in 1999 when his works were displayed at the Place de Vandome in Paris.
In 1999, he opened the Ju Ming Museum in Taipei County to continue to promote art and culture in Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: 2004 EXPORT ORDER VALUE AT ALL-TIME HIGH OF OVER US$200 BILLION

TEXT.P: Export orders placed for Taiwan companies last year hit an all-time high of US$215.09 billion in value, the first time the figure has broken the US$200 billion mark, the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) reported Monday.
The figure represents an annual increase of 26.5 percent -- a record growth rate since 1988 -- according to tallies released by the Statistics Department under the MOEA.
In December, export orders totaled US$19.8 billion in value, the second highest single-month level in history and a 25.97 percent rise compared to the previous year's level.

Telecommunications and electronics products were the top two items in outbound shipments, worth US$40.295 billion and US$47.028 billion and setting growth rates of 15.12 percent and 38.76 percent, respectively, year-on-year.

Export orders for basic metal products exceeded the US$20 billion level in value for the first time, while figures for outbound shipments of plastics, textiles, machinery and precision instruments also surpassed US$10 billion.

Department Director-General Chang Yaw-tzong attributed the good performance to a strong demand from the international market fueled by a recovering world economy, pointing out that export orders from Taiwan's major trade partners all registered more than double-digit increases in value.

The United States remained one of Taiwan's major export outlets last year, with total order value growing by US$13.08 billion over the 2003 level. Bolstered by robust demand from mainland China, meanwhile, the value of orders from Hong Kong jumped by US$10.8 billion.

Looking at the prospects for this year, Chang predicted that growth will slow. While a double-digit expansion for the whole of the year may be difficult, double-digit growth for single month periods is still possible, he said.

The courses of the international economy and the U.S. dollar, the world oil and raw material prices and the mainland's drive to cool off its high flying economy will be the major factors in the performance of the domestic economy, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN WATCHING AVIAN FLU SITUATION CAREFULLY

TEXT.P: A Department of Health (DOH) official said Monday that the department is watching the situation in Vietnam very carefully after several cases of avian influenza were reported there, but will not raise an alert in Taiwan.
Shih Wen-yi, deputy director of DOH's Center for Disease Control, said the DOH normally pays close attention to the influenza and avian influenza situation in the winter.
With Vietnam reporting nine avian flu cases in one month, causing alarm in the international community, Taiwan also needs to pay attention, Shih added.

But he said that unless there are human-to-human avian flu cases reported in foreign countries, or cases of avian flu reported in Taiwan, the DOH will not raise the alert level, although he stressed that monitoring operations at airports will be strengthened.

DOC.HEADLINE: JAPAN REAFFIRMS NO CHANGE IN 'VISA-FREE' DECISION FOR TAIWAN
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, Jan. 24 (CNA) (By Amy Huang and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Japan's decision to grant visa-free privileges for Taiwan tourists between March 25 and Sept. 25 will not be subject to any change despite protests from the mainland Chinese authorities, a Japanese diplomatic official said Monday.

Akira Chiba, assistant press secretary at Japan's Foreign Ministry, made the remarks after the Japanese Yomiuri Shimbun daily reported that Beijing has protested Japan's visa-free decision for Taiwan.

Chiba told journalists that it is already established that Japan will offer visa-free privileges to Taiwan tourists during the March-September period to coincide with an eco-friendly world exposition to be held in the central Japanese prefecture of Aichi.
"This will not be subject to any change simply because of Beijing's protests," Chiba said.

With a view to attracting more foreign visitors to the Aichi World Expo, the Japanese government has decided to offer visa-free privileges to Taiwan and South Korean tourists during the six-month period. Japan has also decided to issue visas for prospective visitors from all mainland areas during the period. At present, Japan only accepts visa applications from residents in three major mainland cities and five coastal mainland provinces.

The Yomiuri Shimbun reported that a senior mainland tourist official protested the new Japanese policy last week when Japan's Land, Infrastructure and Transportation Minister Kazuo Kitagawa visited Beijing.
The mainland official was quoted as having told Kitagawa that it was unacceptable for Japan to require visas for mainland nationals while exempting Taiwanese tourists from visa requirements.
As Japan does not maintain formal diplomatic ties with Taiwan, it will have to revise its existing law to offer visa-free privileges for Taiwan tourists.

Lawmakers from Japan's ruling coalition of the Liberal Democratic Party and the New Komeito Party are expected to come up with a bill in mid-February to allow visas for Taiwan tourists to be waived during the Aichi Expo.
Sources close to Japan's Foreign Ministry said ruling coalition lawmakers will submit the bill as scheduled despite Beijing's protest.

According to the Yomiuri report, the Japanese government has decided to offer visa-free privileges for Taiwan tourists mainly because Taiwan is Japan's second-largest source of foreign tourists after South Korea and because few Taiwan tourists overstay their visas.

Japanese Prime Minister Junichiro Koizumi informed Lee Yuan-tseh, Taiwan's representative to the 2004 informal leadership meeting of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation forum, of the visa-free decision last November.

DOC.HEADLINE: ENTHUSIASTIC PARTICIPATION IN GOVERNMENT'S SCHOLARSHIP PROJECT

TEXT.P: A program initiated by the government to send graduates to conduct advanced studies abroad has received enthusiastic response, with 2,100 applications presented to the authorities for the first 75 scholarships by the Jan. 20 deadline, government officials said Monday.

The project, jointly sponsored by the Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) , the Ministry of Education and the National Science Council (NSC) , is aimed at nurturing high-caliber intellectuals and technocrats, the officials said.
The applicants will take a series of tests and interviews between March 10 and 15, they added.

Under the program, potential government scholarship winners can choose their subjects for advanced studies in institutes abroad, including basic sciences, biomedical technology, image display, digital content, information and telecommunications technology, semiconductors, energy technology, environment and natural disasters, nanotechnology, international law and politics, culture, arts and humanities.
The shcholarships range from US$15,000 to US$20,000 a year for study in the United States, Canada, Europe and Japan, and up to US$12,000 for study in other areas.
The government plans to send 300 successful applicants in 2005, 300 in 2006, 350 in 2007 and 375 in 2008.

DOC.HEADLINE: 2004 INDUSTRIAL PRODUCTION INDEX SHOWS GROWTH OF OVER 9 PERCENT: MOEA

TEXT.P: Taiwan's industrial production index for the whole of 2004 was up by 9.8 percent year-on-year, at 126.91, a spokesman for the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) reported Monday.

Chang Yaw-tzong, director-general of the MOEA's Statistics Department, said that the country's manufacturing production index also rose last year by 10.48 percent over the 2003 record -- the largest growth since 1988.

Chang ascribed the increase to fierce demand from both the international and domestic markets, and predicted that the two growth rates for 2005 will both fall due to a less brisk export sector as a result of a global economy that is set to lose some of its steam due to weaker demand expected by most of the world's forecasting agencies.

Prices of raw materials and crude oil, interest rate hikes and the fallout of mainland China's efforts to deal with its overheated economy will be the leading elements affecting the Taiwan economy this year, he added.

Taiwan's industrial output index in December last year stood at 130.37, a slide of 0.95 percent compared to the previous year's level, while its manufacturing production index for that month also dropped by 1.99 percent on an annual basis -- the first monthly negative growth since June 2003.

The housing sector showed a jump of 31.88 percent in output in 2004 over the previous year's level, while the mining sector and the gas industry marked annual increases of 2.99 percent and 0.65 percent in production, respectively.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN LAWMAKERS URGE BEIJING TO SIGN CROSS-STRAIT INVESTMENT PACT
DOC.DATELINE: Beijing, Jan. 24 (CNA) (By Stanley Chang and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: A visiting Taiwan delegation, composed of opposition lawmakers and private business executives, urged mainland Chinese authorities Monday to sign a cross-strait investment protection agreement to better protect investors from Taiwan.
The delegation made the appeal while meeting with Tang Jiaxuan, a mainland state councilor.

Opposition Kuomintang Legislator Chu Feng-chih, a member of the delegation, said after the meeting that the delegation has also asked mainland authorities to open mainland China's doors to Taiwan's agricultural products, support Taiwan's bid to join the World Health Organization (WHO) and allow for regular direct passenger and cargo charter flights across the Taiwan Strait.
According to Chu, Tang said Beijing is unlikely to support Taiwan's WHO bid because if it does, Taiwan would ask for entry to other major international organizations.
Chu said the delegation made similar appeals during a meeting with Chen Yulin, director of the Taiwan Affairs Office of the State Council, a day earlier.

The delegation, organized by a Taipei-based private trade association dedicated to promoting cross-strait economic exchanges, arrived in Beijing Saturday. More than 20 opposition lawmakers are among the delegation members. The delegation will travel to Shanghai after the Beijing visit.

DOC.HEADLINE: COLOMBIAN LAWMAKER ARRIVES FOR VISIT

TEXT.P: Colombian Congressman Santiago Castro Gomez arrived in Taiwan Monday for a five-day visit.

Castro will meet with government officials including Chairman of the Council for Economic Planning and Development Hu Sheng-cheng, Vice Minister of Foreign Affairs Francisco Hwang, Vice Minister of Economic Affairs Chen Ruey-lung and Vice Minister of Finance Chen Shu, according to the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOFA).
He will also tour various economic and cultural establishments before departing Jan. 28, MOFA officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING'S PROPOSED ANTI-SECESSION LAW HARMFUL TO CROSS-STRAIT TIES

TEXT.P: The enacting of an anti-secession law by Beijing will diminish cross-Taiwan Strait exchanges and thus will be harmful to the development of bilateral ties, a scholar said Monday.

Shu Yung-ming, an assistant researcher with Academia Sinica, Taiwan's highest research institute, said in a seminar that the people of Taiwan will be afraid of visiting the mainland after the legislation is approved due to its ambiguous definition of secessionist activities.

The people of Taiwan could be arrested when visiting the mainland because of remarks they might make in Taiwan and other areas that are considered by the Beijing authorities as violations of the proposed law, he explained.

Besides, he went on, none of the candidates running for public office in Taiwan can avoid expressing their opposition to the proposed law during their campaigns under the country's current political circumstances.
Furthermore, he continued, the enacting of the anti-secession law will squeeze the political space of those who actually support Taiwan's reunification with the mainland.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Tuesday, Jan. 25, or the 17th day of the 12th month of the Year of the Monkey according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1327: Edward III accedes to the English throne. His reign was marked by the beginning of the Hundred Years' War, the Black Death epidemic, and the emergence of the Commons as a powerful arm of Parliament.
1533: King Henry VIII marries his lover, Anne Boleyn, in secret and in some haste, since she is pregnant.
1759: Robert Burns, the Scottish poet who wrote in lowland Scots dialect and is considered the major poetic voice of his nation, is born. His lyrics celebrate love, patriotism and rustic life.
1878: A Russian boat fires the first torpedo used in war and sinks a Turkish steamer.
1917: The United States buys the Virgin Islands from Holland for the sum of US$25 million.
1924: The first Winter Olympics are held in the shadow of Mont Blanc at Chamonix in France, with competitors from 18 countries participating. The Scandinavians seized the lion's share of the medals in the games.
1928: Eduard Schevardnadze, Russian politician and Soviet foreign minister under Mikhail Gorbachev, is born.
1939: An earthquake in Chile destroys 20 cities and towns, claiming more than 28,000 lives.
1942: Thailand, allied to Japan, declares war on the United States and Britain in World War II.
1944: The Reverend Florence Tim-Oi Lee becomes the first woman Anglican priest in Macao.
1947: Al Capone, America's most feared mobster who made Prohibition-era Chicago his power-base and reportedly made US$105 million in 1927 alone, dies in Florida at the age of 48. He was unmourned and virtually penniless.
1953: Republic of China President Chiang Kai-shek announces the abrogation of the Sino-Soviet Treaty of Friendship and Alliance of 1945 and its related documents.
1954: The first batch (4,687 people) of more than 14,000 communist Chinese POW's captured in the Korean War, who refused to go to mainland China, arrive in Keelung to a warm welcome from the ROC public.
1957: The United Nations orders Israel to quit Aqaba and Gaza.
1959: Soushan Park in the southern Taiwan city of Kaohsiung is inaugurated.
1969: The NR1, the American-built first deep-water nuclear submarine in the world, is launched.
1971: The Uganda Army overthrows Apollo Milton Obote and sets up a military government, with Maj. Gen. Idi Amin Dada heading the new government as president.
1971: Macabre cult leader Charles Manson is found guilty of murdering actress Sharon Tate and four others in a ritual slaughter in August, 1969 that stunned America.
1976: Dr. Cecil Mackey, president of South Florida University, arrives in Taipei for a week-long visit.
1976: The Aviation Medical Association is inaugurated in Taipei.
1978: ROC Premier Chiang Ching-kuo reaffirms that the Republic of China will continue to conduct research on atomic energy for purposes other than war.
1979: The Taiwan Provincial Government announces that it will send the case of Hsu Hsin-liang, chief of Taoyuan County Government, to the Control Yuan for investigation. Hsu, who took part in a protest, was accused of leaving his post without permission.
1981: Chiang Ching, Mao Zedong's 67-year-old widow, is given a suspended death sentence by communist China's supreme court for counterrevolutionary crimes committed with the "Gang of Four" in the mid-1970s.
1980: Japan orders the deportation of ex-Beatle Paul McCartney after keeping him in prison for nine days following the discovery of marijuana in his luggage.
1983: The Netherlands approves landing rights for China Airlines flights, paving the way for a new CAL route between Taipei and Amsterdam.
1990: American actress Ava Gardner dies at the age of 68.
1992: Boris Yeltsin says Russia will stop targeting US cities with nuclear missiles.
1999: Earthquake rocks Colombia, killing more than 900 people.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "A good man who studies extensively in the arts and literature, and directs his studies with judgment and taste, is not likely to get onto the wrong track."

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CHEN APPOINTS KAOHSIUNG MAYOR AS NEW PREMIER

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian announced Tuesday that he has decided to appoint Kaohsiung Mayor Frank Hsieh as new premier.

Hsieh will succeed Premier Yu Shyi-kun who led all Cabinet members to resign en masse Monday to pave the way for the formation of a new Cabinet ahead of the inauguration of a new Legislative Yuan Feb. 1.
Chen also announced at the news conference that Yu will serve as the Presidential Office secretary-general after stepping down as premier Feb. 1.

Hsieh pledged to pursue domestic political and social stability as well as peace across the Taiwan Strait after assuming the premiership. Inter-party reconciliation and political stability will be the new Cabinet's top priority, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: THINK TANK FORECASTS 4.67% GDP GROWTH FOR 2005

TEXT.P: Taiwan will register gross domestic product (GDP) growth of 4.67 percent in real terms for this year, a private think tank predicted Tuesday.

Wu Rong-i, president of the Taiwan Institute of Economic Research, said the nation's 2005 GDP growth rate is expected to be lower than last year's 6.17 percent growth because of an anticipated slowdown in global economic growth and mainland China's measures to coll its overheated economy.
Meanwhile, Wu said that if the United States fails to properly address its swelling trade and budget deficits, the greenback will continue to weaken.
Against this backdrop, Wu said, the New Taiwan dollar will hover at around NT$31.65 to one U.S. dollar, marking a rise of NT$2.08 from the 2004 level.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEWLY APPOINTED PREMIER PLEDGES TO FORM STABLE CABINET

TEXT.P: Premier-designate Frank Hsieh pledged Tuesday to form a stable Cabinet that will pursue political and cross-strait stability.
Hsieh made the remarks after President Chen Shui-bian announced his appointment at the Presidential Office as the new premier.

The Kaohsiung mayor will succeed Yu Shyi-kun who resigned along with the rest of the Cabinet Monday. It was later announced that Yu will serve as the Presidential Office secretary-general, or the president's chief of staff.

The president, who said Hsieh's appointment was based on his outstanding performance as mayor of the southern port city as well as considerations of creating a regional balance in the makeup of the administration, stressed that the new Cabinet will be one that promotes consultations, dialogue and stability.
Hsieh said that he was thrilled to hear the president's call for consultations and stability, pointing out that he is strongly committed to moving in that direction.
The premier-designate said that his basic ideals are co-existence and reconciliation, as well as pursuing political, cross-strait and social stability for the people.

He pointed out that he has been promoting a new culture movement over the past 20 years by writing books and sponsoring activities to promote the ideas of co-existence and cooperation in the belief that this will create a "win-win situation" for the ruling and opposition parties.

Hsieh also said political stability must come from the top down, adding that he would like to take the lead in this respect by spending more time on resolving the partisan conflicts and rivalry within Taiwan.

Hsieh, 59, holds a master's degree in law from Kyoto University in Japan. He served as a defense lawyer for those involved in the "Kaohsiung Incident" -- a human rights rally in December 1979 that turned violent. The incident is considered a milestone in Taiwan's democratic movement.

Hsieh also served two terms as a Taipei city councilor and three terms as a member of Legislative Yuan. He was the Democratic Progressive Party's (DPP's) vice presidential candidate in Taiwan's first direct presidential election in 1996 and later served as the DPP chairman. His popularity has increased steadily during his six years as Kaohsiung mayor, even surpassing that of Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou according to some public opinion polls.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange closed higher Tuesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 11.27 points to close at 5,782.75.
The bourse opened at 5,759.21 and fluctuated between 5,796.85 and 5,734.87 during trading. A total of 2.58 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$47.21 billion (US$1.48 billion).

Three of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with plastics and chemicals shares moving up the most at 0.8 percent, followed by machinery and electronics shares at 0.4 percent, and foodstuff issues at 0.1 percent.

The five other major stock categories lost ground, with cement stocks moving down the most at 2.4 percent, followed by textile stocks at 2.3 percent, construction issues at 0.8 percent, banking and financial shares at 0.2 percent, and paper anf pulp issues at 0.1 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 502 to 291, with 161 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT REAFFIRMS RESOLVE TO SEEK RECONCILIATION WITH OPPOSITION

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian reaffirmed Tuesday his resolve to seek reconciliation and cooperation with the opposition, stressing that the next Cabinet will be one built on consultations, dialogue and stability.

The president made the remarks at a news conference where he announced his decision to appoint Kaohsiung Mayor Frank Hsieh to replace Yu Shyi-kun as the next premier. The new Cabinet is set to be formed on Feb. 1 simultaneous with the inauguration of a new legislature.

Renewing his overture made in his Jan. 1 New Year's address, Chen said nothing should prevent reconciliation and cooperation between the ruling and opposition parties as long as it benefits political stability, people's well-being, ethnic amity and cross-Taiwan Strait peace.

For this very purpose, Chen noted, the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) and himself have displayed the highest level of goodwill and sincerity over the past month by making contact with all opposition parties.

Chen said he fully understands that ruling and opposition parties must put aside their selfishness, partisan interests and ideological confrontation in order to reconcile and cooperate with each other.
Chen asserted that he will never be discouraged by the fact that a mature environment for inter-party cooperation is still lacking in Taiwan but will continue to stick to this pursuit.
Chen expressed the hope that the next Cabinet and legislature will facilitate the development of win-win relations between the ruling and opposition camps.

According to Chen, Hsieh's successful experience in interacting with the opposition-dominated Kaohsiung City Council makes him the best candidate for premier. He will help pry open the doors to consultations and dialogue with the opposition and stabilize the political scene, Chen said.
The appointment of Hsieh -- the first politician to jump directly from mayor to premier -- also symbolizes the upgrading of the status of counties and cities, Chen said.

In addition, the appointment will mean the instillation of a southern Taiwan perspective into the central government, which is expected to help balance regional development and shrink the gap in rural-urban development, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES HIGHER ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TAIEX Index futures for March gained 10 points to finish at 5,815, with 221 contracts traded, while June futures gained 12 points to close at 5,807, with 13 contracts traded.
