DOC.HEADLINE: MISSION-ORIENTED NATIONAL ASSEMBLY MAY BE ELECTED MAY 14

TEXT.P: The nation's first-ever mission-oriented National Assembly may be elected May 14 to endorse a package of constitutional amendments passed by the outgoing Legislative Yuan last August, the Central Election Commission (CEC) said Tuesday.

CEC Deputy Secretary-General Teng Tien-you made the remarks after a CEC-organized meeting of representatives from city and county election commissions to discuss the timing for the National Assembly election.
Teng said the CEC proposed three dates -- April 30, May 7 and May 14 -- for the National Assembly election.

"Most people at the conference felt that April 30 would be too soon while May 7 happens to be the date for national civil service examinations. As a result, the participants generally agreed that May 14 would be the most suitable for the National Assembly election," Teng said, adding that a final decision on the timing will be made Feb. 2 when all CEC commissioners will meet to discuss the issue.

The fifth Legislative Yuan, which will finish its term Jan. 31, passed a landmark constitutional amendment package Aug. 23, 2004 to pave the way for sweeping legislative reforms, including reducing the number of legislative seats from the present 225 to 113 and adopting a "single seat, two votes" legislative electoral system starting with the seventh Legislative Yuan to be elected in 2007, as well as phasing out the mission-oriented National Assembly to allow for popular referendum on future constitutional amendments.

Under the current constitutional provisions, the legislature must publicly display its Constitutional amendment bill for six months before a mission-oriented or "functional" National Assembly meets to endorse the bill. The public display period will expire Feb. 26.

The present Constitution also stipulates that 300 National Assembly members should be elected by proportional representation within three months of the expiration of the six-month public display period. Therefore, the CEC must hold a National Assembly election before May 26.

The mission-oriented National Assembly is required to convene within 10 days after the election and complete screening and endorsement of the legislature-proposed amendments to the Constitution within a month.
Against this backdrop, the first-ever mission-oriented National Assembly, which will also be the last of its kind, must complete endorsement of the legislature-proposed amendments by early July.

DOC.HEADLINE: HSIEH NOT RULING OUT INTER-PARTY CONSULTATIONS ON CABINET LINEUP

TEXT.P: Premier-designate Frank Hsieh said Tuesday that he does not rule out the possibility of forming his Cabinet through inter-party consultations, saying that such discussions should be the norm.
Hsieh made the remarks to media after President Chen Shui-bian announced earlier that he will succeed Yu Shyi-kun to serve as the new premier.

The Kaohsiung mayor said that he is amenable to discussing the lineup of the new Cabinet through inter-party consultations, whether party-to-party, caucus-to-caucus in the legislature, or the Executive Yuan to the Legislative Yuan.

Hsieh also said that he does not rule out meeting with the leaders of the opposition parties in the hopes of promoting reconciliation between the ruling and opposition parties to create a win-win situation for both.
He is expected to stay in Taipei for a couple of days to consult extensively on the lineup of his Cabinet.

DOC.HEADLINE: IPO PLANS PROFESSIONAL IPR PERSONNEL TRAINING

TEXT.P: The creation of an institute to train professionals in the finer points of intellectual property rights (IPR) is in the planning phase, officials from the Intellectual Property Office (IPO) of the Ministry of Economic Affairs said Monday.

NT$260 million will be used to open an administrative office sometime this year to do the planning for the facility, the officials said, adding that the office will design seminars and training courses, compile and write textbooks and material for the courses, and train 200 seed lecturers for the planned institute.
They added that the training facility will have a three-year goal of training 1,000 IPR professionals each year to resolve Taiwan's shortage of IPR experts in the academic and judicial sectors.

Other goals of the planned institute include encouraging local industrial companies to apply for patents for their inventions or research and development results, having them build management systems for their intellectual property, and improving judicial personnel's IPR knowledge, allowing them to deal with IPR violations more properly and professionally.

DOC.HEADLINE: TWO PROMINENT INVESTMENT PLANS APPROVED BY ECONOMICS MINISTRY

TEXT.P: Two high-profile investment plans in Yunlin County by the Formosa Plastics Group (FPG) and the Chinese Petroleum Corp. (CPC) have received initial official approval and the companies will be able to acquire needed land in the near term to begin the projects, a government official said Tuesday.

According to a spokesman for the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) , the two investment plans, with a combined value of over NT$500 billion (US15.3 billion) , was given the green light by the ministry a day earlier.

Citing Minister of Economic Affairs Ho Mei-yueh, the spokesman said that if government acquisition of the needed plots from the private sector proceed smoothly, the two companies could buy the land from the government as early as February.

The FPG will need 521 hectares of land for its planned steel mill, while the CPC will have to acquire a plot of more than 700 hectares for its projected petrochemical park, he said, adding that the two investment projects in central Taiwan are now pending final approval from the Executive Yuan.

DOC.HEADLINE: HSIEH'S APPOINTMENT AS PREMIER MET WITH PARTISAN REACTIONS

TEXT.P: The announcement of Kaohsiung Mayor Frank Hsieh's appointment as the next premier was met with reaction along party lines Tuesday.

The ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) welcomed the move, saying that it has "every confidence in him, " and lauded his ideal of "co-existence and cooperation" and his belief in creating a "win-win situation" for the ruling and opposition parties.

The DPP also said that whatever the result of the elections for speaker and vice speaker in the opposition-dominated Legislative Yuan on Feb. 1, it is inevitable that the ruling and opposition parties must move toward "consultation and communication."

Ker Chien-ming, DPP caucus whip in the legislature, said that Hsieh has been a key figure in Taiwan's democratic movement over the past three decades, and his political acumen has led the party forward in every way.
During his six years as Kaohsiung mayor, Hsieh has significantly upgraded the city's image and achieved a south-north regional balance that had never existed before, Ker added.

Another DPP legislator, Tsai Huang-liang, also said that Hsieh is wise and well-rounded, adding that he has created a "Kaohsiung miracle" with his popularity even surpassing that of Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou.

Noting that the opposition "pan-blue alliance" of the Kuomintang (KMT) and the People First Party (PFP) still dominates the 225-seat legislature, Tsai said that Hsieh will face daunting challenges ahead, but he hoped that Hsieh will avoid highly controversial issues, and enter into dialogue with the opposition to end the confrontation between the ruling and opposition parties.

The Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU), an ally of the DPP, was also positive about Hsieh's appointment and expressed the hope that he will push for inter-party reconciliation in response to the public aspiration for political stability.

Chen Chien-ming, TSU caucus whip in the legislature, also urged Hsieh's new Cabinet to pay attention to laborers, farmers and fishermen, women, the elderly and other underprivileged groups to better social welfare.

On the political front, Chen also hoped that Hsieh could respond to the TSU's campaign to "call Taiwan, Taiwan" and to write a new Constitution so that the sovereignty of the nation can be firmly established.

On the other hand, the largest opposition party, the KMT, "regretted" President Chen Shui-bian's appointment of Hsieh, saying that the president will have to bear the full responsibility for naming a minority government.

Tseng Yung-chuan, legislator and executive director of the KMT's Policy Committee, said that according to the spirit of the Constitution, the majority in the legislature should form the Cabinet, and the president has violated that spirit by forming a minority Cabinet.
"If the new Cabinet does not function well and a stable political situation cannot be achieved, the DPP and President Chen must bear the full responsibility," he said.

Liu Wen-hsiung, PFP caucus whip in the legislature, said that whether trust between the ruling and opposition parties can be rebuilt will hinge on President Chen, and not on whether the new premier is well-rounded or not.
Liu said that if the DPP does not abandon its advocacy of Taiwan independence then the spectre of political confrontation will never go away.
He also questioned the minor reshuffle of the Cabinet, saying that it has "failed to give it a new look."

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Washington Post: Army Plans To Keep Iraq Troop Level Through '06; Year-Long Active-Duty Stints Likely to Continue.
The U.S. Army expects to keep its troop strength in Iraq at the current level of about 120,000 for at least two more years, according to the Army's top operations officer, the paper said.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. DOLLAR RISES ON TAIPEI FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar rose against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Tuesday, gaining NT$0.051 to close at NT$31.881.
A total of US$585.5 million changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at NT$31.851 and fluctuated between NT$31.801 and NT$31.884.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER TO DEDICATE HIMSELF TO NEW POST AT PRESIDENTIAL OFFICE

TEXT.P: Premier Yu Shyi-kun said Tuesday he will dedicate himself to his new appointment as secretary-general of the Presidential Office.

Yu, who was earlier appointed as President Chen Shui-bian's chief of staff, said that he told the president that after serving as vice premier and secretary-general of the Presidential Office before being promoted to premier three years ago, he needs some time to rest.

But considering the overall political situation, the president invited him to return to his old post, Yu said. As a member of a team, he has to accept the invitation and dedicate himself to the work if it will benefit the country, he added.

He also said that he felt relieved to step down as premier, saying that he knows that Kaohsiung Mayor Frank Hsieh, who was appointed as the new premier to succeed him, is very capable and will do well.

DOC.HEADLINE: RADIO TAIWAN INTERNATIONAL TO STOP 5 FOREIGN LANGUAGE BROADCASTS

TEXT.P: Radio Taiwan International announced Tuesday that it will stop five foreign language broadcasts as part of its efforts to streamline the company.
The five foreign languages -- Korean, Burmese, Arabic, Mongolian and Tibetan -- will stop broadcasting starting Feb. 1.
Chairman Lin Feng-cheng said that the company currently has a workforce of 488 people broadcasting in 18 languages daily to the world and is the only international broadcasting station in Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: DOH TO IMPLEMENT AUSTERITY PROGRAM TO SAVE HEALTH INSURANCE PROGRAM

TEXT.P: The Department of Health (DOH) will adopt austerity measures to save the shaky national health insurance program from bankruptcy without raising premiums for a year or so, a senior official said Tuesday.

DOH Minister Chen Chien-jen said that since participants to last week's civic meeting on the health insurance program unanimously disagreed with a proposed hike in health insurance premiums, the DOH will respect this conclusion and refrain from raising premiums this year.

Acknowledging that there is room for the annual health care expenditures to be cut by 5 percent to 10 percent, Chen said if waste can be curbed and cost-saving measures can be implemented, the health insurance program should be able to continue operations without the need to raise premiums for another year or so.

Chen urged local people not to use outpatient resources for minor ailments. Each Taiwan citizen makes an average of 14.5 hospital outpatient visits per year, far higher than the average of seven or eight visits in the United States and major European countries.

"If we can minimize unnecessary hospital outpatient visits and medical examinations, we'll be able to save medical resources for those who are suffering from acute, serious or rare diseases, " Chen said.

Other feasible cost-cutting measures will include ceasing payments for epidemic prevention and public health promotion programs as well as subsidies for teaching hospitals, Chen said, adding that those spendings can hereafter be paid from government budgets instead of funds from the health insurance program.

According to Chen, the health insurance program's reserve funds will be used up by the end of March. After March, Chen said the Cabinet has set aside NT$11 billion in its 2005 budget plan to help support the health insurance program.
Chen said the DOH has begun designing a second-generation health insurance program under which the premiums will be collected in terms of total household incomes.

The 20 participants in the Jan. 20-22 conference, organized by National Taiwan University's Sociology Department at the request of the DOH's National Health Insurance Bureau, unanimously agreed that action should be taken to save the program from bankruptcy, but not through an increase in insurance premiums. The participants reached consensus that the health categories covered by the program should not be reduced to deal with the program's financial difficulties.
They suggested a change in how premiums are calculated, from a percentage of an insured's salary to a percentage of their total personal income, saying this would be a fairer system.

In order to raise funds to finance the program, they also recommended levying a health tax on cigarettes and aggressively pursuing claims for damage on behalf of motor vehicle accident victims and against employers negligence in occupational safety.
Abuse and waste in the health insurance program should be curbed to decrease the program's costs, according to the conclusions reached by the conference participants.

DOC.HEADLINE: ANALYSTS HAVE HIGH EXPECTATIONS FOR FRANK HSIEH AS PREMIER

TEXT.P: Local analysts on Tuesday expected that the next Cabinet led by Frank Hsieh will help improve cross-Taiwan Strait relations, temper confrontation between the ruling and opposition camps and balance regional development.

Lin De-chang, director of the Institute of Mainland China Studies at National Sun Yat-sen University (NSYSU), said Hsieh has displayed pragmatism in dealing with the mainland during his term as Kaohsiung mayor and that this attitude is expected to help better cross-strait relations.
For example, Lin said, Hsieh succeeded in breaking through the mainland's suppression, winning Kaohsiung the right to host the World Games 2009.

Also, Hsieh managed to avoid cross-strait political influence while actively promoting the establishment of a free trade zone at Kaohsiung Harbor and the development of the city's tourism and service industries, Lin said.

Lin said an "anti-secession law" that Beijing is expected to enact in March or April will bring cross-strait relations to a state of uncertainty and that the situation will be an immediate test for the new Cabinet.

Instead of trying to retaliate by pushing for the passage of a law against being "swallowed up" by the mainland, Hsieh should lower his profile and extend some gesture of goodwill to Beijing, Lin suggested.
Lee Chin-tarn, director of NSYSU's Department of Business Administration, said Hsieh must pay close attention to the challenges posed by the vast mainland market and its economic power to Taiwan.

In terms of financial and economic policies, Lee proposed that Hsieh work to enhance Taiwan's global competitiveness and strengthen its appeal to international investors, which according to Lee will require the recruitment of more economic talent into the Cabinet.

Liao Da-chi, director of NSYSU's Graduate Institute of Political Science, said Hsieh's flexible and well-rounded style, which she said has helped him overcome a number of difficulties in interacting with the opposition-dominated Kaohsiung City Council, will be very useful in improving cross-strait relations and relations between the ruling and opposition parties.
Also, Liao said she believes Hsieh's appointment as the next premier will benefit the development of Kaohsiung in light of his connection with the port city.
Disagreeing with Liao, Bob Kuo, director of NSYSU's Department of Information Management, said he does not think Hsieh will enjoy much personal maneuverability in the premier position.
Kuo predicted that Hsieh's "Kaohsiung experience" will be overwhelmed by the strong Taipei-oriented perspective in the central government in six month after he assumes the premiership.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW ROC AMBASSADOR TO HAITI HOPES TO STRENGTHEN TIES
DOC.DATELINE: Panama City, Jan. 24 (CNA) (By Ramon Huang and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: New Republic of China (Taiwan) Ambassador to Haiti Yang Cheng-ta said Monday that he will do his best to strengthen diplomatic relations with the Caribbean country.
Yang, who arrived in Haiti Sunday, said that he will need some time to learn the situation in Haiti before he works out future plans, but in the meantime, he will reinforce bilateral relations.

Regarding reports by the Xinhua News Agency that Haitian Minister of Foreign Affairs Yvon Simeon said in a recent meeting with a China delegation that although Haiti and China have not established diplomatic relations, he is sure the situation won't last long, Yang said that as far as he understands, Simeon didn't say that.

He said that China has made every effort to scuttle the relations between Taiwan and the its allies in Central and South America, but the basic stance of Taiwan is to step up cooperation with its allies and not direct all its efforts to outmaneuver China.
Yang said that the more important thing is to strengthen close cooperation with the ROC's allies and seek to promote common interests.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP HOPES TO PASS HUMAN RIGHTS LAW IN THREE YEARS

TEXT.P: The ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) hopes to push through a piece of human rights legislation in three years to safeguard human rights protection in Taiwan, acting DPP Chairman Ker Chien-ming said Tuesday.
Ker said this is part of the DPP's efforts to realize President Chen Shui-bian's concept of making human rights protection part of the foundation of the country.
In the next three years, the DPP will work to introduce a "human rights basic law" and seek to amend laws enacted during the martial law era that violate human rights, Ker said.

Ker made the remarks during a weekly meeting of the DPP's Central Standing Committee, when Liao Fu-teh, vice chairman of the Presidential Office's human rights advisory committee, was invited to give a speech on realizing the goal of building a country with human rights as a cornerstone.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOEA TO FACILITATE ENTRY FOR FOREIGNERS COMING TO TAIWAN MEETINGS

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) is planning to offer easier entry facilities to foreigners and mainland Chinese coming to Taiwan to take part in international meetings and exhibitions, MOEA officials said Tuesday.

A task force to promote tourism under the Executive Yuan reached the conclusion in a meeting in which it agreed that the government will subsidize the private sector in sponsoring large international meetings or exhibitions.
The ultimate goal is for all agencies under the Executive Yuan to hold at least one international convention with attendance of more than 200 people by 2008, task force officials said.

However, the Taiwan Convention and Exhibition Association said that simplifying entry procedures is more important than just providing government subsidies, pointing out that a lot of buyers from South Asia and Africa need guarantors in order to secure a Taiwan visa or have to go to third countries to apply for visas.

MOEA officials said that if foreigners account for a certain level of participation in a convention or exhibition held in Taiwan, they can apply to a MOEA task force to be established after Chinese New Year, which falls on Feb. 9, for selective landing visas.
In addition, mainland Chinese applying to come to Taiwan to attend international conventions or exhibitions will also have their screening time shortened from the present 21 days.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN BUSINESS CLIMATE INDEX FALLS FOR DECEMBER: TIER

TEXT.P: Taiwan's business climate index for December dropped to 99.75 points, down from November's 102.66 points, the Taiwan Institute of Economic Research (TIER) reported Tuesday.
The December index represents the fifth consecutive fall and the lowest level since June 2003 in the TIER monthly survey.

Meanwhile, of the companies polled month-to-month, 19.4 percent were optimistic about business conditions at home over the next six months, a slide from 20.2 percent. Some 65.3 percent, a rise from 61.7 percent, were of the view that their business would maintain stable, while 18.1 percent, an increase over 15.3 percent, were pessimistic about their business prospects, the survey found.

According to the survey results, the respondents thought that business in the textile, garment, retail and cement industries will be regular in the first half of this year, with the car accessory trade the only exception.
The business climate index is a widely observed indicator to assess current economic conditions and future expectations of the business community.

TIER President Wu Rong-i also pointed out that private investment will cool this year despite various major government public construction plans due to a slowing domestic economy. The private sector investment growth rate is estimated to dwindle to just 9.67 percent for 2005, a noticeable decline from the 25.08 percent of 2004, he said.

Affected by a less vigorous world economy, the relatively high prices of raw materials and crude oil, a rising interest rate and mainland China's drive to stem its overheated economy, the Taiwan economy is forecast to grow by 4.67 percent this year, which is lackluster compared to the 6.17 percent for 2004, Wu said.

However, Wu claimed that Taiwan should feel comfortable with an annual economic growth rate of above 4 percent for a nearly mature economy. It would have been unusual to see a rate of more than 7 percent in the old days, he added.

Private consumption, as well as export and import trade, will also post a decrease this year, with expected growth rates of 2.58 percent, 12.1 percent and 14.08 percent, respectively, below last year's 3.06 percent, 20.71 percent and 31.94 percent, he pointed out. The country's whole-year trade surplus is assessed to shrink to NT$3.6 billion from US$6.2 billion, according to Wu.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN URGES JAPAN TO PLAY LEADING ROLE TO ENSURE REGIONAL PEACE
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, Jan. 25 (CNA) (By Amy Huang and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Japan should play a more leading role in Asian affairs to help prevent mainland China from treading a policy line of adventurism, a Taiwan official said in Tokyo Tuesday.

Lo Fu-chuan, president of the quasi-official Association of East Asian Relations (AEAR) , who also once served as Taiwan's representative to Japan, made the call at a pre-departure news conference at the end of a weeklong visit to Japan.

Lo led a group of Taiwan scholars to meet with Japanese politicians and academics in the past week to brief them on the possible adverse impact on regional stability and peace of mainland China's proposed "anti-secession law."
Lo told Japanese politicians that Beijing has refused to talk with Taiwan while unilaterally planning to enact the "anti-secession law" targeting Taiwan.

Stressing that the move reflects Beijing's ignorance of human rights and attempts to unilaterally alter the status quo in the Taiwan Strait, Lo said that if the proposed "anti-secession law" becomes a reality, it will strain cross-strait relations and could eventually affect all of Asia.

Since mainland China is not a democratic country, Lo said it can interpret its law from the aspect of self-interest. Should the "anti-secession law" be enacted, Lo said its target could include not only Taiwan but also the disputed Tiaoyutai Islands, which are known as the Senkakus in Japan. The island group is now under Japan's control, but both sides of the Taiwan Strait claim sovereignty over the island group.

After briefing Japanese lawmakers from across the political spectrum on Beijing's legislative plan Monday, Lo said Japanese lawmakers have come to a better understanding of the legislation's potential pitfalls.

"They are all concerned about Beijing's proposed law, " Lo said, adding that most Japanese politicians are now adopting a wait-and-see attitude and are not prepared to make any public comments until after Beijing reveals the full text of the law.

DOC.HEADLINE: CPC TO COOPERATE WITH CHAD IN OIL DEVELOPMENT

TEXT.P: The state-run Chinese Petroleum Corp. (CPC) is planning to funnel US$100 million into an oil development project in cooperation with the African nation of Chad, CPC Chairman C.T. Kuo said Tuesday.
Taiwan and Chad reached a preliminary agreement in October last year on an oil development cooperation project.
According to Kuo, the CPC's role in the project will be that of shareholder and consultant to Chad.
With Taiwan one of Chad's most important partners in oil exploration, the CPC will assist Chad to make the most effective use of its oil resources, CPC officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The New York Times: Balking at Vote, Sunnis Seek Role on Constitution.
Sunni Arab leaders who have called for a boycott of the Iraq elections say they intend to get involved in politics after the vote.
Wall Street Journal: Prices Increase on Popular Drugs.
Many patients will have to dig deeper into their pockets for prescription drugs after a raft of drug-price increases in the past few months.

DOC.HEADLINE: RISE OF TAIWANESE IDENTITY DIFFERS FROM PRO-INDEPENDENCE: PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Tuesday that the increasing sense of Taiwanese identity in the country should not be equated to a rise in pro-independence sentiment.

Chen made the remarks while meeting with a visiting delegation from the National Committee on U.S.-China Relations, a private U.S. think tank. The delegation is headed by former U.S. Defense Secretary William J. Perry.
With the progress in Taiwan's democratic development, Chen said, there is developing among the people of Taiwan a growing sense of Taiwanese identity distinct from that of mainland China.

This tendency should not be interpreted as a growing pro-independence sentiment, Chen said, adding that the international community should not "hand over free Taiwan to not-free China simply because of worries about the rise of Taiwanese identity."
He stressed that his administration's constitutional re-engineering program has nothing to do with the "unification vs. independence" debate regarding Taiwan's future.

"We'll faithfully follow our constitutional procedures in constitutional amendments and won't go beyond constitutional provisions, " Chen said, adding that holding a referendum to endorse future constitutional amendment proposals is a consensus reached by opposition and ruling parties last year.
He also told his guests that he has appointed Frank Hsieh, mayor of Taiwan's second-largest city of Kaohsiung, to serve as the new premier from Feb. 1.

Noting that Hsieh, a skillful negotiator, is known for his political philosophy of "co-existence and cooperation, " Chen said he believes that this thinking can be applied to address not only Taiwan's inter-party relations but also Taiwan-U.S. relations and Taiwan-mainland ties.
Citing his New Year's Day message, Chen said he is determined to "open a new era of negotiation and dialogue" with both Taiwan's opposition camp and the mainland.

Acknowledging that being free of preconceived ideals, partisan calculation and ideological divides is the cardinal principle for promoting inter-party reconciliation and cooperation, Chen said his administration will stick to this principle to boost national unity.

"We'll search all possibilities for reconciliation with the opposition alliance. We must give up partisan interests and ideological divides, " Chen said, adding that "only with a united Taiwan... shall we achieve cross-Taiwan Strait peace."

He further said the recent landmark cross-strait deal on the launch of direct, non-stop charter flights during the upcoming Chinese New Year holiday to accommodate homebound Taiwan businessmen from the mainland is a good example of these principles.

"The charter flight deal can serve as a good start for a thaw in the long-deadlocked cross-strait ties, " Chen said, adding that his administration will continue pushing for normalization of cross-strait relations.

Touching on worries expressed by some American scholars that the long absence of cross-strait dialogue could escalate tension, Chen said Taiwan is pragmatic and flexible in dealing with cross-strait affairs.

"Although the United States is Taiwan's best ally, Taiwan will never be so naive as to rely on the U.S. for its security. We fully understand our conditions and constraints. We are fully aware that our survival hinges on self-reliance and a pragmatic approach in pursuing national development," Chen added.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW EPZA TOP OFFICIAL TO TAKE OFFICE

TEXT.P: Deputy Taipei County Magistrate Tseng Sen-bao is scheduled to become the new director-general of the Export Processing Zone Administration (EPZA) under the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA), ministry officials said Tuesday.
Tseng will take over from the retiring Chou Yen Jan. 28 in a ceremony held at the Nantzu Export Processing Zone in the southern port city of Kaohsiung.

Tseng, 51, holds a doctorate in land economics from National Chengchi University. He worked as a member of the Cabinet-level Council of Economic Planning and Development and was a secretary of the East Coast National Scenic Area Administration under the Ministry of Transportation and Communications. He has also served as a deputy division director of the MOEA Industrial Development Bureau and as secretary-general of the Taipei county government.

The EPZA, which administers five export processing zones and a warehousing and transportation service center, was formed in the 1960s, a time when the central government's finances were short and unemployment high. To lure foreign investment, the central government enacted several favorable statutes for foreign investors to set up factories to provide jobs for Taiwan people.
Today, the EPZA has successfully solicited enormous capital and state-of-the-art manufacturing techniques so that the country's processing industries have become world famous.

DOC.HEADLINE: OVER 44 MILLION CREDIT CARDS ISSUED IN TAIWAN: FSC

TEXT.P: A spokesman for the Financial Supervisory Commission (FSC) reported Tuesday that as of the end of December last year, 53 banking institutions in Taiwan had issued a combined total of 44.18 million credit cards.
According to the FSC official, 24.59 million cards of the total are valid, with transactions totaling NT$127.2 billion (US$3.9 billion) for December alone.

Outstanding credit card debt hit NT$457.9 billion, about NT$20.3 billion of which was loaned to card holders in pre-pay transactions, the official said. The average narrowly defined overdue loan ratio for December reached 0.51 percent, slightly down by 0.07 percentage points from the November level.

At the same time, around 37.6 million cash cards issued by 35 banking institutions had already been used to secure loans worth NT$241.5 billion as of the end of 2004. The overdue loan ratios posted by cash card holders averaged 0.626 percent for the same month, marking a fall of 0.185 percentage points from a month earlier.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP SETS UP TASK FORCE FOR NATIONAL ASSEMBLY ELECTIONS

TEXT.P: The ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) established a task force Tuesday to nominate the party's candidates in upcoming elections of a mission-oriented ad hoc National Assembly, a DPP official said.

Liang Wen-jye, deputy executive director of the DPP Policy Committee, said the task force is headed by Presidential Office Secretary-General Su Tseng-chang, who is expected to be elected as DPP chairman by the end of this month, and that its members include Vice President Annette Lu, Premier Yu Shyi-kun, Kaohsiung Mayor Frank Hsieh, Acting DPP Chairman Ker Chien-ming, National Security Committee Secretary-General Chiou Yi-jen and Central Personnel Administration Director-General Lee Yi-yang.

The task force will nominate more than 150 candidates who will register with the Central Election Commission (CEC) after their nominations are approved by the DPP Central Executive Committee, Liang revealed.

Given that the DPP has not yet provided any rules and regulations for the nomination of candidates for National Assembly elections, the party's Central Executive Committee will hold a meeting Jan. 31 to draw up a draft that will be discussed and approved by the party congress slated for March 12, he added.
The task force will then nominate the candidates in accordance with the rules and regulations to seek the approval of the party's Central Executive Committee by March 26, Liang went on.

The CEC is planning to hold the National Assembly elections May 7 or May 14 to elect 300 members for the ad hoc assembly that will endorse a package of constitutional amendments passed by the Legislative Yuan last August.

The Fifth Legislative Yuan, which will finish its term Jan. 31, passed the landmark constitutional amendment package Aug. 23 to pave the way for sweeping legislative reforms, including reducing the number of legislative seats from the present 225 to 113 and adopting a "single seat, two votes" legislative electoral system starting with the Seventh Legislative Yuan to be elected in 2007, as well as phasing out the ad hoc National Assembly to allow for popular referendum on future constitutional amendments.
The National Assembly members will be elected proportionally based on the number of ballots garnered by the various political parties or electoral alliances that take part in the elections.

DOC.HEADLINE: INDIA OFFERS EASIER VISA ENTRY FOR TAIWAN BUSINESSMEN

TEXT.P: To help boost trade and economic exchanges between Taiwan and India, the Taiwan External Trade Development Council (TAITRA) and the India-Taipei Association have teamed up to offer better visa treatment for Taiwan businessmen, a TAITRA spokesman said Tuesday.

Starting immediately, the India-Taipei Association will issue one-year multiple entry business visas to Taiwan businessmen who are able to show a recommendation letter issued by TAITRA, the spokesman said.

The move marks a prolongation of six months for Taiwan businessmen wishing to visit India, India-Taipei Association Chairman Vijay Gokhale said, adding that it takes only half a working day for applicants to get the visa.
In the past, Taiwan businessmen, even when recommended by TAITRA, could only receive a six-month multiple entry visa, he said.

Trade between the two countries has expanded rapidly in recent years, with two-way trade expected to have reached US$17 billion for 2004. There is ample room for bilateral trade to further flourish in view of India's large territory and population.
The semi-official TAITRA, formerly known as CETRA (China External Trade Development Council) , was set up in 1970 to help Taiwan companies explore foreign trade.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINA SOUTHERN AIRLINES TO BE 1ST MAINLAND CARRIER TO LAND IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: China Southern Airlines will be the first mainland Chinese carrier to ever make a landing at Chiang Kai-shek (CKS) International Airport, Taiwan's main gateway, officials of the Civil Aeronautic Administration (CAA) said Tuesday.

According to applications received by the CAA, five charter planes will simultaneously take off from airports on both sides of the Taiwan Strait at 8 a.m. Jan. 29 to mark the launch of cross-strait charter flights during the Chinese New Year holiday.

At that time, CAA officials said, a plane belonging to Taiwan's China Airlines will take off from CKS bound for Beijing and four planes belonging to three mainland carriers -- China Southern Airlines, Air China and Hainan Airlines -- will take off simultaneously from Guangzhou and Beijing, respectively, to Taipei or Kaohsiung.
As the China Southern Airlines plane will fly from Guangzhou to CKS, it will be first to arrive due to geographical proximity.

CAA officials said all six mainland carriers authorized to operate cross-strait charter flights have filed applications with the CCA and two of them, Shanghai Airlines and Xiamen Airlines, have already received CAA approval.

Five of Taiwan's carriers have also presented their applications to the CAA and TranAsia Airways is the only carrier that has not yet furnished its flight schedule for approval. The CAA approved China Airlines and EVA Airways applications a day earlier.

According to a landmark deal reached in Macau Jan. 15 by negotiators from both sides of the Taiwan Strait, six carriers from each side will operate a combined 48 direct, non-stop charter flights during the Jan. 29-Feb. 20 period between Taipei/Kaohsiung in Taiwan and Shanghai/Beijing/Guangzhou in mainland China for the convenience of Taiwan businessmen operating on the mainland who wish to return for the Lunar New Year celebrations.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC REPRESENTATIVE TO U.S. MAKES DONATION FOR CULTURAL EXCHANGES
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Jan. 25 (CNA) (By Wennie Chi and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Republic of China Representative to the United States David Tawei Lee donated US$30,000 Tuesday to the Smithsonian Natural History Museum in Washington, D.C. to help bolster cultural exchanges between the two countries.
The money will be delivered to the "Taiwan Heritage Foundation" affiliated to the museum for exclusive use in promoting cultural interactions between the two countries.

Along with the donation, a show was also staged at the museum to display Taiwan's folk and traditional arts to visitors -- the first large public activity sponsored by the foundation since it was set up early last year.

DOC.HEADLINE: OVERDUE LOAN RATIO OF TAIWAN BANKS DROPS TO 2.78%

TEXT.P: The average overdue loan ratio registered by domestic banks had dropped to 2.78 percent as of the end of December, down 0.44 percentage points from the previous month's level, according to a report issued Tuesday by the Cabinet-level Financial Supervisory Commission (FSC).

According to FSC statistics, the amount of overdue loans had fallen by NT$61.6 billion to NT$432.7 billion (US$13.52 billion) as of the end of December, while loans considered prone to becoming non-performing and put under a monitoring scheme totaled NT$158 billion, down NT$16.2 billion month-to-month.
The figures indicate that the banks posted a broadly explained overdue loan ratio of 3.8 percent in December, down 0.11 percentage points from that of a month ago.

FSC officials said it was the first time the average overdue loan ratio had fallen to less than 3 percent, while the broadly defined overdue loan ratio dropped to less than 4 percent, which is the target set originally by the government for the end of this year.
The figures show that the operations of Taiwan's banking and financial institutions are improving, they added.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Wednesday, Jan. 26, or the 18th day of the 12th month of the Year of the Monkey according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1500: Portuguese explorer Vincente Yanez Pinson "discovers" Brazil during a voyage to India.
1837: Michigan becomes the 26th state of the United States.
1841: Britain proclaims sovereignty over Hong Kong.
1880: Douglas MacArthur, US general and supreme commander of the Allied forces in the Pacific during World War II, is born.
1886: Japan sets up the Cabinet system with Hirobumi Ito serving as its first prime minister.
1886: Karl Benz, German automobile pioneer, patents a three-wheel drive automobile and the internal combustion engine.
1905: The Cullinan, a huge diamond weighing 3,106 carats (621.2 grams), is found in South Africa.
1923: Dr. Sun Yat-sen and Adolf Joffe, representative of the Soviet Communist Party, issue a joint statement declaring that neither the communist social order nor the Soviet system is suitable for China.
1925: Dr. Sun Yat-sen is admitted to Hsueh Ho Hospital in Peking (Beijing), suffering from liver cancer. He died on March 12, 1926, at the age of 59.
1926: The British surgeon-general links cigarette smoking with cancer.
1942: For the first time since 1918, US troops arrive in Europe to join the struggle against Adolf Hitler's Nazis.
1949: The Taiwan Garrison Command is established with Taiwan Governor Chen Cheng concurrently serving as its commander-in-chief.
1950: India becomes a democratic republic within the British Commonwealth.
1955: The US House of Representatives approves a resolution authorizing President Dwight D. Eisenhower to deploy US armed forces to defend Taiwan, the Pescadores and "related positions and territories."
1963: Taiwan's Yang Chuan-kwang, who won the silver medal in the decathlon at the 1960 Rome Olympics, breaks the world record for pole vaulting with a jump of 16 feet, 3.25 inches.
1971: Barbados Premier E.W. Barro arrives in Taipei to confer with Chinese leaders.
1973: Ma Soo-lay, board chairman of the Broadcasting Corporation of China, leaves for Tokyo to head the East Asia Relations Association office in Japan.
1974: Taiwan's Premier Chiang Ching-kuo announces an across-the-board price adjustment to help stabilize the economy.
1974: Vice Adm. George P. Steele, commander of the 7th Fleet, visits Kaohsiung in his command ship, the guided-missile cruiser USS Oklahoma.
1975: William J. Casey, president of the US Export-Import Bank, arrives in Taipei with his wife for a three-day visit.
1976: James Wei, president of the Central News Agency, and three others leave for the United States to attend President Gerald Ford's breakfast meeting.
1979: Nelson A. Rockefeller, former governor of New York and vice-president of the United States under Gerald Ford, dies at the age of 71.
1981: Jose Miguel Alfaro Rodriguez, vice president and acting minister of economy, industry, and commerce of the Republic of Costa Rica, arrives to attend the sixth session of the Sino-Costa Rican Conference on Economic and Technical Cooperation.
1982: An explosion on a Taipei-to-Hualien express train in a tunnel claims four lives and injures 13 people.
1984: The ROC Cabinet approves a draft of the criteria for the proposed National Open University.
1987: "Multi-banking" automatic teller machines begin operation, allowing card-holding bank patrons to withdraw money from ATMs of any participating bank in Taiwan.
1989: The Legislative Yuan of the Republic of China passes the Law on the Voluntary Retirement of Senior Parliamentarians.
1996: The Senate of the United States approves the START-2 treaty to reduce US and Russian strategic nuclear missiles.
2000: Visiting Swaziland Prime Minister Barnabas Sibusiso Dlamini presides over the inauguration of his contry's embassy in Taipei.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "The use of the moral sentiment, well-balanced and kept in perfect equilibrium -- that is the true state of human perfection. It is seldom found long so kept up amongst man."

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN MANAGEMENT SETTLES AFTER M'LANDERS COMMANDEER FISHING VESSEL

TEXT.P: Eighteen mainland Chinese deckhands who commandeered a Kaohsiung-based tuna fishing boat in mid-January took control of the vessel again Tuesday after negotiations over severance pay with the Taiwan company that owns the boat were broken off.

A settlement was then reached Tuesday night when the management of the Tongsong Fishing Co. -- which owns the "Tongyi 668" tuna fishing vessel -- agreed to increase the severance pay from US$50 per head to US$500.
The 18 mainlanders are scheduled to fly back to China Wednesday, ending a half-month mutiny incident dating back to Jan. 12 when the "Tongyi 668" was reported missing at sea.
The 493-ton tuna fishing vessel, with 28 crew members aboard, lost communications Jan. 12 while fishing about 700 nautical miles off the west coast of the Maldives.
The "Tongyi 668" was spotted sailing by the British Chagos Islands Jan. 15 towards Indonesia and Singapore, according to a spokesman for the fishing company.

A representative for the Tongsong Fishing Co. flew to Malaysia Jan. 24 to look into the incident after the tuna fishing vessel was intercepted by a Malaysian navy frigate Jan. 23 after being spotted sailing erratically near Malaysian territorial waters.

The officers and crew of the "Tongyi 668" were then interrogated by Malaysian authorities, who learned that the vessel had been commandeered Jan. 11 by the Chinese deckhands because of dissatisfaction with low wages and unfair treatment working aboard the vessel, according to the representative.

The representative said that Chen Kuo-ching, captain of the "Tongyi 668, " phoned the company and his family in Kaohsiung from Malaysia to tell them that he was safe and had only sustained some minor injuries during the struggle with the mutineers.
The representative said that his company is grateful to the Malaysian navy for intercepting the vessel before things got out of control.
He quoted Chen as saying that three other officers on board also sustained minor injuries during the struggle but that they were fine.
In addition to the 18 mainlanders, six Filipino nationals were working as deckhands aboard the vessel.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT MAY ANNOUNCE NAME OF NEW VICE PREMIER DURING OVERSEAS VISIT

TEXT.P: Premier-designate Frank Hsieh said Wednesday that he is actively seeking President Chen Shui-bian's input on who should serve as his deputy and that the president could announce the name of the new vice premier during his upcoming overseas visit.
President Chen will depart Taiwan Thursday to visit Palau and the Solomon Islands -- two Republic of China allies in the South Pacific.
Hsieh said he will be able to remain in contact with the president and that "it is all right" if the president announces the name during the trip.

On the lineup of his Cabinet, Hsieh lamented the difficulties in having exchanges with talent from other political parties due to political factors, saying that the ruling and opposition parties should work together for the nation.
He also said that the lineup of his Cabinet could be finalized within one or two days.
Hsieh made the above remarks after attending the funeral of opposition Kuomintang Chairman Lien Chan's mother-in-law.

DOC.HEADLINE: SIXTH TZU CHI RELIEF MISSION TO POST-TSUNAMI SRI LANKA ON THE WAY
DOC.DATELINE: San Francisco, Jan. 25 (CNA) (By Chiang Ying and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: The sixth relief mission from the Taiwan-based Buddhist Compassionate Relief Tzu Chi Foundation to Sri Lanka following the Dec. 26 tsunami tragedy has left North America for the South Asian country to continue aid efforts there.

A total of 40 Tzu Chi volunteers from Canada and the United States are expected to reach Colombo, Sri Lanka Thursday, mainly to provide medical care and interview locals to gain a deeper understanding of their specific needs. The volunteers are expected to stay there until Feb. 5.

Tzu Chi has been in Sri Lanka's southern city of Hambantota, one of the hardest-hit areas, since Dec. 31, with Taiwanese medical personnel taking turns serving there. The Tzu Chi medical workers have treated an average of 700 people per day in the city over the past 55 days, said Ko Chi-she, a Los Angeles-based doctor who is heading Tzu Chi's sixth relief mission.
According to Ko, the mission's major tasks will be providing medical care and distributing rice to the locals of Hambantota, where the number of surviving tsunami victims is about 83,000.

About 2,500 tons of rice will be distributed over two months to the locals, Ko said, adding that 2,000 cooking utensil sets will be distributed to locals in Tangalla, another southern Sri Lankan city that was hit hard by the tsunami.
In addition, Ko said, Tzu Chi has also begun to build 1,000 prefabricated houses in the most battered areas in Sri Lanka to help accommodate people displaced by the tsunami disaster.
