DOC.HEADLINE: SOME 350,000 STUDENTS HAVE CLASSES IN 'DANGEROUS' CLASSROOMS: LAWMAKER

TEXT.P: Nearly 350,000 students at junior high schools and elementary schools around Taiwan have classes in dangerous classrooms, a legislator from the opposition Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) said Wednesday.

TSU Legislator Cheng Cheng-lung said that his finding is based on the results of an investigation of the age and maintenance of classrooms at junior high schools and elementary schools around the island.

Cheng said that 20 out of the 25 cities and counties took part in the study which found that a total of 6,322 classrooms pose safety hazards but are still in use. He estimated that there are a total of about 8,720 such classrooms in all 25 cities and counties.
Based on the figure of an average of 40 students per class, Cheng calculated that about 348,970 students currently have classes in one of these "dangerous" classrooms.

According to the study, Taichung County has the largest number of dangerous classrooms, at 917, followed by Tainan County at 862, and Pingtung County at 770. The three counties account for nearly half of the total number of dangerous classrooms tallied in the survey.
The cities of Chiayi and Tainan, and the counties of Nantou, Penghu and Kinmen did not take part in the study.
Meanwhile, the Ministry of Education pledged that it will pitch in NT$20 billion (US$630.91 million) over the next five years to renovate the dilapidated classrooms.
Education ministry officials said that the dilapidated classrooms are not necessarily dangerous and that the classrooms will regular undergo safety checks so as not to put any students in danger.

DOC.HEADLINE: TOXIC CHEMICAL CONTAINER LABELS MUST NOW INCLUDE ENGLISH: EPA

TEXT.P: In an effort to protect the safety of foreign nationals working in Taiwan, the Environmental Protection Administration (EPA) has enacted a new regulation requiring that all toxic material containers carry labels in both English and Chinese.

EPA officials said the new regulation requires that the labels on all containers for toxic chemicals, agents and substances include both English and Chinese. Signs in the workplaces where the materials are produced as well as related information documents must also be written in both languages for the safety of foreign workers who might not understand Chinese, they added.
The EPA began monitoring implementation of the new regulation islandwide Wednesday, the officials said.

Meanwhile, the EPA has made available on its official Web site the Chinese and English names of 252 kinds of toxic chemicals to help facilitate the toxicity control efforts by the private business and industrial sectors. The Web site, at www.epa.gov.tw, also has information on chemical disaster prevention measures and policies, the officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC CHAIRMAN WRAPS UP U.S. TRIP
DOC.DATELINE: Los Angeles, Jan. 25 (CNA) (By Chu Lu-sheng and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Chairman Joseph Wu departed Los Angeles Tuesday for Taiwan after concluding a week-long visit in the United States.

Wu told reporters before his departure that the government has a consistent policy towards mainland China and that the MAC will continue to work to promote cooperation across the Taiwan Strait after the new Cabinet is inaugurated Feb. 1.

For example, Wu said, the launch of the special cross-strait Lunar New Year charter flights this year is the result of efforts by Taiwan over a long period of time and represents a major breakthrough.
However, Wu said Beijing's plan to enact an "anti-secession law" and its efforts to isolate Taiwan diplomatically indicate that the mainland is still very unfriendly towards the island.
Wu arrived in Washington, D.C., last week to attend the Jan. 20 inauguration of U.S. President George W. Bush for his second term.
Wu said he also met with some members of the U.S. Congress and major think tanks during the trip to exchange views on cross-strait relations and China's proposed "anti-secession law."
He arrived in Los Angeles Tuesday for a stopover on his way back to Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Straits Times: 250 Indian pilgrims die in stampede.
Pilgrims thronging a temple festival in Western India panicked, causing a stampede that led to the deaths of more than 250 people and casting a pall over today's Republic Day celebrations.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT HAS NOT ASKED OFFICIALS TO RUN IN LOCAL ELECTIONS: TOP AIDE

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian has not asked politically appointed officials to return to the local level to take part in the year-end mayoral and magistrate elections, the president's top aide clarified Wednesday.

Su Tseng-chang, secretary-general of the Presidential Office, made the remarks in response to media reports that there has been discontent within the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) about the reported policy of encouraging politically appointed officials to return to the local level to run in the elections.

The reports said that Minister of Justice Chen Ding-nan, who served two terms as Ilan magistrate between 1981 and 1989, will soon return to his hometown to run for his old post again, resulting in discontent among other DPP aspirants.
Su pointed out that there has been "misunderstanding" about the existence of such a policy.

Premier-designate Frank Hsieh dismissed Tuesday reports that President Chen has asked the politically appointed officials to take part in local chief elections, saying that "this is not the president's policy."

Echoing Hsieh's words, Su said that the president has no such intention. The DPP is in charge of the nomination of the party candidates for the elections, he said, adding that there will be consultations with DPP aspirants and that primaries will then be held to select the candidates.
Su said that the party will give its utmost consideration to each city and county and try to enlist the best talent to serve at the local level.
"Those who come forward for the elections will have to meet local expectations, " Su said, adding that "the DPP has no such culture of designating anyone for posts."
Su, who will soon assume the post of DPP chair0an, also said that as the ruling party, the DPP will assist the new Cabinet to do its job well.

DOC.HEADLINE: NTU PRESIDENT TO CONFER HONORARY DEGREE ON NOBEL LAUREATE IN PARIS

TEXT.P: National Taiwan University (NTU) President Chen Wei-chao has flown to Paris to confer an honorary doctorate on Gao Xingjian, winner of the 2000 Nobel Prize in literature, an NTU spokesman said Wednesday.
Chen headed for Paris a day earlier in the company of Peng Ching-hsi, dean of the NTU College of Literature, the spokesman said.

The nation's top university announced its decision last November to confer the honorary academic degree on Gao, the first Nobel literature laureate of Chinese origin, as part of its 76th anniversary celebrations.

Gao did not travel to Taipei to receive the honor at the university's Nov. 15 celebration ceremony because of poor health, but he addressed the event via a 10-minute pre-recorded video in which he expressed his gratitude for the NTU's recognition of his literary career.
As NTU is closed for the winter vacation, the spokesman said, Chen decided to fly to Paris to confer the honorary degree on Gao in person.
Moreover, the spokesman said, Chen will take advantage of the occasion to discuss technical details regarding Gao's previous promise to give lectures at NTU if his health improves.

As an alternative arrangement in case that Gao cannot make a lecture tour to Taiwan, the spokesman said, NTU may send a literature professor to Paris and have their dialogue recorded as a video for teaching purposes.
The theme of the lectures may focus on "literature and life" and "literature and art," the spokesman added. Gao is both a novelist and painter.

Gao, who was born in mainland China's Jiangxi Province in 1940, left the mainland in 1987 and settled a year later in France as a political refugee. He has been to Taiwan on several occasions. In 2002, an opera written by him in collaboration with mainland composer Xu Shuya, "Snow in August," was premiered in Taipei to rave reviews.

DOC.HEADLINE: ACTING KAOHSIUNG MAYOR CONFIRMED

TEXT.P: Kaohsiung Mayor and Premier-designate Frank Hsieh confirmed Wednesday that Executive Yuan spokesman Chen Chi-mai will take up the post of Kaohsiung mayor.

Hsieh, who will be sworn in as premier Feb. 1, made the announcement after speaking at the Ketagalan Institute youth leader winter camp. The institute was set up by President Chen Shui-bian to nurture political talent.
Chen, 41, holds a masters degree in preventive medicine from National Taiwan University. He was a legislator before serving as the spokesman of the Executive Yuan.
Chen's father, Chen Che-nan, served as deputy secretary-general of the Presidential Office.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. DOLLAR UP ON TAIPEI FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar moved up against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Wednesday, gaining NT$0.013 to close at NT$31.894.
A total of US$526 million changed hands.
The greenback opened at the day's high of NT$32 and slid to a low of NT$31.870 during the trading session.

DOC.HEADLINE: FEMALE FOREIGN WORKERS SAID FORCED TO DO MEN'S JOBS

TEXT.P: A labor group Wednesday claimed that female foreign laborers being forced to do men's jobs is "anti-human rights."

The Taiwan International Workers Association (TIWA) held a press conference at the Legislative Yuan Wednesday to publicize the fact that female foreign workers have been forced to do men's jobs as a result of secret arrangements or opaque operations by labor brokers and labor affairs authorities.

For example, said TIWA Secretary-General Ku Yu-ling, 112 women workers who lost their jobs when the electronics company they worked for in Taipei County closed without notice were forced to work at steel mills, furnace plants, cement plants or heavy machinery factories.

At the press meeting, one Filipino worker said that she and three other women workers from Southeast Asia were assigned to a furnace plant in Linkuo, Taipei County, in mid January. The four of them, she said, felt so deprived and disappointed that they cried all night and could not sleep.
Many of the women workers were repatriated back to their home countries when they either could not do men's jobs or their new employers refused to have them, Ku said.
Ku added that this was probably done to make room for male foreign workers to come to Taiwan to work.
Ku demanded that the government make transparent the data on foreign workers changing jobs and that it allow foreign workers access to choice and the right to refuse jobs.

TIWA officials said that in accordance with existing labor laws, there should be open coordination meetings on individuals when they are changing their place of employment. The so-called coordination meetings, however, have been just a simple supply of basic information about the individuals without interpreters on hand and without allowing the individuals involved to speak their minds, a situation they claimed is tantamount to "an uncontrolled flesh market."

DOC.HEADLINE: CPC CHALLENGES 2005 REVENUE WORTH NT$600 BILLION

TEXT.P: The state-run Chinese Petroleum Corp. (CPC) has set an aim of chalking up revenue of NT$600 billion (US$18.7 billion) for 2005, backed on a business of NT$560 billion racked up last year, CPC Chairman Kuo Chin-tsai said Tuesday.
Kuo vowed to make the CPC a constructive tax payer and said that the company has already swung into full gear toward that objective.

Tallies made public by the Commission of National Corporations under the Ministry of Economic Affairs show that the CPC registered a pre-tax profit of NT$24.88 billion in 2004, double the level set by the government.

According to Kuo, major projects being planned by the CPC for 2005 include a petrochemical park in central Yunlin County on a 700-hectare plot near the coast. He added that the CPC is also determined to expand its oil exploration after relevant facilities at Taichung Harbor have been completed.

DOC.HEADLINE: 2005 ESI RANKING UNFAIR TO TAIWAN: CEPD

TEXT.P: The results of the 2005 Environmental Sustainability Index (ESI) ranking, in which Taiwan is placed near the bottom, is unfair to Taiwan due to insufficient information about the island, officials from the Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) claimed Wednesday.
Taiwan, Haiti, Iraq and Kuwait were placed near the bottom of the 2005 ESI ranking, with North Korea at the bottom. The ESI is an international rating of a country's environmental sustainability.

CEPD officials said that due to Taiwan's difficult situation in the international community and the fact that it is not a member of the United Nations, Taiwan lacks scores in regard to international treaties and participation in international activities, resulting in low scoring in the ESI rankings.

The 2005 ESI rankings of 146 countries and areas around the world was jointly produced by the Global Leaders for Tomorrow Environment Task Force under the World Economic Forum, the Yale Center for Environmental Law and Policy and the Center for International Earth Science Information Network at Columbia University. The rankings are expected to be formally announced at the end of January or early February.
The last time the three organizations published a similar index was in 2002.
CEPD officials claimed that it is unfair to Taiwan, as the three organizations judged Taiwan without obtaining sufficient information about the country.

Environmental sustainability is actually an effort tailor-made by individual countries in accordance with the needs and situations of that country, CEPD officials claimed, adding that they feel it is weird to adopt an international ranking based on a universal set of criteria.

They said that Taiwan was ranked low on the 2005 ESI, which is based on 2003 data, mainly because social pressure on the island was unprecedentedly high immediately after the onslaught of severe acute respiratory syndrome, the resulting decline of people using the MRT, as well as the drought in the latter half of the year, which deteriorated the water quality.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES HIGHER ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were higher Wednesday as the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for February gained 30 points to close at 5,840, with 25,518 contracts changing hands.

TAIEX Index futures for March moved up 30 points to finish at 5,845, with 255 contract transactions, while June futures increased 23 points to close at 5,830, with 23 contracts traded. September futures gained 40 points to finish at 5,755, with 20 contract transactions. No transactions were recorded for December.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Wednesday at 5,810 points for February, 5,815 points for March, 5,807 points for June, 5,715 points for September and 5,783 points for December.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were also higher.

February TE futures gained 3.25 points to close at 217.65, with 5,399 contracts changing hands, while March TE futures moved up 3.85 points to finish at 217.9, with 60 contract transactions. No transactions were recorded for June, September and December.

February TF futures increased 0.8 points to finish at 988.8, with 2,828 contracts changing hands, while March TF futures lost 1.2 points to close at 986.6, with 185 contracts traded. No transactions were recorded for June, September and December.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI SHARE PRICES END HIGHER

TEXT.P: Shares prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) opened high and closed even higher Wednesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 52.62 points to close at 5,835.37.

The bourse opened at 5,815.48 points and fluctuated between 5,847.41 and 5,810.14 during trading. A total of 2.34 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$45.17 billion (US$1.4 billion).

Seven of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with machinery and electronics shares moving up the most by 1.7 percent, followed by paper and pulp stocks by 1.1 percent, textile issues by 1.0 percent, cement shares by 0.7 percent, plastics and chemicals stocks by 0.5 percent, foodstuff shares by 0.3 percent and banking and financial stocks by 0.2 percent, while construction shares prices remained unchanged.
Gainers outnumbered losers 485 to 231, with 246 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Times: Twelve foreign terrorist suspects are to be freed from top-security prisons but kept under virtual house arrest, Charles Clarke will announce today.
The Times has learnt that the Home Secretary will say today that the dozen men detained without trial in Belmarsh and Woodhill jails are to be released and kept under permanent surveillance while agreements are negotiated with their home countries to deport them. Those to be released include suspected Islamic extremists, many of whom are wanted in their home countries for alleged involvement in terrorism.
Financial Times: Blair hints at transfer move after Iraq poll.
Tony Blair has signalled that the US and Britain will begin handing over control of large parts of Iraq to the country's security forces after Sunday's national elections, seeking to underscore the legitimacy of the newly-elected government. As Iraqis prepare to vote in a poll dogged by the insurgency, Mr Blair ruled out setting a firm deadline for the US and UK to withdraw from the country.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Washington Post: Democrats Criticize Rice Over Iraq War; Senate Confirmation Is Expected Today.
Senate Democrats delivered one of the sharpest critiques yet of the Bush administration's credibility and its handling of the Iraq war yesterday, as the Senate prepared to confirm Condoleezza Rice's nomination to be secretary of state today, the paper said.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT, PFP NEED TO SECURE SUPPORT FOR LEGISLATIVE TICKET

TEXT.P: Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jyn-ping said Wednesday that the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) and People First Party (PFP) will try to solidify support for a ticket of himself and PFP Legislator at large-elect Chung Jung-chi in the legislative speaker and vice speaker elections scheduled for Feb. 1.

Wang said that he had contacted Chung about the elections and said the two parties are discussing campaign strategies, adding that there will be a unity meeting Jan. 31 to try to secure votes for a "Wang-Chung" ticket.
He also said that he was "unaware" of whether KMT Chairman Lien Chan had discussed the issue with PFP Chairman James Soong, who is currently visiting the United States.
But he stressed that once the "Wang-Chung ticket" is formed, both men will have to pull out all the stops to achieve victory.
Wang made the remarks after attending the funeral for Lien's mother-in-law in Taipei.
Wang has been campaigning hard to retain his speaker post in the past few weeks, traveling around the island to court the support of re-elected and newly elected legislators.

Party sources said that Wang is almost certain to win re-election, as the "pan-blue alliance" of the KMT and the PFP jointly command a majority of 114 seats in the new 225-member legislature. As for Chung's deputy speakership bid, the sources said, it will depend on whether the two parties can consolidate unity within the alliance.

There have been reports that some KMT legislators-elect would prefer to support the re-election of incumbent Legislative Yuan Vice President P.K. Chiang, who is also a KMT vice chairman and who has also served as minister of economic affairs and chairman of the Council for Economic Planning and Development.
The "pan-green camp" of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party and the Taiwan Solidarity Union, which control a total of 101 legislative seats, has yet to unveil its ticket for the elections.

While DPP Secretary-General Chang Chun-hsiung, who will be a legislator-at-large in the new legislature, has ruled out running for the speakership, veteran DPP Legislator Trong Chai has announced his intention to vie for the top legislative post.
Some reports have speculated that Chai might team up with acting DPP Chairman Ker Chien-ming.

DOC.HEADLINE: VICE PRESIDENT INSPECTS SANATORIUM OVER RELOCATION CONTROVERSY

TEXT.P: Vice President Annette Lu inspected the Leseng Sanatorium for leprosy patients in Hsinchuang, Taipei County Wednesday as part of efforts to review a controversial plan to relocate the institution.
Lu was accompanied by Department of Health Minister Chen Chien-jen and members of the Presidential Office Human Rights Advisory Committee.

Authorities plan to demolish and relocate the sanatorium to make way for a mass rapid transit (MRT) project in Hsinchuang. Opposing the plan, a group of civic activists and patients at the sanatorium have launched a campaign asking that the 74-year-old establishment be preserved and designated a historic site.

Lin Po-yu, head of Taipei County's Cultural Affairs Bureau, said that any change to the MRT project will affect its cost and construction schedule and he asked the Cabinet to step in to help the county government solve the problem.
Lu pledged that the government will provide proper care for the 338 patients at the sanatorium and do its best to preserve cultural assets.
Lu said she hopes the Cabinet will work out a plan that provides proper placement for the patients while not affecting the MRT project after Frank Hsieh is sworn in as the next premier Feb. 1.
She later visited a community for the elderly that was established by the Chang Gung Memorial Hospital in Kueishan township, Taoyuan County.
The community, which provides more than 4,000 housing units on 43 hectares, was built to cope with the need of an aging society, according to Chang Gung officials.
Inspired by the idea, Lu proposed that a community for disadvantaged groups such as the poor and single parents be set up to facilitate care by social welfare authorities.

DOC.HEADLINE: ACTING KAOHSIUNG MAYOR SPEAKS ON DEALS IN CITY DEVELOPMENT

TEXT.P: Executive Yuan spokesman and acting Kaohsiung Mayor-designate Chen Chi-mai said Wednesday that he will push for city development of Taiwan's second-largest city based on the principles of "stability, consultation and progress."
Chen will take up the mayorship left vacant by Frank Hsieh, whose appointment by President Chen Shui-bian as the new premier was confirmed Tuesday.
He expressed appreciation to Chen and Hsieh for their trust in his ability to serve the southern port city.

In the initial stage, he said, the city government will focus on stability and all heads of city departments will remain unchanged. The lineup will only undergo adjustment in July "on a contingency basis," he added.
He also pledged to seek cooperation between the Kaohsiung city government and city council to solicit support across the party spectrum.

Saying that the DPP is the guarantee of quality, he cited the examples of Premier Yu Shyi-kun, who created "the Ilan experience" while serving as Ilan magistrate, as well as President Chen Shui-bian and his "Taipei experience" during his term as Taipei mayor.
Chen said that public polls have found that Hsieh's approval rating was over 80 percent and that he feels it will be a daunting challenge for him to maintain such a high rating.
He pledged to do his best to turn Kaohsiung into a "marine capital and a friendly city."

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The New York Times: Insurgents Vowing to Kill Iraqis Who Brave the Polls on Sunday.
Guerrilla groups in Iraq are trying to intimidate Iraqi citizens and scare them away from the polls with threats of death.
Wall Street Journal: Stocks Post Biggest Gain of '05.
Like toe-tapping wallflowers finally drawn on to the dance floor, investors were wooed yesterday by heartening reports on corporate profits -- and stocks waltzed their way to the year's biggest gains.

DOC.HEADLINE: CEPD, OCAC TO HELP OVERSEAS CHINESE SET UP FIRMS IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: A government plan aimed at inspiring overseas Chinese to start their own businesses in Taiwan to help create more jobs will be launched prior to the Lunar New Year holiday, an official of the Cabinet-level Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) said Wednesday.

In order to encourage overseas Chinese to set up businesses in Taiwan, the Cabinet-level Overseas Chinese Affairs Commission (OCAC) will join hands with the CEPD to launch the NT$200 million (US$6.25 million) business creation project, the official said.

The Executive Yuan's Sino-American Fund for Economic and Social Development will contribute NT$100 million to finance the project, while the remaining NT$100 million will be provided by Bank of Overseas Chinese, Bank of Taiwan and Cathay United Bank, the official went on.

Those who possess overseas Chinese identification cards issued by the OCAC will be entitled to apply for soft loans under the plan, the official said, adding that the plan is expected to offer funds to 50 applicants, creating 200 jobs.
According to the official, annual turnover from the newly created businesses under the plan is forecast to reach NT$1 billion.
OCAC and CEPD officials are scheduled to expound on the details of the project at a press conference Thursday.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN RELATIVELY ADVANCED IN ENVIRONMENTAL SUSTAINABILITY: CEPD

TEXT.P: Taiwan is relatively advanced in the research of environmental sustainability and has assisted various neighboring countries in setting up criteria and methodology to examine their environments, government officials claimed Wednesday.

According to officials at the Cabinet-level Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) , Taiwan is actually strong in this field and has helped Vietnam, Thailand, the Philippines, Indonesia and Malaysia construct a set of "pressure, state, response (PSR) " mechanisms to measure and quantify environmental performance, the findings of which have been periodically disclosed every year since 2003.

Claiming that Taiwan has made noticeable progress in environmental sustainability in recent years, especially on the fronts of pollution control and improving urban environments, the officials also acknowledged that there is ample room for the country to make improvements in environmental conservation, law enforcement and policy.

They ascribed the country's poor performance in a just-released Environmental Sustainability Index (ESI) survey mainly to the lack of reliable data and sufficient information about Taiwan available to the studying agencies.

Due to Taiwan's absence from most world bodies, including the United Nations, the country got low scores in many categories as a result of its inability to take part in international activities and global pacts, they pointed out, arguing that the poll result is extremely unfair to Taiwan.

Their comments came after that the World Economic Forum prepared to publish the results of an ESI survey in which Taiwan, together with Haiti, Iraq and Kuwait, was ranked at the bottom, with North Korea being the very bottom of the list. Finland, Norway and Uruguay were the top three.

The 146-nation poll was jointly carried out by the World Economic Forum, the Yale Center for Environmental Law and Policy, the Global Leaders for Tomorrow Environment Task Force and the Center for International Earth Science Information Network.
It examined 22 key factors that contribute to environmental performance and results, such as urban air quality, overall public health and environmental regulations.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT TO BEGIN TWO-COUNTRY SOUTH PACIFIC TRIP THURSDAY

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian will leave Taipei Thursday for a five-day state visit of Palau and the Solomon Islands -- two Republic of China allies in the South Pacific.
Chen will be the first ROC president ever to visit the nation's diplomatic allies in the South Pacific.

According to the itinerary unveiled by the Presidential Office, Chen will meet with Palau President Tommy Remengesau Jr. shortly after his arrival on the afternoon of Jan. 27. Later, he will address the Palau Parliament and host a dinner in honor of Taiwan expatriates there.

The following day, he will first attend Remengesau's inauguration for a second term after which Remengesau will captain a yacht to take Chen on a leisure voyage that will include a visit to a "dolphin park." In the evening, Chen will attend Remengesau's inaugural dinner party.

Chen will leave Palau for the Solomon Islands Jan. 29. That evening, he will view a qualifying match for the 2006 Oceania Youth Football Championship in the company of the Solomon Islands prime minister and will then attend a welcome dinner in his honor.

On Jan. 30, he will meet with an ROC agricultural mission stationed in the Solomon Islands, attend the inaugural ceremony for a Taiwan-donated hospital and visit a children's hospital. In the afternoon, he will give interviews to the media and in the evening, he will host a "thank you" dinner in honor of Solomon Islands officials, staff of the ROC Embassy and the agricultural mission.

Chen will meet with Solomon Islands Governor-General Nathaniel Waena Jan. 31, deliver a speech at the country's parliament and sign a joint communique before leaving for home, with a transit stop in Guam, where he will meet with the administrative leader and other political figures during a five-hour transit stop in the U.S. territory. He will also attend a dinner hosted by Taiwan expatriates in his honor before leaving for home.
Chen is scheduled to return to Taipei Jan. 31.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC DONATES FUNDS TO U.S. MUSEUM TO BOOST CULTURAL EXCHANGES
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Jan. 25 (CNA) (By Wennie Chi and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: The Republic of China government donated NT$30,000 to the National Museum of Natural History in Washington, D.C. Tuesday to promote cultural exchanges between Taiwan and the U.S. museum.

David Ta-wei Lee, the ROC representative to the United States, donated the money to the museum's Taiwan Heritage Fund on behalf of the government. Paul Taylor, the museum's Asian culture and history program director, received the donation on behalf of the museum.

The National Museum of Natural History is part of the Smithsonian Institution. A group of Taiwanese-Americans began pushing for the establishment of the Taiwan Heritage Fund last year as part of their efforts to boost Taiwan-U.S. cultural exchanges.

Noting that the Smithsonian Institution is the largest U.S. museum group, Lee said the establishment of the Taiwan Heritage Fund will contribute a great deal to bilateral cultural exchanges in the future and that the US$30,000 was part of this effort.

Meanwhile, the natural history museum sponsored a special program Tuesday to introduce traditional Taiwanese festivities and folk arts, including paper-cutting and making traditional figurines out of colored dough.

A film produced by the Government Information Office to introduce Taiwan's major museums, including the world-famous National Palace Museum, the National Museum of Natural Science and the National Museum of Marine Biology and Aquarium, was also shown as part of the program, while a collection of photos featuring Taiwan's natural scenery and beauty also went on display.

Taylor said the Taiwan-focused program is just the start of bilateral cooperation. In the future, he said, the Smithsonian Institution will cooperate with major Taiwan museums in organizing various exhibitions featuring Taiwanese folk music, traditional costumes and other subjects.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. OPPOSES EUROPE LIFTING ARMS BAN ON CHINA DUE TO HUMAN RIGHTS
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Jan. 25 (CNA) (By Oliver Lin and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: The United States opposes Europe lifting its arms embargo against mainland China mainly because of the mainland's human rights record, although regional stability, especially that across the Taiwan Strait, remains one of Washington's long-standing concerns, a U.S. State Department official said Tuesday.
State Department Spokesman Richard Boucher made the remarks at a daily news briefing.

Boucher said it is not the right policy decision and the right time to expand arms sales to the mainland and that such a move sends the wrong signal given the lack of improvement and the negative developments in the mainland's human rights record.

"We would, of course, have particular concerns about particular kinds of weapons systems that might be sold that could alter or change the military situation in the region, particularly vis-a-vis Taiwan. And as you know, in various cases we've expressed those concerns before, but at this point I think it's based on the human rights signal that it would send," Boucher said.

While Washington welcomes the mainland, which is emerging as a power in many areas and growing in importance, to participate more in world affairs, it also expects China to adopt international standards in various aspects such as its roles in the World Trade Organization and the United Nations and human rights protection, he said.
On the European Union's plan to adopt a code of conduct to govern arms sales to the mainland after the embargo is lifted, Boucher said he cannot reject it until he has seen it.
"We would have to look at whatever they come up with to see if it satisfied some of our other concerns," he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Moscow Times: Assad Praises Russia, Wins Debt Deal.
Syrian President Bashar Assad on Tuesday praised Moscow and urged it to play a bigger role in international affairs, expressing hope that his country's Cold War patron will balance U.S. dominance in the Middle East and elsewhere.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAITRA TO HELP PROMOTE TAIWAN'S TOURISM TO FOREIGNERS: OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: The Taiwan External Trade Development Council (TAITRA) will set up an online system to help promote Taiwan's tourism in cooperation with domestic travel agents, a TAITRA official disclosed Wednesday.

Considering that more and more foreign businessmen take advantage of their business trips to Taiwan to visit domestic scenic spots and cultural establishments, TAITRA will open the Web site in a few days, the official said.

According to the official, the main purpose of the Web site is to introduce Taiwan's 20 most-frequented tourist spots and night markets, a variety of delicious foods as well as sports facilities in Chinese, English and Japanese to foreign business people.

In addition, the official said, TAITRA has set up a tourism division which will cooperate with the Tourism Bureau, domestic air carriers and travel agents to boost the nation's tourism by inspiring foreign business people to tour the island after concluding their business activities.

The official voiced the hope that the planned online system will serve as an effective platform to help attract more foreign businessmen to stay an extra day and a half in Taiwan to tour the island after their business activities, creating US$3 million-worth of economic benefits for the nation.

DOC.HEADLINE: NO PROBLEM FOUND IN TEST OF HIGH-SPEED TRAIN

TEXT.P: A high-speed rail train passed inspections with flying colors Wednesday in preparation for a test on the track the following day, officials of the Taiwan High Speed Rail Corp. (THSRC) said Wednesday.

The test was conducted in preparation for an official trial run set for Thursday, when the train will run from the Yanchao depot in Kaohsiung to the Tainan station at a speed of 30 kilometers per hour.
Engineers from Taiwan and Japan spent more than six hours testing various functions of the train to ensure they operate properly and found no problem, the officials said.
The 345-kilometer high-speed railway linking Taipei in the north and Kaohsiung in the south is scheduled to start operations in October this year.
The Taipei-Kaohsiung route will only take about 90 minutes.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC NAVAL OFFICER COMMITS SUICIDE IN U.S.

TEXT.P: The ROC Naval Fleet Command has appointed special staff members to investigate the suicide of a naval non-commissioned officer in the United States, military authorities said Wednesday.
The non-commissioned officer, surnamed Wu, was found in his office at a naval base on the U.S. east coast by his colleagues early Wednesday morning, naval sources said.
According to the sources, Wu's colleagues immediately performed emergency rescue measures and informed their superiors of the incident.

After receiving the information from the U.S. naval base, the sources said, the Naval Fleet Command also immediately notified Wu's family in Taiwan of the tragedy and sent staff members to assist in handling the aftermath.

Wu was a member of the ROC Navy staff working at a U.S. naval base in preparation for taking delivery of four Kidd-class destroyers that Taiwan purchased from the United States in 2001. The four destroyers were originally built for the Shah of Iran in 1979, but was later mothballed after Iran canceled the deal. The four warships are being refurbished and undergoing maintenance on the U.S. east coast before being delivered to Taiwan.

In the past, Taiwan sent special naval teams to the United States to receive training and take delivery of U.S.-built warships. As the work was very complicated and stressful, military sources said, some mishaps involving naval staff have been reported in the past.
According to a recent report, the first of the four Kidd- class destroyers will be delivered ahead of schedule and commissioned into service by the ROC's Oct. 10 National Day this year.

Military sources said the Kidd-class destroyers -- to be equipped with a new missile package -- have superb naval and air defense capabilities and will provide Taiwan with an effective deterrent against mainland Chinese attacks up to around the year 2010 ahead of China further beefing up its navy with advanced weapon systems.

DOC.HEADLINE: UNAUTHORIZED PASSENGERS ON CHARTER FLIGHTS WILL BE PROSECUTED

TEXT.P: Passengers in mainland China who are ineligible to take the inaugural Chinese Lunar New Year charter flights between Taiwan and the mainland but do so anyway will be prosecuted under the document forgery law, government officials said Wednesday.

According to officials with the Bureau of Immigration under the National Police Administration, the charter flights arranged for the Jan. 29 to Feb. 20 holiday period are for the exclusive use of mainland-based Taiwan business people and their families. Taiwan students in the mainland are also excluded from the service.

Anyone who poses as being qualified to take the flights but is not will be punished according to law, the officials said, adding that domestic tourist agencies infringing on relevant regulations will also be dealt with by the Ministry of Transportation and Communications.
They urged the Travel Agents Association of the ROC and Taiwan businessmen's groups in mainland China to clearly verify the status of passengers in advance.

As of noon the same day, about 4,000 Taiwan business people and their dependents in the mainland -- 2,400 in Shanghai, 1,050 in Guangzhou and 480 in Beijing -- have applied to use the direct charter flights to Taiwan. On the other side, only nine people from Taiwan have applied to fly to mainland China during the period.

The historic charter flight deal will allow mainland carriers to land on Taiwan soil for the first time in 55 years under an agreement that six aviation companies from either side can provide the non-stop service.

Only six Taiwan carriers operated the charter flights in 2003, the first time the service was offered. The flights were not direct as is the case this year since the planes had to land in Hong Kong or Macau first before continuing on to their mainland destinations and returning from the mainland to Taiwan.
The charter flights were aborted the next year due to the mainland's refusal to talk with Taiwan over its demand that mainland airlines also be included in the charter flights.
Taiwan and mainland China split in 1949 after a Chinese civil war in the mainland. Direct trade, transport and postal links have been absent between the two sides since that time.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN UNIVERSITIES GEAR UP TO ATTRACT FOREIGN STUDENTS

TEXT.P: About 30 Taiwan universities will take part in an education exhibition in South Korea in March as part of their efforts to attract more foreign students to study in Taiwan, the Ministry of Education (MOE) said Wednesday.

Major local universities will also organize delegations to stage Taiwan higher education exhibitions in Eastern European and Southeast Asian countries as well as in India later this year to introduce their special features and attract talented students in those countries to do advanced studies in Taiwan, MOE officials said.

According to the officials, luring foreign students to Taiwan is one of the MOE's present priorities. In 2002, 1,283 foreign students pursued advanced academic degrees in Taiwan. The ministry hopes to increase the number to 12,830 in 10 years.

Latest MOE tallies showed that 1,568 foreign students were pursuing advanced degrees in Taiwan in 2003 and the number registered a 26 percent year-on-year growth to reach 1,969 in 2004. Among them, 314 hailed from Japan; 272 from South Korea; 262 from Malaysia; 238 from the United States; and 111 from Vietnam.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT'S '4 NOES PLUS ONE' PLEDGE REMAINS IN PLACE: DPP OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: Ruling Democratic Progressive Party Secretary-General Chang Chun-hsiung said Wednesday that the "four noes plus one" pledge made by President Chen Shui-bian in his two inaugural addresses remains in place.

Chang made the remarks after Premier-designate Frank Hsieh said during an exclusive interview with a cable TV station Tuesday that the government should refrain from forcing state-owned enterprises and other institutions to change their names that include the word "China."

As for the constitutional re-engineering plan, Hsieh, who serves now as Kaohsiung mayor, said that several obsolete provisions of the existing Constitution should be revised, but that the government should respect relevant viewpoints from different sectors before revision.

In response, Chang stressed that President Chen has repeatedly pledged to follow his "four noes plus one" policy -- no declaration of Taiwan independence if Beijing does not use military force against Taiwan, no alteration of the national official title, no inclusion of the "state-to-state" description in the Constitution, no referendum to change the status quo in regard to independence or unification and no abolition of the National Reunification Council or the National Reunification Guidelines.

Chang further said that Chen has also reiterated on many occasions that controversial issues will not be treated in the constitutional re-engineering process, adding that Hsieh's advocacy is consistent with the president's long-term policy and stance.

Last December President Chen proposed including "Taiwan" in the names of overseas missions and state-owned enterprises to highlight a separate national identity from mainland China, although the United States does not support such a plan, believing that it would unilaterally change Taiwan's status.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN COOPERATION WITH JAPANESE FIRMS ON TRACK: ECONOMICS MINISTER

TEXT.P: Cooperative ventures between Taiwan and various top Japanese hi-tech companies are on track, an encouraging development that may see promising projects crystallize, Minister of Economic Affairs Ho Mei-yueh said Wednesday.

According to Ho, Taiwan's strong semiconductor and telecommunications industries have helped clear the way for bilateral cooperation during her recent meetings in Tokyo with representatives from top Japanese companies such as NEC, Sony, Access, Namco, CMMI and SCEI.

All these firms agreed to further work with Taiwan's industry and help their Taiwan counterparts in upgrading production processes and promote green businesses, such as the video game industry, she noted.

Access suggested that Taiwan set its sights on devising software and chips capable of serving at least 100 million mobile phones and the semi-official Institute for Information Industry (III) will help toward that aim, she said.

NEC is assessing setting up a glass furnace in Taiwan and outsourcing its software designing business to Taiwan companies under the auspices of the III, while CMMI is planning to seek cooperative partners in Taiwan, she added.

Namco and SCEI are in particular interested in fostering local talent with creative abilities for video game designs, while Olympus and Hitachi are focusing their attention on precision instruments. In addition, NEC and Sony have promised to assist Taiwan in setting up a set of green manufacturing processes in line with the European Union's high standards.
The economics minister visited Japan Jan. 17-22 to woo investment and to thank those that have done business with Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP TO BE FLEXIBLE TOWARD SPEAKER, DEPUTY SPEAKER ELECTIONS: WHIP

TEXT.P: The ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) will exercise a maximum degree of flexibility toward the Feb. 1 elections for Legislative Yuan speaker and deputy speaker, a party whip said Wednesday.

Tsai Huang-liang, a DPP legislative caucus whip, said the DPP's top goal in participating in the speaker and deputy speaker elections is to contribute to inter-party reconciliation and smooth Legislative Yuan operations. "Our top goal is to end the more than four years of inter-party wrangling inside the legislature and inject a new spirit of reconciliation into the new legislature. Therefore, the DPP will refrain from horsetrading strategies in the upcoming elections," Tsai said.

He further said the DPP legislative caucus will not take the initiative to contact opposition People First Party (PFP) Legislator Shen Chih-hwei to seek any possibility of cooperation in the speaker and deputy speaker elections. Shen narrowly lost to PFP Legislator-elect Chung Jung-chi for the party's nomination to run for deputy speaker. Shen reportedly has already gone abroad and will not return to vote in the elections. According to an inter-party deal, the two "pan-blue" parties -- the Kuomintang and the PFP -- will cooperate with incumbent Legislative Yuan President Wang Jin-pyng, who is running for re-election, and Chung running for the deputy speakership. The two parties jointly control a slim majority in the 225-seat legislature to be inaugurated Feb. 1.

Tsai said if those newly elected or re-elected KMT and PFP legislators who are not supportive of the Wang-Chung ticket are willing to cooperate with the DPP caucus, the DPP would be willing to support any makeup of the ticket, such as a PFP-DPP ticket, or a KMT-DPP ticket.
"So long as we can form a majority alliance in the new legislature, we can even not field our own candidates to run for the two posts and instead support 'allies' in the elections," Tsai said.
The DPP caucus will hold a meeting Friday to discuss "winning" strategies and decide on whether to field its own candidates or who should represent the party in the elections.

After DPP Secretary-General Chang Chun-hsiung, who will be a legislator-at large in the new legislature, ruled out running for speaker Monday, veteran DPP Legislator Trong Chai later announced his intention to run for the top legislative post. Acting DPP Chairman Ker Chien-ming has also expressed interest in running for speaker.

DOC.HEADLINE: EVENT LISTING FOR JAN. 27 IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The following are important events scheduled to take place Thursday, Jan. 27:
10: 00, President Chen Shui-bian will leave from the Chiang Kai-shek International Airport to start his visit to the ROC's South Pacific allies.
10: 00, The Ministry of the Interior will hold a news conference at the ministry's headquarters.
10:00, The National Policy Foundation will hold a seminar on the formation of the new Cabinet and its challenges at the following address: 1F, No. 16, Hangchow South Rd., Sec. 1, Taipei.
10: 00, The Institute for National Policy Research will hold a seminar on the direct charter flight services and cross-strait ties at the National Taiwan University Alumni Hall.
10:00, The Reserve Command under the Ministry of National Defense will hold a news conference at the following address: No. 207, Keelung Rd., Sec. 2, Taipei.
10:00, The Overseas Chinese Affairs Commission (OCAC) will hold a news conference at its headquarters.
10:00, The Taiwan High Speed Railway will hold a ceremony at the Tainan Station marking the train's first trial run.
11:00, Vice President Annette Lu will receive visiting Paraguayan Senate Speaker Miguel Carrizosa Galiano at the Presidential Office.
11: 00, The Fair Trade Commission will hold a news conference at the commission's headquarters.
12: 30, The National Science Council will hold a news conference at the council's headquarters.
13: 00, The conference of National Congress of the Taiwan Solidarity Union and the inauguration of the party's new chairman will be held at Grand Formosa Regent in Taipei.
14: 00, The Council for Economic Planning and Development will issue reports on Taiwan's economic performance in December at the council's headquarters.
14: 30, World Vision Taiwan will hold a news conference at the organization's headquarters.
15: 00, Premier Yu Shyi-kun will receive representatives of the Small and Medium Business Association at the Executive Yuan.
16:00, Department chiefs of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs will hold a news conference at the ministry's headquarters.
16: 30, New Zealand's representative in Taiwan will meet with Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou at the Taipei City Hall.
17: 00, The Financial Supervisory Commission will hold a news conference at the commission's headquarters.

DOC.HEADLINE: WORLD VISION TAIWAN RAISES NT$360 MILLION FOR TSUNAMI VICTIMS

TEXT.P: World Vision Taiwan (WVT), one of Taiwan's non-government organizations dedicated to helping the underprivileged, had raised NT$360 million as of Wednesday to help those affected by the Dec. 26 earthquake and subsequent tsunami.
A WVT spokesman said the organization has so far sent 3,700 aid workers to assist in post-disaster relief work in Indonesia, Sri Lanka, India, Thailand and Myanmar.
In the initial stage, the spokesman said, WVT aid workers have so far offered relief services to an estimated 218,000 survivors in those five countries.

In the second stage, the spokesman said, the WVT will assist in post-disaster reconstruction work in hardest-hit regions, including building housing units, providing clean drinking water and electricity, public health care, children's education and psychological rehabilitation.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S ECONOMIC GROWTH MAY TOP 5 PERCENT THIS YEAR: OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: Taiwan's economic growth may top the target of 5 percent set by the Council for Economic Planning and Development Council (CEPD), a CEPD official said Wednesday.

Yeh Ming-feng, a CEPD vice chairman, said that integrating resources by creative ways and means, expanding domestic demand, speeding up structural adjustment and obtaining sustainable growth are the four basic strategies taken by the CEPD for achieving the target.

Commenting on a forecast by the United Nations that predicts Taiwan's economic growth rate will be 4.25 percent this year, less than Hong Kong's 6 percent, Singapore's 5.5 percent and South Korea's 4.5 percent, Yeh said that the U.N. may have miscalculated Taiwan's dynamism due to a lack of updated information, given that Taiwan is not a U.N. member.

The new 10 major construction projects will inject a shot in the arm to Taiwan's economic expansion by increasing domestic demand and job opportunities and improving the country's overall investment environment, he explained.

Also, he said, private participation in public construction projects increased to NT$130.7 billion (US$4.08 billion) in 2004 from NT$109.8 billion posted in the previous year and it is expected to jump to NT$186.9 billion this year, which is estimated to move up the country's economic growth an additional 0.5 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: 'MINI THREE-LINKS' HAS INCREASED CROSS-STRAIT EXCHANGES

TEXT.P: Shipping and personnel exchanges between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait have been increasing thanks to the implementation of the "mini three-links" in 2001, an official of the Cabinet-level Directorate-General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS) said Wednesday.

Taiwan took the initiative to open its two offshore defense outposts -- Kinmen and Matsu -- for direct trade, mail and shipping links with mainland China's Xiamen and Mawei in Fujian province at the beginning of 2001.
According to DGBAS-compiled statistics, travelers made 215,000 cross-strait trips via Kinmen and Matsu in 2004, up 1.5 times from the previous year's level.

A total of 3,029 voyages were made by ships from both sides, up 1,686 voyages year-on-year, with Taiwan- and mainland-registered vessels increasing 445 and 1,241 voyages, respectively, the statistics show.

Meanwhile, people across the Taiwan Strait made 470 million phone calls for a total of 1.75 billion minutes in the first 11 months of 2004, representing an increase of 18.2 percent and 27.5 percent from the previous year's level, respectively.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOST PANAMANIAN PEOPLE WISH TO MAINTAIN DIPLOMATIC TIES WITH ROC
DOC.DATELINE: Panama, Jan. 26 (CNA) (By Ramon Huang & Huang Kwang-chun)

TEXT.P: More than six out of 10 Panamanian people hope that their country maintains diplomatic ties with the Republic of China on Taiwan, according to the results of a poll published Wednesday by a local newspaper.

The poll results posted on La Prensa under the title "Taiwan is better than the People's Republic of China" show that 61 percent of the respondents are in favor of maintaining ROC-Panama diplomatic ties, while 14.1 percent prefer to switch official ties from Taipei to Beijing and 24.9 percent have no opinion on the matter.
The survey was made by LatiNetwork Dichter & Neira Jan. 14-16 under the commission of La Prensa.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Thursday, Jan. 27, or the 18th day of the 12th month of the Year of the Monkey according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1756: Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart, Austrian composer and child prodigy considered among the greatest and most prolific composers in history, is born.
1822: Greece declares independence following its war against Turkey.
1832: Charles Dodgson, British mathematician, is born. Under the name of Lewis Carroll, he wrote "Alice's Adventures in Wonderland," and "Alice Through the Looking Glass."
1880: US inventor Thomas Alva Edison introduces the incandescent lamps, which were first used in New York City three years later.
1903: Sir John Carew Eccles, Australian physiologist, is born. He shared a 1968 Nobel Prize for research on nerve cells.
1923: Former German Army Corporal Adolf Hitler holds the first congress of the National Socialist Party in Munich.
1926: Scottish electrical engineer and inventor John Logie Baird unveils his new "television" machine in front of members of the Royal Institution in London.
1942: Ace US woman pilot Jacqueline Cochran brings a bomber to Britain, becoming the first woman to fly one of the big American planes to Britain for action against Germany.
1943: The US Air Force bombs Germany for the first time when Germany begins conscription of women.
1947: The Taiping, a steamer on its way from Shanghai to Taiwan, collides with another steamer, the Chienyen, near Shanghai, killing more than 700 people aboard the two ships, which sank after the collision.
1955: The 18th US Air Force Fighter Bomber Group moves to Taiwan from the Philippines and Okinawa to help defend the island against Chinese communist invasion.
1959: The Soviet Union and Bulgaria oppose the participation of the ROC in the Third World Basketball Championships in Santiago, Chile.
1964: An explosion at the Hsingchengfu coal mine in Shanhsia, Taipei County, claims 27 lives and leaves nine others with serious injuries.
1964: Paris establishes diplomatic ties with Beijing.
1967: Surgeons at National Taiwan University Hospital perform the ROC's first major heart surgery.
1967: US astronauts Virgil Grissom, Edward White and Roger Chafee die on the ground of asphyxiation when fire breaks out in their Apollo 1 command module during a flight simulation on the launch pad.
1973: US military action in Vietnam comes to an end as a cease-fire is signed in Paris.
1974: Robert Ingersoll, US assistant secretary of state for East Asian and Pacific Affairs, arrives in Taipei for a two-day visit.
1976: More than 200 journalists and government officials, including Premier Chiang Ching-kuo, attend the Garden Party given by the Government Information Office.
1976: Harold R. Crawford, regional vice president for Asia, International Executive Service Corps, arrives in Taipei for a visit.
1981: Rupert Murdoch, Australian press baron, buys the Times of London and the Sunday Times.
1987: The US government announces the establishment of diplomatic relations with the Mongolian People's Republic. The ROC Ministry of Foreign Affairs issues a statement reiterating its position that Outer Mongolia is part of the Republic of China.
1992: Taiwan's Fair Trade Commission is established under the Executive Yuan.
1995: The United States signs an agreement with Vietnam agreeing to set up liaison offices in each other's capitals.
2000: The ruling Kuomintang's candidate Lien Chan and running mate Vincent Siew complete their registration with the Central Election Committee to run in the ROC's second direct elections for president and vice president.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "A moral man, in forming his character, forms the character of others; in enlightening himself, he enlightens others. It is a good method of attaining a moral life if one is able to consider how one would see things and act if placed in the position of others."

DOC.HEADLINE: HIGH-SPEED RAIL TO BE INAUGURATED AS SCHEDULED: THSRC CHAIRWOMAN
DOC.DATELINE: Tainan County, southern Taiwan, Jan. 27 (CNA) (By Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Taiwan High Speed Rail Corp. (THSRC) Chairwoman Nita Ing reassured the country Thursday that the goal of inaugurating the high-speed railway in October this year remains firm and must be achieved.

Ing presided over a ceremony held at the Yanchao depot in Kaohsiung County marking an official trial run of 12 Shinkansen-built high-speed rail train carriages from Yanchao to the Tainan station at a speed of 30 kilometers per hour.
The trial run was carried out without a hitch.
Ing assured that Taiwan's first high-speed railway system will be inaugurated Oct. 31 as originally scheduled despite some technical and financial difficulties.
Vice Premier Yeh Chu-lan, Minister of Transportation and Communications Lin Ling-san, and local government officials from Tainan and Kaohsiung were on hand to witness the historic moment.

In preparation for Thursday's test run, engineers from Taiwan and Japan spent more than six hours Wednesday testing various functions of the high-speed train to ensure that it would operate properly and safely.
When the new 345-kilometer railway is inaugurated, a trip from Taipei in the north to Kaohsiung in the south will take less than 90 minutes.

The high-speed rail, which will form the backbone of western Taiwan's mass rapid transportation network, will connect eight metropolitan areas between Taiwan's two largest cities. It will be able to transport at least 300,000 passengers daily when it becomes fully operational.

Infrastructure, including broadband communication systems, is being built in special zones in the vicinity of the high speed railway stations at Taoyuan, Hsinchu, Taichung, Chiayi and Tainan to facilitate the formation of special business complexes in the five cities.

The THSRC has had a bumpy performance in its fund-raising efforts. It was also hit hard when an international arbitration body ruled that it had to pay a massive amount in damages to its former partner.

Ing declined to answer reporters' questions about whether she has contacted Formosa Plastics Group Chairman Wang Yung-ching for help in raising funds. Ing said that the matter is one of professional planning and that she is not supposed to disclose details during the process.
The multibillion-dollar railway system is Taiwan's first infrastructure project being built under the build-operate-transfer (BOT) model.

Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were mixed.

No transactions were recorded for June and December.

February TF futures gained 0.2 points to finish at 989, with 2,762 contracts changing hands, while March TF futures moved up 1.4 points to finish at 988, with 99 contracts traded. June TF futures lost 9.2 points to end at 983.6, with one contract transaction.
No transactions were recorded for September and December.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN CITIZENS TO BE ISSUED NEW 'FORGERY-PROOF' ID CARDS IN JULY

TEXT.P: ROC ID cards will be more difficult to counterfeit after July when the Ministry of the Interior begins issuing new ID cards with 21 anti-forgery features, Minister of the Interior Su Jia-chyuan said Thursday.
The last time that Taiwan citizens were issued new ID cards nationwide was 19 years ago.
The new ROC ID cards will also have horizontal left-to-right Chinese writing, Su said, adding that the cards will be pinkish-purple and the color will be the same for both men and women.

Su said that it is still unclear whether the new ROC ID cards will contain a space reserved for the owner's fingerprint. "It will be decided near the circulation date based on the household registration law in effect at that time," he added.
Some human rights groups have decried this, saying that mandatory fingerprinting is a human rights violation.

As with the existing ones, the new ID cards will carry the cardholder's name, gender, date of birth, ID card number and issuance date, as well as a photo of the cardholder, Su noted as he showed the media a sample ID card.

The new ID cards will carry the names of the cardholder's parents, the name of his or her spouse, military service category, place of birth and the cardholder's address, as well as an anti-forgery bar code on the back of the card.

Probably the biggest difference from the old ones is that the new ID cards will be designed using horizontal left-to-right Chinese writing to follow legislation passed last year mandating that all official documents and related paperwork in Taiwan be changed to that format from the current vertical right-to-left format.
The vertical, top-to-bottom characters and right-to-left columns writing format has been the main style used by the Chinese for thousands of years.

DOC.HEADLINE: DEPUTY CHIEF OF STAFF, VICE MINISTER OF JUSTICE PROMOTED

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian's deputy chief of staff, Cho Jung-tai, and Vice Minister of Justice Shih Mao-lin will be promoted, according to Premier-designate Frank Hsieh Thursday.

Cho will be a minister-without-portfolio and a spokesman for the Executive Yuan. He will replace current Executive Yuan spokesman Chen Chi-mai, who has been named acting mayor of the southern port city of Kaohsiung, Hsieh said.
Chen Chi-mai will fill the post left vacant as a result of Hsieh's promotion to premier, which was confirmed Tuesday.

Current Vice Minister of Justice Shih Mao-lin will be promoted to justice minister to succeed Chen Ding-nan, who recently has announced he will run for magistrate of his home county of Ilan, Hsieh said.

Hsieh also said that he has sounded out Legislative Yuan Deputy Speaker P. K. Chiang about his being vice premier, but Chiang turned down the offer. Chiang is currently a vice chairman of the opposition Kuomintang.

Noting that the lineup of his Cabinet is expected to be finalized within several days, Hsieh said that he has been actively seeking President Chen's input on who should serve as his deputy and that the president could announce the name of the new vice premier during his current South Pacific trip.
President Chen departed Thursday on a five-day state visit to Palau and the Solomon Islands.
Cho and Shih's appointments marked the second wave of the Cabinet reshuffle since Hsieh became premier-designate Tuesday.
Premier Yu Shyi-kun led the Cabinet to resign en masse Monday ahead of the start of the new legislature Feb. 1.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange closed higher Thursday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 7.39 points to close at 5,842.76.
The bourse opened at 5,849.23 and fluctuated between 5,859.7 and 5,820.72 during trading. A total of 2.34 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$48.01 billion (US$1.51 billion).

Four of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with plastics and chemicals shares and banking and financial shares both moving up at 0.4 percent and cement stocks and machinery and electronics shares both gaining 0.1 percent.

The other four major stock categories lost ground, with foodstuff issues moving down the most at 0.9 percent, followed by construction issues at 0.7 percent, paper and pulp issues at 0.4 percent and textile stocks at 0.2 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 487 to 263, with 214 stocks remaining unchanged.

The Washington Post: Civil Service System on Way Out at DHS; White House Wants All Agencies to Have Option of Setting Own Personnel Policies.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT-PFP COOPERATION IN SPEAKER, VICE SPEAKER RACES UNCHANGED: KMT

TEXT.P: The plan between the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) and People First Party (PFP) to cooperate in the Feb. 1 elections for legislative speaker and vice speaker remains unchanged despite the postponement of PFP Chairman James Soong's return from the United States, KMT Vice Chairman and Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng said Thursday.

While the KMT's Central Standing Committee is scheduled to meet Friday to officially nominate Wang to run for the next speakership, the PFP has decided to name Chung Jung-chi for the post of vice speaker.

Previous reports said that Soong would return to Taiwan Friday to campaign for the joint KMT-PFP candidates and consult with the KMT leadership on details concerning the two parties' campaign strategy.
However, Chung said Thursday Soong has postponed his return until Sunday.
Wang said the change in Soong's schedule will not affect the two parties' cooperation plan and that Soong can still act as a facilitator while in the United States.

During the remaining few days before the elections, Chung will visit KMT and independent legislators to lobby for his bid for vice speaker, and Chung's nephew, Legislator Chung Shao-ho, will visit PFP legislators on his behalf, sources said.
Also, the legislative caucuses of the KMT and PFP are expected to hold a joint meeting ahead of the Feb. 1 elections to boost their morale, they said.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CHEN DEPARTS FOR VISIT TO SOUTH PACIFIC ALLIES

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian left Taipei Thursday for a five-day visit to Palau and the Solomon Islands -- two of the Republic of China's allies in the South Pacific.
Chen will be the first ROC president ever to visit the nation's diplomatic allies in the South Pacific.
The president will attend the inauguration of Tommy Remengesau for a second term on Jan. 28 before heading to the Solomon Islands Jan. 29. He is scheduled to return to Taipei Jan. 31.

Prior to his departure, Chen said regardless whether the ROC's allies are big or small, as long as Taiwan reaches out, it will be able to make friends and promote maneuvering space for the nation in the international community.

Chen noted that Taiwan, just as Palau and the Solomon Islands, are oceanic countries and share the Austronesian culture. It has for years assisted the two allies develop their agriculture, fishery, tourism, and has strengthened infrastructure and upgraded the education of local people.

Saying that love knows no borders, Chen said that the love of Taiwan people has been shown in relief efforts for victims of tsunamis in South Asia, in overwhelming donations to help a trio of brothers in Taiwan suffering from a rare degenerative disease known as adrenoleukodystrophy (ALD) to seek medical treatment in the United States, and in the outpouring of sympathy for an abused four-year-old girl in Taiwan, whose parents later donated her organs after her death.
The more important thing is that Taiwan has sown the seeds of love through the long-term work of overseas volunteers, agricultural mission, and medical mission, he said.
His state visit aims at cementing diplomatic relations as well as letting Taiwan people know how Taiwan's love and friendship has borne fruit with the allies in the South Pacific, the president said.

Chen also said that the new Cabinet under outgoing Kaohsiung Mayor Frank Hsieh will be based on "consultations, dialogue and stability, " adding that he hopes to bring about political stability, ethnic harmony, and cross-strait peace.

On hand at CKS International Airport to see off the president were first lady Wu Shu-jen, Vice President Annette Lu, outgoing Premier Yu Shyi-kun, Premier-designate Hsieh, Presidential Office Secretary-General Su Tseng-chang, Democratic Progressive Party Secretary-General Chang Chun-hsiung, and heads of the Legislative, Judicial, Examination and Control Yuans.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHEN TO STAY CLEAR OF CABINET RESHUFFLE, LEGISLATURE AFFAIRS

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said during his flight to two ROC's allies in the South Pacific Thursday that he will steer clear of affairs pertaining to the current Cabinet reshuffle and who will be the next speaker and deputy speaker of the Legislative Yuan.

Chen said that he has complete confidence in Premier-designate Frank Hsieh's wisdom and ability to make the right decisions on the Cabinet reshuffle, which is being carried out in line with the formation of a new legislature Feb. 1.
The president denied allegations over the past two days that he might announce the name of the new vice premier during his current South Pacific trip.
It is Frank Hsieh who will choose his own deputy and make associated announcements himself, Chen added.
"Not only I am at ease, but also the country and the media should feel comfortable with Hsieh being the premier after I appointed him," Chen said.
President Chen departed Thursday on a five-day state visit to Palau and the Solomon Islands.
Chen and his entourage are expected to arrive in Palau Thursday afternoon.

DOC.HEADLINE: VICE PRESIDENT OFFERS TO SHARE 'TAIWAN EXPERIENCE' WITH PARAGUAY

TEXT.P: Vice President Annette Lu said Thursday that she would help Paraguay learn from the "Taiwan experience" to upgrade the economic development of the South American nation.
Lu made the comments during a meeting with visiting Paraguayan Senate Speaker Miguel Carrizosa Galiano.

Lu said she is actively promoting a town-building project in Central American countries with diplomatic relations with the Republic of China to facilitate bilateral cooperation in terms of agriculture, aquaculture and energy infrastructure development.

Lu said she will help encourage Taiwanese businesses to invest in the feed and textile industries in Paraguay, where there are agricultural products such as soybeans, corn and cotton, to boost employment and the economic output of the diplomatic ally.

Lu said the friendship between Taiwan and Paraguay has remained firm over the years and she hopes both sides will strengthen bilateral cultural and economic exchanges in the future to enhance substantial ties.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT ARRIVES IN PALAU ON STATE VISIT

TEXT.P: Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian arrived in Palau from Taipei Thursday afternoon on the first leg of his two-nation, five-day state visit of the nation's diplomatic allies in the South Pacific. He will also go to the Solomon Islands.

President Chen arrived in Palau at 3 p.m. local time to a warm welcome by Palau President Tommy Remengesau, Jr. as well as over 100 Palau students and Taiwan expatriates waving the national flags of both countries, shouting "A-bian" and "tungsuan." A-bian is the president's nickname and "tungsuan" means "winning election."
The president and his entourage were greeted by large ROC national flags in front of the hotel where the group will be staying. Red banners with words of welcome were also displayed in the hotel.
The president then went to the Presidential Office to call on Remengesau, and later delivered a speech to the Palau Parliament.
In the evening, Chen will receive members of Taiwan's technical mission, Chinese language teachers as well as Taiwan servicemen serving alternative military service in Palau.
He will also host a dinner party at the hotel for Palau political dignitaries, including President Remengesau, former President Kuniwo Nakamura and cabinet members.
President Chen will lead his entourage to attend the inauguration of Remengesau Friday. The Palau president will captain a yacht to take Chen on a leisure voyage that afternoon.
Chen will meet with Marshall Islands President Kessai Note Friday evening.

President Chen's entourage includes Minister of Foreign Affairs Tan Sun Chen, Government Information Office Director-General Lin Chia-lung, Taitung County Magistrate Hsu Ching-yuan, Chiayi County Magistrate Chen Ming-wen, and aboriginal Legislator Walis Pelin.

DOC.HEADLINE: OFFICIALS TO WELCOME CHARTER PLANES FROM MAINLAND TO TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Government officials will greet historic charter flights from mainland China at domestic airports on Jan. 29, the day when the special service begins to carry Taiwan businessmen home for the lunar new year holiday in early February, an official at the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) said Thursday.

According to the MAC official, MAC Vice Chairman Chiu Tai-san, Civil Aeronautics Administration Director-General Chang Kuo-cheng and officials from the Ministry of Transportation and Communications and the quasi-official Straits Exchange Foundation will get together that day at Chiang Kai-shek International Airport (CKS) in northern Taiwan to welcome the planes coming from the mainland.

Celebrations will also be held at Kaohsiung International Airport in southern Taiwan -- two destinations connecting mainland China's Shanghai, Beijing and Guangzhou in the special service for homecoming Taiwan businessmen and their families during the holiday period through Feb. 20.
Nine flights will be offered on the first day of the direct service, to be provided by six aviation companies from either side.

At present, about 4,000 Taiwan business people and their dependents in the mainland -- 2,400 in Shanghai, 1,050 in Guangzhou and 480 in Beijing -- have applied to take the direct charter flights to Taiwan.
Officials from Taiwan and mainland China agreed on the flight model in the middle of this month in Macau, under which mainland carriers are also included in the service.

The ground-breaking deal will allow mainland carriers to land on Taiwan soil for the first time in 55 years since 1949, when the two sides split after a civil war and banned direct trade, transport and postal links across the Taiwan Strait.
It marks a departure from 2003, when the first such Taiwan-mainland charter flights took off -- operated solely by Taiwan airlines which had to fly via Hong Kong or Macau.
The flights were aborted in 2004 due to mainland China's refusal to talk with Taiwan over its demand that mainland carriers be also included in the flights.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Times: Haunted by my father, the camp commandant.
THE voice of Monika Goeth quavers when she remembers her father Amon, one of Nazi Germany's most savage camp commandants: "I have never in my life known of someone so loved, so hated and so feared." Before breakfast he would stride on to the balcony of his villa overlooking Plaszow camp and shoot Jewish workers at random with his hunting rifle. Then he would return to bed to join his mistress -- Frau Goeth's mother. Plaszow is just a short drive from Auschwitz. Some of the Jews there were murdered or worked to death. Some were sent to Auschwitz to die. Some were saved by Oskar Schindler, who wheeled and dealed with Goeth to buy the freedom of many hundreds of Plaszow inmates. Goeth personally killed 500 Jews, and the prosecutor at his trial in Cracow in 1946 called him "a modern incarnation of the biblical Satan ". He was executed. On the 60th anniversary of the liberation of the concentration camps, Monika Goeth faces the dilemma common to all children of Nazi guards and SS torturers: "How far do you separate the murderer from the father? How much of the murderer is in me?"
Financial Times: Doubt cast on Brown's figures.
Taxes need to rise by £11bn a year if Gordon Brown is not to break both of his self-imposed rules on public borrowing and public debt, according to the most authoritative independent analysis of the public finances. In its annual Green Budget, the Institute for Fiscal Studies cast doubt on the chancellor's tax revenue forecasts and calculated that he was likely to fall £6.5bn short of meeting his golden rule - only to borrow to invest over an economic cycle.
