SBC Communications Inc. is in talks to acquire AT&T Corp., a combination that could create the nation's largest telephone company and join a flurry of industry deals as telecom companies try to build muscle to keep pace with new technologies and competitors.

DOC.HEADLINE: TWO AIR FORCE PILOTS SURVIVE FIGHTER JET ACCIDENT

TEXT.P: An Air Force fighter jet skidded off the runway and exploded in eastern Taitung County Thursday, officials said.
The two pilots survived the accident by ejecting in time, according to officials at the Taitung Air Force base.
The two-seat F5F fighter jet was taxing on the runway in preparation for takeoff for a routine training flight when an engine failure occurred at around 7:30 a.m., the officials said.
This caused the aircraft to skid off the runway, which triggered an explosion in its fuel tank, according to the officials.
The fire was put out within 10 minutes, they said.
They said all training programs were suspended immediately after the accident for a comprehensive safety inspection and that an investigation will be launch to look into the cause of the accident.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOST TAIWAN COMPANIES NEUTRAL ON BUSINESS PROSPECTS: CEPD

TEXT.P: Most Taiwan companies feel that it will be business as usual during the first quarter of this year, with pessimistic and optimistic views accounting for only about 15 percent each, according to government poll released Thursday.

According to the survey results made public by the Cabinet-level Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) , 72 percent of companies questioned in December were neutral about their business outlook in the first quarter of this year, while 11 percent and 17 percent were positive and negative, respectively.
The 72 percent reflected an increase of 4 percent over the November level, while the ratios for pessimists and optimists were down by 3 percent and 1 percent, respectively.

In December, sales in Taiwan's manufacturing sector declined by 1.9 percent in value month-to-month but grew by 13.5 percent year-to-year. Total export order value dropped by 1.9 percent as compared to the November figure but rose by 15.1 percent on an annual basis.

At the same time, the December industry capacity utilization rate averaged 80.3 percent, up by 0.2 percent from the previous month but down by 0.1 percent from a year ago. Average business return rates stood at 4.8 percent, a fall of 0.1 percent and 0.3 percent, respectively, as compared to the ratios for November and a year earlier.
The CEPD carries out the survey every month to gauge changes in the domestic business community.

DOC.HEADLINE: MND TO RECRUIT OVER 6,500 YOUNG PEOPLE AS VOLUNTEER SOLDIERS

TEXT.P: The Ministry of National Defense (MND) intends to recruit 6,561 young people this year as volunteer soldiers, Fu Mao-yao, director of the MND Talent Recruiting Center, said Thursday.
Of the recruits, 90 will be women, Fu said.

Those who are qualified to submit applications fall into three categories: those aged 19-23 who have not previously served in the military; those under 25 who have already served mandatory military service; and reservists under 26 who left the army less than three years ago, Fu said, adding that they must be senior high school or vocational high school graduates or above.

Volunteer privates will get a monthly wage of NT$2,7105 (US$852.35) and various stipends. After their service period expires, they can also obtain a retirement pension and government agencies will assist them in gaining professional licenses related to their posts.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW TSU CHAIRMAN TO COUNTER PROPOSED ANTI-SECESSION LAW

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) will promote a law to counter a proposed "anti-secession law" by mainland China, TSU Chairman Su Chin-chiang said Thursday.

Su made the remarks during his inauguration in Taipei. On hand for the ceremony were Vice President Annette Lu, former President Lee Teng-hui, outgoing Premier Yu Shyi-kun, Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng, acting chairman of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Ker Chien-ming, and DPP Vice Secretary-General Lee Ying-yuan.

Su, 52, a graduate of Armed Forces University (the predecessor of the National Defense University) and formerly TSU secretary-general, said that mainland China is fixated on swallowing Taiwan, and has proposed an "anti-secession law " which will be reviewed by the full National People's Congress in March.
The TSU will not be weak, but will "speak up" for Taiwan people by promoting counter legislation, an "anti-containment" bill, Su said.
He noted that it was not part of his career plan to serve as the head of the TSU, but he was inspired by former President Lee.

"The TSU will always be on the side of the people of Taiwan, " Su said, adding that the party will work toward changing the designation of the nation, promote "Taiwanization and democratization" to move toward the goals of a stable political situation, a revitalized economy, a mature democracy and a strong Taiwan.
He also said that the TSU is concerned about underprivileged groups, and is scheduled to formulate agricultural and fishery laws for the benefit of grassroots people.

Meanwhile, former President Lee, who is considered as the TSU spiritual leader, speaking on the same occasion, said that after the Dec. 11 legislative elections, the political machinery faced a new alignment.

He noted that the "pan-green camp" of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party and the TSU fared worse than expectation in the elections and the opposition "pan-blue alliance" still commands a majority of 114 seats in the 225-member legislature.

For the sake of national development, the ruling and opposition parties need to cooperate as long as this cooperation will not deviate from the core values of Taiwan, and the TSU has no reason to oppose such cooperation or become jealous of how others may participate.
The formation of the TSU was not to gain benefits through playing the ruling and opposition parties off each other, but to stabilize the political situation, he reiterated.

The TSU must base itself on the principles of safeguarding the nation's sovereignty and retaining sufficient self-defense capabilities to help the government stabilize the political situation. It must also actively take part in affairs promoting cross-strait peaceful development to allow Taiwan to become a normal country, Lee said.

The TSU needs to do some serious soul-searching for the weaker-than-expected performance in the legislative elections, in which the TSU gained 12 seats, he said, adding that the party needs to reach out to grassroots people and offer attractive platforms to turn crisis into opportunity, he added.
Former TSU Chairman Huang Chu-wen offered to resign after the worse-than- expected performance in the elections.

Vice President Lu said that the TSU and former President Lee had contributed to President Chen Shui-bian and her re-election bid in 2004, saying that the relations between the TSU and the DPP will become even closer.

Premier Yu was positive about the TSU's contribution to the nation's democratization and Taiwanization, saying also that it is the staunch partner of the DPP and without its support many important pieces of legislation, such as the budget, wouldn't have been passed in the legislature.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN ECONOMY RATED GREEN LIGHT FOR DECEMBER: CEPD

TEXT.P: A green light was recorded for Taiwan's economy in December for the third consecutive month, meaning that the domestic economy has gone from "brisk" to "stable, " the government reported Thursday.

According to the five-color rating system devised by the Cabinet-level Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) to gauge Taiwan's economy, red means an overheated economy, yellow-red presents a heating-up economy, green reflects stability, yellow-blue stands for sluggishness and blue points to recession.

Hu Chung-ying, director of the CEPD's Economic Research Department, pointed out that the domestic economy began to slow in the fourth quarter of last year due to a less vigorous world economy, rising oil prices and interest rates and the fallout from mainland China's drive to restrict its overheated economy.

At the same time, the composite index for December fell to 25 points from 28 points in November in response to a slowed economy, CEPD officials said, explaining that should the score drop below the 22-point level, a yellow-blue color will be shown to reflect a lackluster economy.
Meanwhile, both the current index and the leading index slid to 108 and 104.2 in the same month, respectively, down by 2.4 percent and 1.1 percent, respectively, compared to November.
The 2.4 percent fall was the largest in six months, with the monthly industry production index and the manufacturing output index both setting the first negative growth in the same six-month period.

DOC.HEADLINE: FREEDOM, DEMOCRACY CONTRIBUTE TO WORLD PEACE: PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: Freedom and democracy contribute to world peace, President Chen Shui-bian said in a speech delivered at the Palau parliament Thursday.

Echoing United States President George W. Bush's promise to spread freedom and democracy to the "darkest corners" of the world in his Jan. 20 inaugural speech, Chen said that he believes a more free and democratic international community will better contribute to world peace.
In his speech, Chen explained to Palau lawmakers Taiwan's democratization experience, which he said is recognized internationally as a "success story."
He also praised the people of Palau for their efforts to pursue independence and democratization.

Both Taiwan and Palau are oceanic nations and share common values of freedom and democracy as well as the same Austronesian culture, which, he said, constitutes a solid foundation for bilateral relations.

He also thanked Palau for the support and assistance it has extended to Taiwan in its bids to join the United Nations, the World Health Organization and other international organizations. "Palau is a real friend of Taiwan," he said.

Chen arrived in Palau from Taipei earlier that day on the first leg of his two-nation, five-day state visit to two Republic of China diplomatic allies in the South Pacific. He will also go to the Solomon Islands.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER-DESIGNATE UNVEILS IDEAL OF COOPERATION, COEXISTENCE

TEXT.P: Premier-designate Frank Hsieh unveiled Thursday his philosophy of creating a political environment based on cooperation and coexistence to make Taiwan a normal, complete and progressive country.

In an article expounding this philosophy, Hsieh pointed out that the confrontation and struggle between political parties over the past few years has made many people feel pessimistic about the future of the country.
However, he said he does not feel this way because he believes the unrest only heralds the advent of an new era in Taiwan.

"The disorderly situation in the political arena will not continue for long. The situation of chaos is telling us that the old rules of the game are no longer sufficient to guide the situation we are facing. It's time to create a more sophisticated system using a new way of thinking to react to this challenge," Hsieh said.
Politically, Hsieh said, a "non-zero" model of cooperation and coexistence must be adopted to replace the old "zero-sum" format.

For example, two of the most important political issues in Taiwan -- domestic party politics and cross-Taiwan Strait relations -- have both been trapped in a "zero-sum" predicament and require the new model to break out of the deadlock, Hsieh said.

He said the ethnic estrangement and inter-party confrontation resulting from elections must be put to an end because all 23 million people of Taiwan share a common destiny, no matter how bitterly they disagree with each other during elections.
It is for this purpose that President Chen Shui-bian proposed in his Jan. 1 New Year address to create a new situation of stability in Taiwan through consultation and dialogue, Hsieh noted.
Inter-party cooperation, which is unprecedented in Taiwan, must be based on social trust and conducted in a transparent and open environment, he went on.
Such cooperation should not just be political horsetrading, nor should any party be asked to renounce its principle platforms as a condition for cooperation, he said.

"I believe political parties can keep their basic platforms and have no need to give up their basic principles while cooperating with each other on other aspects, " Hsieh said. "Each party can announce what they are reserving and what they have agreed upon with each other, which may include the priority order of policies and legislation," he added.

For the sake of political stability, Hsieh said, the new Cabinet to be formed Feb. 1 must be one that embraces the philosophy of cooperation and coexistence and emphasizes the mechanism of consultation and dialogue.
He pointed out that non-economic factors such as political unrest, a lack of social trust and cross-strait tension, are responsible for most of the problems faced by Taiwan today.
To tackle these problems requires a "Cabinet of stability" with vision, popular support, courage and wisdom, Hsieh said.

"'Restoring confidence' will be the approach to be adopted by the new administrative team to revitalize the economy. As long as the people's confidence in politics can be restored, investors will have a positive impression of Taiwan's economic outlook," he said.
Hsieh said that as the leader of the administrative team, he will bear the responsibility to build up the confidence of the people.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CHEN MEETS PALAUAN COUNTERPART

TEXT.P: Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian met Thursday with his Palauan counterpart, Tommy Remengesau Jr., and promised that he will continue to promote cooperation and exchanges between the two countries.
Chen pointed out that it was their fifth meeting and the first one held in Palau, and that he is the first ROC president to visit Palau or any other country in the South Pacific.
This, he went on, shows his appreciation for the relationship between the two countries.
Chen expressed the hope that he will be able to visit Palau again in June to attend the inauguration of a Taiwan-financed tourist hotel.
During the meeting, Remengesau presented Chen with a Palauan axe as a token of the highest honor.
Remengesau also promised Chen that his country will continue to do its best to help Taiwan join international organizations.
Chen arrived in Palau from Taipei earlier that day on the first leg of a two-nation, five-day state visit to two ROC diplomatic allies in the South Pacific. He will also go to the Solomon Islands.
He will attend the inauguration of Remengesau for a second term Jan. 28 before heading to the Solomon Islands Jan. 29. He is scheduled to return to Taipei Jan. 31, with a five-hour stopover in Guam.

DOC.HEADLINE: SEMICONDUCTOR GIANT FORESEES SLIGHT INDUSTRY DECLINE IN 2005

TEXT.P: The world semiconductor industry will post a slight negative growth this year, but it will noticeably jump again in 2006, Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Corp. (TSMC) Chairman Morris Chang predicted Thursday.

Citing the views of some TSMC customers, Chang estimated that the global semiconductor industry will shrink by 2 percent in output value in 2005 after having seen a 28 percent expansion the previous year.
However, Chang forecast that the industry will surge again in 2006 with 10 percent growth in view of a rising appetite for electronic consumer goods over the long term around the world.

According to the TSMC chairman, the industry will fall by 3 percent in the first quarter compared to the Q4 level of last year. But the market for manufacturing equipment will in turn increase by 3 percent, he added.
Commenting on TSMC's strategy to ward off a fierce price war in the international market, he pointed to "technology, capacity and custom services" as the company's approach.

TSMC spokeswoman Ho Lee-mei reported the same day that the company will show business decreases in various fields. But she said that its average sale price (ASP) will maintain stable thanks to an increase in output of high-end products, and added that the ratio will continue to increase.

According to Ho, the company's capacity utilization rate in the first quarter will dwindle to 78 percent from 88 percent for the previous quarter, while its gross revenue rate will contract to 38 percent from 40 percent quarter to quarter.

However, she said the company is poised to funnel greater investment this year into capital spending, which is likely to reach US$2.5 billion or US$2.7 billion, a rise over last year's US$2.418 billion.
TSMC is the world's largest contract chip manufacturer. It was set up in 1987 and now plays a leading role in the world semiconductor foundry industry.

DOC.HEADLINE: APPOINTED JUSTICE MINISTER VOWS SAFE ENVIRONMENT FOR PUBLIC

TEXT.P: Appointed Justice Minister Shih Mao-lin vowed Thursday to build a safe living environment for the public by improving the rule of law and clamping down on corruption and violence.

Shih made the remarks in a news conference while outlining the focal missions for his ministry. Shih called the news conference after Premier-designate Frank Hsieh announced his appointment earlier the same day.

Describing his appointment as "encouragement, approval and a challenge, " Shih said cracking down on sex offenders, illegal possession of weapons, economic criminals, human trafficking, hijacking, fraud and government corruption will be high on the ministry's work agenda.
Shih promised to do his utmost to accomplish these tasks to meet the public's expectations.
Speaking on the sensitive topic of capital punishment, he expressed his belief that such penalty will "eventually" be abolished once accompanying measures have been comprehensively ironed out.
Shih will take over the post from outgoing Justice Minister Chen Ding-nan, who has decided to quit to prepare for running for Ilan magistrate.

DOC.HEADLINE: TWO CABINET MEMBERS WILL STAY ON: PREMIER-DESIGNATE

TEXT.P: Minister of the Interior Su Jia-chyuan and Council of Labor Affairs Chairwoman Chen Chu will stay on the new Cabinet, Premier-designate and Kaohsiung Mayor Frank Hsieh said Thursday.
Hsieh said the lineup of his Cabinet has been almost finalized and that the names of his deputy and his chief of staff will be announced at the weekend.

However, he declined to confirm if Su and Chen will stay in their present posts and political sources said he failed to persuade Su to accept an earlier offer to be the Executive Yuan secretary-general.

Earlier in the day, Hsieh announced that President Chen Shui-bian's deputy chief of staff, Cho Jung-tai, will be a minister-without-portfolio and the spokesman for the Executive Yuan, while Vice Minister of Justice Shih Mao-lin will be promoted to minister of justice.

Cho will replace current Executive Yuan spokesman Chen Chi-mai, who has been named acting mayor of the southern port city of Kaohsiung, and Shih will fill the vacancy left by Justice Minister Chen Ding-nan, who will run for the post of Ilan magistrate in local government head elections set for December.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Friday, Jan. 28, or the 20th day of the 12th month of the Year of the Monkey according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
814: Charlemagne, king of the Franks and founder of the first empire in Western Europe after the fall of Rome, dies at the age of 72.
1596: Sir Francis Drake, the English naval hero and explorer who was the first Englishman to circumnavigate the world and was vice admiral of the fleet that destroyed the Spanish Armada, dies at the age of 66.
1725: Peter the Great, the czar of Russia, dies at the age of 53 after having established his country as a major European power.
1855: The Panama railroad is completed, linking the Atlantic and Pacific oceans.
1871: After a five-month siege, Paris surrenders to the German army in the Franco-Prussian War.
1909: The United States relinquishes control of Cuba.
1902: Andrew Carnegie, a Scottish steel industrialist, sets up the Carnegie Institution in Washington.
1912: A provisional senate is established in Nanjing, China.
1932: Japanese naval forces attack Shanghai following a wave of murder and arson by their agents in that city. Chinese defenders, the 19th Republic of China Army Corps, resist heroically, drawing international attention.
1936: King George V of England dies and his oldest son becomes King Edward VIII.
1939: German chemist and physicist Otto Hahn discovers how to split the atom. He won a 1944 Nobel Prize for his work on atomic fission.
1939: William Butler Yeats, the Irish writer who is considered among the greatest poets of the 20th century and who won the 1923 Nobel Prize for literature, dies at the age of 74.
1939: The fifth plenary session of the Fifth Central Committee of the Kuomintang decides to create a Supreme National Defense Council with Chiang Kai-shek as chairman.
1943: The whole German adult population is mobilized by Adolf Hitler for Germany's war effort.
1945: The first US truck convoy takes off to reopen the Burma Road following the end of Japanese occupation.
1949: The UN Security Council adopts a resolution to set up a cease-fire in Indonesia, then known as the Dutch East Indies.
1950: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs declares that the ROC will not be bound by any agreement signed between the Chinese communist regime and the Soviet Union.
1950: The French Assembly ratifies the agreement under which Vietnam, Laos and Cambodia become independent states within the French Union.
1953: The Hsilo Bridge in southern Taiwan's Yunlin County, the longest highway bridge in the Far East, is opened to traffic.
1955: US President Dwight D. Eisenhower receives full authority from the Senate to use armed forces abroad to defend Taiwan against possible attack by the Chinese communists.
1955: The US Seventh Fleet and aircraft carrier USS Midway Island cruise through the Taiwan Strait to help defend Taiwan against possible Chinese communist attack.
1974: A five-member Thai Buddhist mission leaves Taipei after a four-day visit. They brought with them two nine-inch Buddhist images made under the sponsorship of His Majesty King Bhumibol Adulyadej.
1977: A military court of the Taiwan Garrison General Headquarters sentences Wang Hsin-nan to life imprisonment for sending a parcel bomb which injured the right hand of Taiwan Governor Hsieh Tung-min.
1978: A fishery agreement is signed between South Africa and the ROC.
1979: Deng Xiaoping, communist China's first vice premier, visits the United States and meets with US congressional leaders.
1980: ROC President Chiang Ching-kuo returns to his office four days after his discharge from hospital following prostate surgery.
1986: The US space shuttle Challenger explodes soon after blasting off from Cape Canaveral, Florida, killing all seven aboard and striking a major blow to the US space shuttle program.
1997: The Chungshan, a warship bearing the name of Dr. Sun Yat-sen, is refloated by a maritime group after sinking in China's Yangtze River 59 years ago.
1998: Hiroshi Mitsuzuka, finance minister of Japan, is forced to step down for his involvement in a bribery case.
2000: The Republic of China and Panama reach a cooperation agreement on an experimental project to commercially raise mouthbreeders.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "I transmit the old truth and do not originate any new theory. I am well acquainted and love the study of antiquity."

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN SEVERS FORMAL DIPLOMATIC RELATIONS WITH GRENADA

TEXT.P: The Republic of China on Taiwan severed formal diplomatic relations with Grenada Friday, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) reported.

The ROC government regrets that the government of Grenada, lured by financial incentives from the People's Republic of China, has decided to establish diplomatic ties with mainland China, the MOFA said in a statement released late Thursday night.
"In order to uphold our national interests and dignity, the ROC government has decided to sever diplomatic relations with Grenada and cease all aid programs as of today," the statement said.

MOFA spokesman Michel Lu said that the ministry has informed President Chen Shui-bian and Foreign Affairs Minister Tan Sun Chen, who are now on a state visit to the South Pacific island nation of Palau, about the latest diplomatic development.

Lu said that Taiwan has actively assisted Grenada in various infrastructure and development projects which have benefited the general welfare of the country since the two countries established diplomatic relations July 20, 1989.
Minister of Foreign Affairs Tan Sun Chen led in person a Taiwan relief aid mission to Grenada immediately after the West Indies country was devastated by Hurricane Ivan last September, Lu noted.

During that visit, Minister Chen not only provided US$200,000 in supplies to Grenada, he also turned a US$1.5 million fund for infrastructure projects into a disaster-relief fund without any preconditions. Furthermore, the MOFA granted a substantial part of a US$8 million package for damage reconstruction work in Grenada, he added.

Nevertheless, incumbent Prime Minister Keith Mitchell, lacking foresight, incorrectly believes that by his leaning toward the PRC, Taiwan can be pressured into significantly increasing its financial assistance to Grenada, paying that country's national debt on its behalf, and increasing the Five-Year Cooperation Plan to as high as US$245 million, Lu quoted the statement as indicating.

"Despite the fact that the ROC government considered Grenada's requests to be insatiable and beyond our capacity, we still made our best efforts to assist the government of Grenada by way of the Financial Bail-out Package, the Stadium Expansion Project, and other major projects. Regrettably, Prime Minister Mitchell still found our assistance unsatisfactory," Lu said.

"The ministry is fully aware that Mitchell has been in contact with China and has been lured by Beijing, " he said, adding that "we have done everything possible to dissuade Mitchell from such behavior, but he has continued to act against our advice."

According to the statement, Mitchell visited Beijing to negotiate issues concerning the establishment of diplomatic ties with China and even sent a letter to Taipei stating that Grenada intended only to retain informal relations with Taiwan.
As a result, the MOFA recalled Taiwan's ambassador to Grenada Dec. 22, 2004, and expressed its most serious protest against Mitchell.
Lu said that Grenada's Foreign Minister Elvin Nimrod and his PRC counterpart, Li Zhaoxing, signed a joint communique on formal establishment of diplomatic relations in Beijing Jan. 20.
The Grenadan government formally notified the ROC Embassy of the decision to withdraw its diplomatic recognition of the ROC Jan. 23, Lu recounted.

Lu said that the ROC government regrets Mitchell's lack of foresight and states sincerely that Taiwan has no intention of participating in a meaningless game of "dollar diplomacy" with China and will never let Grenada waver between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait in order to seek profit.

Grenada is the fifth diplomatic ally with which Taiwan has severed formal relations within the last four years. The other four countries are Macedonia, Nauru, Liberia and Dominica. According to official tallies, the number of countries maintaining formal diplomatic relations with the ROC on Taiwan stands at 26 at present.

DOC.HEADLINE: LIEN URGES SUPPORT FOR KMT-PFP SPEAKER, VICE SPEAKER CANDIDATES

TEXT.P: Opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan on Friday urged all KMT legislators to throw their support behind the candidates of the KMT and its ally, the People First Party (PFP), for the Legislative Yuan speakership and vice speakership.

Lien made the request after the KMT Central Standing Committee decided in a meeting earlier in the day to nominate Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jyn-pyng for re-election and to support PFP legislator-at-large-elect David J. C. Chung in the elections scheduled for Feb. 1.

Lien noted that Wang has served two terms as legislative speaker and has maintained good relations with all the political parties. Versed in legislative proceedings, Wang has often coordinated between the ruling and the opposition parties, contributing to the passage of various major pieces of legislation, Lien added.
As for Chung, Lien said that the candidate for vice speaker has served as a legislator and as a member of the Control Yuan, the top watchdog body in Taiwan, making him a broad-based political figure.
In addition, as Chung was nominated by the PFP, the KMT has to give him its support based on cooperation between the two parties.
He stressed that the speaker and vice speaker elections in the Legislative Yuan are crucial to the future cooperation between the two parties in the legislature.

To show sincerity in KMT-PFP cooperation, ensure political stability and live up to the expectations of the KMT and PFP supporters, Lien said that "all KMT legislators have to toe the party line and support Wang and Chung."
KMT spokesman Chang Jung-kung echoed Lien's words by urging all legislators to toe the party line, or face the steepest party discipline.

Chang said the KMT and PFP caucuses in the legislature will each hold meetings Jan. 31, and then the parties will jointly convene a solidarity meeting with both Lien and PFP Chairman James Soong attending.
Soong is scheduled to return to Taiwan from the United States Saturday to help cement support for Chung, the PFP said Friday.

DOC.HEADLINE: NO PLANS FOR PRESIDENT'S KEY AIDE TO SERVE AS DEPUTY SECRETARY-GENERAL
DOC.DATELINE: Palau, Jan. 28 (CNA) (By S.J. Tsai and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: There are no plans to have Ma Yung-chen, a key aide to President Chen Shui-bian, serve as Presidential Office deputy secretary-general, sources at the Presidential Office said Friday.
The sources noted that a deputy secretary-general must regularly answer questions at the Legislative Yuan, and for this reason, the possibility of Ma serving in that post is minimal.
Jo Jung-tai, deputy secretary-general to the president, has been tapped to serve as a minister without porfolio and Executive Yuan spokesman.

The sources also said President Chen Shui-bian, who is currently on a state visit to Palau, has only exchanged views with Premier-designate Frank Hsieh on who should take over as Kaohsiuing mayor after Hsieh assumes the premiership.
Incumbent Executive Yuan spokesman Chen Chi-mai will be acting Kaohsiung mayor.
The sources said the president fully respects Hsieh's right to form the new Cabinet.

Lin Chia-lung, director-general of the Government Information Office and a member of the president's entourage in Palau, said that Hsieh will announce the new members of the Cabinet soon. He added that Hsieh has been meeting with those members of the previous Cabinet who will continue to serve in the new Cabinet.
Hsieh has said that most of the members of the outgoing Cabinet will stay on and that there will only be a few changes, according to Lin.

DOC.HEADLINE: NATIONAL CLEANING WEEK TO KICK OFF FEB. 1

TEXT.P: A "national cleaning week" will kick off Feb. 1 in line with the local people's habit of carrying out a thorough household cleaning prior to the Chinese New Year, which falls on Feb. 9 this year.

During the Feb. 1-7 "national cleaning week, " the public is urged to take any discarded furniture, mattresses or other large-sized waste to government-designated locations where the items will be collected free of charge.
Meanwhile, cities and counties around the nation will also hold street-sweeping activities Sunday.
Chang Juu-en, minister of the Environmental Protection Administration, urged people clean out any breeding grounds for mosquitos or other disease agents.
Chang urged the public to maintain a clean living environment. In addition to regular cleaning, the public should make it a habit to refrain from littering, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP NAMES KER CHIEN-MING TO RUN FOR LEGISLATIVE SPEAKER

TEXT.P: The legislative caucus of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) on Friday nominated Legislator Ker Chien-ming, who is also the party's acting chairman, to run for the post of legislative speaker.

The decision was made in a vote by DPP legislators in which Ker beat another candidate, Trong Chai, 54 to 16. The caucus also decided to authorize Ker to select the candidate for vice speaker to make way for cooperation with other parties.

Ker said he will not rule out any possibilities, including giving up on the bid for the speakership and running for vice speaker instead. In such a scenario, he continued, the DPP would support a speaker candidate of another party in exchange for its support for the DPP's bid for vice speakership.
The elections for speaker and vice speaker will be held Feb. 1 after the new legislature is inaugurated.

The opposition Kuomintang (KMT) and People First Party (PFP) , which together enjoy a slim majority in the legislature, have decided to jointly support two-term speaker Wang Jin-pyng from the KMT and PFP Legislator-elect David J.C. Chung for the posts of speaker and vice speaker, respectively.

Ker admitted that his bid for speaker will be an impossible campaign. He said he hopes that by joining the elections, he can help change the political environment in the opposition-controlled Legislative Yuan.
Ker said he will seek the support of the opposition Taiwan Solidarity Union and other individual legislators.
DPP Secretary-General Chang Chun-hsiung said the party will make an all-out effort in campaigning for Ker.

Chang said President Chen Shui-bian fully respects the independent operation of the DPP legislative caucus and will continue to seek reconciliation with the opposition and promote inter-party cooperation after the speaker and vice speaker elections.

DOC.HEADLINE: TWO DOCTORS IMPEACHED FOR NEGLIGENCE IN CHIU CASE

TEXT.P: Two doctors were impeached under the Civil Service Law by the Control Yuan Friday for medical negligence in the case of a 4-year-old patient who was denied treatment at several Taipei hospitals after sustaining serious brain injuries when she was brutally beaten by her drunk father.

Wu Chen-lung, vice superintendent of Taipei City Hospital (TCH) and director of the TCH Jen Ai branch, was impeached for negligence in supervision, said Hsieh Ching-hui, a member of the Control Yuan, the top watchdog body in Taiwan, at a press conference.
Liu Chi-hua, a neurosurgeon with the TCH Jen Ai branch, was impeached for medical negligence and lying, Hsieh added.

The Control Yuan began an investigation into the case Monday after the 4-year-old patient, surnamed Chiu, was declared brain dead in a Taichung hospital in central Taiwan Sunday after being in a coma for two weeks.

The ill-fated child fell unconscious after being beaten by her father on the night of Jan. 10. She was refused admittance to Taipei City Hospital's Jen Ai branch, and no other city hospital would admit her during the first crucial hours because there were no beds or necessary facilities available.

The child was eventually taken by ambulance more than 100 kilometers to Taichung for treatment in the early morning hours of Jan. 11, where she underwent two emergency surgeries. She never awoke from her coma.

Hsieh quoted a Control Yuan investigation report as indicating that Dr. Liu Chi-hua lied to medical authorities that another neurosurgeon at the Jen Ai branch, Lin Chih-nan, who was supposed to be on duty at the time when the child was rushed to Jen Ai Jan. 10, was in the emergency ward and decided that the child should be transferred to another hospital because Jen Ai's intensive care unit ward was already full.

Lin Chih-nan later confessed that he had not examined the CAT scans of the critically-injured child when he insisted on transferring her to another hospital on the grounds that Jen Ai was unable to treat the child.

Later police investigations showed that Lin wasn't even in the hospital's ICU ward on the third floor between 2: 05 a.m. and 4: 27 a.m. on Jan. 10 while Chiu was awaiting treatment in the hospital's emergency ward.
Investigators also found that Liu had assisted Lin in making false statements on the girl's medical records.
Liu was impeached while Lin was not because Lin is not a government employee, Hsieh pointed out.
Chiu's father has been arrested on charges of child abuse, while a number of medical professionals and officials in Taipei have been disciplined for negligence.

Chang Hang, director of the Taipei City Department of Health and superintendent of Taipei City Hospital, resigned as a result of the public outcry over the abused child being denied admission to several hospitals in Taipei in the first crucial hours.
The tragedy triggered an uproar which led to judicial investigations into why the child was refused treatment when there were sufficient beds in the Taipei hospitals.
Chang was not impeached because he had only been serving as superintendent of Taipei City Hospital for 10 days when the tragedy occurred, Hsieh said.
Chiu's ordeal highlighted the flaws and deficiencies in Taiwan's medical system and alerted the central and local governments to take necessary steps to plug the holes, Hsieh added.

"We won't let the girl's death be in vain, " Chang said. "We have worked out 10 measures, including strengthening the hospital transfer network in the emergency medical system, to prevent a recurrence of this tragedy."
The Cabinet-level Department of Health announced last Friday that it would make changes to the existing system for patient transfers. The new system will take effect in June.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW CABINET TO MAKE ITS DEBUT FRIDAY

TEXT.P: The new Cabinet to be led by Premier-designate Frank Hsieh was scheduled to make its debut Friday, although the appointment of the vice premier is still up in the air, Executive Yuan spokesman-designate Cho Jung-tai said earlier in the day.
Hsieh will meet with the incumbent Cabinet members who have been retained and the new appointees at a tea party, as the ongoing Cabinet lineup is almost completed, said Cho.
Hsieh, mayor of the southern port city of Kaohsiung, was appointed premier by President Chen Shui-bian Tuesday ahead of the start of a new legislature Feb. 1.
Hsieh said earlier in the day that he welcomes all sectors of Taiwan society to recommend candidates for him to choose from to be the new vice premier.

Hsieh will not exclude any possibility concerning the vice premiership appointment, Cho said, adding that individuals with exceptional backgrounds in economics and finance, talent from the private sector, talent from opposition parties or even sitting Cabinet ministers, are all possible candidates for vice premier. The appointment will be decided by Jan. 31, Cho noted.
Meanwhile, Hsieh is also expected to announce the appointment of the Executive Yuan secretary-general Jan. 31, one day before the new Cabinet is sworn in.
As with the incumbent one, the new Cabinet will have a lineup of the heads of eight ministries, two commissions and seven ministers without portfolios.

DOC.HEADLINE: PARTIES TO BE HELD AT CKS AIRPORT TO WELCOME MAINLAND CHINA CARRIERS

TEXT.P: Three cocktail receptions will be held at Chiang Kai-shek (CKS) International Airport Saturday to welcome the arrivals of six direct cross-Taiwan Strait charter flights operated by mainland Chinese carriers, aviation sources said Friday.

According to a landmark cross-strait deal reached in Macau Jan. 15, six carriers from each side will operate a total of 48 round-trip, non-stop charter flights during the Jan. 29-Feb. 20 period between Taipei/Kaohsiung in Taiwan and Shanghai/Beijing/Guangzhou in mainland China to accommodate home-bound Taiwan businessmen operating on the mainland for the upcoming Lunar New Year celebrations.

China Southern Airlines will be the first mainland carrier to ever make a landing at CKS Airport, Taiwan's main gateway. Its maiden charter flight from Guangzhou is scheduled to land at around 10 a.m. Ten minutes later, a Xiamen Airlines charter plane from Guangzhou will arrive.

China Airlines (CAL) , Taiwan's largest carrier, which has been commissioned to handle ground services for four mainland carriers, will host a cocktail reception at the D6 district of the airport's second terminal to welcome the arrival of the two mainland charter planes.

Han Liang-chung, CAL's public relations division chief, said that Billy K.C. Chang, director-general of the Civil Aeronautic Administration (CAA), will be the only government official invited to attend the welcoming party. The Beijing authorities have been extremely sensitive about any official contact with Taiwan due to its "one China" policy. Han said Chang is invited mainly because the CAA is charge of civil aviation affairs.
CAL Chairman Chiang Yao-chung and Chairman Fan Chih-chiang of TransAsia Airways, which is Xiamen Airlines' ground service agent, will also attend the reception, Han added.

A TransAsia spokesman said the Xiamen Airlines charter flight has been fully booked by Taiwan businessmen from the Guangzhou and Xiamen areas. Xiamen Airlines General Manager Wu Rongnan had invited the presidents of Taiwanese trade associations in Xiamen, Quanzhou and Zhangzhou cities in the southeastern mainland province of Fujian to take the airline's maiden charter flight to Taiwan, the spokesman added.

A second cocktail reception is scheduled to take place later to welcome the arrival of the maiden charter flights of China Eastern Airlines and Shanghai Airlines from Shanghai. The third welcoming party will take place shortly afterwards for the arrival of the maiden flights of Air China and Hainan Airlines from Beijing.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES HIGHER ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were higher Friday as the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for February gained 40 points to close at 5,874, with 32,141 contracts changing hands.
TAIEX Index futures for March gained 52 points to finish at 5,885, with 501 contracts traded, while June futures gained 52 points to close at 5,870, with 22 contracts traded.
September futures gained 42 points to close at 5,790, with 15 contracts traded, while December futures moved up 50 points to end at 5,785, with two contract transactions.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Friday at 5,834 for February, 5,833 for March, 5,818 for June, 5,748 for September and 5,735 for December.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were higher.

February TE futures moved up 2.7 points to close at 220, with 6,007 contracts traded, while March TE futures gained three points to finish at 220.2, with 183 contract transactions. June TE futures moved up 2.85 points to finish at 220, with four contracts traded.
No transactions were recorded for September and December.

February TF futures gained 6.2 points to finish at 995.2, with 4,748 contracts changing hands, while March TF futures moved up 5.8 points to finish at 993.8, with 259 contracts traded. September TF futures moved up 7.2 points to close at 994.2, with one contract changing hands.
No transactions were recorded for June and December.

DOC.HEADLINE: INCOMING CABINET SPOKESMAN PLEDGES TO DO GOOD JOB

TEXT.P: Incoming Cabinet spokesman Cho Jung-tai pledged Friday to do a good job after taking office and said he will "try to compete as an MP3 player, " apparently a reference to similes professed by previous spokesmen, who have likened their positions to fax machines and spin doctors.
Cho, who is currently a deputy secretary-general to the Presidential Office, said he hopes this will draw favor from his listeners.
Cho said he exchanged views with outgoing Cabinet spokesman Chen Chi-mai a few days ago on the post and that Chen shared his experiences with him.

Chen will become acting Kaohsiung mayor after leaving the Cabinet, taking the place of Frank Hsieh, who will be sworn in as premier Feb. 1. The position is expected to pave the way for Chen's bid to run for Kaohsiung mayor in 2006.
Asked if he intends to follow Chen's example and run for Taipei mayor in the future, Cho said he has no such plans.

DOC.HEADLINE: DEVELOPMENT OF OPPOSITION ALLIANCE STILL WORRIES KMT CHAIRMAN

TEXT.P: Opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan said Friday that although the "pan-blue alliance" of the KMT and the People First Party won the legislative elections late last year, the development of the alliance is still worrying him.

Lien made the remarks while hosting a luncheon for more than 80 retired generals, including Hau Pei-tsun, Ho Chi-hao, Wang Ching-hsu, Liu Ho-chien, Chiang Chung-lin and Hsu Li-nung, prior to Chinese New Year, which falls on Feb. 9, to express his appreciation for their years of service.

Lien said that 2004 marked a crucial year for the nation, claiming that the March 20 presidential election, in which President Chen Shui- bian won re-election by a slim margin, resulted in "grave consequences" whose reverberations are still being acutely felt.

The "pan-blue alliance" filed two separate lawsuits over the result of the election and the election itself, both of which were thrown out. The alliance has continued to appeal the cases, despite having no evidence whatsoever to back their allegations.

Lien said that in the Dec. 11, 2004 legislative elections, although the "pan-blue alliance" was not favored, it managed to keep a majority of 114 seats in the 225-member legislature. Looking ahead, however, a lot of people are still disappointed and worried about the development of the alliance, Lien said.

He also said that the KMT must renew itself "to keep in time with the changing environment and meet the needs of the people," but added that the party will continue to insist on its fundamental beliefs "to safeguard the dignity" of the Constitution.

Hau, who served as premier under then-President Lee Teng-hui, said that only Lien can accomplish the integration of the "pan-blue alliance, " adding that a merger of the opposition force of the KMT, the PFP and the New Party is the only road for all three parties.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP CHAIRMAN BY-ELECTION TO BE HELD SUNDAY

TEXT.P: A by-election for the chairman of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) will be held Sunday and party officials have been urging DPP members to come out in droves to vote.
Su Tseng-chang, secretary-general of the Presidential Office, is the sole candidate in the race and has been traveling around the country over the past few weeks trying to secure votes.

He is hoping for a high turnout, noting that Frank Hsieh, Kaohsiung mayor and premier-designate, registered only around 10 percent of the turnout when he was also a sole candidate in previous DPP chairman elections.
There are 347,000 eligible DPP voters for the chairman election, sources said.

The by-election was made necessary after President Chen Shui-bian stepped down from his concurrent post as DPP chairman to take responsibility for the worse-than-expected performance of the party in the Dec. 11 legislative elections. The DPP garnered 89 seats, far less than its target of more than 100 seats in the 225-member legislature.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange closed higher Friday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 37.17 points to close at 5,879.93.
The bourse opened at 5,845.59 and fluctuated between 5,902.72 and 5,836.47 during trading. A total of 3.05 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$63.58 billion (US$1.99 billion).

Six of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with construction issues moving up the most at 1.8 percent, followed by machinery and electronics shares at 1.2 percent, cement stocks, textile stocks and paper and pulp issues all at 0.2 percent and banking and financial shares at 0.1 percent.
The two other major stock categories lost ground, with plastics and chemicals shares moving down at 0.4 percent and foodstuff issues losing 0.3 percent.
Gainers outnumbered losers 605 to 184, with 180 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. DOLLAR DOWN ON TAIPEI FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar lost ground against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Friday, dropping NT$0.061 to close at NT$31.802.
A total of US$584 million changed hands during the day's trading.
The greenback opened at the day's high of NT$31.863 and hit a low of NT$31.770.

DOC.HEADLINE: ACADEMIA SINICA PRODUCES DIGITAL TIME/SPACE ENVIRONMENTS

TEXT.P: History readers have often felt something is missing or inconsistent when they try to connect historical characters with their time and space backgrounds, according to Academia Sinica researchers.

Two newly developed digital systems on mainland China and Taiwan's historical and cultural maps may help address that problem and will definitely be valuable references for historical and cultural research, an Academia Sinica researcher said Friday.

The Academia Sinica's Institute of History and Philology has just completed the Time/Space Infrastructure of the Chinese Civilization and the Taiwan Historical and Cultural Map System based on the knowledge and technology provided by the cutting-edge Geographic Information System (GIS), said Fan Yi-chun, a deputy researcher with the institute.

The Time/Space Infrastructure of the Chinese Civilization contains more than 2,000 years of Chinese history expanding from pre-history to the Ching dynasty, compiled based on the mammoth electronic archive on Chinese civilization compiled by Academic Sinica, data on food price structures in the Ching dynasty, a chorography of the Ming and Ching dynasties, and other historical data, according to Fan.

The system was compiled based on a Taiwan historical and cultural map; a digital archive on Taiwan studies; data on maritime and aerospace navigation in the Taiwan area; a map of Taiwan's fortresses and military structures; a Taiwan topography and a collection of place names in Taiwan, Fan added.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Washington Post: Bush Faces New Skepticism From Republicans on Hill.
When President Bush flies to this Allegheny mountain resort Friday to meet congressional Republicans, he will encounter a party far less malleable and willing to follow his lead than it has been for the past four years, the paper said.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW NAVAL COMMANDER-IN-CHIEF NAMED

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian has appointed Chen Pang-chi, director of the General Political Warfare Bureau of the Ministry of National Defense (MND) , to serve as navy commander-in-chief.
The MND said that Chen will be the first person appointed from the marine corps to head the navy. His appointment will take effect Feb. 1.

Sources said that President Chen Shui-bian has met with Chen several times recently, and as incumbent Naval Commander-in-Chief Miao Yung-ching is going to step down, his appointment has been subject to much speculation.
After Chen's appointment, there will be a new wave of changes in the military top brass in March, sources also said.
Vice Minister of National Defense Hu Cheng-pu will take over the vacancy left by Chen.

DOC.HEADLINE: PUBLIC TO BE ABLE TO APPLY FOR HOUSEHOLD REGISTRATION IN ENGLISH

TEXT.P: The Ministry of the Interior said Friday that from Feb. 1, the public will be able to apply for household registration in English.
The application for English-language household registry will take six days to process, at a cost of NT$150 (US$4.7) per copy.
Applicants will need to submit their passports or documents bearing their English names, as well as their IDs and seals.

DOC.HEADLINE: ACADEMIA SINICA PRESIDENT CALLS PUBLIC ATTENTION TO POLLUTION PROBLEM

TEXT.P: Academia Sinica President Lee Yuan-tseh called public attention Friday to the pollution problem in Taiwan, which he attributed to urbanization.

Lee said tongue-in-cheek that this pollution has contributed to the successful control of malaria in Taiwan, because the oily ditchwater in urban areas has made it impossible for mosquito larvae to survive.
Lee made the comments during the presentation of an Academia Sinica report on the hygiene history of ethnic Chinese societies.

According to Academia Sinica historian Liang Chi-tzu, the Japanese colonial government failed in its attempts to eliminate malaria in farm villages in eastern Taiwan from 1920 to 1930, but its subsequent anti-malaria efforts in urban areas along the west coast were successful.
Lee recalled that ditchwater was clear when he was a child, but has become oily since urbanization began in the late 1960s, leaving no room for the survival of aquatic life.
Liu Shih-yung, another Academia Sinica historian, said technological improvements and ecological surveys done by the Japanese colonial government were of great help in the control of malaria.
The Republic of China government followed the anti-malaria measures in the 1950s after taking power in Taiwan, and malaria was no longer one of Taiwan's top 10 killers by 1956, Liu said.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC PRESIDENT ENJOYS SNORKELING IN PALAU
DOC.DATELINE: Palau, Jan. 28 (CNA) (By Tsai Shu-jung & Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian went snorkeling in the South Pacific island country of Palau Friday, where he is paying a two-day state visit.
Chen said after his first underwater experience that he saw an enchanting world under the sea and that he would have liked to have stayed longer.

Chen was accompanied by his deputy chief of staff, Huang Chih-fang, Lin Ching-chang, a consultant member of the National Security Council and Liu Shih-chung, a consultant at the Presidential Office's secretarial department.
During his 15 minutes in the water, Chen, a non-swimmer, was guarded by three Palauan police patrol boats and his own bodyguards.
He arrived in Palau Thursday for a two-day official visit to attend the Jan. 28 inauguration of Palau President Tommy Remengesau Jr. for his second term.
Palau is Chen's first leg of a two-nation, five-day state visit to two ROC diplomatic allies in the South Pacific region that will also take him to the Solomon Islands.
He is scheduled to leave for the Solomon Islands Jan. 29. before flying back to Taipei Jan. 31. During the return trip, the president will have a five-hour stopover in Guam.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC, GRENADA SEVER TIES DUE TO INSATIABLE DEMANDS FROM GRENADA: VP

TEXT.P: Vice President Annette Lu said Friday that Taiwan has been unable to meet the "insatiable demands" of Grenada Prime Minister Keith Mitchell, which she said led to the severance of diplomatic relations with the Caribbean country.
Lu made the remarks on the sidelines of a trip to a factory belonging to the I-mei Food Company in Taoyuan, northern Taiwan.

The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) announced earlier in the day that the government had severed formal diplomatic relations with Grenada Friday as it had decided to establish diplomatic ties with the People's Republic of China, lured by Beijing's offers of cash and aid.

Lu said that the severance of diplomatic relations highlights the fact that the mainland is using every possible means to try to squeeze Taiwan's living space internationally and is using "dollar diplomacy" to lure allies from Taiwan.
She said that Beijing was able to scuttle ROC-Grenada relations because Taiwan could not meet the "insatiable demands" from Mitchell and that she felt Beijing's efforts were "shameful."

She expressed the hope that Taiwan will increase substantive exchanges in technology, industry, culture, academia and women's issues with other nations and not focus simply on counting the number of its diplomatic allies.
However, Taiwan will still try to safeguard its relations with its allies with the maximum sincerity and goodwill, the vice president added.
Grenada is the fifth diplomatic ally with which Taiwan has severed formal relations within the last four years. The other four countries are Macedonia, Nauru, Liberia and Dominica.
According to official tallies, the number of countries maintaining formal diplomatic relations with Taiwan stands at 26.

DOC.HEADLINE: ENVIRONMENTAL CHIEF TO REMAIN IN CABINET

TEXT.P: Environmental Protection Administration (EPA) Administrator Chang Juu-en confirmed Friday that he will retain his current post in the impending Cabinet reshuffle.
Chang, formerly a National Cheng Kung University professor, joined the government in April 2001 as EPA deputy chief. He succeeded Hau Lung-pin as the top EPA administrator in October 2003.

Chang said he will continue to promote the policy of having all garbage classified and recycled and will formulate effective measures to cope with the Kyoto Protocol requirements for reduction in greenhouse gas emissions.

In the future, he went on, the EPA will also streamline industrial waste management, promote a new environmental protection code of conduct, encourage public participation in environmental cleanup and ecological conservation and participate in more international environmental protection activities.

DOC.HEADLINE: OVER 600 TO FLY FROM BEIJING TO TAIWAN ON FIRST DAY OF CHARTER FLIGHTS
DOC.DATELINE: Beijing, Jan. 28 (CNA) (By Stanley Chung and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: More than 600 Taiwan businessmen and their dependents have been verified as eligible by the Taiwan Businessmen's Association in Beijing to take Jan. 29 charter flights home for the Lunar New Year holiday, a spokesman for the association said Friday.

The spokesman told CNA that a total of 673 Taiwan businessmen and their dependents in Beijing have been approved by the association to board the direct charter flights on the first day of the service, arranged by Taiwan and mainland China during the holiday period.

Some 193 and 185 of them will make the flight on Taiwan-based China Airlines and EVA Airways, while mainland-based Air China and Hainan Airlines will carry 141 and 154 passengers, respectively, on that day, he said.

According to aviation companies, the ground-breaking Taipei-Beijing flight agreement means a lot to them owing to the two cities' special status, despite the fact that Beijing is not home to the largest number of Taiwan businessmen operating on the mainland.

It would be the very first step toward the opening of full air links between Taiwan and the mainland, they claimed, adding that celebrations will be held Jan. 29 at both the Taiwan and Beijing airports to mark the maiden flights. A total of nine flights will be provided on the first day of the service.

Six aviation companies on either side will provide the service from Jan. 29-Feb. 20 on a "non-stop, round-trip, multi-destination" model that was agreed upon in mid-January in Macau by representatives from the two sides of the Taiwan Strait.

Taiwan's Kaohsiung and mainland China's Beijing and Guangzhou are new additions to the direct services, marking a difference from the first time the flights were offered in 2003, when they were operated only by Taiwan airlines on the Taipei-Shanghai route via Hong Kong or Macau.

The landmark deal will allow mainland airlines to land in Taiwan for the first time in more than 55 years since 1949, when direct transport, trade and postal links were severed in the wake of a civil war.
The service was aborted in 2004 as a result of Beijing's reluctance to talk with Taiwan over its demand that mainland carriers also be permitted to take part.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Times: Terror blitz as Iraq seals borders for election day.
Iraq last night began locking down its cities before Sunday's election as insurgents bent on derailing the country's first free vote in half a century stepped up their campaign of terror. As many as 19 Iraqis were killed in a spate of attacks on security forces, election officials and polling stations around the country. A videotape published on an Islamic website by followers of the Jordanian terrorist Abu Musab al-Zarqawi showed the killing of a man described as a secretary of Iyad Allawi, the Iraqi Prime Minister.
Financial Times: EU drug chief urges shake-up.
The European Union's top medicines regulator has called for a radical shake-up in drug safety with greater monitoring and independently funded research to identify problems with treatments already used by patients. Thomas Lonngren, director general of the European Medicines Agency (EMEA) said that although the EMEA relied on a network of regulators and medical researchers across the EU's 25 member states,"We do not have any intensive drug monitoring system.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Moscow Times: Putin Expresses His Shame for Russia.
As world leaders and death camp survivors mourned victims of the Holocaust on the 60th anniversary of the liberation of the Auschwitz death camp, President Vladimir Putin acknowledged Thursday that anti-Semitism and xenophobia had surfaced in Russia, tackling an issue that the Kremlin had long failed to confront directly.

DOC.HEADLINE: GIO OFFERS FUNDS FOR DOCUMENTING PROMINENT TAIWAN FIGURES

TEXT.P: The Government Information Office (GIO) will provide NT$32 million (US$1 million) for documenting outstanding individuals in Taiwan and the films will be broadcast on the Discovery Channel across Asia, Deputy Director-General Yih Jung-tzung said Friday.

Speaking at a news conference, Yih said that the "Portraits Taiwan" project will again team the GIO with Discovery to allow for more exchanges between Taiwan's document film-makers and international media and to help local people promote their products on the world stage.

Six leading figures, each from the areas of business, technology, social welfare, arts, mass culture and entertainment, as well as education and sports, will be subjects of the films to present Taiwan's vigor and spirit to the international community, Yih said.
According to the GIO deputy chief, six teams will be selected and talented directors, screen writers and producers will be needed for the mission.
Those interested in the project can go to www.gio.gov.tw and www.discoverychannel.com.tw for details.

DOC.HEADLINE: ACID RAIN STILL PRESENT IN NORTHERN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Up to 70 percent of the rain that falls in northern Taiwan is acidic, with its acidity equaling that of soda water or tomato juice, according to a report released recently by the Environmental Protection Administration (EPA).
The survey was conducted by the National Central University (NCU) at the EPA's commission. It is based on data gathered since 1990 through a national acid-rain monitoring network.

The survey found that the acid content of rain falling in major urban areas such as Taipei, Kaohsiung and Chungli fell after surcharges were imposed on the purchase of materials that contributed to pollution, such as gasoline and coal. However, the rain is still somewhat acidic.

Ho Shun-chin, chief of the EPA's Department of Air Quality Protection and Noise Control, said sulfur oxide and nitrogen oxide in urban rainwater have dropped only slightly, with the pH level of rainwater standing at 4.91 in Taipei, 4.61 in Chungli and 4.86 in Kaohsiung.

Acids have pH values under 7, and alkalis have pH values over 7. If a substance has a pH value of 7, it is neutral -- neither acidic nor alkaline. The pH scale is logarithmic so a one digit change represents a 10-times difference.
Normal rain has a pH of about 5.6. This is because naturally present carbon dioxide from the Earth's atmosphere dissolves in the rain to form carbonic acid.

It was found that more than 50 percent of the pollutants that caused acid rain were from mainland China, and the content of sulfur oxide in rainwater in autumn and winter -- the season of northeast winds -- is double that of rainwater in summer.

Lin Neng-huei, head of NCU's Department of Atmospheric Sciences, said Taiwan's efforts to reduce sulfur oxide emissions, such as the use of surcharges and requiring the use of low-sulfur fuel oil, have not lead to significant improvement in the acid rain problem mainly because the pollutants come from the mainland.

Lin pointed out that sulfur oxide emissions on the mainland are increasing year after year owing to its rapid economic development, and he proposed that Taiwan and the mainland set up a platform for sharing data to tackle the problem.
Although acid rain does no immediate harm to humans and the environment, it can erode metals and cause sickness in trees over a long period of time, Lin said.
People with allergies should also limit their exposure to rain, which may cause allergic skin reactions and loss of hair, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The New York Times: Bush Says Iraqi Leaders Will Want U.S. Forces to Stay to Help.
President Bush said in an interview that he would withdraw U.S. forces from Iraq if the new government asked him to do so.
Wall Street Journal: P&G to Buy Gillette for $54 Billion.
Procter & Gamble Co., rejuvenated after an aggressive push into the women's beauty business, has struck a deal to march into men's grooming as well by buying Gillette Co. for about $54 billion in stock. The move will strengthen its clout with retailers and deepen its presence on supermarket -- and bathroom -- shelves.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN PAID US$36 PER BARREL OF OIL ON AVERAGE IN 2004: DGBAS

TEXT.P: Taiwan paid US$36 a barrel on average for imported crude oil last year, a jump of 28.1 percent over the 2003 average, according to the newest government statistics.

The international price of oil peaked in October last year, with per-barrel prices averaging an historic high of US$45.4 before falling back to US$35.9 in December, the tallies compiled by the Cabinet-level Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS) showed.

Fanned by tensions in the Middle East and a political crisis in Nigeria, as well as strong demand from Brazil, India, mainland China and Russia and a cooler than expected winter, high oil prices have showed no signs of abating in the world market, DGBAS officials said.
At the same time, prices for raw and industrial materials also surged in 2004, the third consecutive year of increases, putting heavy pressure on government finances, they said.

On average, prices of import products increased by 11.8 percent in U.S. dollar terms for Taiwan last year, they pointed out, noting that the country relied heavily on imports for prime materials and farm goods -- 70 percent of all such inbound shipments.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER-DESIGNATE GATHERS NEW CABINET FOR PEP TALK

TEXT.P: Premier-designate Frank Hsieh hosted an informal meeting Friday with members of his Cabinet to be inaugurated Feb. 1.

Except for those who will definitely leave their current posts or are on official duties abroad, nearly all incumbent Cabinet members attended the tea party hosted by Hsieh at the Civil Service Development Institute in Taipei.
Hsieh said the incoming Cabinet's top priority for now is to see to it that the people have a happy and safe Chinese New Year holiday. The Lunar New Year Day falls on Feb. 9.

"I hope all Cabinet members can present concrete measures at the Feb. 1 provisional Cabinet meeting to make local people feel that the government has new initiatives and a new vision," the popular mayor of the southern port city of Kaohsiung said.
In the future, Hsieh said, the government will set a new theme for each year to guide national development; for example, a "year for health."
"Designating a development theme each year will focus our energies in a set direction," Hsieh explained.

Hsieh further said that all central government departments should never distance themselves from the common people and should instead strengthen communications to help them understand the nature of major public policies.

"Various governmental agencies should also reinforce inter-department coordination and boost dialogue with the Legislative Yuan and the public so that the Cabinet's policy initiatives will have sufficient backing," said Hsieh, himself a skillful negotiator and communicator.
Moreover, Hsieh said, all Cabinet members must attach great importance to the sentiments of the people.

"The way people feel should be a critical index in weighing policy goals. Whenever a policy or measure gets a bad response from the public, we should immediately review the plan and make necessary improvements," he added.
Noting that many incumbent Cabinet members took office only last May, Hsieh said he will give them at least six more months to implement their ideals and initiatives.

Therefore, Hsieh said, the Cabinet will undergo only minor adjustments. "I know every individual has his or her own character and taste. I want to give all of you at least six more months for us to adapt to each other and to see if we have shared values and opinions, " Hsieh said, adding that he hopes all of his Cabinet members will speak freely with each other, work as a team and take pride in their jobs.

Incumbent Vice Minister of Justice Shih Mao-lin, who has been tapped as the new minister of justice, was the only would-be Cabinet newcomer to be present at the tea party, while Minister-without-Portfolio Lin Yi-fu was the only incumbent member who didn't receive an invitation because he reportedly would be assigned to another post.

Also absent were outgoing Minister of Justice Chen Ding-nan, who will return to his home county of Ilan to run for magistrate late this year; Central Personnel Administration Director-General Lee Yi-yang, who will soon become secretary-general of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP); and Department of Health Minister Chen Chien-jen who will return to his teaching post at National Taiwan University.

Three officials who didn't attend Hsieh's tea party due to official duties were Mainland Affairs Council Chairman Joseph Wu, who was busy drawing up a response as mainland China marks the 10th anniversary of Jiang Zemin's "Eight Points" speech on cross-Taiwan Strait relations Jan. 31; as well as Minister of Foreign Affairs Tan Sun Chen and Government Information Office Director-General Lin Chia-lung, both of whom are accompanying President Chen Shui-bian on a visit to the South Pacific island nation of Palau. The three officials will remain at their current posts.

Notably present was Council of Labor Affairs Chairwoman Chen Chu who was once regarded as a candidate for vice premier, but she told the media earlier in the day that she will stay at her present post.
Who will be the new vice premier, Executive Yuan secretary-general, personnel chief and health chief remains uncertain.

Earlier in the day, DPP Secretary-General Lee Ying-yuan said Hsieh has invited him to join the new Cabinet to serve as Executive Yuan secretary-general, a post that Lee held before he was drafted by the DPP to run for Taipei City mayor in 2002. As Lee is now busy with the DPP's Jan. 30 party chairman by-election, Hsieh will not announce Lee's return to the Executive Yuan secretary-general post until Jan. 31.

DOC.HEADLINE: EPA HEAD MIFFED AT TAIWAN'S DISMAL RATING IN ENVIRONMENT, PASSES BLAME

TEXT.P: Taiwan's Environmental Protection Administration (EPA) chief Friday blamed the nation's inability to participate in international activities for the poor showing in environmental sustainability as rated by several organizations working for the World Economic Forum (WEF).

Taiwan ranked 145th out of 146 nations, only ahead of North Korea on the 2005 Environmental Sustainability Index (ESI) survey, which was unveiled by the WEF earlier the same day. Finland, Norway and Uruguay were the top three performers. The United States was in 45th place, ahead of Britain in 66th and Japan in 78th.

While acknowledging that many serious problems have arisen from Taiwan's large population, Chang Juu-en, head of the Cabinet-level EPA, blamed Taiwan's absence in most international organizations and global pacts for its low ranking.
Chang claimed that the rating organizations did not have access to up-to-date information on Taiwan and if they had, the island would have rated better.
However, he promised to do his best to improve Taiwan's environment and said that Taiwan's rating in the survey will serve as a valuable reference.
EPA officials also complained that the poll result was extremely unfair to Taiwan and said that the country is relatively strong in environmental sustainability compared to neighboring countries.

Taiwan helped Indonesia, Malaysia, the Philippines, Thailand and Vietnam in devising criteria and methodology to examine and measure their environments based on a set of "pressure, state and response" mechanisms, they said.

The 146-nation poll was jointed worked out by the WEF, the Yale Center for Environmental Law and Policy, the Global Leaders for Tomorrow Environment Task Force and the Center for International Earth Science Information Network.
It examined 22 major factors that contribute to environmental performance and results, such as urban air quality, overall public health and pollution control.
The entire report and associated material can be found at http://www.yale.edu/esi/.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC, PALAU SIGN JOINT COMMUNIQUE
DOC.DATELINE: Palau, Jan. 28 (CNA) (By S. J. Tsai & Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian signed a joint communique with his Palau counterpart, Tommy Remengesau Jr., Friday, reaffirming their commitments to further strengthen bilateral cooperation.

The two presidents also stressed in their joint communique that all countries around the world should resolve international disputes with peaceful means based on the principles of sovereignty and equality.
Chen and Remengesau also exchanged views on the general international and regional situations and matters of mutual concern, including measures to further boost bilateral exchanges and cooperation.
Chen arrived in Palau Thursday on the first leg of his current two-nation South Pacific visit that will also take him to the Solomon Islands.
On Friday morning, Chen attended Remengesau's inauguration for a second term.

After the ceremony, he went snorkeling in the company of security guards from both countries. Chen, a non-swimmer, said after his first underwater experience that he saw an amazing world under the sea and that he would have liked to have stayed longer.
He is scheduled to leave for the Solomon Islands Jan. 29. before flying back to Taipei Jan. 31. On his way back, Chen will make a five-hour stopover on the U.S. territory of Guam.

06:30, China Airlines will hold activities marking the departure of its first cross-strait charter flight at the second terminal of the Chiang Kai-shek International Airport.
