DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CHEN HAILS LAUNCH OF CROSS-STRAIT HOLIDAY CHARTER FLIGHTS
DOC.DATELINE: Palau, Jan. 28 (CNA) (By S. J. Tsai and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian in Palau Friday hailed the imminent launch of special two-way, non-stop charter flights across the Taiwan Strait, saying that the flights mark a step forward in cross-strait reconciliation and rapprochement.
Chen, who is currently on a state visit to the South Pacific island nation, made the remarks in an interview with Japan's Fuji TV and Kyodo News Agency.
His statements came a day before six direct cross-strait charter flights operated by mainland Chinese carriers are scheduled to land at Chiang Kai-shek International Airport, Taiwan's main gateway.

According to a landmark cross-strait deal reached in Macau Jan. 15, six carriers from each side will operate a total of 48 round-trip, non-stop charter flights during the Jan. 29 to Feb. 20 period between Taipei/Kaohsiung in Taiwan and Shanghai/Beijing/Guangzhou in mainland China to accommodate homeward bound Taiwan businessmen operating on the mainland for the upcoming Chinese New Year celebrations.

Chen said the special holiday charter flight deal indicates that so long as the two sides of the Taiwan Strait are sincere and are willing to sit down to talk, they can certainly break some of the obstacles standing in their way.

Even though the holiday charter flights do not necessarily signal the establishment of full-fledged cross-strait air links, Chen said they at least mark a good start for a thaw in the long-deadlocked bilateral ties.

The takeoff of the special holiday charter flights also indicates that the two sides can definitely find ways around their differences so long as they can shelve political disputes and ideological differences, Chen said.
This time around, charter planes from both sides must detour and fly over Hong Kong airspace because of Beijing's political considerations that the flights not be regarded as international ones.

In the future, Chen said, he hopes that regular cross-strait cargo charter flights and passenger charter flights can be launched and can be allowed to fly over Seoul and Okinawa airspace to save fuel costs and time. For instance, he said, Taiwan-Beijing charter flights could fly through Seoul airspace and Taiwan-Shanghai charter flights through Okinawa airspace.
Chen is the first Republic of China president ever to visit any South Pacific ally. He will also visit the Solomon Islands after his two-day Palau state visit.

DOC.HEADLINE: NTU PRESIDENT CONFERS HONORARY DEGREE ON NOBEL LAUREATE IN FRANCE

TEXT.P: National Taiwan University (NTU) President Chen Wei-chao conferred an honorary doctorate on Gao Xingjian, winner of the 2000 Nobel Prize in literature, at the University of Provence in southern France Friday.
The presentation ceremony took place before an international seminar on Gao's literary achievements at the university.
Gao said it was a great honor to receive the honorary degree from Taiwan's top-notch university.

Gao, who was born in mainland China's Jiangxi Province in 1940, left the mainland in 1987 and settled a year later in France as a political refugee. He has been to Taiwan on several occasions. In 2002, an opera written by him in collaboration with mainland composer Xu Shuya, "Snow in August," was premiered in Taipei to rave reviews.

Gao said his books have been banned in mainland China. "I didn't have motherland. But I'm fortunate to have many friends in Taiwan and France. Their support and assistance have help had my books published in many countries in many languages. I'm very grateful for this true friendship," an emotional Gao said at the ceremony.

Sorces of scholars from the United States, Taiwan, Japan, Hong Kong, Britain, Australia, South Korea, Vietnam and Singapore are attending the two-day seminar on Gao's literary works at the University of Provence.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING URGED TO DEAL WITH CROSS-STRAIT TIES WITH NEW CONCEPT

TEXT.P: Beijing should deal with cross-Taiwan Strait relations with a new concept and set aside fetters imposed by former mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin's eight-point proposal, Taiwan's top mainland policy planner suggested Friday.

Joseph Wu, chairman of the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council, said that this year will be crucial to the development of cross-strait ties, given that the internal situations of the United States, mainland China and Taiwan have been relatively stable in comparison with those of last year where there were presidential elections and legislative elections in Taiwan and the U.S. and a transfer of power in the mainland.

Wu blamed poor understanding or negligence of Taiwan for the criticisms made by Chinese People's Political Consultative Conference Chairman Jia Qinglin earlier that day on Taiwan's constitutional reforms, although he declined to comment on Jia's remarks marking the 10th anniversary of Jiang's policy proposal on unification with Taiwan.
It is an error and a misunderstanding to see Taiwan's constitutional reforms as activities to seek Taiwan's independence, he pointed out.

Beijing should do more to learn of Taiwan's democratic development and what the people of Taiwan want, Wu suggested, adding that Beijing should seriously consider a proposal he initiated for sending scholars from either side to be stationed on each side.
No responsible government or political party in Taiwan will accept the "one China" principle authored by Beijing, he added.

Wu said, however, the government of Taiwan will continue to seek acceptable ways and means by which the two sides of the Taiwan Strait can lay the a foundation for resuming the long-stalled cross-strait dialogue.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Saturday, Jan. 29, or the 20th day of the 12th month of the Year of the Monkey according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1596: Sir Francis Drake, the naval hero and explorer who became the first Englishman to circumnavigate the world in 1577 (repeating the feat in 1580) and who was vice admiral of the fleet that destroyed the Spanish Armada in 1588, is buried at sea off the coast of Panama after having suffered from dysentery for several weeks.
1737: Thomas Paine, the British-born writer and American Revolutionary leader who wrote the pamphlet "Common Sense," arguing for American independence, is born.
1819: Sir Stamford Raffles lands on Singapore and signs a preliminary treaty with a local ruler to set up a British trading post.
1843: William McKinley, the 25th president of the United States, is born. His presidency was marked by the Spanish-American War, the annexation of Cuba and the Philippines, and the passage of the Gold Standard Act.
1861: Kansas becomes the 34th state of the United States.
1886: Karl Friedrich Benz, the German automobile pioneer credited with manufacturing the first vehicle powered with an internal-combustion engine, patents his design for an automobile.
1916: Britain begins military tank trials at Hatfield, Hertfordshire.
1944: The USS Missouri, the largest warship in the world at the time, is launched.
1947: The U.S. State Department announces the abandonment of efforts to mediate between the national government and the communists in China.
1955: The U.S. Senate approves by an 85-to-3 vote a resolution authorizing President Dwight D. Eisenhower to deploy U.S. armed forces to help defend Taiwan. The resolution was then signed into law by the president.
1958: Construction of the Wuhsieh branch section of the East-West Cross-Island Highway is completed and opened to traffic.
1964: Alan Ladd, U.S. actor who specialized in cowboy and tough-guy roles, dies.
1966: A U.S. C-130 Hercules aircraft group moves to Taiwan to help American forces fighting in Vietnam.
1973: The United States, the Soviet Union, and 17 other countries agree to meet in Vienna to try to reach an accord on cutting the strength of armed forces in Europe.
1974: A seven-member agricultural mission from the Republic of the Ivory Coast, headed by J. Ada-Anghui, director of the Agricultural Development Bureau, arrives in Taipei for a weeklong visit.
1975: Colombian Representatives Hector Charry Samper, Heraclie Fernandez Sandoval, and Fernando Sandoval Molina arrive in Taipei for a six-day visit.
1976: An ROC team leaves for Wellington, New Zealand to take part in the 4th World Cup Men's Softball Championship Tournament.
1978: Sweden becomes the first country in the world to ban the use of ozone-depleting aerosol sprays.
1979: U.S. President Jimmy Carter commutes the prison sentence of Patricia Hearst, grand-daughter of newspaper magnate William Randolph Hearst. She had willfully joined her former kidnappers, members of the Symbionese Liberation Army, in an armed bank robbery.
1982: Lee Ken-tao, a communist Chinese scientist doing advanced study in West Germany who had previously defected, flies to Taipei with his wife via a third country.
1987: Soviet leader Mikhail Gorbachev tells the Soviet Communist Party's Central Committee that the time has come for greater "control from below," meaning free elections for local councils.
1987: President Corazon Aquino of the Philippines puts down an attempted coup against her administration, forcing rebels to abandon the Manila television station they seized two days earlier.
1990: Erich Honecker, the ousted East German Communist Party leader, is arrested and ordered to stand trial for high treason.
1992: The Republic of China and Latvia announce the establishment of relations at the consulate-general level.
1996: Venice's opera house La Fenice is destroyed by fire for the second time in its history.
2000: Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou reaffirms his determination to support the ticket of Lien Chan and Vincent Siew of the ruling Kuomintang in the March 18 presidential election.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "Neglect of godliness; study without understanding; failure to act up to what I believe to be right; and inability to change bad habits: These are things that cause me constant solicitude."

DOC.TEXT:
Manila Bulletin: 8,000 OFWs from Malaysia to return
Eight thousand undocumented Filipino workers are expected to come home soon after being repatriated from Malaysia, the Department of Social Welfare and Development (DSWD) said yesterday.
The Philippine Daily Inquirer: Anti-VAT groups take to the streets AFTER losing the House vote on the measure seeking an increased the value-added tax, opposition lawmakers will take to the streets in an effort to raise the awareness and gain the support of the public.

Forty suspected terrorists -- two leaders of the Indonesia-based Jemaah Islamiyah and 38 Moro Islamic Liberation Front (MILF) rebels -- were killed and many others wounded in Thursday's massive airstrikes and artillery barrage on a terrorist base in Maguindanao.
The Manila Times: JI lairs bombed; 40 slain As many as 40 Islamic militants, including two Indonesian suspected mem--bers of the al-Qaeda-linked Jemaah Islamiah, were believed killed in a military air strike on their hideout in a marshland in Maguindanao on Thurs-day.

The Japan Times: Jobless rate edges to six-year low But 2.7 million listed as unemployed
Japan's unemployment rate edged down 0.1 percent to a six-year low of 4.4 percent in December.The government said Friday the December data brought the nation's average unemployment rate in 2004 to 4.7 percent, down 0.6 percentage point from the previous year and representing a second straight year of decline.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CHEN DEPARTS PALAU FOR SOLOMON ISLANDS

TEXT.P: Republic of China (ROC) President Chen Shui-bian departed Palau Saturday for the Solomon Islands for the final leg of his official visit to two ROC diplomatic allies in the south Pacific.
Chen and his entourage are expected to arrive in the Solomon Islands capital of Honiara in the late afternoon.

During his three-day visit, Chen will call on Governor-General Nathaniel Waena and Prime Minister Allan Kemakesa, as well as inspect the operations of the Taiwan Technical Mission to the Solomon Islands.
Chen is scheduled to return to Taipei Jan. 31.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
: The Straits Times: Bird flu alert stepped up.
Singapore is on bird flu alert. New cases of poultry infections in the region have prompted food safety authorities here this week to intensify their checks on farms and poultry imports at border checkpoints.
They have also heightened the alert level up a notch to Code Orange, just below full-danger Code Red when all birds will be culled and a ban imposed on imports from risky countries.
But even their best efforts are no match once the H5N1 virus makes the jump and transmits easily from human to human, a mutation that can unleash an attack more forceful than even Sars.
The Lianhe Zaobao: China willing to talk to Taiwan leader if he acknowledged the 1992 consensus on one China.
China yesterday extended an olive branch to President Chen Shui-bian, saying it was ready to move on and hold talks with the Taiwanese leader if he acknowledged the 1992 consensus on one China.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The New York Times:
Shiite Faction Ready to Shun Sunday's Election in Iraq
A radical cleric's refusal to endorse the election foreshadowed a less than overwhelming voter turnout in Iraq.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CHEN TO SEEK TO IMPROVE CROSS-TAIWAN STRAIT TIES: AIDES
DOC.DATELINE: Palau, Jan. 29 (CNA) (By S. J. Tsai and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian will seek to improve Taiwan's ties with mainland China and set up mechanisms to bolster bilateral exchanges during the rest of his second term, aides to the president said Saturday.

While building positive relations between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait will be a top priority on the president's policy agenda, as evidenced by the inauguration of the special cross-strait Chinese New Year holiday charter flights, the president is also poised to explore relations with other friendly countries, the aides said.
They said that Chen will also do his utmost to step up interaction s with the United States and Japan based on Taiwan's business, strategic and political interests.

The president is slated to visit the Marshall Islands -- one of the Republic of China's diplomatic allies in the South Pacific -- in May and is planning to take part in the fifth summit between the ROC and its Central American allies later this year, according to the aides.

Chen is currently on a two-nation tour in the South Pacific. He is scheduled to arrive in the Solomon Islands late Saturday afternoon after wrapping up a three-day visit to Palau. He will fly back to Taiwan Monday.

DOC.HEADLINE: CROSS-STRAIT LUNAR NEW YEAR CHARTER FLIGHTS KICK OFF

TEXT.P: Special cross-strait Lunar New Year charter flights were launched Saturday to carry mainland China-based Taiwanese businesspeople and their families home for the holidays, marking the first time in 56 years that civilian aircraft from the mainland have been allowed to land in Taiwan.

Unlike the previous Lunar New Year charter flight services in 2003, which were operated solely by Taiwanese airlines between Shanghai and Taipei/Kaohsiung via Hong Kong/Macau, this year's services are being jointly operated by a total of 12 air carriers from Taiwan and China, with flights between Beijing/Shanghai/Guangzhou and Taipei/Kaohsiung.
The flights, arranged for the Jan. 29-Feb. 20 period, are not required to land in a third location en route this time around, although they still need to detour over Hong Kong's air space.
On the first day of the charter services, a total of nine flights were offered by eight air carriers from the two sides of the Taiwan Strait for more than 2,000 passengers.

The six mainland airlines joining the landmark services Saturday included China Southern Airlines, Xiamen Airlines, Air China, Shanghai Airlines, Hainan Airlines and China Eastern Airlines. The Taiwanese carriers involved were China Airlines and EVA Airways.

The first flight operated by China Southern Airlines from Guangzhou arrived at Taoyuan's Chiang Kai-shek International Airport at around 9: 25 a.m. with 234 passengers. It was followed by another by Xiamen Airlines, also from Guangzhou, which arrived 15 minutes later with 189 passengers.
At a welcome ceremony held at the airport, Civil Aeronautics Administration Director-General Billy K.C. Chang said he feels very excited to be able to witness this historic moment.

Chang said that the launch of this year's charter services has laid a solid foundation for cross-strait civil aviation exchanges and that he believes regular passenger services will open across the strait very soon.

Also attending the ceremony were Mainland Affairs Council Vice Chairman Chiu Tai-san, Vice Minister of Transportation and Communications Tsai Duei and Vice Minister of Economic Affairs Chen Ruey-long.
Meanwhile, two flights operated by Taiwan's China Airlines and EVA Airways arrived at Beijing from Taipei at 12: 20 p.m. and 12: 50 p.m., respectively, carrying a total of 451 passengers.
According to the airlines, the flight from Taipei to Beijing takes only four hours and 20 minutes, which is at least two hours faster than a flight with a stopover in Hong Kong or Macau.
Direct cross-strait transportation links were suspended since 1949 after a civil war in China.

DOC.HEADLINE: INDUSTRIAL DEVELOPMENT BUREAU SETS INVESTMENT GOAL AT NT$849 BILLION

TEXT.P: The Industrial Development Bureau under the Ministry of Economic Affairs is doing its utmost to achieve its goal of attracting major investment projects totalling NT$849 billion (US$26.69 billion) for 2005, Chen Chao-yih, the bureau director, said Saturday.
The ministry defines a major investment project as one with a total investment of over NT$200 million, Chen said.

To contribute to Taiwan's sustainable economic development, the bureau will continue to promote what it terms Taiwan's "two-trillion, two-star" industries -- semiconductor, display, digital content and biotechnology, he said.

Furthermore, the bureau plans to promote new industries, including those related to home care, digitized home, and liquid crystal display (LCD) products, as part of the government's efforts to transform Taiwan into a "green silicon island," he continued.
Major investment projects for 2004 totalled NT$840.3 billion, up 20 percent over the previous year's level, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: THIRD ROUND TALKS ON TAIWAN-NICARAGUA FTA TO KICK OFF JAN. 30

TEXT.P: The third round of talks between Taiwan and Nicaragua on a proposed free trade agreement (FTA) is slated to kick off Jan. 30 in Miami, Florida, Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) officials said Saturday.

The Taiwan delegation will be headed by Deputy Minister of Economic Affairs Chen Ruey-long and will include officials from the Ministry of Finance, Ministry of Justice, Council of Agriculture, MOEA Industrial Development Bureau, and MOEA Bureau of Foreign Trade.
The meeting, which will run through Feb. 4, will center on the topics of market access regulations and procedures, investment, and the service industry, according to the MOEA.

The two sides are expected to reach consensus on the formation of detailed articles of the proposed agreement during the Miami talks, a MOEA official suggested, adding that they are expected to begin the legal review of the planned accord.

The two sides are also expected to focus more on issues concerning tariff reductions for agricultural and industrial products, a list of products to benefit from market opening, and regulations on product designations, the official said.

In light of the fact that bilateral trade between Taiwan and Panama grew by 112 percent for the year after the Taiwan-Panama FTA came into effect Jan. 1, 2004, it has believed that an FTA between Taiwan and Nicaragua will significantly boost bilateral trade between the two countries, MOEA officials said. They added that the ministry also hopes the signing of an FTA will increase economic and investment relations between the two countries.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN SHOULD NOT LET DOWN GUARD AGAINST MAINLAND CHINA: VP

TEXT.P: Taiwan should not let down its guard against mainland China despite the inauguration of special cross-strait Chinese New Year charter flights, Vice President Annette Lu said Saturday.
Lu made the remarks while answering questions from reporters after attending the opening of a special Chinese New Year bazaar at the Pinchiang Market in Taipei City.

Stressing that Taiwan must not let down its guard against mainland China, Lu called Beijing the biggest obstacle in Taiwan's efforts to enter international organizations. She urged the public to be fully aware of Beijing's plots.

The vice president said Beijing is apparently using the "carrot and stick" approach by to try to entice the Taiwan people with the special charter flights while at the same time seeking to obstruct Taiwan on the diplomatic front, as evidenced by the fact that Grenada shifted its diplomatic recognition from Taipei to Beijing Thursday.
Grenada had maintained formal diplomatic relations with Taiwan since 1988.
If Beijing were truly friendly toward Taiwan, it would not block Taiwan's bid to join the United Nations and would help Taiwan join the World Health Organization, Lu said.
Should Beijing take the initiative by dismantling its missiles aimed at Taiwan, then the Taiwan government will also be willing to review many policies related to mainland China, she added.

DOC.HEADLINE: PASSENGER NUMBERS UP ON XIAMEN-KINMEN FERRY SERVICE

TEXT.P: Passenger numbers on the ferry service between Taiwan's frontline island of Kinmen and the mainland Chinese port of Xiamen were up Saturday despite the kick off of special cross-strait Lunar New Year charter flights the same day, according to a Kinmen County Government official.

Lin Cheng-cha, director of Kinmen's Transportation and Tourism Bureau, said a total of 462 mainland-based Taiwanese businesspeople arrived in Kinmen aboard two ferries Saturday before flying on to Taiwan, marking a single day high for the year.
With the approach of the Chinese New Year, Lin predicted that passenger numbers will continue to increase as more and more Taiwanese businesspeople head back home for the holidays via Kinmen.

The ferry service was inaugurated four years ago to facilitate Taiwan businesspeople traveling between Taiwan and the mainland in the absence of direct cross-strait flight services. The service seemed unaffected by the launch of the special cross-strait charter flights Saturday.

A Taiwan businessman, surnamed Liu, told CNA at the pier at Shuitou, Kinmen that the charter flights don't extend to Xiamen where some 300,000 Taiwan businesspeople are based. For these individuals, traveling via Kinmen is still the most convenient way to return to Taiwan, he noted.

Liu, who comes from Taichung, central Taiwan, said the Kinmen route is quicker than flying from Fuzhou, Fujian Province to Guangzhou in Guangdong Province before boarding one of the special charter flights to Taoyuan or Kaohsiung in Taiwan.
"The Xiamen-Kinmen route is irreplaceable for Taiwanese operating in Fujian." he said.

Meanwhile, Lin said there are currently four round trips offered per day on the ferry route between Kinmen and Xiamen, with the number to increase to six round trips Feb. 1, with a total capacity of 3,216 passengers per day.
He estimated that more than 30,000 passengers will use the ferry service before the Chinese New Year holidays end Feb. 18.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAINLAND PILOTS EXCITED ABOUT HISTORIC FLIGHTS TO TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Mainland Chinese pilots who flew landmark Lunar New Year charter flights to Taiwan on Saturday could hardly contain their excitement and joy at being able to take part in the services.

Seven charter flights operated by six mainland carriers arrived in Taipei/Kaohsiung from Beijing/Shanghai/Guangzhou on the first day of the charter services, carrying about 1,700 Taiwanese passengers home for the holidays. They were the first mainland civilian aircraft to be allowed to land in Taiwan in 56 years.

Hao Jianhua, captain of the China Southern Airlines flight from Guangzhou to Taipei -- the earliest among the seven flights to arrive in Taiwan -- waved excitedly from the cockpit to reporters waiting at Taoyuan's Chiang Kai-shek International Airport soon after landing.
Hao said he is very happy about his first trip to Taiwan.

Song Chengren, captain of the Xiamen Airlines flight, also from Gaungzhou, which arrived at the airport second, said the flight to Taiwan has fulfilled his long-time dream in his 44-year career as a pilot.
However, Song said he feels some regret for not being able to enjoy the view over Taipei because of poor visibility during the flight.
Xiamen Airlines general manager Wu Rongnan, who had visited Taiwan twice in the past, joined the Taiwanese passengers on the flight to Taipei.

Wu said that he had hoped to do something to promote the opening of direct transportation links across the Taiwan Strait 20 years ago and that the launch of this year's charter services is a good start that will be helpful in pushing for a launch of regular cross-strait passenger services in the future.

Meanwhile, the mainland-based Taiwanese businesspeople who took the first-day flights home also expressed their hope that direct cross-strait air and shipping links will be opened soon to facilitate their transportation needs.
In Shanghai, Vice Mayor Tang Dengjie agreed that the availability of a convenient means of transportation is very important in light of the frequent exchanges between people from the two sides.
While more than 300,000 Taiwanese now live in Shanghai and its neighboring areas, Taiwanese made more than 1.32 million trips to Shanghai in 2004 alone, according to Tang.
The number of investment projects made by Taiwanese in Shanghai totals 5,440 to date, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CHEN ARRIVES IN SOLOMON ISLANDS
DOC.DATELINE: Honiara, Solomon Islands, Jan. 29 (CNA) (By Tsai Shu-jung & Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian arrived in Honiara, the capital city of the Solomon Islands, Saturday for a three-day state visit.
Chen was warmly greeted at the airport by Solomon Islands Governor General Nathaniel Waena, Prime Minister Allan Kemakeza and other top officials of the South Pacific nation.

During a welcome ceremony at the airport, Waena bestowed Solomon Islands' highest honor -- a necklace made of local shell money -- on Chen and invited him to examine the honor guard. A traditional warrior dance was also performed to welcome Chen's visit.
The Solomon Islands is the final leg of Chen's official visit to two ROC diplomatic allies in the South Pacific region which has also taken him to Palau.
Taiwan has forged cooperation relations with the Solomon Islands in the fields of agriculture, fishery and medical treatment, according to ROC Ambassador Chen Lien-yun.

With bilateral cooperation in fishery, the ambassador said, 80 Taiwanese fishing boats have been operating in the territorial waters of the Solomon Islands. Annually, these vessels earn over NT$10 billion (US$314.96 million) in terms of fishery production for Taiwan, he added.
The ambassador also noted that the Solomon Islands has supported the ROC's bid to join international organizations and that the bilateral ties and friendship between the two countries are solid.
During President Chen's three-day visit, he will call on Waena and Kemakesa, as well as inspect the operations of the Taiwan Technical Mission to the Solomon Islands.
He is scheduled to return to Taipei Jan. 31.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. LOOKING AT BEIJING OFFICIAL'S REMARKS ON CROSS-STRAIT TIES
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Jan. 28 (CNA) (By Oliver Lin & Huang Kwang-chun)

TEXT.P: The United States is looking at remarks made by a Beijing official to mark the 10th anniversary of former mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin's eight-point proposal on reunification with Taiwan, U.S. State Department spokesman Richard Boucher said Friday.

Boucher was referring to a speech delivered by People's Political Consultative Conference Chairman Jia Qinglin in which Jia reiterated Beijing's insistence on the "one China" principle and claimed that Beijing remains open to cross-strait negotiations.
Jia also criticized Taiwan's constitutional reform plans, describing them as an attempt to realize de jure independence for the island.
"We'll look at (Jia's speech) very carefully," Boucher said.

He also reiterated the United States' interest in a peaceful resolution of cross-strait differences and its support for the idea of cross-strait dialogue, which he said is the best way for the two sides to resolve their differences.

DOC.HEADLINE: BUSES, FERRIES WITH DIMO TV INAUGURATED IN KAOHSIUNG CITY

TEXT.P: The Kaohsiung City Government inaugurated buses and ferries offering DiMo TV Saturday, according to Chang Chun-yen, secretary-general of the southern port city's government.
The inauguration ceremony, held at the square by the mouth of the Love River, was presided over by Chang and Public Television Service Foundation (PTSF) chairman Hu Yuan-hui.
Dimo TV will play commercial-free digital programs offered by the PTSF, which will do its utmost to uphold the program quality, Hu said.

On Jan. 24, the city government inaugurated the country's first digitized services on the city's bus routes, including 130 bus stop signs offering digital information, TV monitors on 448 buses that will play real-time programming, and a hotline offering bus information, Chang said.

DOC.HEADLINE: PFP CHAIRMAN RETURNS TO TAIWAN FROM U.S.

TEXT.P: Opposition People First Party (PFP) Chairman James Soong returned to Taiwan Saturday from the United States ahead of the Feb. 1 elections for legislative speaker and vice speaker.

On behalf of opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan, Legislative Yuan speaker Wang Jin-pyng and Taipei Mayor Ying-jeou, who are both vice chairmen of the party, welcomed Soong at Chiang Kai-shek International Airport upon his arrival.
Wang said the gesture was aimed at displaying the KMT's sincerity in cooperating with the PFP in the speaker and vice speaker elections.

Wang added that he hopes Lien and Soong will jointly campaign for the two parties' candidates to boost their chances of victory, but he denied any knowledge of when the two leaders will meet to discuss details about the elections.

The KMT and PFP, which together enjoy a slim majority in the legislature, have decided to jointly support Wang and PFP Legislator-elect David J.C. Chung to run for speaker and vice speaker, respectively.
In an effort to secure support for Wang and Chung, the KMT has also decided to discipline any of its legislators who don't toe the party line and vote for other candidates.

Meanwhile, Soong denied reports suggesting that he had met with some ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) politicians during his stay in the United States and had reached a deal with the DPP on inter-party cooperation.
Soong said he did not meet with any KMT representatives, either, and that he only met some U.S. officials and members of major think tanks.

The PFP chairman said that after some serious contemplation, he has come to realize that reconciliation is needed in Taiwan in terms of its relations with mainland China as well as among different ethnic groups and political parties.

Soong said the PFP will play the role of balancer to push the DPP to change its pro-independence position and in order to assist the KMT in reforming itself, adding that the PFP rejects any form of inter-party cooperation that is based on horse trading.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINA NEEDS NEW APPROACH TO BREAK CROSS-STRAIT IMPASSE: MAC

TEXT.P: Mainland China can hardly expect any progress in its relations with Taiwan if it continues to adhere to its out-of-date approach and political ideas without heeding public opinion in Taiwan, according to a statement issued by the Mainland Affairs Council.

In a response to remarks made by Jia Qinglin, chairman of the Chinese People's Political Consultative Conference, in Beijing the previous day, the statement said Beijing has not revamped its Taiwan policy which is based on its "one country, two systems" formula for reuniting with Taiwan.

Although Taiwan has persistently pursued peace and stability in its relations with China, these goals are unattainable unless Beijing gives Taiwan its due respect and does not deny its existence, the statement said.
The "one Country, two systems" formula has never won the endorsement of Taiwan people, and the policy based on this formula is doomed to fail, the statement said.

Furthermore, the statement said, Beijing's attempts to bring Taiwan back into its fold by enacting an anti-secession law has seriously worsened its ties with Taiwan and has caused considerable concern in the international community despite its efforts to play down the bill's significance.

China's attempts to justify a possible invasion of Taiwan with this anti-secession bill will only aggravate the confrontation between Taiwan and China, alter the status quo across the Taiwan Strait, threaten the stability of the region and make any improvement in bilateral ties impossible, the statement said.

The statement rebutted Jia's claims that Taiwan's efforts to amend its Constitution is a bid to seek de jure independence for the island, saying that Taiwan's political reform is aimed at sharpening the country's competitiveness and that it has won the international community's admiration.
Beijing has only exposed its ignorance of democracy by it's criticism, the statement claimed.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHARTER FLIGHTS HELPFUL TO CROSS-STRAIT RELATIONS: MAC OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Vice Chairman Chiu Tai-san on Saturday hailed the special Lunar New Year charter flights between Taiwan and mainland China which kicked off the same day, voicing the hope that the services will help pave the way for improvement in cross-strait ties in other areas.

Chiu made the remarks while giving a speech in a ceremony at Chiang Kai-shek International Airport to welcome arriving Taiwan business people and their families on board the homebound flights from the mainland on the first day of the service that will run through Feb. 20.

Legislators and government officials, including Vice Minister of Transportation and Communications Tsai Duei and Vice Minister of Economic Affairs Chen Ruey-long, were also present on the occasion to witness the historic first landings on Taiwan soil of mainland aircraft in more than 55 years.
Chiu said that the government keenly hopes that the flight services will help set a precedence for bilateral talks in other areas in the future.

The successful launch of the flights means that Taiwan and mainland China could brush aside their political disputes and engage in mutually beneficial negotiations based on parity and respect, he said.
The MAC vice chairman said that the government hopes to see major breakthroughs in Taiwan-mainland relations this year and that it is looking forward to promoting broader cross-strait exchanges.
He voiced his expectation that the charter flight services will not turn out to be an isolated case of cooperation and called for concrete measures by the two sides to build on this success.

Meanwhile, more than 2,000 Taiwan business people and their families took the charter flights on the first day of the service, with Taiwan-bound passengers well outnumbering those bound for the mainland.
The flight services are only being provided for Taiwan business people and their dependents, whose status must first be verified by Taiwan businessmen's associations in mainland China.

Returning Taiwan business people and their families expressed satisfaction with the implementation of the charter flights in terms of enabling them to save time and money. They urged the government to implement charter flight services for other major holidays, such as the Dragon Boat Festival and the Mid-Autumn Festival.

Representatives from Taiwan and the mainland reached the ground-breaking agreement on the Lunar New Year holiday flights earlier this month in Macau, allowing six airlines from each side to participate in offering the services between the Taiwan cities of Taipei and Kaohsiung and the mainland cities of Beijing, Shanghai and Guangzhou.
It marks a sharp departure from the charter service in 2003, when the flights were run only by Taiwan aviation companies which had to fly via Hong Kong or Macau.
The charter flights were aborted the next year due to the mainland's refusal to talk with Taiwan over its demand that mainland carriers also be included in the service.

DOC.HEADLINE: ACTIVISTS URGE GOVERNMENT TO LEARN FROM LOW RANKING IN ESI SURVEY

TEXT.P: Taiwan should learn something positive from its low ranking in a recent Environmental Sustainability Index (ESI) survey, and the government should call a meeting to review its policy, eco-friendly activists said Saturday.

Chen Shu-hua, head of the Taiwan Environment Protection Alliance, called on the government to call a meeting as soon as possible to revamp its policies regarding recycling, nuclear power and alternative energies.

Although Taiwan is not able to take part in international activities and global pacts affiliated with the United Nations, the country can still contribute to environmental protection and conservation through non-governmental organizations, Chen said.
Taiwan's poor showing in the poll may be discouraging, but the government should use outside criticism as a valuable reference to make concrete improvements, she said.

Taiwan ranked 145th out of 146 nations in the ESI survey carried out jointly by the World Economic Forum and other agencies. The survey results were made public on Friday, with Finland ranking at the top of the list and North Korea at the bottom.

Environmental Protection Administration officials ascribed Taiwan's poor performance to the country's inability to participate in international affairs, though they also acknowledged that many serious problems have arisen from Taiwan's large population and that there is an urgent need to make improvements.

DOC.HEADLINE: WORLD PEACE SHOULD BE BASED ON FREEDOM AND DEMOCRACY: PRESIDENT CHEN
DOC.DATELINE: Honiara, Solomon Islands, Jan. 29 (CNA) (By Tsai Su-jung & Huang Kwang-chun)

TEXT.P: World peace and prosperity should be based on freedom, democracy, and respect for human rights and pluralism, Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian said Saturday.

Addressing a state banquet hosted by Governor General of the Solomon Islands Nathaniel Waena in his honor, Chen said that the ROC is willing to share its experience in democratization and economic development with the Solomon Islands and to play an active and constructive role in the South Pacific nation's development.
Chen said that he is proud to be the first ROC president to visit the Solomon Islands, adding that his visit marks the beginning of a new era in the development of ties between the two countries.

The ROC-Solomon Islands relationship is based on the principles of equality, reciprocity, mutual respect, freedom and peace, for which the two nations have established a lasting friendship, Chen noted.
In response, Waena praised the ROC's achievements in economic and political development.
He said that Taiwan has every right to join international organizations and that the Solomon Islands will continue to support Taiwan's bids.
He also thanked Chen for the assistance the ROC has extended to the Solomon Islands and expressed the hope that the bilateral ties will be further strengthened.
Chen arrived in Honiara, the capital of the Solomon Islands, earlier in the day for a three-day state visit.
Chen was warmly greeted at the airport by Waena, Prime Minister Allan Kemakeza and other top officials of the South Pacific nation.
The Solomon Islands is the final leg of Chen's official visit to two ROC diplomatic allies in the South Pacific region which has also taken him to Palau.
He is scheduled to return to Taipei Jan. 31.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Sunday, Jan. 30, or the 22nd day of the 12th month of the Year of the Monkey according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1641: The Dutch obtain the Malacca area of Malaya (now part of Malaysia) from the Portuguese.
1649: King Charles I of England, Scotland, and Ireland, whose power struggle with Parliament resulted in the 1642-1648 English civil war in which he was defeated, is beheaded.
1882: Franklin Delano Roosevelt, the 32nd president of the United States and the only one to be reelected three times, is born.
1902: Britain signs a treaty with Japan providing for independence for China and Korea.
1931: Gene Hackman, U.S. actor who won an Oscar for "The French Connection," is born.
1932: The ROC government moves to Loyang because of the Japanese invasion.
1933: President Paul von Hindenburg appoints the 43-year-old Adolf Hitler as Chancellor of Germany.
1943: The German army is destroyed by Soviet troops southwest of Stalingrad.
1948: Orville Wright, the U.S. aviation pioneer who, along with his brother Wilbur, invented the airplane and made the first sustained flight in a heavier-than-air vehicle on Dec. 17, 1903, dies at the age of 77.
1948: Mahatma Gandhi, Indian nationalist and spiritual leader who developed the practice of nonviolent civil disobedience that forced Great Britain to grant independence to India in 1947, is assassinated by a Hindu fanatic at the age of 78.
1957: Chou En-lai, premier of Communist China, receives an honorary doctorate from India's International University.
1958: Yves Saint Laurent, a genius of Paris fashion and head designer of the Dior fashion house, holds his first major show in Paris at the age of 22.
1964: General Nguyen Khanh of South Vietnam seizes power in a coup in Saigon.
1968: North Vietnamese troops and Viet Cong guerrillas launch the "Tet (New Year) Offensive," targeting more than 100 towns and cities, including Saigon, in South Vietnam.
1969: Li Tsung-jen, who was temporarily empowered to exercise presidential powers after President Chiang Kai-shek announced his retirement on Jan. 21, 1949, dies in Beijing at the age of 79.
1971: ROC students stage demonstrations in various U.S. cities to show their support for ROC sovereignty over the Tiaoyutai (Senkaku) islands.
1973: The Republic of China severs diplomatic relations with the Republic of Zaire.
1973: Nyuyen Van Hao, director of the National Economic Development Fund of South Vietnam, arrives in Taipei to sign a US$5 million loan contract with the ROC government.
1973: Watergate conspirators Gordon Liddy and James McCord are convicted in the United States of spying on the Democratic Party headquarters.
1974: Jose Mario Armero, president of Spain's Europe Press, and Antonio Garringues Walker, United Nations high commissioner for refugees in Spain, arrive in Taipei for a four-day visit.
1975: Finance Minister K.T. Li leaves for Manila to attend the annual board meeting of the Asian Institute of Technology.
1978: President Chiang Ching-kuo receives members of a U.S. Congressional mission led by Representative George Hansen.
1988: The Legislative Yuan passes a new income tax regulation raising the income tax deduction for the tax-payer and each dependent to NT$37,000.
1989: Five black Pharaonic figures dating from 1470 BC are found in Luxor in Egypt.
1995: Mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin offers an eight-point proposal urging Taiwan to hold talks with the mainland to officially end the hostile standoff between the two sides.
2000: New Party presidential candidate Li Ao and his running mate Legislator Elmer Fung complete their candidacy registration with the Central Election Commission, marking their official entry into the ROC presidential race.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "Seek wisdom; hold fast to godliness; live a moral life; and enjoy the pleasures derived from the pursuit of the polite arts."

Lovefest at CKS marks direct flights.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN WILL CONTINUE TO AMEND TIES WITH PRC: PRESIDENT
DOC.DATELINE: Honiara, the Solomon Islands, Jan. 30 (CNA) (By S.J. Tsai and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian said here Sunday that Taiwan will continue to hold out olive branches to mainland China even though Beijing has made no effort to improve cross-Taiwan Strait relations over the past decade.
Chen said that the Beijing leadership has not tried to resolve cross-strait differences over the past 10 years but has rather widened the distance between the two sides.

He said Beijing's behavior has been inconsistent with its rhetoric, citing the mainland's live-fire missile tests in the Taiwan Strait in 1996 and various intimidation and containment measures that Beijing adopted toward Taiwan prior to the island's presidential election in 2000.
Despite this, Chen went on, Taiwan will continue to demonstrate goodwill toward the mainland in an effort to amend the fragile cross-strait ties.

Chen made the remarks at a time when the mainland is marking the Jan. 30 10th anniversary of former Chinese President Jiang Zemin's eight-point proposal on unification with Taiwan and the ground-breaking inauguration of special cross-strait Chinese New Year holiday charter flights offered by airlines on both sides of the strait.

He was referring to a speech delivered by People's Political Consultative Conference Chairman Jia Qinglin Jan. 28 in which Jia reiterated Beijing's insistence on the "one China" principle and claimed that Beijing remains open to cross-strait negotiations.
According to Jia, Beijing will continue to promote peaceful unification and the "one country, two systems" formula toward Taiwan based on Jiang's proposal.

Jia also claimed that so long as Taiwan gives up its constitutional reform plans, which he described as an attempt to realize de jure independence for the island, Beijing is willing to engage Taiwan in dialogue and interaction.
"Beijing holds no prerequisite for resuming cross-strait dialogue, nor for who will represent Taiwan in the talks, " Jia was quoted as saying.
Chen is currently on a state visit to the Solomon Islands after wrapping up a three-day official visit to Palau, another ROC diplomatic ally in the South Pacific.

Chen, in the company of Solomon Islands Prime Minister Allan Kemakesa, inspected the Taiwan Agrotech Mission to the Solomon Islands Sunday and the two leaders rolled up their sleeves and trouser legs to transplant rice seedlings in a paddy.
Chen and Kemakesa also visited a hog-raising farm operated by the Taiwan Agrotech mission.

The Taiwan Agrotech Mission, which became operational in the Solomon Islands in 1983, has been offering guidance to the Solomon Islands people in the farming of vegetables, fruit and grain, as well as in chicken and hog raising.
The mission has also help agricultural schools to run their own farms and orchards.

Later in the day, Chen and Kemakesa attended a ceremony to mark the inauguration of the Taiwan-built Central Hospital and visited a children's ward and a dentist, where Taiwan dentists have been offering free dentistry.
Chen will also meet the Solomon Islands Cabinet at a luncheon to be hosted by Kemakesa.
He is scheduled to deliver a speech at the Solomon Islands parliament Monday and he and Kemakesa will sign a joint communique on bilateral ties before departing for home.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRIVATE INVESTMENT IN INFRASTRUCTURE TO REACH AT LEAST NT$22 BILLION

TEXT.P: The government is expected to sign agreements with private investors on investment in at least nine infrastructure development projects to be completed this year worth some NT$22 billion (US$0.69 billion), officials from the Ministry of the Interior (MOI) reported Sunday.

According to MOI regulations, private investment can participate in 20 categories of public development and construction programs, including sewage works and systems, tourism locations and facilities, parks and facilities and new township development.

As of Jan. 28, the private sector has decided to strike pacts with the government on nine infrastructure development projects, including sewage development and maintenance in Tamshui, Taipei County, a tourism and holiday park zone in Fenglin rural township in Hualien County, eastern Taiwan, and an ecological and wildlife conservation park in Kuanshan, Taitung County, eastern Taiwan, officials from the MOI's Construction and Planning Administration said.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER-DESIGNATE REITERATES HOPE FOR INTER-PARTY COOPERATION

TEXT.P: Premier-designate Frank Hsieh reiterated his hope Sunday for achieving inter-party reconciliation and cooperation after assuming the premiership.
Hsieh, who will take over as premier Feb. 1, made the remarks while presiding over a "National Cleanup Week" program in his capacity as mayor of the southern port city of Kaohsiung.
The incoming premier clarified media reports that Legislative Yuan Vice President P.K. Chiang, who is a vice chairman of the opposition Kuomintang, is his "dream choice" for vice premier.
In fact, Hsieh said, he has no specific target to court for the post at the moment.

"I prefer to leave the post vacant for the time being so that the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) will have leverage to promote reconciliation and cooperation with the opposition, " Hsieh explained.

Noting that the DPP and its traditional "pan-green" ally of the Taiwan Solidarity Union do not control a majority in the legislature, Hsieh said the DPP must continue striving to forge reconciliation and a working partnership with the opposition to ensure domestic political stability.
As the major political parties are busy with the Feb. 1 legislative speaker and deputy speaker elections, Hsieh said, the atmosphere at present is not favorable for inter-party reconciliation.
Nevertheless, Hsieh said, the political climate for inter-party reconciliation will mature after the speaker and deputy speaker elections.
"Once the speaker and deputy speaker are elected, we'll make all-out efforts to activate consultations among various legislative party caucuses and among top party leaders," Hsieh said.
Against this backdrop, Hsieh said, he will keep the vice premier post open for the time being in order to facilitate inter-party reconciliation and cooperation.
Hsieh also took advantage of the occasion to reaffirm his commitment to allowing the people to enjoy a happy Chinese New Year holiday, which will begin Feb. 8, the eve of the Lunar New Year.
After assuming the premiership, Hsieh went on, he will give priority to ensuring smooth traffic flow ahead of and during the holiday.

"Equally important are maintaining good public order, cracking down on crime, ensuring food hygiene and cleaning up the environment, " Hsieh said, adding that he hopes the public will support the Feb. 1-7 National Cleanup Week program to create a clean living environment and prevent any possible epidemic outbreaks, such as dengue fever.

Accompanied by Environmental Protection Administration Administrator Chang Juu-en, senior Kaohsiung city government officials, municipal cleaning workers and volunteers, Hsieh inspected several residential communities to drum up support for the National Cleanup Week.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP MEMBERS GO TO POLLS FOR CHAIRMAN BY-ELECTION

TEXT.P: Members of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) headed to the polls Sunday to cast their ballots in a by-election for the party chairman.

A total of 167 polling stations were set up around the island from 9 a.m through 4 p.m., with vote counting to begin immediately after the polls close. There are around 347,000 eligible DPP voters for the chairman by-election.

Although President Chen Shui-bian is currently on a state visit to the South Pacific country of Palau, first lady Wu Shu-jen, accompanied by DPP Secretary-General Chang Chun-hsiung, cast her ballot at a polling station in Wanhua District to show the first family's support for Presidential Office Secretary-General Su Tseng-chang, who is the sole candidate for the chairmanship.
Noting that casting ballots is an obligation for every party member, the first lady called for a high turnout to support Su.

For his part, Chang said after casting his ballot that the DPP will continue to seek cooperation among the various political parties for the sake of political stability after the new legislature is inaugurated Feb. 1, which is why, he said, he will not vie for the legislative speakership. Chang is a DPP legislator-at-large-elect.

Premier-designate Frank Hsieh and his wife, accompanied by Kaohsiung Mayor-designate Chen Chi-mai, also went to the polls. After casting his ballot, Hsieh said he supports Su's bid for the chairmanship because a strong DPP will favor the promotion of administrative affairs.
Meanwhile, Presidential Office Secretary-General Su Tseng-chang also voted for himself.

Su, who has been traveling around the country over the past few weeks to secure votes, said the turnout rate for the previous DPP chairman election in which there was also a sole candidate stood at only around 10 percent.

He said he expected the turnout for the by-election to also be 10 percent, but added that it will be difficult to reach the target because DPP members have increased by 200,000 over the past four years and the by-election is being held close to the Lunar New Year holiday.

According to a DPP official, the party is scheduled to announce Su's election as new DPP chairman at a press conference to be held at 6 p.m. The outgoing chairman will hand over his post at a ceremony slated for Feb. 15.
Quoting a report from the DPP chapter on the U.S. east coast, the official said that Su obtained support from 40.53 percent of the overseas members who cast their ballots.

The by-election was made necessary after President Chen Shui-bian stepped down from his concurrent post as DPP chairman to take responsibility for the worse-than-expected performance of the party in the Dec. 11 legislative elections. The DPP garnered 89 seats, far less than its target of more than 100 seats in the 225-member legislature.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S., TAIWAN SCHOLARS AIR VIEWS ON CROSS-TAIWAN STRAIT RELATIONS
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Jan. 29 (CNA) (By Oliver Lin and P.C. Tang)

TEXT.P: Several Taiwan and U.S. scholars aired their views in Washington, D.C. Saturday on cross-Taiwan Strait relations, the day special Lunar New Year direct charter flights between Taiwan and mainland China were launched.

The Taiwan Foundation for Democracy and the American University jointly held a seminar Jan. 28-29 in the U.S. capital in which scholars from the United States, mainland China, Taiwan, Hong Kong and Japan discussed issues relating to U.S.-mainland-Taiwan relations. Joanne J.L. Chang, Taiwan's deputy representative to the United States, also attended the event.

Taiwan and the mainland agreed earlier in January to launch direct cross-strait charter flights between Jan. 29 and Feb. 20 to serve mainland-based Taiwanese businessmen and their dependents wishing to return home for the Chinese New Year holiday.

Saying that the launching of the flights for the first time since 1949 is a significant breakthrough, Chang expressed the hope that Taiwan and the mainland can engage in further dialogue. She also urged Beijing to put aside its proposed anti-secession law targeting Taiwan and to seek a mutually beneficial situation with the country.

Claiming that although the special direct cross-strait charter flights will help reduce the tensions between Taiwan and mainland, Alan Romberg, research fellow of the Henry Stimsen Research Center, said, however, that the exclusion of Taiwanese students studying in the mainland from being allowed to board the flights will harm Taiwan's public relations.
Meanwhile, Lai I-Chung, director of the International Affairs Department of Taiwan Thinktank, said that he is not optimistic about the development of cross-strait relations.
He said that despite the fact that the mainland has agreed to the flights, it has also threatened to get tougher with Taiwan by proposing the enactment of an anti-secession law.
A professor from National Chengchi University also said at the seminar that he hopes Washington can work on promoting cross-strait dialogue and other consultations.

DOC.HEADLINE: DIRECT CHARTER FLIGHTS `SIGNIFICANT MATTER': RUSSIAN MEDIA
DOC.DATELINE: Moscow, Jan. 29 (CNA) (By H.K. Chang and P.C. Tang)

TEXT.P: An influential private Russian radio station said several times Saturday that the launch of direct cross-Taiwan Strait charter flights for the Lunar New Year period is an important matter of "the two countries" across the strait.

According to the Echo Radio Station broadcasting out of Moscow, the Republic of China has been a sovereign and independent state since former President Chiang Kai-shek fled to Taiwan from the communists with his defeated troops in 1949.
The private radio station contradicted Russian policy, which recognizes mainland China as the sole ruler of China and does nor recognize the ROC.

Saying that there have been no direct flight services offered by both sides between Taiwan and the mainland in nearly 60 years, the report added that the flights, which kicked off Saturday, will help economic development on the both sides of the strait.
In fact, the charter flights were operated successfully in 2003, although only Taiwan carriers were involved and they had to transit through a third country or area.

Representatives from Taiwan and the mainland reached an agreement Jan. 15 in Macau to allow carriers from both sides to operate the charter flights from Jan. 29 to Feb. 20 to serve Taiwanese businessmen and their families operating on the mainland wishing to return home for the holiday.
