DOC.HEADLINE: MERCURY TO PLUMMET NEXT WEEK

TEXT.P: The mercury in the Taiwan area is expected to drop sharply in the next several days with approach of a cold front from northern mainland China, the Central Weather Bureau (CWB) reported Sunday.
Temperatures in coastal areas north of Chiayi County, southern Taiwan, are expected to plummet to 8 degrees Celsius at the coldest between Feb. 1-3, the weather bureau reported.

CWB meteorologists said the cold front will arrive in northern Taiwan later Sunday and that the coldest days are expected to be between Feb. 1-3, when temperatures in northern Taiwan and the outlying islands of Kinmen and Matsu are forecast to fall to around 8 degrees Celsius or lower.
The weather bureau called for the farming and fishery sectors to guard against frost damage, particularly at higher elevations.

The bureau also called for fishing boats operating to the north and northeast of Taiwan, as well as in the Taiwan Strait, to be watchful of strong winds and high tides as the strong northeast monsoon is sweeping in.
Taiwan witnessed its coldest weather last year Dec. 31, when a northern cold snap hit, causing the mercury to plummet to around 5 degrees Celsius.
Tatunshan in Taipei's northern suburb saw hail Dec. 31, while it snowed for several days in mountainous areas, including Yushan and Hehuanshan, the CWB reported.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT CHAIRMAN WILL VISIT HONG KONG IF INVITED
DOC.DATELINE: Hong Kong, Jan. 30 (CNA) (By Mandy Wong and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan has said he would be glad to visit Hong Kong at the invitation of academic institutes, a Hong Kong-based Taiwan business executive said Sunday.

Chen Zi-chuang, a British-trained law specialist and a managing director of the Taiwan Industrial and Business Association in Hong Kong, said he conveyed a Hong Kong university's invitation to Lien during a recent visit to Taipei.
Lien said that if he can obtain a visa from the Hong Kong authorities this year, he will accept an invitation from the university to visit Hong Kong to deliver a speech, according to Chen.
Lien last visited Hong Kong Oct. 11, 2003, but only for a transit stay of several hours before heading for another country.

Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou was denied a visa to visit Hong Kong Jan. 11-13 by the Hong Kong authorities, reportedly because of his opposition to a proposed mainland Chinese "anti-secession law" targeting Taiwan.
Ma, who is also a vice chairman of the KMT, was born in Hong Kong in 1950.

He was originally invited to deliver a speech on the rise of Chinese urban development from Taipei's perspective at the University of Hong Kong Jan. 11 and to attend a Taipei tourism promotion activity and seminar at the Hong Kong University of Science and Technology Jan. 12.

The Hong Kong government subsequently "suggested" that the University of Hong Kong postpone the seminar until April because, according to the newspaper reports, the controversial "anti-secession law" is expected to have been passed by that time.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT-PFP UNITY MEETING PLANNED TO SUPPORT LEGISLATIVE TICKET

TEXT.P: With only two days to go until the elections for the Legislative Yuan speaker and vice speaker, the legislative caucuses of the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) and the People First Party (PFP) are scheduled to hold a unity meeting Monday in an effort to secure votes for a KMT-PFP ticket in the race.

KMT Chairman Lien Chan and his PFP counterpart, James Soong, will attend the bi-partisan meeting to help consolidate support for incumbent Speaker Wang Jin-pyng's re-election bid and PFP Legislator-at-large Chung Jung-chi for the vice speakership, Huang Teh-fu, secretary-general of the KMT legislative caucus, told reporters.

Huang said the solidarity meeting, to be jointly presided over by the secretaries-general of the two party caucuses in the legislature, is aimed at showing both parties' determination to support the Wang-Chung ticket and to win the speaker and vice speaker election scheduled for Feb. 1.

The attendance of both Lien and Soong at the meeting will boost the morale of KMT and PFP lawmakers, according to Huang. In order to ensure victory for Wang and Chung, the KMT Central Standing Committee decided at an extraordinary meeting to impose the strictest punishment on any of its legislators who don't toe the party line in the voting.
Soong, who returned from the United States Saturday, refuted media reports that PFP legislators are still divided on the Wang-Chung ticket and that five of them might vote in favor of other tickets.

The reports are incorrect, Soong said after attending the funeral of PFP Legislador Cheng Chin-ling's father-in-law in Taoyuan County. He added that he will meet newly elected and re-elected lawmakers to lobby for their support for the Wang-Chung ticket.

For his part, PFP Secretary-General Chin Chin-sheng claimed that KMT-PFP cooperation in the election is not only an important political mission for the two parties but also a pivotal commitment to society. He further said that the party will do its utmost to cement support for the ticket.

Meanwhile, Liu Wen-hsiung, chief convener of the PFP legislative caucus, said that the opposition expect Wang and Chung to be elected despite strong pressure from the "pan-green camp" of the ruling Democratic Party (DPP) and the opposition Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU).
Liu noted that Soong is seeking to address several lawmakers' opposition to Chung's running for the speakership

Wang has been campaigning hard to retain his speaker post in the past few weeks, traveling around the island to court the support of re-elected and newly elected legislators from the ruling and opposition parties.

Party sources said that Wang is almost certain to win re-election, as the "pan-blue alliance" of the KMT and the PFP jointly command a majority of 114 seats in the new 225-member legislature. As for Chung's vice speakership bid, the sources said, it will depend on whether the two parties can consolidate unity within the alliance.

According to media reports, several KMT legislators-elect have said they support the re-election of incumbent Legislative Yuan Vice Speaker P.K. Chiang, who is also a KMT vice chairman and who has also served as minister of economic affairs and chairman of the Council for Economic Planning and Development.

DOC.HEADLINE: TWO ARATS OFFICIALS TO VISIT TAIPEI TO PAY TRIBUTE TO LATE SEF CHIEF
DOC.DATELINE: Beijing, Jan. 30 (CNA) (By Stanley Cheung and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Two senior officials from the Beijing-based Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS) will travel to Taipei Feb. 1 to pay their last respects to Koo Chen-fu, the late top Taiwan negotiator with mainland China, a mainland official said Sunday.

Chen Yunlin, director of the Taiwan Affairs Office (TAO) of the mainland's State Council, said his deputy, Sun Yafu, who concurrently serves as ARATS vice president, and ARATS Secretary-General Li Yafei, will pay tribute to Koo, the late chairman of the Taipei-based Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF), on behalf of ARATS President Wang Daohan.

Chen said the trip is not only aimed at expressing the mainland's esteem for Koo's contributions to the promotion of cross-strait relations but also at symbolizing the mainland's respect for the people of Taiwan.
"We hope Sun and Li will convey our remembrance and condolences during their trip to Taipei," Chen said.

Koo, a respected business tycoon known for his diplomatic acumen, held a groundbreaking meeting with Wang in Singapore in 1993 in the first formal cross-strait contact in more than four decades. He died Jan. 3 at the age of 88.

The historic Koo-Wang meeting laid the framework for the quasi-official SEF and ARATS to handle cross-strait exchanges in the absence of official ties. In 1998, the two envoys met again when Koo traveled to Shanghai and Beijing to boost further rapprochement. However, Beijing unilaterally suspended regular SEF-ARATS dialogue in July 1999, when then-ROC President Lee Teng-hui defined cross-strait ties as state-to-state in nature.
Wang sent his condolences to Koo's family immediately after learning of Koo's death by issuing a press statement via the mainland's official Xinhua News Agency.

According to a Sunday news release posted on Xinhua's Web site, Sun and Li are scheduled to leave Shanghai for Taiwan Feb. 1 and return to the mainland the following day. Koo's funeral will take place Feb. 2.

DOC.HEADLINE: TICKETS FOR BEIJING-TAIPEI FLIGHTS SELLING OUT
DOC.DATELINE: Beijing, Jan. 30 (CNA) (By Stanley Cheung and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Tickets for Beijing-Taipei Lunar New Year charter flights scheduled for Feb. 5 have been hotly sought after, with many people failing to get one.

All tickets for the 125-seat charter flight scheduled to depart Beijing for Taiwan's Chiang Kai-shek International Airport Feb. 5 have been booked, according to Chen Kuo-yuan, secretary-general of the Taiwan Business Association in Beijing.
There will be three more flights until Feb 20 for the convenience of Beijing-based Taiwan businessmen and their relatives during the Lunar New Year period, Chen said.
Bookings are much more heavily sought-after than had been estimated, Chen added.

Seven charter flights operated by six mainland carriers arrived in either Taipei or Kaohsiung from Beijing, Shanghai and Guangzhou Saturday, the first day of the charter services, carrying about 1,700 Taiwanese passengers home for the holidays. They were the first mainland civilian aircraft to arrive legally in Taiwan in 56 years.

The authorities, as well as private airline operators from the two sides of the Taiwan Strait, reached a consensus Jan. 15 on the long-awaited direct air links, although the charter flight services will last only for 23 days over the holiday period.
The two sides agreed that during the Jan. 29-Feb. 20 period, six air carriers from each side will operate a total of 48 charter flights to serve Taiwanese businessmen and their dependents.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT VOWS TO PICK HEAVYWEIGHT TO LEAD SEF
DOC.DATELINE: Honiara, the Solomon Islands, Jan. 30 (CNA) (By S. J. Tsai and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Sunday he will pick a heavyweight figure to head the quasi-official Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) to underscore the importance his administration attaches to relations across the Taiwan Strait.
Chen made the remarks during an informal meeting in the Solomon Islands with Taiwan reporters covering his current two-nation South Pacific visit that already took him to Palau.

After late SEF Chairman Koo Chen-fu's Feb. 2 funeral, Chen said, he will choose a person of similar stature to head the SEF, which is authorized by the government to handle exchanges with mainland China in the absence of official ties.

"I want to pick a heavyweight figure versed in cross-strait affairs to succeed Koo, " Chen said, adding that he will not name a lightweight successor to downgrade the SEF's status, as some critics have speculated.
During a visit to Palau before coming to the Solomon Islands, Chen recalled that he gained inspiration from seeing lush trees growing on barren rocks on a small islet of the Palau island group.

"Since trees can sprout out of hard and rugged rocks, I believe that with goodwill, sincerity, patience and wise new thinking, we will be able to open Beijing's doors no matter how recalcitrant the mainland Chinese leaders are," Chen said.
Chen also took advantage of the occasion to urge mainland China to abort its proposed anti-secession legislation.

"The so-called anti-secession law is an unilateral move to alter the Taiwan Strait status quo and poses a challenge to the Taiwan Relations Act and the U.S.-Japan defense treaty," Chen warned, adding that Beijing's legislative plan would only anger and further alienate Taiwan people.
If the anti-secession law becomes a reality, Chen said, the two sides of the Taiwan Strait would definitely become farther apart rather than get closer.
During his stay in Palau, Chen, a non-swimmer, went snorkeling. The amazing underwater experience also gave him new inspiration, Chen said.

"When snorkeling, you must bow your head in order to see the beautiful underwater world. In daily life, we must be modest. My administrative team must be modest enough to listen to public opinion and opposition critique," he added.

Accompanied by a small entourage, Chen arrived in the Solomon Islands capital of Honiara Saturday for a two-day official visit. Chen is the first Republic of China president ever to visit the nation's South Pacific allies.

Chen said the journey to the two scenic island nations of Palau and the Solomon Islands has hardened his determination to promote balanced and sustainable development in Taiwan. Both Palau and the Solomon Islands have given priority to protecting their natural ecologies and marine resources.

"Sustainability is more important than anything else. The top concern of the 23 million Taiwan people is Taiwan's sustainable development, not any single political party's partisan interests, " Chen added.
With a view to speeding up Taiwan's development, Chen said he will spare no effort to promote inter-party reconciliation and cooperation.

Chen said he was impressed by opposition People First Party (PFP) Chairman James Soong's appeal in Taipei a day earlier for cross-strait reconciliation as well as domestic inter-party reconciliation and ethnic reconciliation.

"I'm more than willing to cooperate with him. I hope he will honor his promise to assist in forging inter-party reconciliation and cooperation, " Chen said, adding he believes that there should be ample room for ruling and opposition parties to sit down to talk and cooperate.
Stressing that inter-party reconciliation and cooperation differ from political horse trading, Chen said inter-party engagements are subject to public supervision in a democratic country like Taiwan.

Earlier in the day, Chen made an inspection tour of farms established with the assistance of the Taiwan agricultural mission stationed in the Solomon Islands. Chen will address the country's parliament Monday before leaving for home. On his way back to Taipei, Chen will make a five-hour transit stop on the U.S. territory of Guam where he will meet with local administrators and Taiwanese expatriates.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEWLY EXPANDED EVERGREEN CONTAINER WHARFS IN U.S. INAUGURATED
DOC.DATELINE: Vancouver, Jan. 29 (CNA) (By Ho Feng-yun and Luis Huang)

TEXT.P: Two container wharfs newly expanded for Taiwan's Evergreen Marine Corp. in Tacoma, Washington, were inaugurated Saturday.

The Tacoma Port Authority spent less than two years completing the container wharf expansion work and transferred its use to Evergreen Marine for a 20-year lease period at a ceremony attended by Evergreen Group Vice Chairman Kuo Hsuan-yu and port officials.

Speaking at the ceremony, Kuo said that the inauguration of the new wharfs with advanced equipment will help Evergreen Marine upgrade its shipping efficiency, while a managing director of the harbor authority said the project will further boost the economic development in the Tacoma area.

According to the director, the port authority invested US$210 in the first-stage expansion project alone, which includes two 51-foot-deep wharfs with a total area of 171 acres and modern infrastructure.

The completion of the first-stage expansion project will help the marine transport company increase its container handling volume to 840,000 TEUS (20-foot equivalent units) annually, the director said, adding that if Evergreen decides to carry out further expansion, its annual container handling volume will go up to 1.2 million TEUs.
Tacoma is the sixth-largest container port in North America.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC TO OFFER FINANCIAL AID FOR COSTA RICAN HIGHWAY PROJECT
DOC.DATELINE: Panama City, Jan. 29 (CNA) (By Ramon Huang and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: The Republic of China will offer financial aid for a highway construction project in the northern Costa Rican city of San Carlos, the ROC Embassy in Costa Rica said in a telephone interview Saturday.

Embassy staff said the project calls for an outlay of US$62 million. The ROC government will donate US$15 million for the project and offer an additional US$35 million in soft loan. The remaining US$12 million will be raised by the Costa Rican government. Taiwan's Ret-Ser Engineering Agency will be responsible for building the new highway.
ROC Ambassador to Costa Rica Wu Tzu-dan said the Costa Rican government attaches great importance to the highway construction project.

Noting that San Carlos is Costa Rica's dairy industry center which provides 68 percent of the country's demand for milk and other dairy products, Wu said the 30-km highway will contribute to the city's transportation and tourist industry.

Wu visited San Carlos Friday at the invitation of the San Carlos city government and council. Wu said he took advantage of the visit to brief San Carlos city councilors, civilian groups representatives and business executives on Taiwan's economic development, progress in various ongoing ROC-Costa Rica cooperative projects and the blueprint of the new San Carlos highway project.
In the past few years, the ROC has also offered aid for Costa Rica to build a long bridge and a Taiwan friendship park.

DOC.HEADLINE: PCC DEPUTY CHIEF TO BE DEPUTY KAOHSIUNG MAYOR

TEXT.P: Incoming acting Kaohsiung Mayor Chen Chi-mai said Sunday he has invited Cheng Wen-lung, vice chairman of the Cabinet-level Public Construction Commission (PCC), to serve as his deputy.

Chen, outgoing Cabinet spokesman who will take over as acting mayor of Taiwan's second-largest city Feb. 1 when incumbent Kaohsiung Mayor Frank Hsieh will assume premiership, said he has decided to name Cheng as his deputy mainly because Cheng is an engineering expert.

"I need his assistance to oversee construction of the city's mass rapid transit system and a number of sporting facilities for the 2009 World Games to be held in Kaohsiung," Chen explained, adding that Cheng, who has a doctoral degree in civil engineering from the University of Washington, has agreed to join his administrative team.

DOC.HEADLINE: KOO FAMILY WELCOMES MAINLAND NEGOTIATOR'S DEPUTIES

TEXT.P: The family of the late Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) Koo Chen-fu has expressed welcome to Koo's mainland counterpart's decision to send three deputies to Taipei to attend Koo's funeral on his behalf, a SEF official said Sunday.

SEF Secretary-General Liu Teh-hsun told a news conference that Wang Daohan, president of the Beijing-based Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS), has named three deputies -- ARATS Vice President Sun Yafu, who concurrently deputy director of the Taiwan Affairs Office of the mainland's State Council, ARATS Secretary-General Li Yafei, and Ma Xiaoguang, ARATS' research department director, -- to attend Koo's funeral.
"Koo's family is grateful for Wang's decision and welcomes Wang's three deputies' attendance at Koo's funeral," Liu said.

The three ARATS officials are scheduled to arrive in Taipei Feb. 1 and return to mainland China the following day, Liu said, adding that their entry applications will be handled in accordance with a SEF-ARATS agreement on convenient personnel exchanges between the two quasi-official intermediary bodies.
The two organizations have no public contact since mid-1999. Liu said he hopes the two intermediary bodies can resume regular dialogue as early as possible.

Koo, a respected business tycoon known for his diplomatic acumen, held a groundbreaking meeting with Wang in Singapore in 1993 in the first formal cross-strait contact in more than four decades. He died Jan. 3 at the age of 88.

The historic Koo-Wang meeting laid the framework for the quasi-official SEF and ARATS to handle cross-strait exchanges in the absence of official ties. In 1998, the two envoys met again when Koo traveled to Shanghai and Beijing to boost further rapprochement. However, Beijing unilaterally suspended regular SEF-ARATS dialogue in July 1999, when then-ROC President Lee Teng-hui defined cross-strait ties as state-to-state in nature.

On Sunday afternoon, Chen Yunlin, director of the Taiwan Affairs Office (TAO) of the mainland's State Council, said in Beijing that the three ARATS officials' Taipei trip is not only aimed at expressing the mainland's esteem for Koo's contributions to the promotion of cross-strait relations but also at symbolizing the mainland's respect for the people of Taiwan.
"We hope the trio will convey our remembrance and condolences during their trip to Taipei," Chen said.
Wang sent his condolences to Koo's family immediately after learning of Koo's death by issuing a press statement via the mainland's official Xinhua News Agency.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW DPP CHAIRMAN VOWS TO EXPAND PARTY'S SUPPORT BASE

TEXT.P: Newly elected ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Chairman Su Tseng-chang said Sunday he will dedicate himself to the party's cause and create a larger base of support for the party.
Su made the remarks after winning a by-election for the party's top post earlier in the day. Su was the sole candidate and won 68,606 ballots in the by-election.

According to DPP Secretary-General Chang Chun-hsiung, 347,721 DPP members were eligible to vote in the by-election. The voter turnout was 19.73 percent and Su won 99.71 percent of total ballots cast in the by-election.

Chang said proudly that the DPP is the only Taiwan political party that allows its rank-and-file members to elect their party chairman. Su is the party's third directly elected chairman after Lin Yi-hsiung and Frank Hsieh. The by-election was held after President Chen Shui-bian quit the party chairmanship to take responsibility for the party's disappointing showing in last December's legislative elections.
Su, a lawyer-turned-politician who was also a DPP founding member, said after winning the by-election that only a democratic party can defend democratic values.

"The by-election has once again consolidated the DPP's democratic mechanism, " Su said, adding that he will do his utmost to lead the DPP in "building the widest avenue to reflect the broad will of the people, allowing more people to support the DPP."

The 58-year-old Su came to prominence as magistrate of Taipei county, making him a natural competitor with opposition Kuomintang's most popular politician, Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou, for the 2008 presidential race.

Another possible DPP contender for the 2008 race is Premier-designate Frank Hsieh, who enjoyed high popularity ratings as mayor of Taiwan's second largest city, Kaohsiung. Hsieh will formally take over as premier Feb. 1.

DOC.TEXT:
The Washington Post: Iraqis Begin Voting Amid Violence.
Explosions reverberated across Iraq's capital and several other large cities Sunday leaving an estimated 17 dead by early afternoon. But Iraq's first democratic election in nearly half a century was nevertheless well underway, albeit unevenly, with visible jubilation in some areas and shuttered polling places in others.

DOC.HEADLINE: SPEAKERSHIP BID AIMED AT CHANGING LEGISLATIVE CULTURE: DPP CANDIDATE

TEXT.P: Acting ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Chairman Ker Chien-ming, who is also a veteran legislator, said Sunday his decision to run for the legislative speaker post is mainly aimed at changing the legislative culture.
Ker said the Legislative Yuan speaker post has been controlled by the Kuomintang (KMT) for the past 55 years.
"It's time for us to change the legislature's landscape and culture," Ker said, adding that the legislature needs a new culture and an end to zero-sum inter-party political wrangling.

Ker said if he manages to win the election, he will show magnanimity and modesty in promoting inter-party reconciliation and cooperation to maintain domestic political stability and speed up Taiwan's economic development.

Noting that incumbent Legislative Yuan President Wang Jin-pyng, also a KMT vice chairman, is an old-fashioned politician, Ker claimed that if Wang is re-elected as speaker, the legislature will continue its confrontational work style. The political wrangling on the legislative floor over the past three years has left a shameful page in the legislature's history and the chamber's approval rating has also sunk to an all-time low.

As the DPP and its ally -- the Taiwan Solidarity Union -- jointly control only 101 seats in the 225-member new legislature to be sworn in Feb. 1, Ker is facing an uphill battle to defeat Wang. The KMT and its ally -- the People First Party (PFP) -- jointly control a slim majority in the legislature.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Monday, Jan. 31, or the 23rd day of the 12th month of the Year of the Monkey according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1835: U.S. President Andrew Jackson is saved by the double misfire of a would-be assassin's pistol when he is attacked at close range on Capitol Hill.
1917: The United States enters World War I after Germany announces its policy of unrestricted naval warfare and attacks American ships.
1925: Chiang Kai-shek, commandant of the Whampoa Military Academy, holds a campus ceremony to give a pep talk to the troops before launching a military expedition to eradicate warlords in eastern China.
1929: Leon Trotsky, Lenin's former right-hand man and commissar for war, is expelled from the Soviet Union after losing a power struggle with Joseph Stalin.
1930: The United States, Britain, France, Italy and Japan begin the London Naval Conference aimed at disarmament.
1943: German troops surrender to the Russians at Stalingrad after losing 850,000 men in a seven-month siege of the city.
1947: Tuanhungtou Island, south of Green Island off eastern Taiwan, is renamed Lanyu Island. The island is inhabited by the Yami, a small indigenous tribe.
1950: U.S. President Harry Truman gives the go-ahead for the development of the hydrogen bomb.
1954: Express train service between Moscow and Beijing begins operation.
1955: The UNSC discusses the Taiwan Strait cease-fire issue and passes a resolution inviting communist China to take part in the discussion.
1956: An organization calling itself the "Taiwan Republic Provisional Government" is established in Tokyo.
1958: Explorer I, the first U.S. satellite to orbit the earth, is launched at Cape Canaveral in Florida.
1965: ROC athlete Chi Cheng breaks the women's 60-yard low hurdle record in Canada, with a time of 7.7 seconds.
1968: Nauru, jointly administered by Australia, Britain and New Zealand since World War I, becomes independent.
1970: The Pentagon announces a gift of 34 F-100 saber jet fighter-bombers to the Republic of China.
1970: The Taiwan Garrison Command General Headquarters orders the arrest of Peng Ming-min, former professor and director of Political Science Department of National Taiwan University.
1973: ROC President Chiang Kai-shek names Johnson Cheng as ambassador to the Kingdom of Swaziland.
1973: Continental Illinois National Bank and Trust Company of Chicago opens its Taipei branch.
1974: Eleven South Korean legislators led by Kim Jeem-Bong arrive in Taipei for a five-day visit.
1976: A China Airlines-sponsored women's basketball team leaves for the United States to play 18 games in seven cities.
1979: Border war between communist China and Vietnam breaks out.
1979: Deng Xiaoping, communist China's first vice premier, says after meeting with U.S. President Jimmy Carter and congressmen that Moscow is the world's main hotbed of war.
1983: U.S. President Ronald Reagan offers to meet Soviet President Yuri Andropov to discuss a missile pact.
1991: The ROC Executive Yuan approves a budget of about US$303 billion for the Six-Year National Development Plan.
1996: An explosion demolishes an apartment in central Hunan province, mainland China, killing 122 people.
1998: Beijing authorities parole Zhang Xiaoxu, a veteran dissident jailed for 15 years for his role in the 1989 Tiananmen Square demonstrations.
2000: President Lee Teng-hui tells visiting Swaziland Prime Minister Barnabas Sisbusiso Dlamini that the ROC will further expand cooperation with Swaziland.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "In teaching men, I make no difference between the rich and the poor. I have taught men who could just afford to bring me the barest of gifts in the same way as I have taught others."

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CHEN TO MAKE TRANSIT STOP IN GUAM EN ROUTE HOME
DOC.DATELINE: Honiara, the Solomon Islands, Jan. 31 (CNA) (By S.J. Tsai and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian and his entourage are expected to arrive in the U.S. territory of Guam Monday for a transit stop en route back to Taiwan after concluding a diplomatic tour to Palau and the Solomon Islands.
President Chen and his entourage will depart the Solomon Islands shortly before noon Monday. They are scheduled to arrive in Guam at around 3 p.m. local time for a five-hour stopover.

David Brown, a board director of the American Institute in Taiwan (AIT) ; Guam Governor Carl Gutierrez; and a U.S. congressman are expected to meet President Chen at the Guam airport. The AIT is a quasi-official organization authorized to handle U.S. exchanges with Taiwan in the absence of formal diplomatic relations between the two countries.

During his stay in Guam, President Chen is once again expected to echo U.S. President George W. Bush's call for expanding freedom and democracy outlined in his second-term inaugural speech. He will also reaffirm his commitment to promoting reconciliation among Taiwan's ruling and opposition parties.
Chen is scheduled to lay a wreath at the Asan Beach war memorial and meet with Taiwanese expatriates in Guam for a luncheon.
According to Chen's aides accompanying him on his tour, Taiwan experienced no difficulties in arranging for the president's transit stop in Guam, with U.S. officials agreeing to the request.
In the Solomon Islands Monday, President Chen addressed the South Pacific nation's parliament before concluding his state visit.

He praised the people, lawmakers and government of the Solomon Islands for their concerted efforts in resolving differences among themselves and reaching reconciliation after the country was divided over ethnic problems.

He noted that the Solomon Islands' national flag -- which has a yellow diagonal line separating a field of blue with five white stars and a field of green -- provides great inspiration to Taiwan's people and political leaders, saying that the yellow line tells Taiwan that it can serve as a bridge between the "pan-blue" and "pan-green" camps instead of as a dividing line.
"Dialogue is the best way to resolve differences and seek consensus, while reconciliation forms the bedrock of consolidation and sustainable development of a country," he asserted.

President Chen kicked off his five-day visit to Palau and the Solomon Islands -- two Republic of China diplomatic allies in the South Pacific -- on Jan. 27. He plans to visit the ROC's other allies in the region, including the Marshall Islands and Kiribati, in May this year.

DOC.HEADLINE: PROSECUTORS SEEKING LIFE SENTENCE FOR BOMBER SUSPECT

TEXT.P: Prosecutors are seeking a life sentence for Kao Pao-chung, who has been charged with setting off canisters of liquefied natural gas in a huge fire ball at a parking lot outside the Taipei Railway Station in early December.

After more than a month of investigations, prosecutors from the Taipei District Prosecutor's Office recommended in court Monday that Kao be handed a life sentence for violating the arms control statute, attempted murder, and posing a terrorist threat to the public.
The prosecutors said that Kao used an extremely dangerous method to express his personal indignation with Taiwan's political situation and society and should be locked up for life.
Kao, 46, was nabbed by police in Taichung, central Taiwan, in mid January. He confessed to the crime during preliminary inquiries by police.

After a pickup truck loaded with canisters of liquefied natural gas exploded at the Taipei Railway Station Dec. 9, 2004 -- two days before the nationwide legislative elections -- police found a note at the site of the explosion indicating that more bombs had been placed inside the train station. The police then searched the station and found four fake explosive devices with anti-Taiwan independence slogans attached to them.
Prior to Dec. 9, several local television stations also received similar bomb threats which turned out to be hoaxes.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP OFFICIAL DENIES VOTE-BUYING ACCUSATIONS

TEXT.P: Ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Secretary-General Chang Chun-hsiung on Monday denied accusations that the party is trying to buy votes in the upcoming legislative speaker and vice speaker elections.
Chang said the DPP will not interfere in the elections with money, and he dared the accusers to present evidence, if any, to authorities for investigation.
Chang said it is the DPP's hope to reform the Legislative Yuan and engage in clean elections.

Some opposition Kuomintang (KMT) politicians have alleged that the DPP is offering NT$70 million (US$2.2 million) per vote in exchange for legislators' support in the elections, set to be held Tuesday after the legislators-elect are sworn in.
KMT Chairman Lien Chan said earlier in the day that the DPP must be held accountable if the allegations are true.
Lien said it would represent the most serious contempt for the legislature and the greatest humiliation to the lawmakers if money were used to influence the elections.

The KMT and opposition People First Party (PFP) , which together enjoy a slim majority in the legislature, are jointly fielding two-term speaker Wang Jin-pyng from the KMT and PFP legislator-elect David J.C. Chung to run for speaker and vice speaker, respectively.
While the DPP has nominated its acting chairman, Ker Chien-ming, to run for speaker, it has yet to decide on its candidate for vice speaker.

DOC.HEADLINE: PROCESS OF U.S. BEEF REENTERING TAIWAN IN FINAL STAGE: U.S. OFFICIAL
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Jan. 30 (CNA) (By Wennie Chi and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Taiwan is expected to announce in about a month the results of its inspections that mark the final stage in allowing U.S. beef back on the local market following the suspension of imports in 2003 due to the discovery of a case of mad cow disease, an official with the U.S. Department of Agriculture (USDA) said Sunday.

Taiwan suspended beef imports from the United States in December 2003 due to safety concerns over bovine spongiform encephalopathy (BSE), also known as mad cow disease, after the discovery in the U.S. state of Washington of a single BSE-infected case at a cattle ranch.

According to the USDA official, who asked not to be identified, Taiwan health and agriculture officials have traveled to the United States to conduct on-site inspections of the implementation of the U.S. safeguards against mad cow disease.

The Taiwan officials have completed the reviews necessary for resuming the beef trade, the USDA official said, adding that officials from the American Institute in Taiwan (AIT) have also been contacting relevant Taiwan officials in an effort to speed up the paperwork so that U.S. beef can reenter the Taiwan market at an earlier date.
AIT is a quasi-official organization authorized by Washington to handle U.S. exchanges with Taiwan in the absence of formal diplomatic relations between the two countries.

USDA officials are now more reserved and low-key over the reentry issue than before after Taiwan lodged a protest against the USDA for its unilateral announcement late October last year concerning Taiwan's reopening of its market to U.S. beef.

The USDA announced on Oct. 26 that Taiwan has agreed in principle to resume imports of U.S. beef and beef products. Taiwan officials told them that they were close to completing the reviews necessary for resuming the beef trade, with on-site inspections being at the final step in the process, the USDA news release indicated.
If everything went smoothly, it was expected that Taiwan would reopen its doors to U.S. beef and beef products before the end of 2004, the USDA news release said.
At that time, most of the Taiwan officials who were assigned to travel to the United States for inspection missions had not yet gone to the United States.

Taiwan purchased US$325 million worth of U.S. beef and beef products in 2003 and was the sixth-largest importer of U.S. beef before it imposed the ban in December 2003. Since then, Australian beef has replaced U.S. beef in the Taiwan market.

More than 40 countries, including Japan, the largest importer, have imposed embargoes against U.S. beef, seriously affecting the U.S. beef export trade, which is worth at least US$3.8 billion a year. Big names in the beef export trade, including Tyson Foods, Inc. and Cargill, Inc., have exerted great pressure on the USDA for the early resumption of exports to these former importing countries.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange closed higher Monday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 114.3 points to close at 5,994.23.
The bourse opened at 5,905.3 and fluctuated between 6,002.37 and 5,900.37 during trading. A total of 4.45 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$99.73 billion (US$3.13 billion).

All eight major stock categories gained ground, with machinery and electronics shares moving up the most at 2.4 percent, followed by construction issues at 2 percent, paper and pulp issues at 1.9 percent, banking and financial shares and cement stocks both at 1.8 percent, textile stocks at 1.6 percent, foodstuff issues at 1.5 percent and plastics and chemicals shares at 0.8 percent.
Gainers outnumbered losers 741 to 104, with 135 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: PFP CHAIRMAN REAFFIRMS SUPPORT FOR KMT'S BID FOR LEGISLATIVE SPEAKER

TEXT.P: Opposition People First Party (PFP) Chairman James Soong reaffirmed Monday his support for the opposition Kuomintang's (KMT) candidate for legislative speaker, incumbent Wang Jin-pyng.
Soong also expressed his gratitude for the KMT's support for the PFP's candidate for vice speaker, David J.C. Chung.

Soong made the remarks on arriving at KMT headquarters for a meeting with KMT Chairman Lien Chan to exchange views on Tuesday's elections for speaker and vice speaker. He told reporters he will also share with Lien details of his talks with U.S. officials during his just-concluded visit in the United States.

He pointed out that a number of rumors were being circulated in Taiwan while he was away, which included stories suggesting that the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) had sent representatives to meet him in the U.S. and that the PFP was prepared to cooperate with the DPP despite the DPP's pro-independence position.
Dismissing these stories as unfounded, Soong said both the PFP and the KMT are defenders of the Republic of China and opposed to independence for Taiwan.
On reports that President Chen Shui-bian plans to appoint Soong as chairman of the Straits Exchange Foundation, Soong said he has not received any such information.
Also on Monday, PFP Legislator Shen Chih-hwei visited Wang and Chung to express her support for their bids for speaker and vice speaker.
Shen took the move in an effort to clarify reports that she did not support the two candidates.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES HIGHER ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were higher Monday as the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for February gained 108 points to close at 5,982, with 41,876 contracts changing hands.
TAIEX Index futures for March gained 103 points to finish at 5,988, with 1,446 contracts traded, while June futures gained 107 points to close at 5,980, with 24 contracts traded.
September futures gained 110 points to close at 5,904, with 41 contracts traded, while December futures moved up 96 points to end at 5,853, with 13 contract transactions.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Monday at 5,874 for February, 5,885 for March, 5,873 for June, 5,794 for September and 5,757 for December.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were higher.

February TE futures moved up 5.45 points to close at 225.45, with 7,007 contracts traded, while March TE futures gained 5.3 points to finish at 225.5, with 248 contract transactions. June TE futures moved up 0.8 points to finish at 222, with three contracts traded, while September TE futures gained 4.85 points to close at 223.05, with one contract transaction.
No transactions were recorded for December.
February TF futures gained 14 points to finish at 1009.2, with 5,691 contracts changing hands, while March TF futures moved up 15 points to finish at 1008.8, with 549 contracts traded.
No transactions were recorded for June, September and December.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. DOLLAR DOWN ON TAIPEI FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar lost ground against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Monday, dropping NT$0.012 to close at NT$31.790.
A total of US$831 million changed hands during the day's trading.
The greenback opened at NT$31.875 and fluctuated between NT$31.750 and NT$31.936.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Straits Times: High turnout as Iraqis defy insurgents to vote.
The people of Iraq defied insurgents by voting in unexpectedly large numbers yesterday in their country's first independent election in half a century. Although insurgents killed at least 44 people in attacks on polling places, an election official said as many as 60 per cent of Iraq's 14 million registered voters may have voted by the time polls closed at 5pm.
The Lianhe Zaobao: The Iraqi votes enthusiastically.
Iraq held the country's first independent election yesterday in past 50 years. Although insurgents killed at least 44 people in attacks on polling places, an election official said as many as 60 per cent of Iraq's 14 million registered voters may have voted by the time polls closed at 5pm.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER-DESIGNATE NAMES MORE NEW ADMINISTRATIVE TEAM MEMBERS

TEXT.P: Premier-designate Frank Hsieh named several new members Monday to join his administrative team, with Lee Ying-yuan, incumbent secretary-general of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), serving as his chief of staff.

On the last day of his tenure as Kaohsiung mayor, Hsieh, who will take over as premier Tuesday, said he is very pleased that Lee has agreed to serve as the Executive Yuan or Cabinet secretary-general once again.

Lee, who has a doctoral degree in medical economics from the University of North Carolina, had been a legislator, Taiwan's deputy representative to the United States and Cabinet secretary-general before becoming the DPP chief of staff.

"Lee is the best choice for the Cabinet chief of staff post. He has been known for his skill in communications and coordination and is versed in legislative operations. His rich career experiences will well support the Cabinet's smooth interaction with major political parties and the opposition-controlled Legislative Yuan, " Hsieh said.
Meanwhile, Hsieh said, Chang Chun-yen, secretary-general of the Kaohsiung City Government, will serve as director-general of the Central Personnel Administration (CPA) in his Cabinet.

Chang once served as the Kaohsiung City Government's personnel department chief for six years, Hsieh said, adding that Chang had also been the Tainan City Government's financial affairs bureau chief and Kaohsiung Bank chairman before assuming his current post.
Chang will fill the post vacated by Lee Yi-yang, who will become DPP secretary-general.

As to incumbent Kaohsiung Deputy Mayor Lin Yung-chien, Hsieh said he has decided to name Lin as vice minister of the interior. Hsieh said he recognizes Lin's performance as deputy mayor of Taiwan's second-largest city for the past few years. As the vice minister of the interior, Hsieh said, Lin will be able to assist the Cabinet in handling local affairs.

Incumbent Vice Minister of the Interior Lin Chin-yung will replace Cheng Wen-lung as vice chairman of the Public Construction Commission (PCC) . Hsieh said Lee is a lawyer-turned-politician and will be able to more professionally supervise the PCC's procurement and BOT projects in the future. Cheng will serve as Kaohsiung deputy mayor.

As for the vice premier post, Hsieh said the post will be left vacant for the time being to give the DPP leverage to forge reconciliation and cooperation with the opposition. Hsieh said he is very grateful for incumbent Vice Premier Yeh Chu-lan's generosity and magnanimity to voluntarily tender the post.

Noting that the DPP and its traditional "pan-green" ally, the Taiwan Solidarity Union, do not control a majority in the legislature, Hsieh said the DPP must continue striving to forge reconciliation and a working partnership with the opposition to ensure domestic political stability.
As all major political parties are busy with the Feb. 1 legislative speaker and deputy speaker elections, Hsieh said, the atmosphere at present is not favorable for inter-party reconciliation.
Hsieh said last week that as many incumbent Cabinet members took office only last May, he will give them at least six more months to implement their ideals and initiatives.

Therefore, Hsieh said, the Cabinet will undergo only minor adjustments. "I know every individual has his or her own character and taste. I want to give all of you at least six more months for us to adapt to each other and to see if we have shared values and opinions, " Hsieh said, adding that he hopes all of his Cabinet members will speak freely with each other, work as a team and take pride in their jobs.

DOC.HEADLINE: OUTPUT OF OPTOELECTRONICS SECTOR TO HIT NT$1.5 TRILLION IN 2005

TEXT.P: The production value of Taiwan's optoelectronics industry is expected to rise 34 percent year-on-year to NT$1.5 trillion (US$47.17 billion) in 2005 owing to increased global demand for optical display and optical storage products, according to the Industrial Technology Research Institute (ITRI) on Monday.
The production value of the optoelectronics industry was NT$1.1 trillion in 2004, up 43 percent from the 2003 level, an ITRI report said.

Of the NT$1.1 trillion, NT$933.3 billion, or 83 percent, was contributed by optical display and optical storage products, the report said, adding that the combined output of these two kinds of optical products is expected to continue to grow to NT$1.3 trillion in 2005.

While the newly launched production lines for liquid crystal flat panels of Au Optronics and Chi Mei Optoelectronics will raise the output of optical display products, the popularity of DVD players, recorders and burners will boost the demand for optical storage products, according to the report.

Meanwhile, the optical input sector is expected to benefit from the strong global demand for digital cameras, and the development of broadband networking in various countries around the world will also bolster the optical communications sector, the report said.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Washington Post: Iraqis Defy Threats as Millions Vote; Mood Is Festive; Turnout Appears Strong Despite Deadly Attacks.
Millions of Iraqis turned out Sunday to cast ballots in the country's first free elections in a half-century, the ranks of voters surging as attacks by insurgents proved less ferocious than feared and enthusiasm spilled over into largely Sunni Arab regions where hardly a campaign poster had appeared, the paper said.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The New York Times: Defying Threats, Millions of Iraqis Vote.
Defying death threats, Iraqis turned out in great numbers on Sunday to vote in this country's first free elections in 50 years, offering a powerful, if uneven, endorsement of democratic rule 22 months after Saddam Hussein was overthrown.
The Wall Street Journal: Despite Violence,Iraqis Head to Polls In Large Numbers.
Despite lethal insurgent attacks, Iraqi voters turned out in large numbers for a historic election that pushed the country into the next phase of its transition from occupation to full sovereignty.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Times: Iraq embracess a brave new world of democracy.
The last time that Iraqis went to the polls was in 2002 when they voted 100 per cent for Saddam Hussein, the only candidate on the ballot paper. They voted again yesterday, millions of them, for a host of candidates, in the first free elections that any but the very oldest could remember. This time, although 35 people were killed by suicide bombers and mortar shells, they defied those who would keep them in thrall. Initial estimates from the independent electoral commission suggest that around eight million people -- roughly 60 per cent of the eligible population -- took part in the polls, although it admitted that this was little more than a guess. hat was more than enough for President Bush to declare the vote a resounding success.

DOC.HEADLINE: TZU CHI BEGINS RELIEF DISTRIBUTION OPERATIONS IN SRI LANKA

TEXT.P: The Buddhist Compassion Relief Tzu Chi Foundation has began to distribute relief supplies to thousands of tsunami victims in Sri Lanka, members of the charitable organization based in Hualien County, eastern Taiwan, said Monday.

The large distribution operation, begun Jan. 29, was the first of its kind prepared by the Tzu Chi group to help aid the South Asian country, one of the regional countries hit hard by tsunamis triggered by a 9.0-magnitude earthquake off Indonesian island of Sumatra December 26.

Tzi Chi members from the United States, Canada, Singapore, Malaysia and local volunteers joined in the operation to hand out daily necessities, including rice, sugar, oil for cooking and powdered milk, according to the Tzu Chi organization.
The amount of the relief supplies should cover the needs of 1,490 households, or 5,788 people, Tzu Chi members said.

Meanwhile, Taiwan's textile sector presented its donation in a ceremony Monday in Taipei, which was presided over by Taiwan Textile Federation (TTF) Chairman Ho Chun, with representatives of 22 textile business associations from around the island attending.

Textile companies and associated organizations have donated over NT$2 million, as well as surgical masks, clothing and tents to aid tsunami and earthquake victims in South and Southeast Asia, according to the TTF.

DOC.HEADLINE: CROSS-STRAIT TIES STILL DELICATE DESPITE CHARTER FLIGHTS: KMT AIDE

TEXT.P: Relations between Taiwan and mainland China remain fragile despite the successful launch of the Chinese New Year holiday charter flights between the two sides, according to Kuomintang (KMT) spokesman Chang Jong-kung.

Chang reminded the government led by the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) of the fact that bilateral ties are still at stake and urged the government to build on this success to carefully promote fresh two-way exchanges because "the flights do not mean that cross-Taiwan Strait friction has been reduced."

Ascribing the beginning of the historic direct charter flights to high expectations from the United States and to compromises made by the government, Chang claimed that the service would not have begun were it not for the help of the KMT.

He said that in the future, the service should be provided in a more convenient and efficient fashion to cover a broader range of Taiwan people. Taiwan students in mainland China are excluded from the service this time, which was designed solely to carry homecoming Taiwan businessmen and their families based in the mainland.
He suggested that the government learn something from the negotiation model this time and urged it to do its best to push for the opening of full trade, transport and postal links across the strait.

Meanwhile, representatives of Taiwan's aviation industry, including China Airlines and EVA Airways Corp. -- Taiwan's two largest carriers -- said that they strongly hope that the direct charter service would help set a precedence for future reconciliation and negotiations.
Cross-strait links have been banned since 1949 after Taiwan and the mainland separated in the wake of a civil war.

DOC.HEADLINE: INNOVATION IS TAIWAN'S COMPETITIVE EDGE: ECONOMICS MINISTER

TEXT.P: Taiwan will make use of its advantage in innovation as well as research and development (R&D) to compete with other countries economically, Minister of Economic Affairs Ho Mei-yueh said Monday.

With Asia having replaced North America and Europe to become Taiwan's major export market over the past decade, the regional economic integration of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) is posing a challenge to the island, Ho said.

Taiwan must enhance its capability in innovation and R&D, diversify its industries and investment, and encourage businesses to set up R&D centers or operational headquarters in Taiwan to cope with the challenges, Ho said.
A total of 80 Taiwanese enterprises and 25 multinational enterprises have established R&D centers in Taiwan to date, with 252 new products being developed in 2004, Ho noted.
Ho predicted that Taiwan will be able to develop 600 new products per year by 2006, which she said will give the island a competitiveness edge.

Ho said Taiwan will continue to compete with other countries with its high value-added and innovative products in the future and will transfer production to mainland China after the products become universal and production costs fall.
Ho made the remarks during a seminar on Taiwan's economic status and outlook.
According to the minister, Taiwan's economic growth stood at 5.93 percent in 2004, and its private investment and industrial output also rose by 24.9 percent and 9.8 percent, respectively.
Also, the unemployment rate dropped to 4.44 percent in 2004, Ho said.
While foreign trade volume amounted to US$342 billion in 2004, the figure is expected to rise 11.03 percent to US$379.6 billion in 2005, she said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI MISSION IN KOREA OPENS BUSAN OFFICE

TEXT.P: The Republic of China's representative office in South Korea opened a branch in Busan Monday to better serve South Korean citizens and ROC expatriates residing in the country's southern provinces and cities.
The ROC closed its Busan Consulate General in August 1992 when South Korea switched its diplomatic recognition from Taipei to Beijing.
After a nearly 13-year hiatus, the ROC has opened a new representative office in Busan, South Korea's second-largest city after Seoul.

The new office is named the "Taipei Mission in Korea, Busan Office." The Taipei Mission in Korea, headquartered in Seoul, represents Taiwan's interests in South Korea in the absence of formal diplomatic ties.
Lee Tsai-fang, the de facto ROC ambassador to South Korea, traveled from Seoul to Busan to preside over the Busan branch's inaugural ceremony.

Lee said the opening of the Busan office marks yet another step forward in the substantive Taiwan-South Korean relations following the resumption of direct air links last September after a 12-year hiatus.

Once the Busan office begins formal operations in March, Lee said, South Korean residents and Taiwan expatriates in southern South Korea will no longer need to travel to Seoul for visas or document notary services.

DOC.HEADLINE: JANUARY CONSUMER CONFIDENCE INDEX FALLS: NCU POLL

TEXT.P: Taiwan's consumer confidence index (CCI) fell by 1.28 points to 75.85 points for January from the previous month's level, with the confidence indicator in the local job market posting the largest drop, according to a report released Monday.

According to Chu Yun-peng, director of the economic development center under the National Central University (NCU), which carried out the survey, public confidence in the country's job market for the coming six-month period was eroded in particular, representing a drop of 5.65 points month to month to stand at 84.05 points.

The decline marks a contrast to statistics made public recently by the Cabinet-level Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics that show that Taiwan's jobless rate has improved, Chu noted.

Indicators in three other areas -- consumer product prices, family economic situations and the country's economy -- also decreased over the prospects for the next six months by 4.05 points, 2.75 points and 0.05 points, respectively, to 56.15 points, 72.9 points and 75.1 points, the poll found.

However, indicators regarding the timing for purchasing stocks and durable goods in the February-July period rose to 59.2 points and 107.7 points, respectively, up by 4.7 points and 0.15 percent over the December levels.
A score of between 100 and 200 points indicates an optimistic sentiment, while a level lower than 100 points reflects a pessimistic atmosphere, analysts said.
The random telephone survey was conducted from Jan. 18-23, questioning 2,058 residents aged over 20 in Taiwan. It had a margin of error of 2.2 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: VP TO VISIT LATIN AMERICA IN MARCH FOR 'TAIWAN PARK' PROJECT

TEXT.P: Vice President Annette Lu said Monday she will survey potential sites for the establishment of a "Taiwan Park" during a visit she is scheduled to make to Latin America in March.
Lu said the site for the industrial park, which will be 200-500 hectares in area, will be selected from among the Republic of China's diplomatic allies in Latin America.
She made the remarks while making an inspection tour of the Institute for Information Industry with the Presidential Office's technology advisory committee.

According to Lu, the park will bring together traditional, agricultural and technological industries, and the government hopes it will bring results and become a major showcase for Taiwan within three years.
Lu said Taiwan will be able to enter the vast Spanish-speaking market with the support of its strong information technology and manufacturing capability if the project is successful.

DOC.HEADLINE: LEGAL AID FOUNDATION HELPS ONE FAMILY EVERY 67 MINUTES: SPOKESMAN

TEXT.P: The Legal Aid Foundation (LAF) has helped defend one low-income family's legal rights every 67 minutes since its inception July 1, 2004, a spokesman for the non-profit organization said Monday.
As of the end of last year, LAF Secretary-General Cheng Wen-lung said, the foundation had assisted in 3,843 legal cases involving low-income families.
"The figure can be translated into 21 cases a day, or one family receiving legal aid every 67 minutes," Cheng said.

The foundation received 8,283 applications for legal aid in the six-month period from July 1, 2004 through the end of last year, Cheng went on, adding that if the applications involving only legal counseling were excluded, the number of applications for assistance in lawsuit proceedings was 7,250, of which 61 percent were approved.
Over the past six months, Cheng said, the foundation has also issued NT$41 million-worth of guaranty papers for disadvantaged applicants to seek injunctions on their debtors' property.

The foundation now has five branches in Taipei, Taichung, Tainan, Kaohsiung and Hualien, Cheng said, adding that five additional branches will open this year to serve more low-income families who need legal aid to defend their legitimate rights to fight or institute lawsuits. The five new branches will be located in Taoyuan, Hsinchu, Changhua, Ilan and Taitung cities.

The foundation was established in line with the Legal Aid Law that took effect early last year. The establishment of the foundation made Taiwan one of the few countries in the world to create institutionalized mechanisms to protect low-income earners' legal rights. The foundation is supported by an annual NT$500 million budget from the Judicial Yuan.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S IDENTITY TO BE SHAPED BY ACTS NOT WORDS: PREMIER-DESIGNATE

TEXT.P: Kaohsiung Mayor Frank Hsieh pledged in Kaohsiung Monday on the eve of his swearing-in as premier to build a "healthy Taiwan, " saying that the identity of the country should be shaped by acts rather than words.

Chatting with journalists, the premier-designate said he takes pride in the fact that his experience in governing Kaohsiung City for the last six years has been mentioned in reports recently as something of value for his new job as premier.

Noting that the country has spent a lot of time discussing Taiwan's identity, Hsieh said he prefers to shape the country's identity through action such as the just-launched charter flights between Taiwan and mainland China. He did not elaborate on how this might relate to the Taiwan identity issue.
He admitted the necessity of the legislature's supervision of the Executive Yuan but said the supervision should not be just fault-finding for political purposes.

In the working relationship between the Executive Yuan and the Legislative Yuan, Hsieh said, mutual trust is very important. He promised to build up the legislature's trust in the Executive Yuan after he takes office.

As for Chen Chih-mai, the Executive Yuan spokesman who has been named as acting Kaohsiung mayor, Hsieh said Chen is well qualified for the post and is also popular in Kaohsiung in light of the fact he was elected legislator in Kaohsiung in 1998 with more ballots than anyone else.

DOC.HEADLINE: 1.7 WORK OPPORTUNITIES FOR EACH JOB SEEKER IN 2004: DGBAS

TEXT.P: Each job seeker had an average of 1.7 work opportunities last year in Taiwan, up from 1.6 opportunities in 2003, the Cabinet-level Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS) reported Monday.

According to DGBAS officials, companies registered about 897,000 jobs with the government's employment service agencies for the whole of 2004, an increase of 24.4 percentage points over the 2003 level, for a total of 539,000 job seekers, a rise of 19.9 percent year to year.

Of all the nearly 540,000 job seekers, senior high school graduates accounted for the largest portion of 228,000, while around 367,000 jobs out of the nearly 900,000 offered were provided for job seekers with a high school education, DGBAS statistics show.
At the same time, a total of 234,000 certificates were issued by the government to skilled workers in 2004, a passing rate of 57.1 percent, reflecting an annual rise of 2.2 percentage points.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Moscow Times: Ukraine's President Takes the Stage.
The comparisons are inevitable. A year ago, it was the newly elected Mikheil Saakashvili who came to Davos to announce ambitious plans for transforming his country. Bursting with boyish energy, he seemed almost giddy from suddenly finding himself among world leaders curious to meet the young Georgian president.

DOC.HEADLINE: ARATS HEAD SENDS CONDOLENCES TO SEF CHIEF'S FAMILY

TEXT.P: Mainland China's top negotiator with Taiwan has asked his personal deputies to convey a letter of condolence to the widow of the late Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) Chairman Koo Chen-fu, reports from Shanghai said Monday.

According to mainland media reports, Wang Daohan, president of the Beijing-based Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS) , handed the letter to his two deputies -- ARATS Vice President Sun Yafu, who is concurrently deputy director of the Taiwan Affairs Office of the mainland's State Council, and ARATS Secretary-General Li Yafei -- during a meeting in Shanghai earlier in the day.
Wang, who is in his 80s, personally signed the condolence letter to Cecilia Koo during a brief meeting with his two deputies, the reports said.
Wang was quoted as having said he felt nostalgic about his old friend Koo, very much wanted to pay his last respects at Koo's memorial, but was prevented from doing so by ill-health.
Sun and Li will attend Koo's funeral, which is scheduled for Wednesday.
SEF officials said Ma Xiaoguang, ARATS' research department chief, will also pay tribute to Koo in Taipei.

Meanwhile, Vice Chairman Chiu Tai-san of the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council, which oversees SEF operations and charts Taiwan's policy toward the mainland, said the three mainland visitors' Taipei itinerary will be arranged by the ad hoc commission handling Koo's funeral, with the SEF offering all necessary assistance.

Koo, a respected business tycoon known for his diplomatic acumen, held a groundbreaking meeting with Wang in Singapore in 1993 in the first formal cross-strait contact in more than four decades. He died Jan. 3 at the age of 88.

The historic Koo-Wang meeting laid the framework for the quasi-official SEF and ARATS to handle cross-strait exchanges in the absence of official ties. In 1998, the two envoys met again when Koo traveled to Shanghai and Beijing to boost further rapprochement. However, Beijing unilaterally suspended regular SEF-ARATS dialogue in July 1999, when then-ROC President Lee Teng-hui defined cross-strait ties as state-to-state in nature.

On Sunday, Chen Yunlin, director of the Taiwan Affairs Office (TAO) of the State Council, said in Beijing that the three ARATS officials' Taipei trip is not only aimed at expressing the mainland's esteem for Koo's contributions to the promotion of cross-strait relations but also at symbolizing the mainland's respect for the people of Taiwan.
"We hope the trio will convey our remembrance and condolences during their trip to Taipei," Chen said.

Local media reports said three former SEF secretaries-general -- Chen Chang-wen, Chiu chin-yi and Chiao Jen-ho -- plan to jointly host a dinner in honor of the three ARATS officials Tuesday, but they are not sure whether the mainland visitors would accept their invitation.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW LEGISLATURE TO MEET AMID CLOSE RACE FOR SPEAKER POST

TEXT.P: The 225 newly elected lawmakers of the Legislative Yuan will meet Tuesday and elect the president and vice president of the legislature in a fierce race between candidates of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) and the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) and People First Party (PFP).
According to the Secretariat of the Legislative Yuan, the lawmakers should report at between 8:30 a.m. and 9:30 a.m.
They must produce a photocopy of their certificates of election as lawmakers in return for their legislature certificates before being sworn in en masse.
After posing for a group photo, they will vote for the president at 10:30 a.m.
Wang Jin-pyng, who has held the post since 1999, is running for re-election with the support of the KMT and PFP, which command 114 seats between them.
Wang's rival in the race is DPP lawmaker Ker Chien-ming, who has the support of the 89 DPP lawmakers in addition to the 12 lawmakers of the DPP's political ally, the Taiwan Solidarity Union.
In order to win, Ker and his party are doing their best to win over the eight lawmakers from the Non Partisan Solidarity Union and two independents.
If no one wins a simple majority in the first round of voting, a second round should be held immediately, according to the Secretariat.

Another vote will be held in the afternoon for the vice president position. PFP lawmaker David J. C. Chung is running on the KMT-PFP ticket, while the DPP has not yet fielded a candidate. In order to ensure that their lawmakers show up and vote, the KMT, PFP and DPP have threatened to punish lawmakers who fail to toe the party line in the voting.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT TO RECEIVE WINNERS OF NATIONAL AGRICULTURE AWARDS: COA

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian is slated to receive two winners of the first national agriculture awards Friday at the Presidential Office in recognition of their outstanding performances, the Council of Agriculture (COA) announced Monday.

The Cabinet-level COA, which is in charge of awarding the country's top national honor for remarkable individuals or groups in promoting agriculture, said that the two winners, Hsieh Ching-shun and Hsu Chin-si, will each receive NT$1 million (US$31,450) from the government.

According to COA Vice Chairman Lee Chien-chuan, Hsieh, a professor from the National Pingtung University of Science and Technology, won the "agriculture peace prize" for his long-term efforts to help strengthen Taiwan's relations with friendly countries such as Burkina Faso, Gambia, Senegal, Swaziland and Malawi with his rich experience in rice cultivation.

Hsieh's expertise not only helped Taiwan agricultural missions in Africa and Latin America further upgrade their technological levels but also helped local people in those regions to increase their rice production, Lee said, adding that this "rice diplomacy" has made great contributions to bolstering bilateral ties.

For his part, Hsu, chairman of the Chianan Farm and Irrigation Association since 1993, who was granted the "agriculture excellent service prize, " is an exceptional specialist from the grassroots, Lee said.

Hsu has worked at the association for more than 40 years, devoting most of his life to the improvement of infrastructure and living standards in rural areas of southern Chiayi and Tainan counties, Lee said. He added that his winning the prize also underscores the association's achievements in public service.
According to COA officials, the national agriculture awards are designed to reward each winner in five categories.

A total of 51 competitors took part in the selection, but only 10 were screened out of 47 qualified contestants. Hsieh and Hsu got the two prizes, with three others in the fields of food security, innovation and eco-friendly conservation not awarded.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW CONSTITUTION KEY TO MAKING TAIWAN NORMAL COUNTRY: EX-PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: The writing of a new constitution and "rectifying" the official designation of the country is key to making Taiwan a normal country, former President Lee Teng-hui said Monday.

Speaking at a meeting of co-conveners of the pro-Taiwan independence group "Hand-in-Hand to Protect Taiwan Alliance, " Lee said that engineering a new constitution and changing the country's name can be done by the people.
The government will follow the people's opinion when 75 percent of the population reach a consensus on the matters, while foreigners will have no way to intervene, Lee claimed.

Many domestic groups who advocate a Taiwan-centric identity have a common goal of writing a new constitution for the country and changing the country's official designation, Lee noted, adding that the alliance will integrate these resources to continue to fight for Taiwan's future.

He said his victory in Taiwan's first direct presidential election in 1996 in the face of Beijing's missile intimidation, and President Chen Shui-bian's triumph in the following two presidential elections in 2000 and 2004, prove that the people of Taiwan can choose their own lifestyle.
The most important thing for the people of Taiwan this year is to unite themselves to oppose mainland China's proposed anti-secession law, the former president said.

DOC.HEADLINE: CONSTITUTIONAL REFORM IS CONSISTENT WITH U.S. ADVOCACY: PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian said here Monday that his country's efforts to amend its Constitution are consistent with U.S. President George W. Bush's advocacy of the expansion of freedom and democracy.

Chen, who made a transit stop in Guam on his way back to Taiwan after a tour of Palau and the Solomon Islands, told a dinner party given in his honor by a group of Taiwanese expatriates that Taiwan's constitutional reforms will not touch on the controversial issues regarding ROC territory, statehood and whether it will seek permanent separation from mainland China or not.
He said democracy is a universal value that is the basis of the friendship and cooperation between Taiwan and the United States.

Noting that Bush vowed in his second inauguration address to expand freedom and democracy around the world, Chen said his country's efforts to reform the Constitution are virtually an echo of Bush's call.
Although the democracy campaign faces challenges around the world, Chen said, democracy and freedom will prevail eventually.

Touting his country as a vital link in the U.S. defense line in the Western Pacific, which also includes Guam, Chen promised to lead his country to devote itself to maintaining peace, stability and prosperity in the region.
Chen was expected to leave Guam for Taipei later in the day.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT RETURNS FROM SOUTH PACIFIC

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian returned home late Monday after concluding a five-day state visit to Palau and the Solomon Islands.

Chen was warmly greeted at the airport upon arrival by first lady Wu Shu-jen, Vice President Annette Lu, Presidential Office Secretary-General Su Tseng-chang, Premier-designate Frank Hsieh and other government officials.
He did not make a statement at the airport but held brief individual talks with the government officials who were present to greet him, particularly Su and Hsieh.
Chen departed Jan. 27 for a five-day state visit to Palau and the Solomon Islands, two Republic of China allies in the South Pacific.

During the visit, he attended Palau President Tommy Remengesau's inauguration for a second term Jan. 28 before heading to the Solomon Islands Jan. 29. He also made a stopover in Guam Jan. 31 on his way back to Taiwan.
